title: Little Room for Any Real Compromise on SALT
description: WASHINGTON  After the rulers of Spain, in 1804, expressed bewildered indignation that the United States Senate was unwilling to endorse a treaty concluded by its own government, Secretary of State James Madison replied: When peculiarities of this sort in the structure of a government are sufficiently known to other governments, they have no right to take exception at the inevitable effect of them. Maybe so. However, 175 years later, the Soviet Union's Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, last week was muttering, a fantastic situation. And the present Secretary of State is not likely to make so spirited a defense of the Senate's prerogatives.

title: Vacationing Without a Car At a Complete Resort Hotel
description: We might never have gone to the Homestead if there had not been a gasoline shortage. Our usual family vacation is spent in a rented house in the Long Island village East Hampton and in a rented car. I say in a car as well as in a house because we spend a lot of our vacation time in the car. We use it several times a day to go to the beach, to tennis courts, to movies, to the library, to restaurants; to shop for food and other necessaries, to visit friends. The whole vacation depends on that automobile, and with the supply of gas highly uncertain, so, too, were the prospects for a happy holiday.

title: THE YEAR OF THE NUTRITIONIST

This eccentric behavior may seem outlandish, even rude, but aficionados of special diets are not rarities today. More and more people are consulting with nutritionists on a regular basis. Some view it as a means of keeping fit, others as a way of coping with individual physical problems. Interest is particularly keen among those whose careers demand high energy and an ability to cope with constant stress and tension.

title: The Once and Always Champ
description: IN a few hours Muhammad All would strut into a boxing ring for the first time as an officially retired world heavyweight champion. And now, in his suite high in the Meadowlands Hilton last Friday, the blinds were drawn as he stretched out on his bed. Outside perhaps a dozen friends, admirers and leeches were waiting for an audience. But the once and always champ was tired. He had been on the go for more than seven hours in Jersey City, riding in a chauffeured limousine to the howl of police sirens as he hurried to appear at a breakfast, at two playgrounds, at a shopping mall, at a cocktail party, at a picnic in a park, at the medical center. Thousands had squealed, laughed, chanted AhIee, Ahlee and scrambled to touch him.

title: Job Action Jams French Border
description: REKKEM, Belgium, June 30 (Reuters) French customs officers seeking higher wages searched every car at the Belgian border here today, causing a long traffic backup. Most of those delayed were Dutch tourists heading south.

title: Why the Heat Is On the Dollar
description: The armistice is over for the dollar. After seven months of strength and stability, the world's most widely held currency has come under fire again, falling 3.8 percent against the West German mark since the dollar peaked in early June, 4.1 percent against the Swiss franc and 2.3 percent against the yen. Worse, all of the signs of a renewed crisis for the dollar have reappelared, just as the ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries hitched the price of oil up another notch last week and as the leaders of the industrialized nations convened in Tokyo to try to rescue a flagging world economy.

title: Pop: America in the Park

That's been continual complaint about the group, especially its Neil Youngishhit in 1972, A Horse With No Name. But famili- anty in tniS case doesn't mean the accusation is any less applicable.

title: Choosing Judges
description: The President should intervene swiftly and personally to appoint more women, members of minorities and public interest lawyers to the Federal bench. On Oct. 20, 1978, the President signed a law creating 152 new Federal judgeships, an increase of almost onethird in the Federal judiciary. In sign- mg the act, the President noted the almost complete absence of women and members of minority groups among Federal judges and pledged more than token representation on the Federal bench. Now, nine months later, the President has nominated 54 men and 15 women, including three black men, three black women, and three Hispanic men. This record is a vast improvement over that of previous presidents and, in general, the quality of appointments has been high. Yet, when the process is completed, the result will be token representation, not a truly integrated Federal bench, if the President does not take control of the nomination process.

title: Stephen Spender Views Chicago
description: Chicago tries tremendously hard, against tremendous odds. The second largest city in the United States, it would, one feels, be the capital if there were any justice in this world. Why should the capital be on the Eastern seaboard? Why not In the center of the continental land mass? True, Chicago is only a third of the way across the continent, but before the opening up of the West this seemed the center. Moreover, it is at the base of that congress of lakes  Superior, Huron and Michigan - which, on the map, makes it look like the sensitive area of some vital organ - lungs or heart or liver drawing in and giving out blood  a meeting of waterways, airways and railways the pulse of the continent. In the days when one could cross the country from East to West by rail, one had to change trains at Chicago, as though obliged to pay homage to this proud queen of cities.

title: Exploring the Danube Delta
description: In the soft haze amid the towering pale green reeds, Vania Ivanoff, the guide, cuts the powerful Zim engine of his motorboat and suddenly the traveler is overwhelmed by strange sounds  cawing, peeping, tweeting, purring, cooing  the endless symphony of birdsong in the vast delta of the Danube.

title: Executors for Presley Estate
description: MEMPHIS, June 30 (AP)  The late Elvis Presley's former wife will share control of his estate with an accountant and a bank, according to the terms of the will left by his father, Vernon. In a will med yesterday in Probate court, Vernon Presley named Priscilla Presley; Joseph Hanks, an accountant of Memphis, and the National Bank of Commerce as executors of his son's estate, valued in March at $7.6 million. Vernon Presley, empowered to select his successor as executor of the estate of the late singer, died Tuesday at the age of 63.

Sir Roland Hanna and the New York Jazz Ensemble get things started at 2 P.M., followed by Joe Coleman's Jazz Supreme at 4:30 P.M., the David Chesky Orchestra and New Faces in Jazz at 7 P.M., and Buddy Rich and His Orchestra at 8:30 P.M. Everything is free, with parking at the Bellmore and Merrick L.I.R.R. stations, from which shuttle buses will take spectators (and their lawn chairs and blankets) to the park.

Despite this, each year there are daunting lines of bedraggled visitors storming the Louvre, the Centre Georges Pompidou, the Jeu de Paume and the Grand Palais. To be sure, these culture palaces are unique and must be visited, but there are other delights to be considered.

title: Taking On Three By Shakespeare
description: STRATFOFtD, CONN. Kenneth Haigh is a bit testy. He has spent a long, humid afternoon in an airless high school gymnasium rehearsing Brutus's funeral oration, in preparation for the official opening here on Thursday of the American Shakespeare Theater production of Julius Caesar. Mr. Haigh is irritated by the obligatory dinner break at the uncivilized hour of 5 P.M. He is also growing apprehensive at the exhausting prospect of playing Brutus, Malvolio in Twelfth Night and Prospero in The Tempest in the course of the American Shakespeare Theater's revived summer repertory season. (After 22 consecutive summer seasons, the problemridden theater in Stratford, Conn., was closed for reorganization in 1977 and reopened last summer with only one production, Twelfth Night, for a fiveweek run.)

title: UNMASKING ION OF SAM'S
description: For more than a year he had terrorized New York City, but when David R. Berkowitz was finally arrested and charged with killing six persons and wounding seven others, the selfstyled Son of Sam insisted he'd had no choice. Demons, speaking with the voices of barking dogs, had ordered him out on his latenight hunts for victims. Two courtappointed psychiatrists after long interviews with Berkowitz concluded that he believed in his demons, that he was psychotic and therefore not mentally fit to stand trial for murder. A third psychiatrist, however, reached an opposite conclusion, and so did the criminal justice system, which just a year ago accepted his plea of guilty and convicted him of murder, imposing a string of 25-year-to-life prison sentences. And last February, Berkowitz himself called a press conference in Attica prison to announce that he had invented the story of his demons.

title: When Jimmy Comes Marching Home
description: President Carter is right to get on home from Asia without a Hawaiian holiday. He's been out of synch with events here, pretending in Vienna that Russian missiles are the nation's greatest worry and, in Tokyo, that lukewarm pledges of allied cooperation will meet the problems of oil and stagflation. How wrong of his political managers, who meanwhile chose New York again for his nomination, to think they have a year's time to write his 1980 theme song, When Jimmy Comes Marching Home Again.

title: Other World Events
description: I thought I should go out with a bang, but this is too much, joked Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. after terrorists came within a split second of blowing him up as he was driven to work near Mons, Belgium last week. Unhurt, he flew back to the United States, ending five years as commander of North Atlantic forces. He will take to the lecture circuit and is mentioned as a possible darkhorse Presidential candidate as well as an influential voice in the debate on the nuclear weapons limitations treaty. There was no hint as to the motives and makeup of the group that tried to kill him.

title: A Sampling of Some of America's
description: Whatever happened to the Grand Old Resorts, those plush, selfcontained hotels on acres of well manicured grounds where guests stroll at leisure, play tennis and golf, dine in elegant surroundings, dance to live music and above all relax in style? Some of them have disappeared, but a number are still going strong, their usefulness becoming increasingly important as gasoline becomes scarcer. The resorts may be reached by plane, train, bus or boat (and possibly a taxi or limousine ride from the terminal), and once the traveler arrives at the hotel, further transportation is not needed. What follows is a sampler of some of the better known Grand Old Resorts, listed alphabetically, with details on facilities, activities, rates and travel directions.

title: Other Ideas &
description: A widespread form of venereal disease previously resistant to treatment may soon become curable. Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania have announced that genital herpes simplex infection, which affects 13 percent of venereal disease victims, has responded to a drug called 2-deoxy-D-glucose. The disease causes serious pain for its victims and can infect babies during childbirth. Women with some forms of the infection run a greater risk of developing cancer. The new drug has not been licensed by the Food and Drug Administration.

He was last seen alive in Berlin on May 2, 1945, seekiN to escape from the doomed capital. At Nuremberg, he was declared missing and condemned to death in his absence.

title: Headliners
description: How many strikes make an out in boxing? Last week, in a thoroughly precedented move, Muhammad Ali retired (for the third recorded time) from the sport whose chief and most gorgeous ornament he has been since 1964 or so. This time, in contrast to his previous retirements, he said he had sent the necessary letter to the World Boxing Association relinquishing his share in the world heavyweight title. The only thing I can do to increase my popularity, Mr. Ali said (speaking by phone from his home in Los Angeles to reporters in a Newark restaurant), is to lose and win back the title for the fourth time. But I'm too old for that. Just to keep his hand in, Mr. Ali flew to the East Coast and Friday night fought two tworound exhibitions in Jersey City against Gov. Brendan J. Byrne of New Jersey and Mayor Thomas Smith of Jersey City.

title: TV VIEW
description: Expertise is at a premium in television. Most reporters and producers are generalists, flung from one unrelated story to another as research staffs frantically compile essential background information. The medium affords little time for developing more than cursory knowleage waiter Cronkite may become exceptionally wellinformed about space programs, or John Chancellor might prove remarkably articulate about SALT agreements, but these are exceptions, requiring extraordinary time and effort. When such exceptions come along, the result is nearly always dramatically apparent. Not surprisingly, the best examples are likely to be provided by people outside the hurlyburly of daily production, those independents who can set about exploring complicated subjects at relatively leisurely pate. With such independents, the boundaries of expertise are limited only by sensitivity and intelligence. It is nonsense to contend that only an Irishman can be an expert on the subject of Ireland, or that only black can expound on the complexities of Africa.

title: Sporting Gear,
description: The jogger who is always trying to find a place to put his keys, money and identification papers has often found that pockets on his running shorts are not a good solution, since they tend to chafe the skin and don't hold much anyway. So what's the answer? Perhaps the Wrist Jock, a zippered adjustable band that fits around the wrist and serves the function of a wallet  particularly useful to very serious runners, since it's a convenient place to slip notes on racing splits. There's also a nonzippered model with loops that serves as a watchband. Wrist Jocks are available only by mail: Box 32, Merrick, L.I. 11566. The wristwallet model is priced at $4.95, the watchband model at $3.95, and the combined set at $7.95.

Near Hong Kong a rusty freighter lying in still water, with Vietnamese, many painfully thin, seated on the deck, waiting forlornly.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter said a recession was much more likely now because of the price increases announced last week by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. More sharply critical of the Arab oil nations than he had previously been in public, Mr. Carter said that the price rises of 60 percent since December were unnecessarily high and unwarranted. He predicted the possible loss of 800,000 jobs and a 21/2 percent rise In the inflation rate by the end of next year. [Page 1, Column 6.]

description: William B. Franke, Secretary of the Navy in the Eisenhower Administration, died Saturday at the Rutland Hospital in Rutland, Vt. He was 85 years old.

title: Two Hands for Donald Kennedy
description: The Food and Drug Administration lost its best commissioner in a long time Friday when Donald Kennedy moved to Stanford University. When he came to Washington two years ago, the agency was torn by internal dissension and charges in Congress that it had become chummy with the industries it regulates. Morale has been raised and the F.D.A.'s reputation decidedly one of independence. One measure of the respect that Mr. Kennedy won is that spokesmen for both consumer and industry groups, who seldom agree on anything, rate him equally high.

description: TORONTO, June 29  For many years Warren Hughes labored as a food chemist, a soap salesman and an advertising account representative pushing products such as Pepsodent, Pablum and Rothman's cigarettes. They were straightforward jobs, respectable, demanding and ever so normal.

title: New Hiring Expected to Fall
description: WASHINGTON, July 1(AP) A new survey by one of the nation's largest employment agencies forecasts sharp slowdown in new hiring this summer, another sign that the nation may be heading into a recession.of the employers polled expected to increase employment during the third quarter, down from 34 percent a year ago. Seven percent plan to cut employment, compared with 6 percent a year ago, and 61 percent expect no job changes, compared with 57 percent year ago.

title: Paul Newman, Race Driver

Outside the door, immune to the roaring engines, Vivian Crowe, the wife of the driver's crew chief, sat in folding chair, one eye on her needlework and the other on the flapping clothes.

description: HOUSTON, July 1 (AP)  Allan Jamail, the former police chief of Jacinto City who is now a city councilman there, has been found not guilty, with two former subordinates, on charges that they violated the civil rights of two Indiana men by torturing them during questioning.

title: MOSCOW IS RAISING PRICES OF LUXURIES
description: MOSCOW, July 1 - The Soviet Government has ordered sharp price increases for a variety of goods ranging from carpets to cars that are regarded here as luxuries. The apparent purpose is to soak up the savings of Soviet consumers.

title: Talking Business: With Nash of Warburg
description: The dollar has had rough going in foreign money markets recently as gold has showed considerable strength. Currency traders are said to be concerned about the inability of Americans to cut back on their use of fuel and to stem inflation. There also were reports that foreign countries are eager to see the dollar weaken to reduce their own cost of oil, which is priced in dollars.

title: Waiting for Skylab
description: As in the last reel of a lowgrade science fiction thriller, the schemes to head off Skylab's crashing have now been exhausted. Blowing it up would only produce more debris.. Nuclear assaults to burn the debris are prohibited in space. Vaporizing it with lasers or particlebeam weapons is said to lie beyond the state of those arts. Asking the Russians to capture the runaway was ruled out as embarrassing, and also impractical. Even mass meditation by psychics failed budge the flag from its descending course. All that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration still hopes to do is nudge the satellite in its final path toward a landing in the ocean or some other wilderness.

title: 200 Years of the Industrial Age
description: IRONBRIDGE, England- It is hard to imagine, as one looks today at the leafy hillsides and the old Iron Bridge reflected in the Severn, that this town was once regarded as hell on earth, or that a visitor could have said that it would make even the most profligate unbeliever tremble with fright.

title: Korean Talks: A Risky Offer
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 1 - With proposals for threeway talks to resolve the military standoff on the Korean Peninsula, the Carter Administration is taking a plunge into some of the most troubled and uncertain waters of intemational diplomacy.

title: Samuel M. Elowsky, 86, Founder And Chairman of Apparel Maker
description: Samuel M. Elowsky, founder and chairman of Apparel Industries Inc., died Saturday at Lido Beach, L.I. Mr. Elowsky, who also had a residence in Manhattan, was 86 years old.

title: Tarshis Franchise Role Challenged
description: For 16 years Morris Tarshis  whose name unfamiliar to most New Yorkers  has been the undisputed ruler of New York City's obscure but powerful Bureau of Franchises.

title: Ruth Esther Zackson Wed to Crane Taylor
description: Ruth Esther Zackson and Crane Mygatt Taylor, May graduates of the University of Hartford, were married yesterday at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club. State Supreme Court Justice Joseph S. Calabretta performed the ceremony.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: WASHINGTON  Four and eight years ago, when there was talk about Edward Kennedy as the Democratic candidate for President, I never believed that he gave serious consideration to the idea. This time he is thinking seriously about it.

title: USS Chemical Purchase
description: PITTSBURGH, July 1 (UPI) - USS Chemicals, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, said last week that it had bought for an undisclosed price all the outstanding common stock of the Novamont Corporation, a manufacturer of propylene resin and acrylic sheet, that was a member of the Montedison Group based in Milan, Italy.

title: Siebert Faults Marine Merger
description: NEW YORK, July 1 (UPI)  State Banking Superintendent Muriel Siebert said that the proposed acquisition of Marine Midland Banks Inc. by the Hongkong & Shanghai Banking Corporation would hurt the public and could milt in a wave of bank takeovers in mmtatp New York.

title: Deaths
description: LANG WORTHYH. Dayton. On June 30, 1979, beloved husband of Alice. Reposing at Franklin Funeral Home, 42 New Hyde Park Road, Franklin Square, L.I. Religious service Tuesday 10 A.M. Funeral to fol. Way. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. Visiting hours 2.5 and 710.

title: De Gustibus Custard or Oyster Stew Need Not Ever Curdle
description: In reply to an inquiry about the curdling of custards when baked, it was stated that the cause might be that the custard was being cooked at too high a heat and too quickly. A water bath to set the custards in as they heat was also recommended to make the custards cook more evenly.

title: Dressing Smart For the Heat
description: For many women, the plan being considered by President Carter to require most offices and other commercial buildings to lower their thermostats 78 degrees to conserve energy would not only affect the way they live, but the way they dress for work.

title: Stein Plans to Challenge Mayor's Club in Primary
description: Having played a major role in the defeat of Stanley Steingut, former Speaker of the State Assembly, in last year's Democratic primary, Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan plans to take on the Village Independent

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Woollier at I P.M Nntional Oceanic and Atmospheric Administratn/UPI

title: The Day They Beat the House
description: RIGHT after the race, John Veitch put through a call from Belmont Park to Saratoga Springs, N.Y. The phone was answered by Charles, the butler at the summer home of Mm. and Mrs. Gene Markey. Horse racing's bestknown octogenarians couldn't talk just then, it seemed, because they were out on their sun porch their wheelchairs.

title: Tautog Chowder
description: The tautog is a magnificent chowder fish.

title: It's Too Soon to Drill for Oil in Antarctica
description: LONDON - When the Tenth Antarctic Treaty Consultative meeting opens in Washington this September, the environmental reputation of the United States will be at stake. This treaty, under which Antarctica has been jointly and peacefully governed by dozen countries for the last 20 years, reflects American inspiration and influence.

title: The Region
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  Elementary school officials here have been ordered to take steps to insure that pupils confidential records are destroyed, rather than merely thrown into the trash after they are no longer needed.

title: Regency  Theater Books 4th M-G-M Retrospective
description: Continuing its series of retrospectives honoring Hollywood studios, the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street, will present a series of 51 MetroGoldwynMayer films starting Sunday.

title: Interest Renewed in Rationing Bill As Outlook for Gas Remains Tight
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  President Carter's pledge to hold oil imports level for the next five years, and the prospect of continuing tight supplies, has revived interest here, particularly in the House of Representatives, in some sort of gasoline rationing.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Bernard J. Taylor 2d, a veteran of Philadelphia's troubled Fidelity Bank, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Wilmington Trust Company, the largest bank in Delaware, with assets of about $1.5 billion and deposits of about $930 million. The appointment is effective July 16.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSTheresa M. Of Port Wash. ington, N.Y., on July 1, 1979. Devot ed wife of the late Samuel K., dear mother of Jane, Barbara Dolan, and Susanne. Loving grandmother of Lynn Davis, Gregory and Maryiane Dolan. and a greatgranddaughter, Victoria Elizabeth Davis. Friends may call at the Fliedner Funeral Home Inc., 190 Middle Neck Road, Great Neck, L.I. Monday 3.5 and 79 P.M. Mass Saint Peter's of Alcantara R.C. Church, Port Washington, N.Y., Tuesday July 3, at 9:30 A.M.

title: Katherine Solow Is Bride of Peter K. Storey
description: Katherine Solow, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Robert M. Solow of Boston and Chilmark, Mass., was married yesterday to Peter Kennedy Storey, son of Mrs. Richard C. Storey Jr. of Villanova, Pa., and the late Mr. Storey. The Rev. Joseph Williamson performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Increase in Income Aid Approved
description: ALBANY, July 1 - Governor Carey announced today that he had signed a bill that will grant increases to beneficiaries of the Supplemental Security Income program, which assists the elderly, the blind and the disabled.

title: Suffragette Enshrined on the Face of a Dollar  coin
description: Susan B. Anthony, the suffragette, joins the company of American Presidents today. A new dollar coin bearing her portrait goes into circulation, prompting feminist celebrations.

title: Cheers and Jeers Mark Games Start
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 1- Joyous singing and clapping mingled with nationalist cheers and jeers at the opening ceremonies of the eighth Pan American Games today. Riot police wearing black berets and carrying guns and batons lined the perimeters of the fields at Hiram Bithorn Stadium as a precaution against demonstrations by factions favoring independence or statehood for Puerto Rico. No serious protests occurred during the fourhour ceremony that officially began the 15 days of sports competition among 4,400 athletes from 33 nations.

title: Resident of. Fifth Avenue Reports Theft of Jewelry Worth $200,000
description: More than $200,000 in jewelry was reported stolen from an apartment at 910 Fifth Avenue during the weekend, the police said.

title: 3 ECONOMIC EXPERTS GET KEY PEKING JOBS
description: PEKING, July 1  To help put modernization plans into effect, the National People's Congress, China's nominal legislature, appointed three senior economic specialists as Deputy Prime Ministers today, and one of them, Chen Yun, was also made head of a newly created State Finance and Economic Commission. Major changes were also made in the country's legal code and its government structure.

title: The City
description: EightySixth Street between Lexington and Park Avenues was closed to traffic last night after a piece of debris fell from the Gimbels East building onto a working bridge that had been erected over the sidewalk while the facade was being examined and reinforced, the police reported.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list Of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Muriel E. Hommel, Teacher, Bride of Dr. Irving Seidman
description: The Sutton Place Synagogue was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Muriel E. Hommel, widow of Martin Hommel and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Stoll of Lake Park, Fla., to Dr. Irving Seidman, son of Mrs. Herman Seidman of Portsmouth, Va., and the late Mr. Seidman. Rabbi David Kahane performed the ceremony.

title: Panel Studied Japanese Findings
description: In compiling its recent report, the National Academy of Sciences committee studying the effects of radiation considered many earlier findings, the most pertinent of which come from continued observation of those who survived the atomic bombs over Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

title: Israel to Continue Lebanon Raids
description: JERUSALEM, July 1 Israel's Cabinet agreed today that the armed forces should continue hitting Palestinian guerrilla targets in Lebanon despite American urgings for restraint.

title: Marriage Announcement 4 -- No Title
description: Robyn Lynne Sater and Leslie Stuart Trachtman were married yesterday at the Omni International Hotel in Atlanta by Rabbi S. Robert Ichay. Rabbi Joseph Cohen assisted..

title: Cubs Defeat Mets Twice
description: CHICAGO, July 1 - An afternoon that began on a bright note for the Mets turned bleak as the New Yorkers dropped two games today to the Chicago Cubs, 54 and 82.

title: GOING OUT guide
description: CHAMP'S RETURN Larry Adler is back on the local club scene tonight at the Cookery, and with something new added - blues and folk material. If fans of the harmonica virtuoso think they have already heard Mr. Adler perform such numbers, it is probably because he seems to have played everything else during his four decades of appearances in solo concerts, and with symphony orchestras and such personages as Duke Ellington, Fred Astaire and Ingrid Bergman.

title: Notes From the Gas Line
description: On the gasoline lines in the metropolitan area during the last few days, rumors have been abundant. As the lines continued to stretch, so did the stories being passed from car to car.

title: Analysts Expecting Little Relief In U.S. Gasoline Supply for July
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  Despite optimistic words from President Carter in Tokyo about the prospects for gasoline supply in July, oil company and independent analysts say that they expect the situation to be at best only marginally better than it was in June.

description: Amy Rozanne Becker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur. Becker of South River, N.J., was married at noon yesterday to Dr. Jeffrey Allan Mattes, son of Dr. and Mrs. Max W. Mattes of Southfield, Mich. Rabbi Joseph Maza performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Cloud Over California Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 An unusual investigation rumbles into its third week tomorrow and gives every indication of raising far more questions than it will answer.

title: Court Orders Philadelphia to Free 105 Inmates From Crowded Jails
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) Seven years after a state court agreed that local jails were so crowded that staying in them constituted cruel and unusual punishment, a threejudge panel has ordered the city to do something about it

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAN DIEGO, July 1 (AP)  Ted Giannoulas, attempting a comeback as a chickenlike character, has been given a subpoena by radio station KGB and ordered to appear in court July 31 on contempt charges.

title: Vicki Fergon Triumphs
description: DEARBORN, Mich., July 1 (UPI) Vicki Fergon, a virtual unknown on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, gained her first victory today when she made up seven shots on Judy Rankin for a onestroke triumph. She finished with a 69 for 289 in the $150,000 event at Dearborn Country Club.

description: WASHINGTON  Some straight answers to questions being asked by slowburning motorists:

description: LOS ANGELES, July 1 - A seven- hour and nineminute film about Hitler has been bought for distribution in America by Francis Coppola, director of The Godfather and Apocalypse Now.

description: PEKING, July 1  In the novel Man's Fate, Andr Malraux depicted the brave but ultimately tragic uprising organized by a small group of idealistic young Communists in Shanghai in the spring of 1927. Throueh

title: Dance: Stuttgart Shrew
description: IT is easy to understand why choreographers base ballets on famous literary works. Because such works are known quantities, choreographers may feel that they do not need to fret over the mechanics of storytelling, but can concentrate instead on devising dances and giving familiar old tales their own personal interpretations. But for these ballets to succeed, the dances must be imaginative and the new interpretations convincing.

title: Libya Hedges on Oil Plan
description: KUWAIT, July 1 (Reuters)  Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today that it was too early to say when his country might stop oil shipments or how long any stoppage might last. Libya is the'Arab world's fourthlargest oil exporter.

title: San Franciscans at Odds Over Proposal to Limit Rise of Skyscrapers
description: SAN FRANCISCO. July 1 - Battle lines have formed here over a proposal that would bring skyscraper construction to a halt and limit new building heights to 20 stories.

title: The Post in Moscow
description: The minor controversy surrounding President Carter's intention to make Thomas J. Watson Jr. his next ambassador to Moscow brings to mind the precocious comment of the son of an earlier American diplomat the Soviet capital. Asked whether he understood his father's job, the thirdgrade youngster said, Yes. He helps run the embassy. That's like the post office. They deliver messages.

title: Hollywood Moves to Tap Video Market
description: LOS ANGELES DESPITE enough uncertainties about the new technology to make some executives nervous about where it is taking them, Hollywood has begun to move in a big way to tap the market created by the emerging new video gear that frees consumers from dependence on the offerings of the television networks and their local stations.

title: Andrea Dale Kent, Lawyer, Married to Seth Martin Wax
description: Andrea Dale Kent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kent of Massapequa, L.I., was married yesterday to Seth Martin Wax, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Wax of East Meadow, L.I. Rabbi Israel Nobel performed the ceremony at the East Meadow Jewish Center.

title: GEORGE C. ABERNATHY
description: George C. Abernathy, a retired executive for Bamberger's of Newark, died Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, N.J. He was 67 years old and lived at 86 Field Road, Clifton, N.J.

title: Two Wolves Saved in City Unplaced and Facing Death
description: DELMAR, N.Y. Two young timber wolves, once kept as pets in Manhattan, stride incessantly up and down their detention pens here while the state decides whether to kill them because nobody seems to want them. They are too wild to be kept as pets and too tame to survive in the wild.

title: All Orioles Do Is Win
description: BALTIMORE BILL HAGY was sitting where he always sits when the Orioles play. He was in the first seat in the 11th row in the cheap seats upstairs in Section 34. He is strategically located close to the bathrooms. where there is the

title: Excerpts from Communique by Carter and Park
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July .1 (AP) Following are excerpts from the text of a communiqu issued today by President Carter and President Park Chung Hee of South Korea at the end of Mr. Carter's twoday visit here:

title: A Place to Promote Fair Hiring
description: The Federal judiciary, to which citizens so often turn for redress against discrimination, is not an equal opportunity employer.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Disarray in PostAmin Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda - in Africa, there is money to be made in that magic moment when power slips from the grasp of one group of people to another. The shrewd businessman, the European 'Africa hand, seizes that moment, makes the most of it and moves on.

title: Ferry Sails to Jazzland
description: THE Newport Jazz Festival's annual musical boat ride on the Hudson, on which a Staten Island ferry usually takes a load of jazz fans and two jazz bands up the river from South Ferry to the George Washington Bridge and back, changed directions this year. Because Harbor Festival 1979 was using the upper reaches of the river on Saturday, the boat ride went south to the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge.

title: Connecticut Now Allows Right Turn on Red
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 1 Connecticut today became the 49th state to allow drivers to make right turns at red lights unless a sign at the intersection prohibits such turns, virtually completing a nationwide traffic pattern that was designed for convenience and is now mandated to conserve gasoline.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter concedes that a recession is more likely following the OPEC price increases announced last week. The President, speaking as he flew to Honolulu on his way back to Washington, had harsh words for the oil cartel, whose price rises he termed unrestrained and unwarranted. He reiterated estimates that 800,000 jobs would be lost, about 2% percent would be lopped off the gross national product, and inflation would rise two points or more by the end of next year. Officials with him said they expected zero growth in the gross national product this year. [Page Al.]

title: A Perch For Satin Parrots
description: Edith La Bate left Brazil 15 years ago to study anthropology in New York, and she's never lost her childhood interest in native handcrafts.

title: The Yankees Two Managers
description: TWO hours before the Yankees game with the Red Sox yesterday, George Steinbrenner was in his Freudian seat. The principal owner and principal voice of the Yankees was in the swivel chair behind Billy Martin's desk in the manager's office. Billy Martin had not arrived yet, and George Steinbrenner was examining a sheaf of special batting statistics from the Yankees intelligence agency.

title: Green Bus Lines Halted by Strike; Queens Affected
description: A strike by 515 unionized drivers and mechanics early yesterday shut down the Green Bus Lines, the city's largest private bus company, and more than 100,000 daily riders on routes in various sections of Queens were expected to be inconvenieaced.

title: Seoul. Aims To Increase U.S. Trade
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 1  South Korea emphasized to Washington officials over the weekend that it wants to be a responsible trading partner for the United States, and is eager to maintain an importexport balance across the Pacific as it moves to take its position as a world economic power.

description: Arriving Today, July 2

title: Scott Knocks Out Johnson in Rahway Bout
description: RAHWAY, N.J., July 1  James Scott, the lightheavyweight champion of Railway State Prison, his home, ran his professional boxing record to 15 victories and one draw today by stopping Bunny Johnson in the prison ring.

title: How Oil Voices in House Moderated Tax Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  Recent rumors that the oil industry had lost serious measure of its awesome influence in Congress appear, like reports of Mark Twain's death, to be greatly exaggerated.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Expects Parliament to Abolish Rhodesian Sanctions
description: CANBERRA, Australia, July 1 Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said today that she expected British sanctions against Zimbabwe Rhodesia to end in November and hinted strongly that formal recognition of the Government of Bishop Abel Muzorewa might soon follow.

title: Lynn's Picture Swing Now Packs Power, Too
description: They will gather round the batting cage tonight when Fred Lynn takes his warmuos at Yankee Stadium.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Because of trashcollection problems in the aftermath of the tugboat strike, alternateside parking regulations will be in effect today in Manhattan and Brooklyn only.

title: Connally and Reagan Offer 2 Brands of Conservatism to Virginia G.O.P.
description: ROANOKE, Va., July 1  Virginia Republicans, with extra gasoline to speed their way, drove home from their state convention today with their ears ringing from the proven traditional conservatism of Ronald Reagan and the aggressive, tempting conservatism of John B. Connally.

description: Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CENSUS STUDY SHOWS DIVORCETREND RISE
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The results of two decades of changing social attitudes toward marriage and the wide loosening of divorce law throughout the country emerged today with the publication of a new census study showing that in recent years the divorce rate had more than doubled and the number of children involved in divorce had more than tripled.

title: Bethpage Triumphs
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., July 1 Michael Braunstein and Frank Rice scored three goals each and led the Bethpage polo team to a 75 victory over Cornucopia today at Bethpage State Park.

title: G.E. UNIONS SET VOTE ON CONTRACT OFFER
description: Union negotiators early today recommended acceptance of a General Electric contract proposal that union and company officials hope will lead to a new contract between G.E. and 13 unions representing some 114,000 employees.

Rabbis Moses Tendler, Nachum Muschel and Hal Z. Rappaport, uncle of the bride, officiated at Temple Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Latino With Gillespie
description: JAZZ and Latin music have had a long and complicated relationship. Latin music used to mean mostly Cuban music, but more recently it's meant Puerto Rican salsa. For all the skills of its practitioners, salsa is primarily a form of pop, or popfolk, music, based heavily on traditions and formulas so rigid as to preplude the sort of free creativity associated with jazz at its purest.

title: Sidney Glazier Allowed To Make Movie in China
description: Sidney Glazier, the Academy Awardwinning producer of The Eleanor Roosevelt Story, has been granted permission by Huang Zhen, China's Minister of Culture. to make the first internationally produced feature film in China with an international cast of actors and technicians. Filming on the movie, The Marvelous Mongolian, will begin next December and will be completed the following spring. Han Suyin, author of Love Is a Many Splendored Thing, has done the screenplay from a novel of the same name by James Aldridge.

title: U.S. Sweeps 5 Pan Am Swim Gold Medals

title: LUTHER TUCKER
description: SALINA, Kan., July 2 (AP)  Luther Tucker, former Olympic medalist, died yesterday at a Salina hospital. He was 78 years old. Mr. Tucker won a silver medal in the 1920 Games at Antwerp, Belgium, as a member of the tug-of-war team. That competition Is no longer part of the Olympics. Mr. Tucker owned a bowling alley here.

description: WASHINGTON, July 2  Today's Supreme Court decision broadening judges power to close criminal courtrooms to the press and public aroused strong criticism today from both the press and the legal profession.

description: Final action was completed yesterday on a tradein of Federal highway funds that will give New York City $200 million to improve subways and renovate bridges and perimeter roads.

description: MEXICO CITY - Mexico is that place, south of the border, that Americans know capriciously or not at all: a place to acquire a tan, a big hat and a papiermfich dying Christ, a place to get married, divorced, aborted, doped, a place to reap the highest possible return on the cheapest possible labor.

title: S.E.C. Charges American Financial
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the American Financial Corporation, its president and two former company executives with having used company funds to benefit themselves and others in violation of the nation's securities laws.

title: Science Watch
description: Skylab's time is fast running out, and with each passing day the predicted reentry time gets refined to a window of fewer and fewer days. On Sunday, it was predicted that Skylab would come down during one of six days in July. Reentry has now been narrowed to four days.

title: An OilTanker Drama on the Delaware
description: WESIVILLE, NJ., July 2 - The Italian captain and crew of the 100,000ton Texaco Hannover delivered 750,000 barrels of crude oil to Texaco's Eagle Point refinery here today, only to learn that they will have to wait at the dock for three days to finish unloading the cargo because the refinery's storage tanks for crude oil are full.

title: Somoza's Troops Mount Attack On RebelHeld Nicaraguan City
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 2 (AP) President Anastasio Somoza Debayle's National Guard launched a major attack on the guerrillaheld city of Masaya, Guard spokesman announced today. The sound of bombing runs by National Guard aircraft could be heard in Managua, 20 miles to the north.

title: GUIDELINES PENALTY SURVIVES CHALLENGE
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 The Supreme Court removed a major threat to President Carter's antiinflation program today by declining to accept a case testing the program's constitutionality.

title: Israeli Predicts Syrians Will Not Start New War
description: TEL AVIV, July 2 - Maj. Gen. Yehoshua Saguy, director of military intelligence, said today that Syria might try to heat up conflict with Israel in a controlled way to divert attention from domestic problems. But he predicted it would avoid any action leadin2 to war.

title: About New York
description: The most outrageously elemental help was being sought last week in Queens by a woman freshly widowed in blood. It was not simply a new lock to guard against the murderer's return, but some carpeting to replace the grisly rug cutout made by the police as evidence where her husband's body bad curled and bled his life out.

title: A Tag for Terrorist Bombs
description: One would think everybody in a modern society would be relieved to learn that there exists a way to mark explosives so that the police could trace their ori- gin after detonation. When investigating a terrorist at- tack or gangland bombing, detectives could learn as much about the explosive as if they had in hand a dis- tinctive laundry mark.

title: Abduction Victim Tells of 3 Years in Jungle
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, July 2 - Fresh from a barber's chair in which he lost; his shoulderlength gray locks, William F. Niehous seemed today also to have shed nearly three and a half years of fear and anguish in the hands of leftist IriAnsannore

title: Behavior Of Infants And Apes Is Linked
description: ASTANFORD UNIVERSITY anthropologist has found that baby chimpanzees, gorillas and orangutans develop behavior patterns in the first two years of their lives that are identical to the developmental patterns of human infants. But she also found one essential difference - the infant apes vocalization progress stops at an early age.

title: The City
description: The Department of Buildings yesterday reopened a stretch of 86th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues that had been closed to traffic overnight after some debris fell from the Gimbels East building.

title: Top Court Backs U.S. Busing Plan For 2 Ohio Cities
description: WASHINGTON, July 2- The Supreme Court upheld today sweeping Federal busing orders in two Ohio cities, Dayton and Columbus, thereby dispelling widespread suggestions that it was retrenching from a commitment to end racial segregation in Northern school systems.

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court's Opinions on Discretion to Close Trials to Press
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 - Following are excerpts from opinions by the preme Court today in the case of Gannett v. DePasquale. Associate Justice Potter Stewart wrote the majority opinion.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Mixed
description: Yields were mixed on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and the 182day maturities.

title: Parental Consent Law on Abortion Is Struck Down
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 - The Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional Massachusetts law that required unmarried minor girls to get the approval of their parents or a judge before being able to obtain a legal abortion.

title: CORRECTION
description: The obituary of Theodore M. Bernstein in The Times last Thursday reported incorrectly that he had devised the interabang, a combined question mark and exclamation point used for questions that are actually exclamations. The mark was invented by Martin K. Speckter, a retired advertising executive. Under the spelling interrobang, it is recognized by several dictionaries and sold by some type and typewriter manufacturers. Mr. Bernstein had unsuccessfully promoted the pronequark, a question mark lying on Its side, for similar purposes.

title: Tracy Austin Ousts Mrs. King, 6-4, 67, 62
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 Babvcake beat Aunt Billie Jean today.

title: COAST CHIEF JUSTICE REJECTS QUESTIONS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 - Chief Justice Rose Bird refused to answer some of the questions put to her today as the Commission on Judicial Performance sought to trace leaks of information from the California Supreme Court.

title: Swim Star Is Maturing At Me 16
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 2 - Tracy Caulkins spotted her parents on the deck of the El Escambron pool after completing her morning qualifying races at the Pan American Gaines tnrinv

description: All of a sudden, when I went out to do the new season's shopping, I noticed a jump in basic prices. love clothes, so I've found ways of coping. I just spent Saturday doing this. A woman at work told me about the factory outlets in New Jersey, so I spent the day going around to them.

title: Storage Tanks Are Full; Tanker Can't Unload Gas
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 - Early last month, the tanker Mobil Aero sailed from Beaumont, Tex., with a load of gasoline for storage tanks in three cities in Florida. But she was not able to unload all of her cargo because the storage tanks were full, so she returned to Texas with 132,000 gallons still in her hold.

title: Saudis Said To Plan Oil Output Rise
description: Saudi Arabia said in an official radio broadcast yesterday that it would increase production of crude oil.

title: Robert Walmsley, 94; Long an Assemblyman
description: Robert Walingley, a lawyer, banker and longtime New York State legislator, died Friday at New York Hospital after brief illness. He was 94 years old and lived in New York City.

title: Deaths
description: MET RANORebeccaThe Sephardic Temple, congregation Emeth yeShalom of Cedarhurst NY records with regret the passing of our dear member, Rebecca Metrano a most distinguished lady and tireless worker on behalf of the community and the synagogue. Condolences to the children and to the entire family.

title: COURT STAYS U.S. BID TO DROP UNIROYAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) - A Federal judge today temporarily blocked the Labor Department from canceling Uniroyal Inc.'s $36 million in Government contracts.

title: Deaths
description: ELOWSKYSamuel M. The Officers and Directors of National Bank of North America record with dew sorrow the death of our friend and former Director.He faithfully served Trade Bank and Trust Company and National Bank of North America for many years.His devotion and wise counsel were invaluable and his life of service to the community will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to his wife, Isabella and his children and grandchildren.

description: By United Press Internstirost

title: IRAN PREMIER YIELDS ON RIGHTS OF MILITIAFurther Resignations PossibleNeed for Militia Is Conceded
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 2 - Iran's religious leaders have refused a request by Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan that they dilute the authority of the revolutionary militia, and Mr. Bazargan conceded in a speech published today that the militia was here to stay.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Earthquake.Hits Northeast Italy
description: TRIESTE, Italy, July 2 (UPI) - A light earthquake measuring 3.1 on the Richter scale hit northeast Italy today, causing no reported injuries or damage. The Trieste Seismological Institute said the tremor's epicenter was at Friuli.

title: Festival Ends on Swing Street
description: THE Newport Jazz Festival ended its 26th season Sunday afternoon with a free street fair on the two blocks of West 52d Street, between Fifth and Seventh Avenues, that were once known as Swing Street. From three bandstands spread out across the two blocks, 12 jazz groups played from noon until 5 P.M., their music echoing up between the tall buildings that have replaced the brownstones whose ground floors were wall-to-wall jazz clubs in the 30's and 40's.

title: Ottawa to Push Oil Price Rises Aimed at Meeting World Level
description: OTTAWA, July 2  Because they have abundant oil from Alberta and enjoy Government subsidies, Canadians have felt oil shortages and high prices much less than people of other industrialized countries. But prices are about to be adjusted upward.

title: Notes on People
description: Observe the natives in their habitat, as they are observed by a young anthropologist from Staten Island named Robert J. Foster. They are most antisocial. They yell at strangers. They drink, often to excess. They swear. They hurl their garbage to the floor.

title: A Gym Exercisin TuneSaving Methods
description: Andrew Young, United States Representative to the United Nations; goes to the Sports Training Institute to to rehabilitate a bad hip; Billie Jean King, the tennis star, goes there to strengthen. her knees; Roberta Flack wants to firm up and look good for her next concert at the White House; JeanPierre Bonnefous of the New York City Ballet wants to strengthen his legs; Samuel Lefrak, the real estate magnate, wants to stay in shape, and ABCTV correspondent Sylvia Chase, diabetic, wants to prolong, her life, explaining that exercise reduces some degenerative aspects of the disease.

title: Mortgage Rates Off In Sale
description: Americans, affected by high interest rates and heavy debt, have become more cautious about buying homes, Government housing analyst said yesterday after assessing the weekly purchase or residential mortgages by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.

title: Steel Output Off 1% in Week
description: The Associated Press

title: Stage: Family Drama
description: 'BRASS RING by Brian .1. McFadden . is a family drama about the tensions and final reconciliation of father and a son. It is written in a warmish mode; humor and affectionate interludes alternate with quarreling.

title: Big Cars Sell in OilRich Canada
description: TORONTO, June 29 - While auto manufacturers report steep sales declines in the United States, just across the border in Canada the same companies say sales have been growing steadily, especially those of larger Cars.

title: Islip Supervisor Opposing Klein For Nominationr. Klein Responds
description: WEST ISLIP, L.I., July 2  The Islip Town Supervisor, Peter F. Cohalan, announced today he would challenge the Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein, for the Republican Party nomination. He said Mr. Klein's administration had tolerated gross mismanagement and political corruption in the construction of 1 a $1 billion sewer system.

title: I.C.C., Citing Increased Hauling, Says Trucker Strike Is Nearly Over
description: By The Associated Press

title: Francis Cornell, Educator, Dead; Helped Plan W. German System
description: Dr. Francis Griffith Cornell, an author and educator who helped the United States Government shape the postwar educational system of West Germany, died Saturday of a heart attack at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived at 34 Woodcrest Avenue, White Plains.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Supreme Court, In effect, upheld the wageprice guidelines by declining to accept a case testing the antiinflation plan's constitutionality. It voted, by 6 to 3, against hearing an appeal by the A.F.L.C.1.0, which had challenged the authority of the President to use the Government's purchasing power to enforce the guidelines. [Al.]

title: Vance Seems to Persuade Asians To Ease Their Stand on Refugees
description: KUTA, Indonesia, July 2 - Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance apparently made headway today in persuading five Southeast Asian foreign ministers to soften their newly announced policy of barring any further Indochinese refugees from landing in their countries and expelling those already there.KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, .

title: Bridge:
description: The world's most famous fictional bridge characters, headed by the Rueful Rabbit and the Hideous Hog, have made a welcome reappearance in Masters and Monsters, the conclud- ing volume in a highly entertaining trilogy by Victor Mollo, a British expert. The quality of the anecdotes about the human factors at the bridge table is, fortunately, as high as ever.

description: JERUSALEM, July 2 - Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special ambassador for the Middle East, met today with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and repeated Washington's objections to Israel's policy of establishing new settlements in the West Bank.

title: J. I. Kislak, a Realty Executive, 92
description: Julius I. Kislak, founder and board chairman of a nationwide real estate, mortgage financing and insurance organization, died Sunday in a nursing home in Livingston, N.J. He had observed his 92d birthday on June 4. .

description: FOXHenry L. Dearly beloved husband of Rea, devoted brother of Jerome, dear uncle and grand uncle. Funeral services on July 3 at 1:30PM Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: New York Economy Shows Gain
description: New York City's economy improved during the first three months of 1979, with indications that the city could withstand a recesion better than the rest of the country, Robert F. Wagner, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday.

title: North Korea Criticizes Plan for 3Way Talks
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, July 3 (AP)  A North korean commentary carried today by Pyongyang radio criticized a proposal for tripartite talks on Korean reunification by the United States and South Korea.

title: Around the Nation
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, July 2 (AP) - A judge ordered city workers tonight to end strike that has left Toledo with minimal police and fire protection or face fines against their unions of $25,000.

title: New Technology May Curtail Blackouts
description: IT is highly improbablebut not impossible - that a single lightning bolt this summer could start a cascade of mishaps and misjudgments that would black out almost the entire United States east of the Rockies. However, work now in progress could rule out such a widespread disaster.

title: White House Is Moving to Reduce Policy Role of Energy Department
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 - Top White House officials, reportedly dissatisfied with the way energy policy has been handled and concerned about potential political damage to President Carter, are moving to take control of the situation from the Department of Energy.

title: NursingHome Frauds That Exceed $94,000 Charged to 4 by State
description: Four nursinghome operators have been indicted on charges of stealing more than $65,000 in Medicaid funds, accepting $17,000 in kickbacks and cheating patients of $12,000 in prescription drugs, Deputy Attorney General Charles J. Hynes announced yesterday.

title: Carey Signs Bill Raising Tax for Fund for Jobless
description: ALBANY, July 2  Governor Carey said today he had signed a bill designed to make the state's unemployment insurance fund solvent by increasing taxes on employers by $95 million.

title: Screen: Bill Murray in Meatballs
description: 'MEATBALLS, which opens today at Loews State I and other theaters, aims at the same audiences that last summer couldn't get their fill of National Lampoon's Animal House. It is without mercy.

title: Ordinance Restricting Records in Police Files Is Approved by Seattle
description: SEATTLE, July 2 (AP) - The ninemember City Council today unanimously approved an ordinance severely restricting the information on private citizens that can 20 into Police Department files.

title: Iran Drafts Code for Reporter
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 2 - A spokesman for Iran's Government outlined plans today for a new code to be followed by foreign news organizations in reporting on the country's Islamic revolution.

title: F.T.C. Auto Inquiry Backed
description: CINCINNATI, July 2 (AP) - A Federal appeals court refused today to quash subpoenas issued by the Federal Trade Commission in its investigation of major American automobile manufacturers.

description: Lawrence H. He was 83 years old and had lived in New London since 1955.

title: Hunt for Fishing Ship Given UP
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 (UPI) The Coast Guard has given up its search for the fishing vessel Calafia, believed to have eight persons aboard. The ship radioed the night of June 22 that it was sinking, and seven minutes later a caller said, We're going over on our side.

title: Kickback Trial of Cleveland Council President Begins
description: CLEVELAND, July 2  George L. Forbes, the City Council president, and two other city officials went on trial here today on charges of accepting kickbacks in exchange for approving permits to allow carnival owners to operate in city neighborhoods.

title: Serb Pleads Not Guilty In Jet Hijacking June 20
description: CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) - Nikola Kavaja, a Serbian nationalist, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he hijacked an American Airlines jetliner last month and jumped bail in another case. He entered his pleas in Federal District Court and trial was tentatively scheduled for October.

Moreover. most experts believe that these figures underestimate the extent of illiteracy.

title: Oil Threatens Coney Island Beach
description: Maintenance crews struggled yesterday to keep Coney Island beaches open for tomorrow's Fourth of July holiday as oil from a container ship's ruptured fuel tanks began to wash up on the threemile stretch of public beach.

title: WHEW Buys a Drama
description: Borrowing a technique occasionally used by the television networks, Channel 5 will attempt to give its fall schedule a promotional sendoff with the presentation of a special serial drama during the final week of the summer season.

title: Voyager 2 Nearing Its Jupiter Rendezvous.
description: ANOTHER American spacecraft is speedingocloser and closer to the spectacular environs of Jupiter and its large and varied moons. Voyager 2, an identical twin of Voyager 1, which reconnoitered the Jovian system last March, is transmitting photographs of Jupiter every day now as it approaches its rendezvous next Sunday and Monday.

title: Supreme Court Roundup Northwest Indians Upheld By Justices in Fishing Feud
description: WASHINGTON, July 2- The Supreme Court, on the final day of its 1978 term, handed the American Indians of the Pacific Northwest an important victory today by affirming in principle a lower court decision giving them the right to catch up to half the Puget Sound salmon

title: U.N.'s Grain Estimates Cut
description: ROME, July 2 (AP)  Poor growing weather in the Soviet Union has cut into its wheat harvest, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization reported today. As a result. the group has reduced its estimate of the 1979 Soviet wheat harvest to 192 million metric tons from 210 million metric tons.

title: Taxes
description: DEATH and taxes, those two inevitabilities of life, are once again entangled in Congress. The current controversy is a sequel, second. thoughts on the 1976 Tax Reform Act. In that law, after years of debate, Congress enacted what many tax people applauded as a breakthrough in rewriting  and generally stiffeningthe tax rules on sales inherited property. Almost immediately, however, the new law touched off a flood of complaints as unfair and impossibly unworkable. So many, in fact, that last year Congress retroactively delayed the law's effective date until 1980 while it struggled again with the issue.

title: A Tight Market in Apartments Changing the Way People Live
description: The apartment market in Manhattanthe tightest in decades, according to many realestate agents - is forcing people to change not only where they look for homes but also their styles of living. It has also led to a revitalization of some neighborhoods as apartmenthunters carry their search into areas that had formerly been considered less desirable.

title: Carter's Visit Hailed in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 2 - The South Korean Government today portrayed President Carter's weekend visit as a major triumph for President Park Chung Hee while it virtually ignored

title: Issue and Debate; Should Pros Help City Fields?; The Background; The ProTax Side; The AntiTax Side; The Outlook
description: All over New York City, playgrounds and ball fields are deteriorating. Some people attribute the problem to the city's fiscal crisis, which cut the Parks Department's budget 40 percent in two years. Some people say it is due to civic leaders lack of concern for the children, many of whom have a hard time finding a supervised place to play. Almost everyone agrees something needs to be done to rehabilitate the recreational facilities. Hardly anyone agrees on how to do it.

title: Ramada Directors Approve Vegas Deal
description: PHOENIX, July 2 (UPI)- Directors of Ramada Inns Inc. have formally ap, proved the purchase of the Tropicana Hotel and Country Club In Las Vegas. The purchase price is to be determined largely by the future earnings of the hotel's gaming casino, the company said.

title: G.E. and 13 Unions Agree on a Contract for 114,000
description: Union negotiators yesterday approved a new contract that would provide General Electric workers an immediate pay increase of 50 cents an hour plus semiannual cost-of-living payments, greater pension benefits and establish- ment of a dental Dian.

title: Mexico Puts Off OilPrice Move
description: MENICO CITY, July 2 (UPI) Mexico said today that it had postponed announcement of its regularly scheduled oilprice increase while it considered the price rises adopted last week by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Building And Goods Orders Up; Nonresidential Building Up; Building And Goods Orders Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) - New construction spending in May rose 2.2 percent to an annual rate of $221.5 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Deaths
description: CARROLLRobert A. The Officers and Members of the Metropolitan Trial Lawyers Association record with deep sorrow the passing of its past president and highly esteemed member.

title: Helen Flynn, 87, Nun Hailed by Pope in 63 As Founder of College
description: Sister Helen Flynn of the Roman Catholic Congregation de Notre Dame, an educator who was honored by Pope John XXIII for her role in founding Notre Dame College of Staten Island, died Sunday in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. She was 87 years old and had lived at the convent of the Sisters of the Congregation de Notre Dame at 196 East 76th Street in Manhattan.

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD - State troopers who, as part of a job action in a contract dispute, refuse to issue speeding tickets will be subject to disciplinary action, according to Donald Long, Connecticut's Public Safety Commissioner. But he said: I don't anticipate any disciplinary action because I anticipate our men are going to do their job.

title: COMMODITIES Grain and Soybeans Up, Reversing Earlier Selloff
description: Grain and soybean futures prices rebounded yesterday, despite the reluctance of traders to carry positions over a holiday. Indeed, volume in most commodity markets was light, as many traders took the week off.

title: Collective Dose Estimated
description: Federal estimates of the radiation received by workers in these categories assume a collective dose of 50,000 manrams  as high as that for workerS employed at nuclear reactors.

title: Conservatives in Bonn Unite Behind Strauss To Challenge Schmidt
description: BONN, July 2  Franz Josef Strauss, the conservative premier of Bavaria, won endorsement late this evening by the leadership of the German opposition parties to oppose Chancellor Helinut Schmidt, a Social Democrat, in the country's elections next year.

title: Harbor Festival Dampens Backers Hopes

title: Kerr Named Chief Theater Critic
description: Walter Kerr will become chief critic of a unified daily and Sunday theater staff at The New York Times, it was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal. executive editor.

title: Yale Campaign Attains Its Goal Of $370 Million
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 2 After five difficult years of trying to raise $370 million, Yale University announced today that it had reached its 2oal.

title: Jane Rose, 66, Actress On Stage, Screen, TV
description: Jane Rose, an actress whose career over four decades ranged from Broadway to Hollywood to television, died of cancer Friday at her home in Studio City, Calif. She was 66 years old.

title: Japan Fears Impact of OPEC Rise
description: TOKYO, July 2 - The big increases in crude oil prices announced last week by OPEC mean that Japan will not reach its official growth target of 6.3 percent in the current fiscal year, according to economists here.

title: OBSERVER

title: Yankees and John Beat Red Sox, 72; Rice Thrown Out at Plate; Yanks Top Red Sox for John's 12th; When Will Gossage Return?; Yankees Box Score
description: Tommy John survived the Red Sox and his second attack by a baseball in three days last night and pitched the Yankees to a 72 victory over Boston.

title: Equity's Alien Dues Void
description: Actors Equity has been ordered to end its practice of requiring nonresident aliens performing under its jurisdiction to pay higher dues than citizens and resident aliens.

title: EARNINGS Chessie Net Fell 1.6% In Quarter
description: The Chessie System said yesterday that net income of the railroad company fell 1.6 percent in the quarter ended June 30 to $37 million, or $1.87 share, from $37.6 million, or $1.91 share, a year earlier, despite an 11 percent rise in revenues to $496.3 million from $447.6 million.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THAT 65TH FLOOR The Guy Lombardo Royal Canadians, led by the late !maestro's young nephew, Bill Lombardo, open a twoweek stint tonight at the Rainbow Room, supplying dance music for diners. Last Friday evening, the room hummed comfortably with a sizable crowd. So did the two cocktail lounges. And also the Rainbow Grill, whose Viva! Viva! revue just passed its first anniversary; the show closes. July 30.

title: Fire at Altman's Routs Hundreds And Ties Up Traffic in Rush Hour
description: A twoalarm fire destroyed a secondfloor clothing storeroom at B. Altman & Companys midtown department store yesterday afternoon, routing hundreds of shoppers and employees and snarling traffic in one of Manhattan's busiest districts at the height of the rush period.

title: Massive Telescope Expected to Provide Clues on Past
description: SCIENTISTS at the University of California are planning to build a telescope so large that it would be a kind of time machine, affording views of unprecedented clarity back into the murky period that immediately followed the birth of the uriverse.

title: Victory Margin in Bolivia Eludes All Eight Candidates
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia,July 2 - None of the eight candidates in yesterday's presidential elections appear to have received the required majority, leaving the choice of new President to the new Bolivian Cnnprms_ With more than half of the votes counted, former President Hernan Siles Zuazo, the candidate of a leftist front, had a clear lead, polling 37 percent. His closest opponent, former President Victor Paz Estenssoro, the candidate of centrist coalition, had 29 percent.

title: Midtown Bank Robbed of $1,000
description: A welldressed gunman held up what the police believe was his sixth Manhattan bank in two months yesterday when he took $1,000 from the Chemical Bank at 377 Madison Avenue, at 46th Street. The bank is only a block from a Citibank branch the same bandit has allegedly robbed twice, and the police believe he is responsible for at least three other recent bank robberies in the area.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (TelevisionCablevision, P.M. RadioWINS, 7:50 P.M.)

title: Grace Plant Spending
description: W.R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it would spend more than $12 million to expand capacity for manufacturing flexible packaging materials at six plants in Europe and Brazil. The plants are at St. Neots, England; Epernon, France; Hamburg, West Germany; Milan, Italy; Barcelona, Spain, and Sao Paulo, Brazil.

title: Dow Falls 8 Points Despite Reports on Saudi Oil
description: All key stock market averages fell below their Friday closing levels yesterday, and declines outnumbered advances by a ratio of 2% to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, despite reports that Saudi Arabia planned to increase its production of oil temporarily.

description: RIEDHarold N. Beloved husband of. Florence. Devoted father of Horace. Cherished grandfather of Joshua, Amanda and Adam. Service Tuesday, July 3, 12:15 PM, The Riverside, 7651. and Amsterdam Ave.

description: SOUL CITY, N. C., July 2 Officials of the North Carolina Black Leadership Caucus said today that saving Soul City would be the first test of a new effort to organize black political power in the crate

title: Heart Transplants Regain Interest
description: VAST improvement in the results of heart transplants has led doctors to reappraise the merits of the operation, which fell into disrepute shortly after Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard did the first such operation in South Africa in.1967.

title: P.L.O. Asks for Observer Status In World Monetary Organizations
description: W AS I IINGTON, July 3 The Palestine Liberation Organization has applied for the status of observer at the September meeting of the boards of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, officials of the groups have said.

title: Philippine Reactor Delay
description: MANILA, July 3 (Reuters) - The United States Government is withholding export permits on parts for Philippines nuclear power plant until is sure that safety standards are fully met, according to the American Ambassador, Richard Murphy.

title: That Ovation for Roy White
description: Dave Anderson

title: Stocks Up In Quiet Trading
description: Stock prices moved cautiously higher yesterday in quiet preholiday trading, as investors waited for President Carter to present what he has said will be a bold and forceful program for dealing with the nation's shortage of oil.

Services were held Tuesday, July 2 at GutIceman's Rodville Centre LI.

title: Small Coop Sells Debt Issue
description: Occan Spray Cranberries Inc., with sales of $160 million and equity of $28 million, yesterday became one of the smallest companies ever to tap the commercial paper market.

title: Union Oil Forms Unit
description: LOS ANGELES, July 3 (Reuters) The Union Oil Company of California said today that it had formed the Union Energy Mining division to handle the operation of its oilshale and uranium resources. As previously reported, Union plans to construct a $130 million oilshale project in Colorado with an initial capacity of 10,000 tons a day.

title: Truck Drops Nail Box; 50 Motorists Get Flats
description: WESTMINSTER, Colo., July 3 (UPI) - A box of nails that fell from the rear of a lumber truck in rushhour traffic yesterday left at least 50 cars with flat tires and made the breakdown lane look like a parking lot.

title: Bell Won't Disclose F.B.I. Targets
description: NEWARK, July 3 (AP) - Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, saying there was a need to protect relations with foreign governments, balked today at a request to disclose the names of people and countries whose mail was being scrutinized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Phillies Defeat Mets, 42
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 3- The Mets wanted to pitch around Bake McBride tonight, but in the seventh inning it was McBride who went around - the bases. His tworun homer broke a 11 tie and sent the Philadelphia Phillies on their way to their second straight triumph over the Mets, 42.

title: China Pact May Precede Soviet Trade Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The Carter Administration has decided to ask Congress to approve an agreement that would expand trade with China, leaving unclear whether a similar agreement with the Soviet Union would be submitted at the same time, Administration officials said today.

title: Shareholders Suing A.&
description: By The Associated Press

title: Eleanor Bartram Radley, at 78; A Backer of 12Meter Yachts
description: Eleanor Bartram Radley, the first female member of a United States America's Cup yachting syndicate, died on Monday at the age of 78 in Greenwich, Conn., two weeks alter suffering a stroke.

title: Water Skiers Display Skills At a Harbor Festival Show
description: Joe Suncar, a counselor at a Manhattan youth center, had gone his entire 24 years without seeing a live display of water skiing. Then yesterday he saw one - not in Florida, not in California, not in Hawaii, but in the murky waters of the Hudson River off the West 40's.

title: Rebel Group in El Salvador Frees Two Britons Held Seven Months
description: SAN SALVADOR, July 3 (UPI) Two Britons held captive by a leftist guerrilla group since Nov. 30 were released late yesterday, the British Embassy confirmed today.

title: VW Maps Investment
description: WEST BERLIN, July 3 (AP) - Toni Schmcker, the general manager of Volkswagenwerk A.G., presented the giant'auto maker's supervisory board today with a record investment program designed to meet worldwide demand for economical compact cars.

title: Brooklyn Girl Is Thrown From 6th Story Window
description: A 12-year-old Brooklyn girl was critically injured when she was thrown out of a sixthstory window yesterday after battling a knifewielding intruder, the police said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Electric Power Company, a utility holding company, has elected to its board of directors Mills E. Godwin Jr., a former Governor of Virginia.

title: U.S. Said to Tell Seoul Troops Will Eventually Leave
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 3 - Even President Carter decides to continue the freeze on American troop withdrawals from Korea, Defense Secretary Harold Brown has told South Korean leaders that the United States remains committed to their eventual withdrawal, according to senior Administration official.

title: Personal Health
description: Jane E. Brody

title: 45 Injured as 2 Buses Collide in Rye
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 3 - Two chartered buses carrying children from Head Start program in the Bronx collided outside the Playland Amusement Park in Rye this afternoon, injuring 45 persons.
