description: TO facilitate straight cuts when using a portable circular saw or saber saw, or to follow straight line accurately when using a portable rounder, R.A.K.

title: Britain Presses Campaign for Recognition of Rhodesia
description: LONDON, July 4  In a major foreign policy initiative, Britain's two-month-old Government is moving on a number of fronts to normalize its relationship with Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

title: 2 Million Gallons of Gas Is Offered for Long Island
description: BOHEMIA, L.I.  Northville Industries has told tourism authorities that it has two million gallons of gasoline available for distribution and has asked for assistance in persuading the large oil companies to allow their retail outlets.on Long Island to sell it.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Article 3 -- No Title

title: 14 Food Establishments Are Cited for Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health has cited 14 food establishments that it said had violated the city'xs Health Code. The department also listed three restaurants that hadreopened after correcting earlier violations and one restaurant that had been closed for failing to do so.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 4 (AP) Four men and a woman, all members of the Outlaws motorcycle group, were methodically shot to death early today in the tworoom frame house that served as their local headquarters, the police said.

title: TV: All Creatures Great and Small, About Yorkshire Veterinarian
description: ALL Creatures Great and Small clearly has charms that much of the public finds irresistible. The book was an international bestseller, part of an autobiographical series written by James Herriot, a pseudonym for veterinarian practicing in England's Yorkshire Dales.

title: Dr. George R. Shaw, 83, a Leader In Development of Vacuum Tube
description: Dr. George Robert Shaw, a leader in vacuumtube development during the early years of radio and chief engineer of the RCA tube division from 1939 to his retirement in 1961, died July 1 in Charlottesville, Va. He was 83 years old and had lived in Verona, N.J., since 1930 before moving to Charlottesville.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY,JULY 5,1979

title: About Garrison
description: Special to The New York Times

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter canceled tonight's scheduled energy address, even as speechwriters were putting finishing touches on it. The White House gave no explanation, and the move surprised both Cabinet members and White House aides. Shortly after revisions in the draft speech had been rushed to him, Mr. Carter told Vice President Mondale and senior aides that he would not deliver it. Questions on timing and a lack of policy decisions were said to be factors. [Page A1.]

title: The Future: We Are Far Apart
description: Congress is debating a wide range of legislation that would, in one way or the other, put restraint on the development of nuclear energy. The House will vote next month on a proposal for a sixmonth moratorium on licensing of new plants. and decisions are expected later in the year on proposals for more stringent requirements for safety, evacuation and licensing.

title: For Americans in Teheran, a Grim Fourth of July
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 4  The American flag fluttered in the strong wind that swept over Teheran on this fine summer day.

title: Nixon Set on Visiting shah in Mexico Soon
description: ANAHEIM; Calif., July 4 (AP)  Former President Richard M. Nixon says he feels it is important that he and his wife, Pat, visit Mexico to see the exiled Shah of Iran because if the United States doesn't stand by our friends when they're in trouble, we're going to end up without any friends.

title: Miss Navratilova, Mrs. Lloyd Win
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 Tracy Austin, who sometimes giggles like the 16-year-old schoolgirl she is, lost her chance today to become the youngest player to reach the women's singles final at the Wimbledon lawn tennis championships.

title: Building Spree in Atlanta Is Its Busiest Since 60's
description: ATLANTA, July 4  Construction of downtown office space and hotel rooms is soaring in Atlanta again after period of overbuilding and economic retrenchment.

title: WINS Names a Theater Critic
description: Leida Snow, a reporter and producer for WPIXFM, has been named theater critic of WINSAM, one of two allnews radio stations in the metropolitan area. Miss Snow will be the station's first theater critic.

title: Harbor Festival Rides Wave of Cheers
description: The New York City Police Department's marine and aviation units rescued Harbor Festival 1979 yesterday.

title: The City's Losing Clout
description: New York City is a modem rotten thorough, not because of population decline, but because of its massive and continuing falloff in voter participation. New York City's political base is now more apparent than real.

title: PRESSURE MOUNTING ON SOMOZA TO QUIT
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 4  With the Sandinist guerrillas slowly extending their control over Nicaragua, the United States Ambassador returned here from Washington today apparently bent on persuading President Anastasio Somoza Debayle to resign before his National Guard is defeated.

title: Barrels of Chemicals Rot as Disposal Fails
description: OSWEGO, N.Y.  In a vacant lot just mile cast of downtown Oswego, thousands of barrels of chemicals are buckling and rotting, spilling into Wine Creek, a tributary of Lake Ontario.

title: Met Museum Names Drue Heinz Trustee
description: Drue Heinz, a patron of the Metropolitan Museum and chairman of the visiting committee to its European paintings department, has been elected to the museum's board of trustees. At the same time. honorary trusteeships have been bestowed on three persons prominent in the cultural field: Alice Tully, the philanthropist; the architect Philip Johnson and Seymour M. Klein, a lawyer who represents the Robert Woods Johnson Jr. Charitable Trust.

title: Poets of the World Tame Rowdy Romans
description: ROME, July 4  Famous American, Soviet and European poets including Yevgeny Yevtushenko, Allen Ginsberg and Imamu Amiri Baraka snatched victory from defeat last weekend when they refused to relinquish a makeshift openair stage in spite of flying bottles and bullets of wet sand from protesters and an invasion of street poets who wanted the microphone for themselves.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Can you tell me how to remove waterbase interior wall paint

title: One Thousand a Day
description: Homeless people, most with nothing left but their clothes, are still emerging from Vietnam and Cambodia at the rate of about 65,000 a month. A special United Nations conference has been called in Geneva to deal with their plight but it will not start for 15 days. In the meantime, refugees continue to die, a thousand each day.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Because of trashcollection problems in the aftermath of the tugboat strike, alternateside parking regulations will be in effect today and tomorrow in Manhattan and Brooklyn only.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: Article 2 -- No Title

title: Warner to Back Ladd In Film Unit
description: Alan Ladd Jr. and two of his top aides at the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation joined Ted Ashley, chairman, and Frank Wells, president, of Warner Brothers Inc., in announcing yesterday that the three Fox executives will head a new film company, for which Warner's parent company will arrange substantial financing.

title: Stevenson a Patient Champion
description: SAN JUAN; P.R., July 4  He sat on a concrete slab in the center of the courtyard, surrounded by the stacked balconies of highrise buildings.- If it was Madison Square Garden instead of the Pan Ameritan Village, teofilo. Stevenson would be in the middle of the ring. No one else would matter.

title: Bomb Scare in the Met At Ballet Performance
description: A bomb threat at the Metropolitan Opera House during a performance by the Stuttgart Ballet cleared the theater for 20 minutes last night. No bomb was found.

title: U.S. Team Closely Tracks Skylab To Give a Global Alert on Reentry
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 4 Ilown in the hollowedout granite depth of Cheyenne Mountain in the Colorado Rockies, behind steel doors and presumably safe from all falling objects, unaimed or otherwise, the question of exactly when and where Skylab will reenter the atmosphere and then disintegrate is being addressed with the best available technology.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the News of the Theater column in The Times yesterday, the names of the leading actress and her replacement in the Broadway play Knockout were transposed. Judith McGilligan is now playing the role of Kay. She replaced Margaret Warncke.

title: A Burst of Bopu Hopu for China on the 4th
description: PEKING, July 4 Bob Hope and mixed group of other American entertainers staged their own cultural revolution in Peking today.

title: Issue and Debate Scholastic Testing Industry Facing Regulation by State
description: Last month the New York Legislature passed a truth-in-testing bill that would require concerns that give such standardized tests as the Scholastic Aptitude Test to make the questions and correct answers available to students who take them.

title: ALGERIANS DECIDE TO FREE BEN BELK DETAINED 14 YEARS
description: ALGIERS, July 4  The Algerian Goiremment has decided to free former President Ahmed Ben Bella after 14 years under house arrest.

title: Bridge:
description: QuickWitted Players Gain Edge by Masking Decision

title: Fumes at Watersfide Injure 38
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 4 (UPI) Thirtyeight persons were treated at three Charlotte hospitals yesterday after they inhaled chlorine gas at a waterslide. The victims, ranging in age from 7 to 31 years, complained of nausea, burning ip the upper respiratory tract and shortness of breath. No serious injuries were reported.

title: Cosmos Downed by Bayern, 20
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 4  Bayern Munchen, which defeated the touring Cosmos by 71 last fall in Munich, defeated the hometeam Cosmos. 20, at Giants Stadium today in steady drizzle before 42,366 fans.PONTIAC, Mich., July 4 Steve

title: Diane Drobnis Wed To Yale Professor
description: Diane Drobnis, senior medical editor at Elsevier North Holland Inc., a scientific publishing house in New York, was married yesterday in Guilford, Conn., to Dr. Leon E. Rosenberg, professor and chairman of the department of human genetics at the Yale School of Medicine. Justice of the Peace Paul Nere performed the ceremony at the house the couple will occupy.

title: Scholars Take Optimistic View of Energy Problems
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  The energy problem has conjured up grim visions of suburban collapse, a widespread return to the cities and to mass transportation, economic disaster in the Northeast and profound change in American living habits.

title: Red Sox Set Back Royals
description: BOSTCSN, July 4 (AP)  Dwight Evans's 100th majorleague homer, tworun shot off Al Hrabosky with two out in the ninth inning tonight, powered the Boston Red Sox to a 64 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Notes on People
description: The Greek shipping heiress Christina Onassis and the Russian she married year ago, Sergei Kausov, have abandoned Moscow and settled permanently in Switzerland, in a St. Moritz chalet owned by Mrs. Kausov's late father, Aristotle Onassis. Friends and advisers to Mrs. Kausov, who arrived in Greece yesterday with her husband for a holiday, said the move became possible some months ago when Mr. Kausov was granted a multiple exit visa like his wife's, allowing both of them to travel back and forth to Moscow at will. They have retained their apartment there.

title: The Opposition: A Renewed Movement
description: The debate over the dangers of radiation is not new. In the years following World War II, up until the early 1960's, it was intense. The controversy centered on the explosion of atomic bombs in the atmosphere, but there also were some warnings about dangers from the peaceful uses of nuclear energy. The National Academy of Sciences recommended in 1957, for example, that a national system of records be established to keep track of each American's exposure to radiation, proposal the Government rejected as impractical.

title: Visitor From Ork Throws TV Programmers Into Orbit
description: All in the Family was being revised by CBS, and NBC was very vague, talking about a long form show. We had enough confidence to split Happy Days, Laverne and Shirley and Three's Company, and put Laverne on Thursdays, and with Mork and Mindy's popularity growing enormously, we felt it would strengthen Sunday to put it there. The same strategy dictated that another strong ABC show, Fantasy Island, be moved from late on Saturday into that

title: ABROAD AT HOME Decision In The Dark
description: BOSTON, July 4  The most dangerous Supreme Court decisions can be the ones that are made to look easy. When an opinion deals with a question of our fundamental law as if it had only one answer, as if a constitutional problem . could be resolved by a phrase, without reference to experience or the facts of a complicated national life, it is time to beware.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Among the Wall Street analysts who try to determine where interest rates are headed, .the big rumor this week is that Henry Kaufman appears to be changing his tune. Mr. Kaufman, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, major investment banking firm, has long been one of the securities industry's most outspoken prophets of higher interest rates.

title: Canada's New Premier Is Acting As Though He Plans Long Stay
description: OTTAWA  When the defeated Liberals vacated the Prime Minister's offices here in June, they put a large sign in the windows facing Wellington Street. It said, We'll be back!

title: $3 Million Fine in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, July 4 (Reuter) former detective sergeant who retired from the Hong Kong police as a multimil. lionaire was jailed today for two years for corruption and fined the equivalent of $3 million. Lai Manyau maintained at his trial that he had acquired his fortune in China during World War H. But the Judge said he did not believe a millionaire would have Joined the police as constable.

title: Strike Shuts Greek Banks
description: ATHENS, July 4(Reuters)  Banks in Greece were closed today by an indefinite strike called last night by the Federation of Bank Employees protesting an extension of working hours as an energysaving measure. Yesterday,

title: Mental Retardation Post Filled
description: ALBANY, July 4 (UPI)  James E. Introne, deputy state budget director, was named first deputy commissioner of the State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities yesterday. Mr. Introne, who will earn $50,635 year in his new position, formerly served as assistant secretary for human resOurces to Governor Carey, overseeing the mental retardation office.

title: GARDENING
description: THE charm of old roses stems not from their age, but from their background. They are ancestral plants, roses that were popular hundreds of years ago, and they are very different from the roses found in most gardens today.

title: On the Agent Orange Trail
description: Americans whose Vietnam trials included exposure to a defoliant known as Agent Orange have finally gained a forum for their claim that they have suffered an array of disabling diseases. Without the chance to state their grievances to a House Commerce subcommittee. they might still be shuttling around the cold corridors of the Defense Department and Veterans Administration. Spurred by the public embarrassment the hearings, the executive departments have finally agreed to look for links between the chemical and the ailments of which the men complain. How sad that such prods are necessary to remind a Government of its most elementary obligation.

title: Play 'As You Like It By Folger in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 William Penn's music and Louis W. Scheeder's lively and witty staging provide some of the best moments in the Folger Theater's production of As You Like It.

title: Inco Diversifying via Research
description: STERLING FOREST, N.Y.,June 29  Gary Sandrock, sometimes called Mr. Hydrogen at Inco Ltd.'s research center overlooking Blue Lake here, adjusted a valve to let more hydrogen flow as an aide pulled the starter and the small Wankel engine sputtered and began to run.

title: Apollo Loses to Eagles; Victoryless Streak Is at 6
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 4  In failing to win for the sixth straight game, the New York Apollo was defeated by the New York Eagles tonight, 21, before 2,012 rainsoaked fans at Hofstra Stadium.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: A GOODYEAR BLIMP DESTROYED: Wreckage of the blimp Mayflower lies in a cornfield in Mount Pleasant, Iowa, after extremely high winds blew from its moorings and slammed it to the ground. No one was hurt, but the $1.5million blimp was described as a total loss. The Mayflower was one of four blimps owned by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, and it was moored

title: West German Workers Paradise
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. - The major explanation for the decisive victory of Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party in the May 3.electlon may be discovered by contrasting British experience since World War II with that of West Germany. The two countries were remarkably similar in the 1950's in population, natural resources, industrial structures, and education. The British, their economic capacity little affected by the war, were far ahead in gross national product per capita. By 1977, however, West Germany's GNP per capita was almost double that of the British.

title: A Minimalist Does the Unexpected
description: JUAN MONTOYA, 34 years old, is gentle, softspoken advocate of the hard edge, tough industrial materials school of interior design. Or so he is perceived by many in the field. However. like any firstrate designer, his primary interest is finding the right solution to the problem. And while he has evolved a style of his own, he has avoided the inevitable risk of letting it become a clich by returning to predictably repeated furnishings.

title: U.S. to Teach Artists to Improve Marketing Skills
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  A federally financed program of national seminars to teach artists business skills in order to better market their efforts has been announced by Joan Mondale, wife of the Vice President and honorary chairman of the Federal Council on the Arts and Humanities.

title: Oil Price Rise Stirs Review Of U.S. War Moves in Crisis
description: A brisk but unpublicized debate among members; of Congress, military leaders and civilian officials over future United States strategy has taken on new importance since the increase in oil prices by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: A Trio of Potters: Celebrating Clay
description: THEY got into business quite by accident. Mostly by necessity. One day in 1971 they arrived at the school where they taught ceramics and were welcomed by a notice from the city marshal, announcing that the school was out of business. So we scrounged around fora place to work and were forced into business, said Ellen Staller, one of the three partners in Terrafirma Ceramics. We knew we didn't want make mugs, added Susan Kay. So far they haven't had to

title: Design Notebook
description: HOUSES are theater, as we all know. What is played out in them may be comedy or tragedy, historical drama or farce; but no matter what is on the program for the day, every house has its exits and its entrances, its upstage and its downstage, its good seats and its bad seats and, all too often, its prompter's box in full use.

title: Television
description: 5:02(2)Stanley Siegel

title: Apparel Tariff Cuts May Grow
description: The President's special trade representatives and the Commerce Department are expected to disclose tariff cuts this morning for women's and children' apparel imports ranging from 40 percent to 60 percent. These are in contrast to reductions of only 15 percent previously indicated by the Federal Government.

title: Gaye Whedon Zilenziger Married to Scott Geiger
description: The marriage of Gaye Whedon Zilenziger and Scott Alan Geiger, May graduates of Hartwick and Middlebury Colleges, respectively, took place yesterday at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. J. Scottie Griffin, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Francis O'Malley, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Cottage Industry: Hammering Out A Summer Home
description: WHEN my wife and I resolved to find a summer paradise, our requirements didn't seem too exacting: I wanted acreage fronting on a lake, she wanted a cottage in good condition and we both agreed that $10,000 to $15,000 was our financial limit.

title: North Korea Assails 3Way Talks
description: TOKYO, July 4 (UPI)  North Korea today appeared to denounce President Carter's proposal for threeway talks among the two Koreas and the United States, saying it wanted negotiations for reunification without any alien interference.

title: Entertainment Events
description: MARCHING ALONG WITH SOUSA, Allentown Band and Roberta Peters, soprano, Radio City Music Hall, 8.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TORONTO, July 4 (AP)  George (Punch) Imlach was named director of operations for the Toronto Maple Leafs today. He guided the Leafs to four Stanley Cup championships  in 196264 and 1967.

title: John Davies, 63, Ex-Cabinet Aide . And a Leader of Britain's Tories
description: LONDON, July 4 (AP)  John Davies, a former Conservative Party Cabinet minister and Tory spokesman on foreign affairs, died today at'St. Thomas's Hospital in London. He was 63 years old.

title: The City
description: Mediators moved into two of New York City's three private bus strikes, those affecting. Green Bus Lines and Carey Transportation Inc.

title: Disks: Sonatas for Violin And Viola by Shostakovich
description: THE works of Shostakovich's last years tend to be enigmatic and highly personal. It does not make them particularly endearing to the average listener, but it places them among his most fascinating creations. The Violin Sonata (Op. 134) was completed in 1967 and dedicated to David Oistrakh, who gave it its first public performance the following year, with Sviatoslav Richter at the piano. That premiere was recorded and released here on the Angel label, but is no longer listed in the Schwann catalogue.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Article 1 -- No Title

title: Life Sentence for Murder Upheld By Rhode Island Supreme Court
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 4 (UPI) Rhode Island's mandatory life sentence for anyone convicted of firstdegree murder was upheld yesterday by the State Supreme Court.

title: Private Justice, Public Injustice
description: For centuries the idea of open justice has been synonymous with justice itself. Before the Norman Conquest, before English judges spelled out the rudimentary rights of defendants, throughout the development of British and American jurisprudence, the tradition open courts has been honored. Now a 54 Supreme Court majority has ordained an exception: the public trial right belongs exclusively to the defendant, who can waive it if the prosecution agrees that an open proceeding might threaten the right to an impartial jury. One would think the high court would create such an exception only out of compelling necessity. But this ruling, besides disserving justice, was unnecessary.

title: ISRAEL BARS QUAKERS IN ARAB COURT CASES
description: JERUSALEM, July 4  American Quaker welfare workers said today that the Israeli Government had told them to stop providing legal aid to Arabs in the West Bank.

title: Pavarotti to Lead Israeli Tucker Salute
description: Luciano Pavarotti, the tenor, will sing and the. Israel Philharmonic, conducted by Zubin Mehta, will play at a gala Tribute to Richard Tucker in Tel Aviv's Frederic R. Mann Auditorium on Saturday. Today, a bust of the late Metropolitan Opera tenor will be unveiled in the auditorium's lobby.

title: ESSAY Stranger Than Fiction
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  Now that's what I call cruel and unusual punishment, said a colleague, pointing to a paragraph In a Washington Post interview with William Niehous, the American businessman who had been kidnapped and held for more than three years by Venezuelan terrorJct.

title: Beaths
description: RANDMarcell Nelson. Of Darien, Conn., on July 1, 1979. Husband of Jane Edwards Rand, father of James H. Rand, John B. Rand and Richard Rand. Memorial Service at the First Congregational Church, 14 Brookside Road, Darien, Conn. on Friday, July 6, 1979 at 2PM. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to Stamford Hospital, Shelburne Road, Stamford. Conn. 06902

title: Stores Cut Orders for Fall Season
description: The nation's retailers, in anticipation of further slowing in the economy, are reducing their orders of domestic goods, and industry observers have noticed a drop in imports as well.

title: Moffett Says He Won't Seek Seat Now Held by Ribicoff
description: HARTFORD, July 5  Representative Toby Moffett announced this morning that he would not seek the Senate seat being vacated by Abraham A. Ribicoff, a move that appeared to clear the way for another young Democrat, Representative Christopher J. Dodd, to capture the nomination for the 1980 election.

title: Bridge:
description: The fact that the average American woman gives birth to 1.8 children is statistic that some would find confusing. Even more confusing for bridge players is the fact that New York City stages two and twothirds regional championships each year.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Because of trashcollection problems, in the aftermath of the tugboat strike, alternateside parking regulations will be in effect today and tomorrow in Manhattan and Brooklyn only.

title: Associated Press
description: LOST AND FOUND: George Brett of Royals searching vainly for foul pop hit by Butch Hobson of Red Sox in second inning of game at Boston yesterday. Hobson then drove run with single as Red Sox defeated Royals, 54.

title: Five Million See Chiropractors
description: Although chiropractic has been shunned by the medical profession and attacked as an unscientific cult for much of its 84year history, more than five million Americans visit the nation's 20,000 chiropractors each year.

title: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:3D P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 900 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS S5300; NASSAU CO. (516) 74740000 SUFFOLK CO. (510) 0661800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:3D P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 900 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. (510) 0661800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Retailers Sales Gains Slow Down
description: The nation's consumer buying, jarred by shortages and sharply rising prices of gasoline, continued to slow in June.

title: Art: Met Shows Landscape Drawings
description: THE best part of the Robert Lehman Collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art has always been the old master drawings. And although the gallery space designed for their exhibition is not exactly a triumph of intimacy  it Is little more than a circular corridor leading to nothing but itself  it at least avoids the distracting pretensions of the socalled period rooms that house most of the Lehman paintings and decorative objects. In the drawing gallery we are not visually bludgeoned into thinking about anything but the drawings.

title: Companies List Earnings
description: For periods as shown. ( N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Topics Gladiators
description: Back in the 1950's, when G.I. Joe stood with cowboys and centerfielders as an American folk hero, youngsters were eager to play the part of soldiers. Many got their first taste of the Army in the high school version of the Reserve Officer Training Corps. Part of each school day was devoted to learning the difference between parade rest and at ease, watching training films and cleaning M1 rifles. But high school R.O.T.C. lost its appeal during the Vietnam era. Enrollment dwindled and many schools quit the program.

title: 2,000 Flee Toxic Chemical Fumes
description: MEMPHIS, July 5 (AP)  A mushroom cloud of a toxic pesticide erupted from a burning chemical plant today, forcing at least 2,000 residents from their homes and closing the Mississippi River to traffic.

title: DECISION BY CARTER TO PUT OFF SPEECH HAS A BROAD EFFECT
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  President Carter's sudden cancellation of his planned nationwide energy address set off broad political and financial repercussions today, including a sharp drop in the dollar overseas that caused the White House to move to reverse the weakness in the American currency.

title: Royal Bank Of Canada in Shift
description: The Royal Bank of Canada said that it would shift most of its United States division, now in Montreal, to New York City, where it operates a statechartered trust company, a representative office and an agency.

title: Rail Halt Sought By Milwaukee Road
description: CHICAGO, July 5 (UPI)  The financially troubled Milwaukee Road will file a formal application with the Interstate Commerce Commission by Aug. to abandon its rail lines west of Miles City, Mont., it was announced today.

title: Judge May Bar Press From Felony Hearing
description: Citing a decision this week by the United States Supreme Court that gave trial judges broad discretion to close their courtrooms to the public, a New York State Supreme Court justice said yesterday that he would be willing to exclude the press from a hearing in an attemptedmurder case.

title: U.S. Plans AirConditioning Lirriit Of 78 for Nonresidential Areas
description: The United States Department of Energy made public yesterday eryiergency regulations on airconditioning in almost all nonresidential buildings. If the rules are signed by President Carter, they would limit cooling to 78 degrees.

title: Mishap on New Atlanta Subway
description: ATLANTA, July 5 (AP)  After four days of relatively troublefree operation, a transit authority train has broken down, stranding 350 riders in a subway tunnel for 20 minutes. The fourcar train lost air pressure in its braking system yesterday. The pressure was restored, and the train returned to the yard for repairs. Train service began last Saturday.

title: Israel's Settlements Stir Intense Debate Among U.S. Jews
description: Only a short time ago, all divisiveness was seemingly swept away by the euphoria of the IsraelEgypt peace treaty. But as Israel's West Bank settlement policy continued, so, too, has the questioning, and even criticism, by some American Jews, and criticism by other Jews of their questioning and criticism.

title: News Summary
description: A sharp drop in the dollar occurred as a result of President Carter's abrupt cancellation of his energy speech, and the White House moved immediately to correct the situation. Alerted to the drop, President Carter authorized his press office to issue a statement reaffirming his intention to propose a series of strong energy measures at an early date. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: Iran Taking Over More Industries; General Motors Affiliate Affected
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 5 - The revolutionalr Government announced today the nationalization of virtually all of Iran's remaining largescale industry still held by the private sector.

title: G.M. Seeking Information
description: DETROIT, July 5 (AP)  General Motors said today it was trying to find out more about the reported nationalization of its Iranian affiliate. It, declined to disclose the value of the 45 percent share it holds in the Iranian company.

title: N.E.A. Says Teacher BurnOut Causes Thousands to Leave Jobs
description: DETROIT, July 5  Thousands of teachers are suffering from burnout because of student violence, vandalism, highly Inadequate salaries and a lack of support from administrators, the National Education Association declared today.

title: A.M.A. Charged With a Boycott Of Chiropractors
description: Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General, filed suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday against the American Medical Association and 13 other defendants in the medical field, charging them with conspiracy to first isolate and then eliminate the chiropractic profession.

title: Business and the Law
description: DOlNG its part to comply with trade regulation laws, the Control Data Corporation has cautioned its employees to avoid all unnecessary formal and informal contact with competitors or their officers or employees.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Walter S. Holmes Jr. is a certified public accountant who began his career in industry in 1947 as assistant tax director for the RCA Corporation. After 12 years with RCA, he joined the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, the nation's largest publicly owned business and consumer financing company, and today he is its chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Vassallo Brothers Fly Different Flags
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 5  The lane assignments for the second heat of the 200meter backstroke at the Pan American Games today were bellowed over the publicaddress system at the El Escambron Pool. In lane 4, Jesse Vassallo, United States. In lane 7, Victor Vassallo, Puerto Rico.

title: Yale Eight Is Fastest in Trials at Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, July 5  Perfect racing weather brought out record crowds today for the opening round of the 131st rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta.

title: U.S. Envoys Press Drive for Peace In Nicaragua in Six Latin Capitals
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  The United States made new efforts to end the civil war and seek a democratic solution in Nicaragua today as envoys carried out urgent consultations in six Central American and Caribbean capitals.

title: Stocks Rise Slightly; Spotlight Still on Oil
description: There was no official explanation of the President's action, but some investment analysts suggested that he might be taking additional time to formulate a more solid energy policy. Others speculated that the speech was canceled because the President decided that he had little to say,

title: Business Loans Advance At Big New York Banks
description: Business loans at major New York City banks soared by $491 million in the week ended July 9, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the previous week, they rose $238 million.

title: Better Weekend Gas Supply Seen
description: Buying gasoline in the metropolitan New York area and throughout the Northeast is expected to be easier this weekend than during the two previous weekends, according to auto club and state officials.

title: Article 6 -- No Title
description: Department stores becoming more competitive, there's no such thing as wholesale.

title: Joseph Borhin, 67; Author of an Analysis Off. G. Farben Cartel
description: Joseph Borkin, a Washington lawyer, economist and an author whose works included last year's bestselling The Crime and Punishment of I. G. Farben, a critical study of the vast German chemical cartel, died yesterday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 67 years old.

title: U.S. Team Swims to 16th Victory
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 5  Will United States swimmers win every race at the Pan American Games?

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, July 5 (Reuters)  Vietnam told China today it would remove its troops from Cambodia and Laos, but only when the danger it said Peking posed for Indochina was removed.

title: West German Car Sales Enjoying a Record Year
description: BONN, July 5 (Reuters)  While automobile sales in the United States have plummeted in the wake of gasoline shortages and price increases, West Germany's automobile makers continue to enjoy their best domestic year on record.

title: Langford Hurls OneHitter
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 5 (AP) Rick Langford hurled a onehitter, allowing only an infield single by Brian in the fifth as the Oakland A's defeated the California Angels, 30, tonight. Langford (49), who had been in the bull pen the last two weeks, struck out six and walked five.

title: Russians Asks Norway to Return Soldier Who Applied for Asylum
description: OSLO, July 5 (UPI) The Soviet Union has asked Norway to return a 19yearold soldier who walked across the border Monday and requested political asylum, the Foreign Ministry said today. He said he was fed up with the Soviet Union.

title: Mets Top Phils, 32; Swan Strikes Out 10
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5 - Joel Youngblood rapped the fourth pitch thrown in the major leagues by Dickie Noles for a home run tonight, starting the New York Mets toward a 32 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies and an end to their fivename losing streak.

title: Inquiries on Reactor Failure Focus On Delay in Alert on Core Problem
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 - Three separate investigative groups are seeking to discover why the Government was not immediately informed of indications that the core of the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor began disintegrating within a few hours after the start of the accident near Harrisburg, Pa.

title: Market Place
description: MOST money managers and institutional investors on Wall Street insist on visiting the companies whose stocks they might decide buy. The idea is to evaluate management and to gain a sense of what is going on inside the company.

title: Borg and Tanner Advance To Final in Straight Sets
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 5 Bjorn Borg, the tennis machine, ran over Jimmy Connors in straight sets this afternoon, 62, 63, 62, in the semifinals of the Wimbledon Lawn Tennis Championships. Borg shut out his rival in 106 minutes - three minutes fewer than he took to dispatch Connors in the 1978 championship.

title: A Scenario for Mondale
description: There is no doubt in my mind that this comprehensive energy bill is both urgent and critical. I have asked the American people and the Congress to accept this legislation in a spirit of national unity that transcends personal and political interests. In this same spirit, I submit these bills as a vote of confidence in my leadership. If they are not passed promptly  and substantially as written  I shall submit my resignation to the Secretary of State.

title: Atlantic Richfield's Arco Unit Expands
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (UPI) The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that its Arco Chemical division haf started building a new polymeric isocynates plant at the Lyondell complex at Channel!view, Texas.

title: Arms Control Agency's Head Winning Battle of His Own
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Clutching the speaker's lectern with both hands, the 6foot 4inch former Army general leaned forward and solemnly declared: As a young officer in World War II I learned the importance of military preparedness to our national security. Just because I have taken over an agency with the word disarmament in it doesn't mean I believe in unilateral disarmament.

title: Hot Dog King Is Upset By Park FoodTasting
description: The Central Park Hot Dog King, John Zervas, could have had a free pt sandwich with sliced cornichons yesterday, but he told the Park Commissioner, Gordon Davis, that he had an ulcerwhich presumably became aggravated by what Mr. Zervas considered to be incursions into his territory.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE first of the Stiff records from Britain, to be released domestically by CBS haVe now appeared, and several of them  Lene Lovich, Rachel Sweet  have already been discussed in the these pages in their imported versions. But two new ones command attention.

title: Six Lies On Energy
description: CHICAGO - The war against energy, the automobile and a free enterprise economy is being supported by a propaganda war of startling dimensions. The following are among the more blatent untruths being propagated in support of higher energy taxes and tighter controls over voluntary market choices:

title: Agriculture Department Proposes New Limits On Junk Food in School
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  School children who want to buy low nutrition snacks and soft drinks from school vending machines or cafeterias would have to wait until after the day's last lunch is served under rules proposed today by the Agriculture Denartmpnt These rules would affect sales, within the schools, of any food containing less than 5 percent of the basic nutrients in the Government's recommended daily dietary allowance.

title: Homing In on the Peace Corps
description: The Peace Corps, which began lire as an inaepenaent Federal agency, has become the object of recurrent attempts to find it a new bureaucratic home. In 1971, the Nixon Administration, hoping perhaps to bury it, tucked it into ACTION, an agency for domestic as well as foreign voluntary service. Now the House of Representatives wants to uproot it again, transferring it to a proposed foreign aid conglomerate to be known as the International Development Cooperation Agency. The original switch made no particular sense but neither does the proposed change.

title: New Party of Old Backers a Blow To Mrs. Gandhi's Political Future
description: NEW DELHI, July 5  The longwaning fortunes of Indira Gandhi plummeted further this week as her recently disaffected followers merged with older defectors from her cause to form broadened political party that now supplants Mrs. Gandhi's faction as India's major opposition in Parliament.

title: Coordinator of Arms Treaty Describes Job Ahead
description: Mr. Cutler, 61 years old, will organize and coordinate presentations this month before three Senate committees: Intelligence, Foreign Relations and Armed Services.

title: About Real Estate U.S. Housing Devices Offer Little Aid to Occupied Units
description: Washington has recently presented the city with two new housing mechanisms designed to promote the rehabilitation of older apartment houses. They come at a time when rising heatingoil prices threaten to set off new surge of housing abandonment.

title: Senator Byrd, Leaving Soviet, Says He Is Still Undecided on Arms Pact
description: MOSCOW, July 5  Robert C. Byrd, the Majority Leader of the United States Senate, said here today after two days of talks with Soviet leaders that he had still not decided whether to support the new treaty limiting American and Soviet strategic nuclear arms.

title: Two 60's Songbirds in the Park
description: IN the days of hootenannies and 1960's antiwar protests, Joan Baez and Judy Collins lent their fervent, clear voices to the movement, becoming the most popular female folk singers of the time. When the war was over and the flower children grew up, both continued to make successful albums, until a sophisticated late70's audience developed a taste for more slickly packaged female artists such as Donna Summer and Linda Ronstadt.

title: Auto Sales Fell in June
description: DETROIT, July 5 (UPI)  The Big Three auto makers reported today that newcar sales in the final 10 days and full month of June fell nearly 28 percent from the yearearlier levels, continuing a slump that experts ascribe to worries over gasoline supplies and the state of the national economy.

title: Economic Scene
description: SMALL wonder that President Carter was left speechless on oil and energy. In one degree of urgency or another, the central problem of the Carter Administration  the world's heightening dependence on Middle Eastern oil  has occupied every one of his predecessors since Harry S. Truman. The stakes have shifted, from shoring up a cold War liana in !ran to struggling to slow a wnoiesale transfer of global wealth to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, but the economic fields of force are deepset and powerful. The foundations of OPEC's power are older than the 197374 explosion in oil prices.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The immobile is making its 15th annual tour around town, giving free concerts in the neighborhoods on its portable bandstand. Tonight's destination is 91st Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue. The musicians will be the Tito Puente Orchestra. Showtime is 7 P.M. Next week, the immobile will be on the road again, making stops with other musicians in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx. Call 8664900 for the itinerary.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio WMCA, 8 P.M.)

title: Notes on People
description: I hate it, but I do it willingly, Mayor Koch said yesterday, wincing as a nurse stuck a needle in a vein in his arm to draw a pint of blood. Perhaps to keep his mind occupied as he made his annual donation at a Red Cross bloodmobile, Mr. Koch delivered himself of a batch of observations in the trailer parked next to City Hall.

title: Church Members Fined For Their Loud Singing
description: NOTTINGHAM TOWNSHIP, Pa., July 5 (UPI)  The Rev. W.L. King and about 500 members of the Voice of the Nazarene Association of Independent Churches were getting ready for their service on Independence Day in this town 30 miles south of Pittsburgh.

title: Grafton W. Potter, Architect, 49; A Pioneer in Coop Development
description: Grafton W. Potter, an architect who was a pioneer in the development of cooperative housing in brownstones in Manhattan, died Monday of a heart attack. Mr. Potter, who lived on the West Side, was 49 years old.

title: 1020 YEAR THE FRESH AIR FUND
description: 1020 YEAR THE FRESH AIR FUND

title: Aides Lay Delay On Energy Plan To Uncertainties
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  High Administration officials, acknowledging that President Carter has suffered some political damage from his sudden, unexplained cancellation of his energy speech, ascribe the delay to the President's own indecision about how bold and politically risky an energy program to proclaim.

title: U.S. PRESSES EFFORT TO BROADEN MAKEUP OF NICARAGUA JUNTA
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 5 - The United States, confident that Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle is about to resign as President of Nicaragua, is reportedly pressing several Latin American countries to exert a moderating influence over the provisional junta named by the Sandinist guerrillas.

title: The Denim Skirt: A Natural Step From Jeans
description: You'll see them all around the town. Jean skirts are this summer's uniform, replacing the flowered skirts of seasons past.

title: San Francisco Mayor Calls for Police Chief to Quit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 - Mayor Dianne Feinstein today asked for the resignation of Police Chief Charles Gain, who had been severely criticized by police officers for the way he handled the May 21 riots by thousands of citizens angered by the verdict in the killings of Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk.

title: The Region
description: NEWARK  New Jersey Republicans took their party platform hearings to the waiting room at Penn Station yesterday to demonstrate their eagerness to open the party to new ideas from the public, but commuters showed little interest.

title: Mexico Lifts Price Of Its Oil to $22.60
description: MEXICO CITY, July 5 (AP) Mexico's Government oil monopoly, Pemex, raised the price of its crude oil 32.2 percent today to $22.60 a barrel, retroactive to July 1.

title: Precious Metals Lead Jump in Futures Prices
description: Commodity futures prices, led by the volatile precious metals, soared yesterday with many rising the daily allowable trading limit.

title: Screen: Gene Wilder in Aldrich's 'The Frisco Kid':Polish Rabbi Out West
description: ASKING Robert Aldrich to direct a sentimental Jewish comedy on the order of "The Frisco Kid" is like putting the late Gen. George S. Patton Jr. in charge of a tap-dancing class for tiny tots. Not knowing exactly what to do, he doesn't seem to do very much at all. The result is harmless chaos. People keep coming and going and doing ferociously cute things, but never anything that could appeal to anyone except a close relative or someone with a built-in weakness for anything ethnic whatsoever.Mr. Aldrich's strength is his weakness for the violent and the macabre ("The Dirty Dozen," "Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?" and "Ulzana's Raid," among others). "The Frisco Kid" is neither.It's a Gene Wilder comedy of a lesser sort, about a young, nave Polish rabbi who is sent to this country in 1850 to take charge of a San Francisco congregation. The original screenplay by Michael Elias and Frank Shaw is all heart and two inches wide. There's scarcely a plot development, from the moment the rabbi is swindled out of his money on his arrival in Philadelphia, through his adventures on the open range in the company of a kind-hearted, WASP outlaw (Harrison Ford), that isn't telegraphed from the opening, pre-credit sequences. I must admit, though, that this is one of those movies in which the credits don't come on the screen until the film seems half over.I'm a great admirer of Mr. Wilder when, as in his own "Sherlock Holmes' Smarter Brother" and "The World's Greatest Lover," and especially in Mel Brooks's "Young Frankenstein," he plays a character of patently unjustifiable self-assurance, a fellow who's funny because of his complete absorption by the absurd. One of the great, solemnly funny sequences of all time is the "Putting on the Ritz" number from "Young Frankenstein," when the young doctor (Mr. Wilder) and his monster-pupil (Gene Hackman) strut their stuff for the convention of Viennese alienists.Mr. Wilder has two distinct public personalities. As I heard a lady say on a Broadway bus the other day, speaking of a friend's unreliable husband, "He's a regular Dr. Jacobs and Mr. Hyde." So is Mr. Wilder.He's most appealing  nice  when he's being somewhat eccentric. In movies like "Quackser Fortune Has a Cousin in the Bronx" and "The Silver Streak," when he attempts to represent a kind of gentle blessedness, the intelligence of the actor shows through the disguise. The characterization becomes too calculated to be appealing. One suspects the innocent creature of being, at heart, Mr. Hyde."The Frisco Kid," which opens today at the Cinema One, is a movie based on a great idea that, when realized, isn't. The gimmick is exhausted in the telling of it. A Polish rabbi out West? Wow! But unless the gimmick is in some way topped, such a movie runs down hill, like this one.Mr. Ford has a somewhat easier time of it than Mr. Wilder, being required to be little more than stalwart straight-man to the star. From the evidence here, Mr. Aldrich is not most at home in the kind of lovable comedy this film wants to be. The comic timing is always a couple of beats off. Even Leo Fuchs, who was one of the great comic actors in the Yiddish theater and who has a small role at the beginning of the film, is wasted. He seems to be just another dress extra.There's no shortage of talent in "The Frisco Kid," but it's the wrong talent for the wrong material."The Frisco Kid," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains some mildly vulgar language.

title: Bus Specials to Tanglewood and Environs
description: Tonight the Boston Symphony Orchestra gives its first concert in the annual summer festival at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., and its devotees are probably wondering in these days of gas shortages not whether to go, but bow. Alternatives exist, fortunately, in the form of bus tours. Even though they restrict the traveler to the Sunday afternoon concerts, they are worth considering. Some details follow, but it is urged that those who are interested telephone the companies involved.

title: Bank Is Fined For Violation
description: United America's Bank pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to charges that it had violated the Federal Bank Secrecy Act by failing to report 12 currency transactions of more than S10,000 each.

title: Acting Director Appointed Chief Of Currency Bureau in Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)  Harry R. Clements, acting director of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing since April, has been named director of the bureau, the Treasury Department announced today.

title: The F.B.I.'s Bank Withdrawal
description: Bank robberies have always been the bane banks but they were part of the making of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Holdups were dramatic and their solutions often equally so. When J. Edgar Hoover personally led the capture of Alvin (Old Creepy) Karpis, he led the F.B.I. to glory  and to an image that inspired Congressional committees to vie for the honor granting or exceeding his budget requests.

title: Geneva Refugee Parley To Discuss Sea Rescues
description: GENEVA, July 5  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations said today that the issue of rescue at sea of Vietnamese boat people would be on the agenda of the international conference on Indochinese refugees scheduled here July 20.

title: 3 Kidnap Victims Released In Brooklyn After 40 Hours
description: Haggard and shaking with fear after a 40hour abduction ordeal, a 30yearold woman, her 6yearold daughter and a family friend were freed unharmed in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon by a band of kidnappers that allegedly forced the woman's husband to pay a ransom of more than $10,000.

title: Lifeboats at Shea
description: Like ships that pass in the night, the Yankees have departed until after the AllStar Game as if they were millionaires in staterooms on the QE2, while the Mets drift back to Shea Stadium tonight as if in lifeboats, alone and abandoned.

title: U.S. Said to Seek World Credit Curbs
description: The Carter Administration has proposed that the major industrial nations limit the growth of international credit by imposing uniform rules on the amounts banks may borrow in relation to their shareholders invested capital, according to banking sources.

title: MENDY RUDOLPH, 53, DIES
description: Marvin (Mandy) Rudolph, who refereed 2,112 games during his flamboyant 22year career in the National Basketball Association, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home in Manhattan. He was 53 years old.

title: European Fuel Experts Uige Closer OPEC Ties
description: PARIS, July 5  An urgent warning that the United States and other industrial democracies must form a new partnership with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries if they want to escape from the energy crisis without a recession emerged today as the principal theme of a seminar organized here by the Atlantic Institute.

title: Around the Nation
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, July 5 (UPI)  The last of several striking unions overwhelmingly approved a wage contract offer today, but one city official said that the new pact for municipal employees might force layoffs.

title: Coe Posts a World Record Of 1:42.4 in 800Meter Run
description: OSLO, July 5 (UPI)  Sebastian Coe of Britain today set a world record for the 800 meters with a time of 1 minute 42.9 seconds.

title: Walter Kerr Lessons From Shakespeare
description: WOULD that our playwrights had Shakespeare's gall! It occurs to me, of a sudden, that our writers never do learn anything from Shakespeare. It. doesn't even occur to them to try. Seeing a good production of one of his plays, they simply fall back in awe. The man was unique, inimitable, an excel) tion to all the rules, wasn't he? Seeing a bad production, they merely thank God that no one is required to write in iambic pentameter any longer. Either way, they certainly don't say to themselves, Hey! There's a dandy little device! I could use that. When they go to a play written by one of their contemporaries, they may very well be tempted to steal a trick here, transform a gimmick there. Borrowing from competitors goes on all the time. But Shakespeare is sui generis as well as satisfactorily dead, and who could pluck anything profitable from the structural habits of 1601, anyway?

title: Bloomingdale's in Pact To Stress Chinese Goods
description: PEKING, July 5 - Bloomingdale's signed an agreement with China today to undertake a major promotion of Chinese textiles, jewelry and home furnishings in the United States in the fall of 1980.

title: Deaths

Survived by Husband Lydon E., two sons, Thomas C., and John F.. 3 three daughters, Eileen M., Virginia G., and Margaret A.. three brothers endow sister. Reposing Waterbury and Kelly Funeral Home, 45 South Highland Avenue, (Route 91 Ossining. as Friday 24, 79prn. Funeral Mass St. Theresa's Church, Briarcliff Men or, on Saturday at 10am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Ballet: Makarova Triumphs in Stuttgart's Eugene Onegin
description: NATALIA MAKAROVA once said she would like a ballet in which she could dance like a heroine In a Russian novel. She had her chance Wednesday night, as a guest artist in John Cranko's Eugene Onegin with the Stuttgart Ballet.

title: Diary Tells of a Woman's Starvation in Mountains
description: BUFFALO, Wyo., July 5 (UPI) Tammy Mathre was obsessed with the rugged high country of Wyoming and the solace it offered from a 20yearold's troubles. Now only scribblings left in a diary testify to her lingering death from exposure and starvation.

title: Giants Simms Signs for 4 Years
description: Phil Simms, the Giants firstround draft choice from Morehead (Ky.) State, signed a fouryear contract yesterday, making him the highest paid rookie in the team's history.

title: In Feminists Antipornography Drive, 42d Street Is the Target
description: Shyly, they slipped into the booths, dropped their coins into the slots and waited as the metal curtains ascended to reveal two young women dancing naked on a carousel. One of the dancers blinked. Ladies! she cried, pointing to the faces in the booths. One. .. two  three ladies!

title: Deaths
description: FAHLANDERBrynotf W. on July 4, 1979. Husband of the late Lenora. Father of Nancy Gaither of Stur bridge Mass. and Irene Glaccoeill of Valley Cottage N.Y. Grandfather of Irene and John Galiher and Michael and Kristin Glacopelli. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Friday 7.10PM. Service and Interment will be private.

title: Chief Justice on Coast Yields to Questioning By Investigating Panel
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 5  Chief Justice Rose Bird of the California Supreme Court gave the Commission on Judicial Performance written answers today to the questions that she refused to answer in testimony on Monday.

title: I.M.F. Chief Sees Bulge In Oil Debt
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, in a bleak assessment of global economic prospects, said today that the 60 percent increase in oil prices since December had created an unmanageable debt burden for some developing countries and would reduce living standards and economic growth worldwide.

title: Soviet Profits On Oil Exports Up
description: MOSCOW, July 5 (Reuters) The Soviet Union's earnings from oil exports increased to $15.2 billion last year from $14.4 billion in 1977, according to detailed foreign trade statistics.

title: Indonesians Offer Bali As Site for Discussions By Koreans and U.S.
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 5  President Suharto has agreed to play host to threeway talks between North and South Korea and the United States on the Indonesian island of Bali if the North Koreans decide to participate.

title: Restaurants
description: CONSIDERING rant, the expense, energy, hope and a anxiety involved in opening new restaurant, we always hold our breath when reviewing so chancy an undertaking, hoping that the final result will be worthy of the effort that went into it. Fortunately, all such efforts are rewarded at La Tulipe, a handsome, romantic and thoroughly pleasurable bistro that opened six weeks ago on West 13th Street in Greenwich Village.

title: Russians Buy More U.S. Corn
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)  The Soviet Union has bought an additional 375,000 metric tons of American corn for delivery this year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: The Culture Bus Way to Go
description: Milton Miller, a cheerful, rubicund New Zealander who became a chiropractor and settled in Los Angeles, was showing the sights of New York City to his father, Maurice, last Saturday. We've walked so much seeing your city that we got sore feet, said the younger Mr. Miller, settling happily into the padded seat. His father, nearly 80 years old and visiting the United States for the first time, leaned his head forward to nod and smile. With a couple of hours free before dinner and show, they had boarded the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's Culture Bus Loop I at its Pennsylvania Station terminus and were enjoying the view, the airconditioning and the voice on the loudspeaker telling them that this was called the G.P.O. District, for the General Post Office, the city's largest mail depot.

title: Ampco Offers $38 For Forgings Shares
description: PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP)  The AmpcoPittsburgh Corporation has agreed in principle to offer $38 per share for the outstanding common stock of the Pittsburgh Forgings Company.

title: .. . and Mall Merchants Lose Sales to Local Stores
description: LOS ANGELES, July 4  Before the gasoline crisis in May, the Lloyd Dennis family used to go to the sprawling 225store Del Amo shopping center in Torrance once a week. Now? We hardly go at all, said Mr. Dennis, an executive at the United California Bank in Los Angeles.

title: Health Dispute: Issues, Options Facing the City
description: When a pedestrian walks along 210th Street in the Bronx from Bainbridge Avenue, past the low, graceful, dark brick buildings of Montefiore Hospital, a large attractive, modern structure looms ahead. With its burnishedbrick exterior and concrete panels under the windows, it could house offices or be a residential tower or a modern adjunct to Montefiore.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: Movie programs and times are often subject to late changes by theater owners. It is best to check by phone.

description: THEATER OF THE OPEN EYE, a puppet and mime concert featuring Eric Bass Puppets. Friday at 7:33 P.M., and The World of Little Kasper, with Mr. Bass and a life site puppet, Friday at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M.. at the annual Queens Council on the Arts Sum. mar Diversions program. Snow White & the Seven Dwarfs by the Gingerbread Players & Jack, will be given on Wednesday, Thursday and next Friday, 11 AM. and 1 P.M.. all a) Queens Theater In the Park. Flushing Meadow Corona Park, Flushing, Queens. Free; donations accepted. For Information: 291.1100.

title: SyntheticFuel Plans Are Raising Environment and Cost Questions
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  As Carter Administration officials prepare a major program to develop synthetic fuels, high startup costs and possible threats to the environment are being called formidable obstacles by experts inside and outside the Government.

description: xsublectta to approval, record and Payable dates vnann:unced.

title: Cabaret: Swinging Nanette
description: FOR the last year or two, most of the presentations at Michael's Pub have been built around the work of a specific popular composer  Stephen Sondheim. Fats Waller and Arthur Schwartz, among others. This week, and through July 28, Gil Wiest, owner of Michael's Pub, has narrowed the focus to the songs by a composer for a single show  Vincent Youmans's No, No, Nanette.

title: KISSINGER TESTIMONY ON PACT IS DELAYED
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger will not testify on the strategic arms treaty until the fourth week of Senate hearings, a delay that may increase the drama and weight of his opinion, Congressional officials said today.

title: Mobile Film Unit in Bronx and Manhattan
description: The Fiimmobile, operated by the Department of Cultural Affairs and the Black Filmmaker Foundation, will make three stops around the city this weekend, bringing 18 short films about the city made by independent film makers. The films touch on. among other things. Times Square, a Brooklyn baker, cockroaches, the Cyclone roller coaster and a black film maker. Film makers represented include Red Grooms. Claudia Weill, Eliot Noyes Jr. and Roy Campanella Jr. All showings begin at 8:30 P.M., and viewers are asked to bring their own chairs.

title: TV Weekend Lessons for the Disco Dance Floor
description: ONCE again sports, the one major enclave of liveness in a season of reruns, dominates the schedule. AMong the more ambitious projects is NBC's coverage of the Wimbledon tennis tournament from a suburb of London. Beginning tomorrow morning at 9 the network will carry six consecutive hours of the event, including the first live telecast on a new** of. the men's singles final.

title: Partial Transplant Saves Girl's Leg
description: A 15yearold New Jersey girl's right leg was saved from amputation, her doctors said yesterday, by a rare microsurgery operation that was performed recently when she went to the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center for an unrelated condition.

title: The Piano Blues of Blind John Davis
description: Blind John Davis, who's at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street, tonight, tomorrow night and next Wednesday through July 14, was the preferred accompanist of the original Sonny Boy Williamson, Tampa Red and many other top blues stars of the 1930's. He became the first blues pianist to tour Europe when Big Bill Broonzy asked him to Make the trip in 1952. But he says he never made it to New York until now.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Dry Dock Savings Bank has named Rexford E. Tompkins, president and chief executive officer, to the additional post of chairman..

title: U.S. Agency Censures Oppenheimer
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  The Securities and Exchange Commission has censured Oppenheimer & Company, prominent Wall Street brokerage firm, for failing to supervise adequately consultant, Ira J. Hechler, who allegedly traded in at least seven stocks on the basis of inside information.

title: Canada Widens Trade Surplus
description: OTTAWA, July 5 (UPI) - Increased exports to the United States helped Canada increase its trade surplus in May to $216 million from $115 million in April, Statistics Canada reported today.

title: National Book Awards Replaced by New Plan
description: After 30 years, the National Book Awards have been supplanted by a new program, the American Book Awards, which will greatly Increase the number of categories in which prizes are given and broaden the base of participation in choosing the prizes. The new awards will be conducted unaer me auspices of the Association of American Publishers, the same group that administered the National Book Awards.

title: In the Suburbs, Gas Crisis Affects Family Life. ..
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y.There are four Shapiros  Edwin, a lawyer; Sandra, his artist wife; Sarah, a high school senior, and James, a junior at Trinity College  and three Shapiro cars, each with an oddnumbered license plate.

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzl
description: SAFETY IS MAIN FEATURE OF NEW CAR: David Umansky of the U.S. Department of Transportation demonstrating the pliability of a polyurethane fender as used on the research safety vehicle developed by Minicars Inc. The car, built under Transportation Department contract, was on display yesterday at City Hall.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Contrary to the old political saying, the current Supreme Court does not seem to have been following the election returns. If it had been. it would have known that in response to contemporary public opinion Congress and the state legislatures have been adopting sunshine laws against executive sessions, closed meetings and other forms of official secrecy.

title: Skylab's Reentry Date Now Viewed as July 11
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration now says Skylab's crash to earth Is most likely to occur next Wednesday, give or take two days.

title: U.S. Officials Dispute. Report on Tariff Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  Average tariff cuts in the women's and children's apparel sector will be 18.4 percent and will be staged over an eightyear period beginning Jan. 1, 1982, according to the Office of the Special Trade Representative and apparel industry and labor representatives.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Chrysler Raises Prices
description: DETROIT, July 5 (AP)  The Chrysler Corporation joined the other Big Three car manufacturers today in raising prices again. For Chrysler. it was the fourth Increase of the model year, including the rise when the models were introduced last fall.

title: Gone Fishing
description: In Michael Halberstam's recent political novel, The Wanting of Levine, a Presidential candidate figures out why he so likes fishing. No matter how disorderly the world, when one goes fishing everything focuses on the hook.

title: Army in Europe Has Family and Housing Problems
description: BAUMHOLDER, West Germany The United States Army in Europe is facing serious, and unanticipated, social problems: high rates of pregnancy among women soldiers and the financial and emotional difficulties afflicting the growing number of dependents living abroad.

title: U.S. BIDS VIETNAMESE FACE REFUGEE ISSUE
description: CANBERRA, Australia, July 5  The United States, together with Australia and New Zealand, formally declared today that Vietnam must take steps to resolve the problem of the outpouring of refugees at its source, and accused Hanoi of actions which disregard accepted norms of international behavior.

title: Events and Openings
description: THE FRISCO KID, directed by Robert AtdrIchl starring Gene Wilder and Harrison Ford: at the Cinema

title: The City
description: The leaders of 73 homeowners groups have called for an additional fivetosevenyear moratorium in implementing a new state propertyas. sessment plan that they say could triple taxes on private homes in the city by 1981.

title: Menendez Hired by Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 5 (AP)  Al Menendez, an assistant coach with the Detroit Pistons for the last two seasons, was hired today to head the scouting department of the New Jersey Nets.

title: DirectMail Fund Drive Is Begun To Draft Kennedy for Race in 80
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)  With the backing of a Democratic labor leader, a nationwide directmail fundraising campaign is being organized to draft Senator Edward M. Kennedy for President.

title: On Location With Christopher Reeve
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich. THE lilacs are everywhere and they grow on bushes as tall as trees. The blossoms make an unexpected carpet for Christopher Reeve as he trails Jane Seymour and Christopher Plummer through the pale twilight of 1912. How intelligent, a member of Universal's **Somewhere in Time crew says as she watches the actors, to have so many lilacs in town with so much horse manure.

title: Naturalization Fees Raised
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)  The Immigration and Naturalization Service announced today that it was increasing some of its fees by $5 to raise an additional $7 million a year to cover handling costs. Some of the new rates are the application fee for an Alien Registration Receipt Card, up to $15 from $10; application for status as permanent resident, up to $30 from $25, and an application for a certificate of citizenship, up to $15 from $10.

title: The New York Times /John Sotomayor
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 5  Two bills laying the groundwork for more than $1 billion in potential railroad and highway improvements were signed into law here today by Governor Carey.

title: Heating Oil, Gasoline Stocks Up
description: Oil refiners substantially increased their inventories of both heating oil and gasoline last week - a highly unusual occurrence for this time of year according to statistics released yesterday afternoon by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Berkey Photo Inc. said that it would appeal to the Supreme Court last month's decision by the United States Court of Appeals that set aside all but $990,000 of the $87 million thatcit was awarded in its antitrust case against the Eastman Kodak Comany.

title: KOCH AIDE OPPOSES U.S. GAS ALLOCATION
description: The Koch administration contended yesterday that the gasoline shortage in New York City had beezi aggravated by a Federal formula:. favoring  so..calied growth are by blas in operating practices involving jobbers, the Spot market and inventories.

title: Food Kills 8 South Africans
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 5 (Reuters)  Eight boys died after attending a barbecue to celebrate the end of a tribal initiation ceremony, the police said today.

title: Some Physicists Believe the Sun Is Now Shrinking 0.1% a Century
description: The sun may be in a period of decline. A number of physicists believe that its nuclear fires may be burning low and that it is slowly shrinking. The most recent report suggests that the sun has been dwindling for more than a century.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Low clouds cover most of the Northeast and a band of clouds stretchs from the Tennessee Valley to the the Northern and Central Plains States. An area of thunderstorms is visible over southern Florida while another is apparent along the Texas Gulf coast.

title: Critics Say State Is Lax In Policing Auto Repairs
description: Last Aug. 22, Thomas Fleming, an independent trucker from Queens, called the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles with a complaint. He had paid garage $1,800 for repairs to his van, he said, and it was still stalline.

title: The Shortage Game
description: WASHINGTON  The trend of oil prices from 1979 to late 1978 was enough to make any selfrespecting oilcompany chairman or OPEC oil minister furious. For five years, the price of oil remained fairly stable, while the price of nearly everything else went up. Indeed, inflation eroded tne real price of oil by about 30 percent between 1974 and the start of the latest round of price increases. How long did we expect them to take that lying down?

title: Art: Sculptures of David Stromeyer at Staempfli
description: IT is not at all easy in the late 1970's to make a big steel sculpture that doesn't remind us of something that we've seen before. Those forthright readymade elements, those standard lengths that have been bent like India rubber, that halfdinosaur, half heavyindustry look - these are the international lingua franca of sculpture in the 1970's, just as Hiram Powers's Greek Slave was in the lingua franca of the 1850's.

title: C.I.T. and RCA Reveal Discussions on Merger
description: The C.I.T. Financial Corporation and the RCA Corporation announced jointly yesterday that they were conducting merger negotiations.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Many fear that the high cost of television campaigning has magnified the influence of single issue or special interest groups, who alone can supply candidates with enough money to meet these costs. They propose public financing of Congressional campaigns and further regulation of special interest campaign contributions, especially of corporatesponsored political action committees, to curb this perceived subversion of the democratic process.

title: Advertising
description: NEWSWEEK INC. is planning a regional spectatorsports magazine called Inside Sports that will be the first new magazine it has tried since it came into being as a newsweekly 46 years ago.

title: United Press International
description: LEFT FOR DEAD: Linda Mahan was strapped into a litter by Sonoma County Sheriff's deputies, who rescued her from the edge of a cliff near California's Bodega Bay. Mrs. Mahan, who owns a Jewelry store with her husband in San Francisco, said she was robbed of $200,000 in gems, kidnapped, choked, hit on the head with a rock; then thrown from a 70foot cliff.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Auctions
description: THE Impressionist and modern art sales held by Christie, Manson & Woods and Sotheby Parke Bernet in London this week toppled one record after another. The sale at Christie's of Henri Matisse's Le Jeune Marin (The Young Sailor) for $1.5 million last Tuesday, rewrote the auction record for 20thcentury art and set a new high for any painting other than an old master. On Wednesday at Sotheby's; Pierre Auguste Renoir's Le Pecheur a la Ligne (The Fisherman) sold for $1.3 million, one of the highest prices ever paid for a Renoir but less than the record price of $1.5 million paid by the industrialist Norton Simon in 1968 for the French Impressionist's Le Pont des Arts.

title: New Face: Roxanne Hart Coming of Age in Loose Ends
description: TO her own amazement, Roxanne Hart is starring in a Broadway play - almost despite herself. When she went to auattions, sne says sheepishly, she would often hand people her resume accompanied by profuse apologies for how few and slight her credits were. It's real hard to have to sell yourself, she explains with a sigh.

title: Books of The Times
description: ROBERT JUNGK'S The New Tyranny: How Nuclear Power Enslaves Us is a passionate indictment of the international nuclear industry by a German historian and journalist. So over whetrning a case does it seem to make against atomic power that if one took it at face value, one would be in favor of closing down every last nuclear facility in the world no later than tomorrow. What's more, it was originally written (in German) in 1977 - long before the Nuclear Regulatory Commission shut down five nuclear plants in the Eastern United States in March 1979 over questions about their safety during earthquakes; long before the film The China Syndrome began shocking American audiences that same month; and long before the incident at Three Mile Island seemed uncannily to bear out the predictions of The China Syndrome only a short time after the film's release (although Samuel McCracken, in az article in the June issue of Commentary, argues persuasively that The China Syndrome plays rather fast and lose with reality, and that in fact what happened at Three Mile Island bore almost no resemblance at all to the film).

title: Rails Regain Food Shipments
description: LOS ANGELES, July 5  In the 1990's, 90 percent of the nation's food moved coast to coast by rail. By the end of last year, however, that figure had dropped to less than 10 percent.

title: State Accuses A.M.A. of Boycotting Chiropractors
description: Xrays of a patient. In some cases, chiropractors are prevented from seeing the results of previous Xray examinations, according to the Attorney General. The suit says that in 1963 the medical association established a Committee on Quackery, which at all times has had as its prime mission the containment of chiropractic.

title: Broadway
description: THE INTERVIEW, starring, or at least costarring, Gordon Chater, is supposed to open on Broadway in October.
