Mr. Chater, who is British, made his New York debut last April in The Elocution of Benjamin, and got fine reviews. The play. however, did not, and it closed after 24 performances. In The Interview, which is by Thom Thomas, Mr. Chater will play a celebrated novelist, living reclusively and mysteriously in Rome, who agrees to be interviewed by an eager reporter. Keir Dullea was to play the eager reporter; he may still play him, but he must find his way around a movie commitment first. Meanwhile, whatever happens must happen soon. The Interview will try out at the Academy Festival Theater in Lake Forest, Ill., at the end of August.

title: BUDGETCURB PLAN SEEN HALTED FOR 79
description: WASHINGTON, July 5  The drive to mandate a balanced Federal budget by an amendment to the Constitution appears to have failed for this year, but the issue goes marching on.

title: Article 7 -- No Title
description: Leonard Silk is on vacation.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The unexplained cancellation of President Carter's energy speech sent the dollar lower against most currencies on major world markets yesterday, while the price of gold moved to record highs of almost $288 an ounce.

title: At the Movies
description: WHO'S that fellow peeking out from behind the reddishblond beard and mustache? Seen him somewhere before. Well over 6 feet tall. broadshouldered, bit of a swagger in his walk. Wears a dark blue doublebreasted blazer that fits him like paper on a wall, dark gray trousers, bespoke shoes, immaculate linen, a Guards redandblue striped cravat.

title: Crafts Are the Fare at Lincoln Center
description: There's a big show on at Lincoln Center this weekend and you don't need tickets to attend. It is the third annual American Crafts Festival, which has transformed the outdoor plaza at Broadway and 65th Street into a bazaar set for tomorrow and Sunday from II A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: Isle of Man Marks Millenium Of Its Parliament With Style
description: ST. JOHN'S, Isle of Man, July 5  At least a thousand years ago, a hundred years before the Battle of Hastings, the intrepid Vikings who settled this island in the Irish Sea gathered on an ancient burial mound to establish a parliament.

title: Strauss Offers MideastTalk Plan
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 5  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special ambassador, suggested to Israeli and Egyptian negotiators today that they form working groups on specific issues of Palestinian selfrule as a way to break a negotiating stalemate.

title: Architecture: The Buildings of Staten Island a History of Growth
description: WHEN one of New York City's four outer boroughs puts on an exhibition of art, sculpture or architecture, there is sometimes a provincial air to it. We've got art, too, these exhibitions often seem to shout as their only reason for being.

title: Bluefish and Weakfish Are Plentiful Off Jersey
description: AREA A  Charter boats have been loading up With bluefish from 10 to 14 pounds about five miles offshore, according to Capt. Andy's Marina at Margate, N.J., and blues of a pound or a pound and a half are plentiful inshore. Large weakfish are also in ocean waters near Avalon Shoals and are being taken on bucktail jigs. Both weakfish and striped bass occasionally are being caught (the latter on live menhaden) from area bridges at night, and there is good angling for small fluke in Margate Bay. Lighthouse Marina at Bamegat, N.J., reports plenty of small fluke in Barnegat Bay and some fairly good angling for them along the outer beaches. Cut squid, silversides and sand eels are the baits most commonly used. Large bluefish art being caught over Barnegat ridge, both chumming and trolling, and small blties are along the beach.

title: Alexander Frances, 66, President Of Frances &
description: Alexander Frances, president of the Frances & Evans Advertising Agency, died yesterday. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter's cancellation of his energy address set off broad political and financial repercussions. Alerted that the dollar was plunging on foreignexchange markets, Mr. Carter reaffirmed that he would propose strong measures to curb oil imports. He also summoned Vice President Mondale and his domestic policy adviser, Stuart E. Eizenstat, to discuss energy strategy. [Page A1.] High Administration officials ascribed the abrupt, and politically costly, cancellation to the President's indecision about how bold and politically risky a program to proclaim from the policy options given him. [A1.]

title: A Summer Guide to Enjoying the City's Gardens
description: There's nothing like leafy trees, cool grass and summer's flowers to help sooth the spirit and beat the heat, and they are just a subway token or bus ride away.

title: Brewers Beat Yanks On a TwoHitter, 30
description: Of course, Lary Sorensen knew he was hurling a nohitter against the New York Yankees in the eighth inning yesterday. I knew it,': he said later, until they got their first hit.

title: Fires Strike Alberta OilSands Plants
description: CALGARY, Alberta, July 5  Fires struck both synthetic crude oil production facilities operating op the oil sands of northeastern Alberta this week.

title: Gas Lines Draw Plaint By a Man From OPEC
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 5 Iraq, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, swallowed its diplomatic pride here today and complained about the gasoline pinch in New York City. Diplomats, an Iraqi spokesman complained, have no immunity from the long lines at the servicestation pumps.

title: Radio
description: 74 A.M., WNCN. Beatrice and Benedict, Overture; Berlioz; Sonata in D for Flute and Guitar, Scheidler Album for the Young, Nos. 28, I, 15, 5, Schumann; Name Day, Overture, Beethoven.

title: Art People
description: THE 21 Club is a New York institution, if ever there was one, but is not a place that we associate primarily with art. Walter Pater, for instance, would not have found in it a home away from home. The shy, the retiring and the studious are in a minority among its patrons. The College Art Journal is rarely seen in the lobby. And if you can't tell Fuppo from Foppa when you go round an Italian picture gallery, it won't get you in bad with the maitre d'htel at 21': he'll treat you just like everyone else.

title: FixedIncome Securities Ease
description: Prices of most fixedincome securities declined slightly yesterday on unusually light trading activity as the credit markets continued to shuffle through the Fourth of July week. The taxexempt bond market, however, held firm, and The Bond Buyer Index of yields on state and city bonds moved down to its lowest level in eight months.

title: A Carfree Guide To Pleasures and Places In the ThreeState Area
description: The gas lines may not be so painful as they have been lately, and there may be more stations open this weekend in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. But people are getting used to the idea that the future will be a lot different from past years of &leap, easytoobtain fuel. What follows is a guide to the pleasures and places reachable in the region without a car. It is intended not only as a compendium pf possibilities this weekend, but also to provide some suggestions for the summer ahead.

title: New Inspections May Get DC10's in Service Again
description: In a move aimed at clearing the way for resumption of DC10 flights in the United States next week, the Federal Aviation Administration yesterday ordered the most thorough inspections vet of the airliners underwine nylons.

title: Nelson and Devlin Share Western Open Golf Lead
description: OAK BROOK, Ill., July 6 (AP) Larry Nelson shot a 69 and 41yearold Bruce Devlin of Australia posted a 71 today to share the secondround lead at 190, four under par, in the $300,000 Western open golf tournament.

title: Publisher in Colorado Sells His Paper, Then Shares Proceeds With Staff
description: DENVER, July 6  The journalists grapevine in Colorado started picking up odd rumors this week about colleagues in Grand Junrtinn coming into sudden wealth.

title: JOBLESS RATE FALLS TO 5.6%, THE LOWEST SINCE SUMMER OF 74
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  Despite the fuel shortage and widening forecasts of recession, employment rose sharply in June and the unemployment rate dipped to its lowest point since the summer of 1979, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Refugee Parley Set for Geneva Seen as Turning Point
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 6 Authoritative American and other Western officials and Southeast Asian foreign ministers interviewed over the last week regard the coming Geneva conference on Indochinese refugees as milestone, whether it succeeds or fails, in the continuing crisis over the outflow of more refugees than countries want to accept. sources CIOSe io secretary or Mate Cyrus R. Vance, who headed the American delegations at regional conferences this week in Bali, Indonesia, and Canberra, Australia, said that Mr. Vance or Vice President Mondale would represent the United States in the meeting. The session is scheduled for July 20 and 21, with Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations presiding.

title: Quake Kills African Gold Miners
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 6 (AP)  An earthquake caused rock falls in a Johannesburg gold mine today that killed 2 miners and injured 11. Two others were missing.

title: Satellite Use in Cable TV Stirs Dispute
description: WTCGTV in Atlanta and KTTV in Los Angeles are superstations. Once ordinary local television stations, they now reach national audiences because their transmissions are being distributed by satellite to cabletelevision systems around the country. As a result, they have the potential to reach millions of viewers instead of mere thousands.

title: Entertainment Events
description: DR. PEPPER CENTRAL PARK MUSIC FESTIVAL: JUDY COLLINS, singer. Wollman Skating Rink Theater, Central Park, Fifth Aver,ue and 59th Street, 6:30.

title: Cleveland Again Averts Default, Risking Litigation
description: CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP)  The city avoided another default today but risked being held in contempt of court.

title: The City
description: A New York City police officer was killed by a subway train in Brooklyn yesterday in what the police said was an apparent suicide.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: Brat

title: News Summary
description: The resignation of Nicaragua's leader appears imminent. The new United States Ambassador in Managua, Lawrence A. Pezzullo, reportedly told a Nicaraguan business leader that President Anastasio Somoza Debayle's resignation was very, very close. Ambassador Pezzullo has been involved in the efforts to persuade General Somoza to step down. [Page I, Columns 56.]

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE LEGEND LIVES About quarter of a mile up  on the 107th floor of One World Trade Center  in the Hors d'Oeuverie, part of the Windows on the World restaurant complex, Joe Albany is playing the piano.

title: Bomb in Jerusalem Injures 3
description: JERUSALEM, July 6  Three French tourists were injured when a bomb exploded in a grove near the United Nations offices in East Jerusalem this afternoon. The three, two women and a man, who were part of a travel group, were taken to a hospital. One of them wa.. released after treatment. The police opened In inquiry.

title: Hot Lines for Data On 195 Gas Supplies
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  Following are telephone numbers for gasoline information along Interstate 95 from Massachussetts to Florida. The commercial sources often have a more comprehensive and uptodate report than state agencies. Phone lines open seven days a week are in darker type. Those open only weekdays are in lighter type. (800) calls are tollfree.

title: Decorated ExPoliceman Jailed for Attempted Murder
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 6 (UPI)  A judge, acting with what he described as a heavy heart, today sentenced a muchdecorated former New York City policeman, John Spurdis, to 8 to 16 years in prison for the attempted murder of a pharmacist in Yonkers last August.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES San Diego 6, Mets 5 (12 inn.,n.). Cincinnati 2, Pittsburgh 1 (n.). Houston 4, Chicago 2.

title: Veto Fight a New Peril for Brown
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 5  California's struggle to overcome the the loss of revenue from last year's mandatory property tax cut has led to a second legislative overriding of a veto by Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.

title: Bridge:
description: Selecting the unluckiest tournament player in New York would be a difficult task, for there would be many claimants offering hands in evidence.

title: English Girls Have Their Eton, Too
description: BRIGHTON, England  When a young woman was convicted in London a few years ago of peddling heroin, the judge remarked sorrowfully on the heights from which she had fallen. You, he said weightily, were a Roedean girl !

title: John Dahlquist, Bank President; Was Active Many Years in YMCA
description: John M. Dahlquist, president of the Staten Island Savings Bank and an active YMCA official for many years, died Wednesday of a heart attack at Staten Island Hospital. Mr. Dahlquist, who lived in Westerleigh, S.I., was 66 years old.

title: U.S. Puts Off Jet Sale To Egypt After Saudis Delay on Paying Costs
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  State Department officials, noting that Saudi Arabia had delayed paying for 50 American F5E fighter planes ordered for Egypt, said today that the projected sale had been postponed.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 41.

title: Two Air Force Fliers Killed
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 6 (AP)  The two crewmen aboard an F111A fighter were killed when the swingwing jet crashed while on a training mission at the sprawling Nellis Range, the Air Force announced today. The victims were identified as Capt. Gary Mekash, 33 years old, of Green Bush, Minn., the pilot, and Lieut. Col. Eugene Soeder, 90, of Euclid, Ohio the weapons system operator.

title: Mayor Declines To Back Bonds For Transit Use
description: Mayor Koch declined yesterday to support the $500 million transportationimprovement bond issue that will be submitted to New York state voters in November until I find out what the projects are and what percentage the 1 City of New York will receive.

title: T. Harry Williams, Scholar, Dies; Huey Long Book Won a Pulitzer
description: Prof. T. Harry Williams, one of the nation's foremost scholars on Civil War political and military history, died early yesterday at Our Lady of the Lake Medical Center in Baton Rouge, La. Dr. Williams, who won the 1970 Pulitzer Prize for an exhaustive biography of Huey Long of Louisiana, was 70 years old.

title: For Joggers and Muggers, the Trendy Sneaker
description: Sneakers are out of control. The pleasantly homely canvas shoe has traveled off into the sunset or a Norman Rockwell painting over the handlebars of some kid with freckles and flaming red hair. Around us now are the mutants, sneakers in strange colors and bizarre shapes. Lock down. Silk and fiberglass spaceshoes with treads curling up over the toe and heel, rubber studs staring at the sky for no earthly purpose.

title: Gonzalez Stops Oguma And Keeps W.B.A. Title
description: UTSUNOMIYA, Japan, July 6 (AP)  Betulio Gonzalez of Venezuela knocked out Shoji Oguma of Japan in the 12th round today to retain his World Boxing Association flyweight crown.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Yale Crews Continue Advances at Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, July 6  On another bright sunny day for the second round of the Henley Royal Regatta, crews from Yale University provided the brightest spot today for United States competitors.

title: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI
description: Clear Mee are evident over the North and Middle Atlantic States while partly cloudy skies cover New England, the South Atlantic States, the lower Mississippi Valley, the Plains States, the Rockies, the Texas Panhandle, the plateau region, the Cascades, intermountain region and the Pacific Northwest.

title: Federal Judge Disallows Maryland's Plea for Gas
description: BALTIMORE, July 6 (UPI) Federal district judge today denied Maryland's request for additional gasoline as well as the state's request that the entire Federal gasoline allocation system be revamped, saying that that could result in chaos.

title: Television
description: 6: 00(4)Agriculture U.S.A. (5)Pattern for Living

title: For Turks on the Frontier, Greece Is Less Than Threat
description: ILDIRI, Turkey  The small finger of land on the Aegean coast containing the village of Ildiri has been occupied for at least 28 centuries under its ancient name of Erythrai. It was written about by Aristotle and Pliny and liberated from the Persians by Alexander the Great, and it boasted one of the most famous oracles of the ancient world.

title: Two Representatives Find Voters at Home More Resigned Than Angry in Gas Crisis
description: LINWOOD, Pa., July 6  For more than an hour, Ron Nickle stood unobtrusively near the back of the small, dirtygreen union hall here, his arms crossed over his lowslung stomach and his florid face growing increasingly dour.

title: China Air Rights Sought
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 6, (Reuters) Northwest Airlines said today that it was seeking Government permission to resume flights to China after 30 years. Northwest said that it had served China from July 1947 until May 1949, when the Communists took over the mainland.

title: Two Candidates Claim the Lead in Bolivia Election
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 5  The outcome of last Sunday's presidential elections is in confusion with the official returns lagging far behind the unofficial count and two of the eight candidates claiming they are headed for victory.

title: SULFUR DIOXIDE HAZE ON A JUPITER MOON
description: PASADENA, CALIF., July 6 Scientists with the Voyager project reported today the discovery of an extremely tenuous sulfur dioxide atmosphere on Io, one of Jupiter's major satellites. The atmosphere is undoubtedly fed by lo's erupting volcanos.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: 1. In a 5to4 decision, the Supreme Court gave judges wide discretion to order courtrooms closed to the press and public in pretrial hearings. In another ruling, the Court upheld sweeping Federal busing orders in Dayton and Columbus, Ohio. In the third decision, the Court struck down, 8 to 1, a Massachusetts law requiring unmarried minors to obtain parental or judicial approval before undergoing a legal abortion.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN DIEGO, July 8 (AP)  The United States Border Patrol says it is catching illegal Mexican aliens in record numbers, almost 1,600 a day, through a combination of more agents and a crackdown on smugglers.

title: The Region
description: MONTAUK L.I. (AP)  Five passengers of a sailboat drifting in the Atlantic Ocean were saved yesterday after a twoday rescue effort, Coast Guard officials said.

title: 6 Foreign Banks Approved in Spain
description: MADRID, July 6 (Reuters) The Government has given six foreign banks permission to begin fullscale operations in Spain, a Cabinet statement said today.

title: Sports Today
description: Highlights of Wednesday's Firecracker 400 stock car race, at Daytona (Fla.) Interns. bona! Speedway. In another segment the International cliff diving championships, at Acapulco, Mexico, will also be presented. (TelevisionChannel 7, 5 P.M.)

title: A Tenant Reform Becomes Untenable
description: In 1975, New York State legislators realized what was already obvious to anyone who had ever rented an apartment in New York  that the standard lease asked too much of the tenant and too little of the landlord. So they passed a bill that was supposed to even the balance. Now a court has interpreted the revised law in such a way that landlords may be asked to shoulder an unreasonable and even absurd burden. The law has tilted too far, and it needs to go back to the Legislature for rebalancing.

title: Jews Who Survived Nazis Return To Berlin for Visits as City Guests
description: WEST BERLIN, July 6  Inge Deutschkron, now an Israeli, had a tearful reunion with the Berlin woman who hid her in a back room and saved her life. Ruth Abraham, a New Yorker, wept when she saw the house where the Nazi secret police arrested her sister before sending her to her death in a gas chamber.

title: Letter: On Curbing Gas Guzzlers
description: In response to your recent editorial on automobile economy standards mandated for 1985, the order from Congress to the automobile industry to improve fuel efficiency to 27.5 miles per gallon was based on the assumption that the standards could be met through technological development alone. We believe this assumption to be incorrect.

title: Yanks Sweep
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 6  Tommy John and Ron Davis, the team's best starting and relieving pitchers, added to their impressive victory totals tonight in the Yankees sweep of a doubleheader from the hapless Oakland A's.

title: New Arab League, Old Rifts
description: TUNIS, July 2  At a time when militant Arab countries appear to be advancing their uncertain confrontation with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, Tunisia has been given an important role in findine a compromise acceptable to the divided Arab world. When Arab. foreign ministers met in Baghdad in March and decided, in protest against the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty, to move me Arab League headquarters from Cairo to thi! agreeable Mediterranean city, in trutlthere was nowhere else.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The oil and gas operations of the General Crude Oil Company, a subsidiary of the International Paper Company, were sold to the Mobil Corporation yesterday for about $800 million.

title: Takeovers Reviewed
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  The Senate Banking Committee has quietly begun a comprehensive review of the nation's corporate takeover laws to determine whether investors and shareholders are being adequately protected during mergers and acquisitions.

title: New York Futures Exchange Hires Chicago Options Official
description: William M. Smith, the 35yearold president and chief operating officer of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, yesterday was named president and chief executive officer of the New York Futures Exchange, the commodities subsidiary recently created by the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Vicente Llorens, 73, a Professor And Expert on Spanish Literature
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 6 Vicente Llorens, professor emeritus of Romance languages and literatures at Princeton University, died Thursday in Valencia, Spain, after a brief illness. He was 73 years old and lived here.

title: Ballet: Nureyev, Canadians
description: There isn't much room for interpretative leeway in the title role of The Sleeping Beauty. The ballerina who dances Aurora must be able to draw upon considerable technique. But withoit that CleViy racuance tnat personifies the classic's awakening motif, there is no real Aurora and, ultimately, no ballet, although the Rudolf Nureyev version now being performed at the New York State Theater by the National Ballet of Canada does give the prince a good deal more to do than kissing Aurora awake, and then flipping her into a fish dive or two.

title: Consumer Borrowing At a Peak
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) American consumers borrowed a record $28 billion in May, but they also paid off a record $24.3 billion in outstanding debt, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Late Gains in Stocks Lift Dow 10.41 to 846.16
description: The Dow Jones industrial average jumped by 10.41 points to 846.16 yesterday as investors responded to news that President Carter would meet with his top advisers and the governors of key states in an effort to solve the nation's energy problems. inc marKet also appeared to take confidence from Government reports that the country's unemployment rate had slipped to a fiveyear low of 5.6 percent in June and that wholesale prices had risen by only a modest fivetenths of 1 percent. Analysts said that increased institutional activity also helped.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Because of trashcollection problems in the aftermath of the tugboat strike, alternateside parking regulations will be in effect today in Manhattan and Brooklyn only. Beginning Monday, the regulations are to be in effect in all boroughs.

title: Stage: Deadly Delilah
description: Deadly Delilah is possibly of interest to students of the Late Late Show, but almost certainly to no one else. It is, heaven help us, a parody of old Humphrey Bogart movies, with bits and pieces of other movies dropped in as well, and while Christopher Durang very nearly pulled off something like this on Broadway with A History of the American Film, he was a serious author, with a comic sense, too. Raleigh Bond, the author of Deadly Delilah, simply wants to show us he has been to the movies.

title: Key Testimony To Be Allowed In Murder Trial
description: MIAMI, July 6 (AP)  Jurors deciding whether Theodore R. Bundy killed two sorority sisters will be allowed to hear testimony from an art student who has sworn that she saw him run, club in hand, from the murder scene, a judge ruled today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, July 6,1979

title: NASA's Rough Estimate on Skylab Puts Entry Wednesday Across U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  Space agency officials estimated today that Skylab would reenter the earth's atmosphere on Wednesday, about 3 P.M. Eastern daylight time, along a path that could spread debris across the continental United States and on into the Amazon jungle.

title: Driver Held in Death of Fetus
description: LAGRANGE, Ga., July 6 (AP)  A Troup County man has been charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of a 7month fetus in a traffic accident, the authorities said. The suspect was identified as Mitchell Lee Griggs, 23 years old.

title: Elizabeth Ryan, 87, Tennis Star Who Won 19 VVimbledon Titles
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 6 Elizabeth Ryan, whose record total of 19 Wimbledon tennis titles can be eclipsed tomorrow, collapsed on the grounds of the AllEngland Lawn Tennis Club today and died a short while later at St. George's Hospital. She was 87 years old.

title: Chlorine Gas Kills One, Hurts 18
description: ALTON, Ill., July 6 (UPI)  One man was killed last night and 18 other employees were overcome by deadly chlorine gas leaking from a tank at an aluminum recycling plant. William Dempsey, 45 years old, of Lake St. Louis, Mo., was pronounced dead after the accident atthe recycling plant of the Federal Metallurgical Division; U.S. Reduction Company.

title: Police Hunt 6th Suspect in Kidnapping
description: A sixth suspect was being sought by the police yesterday in the kidnapping earlier this week of a Brooklyn woman, her 6yearold daughter and a family friend.

title: Growth of Privacy Laws Complicating Press Problems on Keeping the Public Informed
description: Should news organizations disclose the fact that a public official is having an extramarital affair? Or that the official is an alcoholic?

title: Music Festivals Abound In the Rocky Mountains
description: DENVER  Not only are the hills alive with the sound of music, the whole darn mountain range is ringing with it these days. You can't get to a rodeo in the Rockies any more without tripping over a music festival. The joint is lousy with string quartets.

title: Judge Prohibits Spray to Fight Grasshoppers
description: PIERRE, S.D., July 6 (AP)  A Federal district judge ruled today that ranchers must temporarily stop using the chemical toxaphene to combat an infestation of grasshoppers.

title: Unemployment in City Rose From 8% to 10% in June
description: The unemployment rate in New York City rose to 10 percent last month from 8 percent in May, the largest monthly increase of the 1970's, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: A.&P. Adds 50 Discount Food Units
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 6  The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company will open 50 limitedassortment discount food stores, mostly within the New York, New Jersey area, stockholders were told at the company's annual meeting here today.

title: In Peking, FoodRation Cards Are Selling Briskly
description: PEKING, July 6  Early each morning, a long line forms outside a small shop near the Peking Hotel for a popular northern Chinese breakfast  yu tiao and dou jiang, or fried crullers and bean curd milk.

title: United Press International
description: ARAFAT IN VIENNA FOR TALKS: Yasir Arafat, Palestine Liberation Organization's leader, being greeted airport in Vienna by Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria. Mr. Arafat will meet with Mr. Kreisky and Willy Brandt, former Chancellor of West Germany and head Socialist International, to discuss Mideast situation.

title: People in the Middle: Black Civilians in Rhodesian Conflict
description: GRAND REEF AIR BASE, Zimbabwe Rhodesia  Like many blacks, 16yearold Loinah Mafuya used to ask God in her nightly prayers to spare her from the war that Government troops and their guerrilla foes are waging in the tribal reserves, where twothirds of the 6.8 million blacks of Zimbabwe Rhodesia live.

title: Gas Lines Tell Our Story
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I.  Like the many roads in a system of highways, our paths crossed once again. We met at an intersection of our lives many years after we had last seen each other.

title: Gasoline Allocation System Changed Modestly
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  After promising a review of the controversial gasoline allocation system by today, the Department of Energy this afternoon made two small changes and said a further examination of the system would be completed by July 15.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, July 7

title: A Jailbreak by 5 in Orange County Resembles Plot of Alcatraz Movie
description: Five inmates  three convicted of robbery or burglary and two facing robbery charges  broke out of the Orange County Jail in Goshen, N.Y., late Thursday night or early yesterday.

title: Woman Once Raped by Burglars Dies in Fleeing Second Burglary
description: A 19yearold woman who had been raped by armed intruders six weeks ago jumped to her death from a window in her secondfloor apartment in Queens yesterday while two armed burglars held a male roommate captive in the next room, the police said.

title: The New York Times/Barton Silverman
description: SETS WORLD RECORD: Jesse Vassallo celebrating his triumph in 200meter individual medley yesterday at Pan American Games. Story, page 13.SAN JUAN, P.R., July 6  The fans cheered, chanted Jessee, Jessee and waved miniature Puerto Rican flags. When Jesse Vassallo and his mother embraced on the deck of the E1 Escambron Pool, another rousing ovation was touched off.

title: New York City Is Countersued By Makers of 754 Subway Cars
description: Pullman Inc. and the Rockwell International Corporation, which New York City has accused of selling it defective subway equipment, filed counterclaims yesterday against the city and the Transit Authority, seeking more than $146 million in damaees.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in some copies of Metropolitan Report yesterday stated incorrectly that Governor Carey was accompanied to White Plains by Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive. The Governor was with Harold L. Fisher, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Your Money
description: ONE young New York City renter who has been scanning the real estate listings for a cooperative apartment for more than a year explained recently that he was waiting for prices come down because of a recession and energy problems. He might as well be waiting for Godot.

title: Some of the Skylab Fallout Is on the Light Side
description: Etta Klein said she was buying one of the white plastic construction helmets marked Official Skylab Protection Unit No. 23 because It's a cute idea and my grandson will love it.

title: Van McCoy, Composed The Hustle, Hit in 75
description: Van McCoy, who helped pioneer the disco craze with his 1975 hit song, The Hustle, died yesterday morning of cardiac arrest in Englewood, N.J., after entering Englewood Hospital a week earlier. He was 38 years old.

title: Avon Adjusts Asia Sales For Different Cultures
description: MANILA  The Avon lady, a familiar figure in America and Europe, is developing markets in Asia, traveling by pedicab in Hong Kong, by minibus in Manila and Kuala Lumpur, or by boat along Bangkok's klongs (canals).

title: ARCHIBALD F. GLOVER
description: Archibald F. Glover, trustee emeritus of St. Francis College and a former project engineer of Silas MasonMason Hangar Company Inc., died Tuesday while vacationing in the Virgin Islands. He was 76 years old.

title: Gulf Cutting Back Sales of Diesel Fuel
description: HOUSTON, July 6 (Reuters) The Gulf Oil Corporation said today that it was cutting back sales of homeheating oil and diesel fuel by 20 percent in July, August and September in order to concentrate on building up heatingoil inventories for the winter.

title: Cosmos, Stadium Crew Fight
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 6  Three maintenance men and one Cosmos player were injured today in a fight that broke out at Giants Stadium during the team's practice session. Immediately after the incident, the Cosmos left for a flight to Boston, where they play the New England Tea Men in a North American Soccer League game tomorrow at Foxboro Mass.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, July 6 (AP)  The ruling Christian Democratic Party will reportedly put forward a new candidate for Prime Minister following the rejection by both the Communists and Socialists of Giulio Andreotti's efforts to succeed himself as Prime Minister.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON ELECTRICAL energy created by solar cells and windmills can be stored chemically until it is needed to provide power. Richard Williams and Allen Bloom of RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J., will be granted Patent 9,160,816 for the process next week.

title: Producers Prices Rose 0.5% in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 Another decline in food prices last month helped offset soaring fuel costs and hold wholesale prices in June to a rise of fivetenths of 1 percent.

title: Court Bars Extradition Of Sindona
description: Michele Sindona, an Italian financier who once controlled the Franklin National Bank, won a court decision yesterday that bars his extradition to Italy.

title: Lines Shorten and Prices Stabilize, But Gasoline Warninks Continue
description: Most of the lines leading to gasoline pumps in the metropolitan area seem to have vanished, and prices have stabilized at about $1 a gallon, the New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Bruce C. Ratner, said yesterday. The price represents an increase of more than 20 percent in the last three months.

title: Coming of 78 Thermostats Has Many Owners Worried
description: The owners of many office buildings, restaurants, theaters and retail stores in the New York area say they would comply with a Presidential directive to keep the airconditioned temperatures in their buildings at 78 degrees  unless it gets too hot for business or comfort.

title: West Seen Losing Economic Weight
description: PARIS, July 6  The United States and its Western allies will see their economic weight in the world decline during the remainder of this century as a result of sluggish growth and the emergence of prosperous new industries in many poorer countries, including China and tne Soviet Union, according to a massive new study released today by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Elizabeth Ryan Dies
description: Elizabeth Ryan, who won 19 Wimbledon titles, collapsed at the tournament yesterday and died. She was 87 years old. An obituary appears on Page 24.

title: Somoza Orders Major Offensive; Resignation Termed Very Close
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 6 President Anastasio Somoza Debayle ordered a strong counteroffensive today against strategic guerrilla positions apparently in the hope of bolstering the National Guard before he steps down from office.

title: Books of The Times You Want to Meet the Poet
description: THE POEMS OF STANLEY KUNITZ, 19281978. 249 pages. An Atlantic Monthly Press Book. Little, Brown. $12.50.

title: Judson Laire, 76, Actor Of Stage, Screen and TV
description: Judson Laire, the actor who portrayed Papa in the popular 1950's television series I Remember Mama, died Thursday in Rhinebeck, N.Y. Mr. Laire, who had lived in the Dutchess County community of Clinton Corners, was 76 years old.

title: About New York Memoirs of a Man of Properties
description: A life in the theater doesn't always need words to sustain it. It can be lyricless, mostly blunt and tangible, but still be complete. Solly Pernick is busy backstage at the Plymouth Theatre eight shows a week with another hit on his hands after 65 years of life in the theatre. He is helping to fool people with his stage props, the same way he began in 1914 in the Bronx in his debut with the Cecil Spooner stock company.

title: Judge Rules Homosexual Group May Advertise on Capital Transit
description: WASHINGTON, rON. July 6 (AP)  A Federal district judge ruled today that Washington's mass transit system must accept bus advertising from a homosexual rights group because it had accepted advertising on other controversial subjects.

title: 10% to 15% Rise In Air Fares Likely
description: GENEVA, July 6 (UPI)  Airlines will probably be forced to increase international air fares by 10 to 15 percent because of the latest increase in oil prices, officials of the International Air Transport Association said today.

title: Biologists Lure Draws Salmon Back Up the Connecticut
description: WINDSOR, Conn.  The Atlantic salmon, which deserted the Connecticut River 200 years ago when man interfered with its life cycle by damming the route to its spawning grounds, is gradually returning to struggle upstream.

title: Call for Shooting Pesky Pigeons Just Won't Fly, Says the Mayor
description: Mayor Koch came out against shooting pigeons yesterday.

title: Jazz Piano: Ellis Marsalis Plays at Carnegie Taverti
description: While Ellis Larkins takes a twomonth vacation from the august Forster piano at the Carnegie Tavern, 56th Street at Seventh Avenue (this is an instrument that inevitably shares the billing with whoever plays it), Ellis Marsalis, a pianist from New Orleans, has taken his place at the keyboard, playittg Mondays to Fridays through Aug. 31.

title: Letters
description: It is problematic whether an ownerdriver is an independent small businessman, as the Times editorial of June 22 suggests.

title: PRESIDENT SUMMONS AIDES TO CAMP DAVID FOR A BROAD REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  President Carter canceled his weekend travel plans today and summoned selected aides, political advisers and eight Governors to Camp David for a wideranging review of domestic issues.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter summoned aides and governors from several states to Camp David for a wideranging review of domestic issues. The discussions, expected to continue well into next week, reportedly will go beyond energy and deal with inflation, unemployment and the economic projections for the rest of the year. [Page 1.]

title: Miss Navratilova Captures Second Title at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 6 Martina Navratilova, the Czechoslovak tennis star who defected to the United States four years ago, won her second consecutive title today in the women's singles of the Wimbledon Lawn Tennis Championships.

title: Firefighters Gaining Upper Hand In Weeklong Arizona Brush Blaze
description: PHOENIX, July 6 (AP)  Nearly 2,000 firefighters may have gained the upper hand in their weeklong battle to contain two brush fires that have charred 63,000 acres of forest land, the authorities said today.

title: Warning: Stay Out of the Sahara's Quicksand
description: WASHINGTON  For more than three years, the United States Government has quietly cooperated with the Moroccan Government to supply arms for Morocco's invasion and occupation of the Western Sahara, a mineralrich territory in northwest Africa. A1though obsecure to the Americam public, the growing conflict between Morocco and the guerrillas of the Saharan nationalist group, the Polisario Front, has long been a matter of concern in Europe, Africa, and the Middle East because of the danger that it will develop into a wider war between Morocco and Algeria (which has supported the Polisario Front).

title: CLAUDE C. WILLIAMS; ORGANIZED BLACKS
description: The Rev. Claude Clossee Williams, Presbyterian clergyman whose work in race relations and civil rights in both the North and the South spanned half century, died at the Veterans Hospital in Birmingham, Ala., on June 29. He was 84 years old..

title: Memphis Galled Lucky as Wind Fans Chemical Away During Fire
description: MEMPHIS, July 6 (AP)  A wind shift during a major chemical fire yesterday could have caused 10,000 casualties in downtown Memphis, a University of Tennessee toxicologist said today.

title: Prices of Futures Ease After Sharp Early Gains
description: Most commodity futures prices moderated yesterday following sharp gains on Thursday as traders reacted to President Carter's cancellation of his scheduled energy speech.

title: U.S. Skater Rolls Up a First
description: DORADO, P.R., July 6  It was a combination of the Boston Marathon and Rollerball, with race strategy, a heartbreak hill and some hot finishline tempers. Wheels melted in the 80degree heat. Spectators lined the streets and cheered, sirens sounded and athletes wrestled for a medal.

title: Blind Workers Ask Aid on Pay
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 6 (AP)  The 3,000 delegates to the convention of the National Federation of the Blind have called for an end to a Federal exemption that allows some employers to pay blind workers less than the minimum wage. The federation said yesterday that blind workers were sometimes paid as little as 58 cents an hour.

title: U.S. and China Expected To Sign Trade Accord
description: PEKING, July 6 (UPI) The United States and China will sign a trade agreement in Peking tomorrow despite the failure of negotiations between the two countries on limiting Chinese textile exports, American officials said today.

title: Burnham Carter, Writer And Publicist, Was 78
description: Burnham Carter, a shortstory writer and former partner in the Ivy Lee Public Relations concern, died yesterday at his home in Orford, N.H. He was 78 years old.

title: Padres Top Mets In 12.65
description: The Mets picked on someone their own size last night. But just because their opponents, the San Diego Padres, were farther behind first place (15 games in the West) than the Mets were (14 in the East), that did not make it any easier. It just took longer to lose, as the Padres tvon, 65, on Dave Winfield's 19th homer of the season in the top of the 12th inning.

title: OBSERVER
description: Now the golden rays of July burnish the verdant hillside and the croak of the trout vies with the mewling of the spotted sapsucker and the snarl of the nocturnal tomcat to remind us that nature is not to be trifled with.

title: ISRAEL AND EGYPT AVOID AGENDA SNAG
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 6 Egyptian and Israeli negotiators, acting on the suggestion of Robert S. Strauss, Washington's special representative for Middle East peace talks, agreed today to establish working groups on two of the most crucial and divisive issues.

title: Guerrillas in Zambia To Halt Border Raids During Queen's Visit
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, July 6 (AP) Black nationalist guerrillas announced today that they would suspend their attacks into Zimbabwe Rhodesia from Zambia during Queen Elizabeth's scheduled visit here for the Commonwealth conference late this month.

title: Kickbacks Witness Says He Never Knew Tatals
description: CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP)  The prosecution's star witness in Cleveland's kickbacks trial testified today that he never knew how much money he had turned over to City Council President George L. Forbes.

title: Eiratits
description: BLANKRobert. Beloved husband of Adele. Devoted father of Cecile Jordan, Judith Block and Stephen. Adored grandfather of Philip and Ruth Jordan, Debra, Nancy and Gail Block, Cheryl and Lisa Blank. Loving father in law of Robert B. Block and Marsha J. Blank. Brother of Elizabeth Blank, Morris Blank, Regina Olshwang. Services Sunday July 8th, 11AM at The Riverside 76th St & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions to your favorite charity.

title: Battle Over Synthetic Fuels
description: As the Carter Administration seeks to decide on a plan for production of synthetic fuel and to determine its scope, the most conspicuous opposition has been that of the environmental community. At first glance this seems paradoxical.

title: Queens Jeweler Slain in Robbery
description: The owner of a Queens jewelry shop was shot fatally by two teenage robbers last night, the police said. Mario Pinagas, 38 years old, the owner of the Santa Fe Jewelry Shop, at 9303 37th Avenue, was shot in the throat about 8 P.M. The police said they had not immediately determined what was taken from the shoo.

title: Opinion Asked On Lawyer Tie
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  The Securities and Exchange Commission decided yesterday to seek public comment on a proposal that would require corporations to disclose more detailed information about their relationships with their attorneys.

title: Gas Situation Along Most of 195 Seems Eased, Especially in South
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  Half a tank of gas is all you need to get to Europe, goes a radio commercial being broadcast here this week by The Old Country, the continental theme park at Busch Gardens near historic Williamsburg, Va. The oneway trip is a 170mile cruise from here down Interstates 95 and 69.

title: Jersey Has Chance For Hambletonian
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 6  The Hambletonian Society voted today to consider moving its venerable trotting race out of Du Quoin, a step that could lead to the harnessracing classic being held at New Jersey's Meadowlands for a milliondollar nurse.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: Ozzle Smith of the Padres throwing to first base to complete a double play as Doug Flynn of the Mets slid into second base in an attempt to break up the play during fourth inning last night at Shea Stadium.

title: More Racial Unrest in Birmingham
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Saturday, June 7 (UPI)  The police arrested a group of whites, several of them Ku Klux Klansmen, and confiscated several guns [ate last night as racial violence broke out for the second night in a black &LUIS...M/111%NY 1161 C.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WQXR. Symphony in C minor, Schubert; Fantasia in C minor, Beethoven; A Faust Overture, Wagner; Harold in Italy, Berlioz; Guitar Concerto in F, Giuliani; The Watersprite, Dvorak.

title: 40 Hospital Pickets Arrested
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (UPI) Forty hospital workers picketing at one of three struck Philadelphia medical facilities were arrested last night. The police said the workers were arrested at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital for allegedly violating a court order limiting the number of pickets at the three hospitals where more than 3,000 workers are on strike.

title: Protesters in Malaysia Say U.S. Discriminates
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, July (AP)  About 200 people demonstrated in front of the United States Embassy today and handed a note to Ambassador Robert H. Miller charging that the Americans were taking in only skilled refugees from Malaysia's camps.

title: Nicaragua War Idling Truckers
description: CUAJINIQUIL, Costa Rica, July 5 For the last 20 years, Carlos Enrique Gonzalez has piloted trucks back and forth along the Pan American Highway between Panama and his native Guatemala. For almost eight weeks, however, Mr. Gonzalez has been idled with his 20ton rig herein Costa Rica, unable to move north across the closed Nicaraguan border.

title: Son of Sam Reward To Be Shared 3 Ways
description: A $10,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of David Berkowitz, the 44caliber killer also known as Son of Sam, will be divided in three equal parts, it was announced yesterday.

title: Leaders in Klan And Nazi Party Accused ofRape
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 6  Two acknowledged leaders in the Ku Klux Klan and the Nazi Party have been arrested on charges of raping a 19year. old Philadelphia woman after they discovered that she had been spying on their organizations for the Jewish Defense League.

title: Backpackage Tour: Holiday Travel Minus Mountains
description: You see the backpackers now, lining up at Pennsylvania Station and Grand Central Terminal, catching buses at the Port Authority's Midtown Bus Terminal, arriving at Kennedy International Airport on chartered jets. Most of them are young, most wear jeans and Tshirts and sneakers, and most have sleeping bags strapped to their 90Dound packs.

title: Don't Close Schools Too Fast
description: Two decades ago, this country couldn't build schools fast enough to keep pace with the postwar baby boom. Now school districts from Westchester County to Washington State face the opposite problems of dwindling enrollments and whether to close schools to save money. But in their haste to save on maintenance and fuel, officials are overlooking some larger educational and political benefits.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Gold, a traditional hedge in times of economic uncertainty, rose to record prices yesterday as the dollar experienced a rollercoaster day amid speculation on changes in American energy policy and a possible staff shakeup at the White House.

title: But Never Jam Today Opens July 31 at Longacre
description: Previews for Vinnette Carroll's But Never Jam Today will begin at the Longacre Theater on July 19. The musical based on Alice in Wonderland will open July 31.

title: More Export Sales of Grain
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI)  The Agriculture Department said today that more American grain had been sold by private exporters to unknown destinations, bringing total unknowndestination sales to 13.5 million metric tons.

title: Owners of Las Vegas Gambling Spa Are Ordered to Close It or Sell It
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 6 (UPI) Owners of the Aladdin Hotel, a gambling spa that a Federal jury in Detroit found was infested with secret underworld interests, were notified today that the hotelcasino would be closed in 30 days unless it was sold.

title: Trucker Group Calls Moratorium On Strike by Independent Haulers
description: LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP)  Mike Parkhurst, president of the Independent Truckers Association, said today that he was declaring a moratorium on the nationwide truckers shutdown and predicted that truckers would go back on strike in a few months.

title: Baddest Hea vyweigh
description: Larry Holmes was talking softly, so as not to strain the throat polyps that sometimes Make hint hoarse. But his message tang loud and Clear.mother. not Earnie Shavers; not John Tate, not Gerrie Coetzee.

title: Israelis Attack in South Lebanon; Raze Houses and Kill 2 Guerrillas
description: JERUSALEM, July 6  A military spokesman announced tonight that Israeli soldiers entered southern Lebanon during the day and blew up two houses used by Palestinian guerrillas. In a gun battle, two guerrillas were killed, the announcement said. There were no Israeli casualties.

title: Elizabeth Janeway: Writing for Her Life
description: I get tired of people who say, I've always been a feminist,  says Elizabeth Janeway. But that is what she has always been, and now, at the age of 65, crowned with a full and satisfying life as a novelist, nonfiction writer, critic, encourager of young writers, wife and mother, she has become an unruffled elder stateswoman of the movement.

title: Stage: Camino Real at the Williamstown Festival
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 6 To open its 25th anniversary season the Williamstown Festival has taken the view that laurels are prickly things to rest upon, and has put on a very fine production of one of Tennesee Williams's more problematic plays.

title: California Property Tax Cut
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 6 (AP) Proposition 13 cut local property tax revenues by $6.88 billion in the last year, according to the California Board of Equalization. The board said yesterday that the average property tax rate of $10.90 per $100 of assessed value went down 56 percent, to $4.79. The average homeowner's property tax declined 52 percent.

title: Notes on People
description: The American Cancer Society announced yesterday that Richard M. Nixon had given it $100,000. The contribution was made by check in the name of the former President and his wife, Pat, with an accompanying letter that said: We are making this contribution in memory of John Wayne, Hubert Humphrey, Rogers Morton, John Foster Dulles, Robert Taft, Stewart Alsop, Kyle Palmer, Eugene McGovern, Kate Ryan and others in all walks of life who have had cancer.

title: Pact Reported in Parkway Strike
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., July 6 (AP) A tentative agreement was reached tonight between the New Jersey Highway Authority and union officials representing about 675 striking Garden State Parkway toll collectors and maintenance workers.

title: Korea Isn't Germany Yet
description: Diplomacy around the world has become so intricate that when Communist North Korea says it will brook no alien interference in its dealings with South Korea, no one can be sure whether this is a rebuff to the United States, China, the Soviet Union or all three. Or it could be no rebuff at all; President Carter's bid to arrange coexistence talks between the Koreas may not be clearly answered for months.

title: Deaths
description: LIBIENJesse Samuel. Beloved husband of the late Bertha, devoted father of Myron and Lois Libien. and Harold and Esther Steinholz, adored grandfather of Mindy, Jenny, Elizabeth, Bari, and Matthew. Dear brother of the late Mortimer, and Bert. Services Sunday July 8, 11:70 A.M. at The Riverside 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Army Will Again Waive Diplomas for Its Recruits
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)  The Army reversed itself today and announced that it would again accept 17yearold male volunteers who have not completed high school.

title: Chiola Hanover Wins Trot
description: Jimmy Allen drove favored Chiola Hanover to a secondheat victory and come back an hour later to win the final heat of the E. Roland Harriman Trot for 3yearolds.

title: Rags Wins After Jumpoff At Lake Placid Show
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 6 Rags, owned by Another Villa Stables of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and ridden by Anthony D'Ambrosio Jr., won the featured open jumper class today at the I Love New York Horse Show, beating 17 rivals in a jumpoff.

title: 27 Killed and 60 Hurt in Thailand When 2 School Buses Hit Truck
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 6 (UPI) Two buses packed with schoolchildren successively struck a parked truck loaded with logs, killing 27 children and their teachers and injuring at least 60 others, the police said today.

title: Man, 30, Sentenced For Evading Taxes
description: Paul Caiano, who had been described by the government as a known member of the infamous Purple Gang, which controls a substantial portion of the narcotics trade in the Bronx, received a twoyear prison sentence for incometax evasion.

title: Chevron's Oil Pipeline Tapped by Coast Ring
description: LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP)  An illegal tap in an abandoned fruit stand siphoned off thousands of gallons of gasoline from a Chevron oil refinery pipeline before it was discovered, the authorities said today.

title: U.S. Says WhiteCollar Pay Rose 7.8% in the Year Ended in March
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) Average salaries for selected whitecollar occupations in private industry increased 7.8 percent in the year ended in March, while consumer prices increased 10.2 percent, the Government has reported.

title: New England Brass Works Is Right at Home in Westchester
description: AGOOSE honked and one of the trumpeters razzed back; birds chirped through some Renaissance dances, and ferrets were among the listeners to a Scott Joplin rag, as the New England Brass.

title: POLITICS
description: ASTATE legislature may not be the best authority on clarity of thought or expression, because, it has been said, some lawmakers do not say what they mean or mean what they say.

title: We're Different, But We See Life the Same
description: They could be father and son two softspoken, gentle people keenly alert to life's possiblities for joy and pain. The older of the two is 60, but astonishingly youthful in mien and outlook. The younger man is 37, but gives the impression of having experienced far more than his years would allow. Alan Schneider, director, and Michael Weller, playwright, are, in fact, related only in their common love, which is theater, and together they have shaped and brought to the stage two of the more significant plays of the decade.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WITH the cost of operating an airconditioner climbing higher than ever and with no end in sight for the continuing rise in utility rates, everyone who owns an airconditioner will want to do everything possible to keep operating costs down this summer.

title: Engagements 5022
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo Seymour of Brands Farm, Much Hadham, Hertfordshire, England announce the engagement of their daughter SARAH to WILLIAM JAY DUCAS, son of the late Robert Duces and Mrs. Jean Weir Duces of Quaker Hill, Pawlino, Hew York. The wedding will take place in Lando, in September.

title: Landlord Questioned in Shooting Of an OffDuty Policeman on S.I.
description: A suspect sought in the shooting of an offduty New York City policeman surrendered to the police yesterday afternoon.

title: New Plants Are Bred to Resist Diseases
description: plant diseases are the despair of home gardeners. An apple tree nurtured from the time it was a sapling, succumbs to scab and fire blight. Cucumbers wither under an attack of mosaic virus. Tomatoes on the verge of ripeness are ruined by fusarium wilt.

title: Chicago Scofflaw Faces $62,800 Parking Fine
description: CHICAGO, July 7 (AP)  Laurence Dawson abruptly changed his plea to not guilty when he realized that he was liable for a $62,800 fine for 314 unpaid parking tickets.

title: ABT
description: NEWARK IT IS fitting that the Newark Museum should mark its 70th anniversary this year with an exhibition honoring John Cotton Dana, the museum's first director. He was a champion of American art at a time when the nation's painting and sculnture were demeaned.

title: A Dreary Lear At Drew
description: MADISON FOR its first 1979 production, the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival has performed a nearimpossible task: It has turned King Lear into a dreary play.

title: Blacks Debate Role of Their ModernDay Churches
description: Matilda Jacobs, who is simply Malty to the family for whim she does domestic work during the week, becomes Deaconess Jacobs on Sundays. In the same way, welfare recipients and the menially employed become Sister or Brother or Sunday School teacher, titles that in some measure compensate fir their secular anonymity. The respect is granted by the oldest institution in black America  the church.

title: Around the Nation
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July (AP)  The Marine Corps has begun an investigation into charges that three drill instructors assaulted more than 100 recruits last month.

title: The Portents Were Wrong, Much to the Delight of the Ohio Plaintiffs
description: WASHINGTON  For six years now the United States Supreme Court has declined to hear school desegregation appeals brought by minority plaintiffs seeking to integrate schools. It has heard only those appeals brought by school boards challenging courtordered desegregation plans, and each time it has gradually placed more narrow and mechanistic legal hurdles before those seeking to use the courts to overcome the school segregation that persists in most parts of the country because black children usually do not live near white children.

title: Anne Cadigan Wed To David P. Brown
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of the Shrine of the Sacred Heart in Baltimore yesterday, Anne Cecelia Cadigan was married to David Paul Brown. The Revs. Arthur F. Smith and Alfred E. Smith, uncles of the bride, performed the ceremony. They were assisted by Msgr. E. Melville Taylor and the bride's brother, Timothy J. Cadigan, a Jesuit novice.

title: Oh Slams 15th Homer
description: TOKYO, July 7 (AP)  Sadaharu Oh hit his 15th home run. of the season today, the 820th of his career. The clout broke an eighthinning tie and helped the Yomiuri Giants beat the Hanshin Tigers, 43.

title: Number One, Madison Ave.
description: First came the telephone call from Lee A. Iacocca, who had been jettisoned as president of the Ford Motor Company and was now swinging heavy stick as the new president of the Chrysler Corporation. One early target was the $50 million account with an advertising agency that Chrysler had used for 21 years. They fired us, said Edward N. Ney, chairman and chief executive of Young & Rubicam. We were shocked and amazed.

title: The New Philosopher Kings
description: PLUMBERS, carpenters, electricians and other people who work with their hands used to be strong, silent types, the sort of men who answered your questions in grudging monosyllables, as if you hadn't paid for language, too. But not any more.

title: Cosmos Defeat Tea Men
description: BOSTON, July. 7  The Cosmos, withstanding a secondhalf attack by New England, defeated the Tea Men, 21, tonight on goals by Francisco Marinho and Giorgio Chlnaglia.

title: Ice Cream Flavors A Night of Theater
description: ORIENT  BROADWAY ice cream sodas and hotsy totsy fudge sundaes may not be essential to an evening in the theater, but this summer they're being dished up as a complement to an unusual summer entertainment called Chocolate Vanilla and Strawhat

title: THEATER Side by Side Delights Anew
description: EAST WINDSOR OFFHAND, I would not have considered and still don'tthe elegant little songfest, Side by Side by Sondheim,'. as dinnertheater fare. Dinnertheater audiences, as a rule, prefer schmaltz to sophistication and wit. But the Coachlight has dared to stage this musical tribute to the American lyricist and composer that was conceived in London and became a hit on both sides of the Atlantic, and for me it was a success. I cannot vouch for the audience I saw it with. My impression was that many of Mr. Sondheim's more stringent lines sailed right over their heads.

title: Gardner Osborn, Preservationist, 86
description: Gardner Osborn, historian and landmark preservationist who led the successful fight to save Federal Memorial Hall in downtown Manhattan in the 1930's, died on July 4 after a long Illness. Mr. Osborn, who lived in Tudor City. was 86 years old.

title: Virginia Pender Married to Timothy Michel
description: Virginia Culpepper Pender, daughter of Mrs. James C. O'Shea of Albany and Barneveld, N.Y., and the late Dr. Robert B. Pender, was married yesterday evening to Timothy Mattheus Michel. He is the son of Mrs. Lincoln Mattheus Michel of Sarasota, Fla., and Wayne, Pa. and the late Mr. Michel. The Rev. John F. Harrotd, director of Catholic Charities for Broome County in Binghamton, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the bride's family home in Barneveld.

title: A Universe Inspired by the Past
description: AT the Neuberger Museum of the State University College at Purchase is Seven Planets an exhibition of paintings and works on paper by Michael Torlen through Aug. 22. Mr. Torlen's art in some ways resembles that of John Willenbecher that, reviewed recently, is displayed in the adjoining galleries. Both men take the universe as their subject, use geometry as a vehicle, and draw inspiration from the past. Mr. Willenbecher, however, deals with the deep, monochromatic space of astronomy, and his mysticism is postNewtonian, while Mr. Torlen's space is astrological, and his sources are the civilizations of the Maya, the ancient Greeks and soon.

title: United Press International
description: HARD SLIDE: Pete Rose of PhiIlles scoring on single by Mike Schmidt during first inning of game against Giants Friday in Philadelphia. Phillies defeated Giants, 61.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Who says the United Nations is an ineffectual debating society? Last week, after seven years labor, the United Nations Committee on Outer Space approved a draft of an international treaty to govern exploitation of the riches, if any, of the moon. If approved by the General Assembly meeting in September, it will take effect as soon as five nations ratify.

title: Congress, Noting DC10 Failure, Is Acting to Tighten Safety Rules
description: Efforts are being intensified on Capitol Hill to pinpoint the shortcomings of Government rules and supervision that permitted gaps in data and testing in the original certification of the McDonnellDouglas DC10 jumbo jet as safe for passenger service.

title: THE MARKETS
description: The stock market marked time most of last week as the impact of sharply higher oil prices, the Fourth of July holiday, the cancellation by President Carter of his energy speech and the subsequent criticism of his handling of the oil crisis all served to keep investors off balance. But on Friday, after President Carter announced that he was meeting with his top advisers and governors of several states to seek a solution on energy, the Dow Jones industrial average soared 10.41 points to close at 896.16.

title: an American Games
description: 10,000Meter Relay  1, Tom Peterson, Tacoma, Wash., Chris Snyder, Euless, Tex., 17:42.87; 2, Curtis Cook, Greenacres, Wash., Ken Sutton, Muskegon, Mich., 17:49.02; 3, Raul Subiledt, Carlos Lupea, Argentina, 17:52.61.

title: An OutFront Prosecutor
description: PATERSON I THINK the Prosecutor has to be out in front. It's his office. If things go well, he gets the bouquets; if things don't go well. he sets the brickbats.

title: Sunday Observer
description: It is a summer day. Hot. Beautiful. A perfect day, someone has decided, to be cooked in oil and eaten by flies. We lie basting on beds of sand while insects roam over us, smacking their chops and uttering little cries of yum yum upon sinking their mandibles into dainty morsels of human.

title: Anne Warden Becomes Bride
description: In the Colebrook (Conn.) Congregational Church yesterday afternoon, Anne Hubbard Warden, daughter of Mrs. H.H. Hugo Fries of Wilmington, Del., and Herbert W. Warden 3d of New York, became the bride of Mark Crawford Sinkinson, son of the Rev. and Mrs. George E. Sinkinson Jr. of Farmington, Me. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's father, who retired as rector of St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Owings Mills, Md.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations are not in effect today. Beginning tomorrow, they will be back in effect innll boroughs.

title: First Accord Reported In Connecticut Talks With PUblic Workers
description: HARTFORD, July 7 (AP)  The first tentative contract agreement covering some of Connecticut's unionized state employees was reported today after 22 consecutive hours of negotiations.

title: 199 Indochinese Fly to U.S
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 7 (UPI) A plane carrying 199 Indochinese refugees left today for the United States, where they will settle, an American refugee official said.

title: East Side Shift
description: The MorganGrampian Publishing Company and the David McKay Company, a subsidiary, have leased 30,000 square feet of office space for 10 years at 2 Park Avenue.

title: Drivers Line Up for Exemptions to Gas Sales Rules
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 In Florida it's the traveling salesmen who are angry. In New York and California it's the doctors. In Maryland the nurses and the druggists are irked, and in Texas it's the housewives who are annoyed and getting madder.

title: Letters; The High Cost of Affirmative Action; Mercy Mission in the South Pacific; Why a Draft Now?; Insurance Bonanza; Thank You, OPEC; 1979 OPEC Oil Price Increase Is Not 1974 Revisited
description: To the Editor: When Chief Justice Burger aptly quotes Justice Cardozo in his dissent in Weber and Justice Rehnquist aptly quotes Orwell in his reprimand of the majority of the Supreme Court, the question of why the majority still felt the need to overreach becomes interesting.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE - The Boy Friend. Wednesday to Saturday 8:30 P.M., Sundays at 8. Through July 29. $5.50 to $7.50. Discount available for students, the elderly and groups. Reservations. Country Cabaret, with entertainment and crepe kitchen, Fridays and Saturdays after show. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Routes 6 and 118.6281169. ELMSFORD - Kiss Me, Kate. Tonight only. Cabaret. Tuesday to next Sunday. Through Sept. 16. $18.15 to $20.35. Opens 6:15 P.M., buffet at 7, show at 8:30. Reservations. An Evening Dinner Theater, 11 Clearbrook Rd. 5922222.

title: Questions/Answers
description: Several of my plants have died due to some sort of fuzzy and white fungus. It spreads until it devours the plant. What causes this? B.B., Flushing, N.Y.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: PRINCETON THE Class of 79 has come and gone, and with it the frenetic rites of commencement and reunion. The Class of 83 has not yet arrived. The feverish ritual of registration and resettlement is in abeyance.

title: Get Out the Line and Haul em In
description: THE New Jersey angler should have no trouble finding plenty of bluefish all along the coast this week. Schools of big blues - have arrived off Sandy Hook and can now be found as far south as Ocean City.

title: Campaigns Begin On County Utility
description: THE first radio spots could be heard on local and New York City stations last week, urging no votes in November. Next week, volunteers with canisters will be seeking contributions in supermarket parking lots for the campaign to encourage yes votes on election day. There have been mailings and fundraising events; bumper stickers will come later.

title: Dr. Shu Hua Li, 89, an Educator And Physicist on Columbia Staff
description: Dr. Shu Hua Li, a physicist and educator in China and later at Columbia University, died Thursday of a heart attack at St. Luke's Hospital. Dr. Li, who lived in Manhattan, was 89 years old.

title: Budget for Columbia University Balanced First Time in 12 Years
description: Columbia University put into effect last week its first balanced budget in 12 years.

title: Kathy Hoyne Sets Wedding on Oct. 6
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. O'Brien of Dayton, Ohio, have announced the engagement of Mrs. O'Brien's daughter, Dorothy Kathleen Hoyne, to Joseph E. Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Greenwich, Conn., and Edgartown, Mass. Miss Hoyne is a daughter also of the late William E. Hoyne Jr. of Dayton.

title: Look and Rolling Stone
description: It was only in May that Jann S. Wenner, editor and publisher of Rolling Stone magazine, signed on to run Look magazine as well. Revived in February by French publisher Daniel Filipacchi, Look wasn't making it  and it still isn't. Last week the liaison ended, and Look fired its editorial and art staffs.

title: Astros and Expos Win and Wait For Last Laugh ktakv
description: Actually, the Astros were the first team to dispose of Marshall and Staub, because the Montreal Expos became the second team in 1969. The Expos once had Ken Singleton and Mike Torrez: They had Dave McNally, but not for very long. They also had Coco Laboy, Boots Day, and their public address announcer's favorite: John Boccabeilta. They played in front of fans who did not speak the same language, in a country that provided another tax form to fill out, in weather cold enough that they could see their breath. They were not very good, either.

title: The Region
description: New York City made out like a bandit last week, at least as far as officials in Nassau and Suffolk Counties were concerned. After a campaign. by Governor Carey and Mayor Koch, the city won approval to divert $200 million in Federal funds from rehabilitation of the Long Island Expressway in Queens to improving mass transit and repairing bridges and smaller highways.

title: Sudden Death Is Winner In Lake Placid Jump Class
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 7  Sudden Death, who has been competing for five years despite a heart murmur, won the amateurowner jumper class at the I Love New York Horse Show today and finished in a fourway tie for the chamaionshio.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Proposes for the American economy to what he believes needs doing abroad, chiefly development of the productive capacity of thirdworld countries. He has political program  one based on more community participation and power, more public debate, and a broad coalition of workers, consumers, farmers, environmentalists, Naderites and the elderly.

title: Erosion Imperils Northern Shore
description: SLOWLY but surely, the Island's northern shore, from Great Neck to Orient Point, is being washed into the sea.

title: Floridians Help Win 6Hour Race
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 7 (AP)  Don and Bill Whittington, brothers from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., shared the driving with Klaus Ludwig of Germany to win the'Six Hours of Endurance Race at the Watkins Glen Grand Prix Course today.

title: Gail Lynette Lewis Wed To Scott Darryl Lewis
description: Gail Lynette Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Lewis of Gaithersburg, Md., was married yesterday to Scott Darryl Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cicero A. Lewis of Portsmouth, N.H. The Rev. Robert Thompson, an African Methodist Episcopal clergyman, performed the at the home of the bride's parents. The families are not related.

title: Garden State Parkway's Workers Accept Contract by Wide Margin
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J.,July 7 (AP) Striking Garden State Parkway workers voted by a margin of nearly 2 to 1 today to accept the New Jersey Highway Authority's latest contract offer, a union spokesman said.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: It is unfortunate that the recent article about our village's proposed restriction of overnight rafting in Lloyd Harbor omits any statements from the village or, more to the point, from the Coast Guard.

title: A Glossary of SALT Terms
description: Aggregates. Combined weapon systems ceilings.

title: DrunkenDriving Law Is Struck Down in Part
description: The main portions of New York State's drunkendriving statute have been struck down as unconstitutionally vague by a state appellate court in Manhattan.

title: GARDENING Succulents Flourish In the Outdoors, Too
description: SPRINGTIME was such a confusion to me this year that some of my houseplants are still sitting on windowsills, patiently waiting for their summer vacation.

title: The World
description: BONN  Franz Josef Strauss, West Germany's most confounding politician, barely waited for the idea to sink that he will be the Christian Democratic candidate for Chancellor before starting to confuse and fascinate once again.

title: Ford Cancels Project to Produce 1982 FrontWheelDrive Compact
description: DETROIT, July 7 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company has confirmed that it has dropped plans for a new frontwheeldrive automobile that was to have replaced its Fairmont and Zephyr models in 1982.

title: Deaths
description: KELMANFannie, beloved mother of Mimi Fogelman, Norman J. Cohen and Dr. Lawrence S. Cohen. Loving stepmother of Edythe Finder and Sandy Colter. Dearest motherinlaw of Irving Fogelman. Selma Cohen. Jane Cohen and Marvin Finder. Dear sister of Bellamin, Irving and Lou Cooper. Adored grandmother of Lynne, Maxine, Mitchell, Lee. Cindy, Melanie, Wendy. Alan, Michael, Dore and Mary. Great grandmother of Adam, Even and Carrie. Services Sunday 12:15 PM at The Colonial Chapels, of I.J. Morris Inc, 46 Greenwich St, Herrxostead, L.I.

title: Brokers See Role In Sales Imperiled
description: Small independent realestate brokers across the country are voicing alarm over what they consider an intrusion by large relocation companies into their traditional markets.

title: R. C. Bondy, Miss Pollock Set Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Fithian Pollock of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Cunningham Pollock, to Richard Charles Bondy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Lederer Bondy of Carefree, Ariz.

title: DINING OUT
description: WESTPORT LUNCHING outdoors in the early summer sunshine, sheltered from Westport's main road by an attractive, woodslatted partition, is so agreeable one wishes that alfresco dining in Connecticut, especially now that the summer theatrical productions there begin to attract neonle from Westchester, were more the rule than the exception. The Mushroom management has shown ingenuity in making maximum use of very limited space, with fresh plantings of marigolds and vibrant purple clematis climbing the partition.

title: A Mother And Daughter Duo
description: Afascinating motherdaughter pair of records has just been released on two separate labels. The disks are Louise Got fin's debut album, Kid Blue, on Asylum, and Carole King's Touch the Sky on Capitol.

title: U.S. Has New Student Aid Form That Is Written in Plain English
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)  The Government has unveiled a new student aid form to replace one that it acknowledged has been unnecessarily complex and confusing for college students.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: GAIDGEHAMPTON  Works by Frances Miller; through July 25; Peter S. Loonam Gallery, Main St. For hours, 5373775.

title: Indonesia Reportedly Tows Boat With 800 Refugees Back to Sea
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 7 (AP) Indonesian authorities reportedly towed a wooden boat carrying 800 Vietnamese refugees out to sea today.

title: Jan Merrill First in 3,000 at San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 7  At 10:02 A.M. today, he was disqualified after having arrived two minutes late for trials that never took place. At 3:30 P.M., he was reinstated following daylong appeal. Tonight, Carl Lewis won a bronze medal in the long jump at the Pan American Games with the best performance of his career, 26 feet inches.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: in answer to tne article oy Jonn Breasted regarding the uselessness of residential programs at colleges and the University of Connecticut at Storrs in particular (Is Storrs Too Far From Real Life? June 24), I am a recent UConn graduate ('79) and spent all four years living in the residential system. It is unfortunate that the incident that happened at the close of the 197879 year has received so much attention in the press. To paint a picture of UConn as being a place of rampant destruction and disregard for property because of one incident is unrealistic.

title: Foyt Breaks Own Record
