description: MILWAUKEE, July 7 (AP)  A.J. Foyt broke his own track record today to win the pole position for tomorrow's 200mile United States Auto Club stockcar race at the State Fair park.

title: 2 New York City Residents killed In a Helicopter Crash in. Catskills
description: Two New York City men were killed and a husband and wife from Schenectady, N.Y., were critically injured when their fourseat helicopter crashed yesterday while attempting to take off near the resort village of Tannersville, N.Y., in, the Catskill Mountains, the state police renorted.

title: Miners Get Extension for Claims
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)  The Labor Department has reported that coal miners receiving monthly blacklung benefits from the Social Security Administration will be been given an additional six months, to Dec. 31, to file their claims for medical benefits from the department, Donald Elisburg, assistant Labor Secretary for employment standards, said Tuesday.

title: Music Notes: Some Newport Novelties
description: When the Newport Music Festival changed hands in 1975, there were signs that it was changing direction with respect to artistic content as well. The festival in the Rhode Island resort town, originally guided by Glen Sauls, had become famous for its preoccupation with littleknown or forgotten works of the 19th century. Mark P. Malkovich HI, who replaced Mr. Sauls four years ago, seemed to be reverting to less esoteric material, falling back on the more familiar masterpieces of the Romantic era.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, July 8 VOLENDAM (Holland America). Left Bermuda July 6; due 8 A.M. at W. 5Sth Street.

title: Rightist Intellectual Groups Rise in France
description: PARIS, July 7  After more than three decades in hibernation, small but influential rightwing groups in France are again seeking the intellectual limelight, expounding theories on race, biology and political elitism discredited by the defeat of Fascism in World War II.

title: Primary Splits Suffolk G.O.P.
description: WEST ISLIP WHEN he announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for County Executive last week, Peter F. Cohalan played the role of the prizefighter. He strode briskly  almost trotted  through a crowd of cheering fans and held his hands aloft, more like Muhammad All in Madison Square Garden than an Islip Town Supervisor in LaGrange Restaurant.

title: When the Court Was at Its Best
description: The Supreme Court lives in a marble temple and communicates in volumes of cold print, but it is also human institution. During the term just ended, the Court displayed the strengths and weaknesses of both humans and institutions. The justices showed personal pique and intuitive knowledge; the Court exhibited tui collegial splintering and collective courage. Even as we absorb some conspicuous disappointments in the term just finished, we are moved to observe that the Court was at its best in the biggest cases.

title: Lyle Leads European Golf
description: HELSINGBORG, Sweden, July 7 (UPI)  Sandy Lyle of Britain and Mike Krantz of Huntington Beach, Calif., turned in courserecord sevenunderpar 65's today in the $70,000 Scandinavian open. But Lyle held the lead with a 54hole aggregate of nineunder 207, one stroke ahead of the 26yearold Krantz.

title: Ellen Marie Faulkner Married to Raymond R. Lockwood
description: In St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church in Houston yesterday afternoon, Ellen Marie Faulkner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hand Faulkner of Houston, became the bride of Raymond Reynolds Lockwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Lockwood of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Msgr. Alfred Raye performed the ceremony.

title: Topics Singularities
description: The celebration of the 1,000yearold parliament on the Isle of Man the other day was stirring for more reasons than its pageantry. Queen Elizabeth II, of course, presided. The First Deemster, or High Judge, appeared in wig and red gown and thousands of the island's descendants, bearing names like Kermode and Costain, arrived from all over the world to moisten their roots in the partly pagan, partly medieval, partly touristic ritual of this partly independent island in the Irish Sea. It must have been fun.

title: The Hudson River Is His Front Yard
description: There are any number of nice things about being a party guest of Jerome Gary. The movearound room is ample, the view is superb, the food is good, and best of all, one knows one Is wanted. Mr. Gary does not extend casual invitations, and although he's a goodnatured fellow. friends don't often drop in.

title: Worldwide Incidence of Cholera Reported to Continue on Rise
description: ATLANTA, July 7 (AP)  The worldwide cholera pandemic was worse in 1978 than any other year since it began in 1961, the national Center for Disease Control says.

title: U.S. DENIES SEEKING A DEAL WIN SOMOZA
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  The United States indicated today that it was letting Latin American governments take the lead in negotiating with the Sandinist rebels and other groups about a successor to President Anastasio Somoza Debayle in Nicaragua. In a terse response to reporters questions, the State Department also denied that the Carter Administration was negotiating with General Somoza about conditions in connection with his departure from office.

title: CanAm Series Next for Rahal
description: Bobby Rahal, a promising young American driver who has been racing in Europe in hope of making his mark internationally, now thinks the CanAm series could be his ticket to a regular spot in Formula One competition.

title: Carter Agonistes
description: WASHINGTON  The situation: Inflation is rampant and the economy is sluggish; the public is in a contentious mood and Congress is truculent and unruly; the opinion polls show opposition candidates more popular than the President. In a mood of crisis, he retreats to Camp David, summons his advisers, aware that his Administration is at watershed, that his political survival and the nation's economic wellbeing are at stake.

title: F.A.A. Seeks Safer Pilots
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)  The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would start a nationwide drive July 15 to encourage private pilots to sharpen their flying skills. The purpose of the refresher training, the F.A.A. said, is to reduce the rising rate of accidents among general aviation pilots.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: WINNER AT WIMBLEDON: Bjorn Borg holds trophy aloft after defeating Roscoe Tanner and taking singles title for fourth year. Section 5.

title: Nelson Cards 70210 And Leads by Shot
description: OAK BROOK, Ill., July 7 (UPI)  Larry Nelson, continuing his steady play at the Butler National course, birdied the 18th hole for a twounderpar 70 today and a onestroke lead over Tom Watson after three rounds of the $300,000 Western open.

title: Tio Sam's Wallet A Key in Nicaragua
description: No longer able to engage in the gunboat diplomacy it used to install the Somoza dynasty 45 years ago, the United States tried checkbook diplomacy last week, offering reconstruction aid to try to mold Nicaragua's postSomoza future. But even in that poor and battered Central American nation, Washington's 1979 dollars weren't buying instant obedience.

title: Medicaid at Issue In Nursing Homes
description: ALMOST every day Mr. Charles (a pseudonym) carefully packs the fruit, pours the milk, slices the cake, and places it all in a brown paper bag. His wife will not eat unless he brings her food from home. Her doctor says Mrs. Charles would not have lived long without the constant attention of her husband.

title: CAMERA
description: Most people want to look better in a photograph than they do in a mirror, so the photographer's skills in taking portraits will be highly regarded if he or she can conceal what the sitter sees as a fault or liability, or if the photographer can reveal what the subject thinks of as his or her best features.

title: Miss Rathbone Will Be Bride
description: Eliza Rathbone, assistant curator of 20thcenttiry art at the National Gallery in Washington, and Andrew Hamilton, a principal analyst with the Congressional Budget Office, plan to marry in September.

title: MAILBAG
description: To The Editor: Iwas surprised to read the New York Times Camera column on May 20, 1979, entitled Shooting Wedding. The article started off with a claim that a Bob Mahler based in East Brunswick, N.J., graphed more than 9,000 weddings in a 20year period. 1 am in the wedding album photography business and have photographed weddings professionally since 1991. I am also a past president of 1 the Metropolitan Chapter of the Professional Photographers Association of New Jersey. Of the hundreds of photographers that I know in the wedding business, I know of no photographer (including. myself) who would claim that he photographed 4.000 weddings in a 20year period  that is a physical impossibility.

title: Park Concert: The Singing Of Joan Baez
description: During her Friday evening concert at the Dr. Pepper Central Park Music Festival, Joan Baez had to contend with a capacity crowd that kept streaming in throughout her first set; with Mayor Koch and a group of his aides, who were somewhat conspicuous in the center of the orchestra; and with an insistent young man who kept calling out that he loved her. She was friendly and relaxed with the crowd, she urged 9 singalong, city officials included, and she squelched the young man by humoring him: Hey, this must be cosmic. What's your sign?

title: They're Putting a House in Storage
description: NORTH HILLS IMAGINE that one day you see a perfect house, loaded with special features, many that houses don't have anymore, and you fall in love with it.

title: Owner of British Mansion Is Fighting Time and Taxes
description: ALCESTER, England  The eighth Marquess of Hertford slowed his tan Ford Granada and pointed to the side of the country lane.

title: Yonkers Dismissals Raise Racism Charges
description: YONKERS THE dismissal last week of Herman Keith, program manager of the Yonkers Community Development Agency, and several other employees of the agency has touched off charges of racism from this city's minority community.

title: Regulating Commodity Frauds
description: Despite a burgeoning number of regulations, there has been no let up in the scandals involving the sale and marketing of commodityrelated investment opportunities. From the commodity option frauds perpetrated by GoldsteinSamuelson in 1973 to the Lloyd, Carr & Company scandals of 1977 and the abuses in sales of limited risk forward contracts today, Government regulatory agencies have responded to every public disclosure of problems in a by now predictable fashion: They wish it would go away. That is, they don't care if the fraudulent selling practices continue, they just want the frauds to settle on someone else's turf.

title: News Summary
description: Energy experts and President Carter will hold discussions at Camp David today, and they will be followed this week by economic officials and other consultants outside the Administration to help with the energy and economic decisions that confront the President. Mr. Carter's afdes are expected to sub. mit an energy memorandum tomorrow. They are said to disagree sharply on the question of decontrolling gasoline prices. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Even Good News Seems Tainted
description: Normally, the news that unemployment had dropped to its lowest level in five years would be cause for rejoicing. Normally, an announcement that Saudi Arabia planned to increase oil production might tempt energy planners to relax a few notches. But with President Carter and his advisers struggling in the vast economic darkness up at Camp David, these and other normally encouraging developments were seen in Washington as faint flickers, not a steady beacon.

title: Coastal FourLength Victor in Dwyer
description: How good is Private Account?

title: 250,000 Are in Saudi Arabia:
description: CAIRO  In the acrimonious weeks that followed the Arab boycott against Egypt for its peace treaty with Israel, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates hpproached Cairo separately to renew the contracts of Egirptian teachers in their schools and to recruit more.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: VESTED INTEREST

title: Set Point Shows He's Right Pacer
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 7  Set Point won a $100,000 pace today, beating favored Hot Hitter in the final stride at Saratoga Raceway, and thereby hangs a horse's tale.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Heavy clouds and thunderstorms cover most of the South Atlantic States, the Tennessee Valley, the lower Mississippi and Missouri Valleys, the Plains Statee,the southern Rockies and the intermountain region. Scattered clouds are evident over the Texas Panhandle and the Pacific Northwest. Skies are clear elsewhere In the country.

title: Randal
description: Because of the current gas shortage, we will be happy to mail at NO EXTRA CHARGE your phone or mail orders.

title: Deaths
description: BELLISEsther. Beloved wife of Herbert, devoted mother of Maurice P. and Lewis C. Dear sister of Rose Schwartzman and adored grandmother. Services Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd. and 66 Ave., Rego Park, Sunday, 10AM.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: The three theaters, barn and grounds of the O'Neill Center in Waterford will be bustling with activity from tomorrow through Aug. 5, with the National Playwright's Conference; from next Sunday to July 29, it will be overlapped by the ComposersLibrettists Conference. Equity actors coached by professional directors will be performing 12 fully blocked new plays, scripts in hand, evenings at 8:30 and matinees at 2:30 Saturday and July 21 and 28.

title: POLL SHOWS CARTER IS TRAILING IN SOUTH
description: ATLANTA, July 7  Hamilton Jordan and other White House aides who are pressing southern states to set they primaries ahead to offset expected poor showings by President Carter in the early New England primaries are in for shock: A new poll has found that the President is running behind Senator Edward M. Kennedy among registered Southern Democrats by 11 percentage points.

title: Sandy Horner Engaged to George D. Baker
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. G. Philip Lynch of Cedarhurst, L.I., and Martin Horner of San Juan Capistrano, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Sylvia Wigglesworth Horner, to George Dickson Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. J.H. Baker of Scottsdale, Ariz., and Beaumaris, Ontario.

title: A Cure for Ailing Bridges
description: It's not exactly news that the nation's bridges are in bad shape. In fact, fully onethird of them are in a deteriorated condition nationwide, according to Federal estimates, and the Federal bridge replacement outlay is running at more than a billion dollars a year.

title: Survivors Record Memories
description: NEW HAVEN THEY ordered the whole Jewish population of the city to get to certain points, to gather, and when that happened they picked at random every so often, and just shot them. Then we were released to eo home.

title: The Feds Nail the Money Merchant
description: The selfstyled money merchant of Cincinnati, Carl H. Lindner Jr., who built a small family dairy into a $3 billion financial holding company, last week found that his explanations of some insider transactions of his American Financial Corporation didn't hold water with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: lityriagesYkddings 5024
description: Sheila Patricia Winters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl J. Winters of Rockaway Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen D. Kutner at Our Lady of the Skies Chapel at John F. Kennedy Airport. The Rev. Thomas McDonnell, a Maryknoll missionary, concelebrated the Nuptial Mass with the Rev. John Martin, Director of Vocations of the Diocese of Rockville Centre. The bride is an alumna of the University of Dayton. She received her master's degree in Learning Disabilities from AdeIghl University, L.I. She teaches.English at Mater Christi High School in Astoria, N.Y. Her father is a retired educator and her mother Is a Principal in the New York City public schools. Her brother Brian plays Professional basketball for Me Milwaukee Bucks, N.B.A.

title: JURY HEARS OUTLINE ON CAMPUS MURDERS
description: MIAMI, July 7Opposing attorneys in the firstdegree murder trial of Theodore R. Bundy, charged with killing two Florida State University students 18 months ago, had equally sobering words today for the predominantly black, predominantly male jury that will hear the case over the next several weeks.

title: Food
description: One of the most interesting legends about the Milanese appetite has to do with La Scala. It is said that when the famed opera house was opened, there were sitting rooms outside the boxes where the good city folk would sit and feast and drink wine between acts  and sometimes during the performance. Hector Berlioz once observed that the rattle of knives and forks was enough to distract the baton wielder in the pit.

title: Governors at Camp David Parley Say Carter Still Bars WagePrice Curbs
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 7  President Carter, seeking to'go beyond energy and propose solutions for a wide range of national problems that affect the economy, still rejects wage and price controls as an antiinflation measure, a delegation of Governors reported today.

title: And the Answers To Those Questions
description: THE Equal Rights Amendment is widely misunderstood. Many women and men still hold distorted notions of how it will affect their rights. responsibilities and opportunities.

title: Love For Life
description: 212 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $8.95.

title: Questions On My Mind
description: IREAD Eileen Thornton's article on the Equal Rights Amendment [May 27] with great interest. While there is nothing in her philosophy, as stated, with which I disagree, there are some questions in my mind concerning the E.R.A. that perhaps she could answer for me. They are:

title: Three Mile Island Post Reopens With Film for Tourists
description: MIDDI.ETOWN, Pa., July 7  Before mixed house of the convinced and the hostile  viewers wearing antinuclear Tshirts filled about half the seats  the Metropolitan Edison Company today premiered a 19minute film designed to offset the persistent, negative image of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant.

title: AROUND THE GaltaTie
description: Last call to pinch back mums to encourage branching. Keep faded flowers pinched from petunias and snapdragons or they set seed and stop flowering. Apply fertilizer to vegetables once again. Use BT, biological control for caterpillars Check squash, melons for stern borers.

title: Foreigners Widen Investment Search
description: LONDON  The world's best investment, according to Vijay Israni, a young Indian who now lives in West Germany, is not antiques, gold, Persian rugs or even oil wells. It's property in the United States, mostly likely a rgediumsized shopping center or a hotel.

title: Judge Rules F.B.I. Violated the Privacy of a Lawyer
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  A Federal judge has ruled that the Federal Bureau of Investigation violated the Privacy Act when it collected records regarding the public and private political speeches of Detroit lawyer who had been active in several Arab organizations.

title: Open Lands Accord With U.S. Would Add Aid to Urban Areas
description: HARTFORD AFTER a long dispute over whether Connecticut discriminates against minorities in using Federal grants to buy open land for recreational purposes, the state's Department of Environmenal Protection and the Interior Department in Washington are nearing agreement on new guidelines to send more of the Federal dollars to urban areas.

title: Mailbox: A Fan Jabs at Holmes; New York; McCreary's Derby Victory Destined to Stay Obscure; New York; What Was the Document That Billy Martin Signed?; Brooklyn; The Etiquette of Tennis Is Integral Part of Game
description: To the Sports Editor: Emulating Muhammad Ali, Larry Holmes has blustered regularly, since his victory over Ken Norton last year, that he was the baddest heavyweight in the world.

title: Yale Crew Gains Final In Henley Royal Regatta
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, July 7  Into every Henley Royal Regatta a little rain must fall. Today's shower occurred during the luncheon interval, as picnic baskets and umbrellas opened simultaneously. Apart from making the cream run a little more freely over the strawberries, the rain did nothing to dampen the enthusiasm of the record crowd cheering the 131st rowing of this classic regatta.

title: The Beat That's Latinizing Disco and Pop
description: Station yourself outside the executive offices of Fania Records on a Friday afternoon, and in a few hours you will meet many of the movers and shapers of New York's Latin music, or salsa, an art form that is profoundly affecting disco and mainstream popular music in a business whose annual growth from domestic record sales Is conservatively estimated at $25 million a year. On a recent Friday, the callers included several of the top Latin bandleaders; they were taking care of business details before fanning out into upper Manhattan and the booughs, where they work in the clubs and dancehalls that are still the lifeblood of salsa.

title: Study Finds Bilingual Voting Aid Lags in California and Southwest
description: SAN ANTONIO, July 7  A longawaited, report by the Federal Election Commission on the conduct of bilingual elections has, concluded that local officials in parts of California and of the Southwest are providing minimal or even no compliance with either the letter or the spirit of the Federal Voting Rights Act.

title: CHESS
description: What you get out of speculative sacrifice is mostly abuse. If you lose the game, your friends will be quick to chide you for taking chances by not calculating out everything to the end. If you win, you still will not get any credit  they will say you are a lucky, irresponsible gambler.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY  Labor, in the corridors of the Capitol, used to mean burly construction workers and employees in the needle trades and workers in noisy steel mills and auto plants. Today, it more often means state employees who spend their days behind desks and New York City teachers and workers in municipal hospitals.

title: Summertime, and the Arts Are Easy at Lincoln Center
description: The arts are not for the privileged few, but for the many. Their place is not on the periphery of daily life, but at its center.

title: What to Do About Skylab
description: What should you do to avoid getting clunked on the head when big chunks of Skylab fall to the Earth this week? Buy a gaily colored hardhat and enrich your local souvenir merchant? Head for the hills? Crouch on the east side of a mountain to gain some protection against pieces approaching from the west? Seek refuge in Canada north of about 50 degrees latitude, safely outside Skylab's orbital oath?

title: 18771979: THE FRESH AIR FUND
description: 18771979: THE FRESH AIR FUND

title: Capital Report
description: THE fate of a proposal under which the state would buy and operate most of the private bus lines in New Jersey may be settled tomorrow. Administration muscle pushed a bill to accomplish this through the State Senate last month, but many Assembly members are balking.

title: GARDENING; Can't Buy It? Try Propagating It
description: LET'S suppose that you have admired a particularly attractive shrub in a neighbor's gulden, but, upon inquiry at the local nursery, you are told that they haven't heard of it or it just isn't being grown. Should you resign yourself to never having this plant in your garden?

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: REPRESENTATIVES Richard L. Ottinger, Hamilton Fish Jr. and several of their Congressional colleague took a trip last week that could hardly be called a junket. Planned last February with what now seems to be exquisite timing, the venture into California.

title: Carey Signs gill to Ease Penalties Under the Drug Law
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday that he had signed a bill sharply reducing some penalties of the sixyearold drug laws developed by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: Production Outside OPEC
description: Spurred by the lure of high OPEC prices, nonOPEC producers have been increasing their production much faster than most experts thought possible just a few years ago, but they have not been able to close the gap created by the OPEC cutbacks. And in the United States, where drilling has been under way for more than a century, production continues to fall despite the higher prices.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: EAST HAMPTON THE John Drew Theater opened its summer season  under the fancy misnomer Stars of 79  with a Noel Coward rarity, Present Laughter. All Noel Coward plays are, of course, rarities. (Until 15 years ago, all of the 25 plays and musicals he wrote were out of print in this country.) But some are less known than others. Of the least known, Present Laughter may be the one most worth knowing or, certainly as the East Hampton production proves, worth renewing.

title: THEATER MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: There is an important point that resides in Roger Copeland's critique of contemporary American playwriting [Theater in the Me Decade,  June 3].

title: Gloria Barlow Wed To Allen Bernhardt
description: Gloria Chase Barlow, and Allen I. Bernhardt were married yesterday at the Chapel of Our Lady in Cold Spring, N.Y. The Rev. Zane Gordy of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Peekskill, N.Y., and Rabbi Frederick Dworkin of Ahavath Shalom in Brooklyn officiated at the ceremony, which was written by the couple.

title: Rock: No Wave Lounge Lizards
description: The Lounge Lizards, who were at Hurrah Thursday night and will be there again tonight, are one of the most amusing and effective representatives of the burgeoning no wave rock movement in New York. No wave is a reductionist genre in which rock's basics are so simplified as to preclude almost totally any hope of commercial. success. But that doesn't rob it of interest so much as transfer that interest into the realm of the artistic.

title: The Hour That Failed
description: The Backstage Battle Over Sex and Violence on Television. By Geoffrey Cowan. 323 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $10.95.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Dr. Charles I. Villiers was a tenured faculty member at two colleges: the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University, where he taught French during the day, and University College of Rutgers University, where he taught French at night. Neither school knew of his affiliation with the other. In January 1977, someone informed on him.

title: On Language
description: Appoint a committee used to be the political answer to charges of confusion and inaction. When the word committee became synonymous with delay in an impatient public's mind, a new, activesounding phrase was employed: The politician would crisply and authoritatively designate a task force, which had the connotation of aircraft carriers churning resolutely toward Midway Island and a rendezvous with destiny.

title: Farmer's Markets: Shopping Is a Carnival
description: DOWNINGTOWN, Pa.  The big crowds come on weekends. Thousands of Pennsylvanians, bypassing the shopping centers and supermarkets, pour into the Downingtown Farmer's Market here, a gigantic, white building four football fields long. It is the largest farmer's market in the country, a place where shopping is a carnival.

title: N.F.L. Summer Camp: Survival Training
description: Three. years ago, when he was 22 years old, Rich Mauti might have been asked what he expected to be doing this summer. I guess I would. have said working with my cousin, Bill Rocco, Mauti replied in an interview the other day. Bill's in the bagel business, Italian bagels. He has a couple of places upstate, Ithaca and Cortland. Mauti (pronounced MAWti) is a Long Islander who grew up in East Meadow and, as yet, he is not into bagels.

title: An Hour of News in Prime Time? Channel 5 Has the Scoop
description: The 30minute network newscast was born on CBS on the evening of Sept. 2, 1963. Back then, it seemed such a giant leap forward that President Kennedy appeared in an exlusive interview with Walter Cronkite on the premiere broadcast. Equally important, imitation being the surest sign of success, NBC began its 30minute evening newscast a week later, and ABC, then the anemic network, eventually followed suit.

title: Holly Dale to Be Married Sept. 1
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Dale of Pasadena, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Holly Moore Dale, to Ernst Semple Howard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard of Cincinnati.

title: GasOil Equation Much on the Mind Of Homeowners
description: Homeowners worried about the cost and availability of fuel oil this winter are urgently raising basic questions this summer about their home heating systems: Should they convert the entire system  both space heating and hot water  to gas? Or convert the hot water system alone to gas? Or do neither?

title: Audit Finds Abuse of City U. StudentActivity Fees
description: Hundreds of thousands of dollars in studentactivity fees at colleges of the City University of New York have been improperly accounted for and possibly stolen, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday.

title: With Love for His Calling
description: ICHARD EBERHART's best qualities are of the kind that put themselves right out where they can be perceived and admired; his collected prose about poets and poetry, culled from over four decades, is consistently openhearted, broadminded and largemannered. Many people, when publicly reflecting on their own

title: ABOUT CARS
description: SHORT of buying your own service station, there may be few legitimate ways of avoiding the agony of this'summer's gasoline squeeze. One thing you can do, though, is drive for better mileage, controlling the frequency, if not the intensity. of your aggravation.

title: Please, Amtrak, Stop in Yonkers
description: YONKERS MISSED opportunities seem to have become a commonplace occurrence for government bureaucracy. The absence of an Amtrak stop at the main Yonkers railroad station in the city's downtown district during this period of the gas crunch stands forth as a classic case of this condition.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Not long ago in this space, while discussing the new biography of Anton Webern by Hans and Rosaleen Moldenhauer, I speculated that the Austrian composer's ascetic and remarkably constricted approach to music might be traceable to his yearning for a return to a disciplined and orderly society. I even suggested that Webern's loyalty to Germany right up to his death in the closing days of World War II might in some way be relevant to his esthetic ideas. Further than that, I wondered if Webern's deification in advanced music circles since his death in 1945 might somehow be connected with deep fear of social and artistic disorder that his most committed followers shared with him.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today Hunting Hollow, Dix Hills, L.I. Pregreen, young and special working hunter; breeding, short stirrup; 9 A.M.

title: LEMMAS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: I enjoyed your graffiti article in the June 24 issue. A tolerant attitude alone is not the antidote to this esthetically ugly practice. Moreover, graffiti is first cousin to more violent and destructive vandalism.

title: Mayers Return for Forest Hills
description: HE remembers the endless practice sessions, awakening the boys at 4 A.M., an ungodly hour, so they could get the use of an indoor court in winter; the thousands and thousands of balls hit in the backyard of their home in Woodmere; the strategy sessions; the journeys by car and plane to tournaments around the country, and above all the extraordinary patience of his wife, their mother, as he molded their tennis careers.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: COPING with the gasoline shortage may have replaced bad weather as the yardstick by which Connecticut voters measure the effectiveness of their political leaders.

title: China to Publish Zhou's Works
description: HONG KONG, July 4 (Reuters) China plans to publish the collected works of the late Prime Minister Zhou Enlai, who died in 1976, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: Borg Takes Title 4th Straight Time
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 7Blom Borg is human, after all.

title: A Literary Pilgrimage to London's Bloomsbury
description: What cuts the deepest channels in our lives, Leonard Woolf once wrote, are the different houses in which we live. For Woolf, as for his wife, Virginia Woolf, and their circle of literary and artistic friends, many of these channels converged in the district of London that surrounds the British Museum: Bloomsbury.

title: The E. R. A.: A Push For Privilege, Not Rights
description: FOR more than seven years, the Equal Rights Amendment has been stalled short of ratification by the required threequarters of the 50 states.

title: Deaths
description: GLADSTEIN  Beniandn. Beloved husband of Lillian. Devoted and loving father of Arthur H. and Jerome. Devoted and loving fatherInlaw of Roslyn and Belle. Cherished grandfather of Michael, Deborah, Lois and Robert. Also survived by beloved sisters Ethel and Anna. Services today 10 AM at Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (oPP. RR Station), Great Neck, L.I.

title: In Victorian Cape May
description: CAPE MAY VICTORIAN architecture in America covers a wide range, from scrolls and weddingcake trim to cupolas, Corinthian columns, Gothic motifs and mansard roofs. In other words, just about everything that an imaginative carpenter or architect could turn out with the available tools and materials.

title: Man in the Middle
description: PRESIDENT CARTER and conservative Republicans are locked in another battle over the appointment of a Republican to the Federal Election Commission, and for the second time the man in the middle is a New Jerseyan.

title: Waylaid By Fame
description: Illustrated. 341 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $12.95.

title: Holdup Suspect Shot by Officer
description: An unidentified man was shot and critically wounded by a New York City police officer yesterday after he attempted to hold a woman hostage in the lobby of a transient hotel at 601 West 113th Street, the police reported. Officers said the suspect had tried to take a purse from the woman, identified as Nancy Addelson, 20 years old. When the woman resisted, they said, the man drew a knife. He was listed in critical condition at St. Luke's Hospital last night.

title: Shows and Events
description: Wednesday through Saturday Nostalgia show at Riverside Square, Route 4 and Hackensack Avenue, Hackensack. Fifty dealers. Free admission. Hours: Wednesday through Friday, 10 A.M.9 P.M.; Saturday, 10 A.M.6 P.M. For information, call (201) 2623063.

title: A Sense Of Loss
description: By Ernest Hebert. 255 pp. New York: Viking Press. $9.95.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: SHORT of buying your own service station, there may be few legitimate ways of avoiding the agony of this summer's gasoline squeeze. One thing you can do, though, is drive for better mileage, controlling the frequency, if not the intensity, of your aggravation.

title: Fashion
description: Designers now treat leather as if it were a fabric as supple as silk. The skins are wrapped at the waist, draped into folds, and gathered into ruffles. Here are some of the newest leather fashions saturated with rich colors for fall. hair and makeup,Rick gillete,location,ron nodon

title: Ron Franklin: Success, Failure and Confusion
description: STANTON, DEL. ALL day long the little blondehaired girls who lined the rail near the paddock stopped Ronnie Franklin, asking for his autograph, his mudspattered goggles, his riding whip. Before the eighth race, as the horses paraded from the paddock into a steady drizzle, one of the girls leaned over, patted the horse Franklin rode and said: Come on, Ronnie. You've got the horse.

title: MentalHealth Centers Seek Broader Base
description: WHITE PLAINS LATE last month, clients visiting the newly relocated County Mental Health Clinic at 45 South Broadway in Yonkers were surprised to learn that the facility had changed its name to the Community Service Center. The new name, which will soon be carried by the three other countymaintained mentalhealth clinics in Westchester, was the first public symbol of a recent internal reorganization by the Westchester County Department of Community Mental Health.

title: Can. Frank Langella ReVamp Dracula?
description: Frank Langella swings his trim 6foot4inch frame into a rear booth at a favorite coffee shop near his Upper East Side apartment. His hair is graying at the temples and his clothes are casually elegant, but his expression betrays a certain inner agitation.

title: Debra Bowis Bride Of James H. Veghte
description: Debra Bench Bowls, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Hans Bowls of Bethesda, Md., was married there yesterday to James Howell Veghte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Veghte 2d of Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Hall performed the ceremony in the Bradley Hills Presbyterian Church.

title: Muzorewa Due in U.S. Tomorrow to Defend Policy
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa of Zimbabwe Rhodesia will come here on Monday with the hope of presenting to President Carter his case for the removal of American sanctions and for formal recognition of his fiveweekold biracial Government.

title: 100 Years Old and Still Practicing Medicine
description: EAST ORANGE EVERY weekday morning, Dr. Walter L. Pannell walks the few blocks from his home to his office in a professional building here to see a few patients and to keep up with the medical literature that flows into his office.

title: How Jerseyans Pay for 3Mile Island
description: NEWARK WHEN Unit No. 2 of the nuclear complex at Three Mile Island near Harrisburg, Pa., came close to a meltdown on March 28, it set into motion a financial chain reaction that is still going on.

title: Harry Edmonds, Who Established International House, Is Dead at 96
description: Harry Edmonds, founder of International House, a worldwide network of residences and program centers for graduate students, died Friday at Clifton Springs (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 96 years old and had been in retirement since 1935.

title: ART VIEW
description: Abstract art now occupies such a large and powerful place on the American cultural scene, and continues  despite strong esthetic challenges from other quarters  to wield such an enormous influence in the realm of public taste, that for many people it is now difficult to recall a time when it was completely ignored or else roundly condemned as an artistic aberration.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The National Hot Rod Association will hold its annual Summernational championships at the Madison (N.J.) Township Raceway Park, beginning Thursday and concluding Sunday. The final on Sunday will start at noon.

title: Eileen Manning Is Married
description: Eileen Manning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred W. Manning of Leighton and Lake Naomi, Pa., was married yesterday to Leslie C. Quick 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Quick of Laurel Hollow, L.I. The Rev. T.G. O'Callaghan performed the ceremony in SS. Peter and Paul Roman Catholic Church in Leighton.

title: Miss McInemy Triumphs In U.S. Clay Court Tennis
description: PITTSBURGH, July 7 (AP)  Topseeded Shiela Mclnemy of the University of Southern California beat 14. yearold Kathy Horvath of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., 60, 26, 63, today in the women's singles tennis final of the national amateur clay court championships.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: Andy Lovin  Block Stor

title: Travels, Travails Of a Pole Vaulter
description: THE latest fiberglass vaulting pole bends into a bananashape. The idea of the fiberglass pole, which came into popularity in the early 1960's, is that the bend on the pole gives extra spring to the vaulter. An effort was made to limit the amount of bend in the pole, but this failed. Nowadays, the height a vaulter can reach is to some degree determined in laboratories by industrial chemists.

title: In Spain, Socialists Battle Over Control of Their Party
description: MADRID, July 7  A struggle is on for the control of the heart of the Spanish left, and a 37yearold politician named Felipe Gonzlez Mrquez is a key man in the struggle.

title: Notes Ways to Handle the Gas Shortage
description: One indication of mounting concern over gasoline shortages is the growing number of walking and bicycling tours being promoted around the country. Another is the lengthening list of telephone hotlines being set up to provide uptotheminute information on gasoline availability.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The key persuader of the Carter Administration's voluntary antiinflation plan, the power to withhold contracts from companies that won't comply with its price guidelines, survived court challenge last week.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  American Association of Motorcycle Road Racers program of 10 eightlap sprint races, at Bridgehampton (L.I.) Race Circuit, at 1 P.M.

title: Residents of Guam Gain a Vote For the United States President
description: AGANA, Guam, July 7 (AP) Residents of the United States Territory of Guam will be able to vote for President for the first time next year, even though their ballots will not count.

title: Wine Days of Wine and Prose
description: It's funny about wine people who drink it become charming; people who write about it become pedantic.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: This spring, China suddenly seemed less interested than it had been in fomign trade. NewsPapers carried stories about Chinese trade negotiators packing their. bags and going home, about China supposedly cancelling contracts it had already signed. In May and June, China seemed to toughen its bargaining position in talks with American. officials, and an impasse developed when Washington refused to accommodate China's requests for a higher textile export quota to the United States.

title: Douglass Warren Weds Nancy Shore
description: Nancy Anne Shore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Williath Francis Shore Jr. of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married there yesterday in St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church to Douglass Lory Warren. He is a son of Mrs. Charles Edison Lewis of Memphis, and the late Thomas Eugene Warren. The Rev. James E. Collins, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: A Cautionary Note on Wild Animals
description: On May 22 three young Montanans were hiking through the northcentral section of Yellowstone National Park when they came upon a grizzly bear and her two cubs. The bear charged the men and when one fell, bit him on the right thigh. When the downed man feigned death, the bear turned her attention to his companions, who had scrambled up trees. Unable to climb herself, the bear made a desperate lunge and managed to bite a second hiker on the foot before following her cubs into the brush.

title: A Grim Reminder of the Past
description: I THINK I now know what it is to be a Jew. If you grow up in New York City, as I did, you become a little bit Jeiish simply by some process of urban transference, just as you become a little bit Italian, a little bit Irish or a little bit black.

title: Have Blacks Done Better?
description: WASHINGTON  It may be that school integration should be undertaken regardless of whether it works in terms of academic achievement. It may be, as Robert L. Crain and Rita E. Mahard of the RAND Corporation have stated, that it is mistaken to judge the social and economic benefits of integration on the basis of whether children can decode a paragraph about the nesting habits of bluebirds.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WITH the cost of operating an airconditioner climbing higher than ever and with no end in sight for the continuing rise in utility rates, everyone who owns an airconditioner will want to do everything possible to keep operating costs down this summer.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Only medieval enamels, Gutenberg Bible and oldmaster paintings have brought more at auction than the $1.7 million paid two weeks ago for a giltencrusted French 18thcentury corner cupboard. That curvaceous LOUIS XV treasure, awash with gilded metal mounts called ormolu, and topped by a rococo clock, was the star performer in the spectacular sale of the Akram Ojjeh collection, all of which the Saudi Arabian financier purchased 19 months earlier from the artdealer Daniel Wildenstein.

title: A Play for Funds of the Sixties
description: One of the better buys for both individual and institutional investors these days, according to a number of Wall Street brokers and money managers, is a littleknown type of investment fund that offers security, levdrage, tax benefits  and nearly all the shares are selling at deep discounts.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Wallkill Kennel Club allbreed and obedience, Temple Hill School, Union Avenue, Newburgh, N.Y.; 1,163 dogs; 9A.M.

title: 3 Schmidt Homers Are Wasted
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (UPI) Mike Ivie drove in four runs with two home runs and a single tonight to spoil a threehomer performance by Mike Schmidt of Philadelphia as the San Francisco Giants posted an 86 victory.

Dr. and Mrs. Peter A. Tuby (Heidi Schiff) joyfully announce the birth of Kimberly's Sister, Jennifer Rachel, on June 28th in Boca Rah Fla. Delight. ed grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Richard Schiff and Dr. end Mrs. Joseph Tuby.

title: A Correction
description: A telephone number for Meson Granados, a Spanish restaurant inGlen Head that recently received a threestar rating in the Long Island Weekly section of The New York Times, was given incorrectly. The correct numbers are 6714020 an 6714021

title: Transit Officer Is Injured By Thrown Cinderblock
description: A Transit Authority police officer on duty at a Central Park West police station was struck with a cinderblock in what investigators said was an unprovoked attack yesterday by a youth who fled.

title: Odyssey in Innocence: Pennsylvania's Train. Museums
description: For boys who never found the exact electric train they wanted under the Christmas tree, and for girls who never Sound any train at all, there is still Pennsylvania. The Keystone State offers enough toy and real train attraclions within a weekend's drive of New York to compensate for many a disappointing Christmas morning.

title: LEITERS
description: To the Editor: I am surprised that not one of the contributors to Immortal Nominations (June 3) mentioned The Good Soldier Schweik and Catch22.

title: Births 5016
description: David and Linda, (rwe Lawton 1, New. ton Mass, announce the birth of JessiCa's brother, Joshua Daniel, on July 2, 1979. Happy grandparents are Louis and Anita Berkowitz of Roslyn Heights, L.1, and Benlamin and Marie Lawton of Harvard, Mass..

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: STOCKHOLDERS of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company learned last week that the utility had successfully raised trout, catfish, shrimp, lettuce and tomatoes in the warm effluent that flows from its Mercer generating station in Hamilton Townshin.

title: Friendly Towns Play Host to the Fresh Air Needy
description: As the train pulled out of Pennsylvania Station in New York City, headed for the North Jersey shore, 11yearold William Thompson looked out the tinted windows into the darkened tunnel. They shoot horror movies and stuff in train stations like this, he advised all who would listen.

title: Text of Eizenstat's Memorandum on Energy With Recommendations to Carter
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  Following is the text of the memorandum on energy, dated June 28, from Stuart E. Eizenstat, the White House adviser, to President Carter:

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Lobster House is as much a Cape May institution as the town's gingerbread Victorian houses. The family of Wallace Laudeman, originally from Philadelphia, began a fish business here in 1920, and it has since expanded into the present fishingdrinkinganddining enterprise that takes up most of Fisherman's Wharf. The most recent addition is a takeout counter for fried seafood; it is in the fish market adjoining the restaurant.

title: William Johnson, 54, Episcopalian Official
description: The Rev. William Alfred Johnson, public affairs officer for the Episcopal Church executive council staff in the Diocese of New York, died yesterday at his home in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 54 years old.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: IT has long been apparent to members of New York's religious community that Paul Moore Jr., Episcopal Bishop of this city, is in many respects a remarkable man. Since his youth he has been an advocate of liberal social views. His theological opinions are at the same time sound and generous. More important, he has been compassionate and supportive to minority groups in our society: the poor, 200 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $8.95. the black, the female, the homosexual. His new book a forthright account of his defense, on moral and humane as well as religious grounds, of his position on two matters that have gravely disturbed his and other churches: the ordination of women, and the ordination of one young woman in particular, Ellen Barrett, who had been candid about her lesbianism.

title: CARTER SHIFTS FOCUS OF TALKS ON ENERGY AND ECONOMIC ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  After discussions with a wide range of public figures at Camp Dayid yesterday and today, President Carter began to shift his deliberations from the politics of energy to the substance of energy and economic policy, orchestrating a series of meetings with Administration and outside experts over the next several days.

title: Camp Nevermore
description: TEN years have passed; 10 summers with the length of 10 long winters, and again I hear the sound of screaming 7yearolds, the plop of a wet mop against tile, the squeak of plastic garbage bags being rubbed together. The northern westchester day camp didn't pay me much for being a waiter in the summer of 69. What's more, I got a better tan when I handsanded school buses a few years later, and had more fun working in a French restaurant. But in a society where bringing home a paycheck is somewhat of a sacramental act, your first summer job is special.

title: Aboard the Bus, Another World
description: NOBODY rides the bus unless they have to, said a woman I know who is very attached to her car. Well, I've had to take the inelegant bus to work for nearly two years now, and I trust the bus.

title: At Home: The Tradesman As Philosopher-King
description: Them typed. Printed return addreses. Untouched by human hand. Vacuumpacked. Sterile. There was a time when it was cosidered impolite to type letter, when every carrier worth the name was a bit of a graphologist. I can remember perfumed envelopes.

title: A Surprise In Dallas
description: Sometime this fall, lawyers for the Dallas Independent School District will tell the Supreme Court of the United States that it was mistaken in saying in the 1954 Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka decision that Separate educational facilities are inherently unequal. That assertion isn't new. But the Dallas school district, the nation's eighth largest with almost 140,000 students, will come aried with what It claims is proof that racially segregated schools can be equal to integrated ones.

title: STAMPS
description: The United States is rendering philatelic tribute to a branch of knowledge as old as civilization itself: veterinary medicine, the medicinal science that deals with the prevention and treatment of diseases in animals. It is the first by this country and rare in the whole realm of philately.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Face the Nation: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader.

title: Vietnam BlamesU.S. And China For Exodus Of Indochina Refugees
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 7  Hanoi strongly denied responsibility today for the exodus of hundreds of thousands of refugees from Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia and, placed all blame on the United States and China.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. San Diego Padres, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 1 P.M. (Television  Channel 9, 1 P.M. Radio WMCA, 1 P.M.)

title: Andrei Voznesensky: Against Authority
description: HETHER or not Andrei Voznesensky is the best poet now writing in Russia can be disputed  he himself, along with many another, would give that title to Bella Akhmedulina  but what nobody would dispute is that Mr. Voznesensky is very good indeed at reading his poems aloud. He was a great success in his recent appearance at the Kennedy Center in Washington, and tie was in very good spirits when he passed through New York on the way back to Moscow. People had loved what he did, beyond a doubt, and they loved it all over again New York.

title: Their Movie Gives Students a New Image
description: MY name is Michael. I'm 18 and a student at ACES. This is a movie about me and my friends at ACES and about choices. I mean, some of it ain't too nice. Maybe some of my future ain't too nice either.

title: ARAFAT VIENNA VISIT STIRS ISRAELI ANGER
description: JERUSALEM, July 7  A visit to Vienna by Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, for talks with Austrian and West German Social Democratic leaders has caused dismay and anger in Israel.

title: Yankees Win, 83, From A's
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 7  When Reggie Jackson first played baseball in Oakland, Mike Morgan was in the second grade learning how to add and subtrart.

title: Headliners
description: Disco came to Peking's Temple of Heaven last week with Bob Hope's Fourth of July party. Peaches and Herb sang their No. 1 number Reunited, and Peaches, who in real life is Linda Green, was asked if she knew that the temple was the sacred spot where the Emperor sacrificed at the winter solstice to keep China from flood and famine for another year. It sounds like something heavy, she said.

title: World News Briefs
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 7 (UPI)  Mil. lions of Nigerians voted today in the first of five elections ushering in a democratically elected civilian government after 14 years of military rule.

title: THE ONCE AND FUTURE MET
description: Preserving the past is an unending job for the museum's conservators. Here they reveal their techniques, and the director discusses the dilemma being acquisitive. Second of a twopart series.

title: Motorist Critically Burned in Accident at Gas Pump
description: A 44yearold motorist buying gasoline at a Long Island service station was critically burned in a freakish accident yesterday when his car was struck by another automobile and pushed into gasoline pump, which ruptured and exploded in flames that enveloped him.

title: A Boy Whose Parents Fled U.S. To Avoid Transfusions Is Dead
description: SAUGUS, Mass., July 7 (AP)  A 2yearold boy whose parents fled Massachusetts to keep him from getting blood transfusions is dead of leukemia, his mother confirmed.

title: Piano: Gregory Thompson Debut
description: Gregory Thompson made his New York debut last Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. The young pianist studied at Limestone College in Sumter, S.C., and received his master's from the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore, where he has appeared in recital and with the Baltimore Symphony.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: It might seem odd to get excited over still another Sleeping Beauty at a time when there are so many versions on the boards. But then there are not so many productions of Sleeping Beauty to be excited about. Some are too heavy, some are too thin. These are not Weight Watchers categories but descriptions of the atmosphere created by a ballet that should be all atmosphere.

title: Connecticut/ThisWeek
description: AVON  Susan Carter, sculpture; Betsy Feick, prints and drawings, through July 21, Farmington Valley Arts Center, Avon Park North. Tuesday through Saturday 11 to Sunday 1 to 4. Phone 6781867.

title: U.SGREEK RELATIONS DETERIORATE SHARPLY
description: ATHENS, July 7  Greek and American officials here say that relations between Greece and the United States have deteriorated sharply in recent weeks, since Washington announced support for a new set of proposals on Greek reentry into the military wing of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Soviet Emigres Form an Orchestra
description: Diminuendo, yes? Like birds, said Lazar Gosman, lifting his violin to his chin and playing Vivaldi phrase. It sounded like birds. It should not be a simple piano, it should be something unusual, somethine unbelievable. He smiled.

title: County Confronts The Gas Crunch
description: WHITE PLAINS POLICE cars on the county's parkways are going to be spending less time traveling around on patrol and more time standing still at various strategic posts.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: THE irony of Princeton is that, despite being surrounded by areas with enough open farmland to gladden the heart of any speculative developer, there is virtually no elbow room in the 1.76squaremile borough in which to build substantial new housing.

title: Allocating the Shortage
description: The rules by which the companies must distribute their products during shortages were first formulated by the Federal Government during the Arab oil embargo more than five years ago, and were originally designed to protect dealers, not consumers. The regulators have amended them considerably since then as complaints have poured in from both buyers and sellers, but the regulations still fall short of satisfying everyone.

description: Hollywood was abuzz with the who, the why and the where of it all, and Wall Street was caught up with the what.

description: ROTTERDAM  The tanker was called the Kherson, out of Ventspils on the Baltic Sea, and she was heading for Rotterdam with 26,000 metric tons of Soviet gasoil, a heating fuel, on board.

description: JERUSALEM, July 7  Four persons were killed and 11 injured when a bomb went off today at Kafr Manda, a village northeast of Nazareth.

title: CRIME
description: The terrorists are at it again in THE VATICAN TARGET by Barry Schiff and Hal Fishman (St. Martin's, $8.95) and EARLY WARNING by Christopher Fitzsimons (Viking, $9.95). Arab terrorists, to be precise. What will happen if peace comes to the Holy Land and the Palestine problem is resolved? Novelists will have lost a surefire source of plots  a source that by now has assumed the proportions of heavy industry.

title: O.A.U. Ministers Open Conference in Liberia
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 7 (UPI) African nations began their annual review of continental problems today, plagued by deep differences over Egypt's peace treaty with Israel and the new black Government in Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

title: SPORTS

Events prompted one man out of a lot of angry aeonle to do something about the brawls, dirty play, senseless injuries and general brutality that have become so commonplace in scholastic competition.

title: LAWYER'S ADS UPSET WISCONSIN BAR UNIT
description: MADISON, Wis., July 7 (AP)  Clients who hire Ken Hur do not get just an experienced trial lawyer. They also get 300pound ham.

title: Congressman Returns Constituent's Barrage
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C., July (AP)  Representative Mendel J. Davis, Democrat of South Carolina, who has announced that he would not seek reelection, has taken off the kid gloves with a constituent. in a June 26 letter to Robert Payne, Mount Pleasant town councilman and member of the John Birch Society, Mr. Davis wrote:

description: have already been confined to specified areas, under penalty of fines. Meanwhile, in Denver, policemen rolled right along with a Skate for the Health of It rally.

description: For two decades, Netherlands Dance Theater has devoted itself to balletic innovation. It has encouraged Dutch choreographers, it has Imported guest choreographers from abroad and, although its dancers are classically trained, it has been sympathetic to modern dance. Each year, it offers minimum of eight premieres and in some years there have been a dozen or more.

title: OPPOSING CAMPS
description: Gardner: I try to find out, by honest thought, psychological response by psychological response, what it is that I can affirm as true and good  By telling a moving story  I'm trying for an affirmation that has something to do with how to live; Bill and other writers like him are trying for an affirmation of just living.

title: FOOD
description: GREAT NECK SALAD bars have become a, popular feature in many of the Island's restaurants. Now there's a place in Great Neck that's all salad bar, nothing else. It's called Salad Encounter.

title: IN THE NATION
description: On Nov. 3, 1969, in a televised. address justifying continuation of war in Vietnam, Richard Nixon produced his blood bath theory. A precipitate American withdrawal, he said, would permit the Communists to repeat the massacre that follovh4 their takeover in North Vietnatit. 1954, when they murdered more thari 50.000 people.

title: He Calls Cannibalism A LongLived Myth
description: IF you've been chuckling for years at cartoons showing an explorer in a cannibal's pot or shuddering over the thought that somewhere in the world there are peoples who like to dine on human flesh, chances are that you are a victim of one of science's most Prevalent myths.

title: Mondale, at Dinner, Defends Carter
description: BARDSTOWN, Ky., July 7  Vice President Mondale and Rosalyn!) Carter, standing in for the President, came to his defense tonight before an audience of Democratic contributors at a $100perplate fundraising barbecue.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE summer of 1979 is going to be remembered as the time the Island expanded, like a Thanksgiving Day balloon being filled with helium. The Island used to be something you could feel in your two hands, but now it is an oversized mass, impossible to grasp.

description: When Alexis Arguello defends his World Boxing Council superfeatherweight championship against Rafael (Bazooka) Limon of Mexico at the Felt Forum today, he will have more than boxing on his mind.

title: TV VIEW
description: Television is at its best, we are frequently being told, when it is offering live coverage of an event. This bit of conventional wisdom adds up to sappy nonsense. Of course, the claim does contain an element of truth. The lists of memorable live productions is long and dazzling: a man setting foot on the moon, a President resigning to avoid the ignominy of impeachment, an Egyptian leader making an historic trip to Israel, terrorism at the Olympic Games and, simply in sports, the Olympics themselves, the football Superbowls, and the baseball playoffs and World Series.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BEACH HAVEN (Surflight Summer Theater Engleside Avenue)  Chicago (througi tomorrow); The King and I, opens Toes day (through July 16). 8:30 P.M. $545.50. (609)4929477.

title: Nearly 60% of Japanese in a Poll Assert They Fear Nuclear Power
description: TOKYO, July 7 (UPI)  Nearly 60 percent of Japanese polled by a Tokyo newspaper said they feel fear at the very words nuclear power, the paper reported this week.

title: SUspect in L.I. Murder Is Captured in Nassau After Break From Jail
description: A 20yearOld accused murderer escaped from the Nassau County Jail in East Meadow, L.I., early yesterday but was captured in midafternoon at the home of a relative in Hempstead, L.I.

title: Anatomy of the Gasoline Crisis: Its Origins, Reality and Handling
description: An examination of the petroleum data published by both the Government and the oil industry suggests that the current shortage of gasoline stems more from the mishandling of available supplies than from a scarcity of crude oil.

Thornton of Lexington, Ky. The ceremony was performed in the Lower Brandywine Presbyterian Church in Centreville, Del.. by the Rev. Robert F. Scott.

title: Looking at Jackson From Another Side
description: IT was raining hard in Fort Lauderdale that day in March 1978 when Bea Dreesen and I arrived from New York to meet Reggie Jackson during spring training. Bea is president and I am executive director of the National ALS Fnuntlatinn.

title: The Nation
description: Since 1973, when the United States Supreme Court ruled that a woman has a constitutional right to abortion, the court has been telling states how far they can go in attempts to narrow the impact of that ruling. Last week came the latest round of instruction. The court declared unconstitutional, 81, a Massachusetts requirement that an unmarried minor who wants a legal abortion must first obtain the approval of a judge or her parents.

title: Family Hit by Fire Faces $33,000 Bill
description: WYANDANCH A 10member Wyandanch family, driven from home last April when a blaze that the police said was set by arsonists nearly destroyed the building, is still sharing a small house with another large family. And now it has another burden to contend with: a $33,000 hospital bill for the treatment of a child who was severely burned in the fire.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor: The article I.B.M.'s Long Reach (July 1) cites Gene Amdahl's distress, presumably at the what the article describes as the aggressive pricing of I.B.M.'s 4300 series, and at industry rumors of future products.

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: FILM VIEW
description: One of the many witty conceits in Moonraker, the new superJames Bond adventure, is that Drax, this film's equivalent to Goldfinger, should live in VauxleVicomte, the magnificent chateau that was built in 165659 by Nicolas Fouquet, Louis XIV's finance minister, and that was the prime reason Louis eventually sacked Fouquet and put him in prison. The Sun King didn't take kindly to Fouquet's spending public funds (i.e., the king's) to outshine him. Today, VauxleVicomte stands where it has always stood, near Melun, miles southeast of Paris, though in Moonraker we are given to believe that Drax  the wretch  has had it moved, brickbybrick, to California.

title: Closed Courts Are Usually A Weapon for The Defense
description: Last year, only three trials of serious crimes were completed in Seneca County, in upstate New York. The year before none of the 50 or so indictments handed up in the county led to trials. Nor were there any trials in 1976, the year that former Rochester police officer was killed in quiet Seneca County.

title: Japan Sends Aide to Mideast to Assure Oil Supplies
description: TOKYO, July 7  Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira sent a senior Cabinet minister to the Middle East today to seek direct oil supplies from Arab countries to replace dwindling supplies of crude obtained through international oil companies.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: SHORT of buying your own service station, there may be few legitimate ways of avoiding the agony of this summer's gasoline squeeze. One thing you can do, though, is drive for, better mileage.

title: The State Treasury and Social Issues
description: APASSAGE from Neil A. Jacoby's book, Corporate Power and Social Responsibility, is instructive.

title: Mary Noyes Is Fiance of Dr. Eric C. Martin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Noyes of Farmington, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Bright Noyes of Fort Lee, NJ:, to Dr. Eric C. Martin of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Archibald Martin of Lancaster, England. A Nov. 3 wedding is planned.

title: Colossus of British Politics
description: FEW politicians legends linger for very long after their own lifetimes. But Theodore Roosevelt's still does in tne United States, so does William Ewart GladStone's in Britain. They were, of course, very different figures, not least in the length of their careers. Theodore Roosevelt may have dominated politics for fewer than a dozen years; Gladstone in Britain much more like Franklin.

title: The Bounding Pound and North Sea Oil
description: Just three years ago, the British pound was in such a state of collapse that the subsequent dilemmas of the dollar seem like a case of the sniffles. Headlines then were calling the proud old pound mere confetti, and the whole British economy was written off as terminally diseased. On Oct. 26, 1976, the pound plunged a full five cents to $1.595; it sagged a few more cents, then began a long recovery.

title: Tamblyn, Miss Lachman Are Engaged
description: Announcement his been made by Ruth Mabee Lachman of New York of the engagement of her daughter, Linda Lee Lachman, to Ian Tamblyn, son of Leslie R. Tamblyn of Llanfairfuill, Anglesey, Wales, and the late Eva M. Tamblvn.

title: ANTIQUES
description: CONNECTICUT collectors will have a choice next weekend of visiting the 19th annual Country Antiques Festival at Riverton, near the Massachusetts border, or an exhibit of 18thcentury Connecticut furniture, provided by the Norwalk Historical Society, in the southwestern nart of the state.

title: Laura Howe Sets Wedding For Sept. 29
description: Nathaniel Saltonstall Howe of Lyme, Conn., formerly of Oyster Bay, L.I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Laura Williams Howe, to David Paul Danielson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Danielson Jr. of Surry, Me. A Sept. 29 wedding is planned.

title: Stalking the Killers
description: By Robert Tanenbaum and Philip Rosenberg. Illustrated. 343 pp. A Henry Robbins Book. New York: E. P. Dutton. $10.95.

title: ART
description: HEMPSTEAD SMALL museums are up against it, especially small university museums such as Hofstra's Emily Lowe Gallery that have to operate on extremely tight budgets. They never have sufficient funds for their exhibitions and even less money for their acquisitions. They must depf..nd on the generosity of city, state and Federal governments and on friends who make contributions of time, assistance and occasionally works of art.

title: Wendy Dixon To Be a Bride
description: Mrs. Lawrence H. Dixon of Lawrence, L.I., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Wendy Merritt Dixon, to Stephen Chase Fog, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario A. Fog of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.
