title: Deaths
description: SCHELLJoseph. Beloved husband of Marianne; devoted father of Felix and Kurt; loving grandfather. Services Tuesday, Juiv 10, 10:15AM at The Riverside, 76th St 16 AMsterdem Ave.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Market researchers. Mary Kuczkir and Roberta Anderson are two ladies with a lot in common. Both describe themselves as suburban housewives with husbands and children to cook for and clean up after. To help round out their families budgets, they both took jobs doing market research near their North Jersey homes; indeed, it was during one such stint that they first met back in 1973. Not Jong after, trying to kill time while they were on a boring assignment an Edison, N.J., drugstore, they borrowed several romances from the paperback racks and read them carefully. They both agreed that they could write better ones themselves and that they ought to get together and give authorship a try. They bought typewriter, taught themselves to type and set out to write the sort of story that their neighbors  young married women with romantic ideas in the back their heads and time on their hands  would Those two suburban housewives now share a career and a pseudonym. As Fern Michaels, they have published four Ballantine historical romances during the past three years. The latest two, Captive Passions and Captive Embraces, have a total 1,540,000 copies in print.

title: Gas Pinch Makes Broad Inroads
description: BOHEMIA WE E have lost June; we may lose July, Stanley Novak, owner of the Long Island Game Farm, told a group of business and political leaders last week. Compared with other assessments of the gasoline shortage's economic impact on the Island, his was not extreme.

title: PEKING SIGNS TREATY ON TRADE WITH U.S., LOOKS TO TARIFF CUT
description: PEKING, July 7  The United States and China signed a trade agreement here today. The accord, if endorsed by Congress, would provide the mostfavorednation tariff treatment long sought by the Chinese.

title: U.S.O.C. Training Centers Open to Foreign Athletes
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 7 (UPI) Robert J. Kane, president of the United States Olympic Committee, has announced that the Olympic training centers in Colorado Springs and Squaw Valley, Calif., will be opened to foreign athletes from emerging countries for training on a scheduled basis.

title: The Squeeze at the Refinery
description: One big reason that the shortage has been so acute of late is that it has been concentrated over just the last few months. During the first quarter, when exports from Iran halted, the oil companies delivered 2.2 percent more refined oil than they did during the first quarter of 1978, or roughly enough to meet overall demand. They did so by drawing heavily from their inventories.

title: Court is Firm On School Busing
description: In the rhetoric of contemporary politics, white flight has come to be thl inevitable result of busing. But the United State Supreme Court, which has not shown itself to be totally unmindful of public opinion, last week nonetheless announced its approval of broad busing plans mandated by lower courts for Columbus and Dayton, Ohio. The ruling cleared the way for renewed assaults on segregation in the North and West.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Just six years ago Peter Benchley was a struggling freelance writer and former reporter, obituary writer, television critic, onscreen television commentator and Presidential speechwriter. Today he is the author of the best seller The Island, and twotime former bestselling author Jaws, The Deep). From $150 a week and $600 in the bank he has gone to a neat haul of some $2 million for the movie rights to The Island, which Universal is said to have bought before the book was even written.

title: New York's New Foreign Bankers
description: When the Bankers Trust Company decided to sell most of its branch banks in a move to concentrate on corporate and other forms of banking, it wasn't Citibank or Chase Manhattan or Chemical that went after them. All the buyers so far are foreignowned banks in New York.

title: In Summary Helping Hands Are Offered to Vietnam's Refugees
description: A few hopeful glimmers appeared last week suggesting real help may be on the way for thousands of refugees from Vietnam. But hundreds trying to land in Malaysia in rickety boats still were being towed back into the South China Sea. Desperate to stay, one group of 400 smashed their engine and tried to burn their boat, but Malayasian authorities said they would be expelled in another boat.

title: The Skyscraper Business: Getting Off the Ground
description: From his office window, Tom Boland looks out over a muddy scene where machines are gouging out a 50foot hole for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company building. Across the street others are digging an even deeper hole for an International Business Machines Corporation building.

title: Inside and Outside Beleaguered Nicaragua, Strong Political Forces Are Poised to Claim Dominance
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  President Anastasio Somoza Debayle long ago predicted that political chaos and communism would follow his ouster. By hanging on to power while Nicaragua was torn apart by war, many of his countrymen feel he has done his best to fulfill his own prophecy.

title: Diverse Jewish Havtzrah Movement Grows
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 7 Rivkah Walton was reared as a nominally religious Jew, but she says that four years ago, as an adult, she set out one Friday evening for a synagogue in the Middle West for the purpose of saying goodbye to Judaism.

title: John H. Callan Is Fiance Of Janice Patricia Pitt
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Ray Pitt 3d of Port Washington and Montauk, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janice Patricia Pitt, to John H. Callan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Callan of Garden City and Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: POLITICS
description: ASUFFOLK County Democrat who was removed from the bench because of judicial misconduct is playing a major role in Dr. Martin J. Feldman's Democratic campaign for Suffolk County Executive and presumably would be top figure in a Feldman administration.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Robert Packard's Pisan misadventures in the article There's More to Pisa Than a Tower (Travel Section, June 3) reminded me of my experience at the Pisa Railroad Station. The nice woman at the information desk told me which bus to take td the Leaning Tower of Pisa, and soon I was off in a cloud of bus dust.

title: A Superfund For Toxic Waste
description: WASHINGTON SENATOR Bill Bradley and Dr. Glenn Paulson, assistant commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, have told a Senate subcommittee that the $1.6 billion hazardouswaste and oilspill superfund proposed by the Carter Administration would not be enough to help states like New Jersey.

title: U.S. Girl Swims to Record
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 7 (UPI)  United States swimmers and divers, led in a world record effort by 14yearold Mary Meagher in the 200meter butterfly, delivered more flawless performances tonight at the Pan American Games, taking the five gold medals available in the events.

title: Southern Conflict
description: Photographs by Earl Dotter. 228 pp. New York: Anchor Press /Doubleday. $10.95.

title: After All, Skylab Will Be the 6,812th Manmade Dropout From Outer Space
description: WASHINGTON  An 80foot high Thor Able Star rocket blasted aloft from Cape Canaveral on Nov. 30, 1960 and streaked into the stratosphere to the southeast, headed on course to place in orbit a Navy navigation satellite and a smaller spacecraft to monitor solar radiation. Two and a half minutes later, trouble developed in the rocket's second stage and the range safety officer beamed a command to the vehicle that blew it up  all over Cuba's Oriente Province, just north of the American base at Guantanamo Bay.

title: Passion Play at Oberammergau
description: The Passion Play of Ob.rarnmergau, held every decade in the West German Alpine village of Oberammergau, 55 miles from Munich, is scheduled to take place again in 1980, and a sellout has been predicted.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: ROWAYTON APREVIOUS engagement with some mackerel kept Bill Forelli from being immediately available. He said that he had planned to take his house out fishing, and when he returned there would be fresh mackerel for dinner cooked over the barbecue out back.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTON  Twentyfive years in the State Department, half each under the Democrats and Republicans, makes one cautious about sweeping generalizations regarding American foreign policy. One is not given to strong partisanship or suddenly to becoming giddy with irresponsibility. It is not surprising, therefore, to hear a friend say, after listening to a recent speech of mine assessing the Carter Administration's record in foreign affairs, that this observer had left the State Department, but the State Department had not left him.

title: Vietnamese Refugees Turn to Uninhabited Islands
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 7  Turned away from the Malaysian coast, Vietnamese refugees have begun landing by the thousands on isolated Indonesian islands where food and fresh water, are reportedly scarce and relief efforts have barely begun. spcieal to The New York Times

title: Padres Turn Back Mets by 113
description: The most exciting happening at Shea Stadium yesterday was not how the Mets lost, 113, to the San Diego Padre S.

description: Melissa Dent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Henderson Dent of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Edmund Brandt Wood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leighton Christopher Wood, also of New Canaan. The Rev. Walter H. Taylor performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien. Conn.

title: Book Tells Of Haven For Jews
description: WHEN Philip Hallie read a brief account of a small French village that had become the safest place in occupied Europe during World War H for 2,500 Jews fleeing to Switzerland and salvation, it was with a profound sense of personal and moral relief. and he went.

title: Fashion
description: Leather and suede offerings for autumn accentuate the softness of these materials with quilting and light padding. Even classic fashions take on a fresh look when these treatments and the latest colors are applied.

title: The Nisseauogue: A River That Manages to Cope With Man
description: SUNKEN Meadow State Park was laid out a number of years ago, before environmentalists finally made it known, and publicly acceptable, that marshes are not wasted land. So out of the marshes emerged a beautifully designed park and one obviously worth environmental protection, even though the land is not as it was before development.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: These recently published volumes are notable examples of a significant trend in paperback publishthey are valued as much  more, in some instances  for their illustrations and graphic design for their text.

title: The Coast Guard Steps Up Patrols to Stem the Illicit Flow From I South America
description: The coves, inlets and beaches of Long Island proved hospitable to rumrunners during Prohibition that it probably was only a matter of time before their modern counterparts, the drug smugglers, discovered them.

title: Boxing in Our Time Means Ali
description: Harry Markson, who once was reporter for. The Bronx Home News before he became the impresario of boxing for Madison Square Garden, was home on the Jersey Shore, the other day when Muhammad All announced that The Era had ended. Now if the historians need any help in assessing the era, Harry is ready.stalker. But Ali had the speed to stay away from him. And over 15 rounds, I think All would have beaten even Merciano. Sports of The Times For openers, he remembers when he went to Rome in 1968 to sign Nino Benvenuti and was introduced to Pope Paul VI as Harry Markson of Madison Square Garden. The Pope stepped back and exclaimed: Ah, Madison Square Garden- boxing.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Jones Beach Marine Theater's production this season of The Music Man can provide more than music to the ears of gasseeking motorists, under an agreement reached last week between the Long Island State Park Commission and its gasoline dealer.

title: A Stay for Main St.
description: SOME determined citizens in Waterbury have won another round in their court fight to prevent the demolition of buildings that they regard as reminiscent of a classic turnofthecentury Main Street

title: Study Fails to Pinpoint Cause of Coast Land Bulge
description: LOS ANGELES, July 7  An extensive 18month Federal investigation of the mysterious Palmdale bulge, a fluctuating 32,000squaremile land irregularity north of Los Angeles, has failed to pinpoint either its cause or its prospects.

title: No Pool Like Your Own Pool
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK THEY swim. They hold pool parties. They come home on the commuter bus and take quick dip before dinner.

title: Guerrilla Cattle Rustlers Hurt Rhodesian Economy.
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia By concentrating on cattle rustling, black nationalist guerrillas have undermined one of this country's most successful industries and seriously threatened a crucial source of foreign exchange.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Munich before 1914 was one of the great cities the Western world. It was wonderful to look at. Nothing was too big or too far away. There were still people around who remembered when Henrik Ibsen was Munich's dramatistinresidence and Richard Wagner was the composer whose new works Tristan and Die Meistersinger, to name two only would have their premieres at the Court Opera in Munich. To poets, novelists, dramatists, painters, sculptors and composers Munich offered an unlimited hospitality.

title: CALENDAR
description: Friday througn Sunday. Country Antiques Festival. Fairgrounds buildings, off Route 8, Riverton. 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. 36 exhibitors.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: For jazz buffs, this week is something of a jam session of casual, outdoor events where one can catch it for free. In more or less geographical order, at the Channel Gardens of Rockefeller Center, the Widespread Depression Orchestra will hold forth late Wednesday afternoon as part of the Music for a City Evening series. At Bryant Park behind the New York Public Library, brownbaggers may take their lunch to the tune of Sal Pace's Dixieland band on Monday, Tom Gambino's stage band on Thufsday and Sam Jacobs's jazzband on Friday. At Union Square Park on Wednesday at lunchtime, a group called Cookb6ok will send up their sounds. Moving further south, at Battery Park, Hakim Jami Ancestral Ties will perform from 11 until 2 Thursday afternoon, and, at Prospect Park, We Music House will be on deck on Friday for the picnic dinner hours of 6 to 9 P.M. Finally, the Jazzmobile sets out on Monday for a 7 P.M. concert by Houston Person and Etta Jones at St. Nicholas Ave. and 111th St., after which it will tout the boroughs Tuesday through Friday evenings (for further details, call 866The Art of Textiles.

title: Young People Just Can't Get jobs Anymore
description: CHICO, Calif.  In The Jungle, Upton Sinclair portrayed the influx of muscled young men into Chicago's slaughterhouses. The supply of immigrants continued, giving their strength for wages until they no longer had strength, then the wages were denied. And in Blood on the Forge, William Attaway described closed boxcars rattling north from Alabama, Tennessee and Kentucky filled with black muscle that would strain and break over open hearth furnaces in Pittsburgh. Man was a mule, easily trained, easily thrown aside. For every one who collapsed, crippled or dying, a dozen were waiting to take his place.

title: Reagan and Ford Lead Poll in Republican Race
description: The latest Gallup Poll indicates that Ronald Reagan and Gerald R. Ford are the leading choices for the Republican Presidential nomination, with Mr. Reagan widening his lead as the preferred nominee. me polling organization attributed the current standings of the two men to the close relationship between name recognition and nomination support.

title: Images, Artifacts, Entertainments
description: The beginning of her latest book Denise Levertov says: The poems I had been moving toward were impelled by two forces: first, a recurring need  to vary a habitual lyric mode  to explore more expansive means; and second, the decision to try to avoid overuse of the autobiographical, the dominant first person singular.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WITH the cost of operating an airconditioner climbing higher than ever and with no end in sight for the continuing rise in utility rates, everyone who owns an airconditioner will want to do everything possible to keep operating costs down this summer.

title: High Court Upholds Judicial Right To Close Hearings
description: It has to be small consolation to the news gatherers of the land that the United States Supreme Court will rule no more until this fall, for the court ended its 1978 term last week by drawing a still smaller circle around the First Amendment. It decreed that a trial judge has broad powers to close his courtroom whenever the defense claims that publicity could be damaging and the prosecution has no objections.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The nation's Bicentennial is ancient history now  or so it probably seems to most Americans. However, the Bicentennial file is far from closed at the U.S. Mint. Three years after the national observance of Uncle Sam's 200th birthday the Mint is still selling its mementos or mat occasion: sets of Bicentennial coins. To be more precise, it is offering them for sale this is one case where the supply far exceeds the demand.

title: A Life Worth a Biography?
description: About two years after Rolfe Humphries died of emphysema in Redwood City, Calif., I was dining with his wife, Helen, in New York. The subject had turned to the collection of manuscripts and letters that she was establishing in his name at Amherst College, his alma mater.

title: ProPalestinian Statement Failed at the Tokyo Summit
description: TOKYO  When the heads of the seven leading industrial democracies met to discuss economic dangers 10 days ago, Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira, their host, offered proposal for a joint declaration on the Middle East calling for recognition and respect for the rights of Palestinians.

title: Karen Avril Bride Of Joseph Hakim
description: The marriage of Karen Carlson Avril, an assistant vice president with Citibank's consumer services group, to Joseph E. Hakim, treasurer of Joseph P. Kennedy Enterprises, took place yesterday in Trinity Episcopal Church. The. Rev. Bruce Lederhouse performed the ceremony.

title: A Pinch in Time Makes Mums Flourish
description: AS if chrysanthemum were not enough of a tonguetwister for youngsters to learn, the flowers can also pose a dilemma for gardeners. There are just too many choices in this huge group of plants.

title: What's oing in NEWPORT
description: REVIVAL  Newport's renaissance began in the America's Cup summer of 1974, when the yachting crowd discovered the new cluster of restaurants and nightspots around Bowen's and Bannister's Wharves, but it was the Bicentennial that firmly restored the seaside city to its turnofthecentury position as queen of the summer places. In 1976 the Tall Ships came to Newport. Queen Elizabeth II and the Archbishop of Canterbury came to Newport. President Ford came to Newport and the Prince of Norway found a room on Bellevue Avenue. The television cameras came and recorded it all.

title: Laughter and Trembling
description: THE BEST OF SHOLOM ALEN:BEM Edited by Irving Howe and Ruth R. Wisse. 276 pp. Washington: New Republic Books. $12.50.THIS new collection of tales by the famous humorist Sholom Aleichem (the pen name Sholom Rabinowitz) consists of 22 pieces of varying length and quality, translated from the Yiddish by such distinguished writers and translators as Saul Bellow, Etta Blum, Frances and Julius Butwin, Isaac Rosenfeld, Miriam Waddington and Leonard Wolf, and prefaced by an excellent introduction, in epistolary form, by Irving Howe and Ruth R. Wisse. Like all good anthologies, it is more than simply a heterogeneous collection of pieces linked by common theme or author: it is also a statement, an argument, an attempt at redefinition.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A fourhour Arab Cultural Heritage Celebration, the first of a series of ethnic festivals in the county this summer, will be held today in Tibbetts Brook Park, Yonkers, beginning at 4 P.M.

title: Deaths
description: CRONINFrancis Leo, of Lauderdale by the Sea, Florida. Former resident of New York City. Died on Friday, July 6, 1979. Survived by his wife Dorothea (Nee Hese(ton, brother James of Boston, Massachusetts,: a niece and 2 nephews. Funeral Mass In Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Interment in Massachusetts on Wednesday, July 11, 1979. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Chapel Fund, Holy Cross Hospital, PO Box 23160, Fort Lauderdale, Fla 33307

title: Supply of Gas Rises, Lines Dwindle And Business Picks Up for Resorts
description: Gasoline was easily available and fillingstation lines almost nonexistent in the New York City area yesterday on what officials called the best Saturday for motorists in weeks.

title: Maria Colligan Is Married To Christopher Taylor 3d
description: Maria Teresa Colligan, daughter of Mrs. Richard V. Colligan of Darien, Conn., and the late Mr. Colligan, was married there yesterday to Christopher J. Taylor 3d of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Taylor Jr. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Christopher J. Whatley, the bridegroom's Latin teacher at Xavier High school in New York.

title: Frederick E. John And Suzanne Reed To Marry Sept. 29
description: Suzanne Reed, a member of the California Energy Commission, and Frederick Elias John, vice president and secretary of the Glenborough Management Corporation, plan to be married in New Haven on Sent. 29.

title: Letter
description: All hail to The New York Times Magazine for featuring the Muppets and their inspired creator (The Muppets in Movieland by John Culhane, June 10). In this socalled decadent world, what could be more reassuring than the national (and international) lunge for this unvulgar, unviolent creation.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: SHORT of buying your own service station, there may be few legitimate ways to avoid the agony of this summer's gasoline squeeze. One thing you can do, though, is drive for better mileage, controlling the frequency, if not the intensity. of your annravation.

title: BRIDGE
description: Dreams touch many diverse spheres. Ask a theologian and he might mention Jacob and his ladder. Ask a professor of English literature and he might cite Coleridge's opiuminduced dream that gave birth to Kubla Khan'. A musician would be reminded of Elgar's Dream of Gerontius'. And a student of modern history would no doubt think of the powerful rhetoric of Martin Luther King Jr.

title: JeanPierre LaffontSygma
description: In black leather jacket, John Gardner  novelist, critic, writer of short stories, children's stories, movie scripts, operas, poems  rides his Honda 750 near the State

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: CHILDRENS S BOOKS
description: Illustrated. 88 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $5.95. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: Mark of a Champion: Cool and Consistent
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 7 The Bjorn Borg chocolate bar sells for only 7 pence in the South Fields subway station in Withbledon, a suburb of London,. but there is no telling what the price will, be from now on after the Swede won his fourth straight Wimbledon tennis title today.

title: Television This Week
description: 12:30 P.M. (7) DIRECTIONS. The Boat PeopleNo Port in the Storm? A rebroadcast of a halfhour report produced last year about the plight of Vietnamese refugees who have fled their homeland in boats and the treatment accorded them by other countries.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WITH the cost of operating an airconditioner climbing higher than ever and with no end in sight for the continuing rise in utility rates, everyone who owns an airconditioner will want to do everything possible to keep operating costs down this summer.

title: Health
description: The Williston Park Community Pool in Mineola, N.Y., had no doubt been the scene of more daring displays of flesh than Barbara Damon's. Mrs. Damon, wearing a onepiece bathing suit and draped in a towel, was breastfeeding her 2monthold son. Michael. when the lifeguard confronted her, saying she was offending the other sunbathers. He told me that I could nurse my baby in the restroom, Mrs. Damon said. I said that the bathroom was not an appropriate place to nurse the baby.

title: Walking Cape Cod With Thoreau
description: Early in the morning of Thursday, Oct. 11, 1849, Henry David Thoreau set off to walk the 30 miles of uninterrupted beach facing the Atlantic at the tip of Cape Cod. A heavy rain was falling. Strong winds, the aftermath of a great storm, lashed the narrow strip of land known as the Lower Cape. Thoreau responded to the weather with the rising spirits of one who made it his business to deal forthrightly with nature. He unfurled his umbrella and strode on.

title: SUPPORT THE FRESH AIR FUND
description: SUPPORT THE FRESH AIR FUND

title: Rowland D. Miller, an Architect, to Marry Eleanor M. Bingham, TV Producer, in Fall
description: Mr. and Mis. Barry Bingham of, Louisville, Ky., and Chatham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Miller Bing. ham, to Rowland Dumesnil Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gordon Miller. also of Louisville. The wedding is planned for the autumn in St. Francis in the Fields Episcopal Church in Harrod's Creek, Ky.

title: THE SOUND AND FURY OVER FICTION
description: John Gardner wears a black leather jacket and dirty blue jeans when be rides his Honda 750 onto the campus at the State University of New York, in Binghamton, where he teaches creative writing. He is a small, potbellied man and his white hair falls over his shoulders.

title: SOMOZAS DEPARTURE REPORTED DELAYED
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 7 Despite Washington's apparent success in persuading President Anastasia Somoza Debayle to agree to resign, his departure from Nicaragua is being delayed by lack of progress in separate negotiations with a rebelbacked provisional junta, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Mass Transit Funds Hitting Roadblocks
description: WASHINGTON DESPITE the spread, especially in the Northeast, of long lines of motorists waiting to get gasoline, the Administration and Congress remain reluctant to increase financing for mass transit substantially above current levels. As a result, major projects involving new construction and new equipment in the Greater New York area face delays and even sidetracking.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The subject chosen by the CooperHewitt Museum for its third Immovable Objects show is as big all outdoors. Or almost. It is called Urban Open Spaces and it consists of a dozen exhibitions scattezed throughout Manhattan that deal with the subject of outdoor space in the city, from streets to rooftops. Tnhere is also a series of related lectures, walking tours, film showings and a number of what used to be called happenings, such as temporary street closings, that will continue through the summer until the middle of September.

title: Marriage Market Held in India
description: NEW DELHI, July 7 (AP)  About 10,000 marriages were arranged at weeklong Hindu convention with neither brides nor grooms present, according to United News of India. It said fathers had made arrangements at the annual marriage market attended by 100,000 Brahmans, members of the highest Hindu caste, at Saurath, in the state of Bihar. Women were barred from the convention.

title: Greenland: A Fringe Of Color on the Icecap
description: Do not believe those high school textbooks. Greenland is green, at least in the summer when most people are likely to go. Temperatures at this time of the year can rise to 68 degrees, perhaps warmer than many people kept their living rooms last winter.

title: Skylab ReEntry Time Is Refined
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI)  Space trackers reinforced today their estimate that Skylab would most likely crash on Wednesday, but they moved the probable time back slightly to 9:30 P.M. Eastern daylight time, when the space station would be crossing South America and heading over the Atlantic.

title: More GasLines Likely This Month
description: TRENTON THE 4.9 million New Jersey motorists who sat in gasoline lines during the last two weeks of June may have to do it again the last 10 days of July.

title: Shoestring TV Draws a Mixed Audience
description: NO ONE told Ken Taishoff, general manager of WTVG (Channel 68), that New Jersey has no television stations, as many residents have complained. Somehow, his 75,000 daily viewers did not get the word either.

title: DINING OUT; More Flavor Than Fire; Szechuan Palace
description: ZECHUAN PALACE in Syosset serves the food of Szechuan Province  or Sichuan, as it is nOw officially called  as well as that of several other regions of China. The palace part of the name is a bit of an exaggeration; this is a basically plain restaurant, a lowslung, sprawling building with only a halting effort made at interior decoration. Heavy, dark wood trim, carpeting and excessively bright lighting are as far as it goes.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: The news in books is nukes. If you want to argue about energy, build a reactor or break ground for your leadlined shelter, there are many books to tell you how. On the whole, the tilt seems to be against the development of nuclear energy and toward the search for alternative sources. Here with an assist from the American Bookseller list  are some of the books on both sides of the nuclear fence:

title: Design
description: One should never design with the Idea of being extraordinary, says John Dickinson, a San Franciscobased designer of interiors and furniture. Logic and function must always be the primary motivations and, having satisfied them, you can then take as many liberties as your own good sense allows. If you can bring a little of the time you live in and a sense of freshness to a design, without sacrificing proportion and good sense, you're on the right track. The interiors shown here amply illustrate Dickinson's design philosophy. They are logical, even deceptively precise, yet full of fanciful touches. They belong to a house which was built in northern California in the 1930's. The present owner, a plastic surgeon, gave Dickinson carte blanche to renovate but, says the designer, he had obviously done his homework, knew my work and what to expect.

title: DINING OUT; Improved Chinese Fare in Westport; The Peking Inn
description: WESTPORT HAVING sampled the fare at the Peking Inn shohly after it opened this year, and then having been back twice in recent weeks, we were pleased to discover that there have been some changes made  and for the better. A new restaurant needs time to shake down, to develop its own rhythm. The Peking Inn would seem to have done lust that.

title: Under18 Set Comes of Age On the Floor of the Discotheque
description: THEY wear spike heels, satin pants and sequined tube tops; their partners shirts are open to the waist. When the D.J. puts on Donna Summer, they mouth the lyrics to Hot Stuff as they move ecstatically under the flashing lights. But they end their nights around the same time as their adult counterparts are just beginning to step out, and they do not have to worry about making a graceful or impressive exit. About midnight, they cluster around the pay phone and call their parents to pick them up and take them home.

title: Maybe It's Time to Take Libya More Seriously
description: WASHINGTON  Americans don't know much about the square block of North Africa between Egypt and Tunisia that is mostly desert and oil wells, sparsely peopled by two and a half million Arabs, Bedouins, Berbers, Tuaregs, blacks and others known by the name of the ancient tribe of the Libyans. But one thing is certain about Libya  like no other country on earth, it represents every wickedness that Americans can imagine.

title: On the Gas Line
description: The energy crisis is not all bad. Meditation is making a comeback. Waiting on a gas line is the ideal setting  no television, no radio, just a sports page for contemplation and reflection. Here are some thoughts from the gas line, beginning with the most vital issue of the week  the starting lineups for the AllStar Game in Seattle a week from Tuesday night. With both Rod Carew of the Angels and Ted Simmons of the Cardinals unavailable, this was one man's ballot: National League  first base, Pete Rose, Phillies; second base, Davey Lopes, Dodgers; shortstop, Craig Reynolds, Astros; third base, Mike Schmidt, Phillies; catcher, Johnny Bench, Reds; outfield, Dave Kingman, Cubs; George Foster, Reds; Dave Winfield, Padres. American League  first base, Carl Yastrzemski, Red Sox; second base, Bobby Grich, Angels; shortstop, Roy Smalley, Twins; third base, Graig Nettles, Yankees; catcher, Brian Downing, Angels; outfield, Fred Lynn, Red Sox; Jim Rice, Red Sox; Don Baylor, Angels.

title: News Guild Refusing U.S. Financing toAid Latin American Drive
description: The Newspaper Guild, in a reversal, has decided to ban the acceptance of any United States Government funds to support unionizing activities in Latin America, scuttling a program begun there last May.

title: Radcliffe And After
description: By Rona Jaffe. New York: Delacorte Press. 338 pp. $9.95.

title: Financing the Arts: A Thorny Problem
description: WASHINGTON ALTHOUGH the National Endowment for the Arts reversed itself late last month and approved a request for $105,000 from the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, the initial rejection did more than embarrass Governor Byrne's administration by making New Jersey the first state to be turned down in the endowment's history.

title: The World
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Nigeria's 48 million registered voters participated in an election yesterday for the first time in 13 years, choosing members of a federal Senate. four additional elections, one each week for the next month, Africa's most populous nation will choose civilian leaders replace the soldiers who have ruled here since 1966. On Oct. 1, the civilians  a president and vice president, 19 governors and nearly 2,000 legislators  are scheduled to swear their allegiance to a Constitution based on that of the United States. What happens after that is anybody's guess and everyone's concern.

title: Gas Crisis Creates BackyardGadget Boom
description: IT'S time to turn on the bug zapper, light the gas under the lava, step off the prairie film and jump into the Jacuzzi. These are this year's version of last year's outdoor living comforts. and replace insect repellent. charcoal hibachis, flagstone terraces and the oldfashioned swimming pool where the water just sat still until someone jumped in.

title: Editors Choice
description: BLOOD OF SPAIN, by Ronald Fraser. (Pantheon Books, $15.95.) The feel Spain during the Civil War captured through hundreds of interviews with people who were there; a moving and original work.

title: GARDENING
description: AS if chrysanthemum were not enough of a tonguetwister for youngsters to learn, the flowers can also pose a dilemma for gardeners. There are just too many choices in this huge group of nlanta.

title: VOYAGER 2 CAMERAS FOCUS ON VOLCANOES
description: PASADENA, Calif. July 7  When Linda Morabito looked at the display screen of her computer terminal the other morning, she saw a familiar sight and felt as if she was coming home again.

title: ART
description: WESTPORT THERE may come a time when Connecticut residents no longer feel a pressing need to visit New York for contemporary art. Not only is there an abundance of talent working and showing locally; artists normally associated with the New York scene are increasingly appearing outside it.

title: Guardian of the Old Ways
description: 269 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Cloth, $10.95. Paper, $4.95.C. S. LEWIS was a writer of children's fiction, adult fantasies, Christian polemics and literary criticism  varieties of writing that wouldn't seem likely to lead to the bestseller lists. Yet today, years after his death, his books are still selling two million copies a year. Who can his readers be? Most them are probably children, working their way.

title: Continued
description: When the Foreign Relations Committee opens ratification hearings tomorrow on the new strategic nuclear weapons treaty with the Soviet Union, Senate undecideds' who will decide its fate will be listening carefully. The issues are so complex that Senators who have studied SALT II extensively will be particularly influential. Three of the most expert are Senators Gary Hart, Democrat of Colorado, who favors the treaty, Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, opposed, and Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, undecided. Senators Nunn and Hart are on the Armed Services Committee which also will hold hearings on SALT as will the Committee on Intelligence where Senator Garn is a member.

title: Miss Debevoise Becomes Bride
description: Josephine Richards Debevoise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dickinson R. Debevoise of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Ralph Newton Davies, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Davies of Cranbury, N.J. The Rev. Joseph D. Herring performed the ceremony in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Millburn, N.J.

title: Her Portraits Make a House a Home
description: PEOPLE EOPLE who see me house portrait sometimes call me Grandma Moses, said Regi Klein, but I'm not that old, and I paint in a very different and personal style. What I seem to be doing is giving people a tangible representation of their world, life style and accomplishments.

title: Two Builders Challenge Tradition
description: TED KASPER and his wife, Renee, have lived in their 10room Oceanside home for the last 17 years. Now, with their youngest child away at college, they are beginning to think of making the move to a smaller home. But where?

title: James Bond, Crop Forecaster
description: WASHINGTON  In the cool, dark hours before dawn on Wednesday, seven men will quietly leave their homes and hotels and slip through the capital's deserted streets to their rendezvous.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Arthur Miller's The Price, now in revival at the Playhouse, must be one of the most lopsided plays I have ever seen, and the truly curious thing about it is that the lopsidedness works. Works to the play's advantage, I mean, shoring up what it should be tumbling over. A strange place, the theater, baffling to its core.

title: Slow Going for Mass Transit
description: WASHINGTON DESPITE the spread of long lines of motorists waiting to get gasoline, the Administration and Congress remain reluctant to increase masstransportation financing substantially above current levels. AS a reswt, major projects involving new construction and new equipment in the greater New Yorknorthern New Jersey metropolitan region face delays and sidetracking.

title: Joan Mary Clawson Is Married
description: Joan Mary Clawson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Clawson of Canandaigua, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Geoffrey Stevenson Poor, son of Mrs. Henry V. Poor of Port Washington, L.l., and the late Mr. Poor. The Rev. James Salters performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Toledo Walkout Last Week Was an Example of the New Militancy
description: WASHINGTON  When police and firemen Toledo, Ohio went on strike for higher pay last week, they didn't simply hang up their uniforms and shuffle out to a picket line. Instead, they switched on the flashing lights of their vehicles, locked the doors and walked off to. let the batteries run down. In more ways than one, the action symbolized the increasing friction between uniformed public servants and the municipal governments that employ them.

title: Rock's Golden Oldies Revived With Pizazz
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH FOR the last four years, Wilson's Garage, one of Westhampton Beach's bestattended music clubs, has kept a slot open for the Fabulous Greaseband Rock n Roll Revue. Although the eightmember group, which hails from Trenton, doesn't play anywhere else on the Island, it has garnered a substantial local following and a strong enough wordofmouth reputation to insure capacity crowds almost every Wednesday night.

title: Avram Katz Weds. Nadine T. Mansky
description: Nadine Toby Mansky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Mansky of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Avram Yitzchak Katz, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Leon Katz of Clifton, N.J. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at Temple Ades Israel in Passaic, N.J., where Dr. Katz has been the spiritual leader for 40 years.

title: Senator Baker, on Campaign Trip, Stresses Value of Politician's Role
description: DES PLAINES, Ill., July 6  Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. is running for Plesident on the theory that the vogue of the nonpolitician is over in Atneiica and that the country is ready for a, professional, a President who is proud of being a politician.

title: The City
description: Carrying a black coffin, a group of auxiliary police officers marched in front of the New York City office of Governor Carey yesterday to urge him to sign legislation that would permit the civilian forte to carry nightsticks.

title: Miss Woodhead Wins 5th Gold
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 8  It finally dawned on Cynthia (Sippy) Woodhead with about 25 meters left. She was in front, so close to a fifth gold medal in the Pan American Games that she could feel it.

title: Utilities Fighting Oil Cost By Burning Natural Gas
description: Power companies in the metropolitan area have begun burning natural gas to produce electricity in a shortterm attempt to reduce their dependence on oil and to cut generating costs.

title: Confusing Prescription for Darvon
description: The ruling by Secretary Califano of H.E.W. on the popular painkilling drug, Darvon, is enough to give users a nagging headache. Mr. Califano said he would not ban the drug or restrict it, because he lacks enough evidence of hazard or abuse to do so. At the same time, he urged patients, doctors and pharmacists never to use Darvon unless there is no alternative, and then only with care. Since there is almost always an alternative, ranging from aspirin to codeine, his words came close to calling for a ban.

title: John B. Lanigan, 69, a Consultant To the TV Industry on Production
description: John B. Lanigan, a retired television production consultant, died Saturday at his home in Irvington, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: Life Goes on Placidly in Maldives After the End of OneMan Rule
description: MALE, Maldives  It appears to have been little noticed elsewhere in the world, but the Republic of Maldives has had new Government since November, ending one of the longest stretches of oneman rule anywhere. Ibrahim Nasir had been in charge, as Prime Minister or President. since 1954.

title: TV: Sportscasters Found Wanting  Restraint
description: SPORTS fans must be grateful, really, to NBCTV for carrying live the Wimbledon Lawn Tennis Championships on Saturday morning. The final between Bjorn Borg and Roscoe Tanner proved to be superb tennis, a demonstration of extraordinary skill that each player could look upon with pride. Borg's uphill battle to win made the event all the more excitina. Thank you. NBC.

title: MozartWheeler Opera to Open Kennedy Season
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 Hugh Wheeler thinks Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart would have been pleased. At least, says Mr. Wheeler, the threetime Tony Award winner who has just written a new book for Mozart's opera The Impresario, whether I have done it well or not, I think Mozart would have loved it because he loved things to be funny, and we are not in any way outraging his material.

title: Interest in Unionizing Increases Among Female Office Workers
description: Employers be forewarned. The poor little working girl has some powerful new friends.

title: Don Drysdale's `Inside Pitch
description: BATTING averages are up. Home runs are up. When asked why, most baseball people believe that the ball is livelier. But to Don Drysdale, another factor exists.

title: Mindy Goldfischer Bride of M.L. Innerfield
description: Mindy Ann Goldfischer and Michael Lee Innerfield were married yesterday at the Tammybrook Country Club in Creskill, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Solomon Rothstein.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Koch's Pledges of 1977: Not All Became Reality
description: Tucked away in a City Hall file is document marked basic speech, ninepage compilation of catch phrases that Edward 1. Koch, mayoral candidate, used in his 1977 campaign.

title: Manila's Nuclear Debate
description: MANILA, July 8  The Philippine Government commission's inquiry into the safety of the Westinghouse Corporation's nuclear power plant in the Bataan Peninsula west of here is producing a classic confrontation between technological experts on the one hand and a wary public, or its representatives. on the other.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Takeover Bid Gains
description: The Transamerica Corporation, a diversified financial and entertainment corporation with headquarters in San Francisco, said that, under its tender offer, it had acquired more than 4.3 million shares of the Interway Corporation's common stock as well as notes convertible into almost 400,000 shares, giving it about 96 percent of all shares outstanding.

title: Give a Man a Fish? No1. Teach a Man to Fish
description: Congress is right to insist that development assistance help the poor, rather than a narrow elite. But that worthy end has been undermined by highly inefficient means. Instead of rapidly building local manpower capable of tackling rural development priorities, the United States has flooded the developing world with expensive American technicians. These tecnnicians nave not had and cannot have a meaningful, longterm impact on the staggering problems afflicting the impoverished rural masses; only skilled nationals and national institutions can achieve that impact. It would be good to remember the Chinese proverb, Give a man a fish, and you feed him fora day. Teach a man to fish, and you feed him for a lifetime.

title: Yale Junior Varsity Is Victor at Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, July 8  The 131st rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta concluded today in weather that was as sparkling as the champagne that was quaffed by the winners In the steward's Enclosure.

title: Tour de France: A Rider's stoty
description: DEALIVILLE, France. July, 8  Paul Jesson was tired and sick when he arrived in this seaside resort in Normandy last week, and he seemed to be in the right hotel for treatment and regabilitation. Across the street day a complex of thermal baths Beyond them was the English Channel, calm and moderately warm. Next door was a gambling casino, and there also was a series of restful concerts and bridge. and chess tournaments.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Parking regulations return to normal today, with alternatesideofthestreet rules in effect in all boroughs.

title: EXPRESS CONCERN OVER ISRAELI SETTLEMENTS: Chancellor Bruno BratsIcy of Austria, center, and Willy Brandt, former West German Chancellor, meeting with Yasir Arafat, head of the P.L.O., in Vienna. Page A9.
description: VIENNA, July 8  Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria and former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany concluded talks tonight with Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and issued a communiqu expressing extreme concern over Israel's settlement activities in the occupied territories.

title: Inventors Need Carrots
description: Patent applications, with lawyers fees, drawing fees, patent searches, and typing can cost anywhere from $500 to $2,000, a sizable amount to put into a very uncertain dream.

title: Bicycle Maker Consents To Ads for Safety on TV
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP)  Under the pressure of a Federal agency, one of the largest manufacturers of bicycles agreed today to produce television messages promoting safe riding.

title: Notes on People
description: One casualty in the perennial siege of Beirut was Mady Imad, a 7yearold boy whose pelvis was broken when a 100pound sandbag fell on him in a bomb shelter. The result was a severely damaged urinary tract that left doctors in Lebanon baffled as to how to repair it and the child with the prospect of having a'serious impairment for the rest of his life.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 8 (AP) Judy Geer, the women's rowing coach at Dartmouth and Jan Palchikoff, who handles the crews at Amherst University and Smith College, scored a onehalf length victory over Lisa Hansen and Liz Hills in the National Association of Amateur Oarsman world women trials for double scullers. The victors rowed the 1,000meter course in 3 minutes 27 seconds.

title: Portland, Its Energy Supply Threatened, Planning Drastic Measures for Conservation
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 8  President Carter's moral equivalent of war may have found its front line in this Pacific Northwest city where officials are drafting what may be the country's most comprehensive energy conservation regulations.

title: Bahrain Bans New Banks
description: BAHRAIN, July 8 (Reuters)  Bahrain announced yesterday that it would ban the opening of new banks at least until the end of the year. The secretary general of the Bahrain Monetary Agency, Sheikh Ibrahim Bin Khalifa alKhalifa, told reporters that the moratorium was imposed because the regional market already had enough banks. Bahrain currently has about 70 banks, including more than 50 offshore banks, with assets estimated in 1979 at about $23.4 billion.

title: Last Week's Active Issues
description: For the week ended July 6, 1979

title: Skylab's Control Post Is a Makeshift Affair
description: HOUSTON, July 8  Flight controllers whose job is to keep the Skylab space station away from heavily populated areas as it plunges toward Earth this week are working in a secondstring, juryrigged command center that is a bit primitive by the standards of the space program's glory years.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON THE Carter Administration will officially acknowledge in the midyear revision of its economic forecasts, due this week, that a recession is under way as a result of higher oil prices and that unemployment will now move up sharply over the next 18 months. Administration sources say.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: What One Reactor Makes a Year
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  The volume of various radioactive wastes produced by commercial nuclear reactors is considerable.

title: Cosmos, in Brcic, Have Emerging Star
description: BOSTON, July 8  For the time being, the goalkeeping job of the Cosmos, a team dominated by foreign stars, belongs to a 22yearold native of St. Louis.

title: Orioles Triumph, End Skid
description: In April, May and June, The Baltimore Orioles grudgingly lost a total of 24 games. In the first seven days of July they added five losses to their total, but they reversed their fortunes yesterday with a 32 victory over the California Angels.

title: Gains Affirm Indians' Rights Demands
description: BOSTON, July 7  A decade after the Indian rights movement began to focus attention on Indian problems, tribes from Maine to California are beginning to make major gains in the courts and at the bargaining tables.

title: Rachel Nili Rosen Bride Of S. P. Hanau, Student
description: Rachel Nili Rosen and Stuart P. Hanau were married yesterday at the Lincoln Square ,Synagogue by Rabbi Moses Steinberg, chief of the Beth Din of America.

title: KHOMEINI SUPPORTER IS KILLED IN TEHERAN BY MOSLEM RADICALS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 8  A wellknown supporter of Ayatollah RUhollah Khomeini was shot and killed here early today.

title: A Dilly of a Story Turns Sour
description: A bizarre story telling how a Connecticut biochemist had developed red, white and blue pickle complete with about 50 stars found its way onto the national news wires of United Press International and the airwaves of radio and television stations across the country yesterday.

title: Nelson Triumphs In Western Open
description: OAK BROOK, Ill., July 8 (AP) Larry Nelson hit a 9iron second shot two feet from the cup on the first playoff hole and then sank the putt for a birdie to defeat Ben Crenshaw and win the $300,000 Western open golf tournament today.

title: Michael Wilding Is Dead at 66; Briton Starred on Stage and Screen
description: Michael Wilding, the actor, died yesterday, 12 hours after he was injured in a fall on Saturday at his country home in Chichester, England. He was 66 years old and had been in failing health for some time.

title: ESSAY Carter's 4th of July Panic
description: WASHINGTON  The hollowness at the core of the Carter Administration was revealed in three events surrounding the panic that gripped Mr. Carter on Wednesday, the Fourth of Tiviv

title: A Fading Fleet Sails Brightly In Connecticut
description: STONINGTON, Conn., July 8 When you have anything to do with the sea, you pray, James Henry said. We pray that we will come back. Some of us don't.

title: In Cafro, Dance of a Cult Pacifies. Demons
description: CAIRO  A greeneyed young woman rose from the dirt floor, tossed back her long black hair and yielded her body to the devil who possessed her. Her hands were stained with henna for luck, and golden bracelets jangled on her slender arms as she swayed from side to side.

title: Deaths
description: SCHMIDT Vivian J. Of Madison N.J.: formerly of N.Y.C., suddenly on July 4, 1979, wife of the late George Schmidt, survived by two sisters, three nephews, two nieces, seven grandnieces and grandnephews. Funeral services will be held at William A. Bradley and Son, Funeral Home, 345 Main Street, Chatham, N.J. Tuesday July 10 at 11 A.M. Friends may call Monday 3.5 and 79 P.M.

title: G.M. Bringing Austria Into Auto Industry
description: VIENNA, July 8 For three years, Austria has been trying with increasing desperation to break into the big time of the European automobilemanufacturing industry.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, July 8 (UPI)  The French Government announced today that it would send Deputy Foreign Minister Olivier Stirn to Vietnam on Wednesday to urge Prime Minister Pham Van Dong to halt the outpouring of refugees in Southeast Asia.

title: Tax Cut Held Likely As Stimulus
description: If the economy continues to slow, Congress is likely to try to stimulate by cutting taxes, the Conference Board said yesterday in an analysis of the Federal budget.

title: Commodities
description: WHEN Moscow said last week that it would invite American garment makers to produce jeans in the Soviet Union, logic suggestsd that the move would be bullish for cotton. After all, the more cotton used by the Russians, who are big producers and exporters of the fiber, the less competition for American extorters.

title: Books of The Times
description: MANYHUED but identical in their design, Lionel Trilling's collected works are now being issued in a uniform edition that radiates intellectual gravity; they remind one of those austere Pliade editions in which the French classics are enshrined. The portent of these volumes is clear; Trilling has become, since his death in 1975, a modern classic.

title: Jazz: Tony Williams's 5
description: TONY WILLIAMS had achieved greatness as a jazz drummer by the time he was 17 years old. His accompaniment and solos with the Miles Davis quintet and on a numher of Blue Note albums from the middle and late 60's are almost unfailingly ingenious in their exploitation of the drum kit's timbre] resources and their orchestration of densities and silences. Coming up with an encore hasn't been easy; Mr. Williams was at the Bottom Line over the weekend at the helm of a new quintet, still trying.

title: Chinese Grain Yield Rises
description: TOKYO, July 8 (AP)  Grain output in China has increased 7.8 percent over the past year, yielding a record 309.75 million tons, the official Chinese news agency Xinhua reported. It attributed the bumper crop to farm improvement projects and water conservation, which have tripled China's irrigated land area since the Communists took over in 1999

title: Race Is on to Overtake Ford Motor
description: Our job is to be No. 1 outside the country as well as inside the country.

title: Spain Besieged by Foreign Investments
description: MADRID, July 8  After living four decades with isolated, protectionistminded capitalism, Spaniards have been mildly stunned by a recent, seemingly unending succession of international bankers and business executives  most recently, David Rockefellerannouncing that they are opening branches or making investments here.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: A Vote for the Federal President
description: A strong alliance of reformers is again pushing the idea that we elect our Presidents by direct popular vote, without the filter of an Electoral College. Counting every vote equally sounds so simple and attractive that normally cautious politicians find it difficult to resist. A Constitutional amendment to abolish the College reaches the Senate this week with an outside chance of obtaining the necessary 67 votes.

title: Sally Canter Bride Of Jerrold GanfieId
description: Sally Jacqueline Canter, a certified public accountant, and Jerrold Joseph Ganzfield, a New York lawyer, were married yesterday at the Copley Plaza Hotel in Boston. Rabbi Terry Bard of Boston performed the ceremony.

title: Walker Victor in Hurdles
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 8 (UPI) The United States and Cuba split their first two confrontations in their Pan American Games track competition tonight when James Walker sped to victory in the 400meter hurdles and Silvio Leonard of Cuba beat Harvey Glance in the 100meter dash.

title: Saudis Said To Increase Oil Output
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 8 (AP)Saudi Arabia increased its crude oil production by one million barrels a day as of July 1, the Middle East Economic Survey says in its edition dated tomorrow.

title: Knight Again In Trouble
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 8 (UPI)  Bobby Knight, coach of the United States basketball team at the Pan American Games, was the center of controversy again today. He allegedly struck a policeman at the team's practice session.

title: The Region
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  Federal investigators are looking into the awarding of construction, labor and hauling contracts for Hempstead Town's privately built $110 million garbagerecycling plant.

title: Rosberg Captures Watkins CanAm
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 8 (AP)  Keke Kosberg, who held the pole position, led from start to finish today for an easy victory in the CanAm sports car event at the Watkins Glen Grand Prix roadracing course.

title: Study Opposes More Refineries
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI)  Itmakes little sense to build new oil refineries in the United States at a time when existing ones are underutilized and crude oil is becoming scarcer, according to a General Accounting Office report released last week.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300, NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500 SUFFOLK CO (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3467767.

title: Governor Signs HealthBill Package
description: ciovernor Carey rias signed a package of healthrelated legislation, including one bill regulating emergency ambulance services and another permitting physicians to accept fees for private patients in public hospitals, he announced yesterday.

title: How  Many More US:Opens for Miss Lopez?
description: Nancy Lopez is only 22 years old, but time may be running out on her chances to achieve distinction as one of the three or four best women who ever played golf.

title: Critics Notebook: Berenice Abbott
description: WHEN the American photographer Berenice Abbott turned up in Paris recently to attend the opening of a show of her work at the Galerie Zabriskie, it was something of an event in French photographic circles. The pictures on view were all portraits that Miss Abbott had made in Paris in the 20's. Many of the subjects are renowned writers  among them, Jean Cocteau, James Joyce, Andre Gide, Francois Mauriac, Djuna Barnes and Janet Flanner  and the Parisian literary scene of half a century ago seemed to live again on the walls of the gallery. But for connoisseurs of photography in the French capital; Miss Abbott is as much a legend as any of the people who sat for her  the survivor of a golden age who has become a classic in her lifetime.

title: Tanglewood Off to a Good Start
description: Although advance sales for the Boston Symphony Orchestra summer festival at Tanglewood in the Berkshires almost came to a halt three weeks ago during the gasoline shortage, the orchestra sounded notes of optimism as it end its first full weekend yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: After surviving close semifinal matches yesterday afternoon at the New York Hilton Hotel, teams led by Alan Greenberg and Alan Sontag clashed in the knockout final of the Big Apple Regional Championships.

title: Joe Ruttman Takes 200Mile Stock Race
description: MILWAUKEE, July 8 (AP)  Joe Ruttman, younger brother of Troy Ruttman, pulled ahead for good on the 130th lap today and won a 200mile United States Auto Club stock car race at the Wisconsin State Fair Park track.

title: Outdoors
description: SILUETAS metalicas, a game that entails shooting with highpowered rifles at steel silhouettes of animals, came into the Udited States,from Mexico in the 1960's, and now it'is attracting thousands of new devotees each year.

title: Deaths
description: GUTTMANFred. Aged 96, on July 7, in Westport, Conn, husband of the late Freda, father of Adrah Melzet and Jean Allen, brotherinlaw of Jenny Cahn. Services 1:30PM, Tuesday, Collins Funeral Mome, 92 East Ave, Norwalk. Visiting 79PM Monday.

title: 80 , Gas and Miles of Smiles
description: In East Hampton, L.I.: It's so nice to have people back again, said Paul Cherry, a playwright and professor at Baruch College who is renting a summer house on the Island. It's the busIest weekend of the season. There are lines at all the restaurants and the movie houses, and the beaches are very, very crowded.

title: In Energy Crisis: Demand Grows for Federal Urban Transit Strategy
description: While President Carter was meeting with governors and other leaders about energy and other problems on a hill in Maryland Saturday, some other Americans spent part of their morning on another hill several hundred miles to the Urban Affairs north. These people were in a line at 100th Street and West End Avenue in New York City that stretched four blocks and then around the corner to the Mobil station on 96th Street that was open. Some of those in line had some thoughts about energy and leadership.

title: Erratic Mets Lose and Win
description: The Mets momentum stopped yesterday. They won a game.

title: The Editorial Notebook Hiding Behind Inflation
description: Remember Fred Kahn, the witty Cornell professor who presided triumphantly over the deregulation of the airline industry? Since he took the job of chief inflation fighter, the bloom has faded from Mr. Kahn's cheeks. To those who still listen, he seems as smart as ever. But with inflation running at the rate of 13 percent, Mr. Kahn and, for that matter, the whole economics profession are losing credibility.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Moneymarket rates should rise in the near future, and the bond markets should weaken; this was the bearish implication of much of the analysis last Friday after moneymarket economists assessed newly released Government statistics that showed unexpectedly strong growth in employment and a moderate increase in wholesale prices.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many major league baseball players have won the triple crown (leading a league in batting average, runs batted in and home runs in a single season)? Did any fail to be selected as most valuable player in his league the year he took the crown? If so, who was selected?

title: In the South Bronx, a Business Blooms
description: John Marietta and Fred Neuberger are an odd couple whose relationship took little bit of adjusting, as John said. But they worked it out: Fred, a Rumanian Jew and a mechanical engineer, sold his Buick for $2,000 nine years ago to go into business with John, a Puerto Rican diemaker.

title: High Court Term Report: Advances in Civil Rights
description: WASHINGTON, July 8  The Supreme Court term that ended last week will be remembered as the term that upheld both affirmative action to eliminate job discrimination and busing to integrate schools.

title: Borg Proves Again Wimbledon Is His
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 8 Just after John McEnroe and Peter Fleming won the men's doubles championship here, McEnroe was asked at a news conference how he would have played Bjorn Borg if he had made it to the final of the men's singles.

title: New Tokyo Initiative: Aid for Refugees Bolsters U.S. Ties
description: TOKYO, July 8  The Japanese Government, in a move that has implications for relations between the United States and its chief ally in East Asia, has made important decisions in critical policy area: the problem of Indochinese refugees.

title: Growing Waste Problem Threatens Nuclear Future
description: WASHINGTON  Every year, each of the atomic power plants in the world generates tens of thousands of cubic feet of potentially harmful radioactive waste, and as the amount grows so does the still unresolved problem of how to dispose of some of those wastes safely.

title: Newsweek and Boston Globe Call For More Leadership on Energy
description: Newsweek magazine and The Boston Globe sounded unusually strong appeals ever the weekend urging President Carter and Congress to assume more leadership with a comprehensive energy program.

title: De Gustibus The Bundt Pan Mystery: Enter a Royal Baker
description: Some weeks ago, a researcher asked if this column could possibly explain the word bundt as it pertains to the fluted, tube pan used for baking cakes. The query elicited a number of responses from around the country including Oregon.

title: Libraries Are Essential
description: There is an understandable but alarming Proposition 13 fever in the country today  a revolt by taxpayers against the burdens of regressive taxing of middleincome people to provide the funds for local services that are available to everyone. Public norarres snould not be dependent upon the good will of local taxpayers; nor should those local taxpayers bear the lion's share of the cost of operating institutions for all.

title: Latins Pressing Nicaraguan Left For Concessions
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 8Working in harmony with the United States, several Latin American governments have begun pressing a rebelbacked Nicaraguan provisional junta to make major political concessions in exchange for the resignation of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: Letters
description: What is the policy of the U.S. regarding human rights in the Peoples Republic of China, Cuba, and the dictatorships of Black Africa and Eastern Europe? If human rights considerations have entered into how we formulate our foreign policy toward these or any other leftist regimes, it is one of the Administration's best kept secrets.

title: Quake Jars Washington State
description: NEWPORT, Wash., July 8 (AP)  A minor earthquake, registering 3.8 on the Richter scale, was recorded yesterday in the puthwestern part of the state of Washington, officials said. Leonard Kerry, chief of the Newpott Geophysical Observatory, who described the quake as minor, said no injury or damage was reported.

title: Hearings on Arms Treaty Opening As Chances for Reservations Grow
description: WASHINGTON, July 8  Senate committees will begin formal consideration this week of the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union, with a growing likelihood that the Senate will attach some conditions to the aereement

title: Changing Attitudes Aid Games
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 8  In the past, they were always an afterthought for United States amateur athletes. The Pan American Games? They were an easy place to pick up'a medal. You can train through them and savor the summer before things

title: Barbara Cole Chappell Wed To Joseph Frank Buscarenc
description: At the Huntington (L.I.) Baptist Church yesterday, Barbara Cole Chappell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey E. Chappell of Huntington, became the bride of Joseph Frank Buscareno, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Buscareno of Northport, L.I. The Rev. Robert Brown performed the ceremony.

title: Chess:
description: It is quite clear who the strongest 16yearold chess player in the world is Garik Kasparov of the Soviet Union. For some years a pupil of Mikhail Botvinnik, the former world champion, Kasparov proved by a brilliant success in an international tournament in Banja Luka, Yugoslavia, that school is out. He captured first prize with a whopping 113 score, two points ahead of his closest rivals.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter, still at work on energy policy, continued to receive a constant stream of political, technical and other experts at Camp David. Decontrol of gasoline prices was said to be the single issue on which his staff remained at odds. [Page A1.]

title: Tiant Pitches OneHit Victory
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 8  Luis Tiant, the ancient marvel of the Yankee staff, shook his head in his inimitable pitching motion today and caused the Oakland A's to shake their heads in awe by allowing them just one hit in a 20 Yankee victory.

title: Arms Treaty Fails to Slow Soviet Propaganda Against U.S. Policies
description: MOSCOW, July 8  The Soviet Union and the United States have signed the most important armscontrol treaty in the history of their relations, the Soviet press keeps saying, but it has not led to any letup in a propaganda war against American policies of almost every kind.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Cooper Industries, a Houstonbased manufacturer of large diesel and gas engines, has named Thomas E. Naugle to the new corporate position of senior vice president, compressors and petroleum equipment operations.

title: Miss Stacy Victor Ina 3Way Playoff
description: NOBLESVILLE, Ind., July 8 (AP)Hollis Stacy sank a onefoot putt on the second hole of a suddendeath playoff today to win a $100,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Music: Bill Lombardo Is No Guy
description: BILL LOMBARDO, the 31yearold nephew of Guy Lombardo who has been leading his late uncle's Royal Canadians for more than a year, has inherited both a valuable identifiction and a problem.

title: Cynthia Straker, Lawyer, Married to Judge
description: Cynthia Straker, a lawyer with the office of the general counsel of the Department of Transportation in Washington, was married in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday to Judge Lawrence Warren Pierce of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Deaths
description: LUDINGTONLouise Howard, on July 5, 1979. in London, England, after a brief illness, daughter of Mrs. Bentz Howard, of Danville, VA, and the late Mr. Howard. Mrs. Ludington is survived by a son, Leland Howard Ludington of London, and a sister, Mrs. Nancy H. Butler of Washington, D.C., Service Thursday, July 12, 3 PM, in London.

title: French Banker Confident About International Role
description: In striking contrast to his counterparts throughout the world, Maurice Laur, chairman of Socit Gnrale, France's thirdlargest bank, is placidly confident about his company's future role in world finance.

title: Pamela P. Smith  Married to Lawyer
description: At the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Pamela Putnam Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Smith Jr. of Greenwich, was married to ChristianMichael Stever, son of Jurgen Stever of Lubeck, West Germany, and Mrs. Karl Gustav Wollenweber of Munich, West Germany. The Rev. Sherman Beattie performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Seeks a Strategy to Employ Its Conventional Forces
description: The next 18 months are likely to resound with partisan political argument on the question of whether the United States is strong or weak in relation to the Soviet Union. Many in the Pentagon and Congress, however, believe that the real

title: Cutbacks Voted by Brooklyn Museum
description: Beset by fiscal problems, the board of governors of the Brooklyn Museum has voted to abolish as a separate unit its department of Middle Eastern art and make staff and program cuts in a number of other areas, including its department of community services and its Art School, it has been learned. The cuts will result in a layoff of about 20 employees out of a staff of 250.

title: Study Finds Urbanites Dissatisfied With TV
description: Most city dwellers watch television from 10 to 25 hours a week and consider it an important part of their lives, yet most of them are dissatisfied with what's available on the tube, according to a new study.

title: Crumbling Sidewalks Trouble city As Accidents Lead to Legal Claims
description: Dr. MattneW J. Ferguson, a general practitioner in Greenwich Village, treated three patients within 10 days recently for injuries from falls on broken sidewalks.

title: Hazy Purchasing Trend
description: The nation's purchasing agents, the people who buy the fuel, steel, plastics and other building blocks of industry, appear in their latest report to have tentatively joined those who say a recession is building.

title: Events
description: DR. PEPPER CENTRAL PARK MUSIC FESTIVAL: BLONDIE AND ROCKPILE, rock groups, Wollman Skating Rink Theater, Central Park, 6:30.

title: Sports World Specials
description: One of the greatest of Eastern collegiate basketball teams was the Rutgers squad of 197576, which had won 30 games and lost none before succumbing to the University of Michigan in the National Collegiate semifinals. And for every killjoy who has ever mumbled that good times, once had, can never be recaptured, the six men who provided most of the power for that team have an answer: They have assembled for the summer in the Jersey Shore Summer Basketball League as the Phoenix Business Systems, a club that has won all its five games so far.

title: Ilise Amy Zimmerman Wed to Dennis Posen, Architect
description: In the Jewish Community Center of West Hempstead, L.I., Ilise Amy Zim- merman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Zimmerman of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday to Dennis An- drew Posen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warner Posen of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Kalman Fliegelman.

title: PARAGUAY PRESSED TO GIVE UP MEN6ELE
description: WASHINGTON, July 8  Paraguay coming under increasing pressure to apprehend and extradite Dr. Josef Mengele, a Nazi concentration camp physician who escaped to Latin America after the war. officials here say.

title: Ballet: Augustyn as Florimund
description: NEW York has so far seen only Rudolf Nureyev as Prince Florimund in Mr. Nureyev's The Sleeping Beauty, performed by the National Ballet of Canada last week at the New York State Theater. On Sunday afternon Frank Augustyn took over the role, to the very audible delight of some vocal admirers. Their enthusiasm was not misplaced.

title: Columbus Board Divided On Defying Busing Order
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 7  A divided Board of Education in Columbus is considering a lastditch effort to stave off desegregation of its 157 schools, despite a decision by the Supreme Court this week upholding a sweeping Federal busing order here.

title: MIOREWA DEPARTS FOR U.S. AND BRITAIN
description: ON A MISSION OF PERSUASION: Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa of Zimbabwe Rhodesia as he left on a trip to the United States and Britain to try to gain support for his new government. Article is on page A4.SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, July 8  Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa left here today for the United States and Britain, vowing to use the journey to remove the blindness from those in the Carter Administration and elsewhere who refuse to accept his coalition of blacks and whites as genuine majorityrule government.

title: Why Is Transkei Still Portrayed as a Stooge?
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  On Oct. 26, the Republic of Transkei will celebrate three years of legal independence from whiteruled South Africa. Transkei (across the Kei River) is the territory, somewhat larger than Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island combined, that is wedged between the Kingdom of Lesotho and the Indian Ocean, a bit South of the Port City of Durban. Its resident population or two million includes fewer than 17,000 people who are not black Africans. Nearly all are Xhosaspeaking, though English is also an official language. Extremely undeveloped and thoroughly tribal in its social structure, Transkei is surely one of the world's economic and social backwaters. But diplomatically, the new state is even more isolated from the modern world. Since 1976 no government outside South Africa has been willing to recognize Transkei, because of Pretoria's original sponsorship of it as part of its internationally condemned policy of separate development. And Umtata (the Transkei capital) itself broke diplomatic relations with Pretoria in April 1978.

title: Moonlit Benefit at the Pines
description: Some small towns organize chicken barbecues, others sell lottery tickets. But when Fire Island Pines, L.I., wanted to raise funds, it called on the many talents of its designconscious summer residents. The result was Beach Fire Island 79, a spectacular Oceanside party 10 months in the planning which took place from sunset on Saturday night to sunrise yesterday morning.

title: Market Place
description: IT HAS been a good time for the gold bugs: the price of bullion has risen steadily, and Friday for the first time ever it moved above $290 an ounce in the London and Zurich markets.

title: Around the Nation
description: WALLA WALLA, Wash., July 8 (AP) More than 200 Washington State Penitentiary inmates who hurled toilets and sinks around their cellblock in a demand for showers satin the prison yard today, victims of their own vandalism.

title: Garvey Voted Starting Berth
description: Steve Garvey of the Los Angeles Dodgers received a late flurry of votes to gain the starting position at first base over Pete Rose on the National League AllStar team, which was announced yesterday by Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball.

title: Deaths
