description: FRIEDMANEdward, of Palisades Park, NJ, beloved husband of Miriam Pat (nee Mantell), loving uncle of several neices and nephews. Services will be held at GuttermanMusicantKreitzman, corner of Park and Passaic Stris, Hackensack, NJ. on Tues. July 10, at 11 AM. The memorial period will be observed at the residence. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to The Heart Fund or The American Cancer Society.

title: Advertising
description: AFTER seven years of existence, Cuisine magazine. (formerly Sphere's Cuisine; Sphere, the World of Today's Woman, and Sphere, the Betty Crocker Magazine) may begin to make some money.

title: Deaths
description: CREAMERWarren Milton. Of 100 Main Street, Farmington, Conn. At the Hartford Hospital on July 7, 1979, survived by his wife Elizabeth Glazier, a daughter, Mrs. Binlemin T. Richards Jr., of New Yerk City, and two grand daughters, Elizabeth and Cordelia. Funeral services at St. James Episcopal Church. Far. mington, Tuesday, July 10, at 1:30 P.M.

title: Shinichiro Tomonaga, in Tokyo; Won 1965 Nobel Prize in Physics
description: TOKYO, July 8 (AP)  Shinichiro Tomonaga, one of Japan's premier scientists and a winner of the 1965 Nobel Prize for Physics, died of cancer here today at the age of 73. He had been hospitalized since November.

title: Dr. WALTER LEVY
description: Dr. Walter Levy, a pediatrician who was a former president of the Bronx Pediatric Society, died Saturday at SloanKettering Memorial Hospital following a heart attack. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 2 Soviet Jews to Study as Rabbis at New York's Yeshiva University
description: MOSCOW, July 8  Two Soviet Jews in their early 30's are to leave for New York next September for a threeyear crash course in rabbinical studies at Yeshiva University, as part of a Sovietapproved effort to fill the void in Jewish religious leadership in the Soviet Union.

title: Karachi Disrupted by Strike
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 8 (Reuters)  Business in Karachi, the commercial center of Pakistan, was disrupted today as businessmen and other opponents of the Government's tough budget policy went on a oneday strike. The budget, which introduced higher taxes, was designed to overcome large and continuing foreign deficits. During the strike, called by a makeshift alliance of rightwing and religious groups, buses were stoned, and roadblocks and bonfires blocked Karachi streets.

title: Indian Relics Found in Brooklyn
description: A fire pit used 1,000 years ago by American Indians on a shellfishing expedition has been unearthed by Brooklyn College archeological students in Marine Park in Brooklyn along a tidal inlet.

title: Stanley Goldklang, Ph.D. Student, Weds Susan Isenberg
description: Susan K. Isenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Isenberg of Rossmoor, N.J., was married yesterday to Stanley Goldklang, son of Mrs. H. Robert Ringel of Briarwood, Queens, and the late Jacob Goldklang. The ceremony was performed at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club by Rabbi Samuel Z. Glaser.

title: MONDALE PREVIEWS CARTER ENERGY PLAN BEFORE GOVERNORS
description: LOUISVILLE, July 8  Vice President, Mondale said today that the Carter Administration was preparing steps to deal with both the short- and longterm impact of the energy crisis, including a project to develop alternative fuels as ambitious as the program that put Americans on the moon.

title: Deaths
description: AARONSONIrving (lisle), of Bakers Union Local 3, who helped to merge from Local 87 to Local 509, then to Local 579, then to Local 3. He was Business Agent in all the merged locals. Survived by dsughters Evelyn Citrin, Dorothy Krimsky and Ethel Pomarlco, gran hildren and greatgrandchildren. Services were held July 8 at the Riverside Chapel in Far Rockaway.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AIRS AND AIR The public is invited to board the environmental sloop Clearwater early tomorrow evening for a program of free music and dancing as the vessel lies moored at Waterside Plaza, 25th Street and the East River. The festivities will precede a Wednesday sail around Manhattan that is geared for environmental education.

title: ARTHUR H. GOODMAN
description: Arthur H. Goodman, chairman of the board of the Ormond Shops, a retail chain specializing in women's apparel, died Saturday in Beth Israel Hospital. Mr. Goodman, who lived in Manhattan, was 88 years old.

title: Arguello Stops Foe in 11th
description: Alexis Arguello exploited a deep gash over Rafael (Bazooka) Limon's right eye and stopped the Mexican at 1 minute 40 seconds of the 11th round to retain his World Boxing Council superfeatherweight championship yesterday before 1,547 viewers at the Felt Forum.

title: SmallTime Hero, BigTime Hopes
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. WHEN Phil Simms was growing up in Kentucky bluegrass country, a trip to Churchill Downs for the Derby was a yearly outing. Did you ever pet one of 1 those horses? asked the Giants firstround draft choice and quarterback of the future. I Just enioved looking at them. never had any money to bet them. On Friday, one day after having signed a fouryear contract said to be worth more than a millinn rInllane and week before the start of training camp, Simms found himself a pampered guest at the Meadowlands track with enough money in his pocket to bet every race. A dinner reservation had been made for him at the ritzy Pegasus club, he had been allowed past the guards despite violating the dress code by wearing dungarees, his table was right by the window, and his meal was on the house.

title: The U.N. Today
description: July 9, 1979

title: Politics Delays Javits's Proposal for a Federal Judge
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  For a year, a key Federal judgeship in the Eastern District of New York has gone unfilled while Senator Jacob K. Javits has weighed his choices for the job. The judgeship is only the second one the New York Republican Senator has been allowed to fill since President Carter's election, and the delays tell something about the political nature of the process, as well as Mr. Javits's political sensitivity.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Three new 10speed bicycles by AMF Roadmaster have a new device that helps eliminate the guesswork usually accompanying twolevel gear shifts. It's a singlelevel cam shift that, in one action, operates both derailleurs in unison. Included is a dial that indicates which gear you are in, and the unit also allows you to select a gear before starting out. The device is called Quick shift, and it's standard equipment on the 27inch Black Gold men's racing model ($120) and the 26inch Bruce Jenner Decathlon models for men and women ($119). They're available It Alexander's, J.C. Penney and ToysRUs, as well as at bicycle shops usually carrying AMF equipment.

title: F.A.A. Is Expected to Lift the Ban On the DC10 Today or Tomorrow
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is expected to announce today or tomorrow the lifting of its June 6 order that grounded the nation's 138plane fleet of McDonaldDouglass DC10 jumbo jets.

title: Bad Henry and Bjorn Borg
description: JOE TORRE sat behind his desk in Shea Stadium on Saturday and stared at the television set while Roscoe Tanner was threatening to upset Bjorn Borg in the singles final at Wimbledon. When Borg finally prevailed in the fifth set, winning the tennis title for the fourth straight year, the manager of ,the Mets was impressed.

title: PEKING ISSUES RULES TO LURE INVESTMENT
description: PEKING, July 8  China made public, today its first, law on joint ventures, a statute that will alloWfoielEnchusinesses to invest in China and repatriate part of their profits.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: For Derald H. Ruttenberg, chairman and chief executive officer of StudebakerWorthington Inc last week must have been a busy one. His company announced that a large United States industrial company had expressed interest In a takeover, and the Wall Street rumor mill began working overtime to determine the name of the suitor.

title: News Summary
description: Energy

title: PRESIDENT EXTENDS CAMP DAVID SESSIONS
description: WASHINGTON, July 8  Visitors shuttled back and forth to Camp David today as President Carter continued his broad examination of domestic issues with a sometimes narrow focus on energy.

title: Iran Steel Complex May Have to Close
description: TEHERAN, Iran July 8 (Reuters)  Authoritative industry sources said that Iran's giant Sovietbuilt steel complex at Isfahan might be forced to close in less than two weeks because of an acute shortage of coking coal. The sources said that the closing would be necessary unless sufficient coal was imported within the next few days.

title: Financing Activity To Increase
description: Financing activity, which slowed last week because the credit markets were closed for the Independence Day holiday, will pick up this week, with the Farm Credit System scheduled to raise more than $1.1 billion of new cash and corporate and taxexempt bond sales due to increase sharply.

title: Jailbreak Nothing New or Exciting in Goshen Life
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., July 8  The getaway car was Jim King's tan 1966 Chevrolet station wagon, parked outside his threestory frame house on Montgomery Street in back of the Orange County Jail. It wasn't much of a car, he said yesterday  in fact, the neighbors did not believe him when he said it was stolen.

title: EASING OF FUEL SHORTAGE BRINGS OUT CROWDS: More than a million visitors flocked to Coney Island yesterday, largest crowd In a year. Gasoline was easily available around New York, and shore resorts were packed. Page B1.
description: Gasoline was once again easy to obtain yesterday in the New York City area, and lines at filling stations were generally short. Highway traffic increased sharply from Saturday, and beaches and parks reported heavy congestion.

title: Money Curbs Urged on Bonn
description: MUNICH, July 8 (Reuters)  West Germany's Economics Minister, Otto Lambsdorff, has called on his nation's central bank to counter accelerating inflation with a prudent curb on the money supply.

title: Remington Sues Philips
description: Remington Products Inc. said that it had filed suit last week in Federal court seeking $15 million in damages from the North American Philips Corporation, the maker of Norelco electric shavers. It said that it was charging Philips with attempting to establish a monopoly, restraint of trade and unfair competition in the market for electric shavers. The suit followed a legal action taken recently by North American Philips, which is trying prevent Remington from using the description triple head in advertising and marketing its electric shavers.

title: 21 Governors Endorse Reelection of Carter, Giving a Timely Boost
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 8  A heavy majority of the nation's Democratic governors today endorsed President Carter for renomination and reelection in 1980, calling him true to the principles of the Democratic Party.

title: A Fiscal Struggle to Stay Aloft
description: BOSTON, July 8  It sounds like Harvard Business School casebook study in what to avoid.

title: Benjamin Ginsberg Weds Jo A. Talbot
description: Jo Anne Talbot, daughter of Dr: and Mrs. Eugene Talbot of Stockbridge, Mass., was married there yesterday to Benjamin Ginsberg, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold S. Ginsberg of New York and Monterey, Mass. Rabbi Arthur Relnick performed the ceremony at the Talbot home.

title: Israel Calls Vienna Envoy Home
description: JERUSALEM, July 8  Israel's Ambassador to Austria was called home today as a sign of protest against official hospitality in Vienna for Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Budget Trims and Miscalculations Doomed Skylab
description: WASHINGTON, July 8  Skylab is falling because of a series of events that have occurred over the last decade in places as near as the White House and as far away as the sun.

title: Taxes
description: WASHINGTON IT never seems to work out quite right. Ten years ago, Congress rectified one tax inequity by reducing the traditionally heavier income tax rates paid by single people. Now, with the ranks of working wives swelling, complaints are mounting that families with two earners suffer a marriage penalty, paying higher rates than if they lived in sins.

title: A SUBSIANTIAL RISE IN SAUDI OIL OUTPUT IS REPORTED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON July 9  The Carter Administration said today that Saudi Arabia was substantially increasing its production of crude oil, raising prospects that shortages of gasoline and other fuels would quickly fade.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT'S St. JeanCap Ferrat in 1955an exotic and ridiculous setting for the peculiar drama that we played out on our verandahs and gardens and terraces that year. Drama is not a very good word any more. It was more of a confrontation. What else

title: The Doctor's World
description: THE modern diagnosis and treatment of heart disease is based on a revolutionary Nobel Prizewinning selfexperiment done secretly 50 years ago by a German doctor, Werner Forssmann, whose death in the Black Forest last month was little noticed in the United States.

title: Cornelia Otis Skinner, Actress and Author, Dies
description: Cornelia Otis Skinner, whose quicksli: ver humor was displayed as an actress, playwright and memoirist, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday morning at her home in New York. She was 78 years old.

title: Discophobia
description: Disco. Two unmellifluous syllables describe the most important cultural phenonenon in America today. Americans disco at private clubs, in condemned warehouses, in rollerskating rinks and at bar mitzvahs. Soon we will be discoing in voting booths, at I.R.S. audits and in operating rooms during openheart surgery.

title: Efforts Increase to Aid Groups That Salvage Unwanted Food
description: In 1977, according to Government figures, 20 percent of all the food produced in the United States was lost or wasted before it got to the people who need it. The General Accounting Office estimates the loss at 137 million tons valued at $31 billion. Of that amount, about 60 million tons, worth $ 5 billion, was simply left in the fields and the orchards because there was no commercial market for it. This at a time when, according to other Government figures, millions of Americans were unable to get enough to eat.

title: Jersey Employees Strike Averted
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 9 A threatened strike by public employees was averted today when the leadership of two unions recommended, by a narrow margin, a $60 million, twoyear economic package to the union's 32.000 members.

title: Venezuelan Jeep Output
description: The American Motors Corporation said that it had arranged with a Venezuelan company, C.A. Venezolana de Acciones Metalmecnicas, to double capacity for Jeep production to 14,000 Jeeps a year. The action is subject to approval by the Venezuelan Government.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  Four Trenton men and one woman were indicted yesterday on charges of forging and attempting to cash $30,000 in fostercare payment checks that were stolen last February from the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services.

title: Merrill Vies For Bank Customers
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, the nation's largest securities concern, yesterday began to compete for business on Long Island that had been the exclusive domain of commercial banks and savings institutions.

title: Arrest Links Crime Family to Drugs
description: BUFFALO, July 9  Four persons, including a man reputedly linked to organized crime, pleaded not guilty in united States District Court here on charges involving the seizure of more than two pounds of heroin with a street value estimated at $2.25 million.

title: Dow Gains 6.83 in Busy Trading
description: In the thirdbusiest trading day of this year, the stock market continued the strong rally yesterday that it began last Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 6.83 points to 852.99 on a turnover of 42.5 million shares.

title: Letters
description: The Mayor's Plan to Close. City Hospitals

title: Q&A
description: Q. Has human, evolution been af fected in any way by cataclysmic changes in the earth's evolution?

title: Officer Driving a Taxi Wounds Holdup Man
description: In the second such incident in two days, an offduty policeman moonlighting as a cabdriver shot and critically wounded a passenger who alledgedly tried to rob him at gunpoint early yesterday.

title: Mortgage Yield Drops Below 11%
description: Interest rates on mortgages purchased by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation declined yesterday for the second consecutive week, apparently reflecting some softening in demand for residential loans.

title: IN THE NATION
description: President Carter has reached the low point not only of his Administration but perhaps of the postwar Presidency. That is bad for the man and worse for the country; either he pulls things together in the immediate future or the rest of us are stuck with a

title: Spanish Newsmagazine Being Broadcast Monthly
description: A monthly Spanishlanguage newsmagazine, Portafolio, is being broadcast by the Spanish International Network and its local station, WXTVTV Channel 41.

title: Tax Treaties Approved
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)  The Senate today approved treaties precluding residents of four countries from paying double taxes. The treaties, approved 98 to 0, were established between the United States and Britain, France, South Korea and Hungary. They grant the country of residency the right to tax estates and. transfers on a worldwide basis.

title: Erostophanes Upsets Field In Jumpoff at Lake Placid
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 9  Less than a year ago, a 10yearold stallion arrived at Willow Tree Farm in Woodside, Calif., from Belgium. He had virtually no experience in the show ring and, in fact, had bad feet  so bad that his debut had to be put off by his new rider, Graeme Thomas.

title: Carey Approves Driver's Licenses Carrying Photos
description: ALBANY, July 9  In an effort to thwart false . identifications, New York State will add individual photographs to the driver's licenses of its nine million motorists, Governor Carey announced today.

title: Chairnan Quits City Rent Board Citing Burden
description: The resignation of the chairman of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board was announced yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: CBS's Old Camera Three Returning on Public TV
description: PROVING that television can occasionally come up with firstrate happy ending, Camera Three is returning to a regular weekly schedule. CBS had canceled the longlived cultural series last fall to make room for a Sunday morning news program. Now with the cooperation of CBS, Camera Three will move to the Public Broadcasting Service, offering a combination of new broadcasts and programs from its repertory.

title: DEFINITION OF CRIME CLARIFIED BY PEKING
description: PEKING, July 9  With the promulgation of China's new Criminal Code and Law of Criminal Procedure last week, ordinary Chinese, for the first time since. the Communists came to power in 1949; can tell what acts are punishable as crimes and how they can defend themselves.

title: EARNINGS General Mills Profit Up 37.7%
description: General Mills, the giant food processor, reported yesterday that profits had increased 37.7 percent in its final quarter, ended May 27. Earnings for the period were $30.3 million, or 60 cents a share, up from $22 million, or 44 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 11.1 percent to a record $896.9 million.

title: Output Off At Iranian Oil Refinery
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 9 (UPI) Production at the Abadan oil refinery, the world's largest, has been reduced by more than 80 percent as a result of explosions at major pipelines over the weekend, the Governmentrun Pars News agency reported today. The biasts cut the refinery's supplies of crude from the Aghajari oilfields.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, July 9,1979

title: North Korea Rejects Talks
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, July 10 (AP)North Korea today rejected threeway talks on Korean reunification proposed by the Urdted States and South Korea, Pyongyang radio reported

title: Robert B. Woodward Dead at 62; Harvard Chemist Won Nobel Prize
description: Robert Burns Woodward, winner of the 1965 Nobel Prize for chemistry and Donner professor of science at Harvard who was preeminent in his field of chemical synthesis for more than 30 years, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 62 years old.

title: Robinson Outraces Juantorena in Games
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 9  James Robinson of Oakland, Calif., outkicked Alberto Juantorena of Cuba in the final straightaway tonight and then withstood a twohour postrace protest to win the gold medal in the 800meter run at the Pan American Games.

title: Wide Differences Persist Over Safety and Methods of Nuclear Waste Disposal
description: RICHLAND, Wash.The tunnel, its floor thick with, oozing mud and its air pungent with the'acrid odor Of blasting powder, rang with the scream of the dieselpowered earth loaders.

title: Pension Suit Costing William Loeb Part of Manchester Paper's Control
description: CONCORD, N.H., July 9 William Loeb, whose conservative views and often vituperative editorials as publisher of The Manchester Union Leader have inquenced the conduct of Presidential primaries in New Hampshire for decades, agreed today to settle a suit cnarging pension law violations on terms that will cause him to lose control of 2t percent of the newspaper's stock.

title: Market Place
description: REAL estate investment trusts have endured a horrendous boom and bust on Wall Street in the last decade. From a standing start of $1 billion in 1969, assets of this fledgling industry expanded to nearly $20 billion in less than four years. When the bust came, investors lost billions or dollars in cash and an untold amount of faith in the stock market.

title: EDUCATION
description: SOME private colleges and universities are beginning to reexamine the changes they have made in their curriculums, educational philosophies and admissions policies in the last few years to attract students and increase the institutions chances of survival.

title: Asarco Raises Lead Prices
description: Asarco Inc., one of the nation's largest lead producers, said yesterday that it had increased its lead price by 4 cents a pound, to 62 cents, a record high. Other United States companies are currently selling lead for 55 to 60 cents pound. Demand for lead has been outstripping supply for more than a year, and the company said the shortage was primarily a result of lead's being shipped overseas where higher prices are being paid.

title: Gas Lines Still Short
description: Lines at filling stations were generally short again yesterday, and gasoline was easily available in the New York City area and in New Jersey and Connecticut. Traffic was reported to have picked up over last week.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Poll Says Gas Price Rise Will Curb Holiday Trips
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP)  Onethird of the people planning vacation trips this year will not travel if gasoline prices increase to $1.25 a gallon, according to a survey of residents in six American cities.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Area Disaster Agencies on Alert
description: OUNDTHECLOCK watches yesterday were scheduled for disastercontrol headquarters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut as authorities prepared to marshal emergency aid if parts of Skylab should fall in the tristate area.

title: Storing Gas: Commonly Done, but Dangerous and Sometimes Illegal
description: Warnings about the danger of storing cans of gasoline in automobile trunks or at home seem to have had little effect over the last few weeks. Motorists who feared a worsening of the fuel shortage have used everything from metal containers to plastic buckets and jars to carry away from the gas pumps more than their cars tanks could hold.

title: Bonn Economic Lag May Loom
description: BONN, July 9  The West German economy, which has managed to avoid many of the oilinduced problems facing other nations, is beginning to show signs that trouble may be brewing for the vear ahead.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Government bond prices dropped sharply yesterday, pushing interest rates higher in light volume.

title: U.S. Said to Enlist Bonn to Press Israel
description: BONN, July 9  President Carter has asked Chancellor Helmut Schmidt to urge Israel to change its policies on settlements in occupied Arab territories, an authoritative West German source reported.

title: McEnroe Pursues Big Prize
description: It is easier to plant ivy at the concrete stadium at FluShing MeadowsCorona Park than to grow new tradition at a venerable tennis club, but Lamar Hunt is trying to do that at Forest Hills.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Saturday gave an incorrect rOOR rate for students at the Prince George Hotel on East 28th Street. The price by special arrangement with American Youth Hostels Inc., when four share a room, is $12 a person.

title: Skylab and Other Mishaps Tarnish Technology's Image
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 These are not good times for those who want to press forward with technological advances in the name of progress. So many things have been going wrong with man's shining symbols of tech nology, it seems, that they have lost their luster. The imminent fall of Skylab is only the latest example.

title: Wide Amnesty in Iran Declared by Khomeini
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 9  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini declared a general amnesty today covering all people who committed offenses under the past regime except those involved in murder or torture.

title: Socialist Named to Form Regime In Italy but He Faces Long Odds
description: ROME, July 9  In a surprise move, Bettino Craxi, secretary of Italy's Socialist Party, was asked today by President Sandro Pertini to try to form a Government.

title: Release of DC1O's Held Up by Newly Discovered Crack on United Plane
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yeterday delayed the expected decision to end the grounding of DC10 Jumbo jets to await analysis of a crack found over the weekend on the engine mount, or pylon; of a United Airlines plane.

title: JEAN LOGAN LEDOUX
description: Jean Logan Ledoux, an organizer and supporter of many associations promot ing the study and appreciation of Oriental art, died Monday in her home at 139 East 79th Street. She was 93 years old.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JULY 9, 1979.

title: Around the Nation
description: Independent truckers were back on the roads in full force yesterday, their monthlong strike ended by mass defections in their own ranks. Many participants in the strike succumbed to the lures of bigmoney hauls and creditors pressures.

title: Arts Center Attempting Renovation
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is beginning to show signs of physical wear and tear  the dubious legacy of the more than 20 million people who have passed through its doors, wandered its corridors and enjoyed opera, theater and the dance since the center opened in September 1971.

title: Davis (80) Is on Spot as Gossage Returns
description: SEATTLE, July 9  In the last six weeks, Ron Davis has won eight games and lost 12 pounds.

title: Koch and Top City Officials In Line For Pay Rises Today
description: Pay increases of $20,000 a year for Mayor Koch and $10,000 each for Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, City Council President Carol Bellamy, the five Borough Presidents, and the 43 members of the Council were assured yesterday with Finance Committee approval of legislation for action by the full Council today.

title: The Ballet: 'Sinfonietta By Netherlands Dancers
description: HE Netherlands Dance Theater, a company that champions what's new in ballet, opened a twoweek season last night at the City Center 55th Street Dance Theater. It was an exciting program and almost everything about it was new. Three ballets received their New York premieres, two of them by the company's new artistic director and choreographer, Jiri Kylian.

title: Austrians Reject Protests on Arafat
description: VIENNA, July 9  Austria today rejected Israel's protest against the talks held here over the weekend with Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and Chancellor Bruno Kreisky said the sessions served the cause of peace.

title: U.S. Bill Rates Climb Sharply
description: Treasury bill rates climbed sharply in the Governments weekly auction yesterday. The average rate for sixmonth bills rose above 9 percent for the first time in a month.

title: Near Jupiter, Voyager 2 Uncovers Surprises
description: PASADENA Calif., July 9  Voyager 2 streaked within 404,000 miles of the planet Jupiter today, sending back a flood of scientific data and stunning photographs of the planet, and then trained its cameras on Jupiter's mysterious neiehbor satellite. Io.

title: Bridge:
description: New York's most successful bridge team recorded another victory in the knockout team championship at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday night. In the concluding event of the Big Apple Regional Championships. Alan Greenberg, Matt Granovetter, Jim Cayne, Neil Silverman, all of New York, and Bob Lipsitz of Potomac, Md., won by 35 points against Alan Sontag, Peter Weichsel, Martin Scheinberg, Ron Snyder and Jim Rosenbloom, all of New York.

title: Expos Beat Dodgers For Lee's 3d Shutout
description: MONTREAL, July 9 (UPI)  Bill Lee singled home two runs during threerun fifthinning rally and scattered seven hits to post his ninth victory tonight, leading the Montreal Expos to a 30 triumph over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CALLING DR. FERGUSON the Quaigh Theater calls Men in White, its new revival, the granddaddy of the host of medical shows that 40 years later were to swamp television.

title: Chinese See Broad Spectrum of Western Dance on U.S. Tour
description: CHEN JINQING arrived in the United States thiee weeks ago to take a look at Western dancer By Monday, when Miss Chen and seven colleagues from the Peking Dance Conservatory and National Dance Company of China return home, they will have seen more dance and a wider spectrum of dance styles than many people see in a lifetime.

title: Science Watch
description: Using the socalled gap method of earthquake prediction, a team of specialists has concluded that a major quake is due near Cape Yakataga on the coast of Alaska midway between Anchorage and Juneau.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: When the monthly survey report of the National Association of Purchasing Managementess appeared in many newspapers yesterday, the name of E.F. Andrews, corporate vice presidentmaterials and services of Allegheny Ludlum Industries, was missing for the first time in 18 years. Mr. Andrews has been succeeded as chairman of the association's busin survey committee by Charles T. Haffey, vice president of the corporate purchasing division of Pfizer, Inc., who starting this month comments on and analyzes the results of this authoritative survey.

title: Washington Star Out in Morning
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)  The Washington Star, an evening newspaper, today published its first A.M. Extra, a new morning edition that competes directly with The Washington Post. The Star already had published morning editions on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

title: Last of Miracle Mets
description: This is supposed to be a week of proud memories at Shea Stadium.

title: In Velvet and Mahogany, Evoking Le Train Bleu
description: En voiture, attention, passagers pour Lyon, Marseille et MonteCarlo, announces an invisible, gentlevoiced stationmaster when one reaches the top of the carpeted stairs and then steps onto the platform of Le Train Bleu, the new restaurant tucked at the back of Bloomingdale's sixthfloor housewares department.

title: Nonwhites in Britain Display New Sense of Militancy
description: LONDON, July 9 - One cold night few months ago, a gang of white youths tore through a Bangladeshi neighborhood in the East End of London, screaming obscenities and bombarding the mean little brick houses with milk bottles.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 9 (AP)  The Charter Company announced today that it had reached an agreement. with the Nationaliranian Oil Company settling an outstanding debt of $160 million and assuring a ccintinuing supply of crude oil for Charter's refinery in the Bahamas.

title: Canada Gas Discoveries Aid Commercial Outlook
description: CALGARY, Alberta, July 9  New discoveries of natural gas off the shores of Nova Scotia have increased the likelihood that reserves there are large enough to be commercially exploitable.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Futures prices of precious metals advanced yesterday as growing uncertainty about the Administration's energy and budgetary policies swept the market.

title: U.S. in Role of Key Nicaragua Arbiter
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 9  By using the promise of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle's resignation to bargain for concessions from a rebelbacked provisional junta, the United States seems to be assuming its traditional role as final arbiter of Nicaragua's political destiny.

title: Ruling Upheld on Exclusion Of Press at Pretrial Hearing
description: The New York State Court of Appeals yesterday unanimously upheld the decision of a Bronx Judge to exclude the press from a pretrial hearing on a murder charge against a 13yearold boy.

title: End to Federal Revenue Sharing Expected in Forthcoming Budget
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 9  Revenue sharing, the Federal Government's practice of turning a portion of its money over to the states and localities to use pretty much as they wish, has come on hard times and is likely to be wiped out of the next Federal budget, according to a wide range of authorities.

title: Israelis Kill 3 Guerrillas Crossing From Lebanon
description: TEL AVIV, July 9 (AP)  An Israeli Army patrol intercepted three Palestinian guerrillas heading for Israel yesterday and killed them in a brief battle, the military command reported today.

title: Arco Discovers Oil In Indonesian Wells
description: LOS ANGELES, July 9 (Reuters) The Atlantic Richfield Company said it discovered oil at two wells in the Java Sea off Indonesia.

title: Richmond U., Now Rich, Seeks Excellence
description: RICHMOND  Ten years ago, the University of Richmond had a small $6 million endowment and an uncertain future, with a distinct possibility of being taken over by the state or going out of business by the end of the 1970's. Its facilities were inadequate, its faculty was grossly underpaid and almost no one outside Virginia had heard of the school.

title: Blind Bidding for Films on Trial
description: LOS ANGELES. July 9  The war between theater owners and movie distributors over the blind bidding of motion pictures haS moved into the courts

title: Mayor Hopes Voters Will Allow Casinos in New York
description: Mayor Koch surveyed the surroundings yesterday from a blackjack table Caesars World in Atlantic City and spent three hours in the resort town to see what it's like to have casinos in operation. When New York gets casinos, the Mayor said in a Boardwalk interview, many people who now go to Atlantic City to gam will go to New York instead. How are you going to keep em Atlantic City once they've seen New York with casinos? he asked.

title: Advertising
description: IF the world doesn't know of Jerry Della Femina, it's not his fault. The chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners knows how to get into the limelight. And once he's there, he basks in it, mostly because it has proven good for business.

title: John Reed King, a Host On Radio and Early TV
description: John Reed King, a familiar name to listeners of radio quiz shows in the 1940's and one of the early hosts of audienceparticipation programs on television, died Sunday in Woodstown, N.J., of heart attack while visiting his brother, Charles B. King. He was 64 years old and lived in Fresno, Calif.

title: New PlantAnimal Interaction Found in Desert
description: BAJA CALIFORNIA, MEX. THE thermometer on the ground next to us read 152 degrees Fahrenheit as we lay on our bellies in the midafternoon desert sun, trying to unravel the social structure of a newly discovered species of seedharvesting ant. But the ants were not so foolish as their twolegged observers. With one or two exceptions, they waited out the scorching heat in the relatively cool tunnels of their huge underground nest.

title: Hurled Rock Injures A Conrail Engineer, Halts Train in Bronx
description: A rock hurled at a Conrail express train in the Bronx during yesterday's evening rush period injured the engineer and delayed the train for 32 minutes.

title: Dryden Retires From Hockey
description: MONTREAL, July 9 (UPI) Ken Dryden, the goalie who won the Venezia Trophy four times, formally announced his retirement today after eight seasons and five Stanley Cups with the Montreal Canadiens.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, July 9 (AP)  The Unity Party of Nigeria took an early lead today in returns from Nigeria's first democratic elections in 13 years.

title: Events
description: Theater

title: News Summary
description: Forecasts of more gasoline and other fuels followed the Administration's confirmation that Saudi Arabia would substantially increase its crude oil production. Administration officials and individuals close to the Saudis estimated that the increase would be one million barrels daily for at least three months. There were indications, two Administration officials said, that the higher rate of 9.5 million barrels daily would be maintained for the rest of the year. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Issue and Debate Rail Use in Gas Crisis vs. Amtrak Austerity
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  With gasoline lines fresh in the minds of East Coast drivers and a growing wariness of longdistance highway travel nearly everywhere, intercity travelers have headed for Amtrak trains in record numbers.

title: Pioneer Bus Ending Its Runs in City
description: The Pioneer Bus Company confirmed yesterday through its lawyer, Samuel B. Zinder, that it would not seek renewal of a New York City franchise because of the bleak outlook for private bus operations.

title: Bundy Jury Hears 2 Women Who Survived Attacks
description: MIAMI, July 9 (AP)  Two young women who survived savage beatings at their sorority house 18 months ago recalled today the night of violence as jury began hearing testimony in the murder trial of Theodore R. Bundy. The women said that they could not identify their attacker.

title: Hispanics Angered as U.S. Bars Brutality Charges Against Police
description: HOUSTON, July 9 The Justice Department, under increasing fire from MexicanAmerican leaders for its decision not to bring charges in the death a 27yearold Chicano in a West Texas jail, has declined to act on more than 40 other complaints of police brutality against Hisnanics.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. I Vespri Siciliani, The Four Seasons, Spring, Verdi; Variations on the name Abegg, Schumann; Pavane pour one infante defunte, Ravel.

title: Louis to Dance in Osaka
description: Murray Louis, the choreographer and dancer, will perform two moderndance solos at the Second World Ballet Festival this summer in Osaka, Japan. He will present A Suite for Erik and Dj Vu at the showcase that is mainly for classical pieces. Among the other performers at the festival, to be held from July 23 to Aug. 9, are Alicia Alonso, Fernando Bujones, Richard Cragun and Patricia McBride.

title: June Car Sales Climb in Britain
description: LONDON (AP)  Britain's June car sales set a record for any month, rising 51 percent from the previous June, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders reported yesterday, Imports registered sharp gains, accounting for 56 percent of the market during the month, up from 48 percent a year earlier

title: Guarded Optimism on Power
description: In early June, Federal officials were worried that the shortage of oil and the shutdown of several of the nation's nuclear reactors could lead to electricity shortages in July and August. the peak months for consumption. They proposed setting thermostats in most public buildings at 80 degrees as one way of easing the demand for power.

title: Dr. Mario Domandi, 50 Years Old; A Professor of Italian at Vassar
description: Dr. Mario Domandi, professor'of Italian at Vassar College, died Sunday at the Vassar Brothers Hospital, in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Dr. Domandi, who lived in Poughkeepsie, was 50 years old.

title: Reporter's Notebook : Carter Makes Bid to the Governors
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 9  President Carter didn't come, but all weekend he used this city on the Ohio River as a message board to transmit the news, hopes and fears of Washington and Camp David.

title: Stage: Julius Caesar Acted in Modern Mode
A NitriteFree Hot Dog That Cuts the Mustard
description: Sausage lovers who worry about consuming excess fats or chemical preservatives such as the sodium nitrite that is present in almost all sausages are faced with a particularly difficult dilemma: Whether to forgo this favorite food or to eat what they are afraid to eat.

title: U.S. Brings Big Foreign Payoff Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the International Systems and Controls Corporation had disbursed $23 million in bribes and improper payments since 1970 to entities controlled by foreign government officials.

title: Moscow Is Reported to Bar a Pledge on Emigration
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  The Soviet Union has declined to give the United States the kind of assurances on emigration that would qualify it for American trade concessions, Administration officials said today.

title: No Yank Voted A.L. Starter
description: The New York Yankees won the World Series the last two years, the Baltimore Orioles lead the Eastern Division and the Texas Rangers are currently the top team in the Western Division. Yet none of those teams placed a player in the starting lineup for the American League AllStar team picked by fan balloting. The results were announced yesterday by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn.

title: Koch Foes File Petitions on Recall of City Officials
description: Petitions to permit the recall of New York City officials were filed yesterday  couched as a technical change in the law, but considered by both friends and foes as a challenge to Mayor Koch.

title: Judge Rules For Becton In Sun Case
description: A Federal judge ruled in Manhattan last night that the Sun Company's private purchase of 34 percent of Becton, Dickinson & Company stock for almost $300 million last year constituted a tender offer that violated Federal securities laws.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: METZ, France, July 9 (AP) Hennie Kuiper of the Netherlands led an 80mile breakaway from the pack in today's Tour de France leg from Rochefort, but by the time the stage ended here most of his advantage had been dissipated.

title: Indictment of Executives In Chicle Blast Reinstated
description: An appellate court in Brooklyn yesterday reinstated indictments charging the WarnerLambert Company and four of its executives with manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide in a 1976 explosion at a Queens chewing gum factory. six workers were killed and dozens were severely burned.

title: Chile, in Apparent Effort to Undermine Unions, Issues New Labor Rules
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 9  Chile's military regime issued a series of decrees last week that, in the name of freedom of association for workers, appears to undermine drastically the rights of organized labor.

title: President Elicits Congress's Help For Energy Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  President Carter, bolstered by Saudi Arabia's promise of an early increase in oil production, pursued his marathon brain- storming session at Camp David today and worked to build support among Democratic Congressional leaders for an energy program that his staff is scheduled to deliver to him tomorrow.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy

title: Shift of Chemicals in Queens Sought
description: Almost 100 drums of pesticides, waste oil and unknown chemicals are piled up in a storeroom in the New York State Pavilion on the grounds of the 1964 World's Fair, and the city's Parks Department is calling in wastedisposal contractors to get rid of them.

title: Stabler Allowed to Make Trade
description: The Oakland Raiders have very reluctantly given their unhappy quarterback, Ken Stabler, permission to try to work out a trade with four clubs, including the Giants.

title: 3 Win Humanitas Prizes
description: LOS ANGELES, July 9 (AP)  Episodes of CBSTV's Lou Grant, ABCTV's Taxi and NBC's television movie Summer of My German Soldier were named winners today of the 1979 Humanitas Prizes for television writing.

title: The City
description: Rupert Murdoch, the publisher of The New York Post, has filed a xi million libel suit against Esquire magazine, its former publisher, Clay Felker, and two of its current editors, Richard Reeves and Chris Welles, charging them with defaming several Murdoch publications including The Post.

title: 4 Lead By Shot In Open
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., July 9  Mal Galletta of Glen Cove, who led early in the day, found himself in a fourway tie late this afternoon after the first round of the New York State open golf championship.

title: Ship Tries to Solve Sea Riddle
description: ABOARD GLOMAR CHALLENGER GO in the hole! shouted Glen N. Foss, the operations manager, and the command was echoed joyously across the floodlit drill platform and up into the towering derrick Sunday evening. It became a lusty cheer.

title: Consensus Is Reached: Psychotherapy Works
description: FOR decades, scientists have been unable to reach a consensus on whether or not psychotherapy does much good. But when 200 specialists from around the world gathered in Oxford, England, last week there was hardly any disagreement with the thesis that it is, indeed, effective.

title: A Skinner Sampler
description: The ideal of woman was the exquisite, perfectly dressed Parisienne, the gracefully agitated beauty of the canvas by Boldini, that Paganini of the teagowns, whose swirling brush made fairly audible the rustle of taffetas and the whisper of satins. She was the heroine of the popular novel by Paul Bourget, the alluring little married woman whose soul was complicated, whose mind was simple and who was constantly, madly and clandestinely in love. It was usually an involved but superficial love, one which could find fulfillment only in that afternoon rendezvous which was known as the fourtofive, the hour when she could risk rushing to her lover's apartment for an all too brief encounter.

title: Companies Report Their Earnings Results for Latest Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: REENTRY OF SKYLAB IS LIKELY TOMORROW
description: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 10 Skylab's expected reentry time is now set for shortly after noon tomorrow over Ascension Island in the South Atlantic. If the latest predictions are correct, debris from the spacecraft, which is expected to disintegrate when it hits the earth's atmosphere, will fall along a 4,000mile path starting in the southern Indian Ocean and ending in the northern Pacific just south of Alaska.

title: About New York
description: As the city's buses go, the Q101 carries the most troubled riders. These are the relatives and loved ones of an island of accused criminals who can't make bail  quiet bus passengers who make the round trip between freedom and Rikers island prison, grasping shopping bags of treats for the accused and holding the hands of small children spawned into a world they did not make, a world filled with crime and streaked with retribution.

title: How to Move the Bishop
description: Bishop Abel Muzorewa, the Prime Minister of Zimbabwe Rhodesia, is. in Washington this week because he believes that early American acceptance is the key to the survival of his embattled Government. He is probably wrong about that; what he most needs to demonstrate is that he is accepted by the Rhodesian people. But his visit will serve a useful purpose if it leads the Carter Administration to define for him the conditions under which it might eventually recognize his Government and end American economic sanctions against it.

title: Theodore Lyle Hazlett Jr., at 60; Was Head of A.W. Mellon Trust
description: PITTSBURGH, July 9  Theodore Lyle Hazlett Jr., president of the A.W. Mellon Educational and Charitable Trust, died yesterday in St. Francis General Hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: Big Rails Had Profitable Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  The Interstate Commerce Commission reported today that the earnings of the nation's largest railroads bad moved into the black in the first quarter of this year.

title: Sun Increases July Gasoline
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (UPI) Sun Petroleum Products Inc. said today that it had increased its July gasoline allocation level from 70 to 75 percent, retroactive to July 1.

title: Plain Truth for an Old Region
description: Regional recovery, says the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, is the business of the 1980's. By choosing the word recovery instead of the familiar development, the authority emphasizes the kind of improvement the economy needs. This region experienced its first growth long ago. The task now is to face the reality of decay and then, harder still, to overcome it while competing with younger cities.

title: Turkey Is Not Iran
description: CLEVELAND  One of the side effects of the revolution in Iran has been an upsurge of newsmedia interest in Turkey. Although the coverage is nowhere near the amount given to Iran, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's neighbor to the west has been getting more than its usual share of attention.

title: Split Appeals Court Orders Torsney Freed From State Mental Hospital
description: Robert Torsney, the white police officer acquitted by reason of insanity in the killing of a black Brooklyn youth, was ordered released from a mental hospital yesterday by a sharply divided Statecourt of Appeals. The court found he was not presently dangerous either to himself or to others.

title: Now Hear This: A Woman Is Running the Ship
description: ABOARD S.S. SURVEYOR OFF ALASKA  Ashore, in her Navy. style uniform, Kathleen Edwards has sometimes been mistaken for a meter maid and beseeched by motorists not to write them overtime parking tickets  which she always graciously refrains from doing.

title: Deaths
description: ABELOWAryeh Leib. Young Israel of Oceanside extends condolences to member Mr Aaron Abelow and family upon the loss of his beloved father.

title: Rights of Shoplifting Suspects
description: A Manhattan appeals court yesterday ruled that a shoplifting suspect cannot be photographed or fingerprinted while being detained by a store's security force. The 2to1 decision by the Appellate Term stemmed from a false imprisonment suit brought by a man who had been detained as a suspected shoplifter by Bloomingdale's security force. After being asked to fill out forms and being photographed and fingerprinted, the man was released and no criminal charges were ever brought against him.

title: Nicaragua's Rebels Plan for Economy
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 9Advisory groups set up by the Nicaraguan rebel junta to guide its economic thinking have recommended greater government involvement in the economy, protection of private enterprise that is fulfilling a social function, redistribution of land based on farm cooperatives and new regulations on foreign capital.

title: Handicapping the Arms Debate
description: Two questions, not one, confront the country as the Senate begins hearing testimony for and against the SALT II treaty: 1. Are American weapons adequate to deter a Soviet nuclear attack? 2. Will the treaty make them more or less adequate?

title: Dial	a-Skylab
description: The phone company; which has given us DialaJoke, DialaHoroscope and other homeopathic aids, has lnaugurated a new service that has a life expectancy of about three days, give or take a day.

title: Fund to Buy 19% Interest In Domtar
description: The Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec, the pension fund office of the province of Quebec, agreed yesterday to pay: $75.6 million (Canadian) for nearly 19 percent of Domtar Inc., Canada's thirdlargest forestproducts company.

title: Library Ousts Store Manager After Paying $82,000 forFake Supplies
description: The manager of the New York Public Library's two retail sales shops was dismissed last month after an audit indicated that the library had paid $82,000 for nonexistent supplies.

title: Many in Congress Doubt Voters Back Carter Call for Fast Action on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  Congress returned to the Capitol today from a week at home, with many of its members saying that President Carter's desire for legislative action on energy appeared greater than their constituents'.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Miss Gayle Named for Arts Post
description: Margot Gayle, founder and president of the Friends of Cast Iron Architecture, many examples of which are found in the SoHo district, was nominated by Mayor Koch yesterday as a member of the Art Commission. He also proposed Dr. Thomas H. Fay, director of the speech and hearing clinic at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, and Ramon W. Pagan, a Queens lawyer, as members of the Environmental Control Board.

title: Knight's Intensity Stirs Games
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 9  Bobby Knight is having problems. People do not seem to understand him at the Pan American Games.

title: Senator Talmadge Begins Defense
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)  An accountarn testifying in behalf of Senator Herman E. Talmadge told the Senate Ethics Committee today that the Senator's chief accuser had spent. $38,000 more than his income Over two years in which be was laundering money through secret bank account in Washington.

title: VANCE AND BROWN DEFEND ARMS PACT AT SENATE HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  The Carter Administration began a detailed defense of the strategic arms treaty today, with a central argument that the United States would be safer with the agreement than without it.

title: Money
description: Dealer's Com. Paper:

title: Notes on People
description: A festive weekend in Las Vegas in 1975 turned decidedly sour for William J. Levitt, the pioneer builder of housing developments, and his wife, Simone. The New York couple, staying at Caesars Palace with other wellknown invited guests for a tennis tournament organized by Alan King, were the the victims of jewel thieves.

title: Gifts of John D. Rockefeller 3d Totaled $94 Million Over His Lifetime
description: The first listing ever made of a lifetime of giving by John D. Rockefeller 3d  who died a year ago today has tallied $94 million in philanthropic contributions by the man regarded as the least public of five Rockefeller brothers.

title: OBSERVER Let's Play President
description: The easy way is to make Saudi Arabia the 51st state. We get the oil while the Saudis get two seats in the Senate and the blessings of life under the Equal. Employment Opportunity law. Sweet deal.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS India's Police Riot
description: NEW DELHI  A national commission appointed by the Indian Government to look into the working conditions of the 900,000strong police force. reported recently that the people looked upon it as brutal, corrupt and inefficient.

title: News of the Theater Gasoline Crisis Clips Peter Pan's Wings
description: PETER PAN is trying to find a way around the gasoline shortage  just like ordinary mortals. This musical revival, starring Sandy Duncan and George Rose, has just started a crosscountry trek that was supposed to have reached Broadway, its final destina tion, in October. But the producers are so worried about the impact of the gas scarcity on outoftown ticket sales that they have dropped four cities from the road tour and plan to open the show here on Aug. 23 at the LuntFontanne.

title: Ballet: Cubans in Unusual Premiere and Sylphides
description: THE National Ballet of Cuba, which made its United States debut last, year, returned last night to the Metropolitan Opera House for a threeweek season. This year there was a difference. Very deliberately, the comoany's founder director and prima ballerina, took back seat. Or at least, she appeared last in a brief pas de deux on a program of five ballets.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: A Reporter's Notebook: For Somoza's   Circle, U.S. Visas
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 10 Shortly after curfew ends at 4 A.M. each morning, the crowds start gathering outside the iron gates of the United States Consulate here. By the time the offices open at 7 A.M., there are usually 300 or more people crying, imploring or angrily demanding a visa to enter the United States.

title: Entertainment Events
description: SOVIET EMIGRE MUSICIANS FESTIVAL, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

title: Bank Earnings Results Listed
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) over-the-counter.

title: U.S. and Soviet Join in a Proposal To Forbid Radiological Weapons
description: GENEVA, July 10  The United States and the Soviet Union joined today in proposing an international treaty that would outlaw weapons designed to cause destruction and injury by spreading radioactive materials without a nuclear explosion.

title: Aide Says Talmadge's Former Wife Made Threats
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) Senator Herman E. Talmadge's former wife made threats that if her husband divorced her she would get him if it was the last thing she ever did, a senior aide to Mr. Talmadge testified today.

title: The Politics of Sugar...
description: WASHINGTON  When the Sugar Act of 1764 was passed by the British Parliament, imposing strict enforcement of taxes on sugar and molasses imported to North America, it so angered the colonists that they attacked and burned British vessels patrolling for colonial sugar smugglers.

title: Money
description: TUESDAY, JULY 10, 1979

title: Dodgers Beat Mets, 74, in Rain
description: The Mets and the Los Angeles Dodgers played for nearly three hours last night to determine which team would own the worst record in the National League. The Mets lost the game, 74, and won the honor.

title: COMMODITIES Grains and Soybeans Dip In Selloff by Speculators
description: Soybean and grain futures prices tumbled yesterday as heavy selling by Chicago speculators more than offset the continued buying by export and other commercial interests.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, JULY 10, 1979

title: Hong Kong Gets 1,300 Refugees
description: HONG KONG July 10 (Reuters) More than 1,300 KONG, refugees arrued today in seven boats, bringing the population of boat people in this overcrowded city to 64,000, a Government spokesman said.

title: Real Estate
description: GREAT NECK, L.I. At a construction site on Great Neck Road the other day, all attention focused on the crane. Its job was to lift eightton airconditioning units to the roof of a steel skeleton that one day would be The Towers, a large office building.

title: Q&A
description: Q I have a curious habit of buying odd ingredients sometimes without knowing quite what they are to be used for. One of my recent purchases was a can of walnut oil that I found in France. Now I'm h6me and don't know what to do with it.

title: Behavior of Z Judges Is Criticized As Court Reverses 3 Convictions
description: In a rare action, New York State's highest court, the Court of Appeals, overturned three convictions yesterday because of the personal behavior of two trial judges.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DENVER, July 10:(AP)  The Hamilton Brothers, ,Pgtroleutii? orporation has,agreed inn principle to sell its working interest, in :'substantially all ite Canadian .preluding oil And gas propertiesto Carter Oil andLtd. of Vtincouver, British; Columbia, it was ;announcedtoday.

title: Shcharansky Blindness Is Feared
description: Moscow, July 10  The mother of Anatoly B. Shcharansky said today that her son was in danger of losing his eyesight in prison where he is serving a 13year sentence for treason.

title: Vote Proposal Dies in Louisiana
description: BATON ROUGE, La., July 10 (AP) A resolution to approve voting representation in Congress for the District of Columbia failed to reach debate in the Louisiana House and died as the session ended. The Senate had passed it. The proposal would give the District two United States senators and at least one representative. It is now represented in the House by a nonvoting delegate.

title: Gold Watch: Now or Later?
description: The American predilection for early retirement appears to be waning, slowing a trend of the 70's that many futurists once predicted would put the nation's average retirement age below 55 by the year 2000.

title: Union Plans Offshore Rig
description: The Union Oil Company of California said yesterday that it planned to build a $90 million offshore oil and gas drilling platform in the Gulf of Mexico, about 100 miles south of Galveston, Tex., Union Oil said that it would act as operator for a group that includes the Mobil Oil Company and the Amoco Production Company.

title: Canadiens Breakup
description: Piece by piece, like Skylab, the Montreal Canadiens have begun to fall. Keim Dryden, the scholarly goaltender, has retired in order to devote his intellect to studying law books instead of stopping slap shots. Jacques Lemaire, the best hockey player that virtually nobody knows, has defected to a Swiss team for a $65,000 taxfree

title: 81 AllStar Game Site
description: CLEVELAND, July 10 (AP) Cleveland will be the site of the 1981 AllStar Game, Gabe Paul, president of the Cleveland Indians, announced today. The last AllStar Game in Cleveland attracted only about 44,000 fans in 1963.

title: News Summary
description: Price controls on gasoline will be kept. by President Carter because he be. lieves that prices would rise sharply if they are lifted, his press secrertary, Jody Powell, said. White House aides expect the President to take measures to reduce oil imports by four to five million barrels daily next year through conservation and the use of synthetic fuels and alternate energy sources. They were preparing a series of options for an energy program for delivery to

title: Western Reporter Says Soviet Is Harassing Him
description: MOSCOW, July 10 (AP)  The correspondent of The Financial Times of London said today that the Foreign Ministry has renewed his accreditation, not for the usual sixmonth period, but for six weeks.

title: No Title
description: Doug Gilbert, at 40, Columnist In Sports for The Edmonton Sun

title: Shopping for Lower Gas Prices Causes Car Lines at Some Sellers
description: Most service stations in the metropolitan area were pumping gasoline with little delay yesterday, but lines occasionally reappeared as some costconscious motorists decided that a lower price was worth a little wait.

title: O.E.C.D Prices Up in May
description: PARIS, July 10 (AP)  Consumer prices in the 24nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development rose 1 percent in.May, the organization said today. The increase in the 12 months ended in May was 9.1 percent. Prices rose 4.7 percent in the first five months of the year in the O.E.C.D. countries.

title: Frail and Alone, a Jewish Activist Waits in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, July 10  In a bare tworoom apartment left from better days, one of the last of the Jewish activists lives alone, in frail health, waiting for an answer he was promised within a month six months ago.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: THERE are those who believe that feeling guilty isn't what it used to be. They say that there is absolutely no remorse these days getting away with whatever can be gotten from a certain department of government, that extramarital flings don't raise an eyebrow, and that the number of aunt's funerals that are celebrated at Yankee Stadium each summer, without so much as qualm, is too awesome to contemplate.

title: WNBC Gives 9 Segments Of Knowledge to PBS
description: In an unusual move, WNBCTV has donated nine installments of its earlymorning Knowledge series to PBS for distribution on noncommercial stations.

title: Son of Sam Killer Is Slashed in the Neck at Attica
description: ATTICA, N.Y., July 10  David R. Berkowitz, the confessed Son of Sam killer, was slashed in the neck today on a work detail at the Attica correctional facility, where he is serving 25 years to life for murder.

title: Everybody's Pops
description: A few years ago, someone discovered that whitehaired Arthur Fiedler, the conductor of the Boston Pops Orchestra, was not truly Santa Claus. He had a temper; he liked to make money; he was contemptuous of those who pestered him for, autographs; and he even professed a distaste for children that would have pleased W.C. Fields. Pedantic music lovers, and a few who were merely serious, pointed out that Mr. Fiedler's concerts appealed to those who preferred hear only the music they had liked before sitting down in the concert hall.

title: Arthur Fiedler, 84, Conductor Of Boston Pops 50 Years, Dies
description: Arthur Fiedler, conductor of the Boston Pops Orchestra for 50 years and one of the world's bestknown musical figures, died yesterday morning at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 84 years old.

title: Frenchman Upsets Vilas
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 10 (UPI)  Pascal Portes of France sprang the major upset of the first round of the $75,000 Swiss open tennis championships today by defeating topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, 61, 62.

title: Scientists Warn U.S. Of Carbon Dioxide Peril
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 In a report to the Council on Environmental Quality, a group of scientists warned today of the rapidly growing impact of carbon dioxide on the earth's climate and asked that the problem be addressed in the formulation of new energy policy by President Carter.

title: Many Ways to Cut Down on Sodium
description: To lower your own salt intake, start by not adding salt at the table and certainly never before you taste your food. At the same time, gradually reduce the amount you use in cooking.

title: Among Futurists, A Prophet of Boom
description: EVERYWHERE the prophets cry gloom and doom. Our energy future is a mess, they say; the prospects for the coming decades dismal.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter will retain controls on gasoline prices because of his belief that prices would probably rise sharply without the controls, said Jody Powell, the White House press secretary. But White House aides also expect the President to adopt a program intended to reduce oil imports by four million to five million barrels a day next year through conservation and the use of synthetic fuels and alternative energy sources. [Page A1.]

title: Mayers Score Upset in Doubles
description: There are only four teams in the Forest Hills Invitational doubles field, but when tennis fans remember the opening round of this year's invitation  if they remember the opening round of this year's invitation  it will be because of a doubles match that overshadowed the singles competition.

title: Edwin A. Mason, 74, a Naturalist
description: Edwin A. Mason, a naturalist, lecturer and author of books and articles on conservation, died Monday at the Hughes Convalescent Hospital in West Hartford, Conn., after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Farmington, Conn.

title: Business Records
description: TUESDAY, JULY 10, 1979

title: Ribicoff May Delay Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 President Carter was warned today that his timetable for rapid enactment of legislation to implement a new trade liberalization pact was jeopardized by his failure to offer a plan to reorganize the Administration's trade authority, which is now lodged in a dozen offices and agencies.

title: After the Gas Lines Disappear
description: President Carter seemed determined to return from his retreat to Camp David with an energy strategy that will save the economy from OPEC and his Presidency from derision. There is a danger, however, that in the serenity of the Catoctin Mountains, his resolve will ebb. For even if the country is sincere in professing to want bold actiozf, shaking loose from OPEC's grip will require a level of public sacrifice that is not likely to be politically Ovular.

title: Kucinich Blames Bank for Default
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich said today that Cleveland had beh forced into financial default by one big bank's lust for Dower.

title: Tim Gullikson Triumphs In Rhode Island Tennis
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 10 (AP) Topseeded Tim Gullikson survived a strong effort by John Austin today and defeated the older brother of Tracy Austin, 64, 6.7, 63, in the $100,000 Hall of Fame tennis tournament.

title: Mellon Profits Up in Quarter
description: The Mellon National Corporation yesterday announced a 24 percent increase in secondquarter net operating earnings to $25.2 million, or $1.29 a share, compared with $20.3 million, or $1.04 a share, in the yearearlier period.

title: COSTA RICANS EXPEL U. S. AIR FORCE UNIT
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 10  Costa Rica's Government today ordered the United States to withdraw a small Air Force contingent that landed near the border with Nicaragua on Sunday night because permission to station the troops there had not been properly obtained.

title: Bridge Unit Drops 2 Accused as Cheats
description: Two of the country's most(successful players,,. Steve Sion of Masgate, Fla., and Allan Cokin of Pompano Beach, Fla., i%ere expelled from the American Contract Bridge League earlier, this week after a lengthy hearing had considered cheating charges against them. When the accusations were filed against them last month, they denied the charges and refused public comment.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: It's hard to resist Oriental shops. Among all the gimcrack objets d'art, it's also possible to finding something to wear that's both inexpensive and chic. There is a delightful new spacious emporium called Orienhouse Enterprises at 424 Broadway, near Canal Street, where the merchandise is mainly Chinese. It has a counter devoted to karate and kung fu gear. The jacket and pants outfits are perfect to wear around a beach house or the beach itself: the wrapped karate coat, of heavy white cotton, goes with pants that have slotted drawstring belts at the waist ($20.50 to $28.50, depending on size). The kung fu outfit is black cotton, with white frogs on the jacket and midcalf pants with drawstrings at the bottom of the legs ($28). Fabric kung fu shoes are $5 and $5.50. Check out the crocheted white cardigan sweaters and the quilted silk jackets, some of which are reversible and padded with camel hair. If you know a small child, you'll probably not resist the felt baby shoes, embroidered with butterflies and flowers ($2.50).

title: Course on Film Comedians To Be Given at the Modern
description: Leonard Maltin, a film historian and author, will present eight lectures about great film comedians beginning next Wednesday at the Museum of Modem Art.

title: SENATORS BACK RISE IN REFUGEE QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  The Senate Judiciary Committee unanimqusly approved, a bill today that would significantly facilitate the entry into this country of large numbers of refugees from Indochina and elsewhere.

title: Italy's Steelworkers Start Strike; Clashes Are Reported in 2 Cities
description: ROME, July 10 (UPI)  Steelworkers went on strike throughout Italy today, blocking major highways and clashing with the police in two cities.

title: Mariners Foil Guidry In the Kingdome, 51
description: SEATTLE, July 10  The Kingdome syndrome struck the Yankees once again tonight, not only adding a loss to the team's woefully poor record in Seattle, but also raising a couple of problems the Yankees never had encountered in the Mariners' indoor stadium.

title: French Vineyards: A Spirited New Guide
description: JUST before you reach Margaux, as you drive north from Bordeaux into the wine country of the Mdoc, you pass through the tiny hamlet of Cantenac, the site of Alexis Lichine's famous Chateau PrieurLichine. Just before Cantenac is the equally tiny town of Labarde. Mr. Lichine also owns few vines there.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Byron H. Miller, a 52yearold onetime Navy pilot and former executive of the Boeing Company, was named president yesterday of Airbus Industrie of North America, the American sales organization of the fournation European consortium that produces the Airbus jumbo jet airliner. He succeeds George A, Warde, 58, the former American Airlines president who was promoted to senior vice presidentcommercial for the consortium in Toulouse, France.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, July 10 (AP) The National Party of Nigeria held a narrow lead today in Senate elections, winning 22 of the 63 seats so far decided, against 21 for the Unity Party of Nigeria, 16 for the Nigerian People's Party and 4 for the Great Nigeria People's Party.

title: The City
description: The City Council voted 28 to 11 yes- terday to raise the pay of the Mayor and 50 other elected officials, including the 43 members of the Council.

title: Many Pet Foods, Too, Are High in Salt Content
description: Is the family pet getting more salt than it needs?

title: Abstinence Without Remorse
description: EVEN as a child I had almost an addiction to salt. It was customary in my home to make fresh ice cream every Sunday in a handcranked freezer. To prepare it, the dasher would go into the freezer barrel, the custard would be added and the barrel set to turn, surrounded by a heavy packing of ice and rock salt.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The Times on Monday discussing American military strategy, a paragraph about Soviet activity in the South China Sea was incorrectly attributed to Adm. Harry D. Train. The material should not have had quotation marks.

title: Falling Craft Recalls Odd Array of Objects That Crashed to Earth
description: The sky may not be falling, but this will not be the first time that strange objects have descended from it.

title: The Region
description: Rejecting pleas by state health officials, the New York Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the right of parents to choose laetrile as cancer therapy for their child.

title: Carey Signs Bill to Cut Premiums for Houses In Areas of High Risk
description: Governor Carey signed a bill yesterday that sharply reduces home insurance rates for those unable to buy insurance on the normal market because their neighborhoods are considered bad risks.

title: Banco Exterior Plans Purchase
description: The Banco Exterior de Espana, which owns the Century National Bank in New York, plans to acquire the Bank of Suffolk County in Stony Brook, L.I., for $5.4 million, it was announced yesterday.

title: In a Hotel's Lobby, Echoes of the Forlorn and Eager
description: A New York City hotel lobby at midsummer is teeming and lonely, full of ennui and anticipation.

title: In Midlife, Symptoms of Adolescence
description: SME is 13. I am 44. She is fierce, stubborn, restless, impatient, lovable, lazy, a pack rat, bankrupt, charming, already taller than am. I understand perfectly when she asks me the meaning of the word voluptuous. And the ener gy. It rolls before her like a long sea swell, rolls right through these rooms, right out the windows.

title: NASA Aides Are Relieved Maneuver Seems Unneeded
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  If current predictions hold, Skylab officials will be spared the moral dilemma implicit in any action taken to change the doomed space station's reentry time and place, which would have reduced the risks of some people being injured by falling fragments at the expense of others.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Cordura Corporation, a Los Angelesbased diversified businessservices company, has named Alfred Di Scipio chairman and chief executive officer of Douglas Dunhill Inc., Oak Forest, Ill., a subsidiary.

title: Army Weighing City Plea to Help Demolition Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  A proposal to use Federal troops and military technicians to demolish or seal up abandoned buildings throughout New. York City is being seriously considered by the Secretary of the Army.

title: In Paris, An Affection for American Food
description: LTHOUGH it would be a gross exaggeration to say that American food is taking Paris by storm, there are conspicuous examples of its increasing impact: iceberg lettuce in fancy food shops, hamburgers ,classique in the women's magazines, and a new flourish of casual American restaurants. At least a few such places have achieved a steady popularity with a clientele that is primarily French, young and fashion conscious. Most of these restaurants reflect the easygoing informality of P.J. Clarke's on Third Avenue, complete with lively bar scenes and blackboard menus that list (in English only) hamburgers, fried or barbecued chicken, spareribs, chili, broiled fish, baked potatoes, cole slaw, spinach salad, brownies, lemon meringue pie and cheese cake. And at all of them a complete meal can be had for between $10 and $15, no small achievement in Paris today.

title: Skylab Controllers in Effort to Steer Falling Craft Into the Indian Ocean
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, July 11Space officials said early this morning that the doomed Skylab space station was heading toward a reentry into the earth's atmosphere over the Pacific Ocean.

title: Vance Tells Senate Panel Pact Defeat Would Hurt NATO
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that Senate rejection of the strategic arms treaty would cause a severe worsening of relations with the Soviet Union and would be a terribly severe blow to the Western alliance.

title: Provenzano Gets A 20Year Term In Rackets Case
description: NEWARK, July 10  Anthony (Tony Pro) .Provenzano,. 63-year-old former New Jersey teamster boss and a suspect in the 1975 disappearance of James R. Hotta, was sentenced to 20 years in Federal prison today for labor racketeer-

title: Radio
description: 7Noon, WNYCFM. Sonata for Violin and Guitar, Corelli; Violin Concerto in A, Vivaldi; Symphony in D, Boccherini; Divertimento No.1 in E flat, Mozart; Slnfcaia da camera, Richter; Overture L'Itallana in Algeri, Rossini; Fantasy on a Theme from Moses in Egypt, Paganini.

title: Bonn Is Warned On Interest Rates
