description: PARIS, July 10  The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development publicly warned the West German central bank today that the bank would aggravate a general economic slowdown facing the world if it reacts to rising oil prices by increasing German interest rates.

title: 50 Translators Sought to Assist Relief Recipients
description: New York City's Human Resources Administration announced plans yesterday to hire 50 bilingual workers and to develop EnglishSpanish application forms to improve services to Hispanic welfare recipients.

title: Sam Taub, 92, Fight Announcer; Broadcast First TV Bout in 1941
description: Sam Taub, a former newspaper Office boy for Bat Masterson who became one of the pioners of sports broadcasting and the announcer for the first televised boxing match in the United States, died yesterday at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. He was 92 years old.

title: Washington Post Pact Voted
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) Reporters and other whitecollar employees at The Washington Post voted overwhelmingly today in favor of a new 36month contract providing firstyear raises averaging 7.15 percent for 1,000 employees. The contract is retroactive to April 1. In the second and third year, employees will receive pay increases averaging 3.5 percent a year.plus up to percent a year in costofliving raises, said Lawrence Wallace, The Post's chief bargainer.

title: Ford Recalls 77,700 Vans
description: DETROIT, July 10 (UPI)  A front braking system defect blamed in two accidents has prompted the Ford Motor Company to recall 77,700 1979model Econoline Vans and Club Wagons. A Ford spokesman said yesterday that no injuries had been attributed to the defect.

title: Exponent of Populist Music
description: The easiest and perhaps best way to appreciate Arthur Fiedler's accomplishment is to take him on exactly the terms he wished himself to be taken as a genial, extroverted and vigorous exponent of populism in the realm of

title: PRESIDENT PLANNING TO RETAIN CONTROLS ON GASOLINE PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  President Carter has decided against removing controls from the cost of gasoline because he believes that prices would rise more sharply than they already have and worsen inflation, his press secretary, Jody Powell, announced today.

title: Senate RollCall
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate yesterday defeated an amendment to provide direct popular election of the President:

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: THE culinary habits of various countries have long intrigued me. An Italian friend reminded me recently that tarragon is almost unknown and little used as a flavoring in Italy. In fact there are very few Italians who know that the name of the herb is dragoncello.

title: Dow Falls 2.65 as 4Day Rally Ends
description: A fcu.r.day market rally ended abruptly yesterday as profittaking and some investor nervousness over President Carter's prolonged public silence on the energy problem depressed the Dow Jones industrial average by 2.65 points. But volume continued heavy.

title: Galletta Leads by 4 In State Open Golf
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., July 10It's sweet, real sweet. I'm glad there's one more round to play, Mal Galletta Jr. said today after turning in another 68 in the second. New York State open golf tournament. That matched his effort yesterday and left the 38yearold head pro from Glen Cove Golf Club at sixunderpar 136 with a fourstroke lead.

title: Divers Hopes Rise for Treasure in Sunken Galleon
description: KEY WEST, Fla., July 10 (AP)More than 300 years ago, wealthy passengers eager to strip the New World of its treasure boarded the Spanish galleon Nuestra Senora de Atocha. Now divers salvaging what they believe is the sunken ship say they have reached firstclass compartments and the loot of her longdead occupants.

title: EARNINGS
description: Sales and earnings of the Caterpillar Tractor Company set records in the second quarter, but gains were pared from the initial three months,accord ing to a semiannual report issued yesterday by the nation's largest maker of earthmoving machinery and equipment.

title: Times Gives Court Data On Minority Employees
description: Updated statistics show that The New York Times has more minority employees than the percentage in relevant labor pools nationally and locally, according to a study the newspaper filed in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Forecasts Revised For North Sea Oil
description: LONDON, July 10 (AP)  Britain's Department of Energy reduced its estimates of oil production in the North Sea during the next three years, citing technical delays. However, in today's annual report on the development of the nation's oil and gas reserves, the department said the delays would lead to larger production than previously predicted for the late 1980's.

title: Economic Scene
description: AS we reach the summer of 1979, that summer perennial weed, crisis energeticus, is in full bloom, richly fertilized this year by the production and pricing policies of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Bowker to Quit as Berkeley's Chancellor Next June
description: BERKELEY, Calif., July 10  Albert H. Bowker announced today that he would resign next June as the chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, a position he took in 1971 when the institution still felt the impact of antiwar demonstrations and was trying to cope, with the effects of diminished state financial support.

title: Notes on People
description: Since the funeral of Howard R. Hughes, there has been much speculation on the cause of his death. Some associates said an addiction to the tranquilizer Valium was the direct cause, while others said it was an addiction to the painkiller, codeine.

title: Governors Unit Backs Decontrol of Oil Prices With Tax on Windfall
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 10  The National Governors Association today endorsed phased decontrol of domestic oil prices combined with a windfall profits tax, but went part of the way toward the industry positidn by saying that oil companies should be able to avoid some of the tax by putting profits into new energy development.

title: 2,000 Jersey Workers Go on Wildcat Strike Over Pact
description: TRENTON, July 10  Between 2,000 and 3,000 of the state's 70,000 employees defied the leadership of two unions today and staged a wildcat strike that disrupted some state services and appeared to be gaining strength.

title: Companies List Their Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (o) overthecounter.

title: Lessons of a Bad War
description: Over the last several months, seems that everyone, from President Carter to liberal newspaper columnists who imply an earlier and stronger opposition to the war than careful reader recalls, has come down with a case of the guilts regarding Vietnam veterans. Inconsonance with the r recent spate of awardwinning movies and books, they make the point that American G.I.'s were somehow cheatedout of their due, that instead of honor and gratitude they have been received with apathy; and abuse.

title: No Title
description: Ernst Kuhrmeier, 59; Sentenced After Crdit Suisse Bank Scandal

title: Retail Sales Off Again In June
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  Retail sales fell in June for the third consecutive month, giving further evidence that the nation's economy may be moving into a recession, the Government said yesterday.

title: Director of Skylab Project
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  If there could be said to be a spaceage man, the term most likely would apply to the director of the Skylab Project at the program's very end.

title: ADM. J.C. DEMPSEY, SUBMARINE SKIPPER
description: Rear Adm. James Charles Dempsey. retired, the submarine commander who sank the first Japanese destroyer in World War II and evacuated the last Americans. from the island of Corregidor, died Monday night of congestive heart and kidney failure at the Portsmouth Naval Hospital in Norfolk, Va, He was 70 years old.

title: T.W.A. to Pare Overseas Service
description: Citing soaring fuel costs, Trans World Airlines announced plans yesterday to discontinue service on several marginal overtions. The flight cancellations, effective in October, represent less than 1 percent of the airline's capacity. T.W.A. said.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ON THE TOWN John Tauranac knows New York. He has just helped create the'city's new subway map for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, where he works. He is the author of Seeing New York: the Official MTA Travel Guide, a contributor to New York magazine and, a tour guide for the Municipal Art Society, Classical America and the Mayor's office.

title: U.S. Defeats Cuba, 10183; More Problems for Knight
description: SAN JUAN, P.R. July 10  Still surrounded by controversy, the United States men's basketball team remained unbeaten in the Pan American Games today by defeating Cuba, 10183, with Mike Woodson of Indiana scoring 27 points. Meanwhile, Coach Bobby Knight was confronted with another problem.

title: 2 National Air Bidders Advance
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  The Civil Aeronautics Board today tentatively approved bids by both Pan American World Airways and Texas International Airlines to acquire National Airlines, setting the stage for a scramble for the stock of the Miamibased air carrier.

title: Thea ter. Giorio us Monster
description: THE Glorious Monster in the Bell of the Horn is complex and often obscure, but a formidable beauty, and wit come through ft. It is, in its present state, an exciting possibility waiting to become fully real.

title: Jersey's Turnpike Bonds Sell Readily at 7.08%
description: Disregarding the gasoline shortage, investors spoke up quickly yesterday to buy $591.5 million worth of New Jersey Turnpike Authority bonds that are being sold today at taxfree yields as high as 7.08 percent.

title: No Title
description: Arthur L. Jacobs, 77 Years Old; Lawyer and Official of Arts Club

title: Begin Meets Sadat at Alexandria; Visits a Synagogue and Is Cheered
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 10 President Anwar elSadat and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel opened talks here today about autonomy of Palestinians in Israelioccupied territory and other issues.

title: Israel Plans New Village On ArabClaimed Land
description: TEL AVIV, July 10  The Israeli Government asked the Supreme Court in Jerusalem today for clearance to start building another Jewish village on Arab land in a strategic area of the occupied West Bank.

title: Iran's Premier Yields to Khomeini, Agreeing Not to Dismiss a General
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 10  The Government of Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan has given up efforts to remove a senior army commander who objected to any return of foreign military experts, mostly Americans, to maintain Iran's huge arsenal of Western weapons.

title: Paris Museum Salutes a Dealer
description: THE Museum of Modern Art of Paris has assembled a remarkable array of paintings, drawings and sculptures. Remarkable in its size  232 works  and its variety: from Arp to'Zao Wouki, from Picasso and Matisse to Kandinsky and Ernst. Helton, Giacometti and Balthus rub frames with African masks, New Guinea statuary and Coptic textiles.

title: Report on WholeLife Insurance Says Buyers Lose Billions Yearly.
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  Buyers of wholelife insurance, the most popular form of insurance sold in this country, are losing billions of dollars a year because insurpnce companies are not providing the kind of information needed for consumers to make intelligent decisions, a report released today by the Federal Trade Commission concludes.

title: Survey Finds Youths Lacking in Knowledge Needed by Consumers
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)Many 17yearold high school students are being shortchanged on the skills they need to be good consumers, a Governmentfinanced study indicates. the report, made public yesterday by the National Assessment of Educational Progress, is based on a survey of 4,300 young persons.

title: Farm Groups Seek Law to Force GoodFaith Deals by Middlemen
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI)  Four farm organizations today joined in asking Congress to force middlemen and food processors to bargain in good faith with farmers' organizations in setting terms of sale and prices for food products.

title: Pilot Trading Plan Is Set For Commodity Options
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, taking a major step toward allowing trading of commodity options, set guidelines yesterday for a pilot program in options on three commodities and directed its staff to develop a complete rules program by the end of this month.

title: Voice Fire Alarms Save 60,000 Runs in 6 Months
description: The New York City Fire Department's sevenmonthold policy of not responding to alarms from voiceoperated street boxes unless someone is heard requesting help has saved more than 60,000 unnecessary runs by firefighting equipment in the last six months, the city's Fire Commissioner said yesterday.

title: No Title
description: Kurt F. Rosenblad, 80; Invented Heat Processes Kurt F. Rosenblad, 80; Invented Heat Processes

title: Synthetic Fuel Costs Called High
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  An analysis prepared by the Rand Corporation for the Energy Department concludes that any crash effort to build syntheticfuel plants in the United States would cost billions of dollars more than the initial estimates and could crowd out other investments that would bolster industrial productivity and help control inflation.

title: New Dance by Paul Taylor To Have Premiere on TV
description: The world premiere of Profiles, a new dance by Paul Taylor, will be televised nationally from Durham, N.C., by the Public Broadcasting Service's Live From the American Dance Festival program on July 28. This marks the first time a dance premiere will be broadcast live.

title: Thais Readmit 1,000 Cambodians For Later Resettlement Elsewhere
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 10About 1,000 of the more than 45,000 Cambodian refugees forcibly returned to their country by Thailand last month have been allowed to cross back into Thailand.

title: Air Canada Orders Dozen 767's
description: OTTAWA, July 10  Air Canada has decided to buy 12 Boeing 767's for total of about $468 million in American currency in a further step toward renewal of Canada's civil and military air fleets.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI)  In the biggest surge since the recession of 197475, violent crime soared 17 percent in the first quarter this year and the overall crime rate rose 11 percent, the Government reported today.

title: JAPANESE ESTIMATE ON REFUGEES IS CUT
description: TOKYO, July 10  Japan expects to allow fewer than 100 Indochinese refugees to settle here permanently despite its pledge to accept up to 500 refugees under an expanded program announced three months ago, a senior Government official said today.

title: Trust Holds 2d Hearing On Modern Museum Plan
description: Sparse attendance and lackluster questions marked a twohour public hearing On the proposed, expansion of the Museum of Modern Art last night.

title: 3Year General Electric Contract Is Ratified by Two Major Unions
description: A new contract between the General Electric Company and two major unions representing 85,000 employees was ratified yesterday by union members.

title: Sun to Appeal on Becton; Opinions on Ruling Differ
description: The Sun Company, stung by a Federal court ruling that its purchase last year of a 34 percent stake in Becton Dickinson & Company, a New Jerseybased hospital supplier, constituted an illegal tender offer, said yesterday that it was deeply disappointed and was preparing an immediate appeal to a higher court.

title: 3d Cab Robbery Foiled By an OffDuty Officer
description: A taxicab robbery was thwarted by an offduty policeman for the third straight day yesterday when Officer Milton Washington of the 71st Precinct wounded a gunman attempting to rob cabdriver in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Strand of Hair and Teeth Marks Cited in Murder Trial of Student
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., July 10  A set of keys with what appeared to be bloodstain, a strand of red hair and teeth marks have emerged as the central items of evidence in the trial of a 29yearold Columbia University medical student accused of murdering a fellow student.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: North Korea Rejects 3Way Talks
description: TOKYO, July 10 (Reuters)  The North Korean Foreign Ministry today rejected as not feasible a proposal for talks between the two Koreas and the United States to reduce tension on the Korean peninsula, according to the North Korean news agency.

title: Quality and
description: CHICAGO, July 10  It's doubtful that any housewife ever stood, wideeyed and wishful, in the middle of her kitchen, praying for the invention of crepe maker, a crock pot or electric carving knife. But when these inventions waddled off the assembly line, consumers mahaged to create at least a momentary demand.

title: 8 Court Nominees Gain; Vote on Woman Put Off
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved eight of President Cdrter's nominations to Federal appeals courts, but it postponed action on the disputed nomination of Patricia M. Wald to be judge of the Court of Appeals here.

title: Carey Vetoes Increase In Some City Pensions
description: ALBANY, July 10  At the urging of Mayor Koch, Governor Carey has vetoed a bill that would have added a costofliving increase to the pensions of 11,000 New York City general employees, teachers and policemen who retired before 1969.

title: Bedford Hills Informant Stabbed to Death in Jail
description: An informant in the May 10 killings of four Bedford Hills, N.Y., residents was stabbed to death in the Brooklyn House of Detention last night where he was being held in protective detention on robbery charges.

title: Times Mirror Is Seeking To Buy Hartford Courant
description: The giant Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to buy The Hartford Courant Company for $105.6 million, a move that would substantially add to its Eastern operations.

title: Carter Orders a 78  Cooling Limit ForPublic Buildings This Summer
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  President Carter signed a proclamation today requiring that airconditioning in commercial, government and most other public . buildings be maintained at temperatures no lower than 78 degrees Fahrenheit this summer.

title: Chess:
description: Zigzag strategy comes into play against a position that exhibits only slight weaknesses distributed across the board. In such a situation, to concentrate force against any particular soft spot only results in an impasse, but by switching operations from one weakness to another you may catch the defender off balance.

title: OftenTroubled SummerJob Program Under Way Without a Hitch
description: For the first time in history, we have the program under control, Lawrence MInard, executive director of New York City's summer youthjobs program, said yesterday.

title: Whereto Shop for LowSalt Foods
description: Health food stores are the best source for saltfree and lowsodium versions of common foods. They offer a choice of cheeses (most often Holland gouda, hut sometimes mozzarella, Monterey jack, muenster, cheddar and swiss), cottage cheese, butter and margarine. and nut butters (cashew, almond, peanut and tahini); breads, crackers and toasts; herb mixtures for seasoning salads, meat, poultry and fish; canned fruits, vegetables and soups; tins of tuna, sardines and salmon; spaghetti sauce and pastas, and cereals.

title: Four Held in the Seizing Of a Hostage at Caverns
description: CARLSBAD, N.M., July 10 (AP) Four armed men held a National Park Service worker hostage deep underground at the Carlsbad Caverns for about four hours today. The worker was released unharmed after a local newspaper publisher met with the men, who later surrendered.

title: MAINTENANCE FLAWS CALLED KEY FACTOR IN DC10 JET'S CRASH
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  A Government report today blamed American Airlines maintenance procedures in large part for the crash of a DC10 jumbo. jet in Chicago last Ray and disclosed serious shortcomings in the training of the airline's mechanics.

title: John and Guidry On AllStar Team
description: Tommy John, the Yankee who leads American League starters in victories with 13, and Ron Guidry, his teammate who leads the league's starters in earnedrun average with 2.09, were named to the league's pitching staff yesterday for next Tuesday night's AllStar Game in Seattle.

title: Letters
description: The Hope and Promise of Synthetic Fuels

title: China Oil Output Up
description: TOKYO, July 10 (AP)  China's crude oil production rose 3.6 percent in the first half of this year from the levels of the yearearlier period, the official New China News Agency reported today. The agency said production of natural gas was up by 7.4 percent, refined oil by 6.3 percent and gasoline, kerosene, diesel oil and lubricants 10.2 percent.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: AS class mother of my son's eighthgrade class, writes Peggy Boehm, it fell my lot to accompany the class on a trip to New York. Besides myself, our group consisted of a male teacher of indeterminate age and about 30 youngsters at that special 1314year age when their sizes differ widely. Some were still small, underde veloped children, while others had achieved various stages of puberty and even vigorous young manand womanhood.

title: Debating the Treaty: What They Are Saying
description: The outlook for arms control elsewhere would also be dimmed [if the treaty is rejected.] For our arguments in favor of restraint by others will be judged in large part by our commitment to SALT ... Let us therefore demonstrate that our corn mitment to the control of arms is genuine. By acting in our own selfinterest, we can also help create a world environment which promotes the interest of people elsewhere. Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

title: Swimmer Foiled in Attempt to Circle Manhattan Twice
The Pervasive Threat to Health
description: FOR at least 5,000 years, salt  sodium chloride  has been an important, indeed revered, constituent of the human food supply. Salting and drying is believed to be the first method used to preserve otherwise highly perishable meat and fish, making unspoiled food available dur-ing otherwise lean times.

title: Topics
description: One attribute of peace is that it tends to be peaceful, even somnolent. Menachem Begin flew to Alexandria yesterday for a threeday meeting with Anwar elSadat  and the world hardly notices their seventh encounter in 19 months.

title: John Wayne's Estate in Probate
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., July 10 (AP) John Wayne's will, which left the bulk of his $6.85 million estate to his family, was approved for probate today without opposition. In a brief hearing, Judge Bruce Sumner of Orange County Superior Court said three executors named by Mr. Wayne may oversee disposition of the estate. The three are Mr. Wayne's eldest son, Michael; John S. Warren, a Los Angeles attorney, and Louis Johnson, Mr. Wayne's Arizona ranching partner.

title: Books of The Times
description: I'VE been thinking about suspense novels rnd wondering why so many of them are poorly written. An experienced author like Desmond Bagley will learn all about vintage airplanes and about the customs and topography of the Algerian desert

title: Dr. Herman. Within; Pioneered in Studies Of Learning Process
description: Dr. Herman A. Witkin, an internationally known, psychologist who was a senior research, scientist at the Educational Testing Service in Princeton, N.J., died Sunday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 62 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Treaty Could Render U.S. Liable For Payments in Space Accident
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 10 In the early years of developing space technology, the United States started campaign here to convince other countries that an international treaty was needed to guarantee compensation for space accidents.

title: Voyager 2 Shifted to Permit Observation of Uranus
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 10  After what they called a very sweaty night, engineers said today they had maneuvered the Voyager 2 probe onto different path in space to preserve an option to send the craft to the distant planet Uranus in 1986 after a rendezvous with Saturn in 1981.

title: Efforts to Stay at 78 Promised by Owners
description: Owners of restaurants, theaters, office buildings and retail stores in New York said in interviews yesterday that they would try to comply with the President's order to keep the temperature in their buildings at 78 degrees.

title: Price Council Cites Charter Oil
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  The Charter Company, a Floridabased petroleum refiners is in violation of the Government's price guidelines, the Council on Wage and Price Stability said today.

title: Kitchen Equipment Fish Grills
description: THERE are any number of reasons to cook a fish whole: It looks so much grander, for one thing, than when it's decapitated and bereft of its tail. Beyond that, juices that would seep away if the head were removed are retained. But there are problems, too, in attempting to cook a whole fish, a threepound blue, for instance. The most significant is that it is so difficult to maneuver. That's why the fish poacher was invented, with its rack on which to gingerly remove the fish from the pot. And that's the reason there have been many attempts at designing devices to hold a fishintactover an open fire.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, July 2, to Sunday, July 8), fisted according to their rook in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: RCA Ends Discussions With CIT.
description: The RCA Corporation and the C.I.T. FInancial Corporation announced the termination of their merger -negotiations yesterday; triggering a wave of selling in C.I.T. shares..

title: Judy Licht Rejoining WNEW
description: Judy Licht, a former reporter for WCBSTV and WNEWTV, will return to WNEW as a coanchor of the station's 10 P.M. weeknight .newscast. Miss Licht joined WNEW, Channe!'5, in 1973 and was a reporter from 1974 to February 1978, when she left for WCBS, Channel 2. She will share anchor duties on Channel 5 with John Roland and gill McCreary.

title: Senate Rejects Proposal To End Electoral College
description: WASHINGTON July 10  The longstanding proposal to substitute direct popular election of the President for the Electoral College was defeated decisively in the Senate today and appeared to be dead for the foreseeable future.

title: Beard Advances In Games
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 10 (UPI) Jackie Beard of Nashville, and Tony Tucker of Grand Rapids, Mich., survived cuts tonight to advance to the semifinals of the Pan American Games boxing competition.

title: Market Place
description: ALL options in the July series expire automatically with the close of trading on Friday, July 20. In the risky, and sometimes rewarding, world of options trading there are always memories for the players as each series nears its final days.

description: Warren Milton Creamer, 84, Dies; Helped Design Merritt Parkway

title: U.S. Told Six Million Did Not File 77 Tax
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  In the Government's first attempt to measure the underground economy in the United States, the. General Accounting Office estimated today that six million persons failed to file Federal income tax returns in 1978 and that this cost the Treasury several billion dollars.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: As the credit markets stabilized yesterday in the wake of their sharp decline late Monday afternoon, the Farm Credit System priced three bond issues totaling $2.44 billion for sale today at yields ranging from 8.90 percent to 9.10 percent.

title: Careers
description: THE energy crisis has opened up some unusual job opportunities, and perhaps none is more esoteric and more fruitful than the field of palynology, the study of pollens.

title: Advertising
description: WHILE D'ArcyMacManus & Masius may be among the top 10 American ad agencies worldwide, its office in New York, the capital city of advertising, is relatively small.

title: What Nicaragua Doesn't Need
description: Concerning Nicaragua, the United States could usefully take a lesson in tactics from the shrewdest revolutionary in Latin America. Fidel Castro recently remarked that the best thing Cuba could do for the Sandinist rebels was to do nothing for them. In other words, for Cuba to sponsor or send arms to the Nicaraguan guerrillas would arouse a clamor for American military intervention.

title: Colorado's Coors Brewery Wins Virginia Zoning Fight
description: HARRISONBURG, Va., July 10  The staterun liquor stores here in the dry Shenandoah Valley do not display the promotional window signs saying Coors Is Here!

title: Paramount, EMI in Deal
description: LONDON, July 10  EMI Ltd., the entertainment and electronics company that made a fortune from the Beatles, is selling a half interest in its music business to the Paramount Pictures Corporation for about $154 million, it was announced today.

title: In the Loving Arms of Her Mother
Rock: Blondie in Park
description: SOMETIMES Ron Delsener puts an act into the Wollman Rink in Central Park that is really too big for the facility. Such was the case Monday night with Blondie. Not that Mr. Delsener can really be accused of a misjudgment. At the time he booked the group, it must have seemed as it this was a New York newwave rock act that was maybe beginning to break into the mainstream. But pop music moves fast, and right now Blondie is hot, with several top singles, a bestselling album and loads of national publicity.

title: Best Buys
description: ALTHOUGH labor problems in the trucking industry have eased, food costs on the whole have not. In fact, they've been showing continued rapid rise as the increased costs supermarkets had to pay during the height of the strife continue to be reflected on the shelves.

title: Carter's View Beyond Crisis
description: News Analysis

title: Miss Swados to Aid Guild Hall
description: Elizabeth Swados, the author and composer who created Runaways and the recent Dispatches, will give a benefit concert for Guild Hall of East Hampton, L.I., at the hall on Sunday night, July 22. Swados and Friends, an evening of music, will begin at 8:30. Tickets are $15 and 810; for information, call (516) 3244050.

title: MUZOREWA, IN U.S., RESISTS POLICY SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa indicated today that he would resist pressures from the Carter Administration to broaden the base of his Government and move toward more complete majority rule in Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

title: PBS Short Story Series Casts Some Productions
description: Although the second series of PBS's The American Short Story series will not be televised until early next year, the casting for some of the productions has been set.

title: Abu Dhabi Oil Exports
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, July 11 (Reuters)  Abu Dhabi exported 44.8 million barrels of crude oil in June, almost the same level as in May, the United Arab Emirates news agency reported.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Kurt F. Rosenblad, 80; Invented Heat Processes

title: Christopher Marshall, 16, a Son Of Labor Secretary Ray Marshall
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) Christoper Marshall, son of the United States Secretary of Labor, died today after a one-and-a-half-year struggle against cancer. He was 16 years old.

title: West. German Sales Up 4%
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, July 11 (AP)  West German retail sales in May were 4 percent above sales in May 1978, after adjusting for inflation, the Federal Statistics Office reported today.

title: Gas Promised by Carey Not Delivered
description: Few if any of the reserve stocks of gasoline that Governor Carey announced would be distributed to hardpressed downstate filling stations in the first 10 days of July have reached the area, according to oilcompany representatives, dealers and New York City officials.

title: Obituary 10 -- No Title
description: DEATH

title: Notes on People
description: It was one of the few court tests involving a practice. that is rarely talked about openly, but has long been assumed to occur on campus. Pamela Price said that when she was a junior at Yale University she refused to yield to a political science professor's sexual demands, and as a result got a C in his course instead of an A.

title: New or Old, Oak Is in Demand
description: IT'S a curious scene: Mouhamed Shami and his band of a dozen Lebanese craftsmen, heads down, faces intent, hard at work recreating part of America's heritage. The wail of Arabic music wars with the whirr of woodworking machines, as each man turns his bit of virgin oak into a spindle, a leaf, a leg or a lion's head. Put together, these pieces become oak tables and chairs of turnofthecentury design.

title: Samuel J. Buzzell, 87, Lawyer Represented Pop Composers
description: Samuel Jesse Buzzell, a copyright and musicpatent lawyer, died Monday in Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Long Beach.

title: Vote in Nigeria is Test of ThirdWorld Democracy
description: LONDON, July 11  In a test of thirdworld democracy, Nigeria is in the midst of an election designed to return civilian government to Africa's most populous country after 13 years of military rule.

title: Village Druggist Named in Illict Sales
description: Frank Elman, who operated a wellknown pharmacy in Greenwich Village, was indicted yesterday for allegedly selling hundreds of thousands of Quaalude tablets for more than $2. million in cash since last October.

title: Rubber Union Accused Of Unfair Labor Tactic
description: AKRON Ohio, July 11 (AP)  The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company filed unfair labor practice charges against the United Rubber Workers today, seeking to bar a strike set for midnight Monday.

title: Communists Leader In Italy Strengthened After Internal Dispute
description: ROME, July 11  Enrico Berlinguer, the secretary Of the Italian Communist Party, emerged from an internal dispute today with his powers within the party leadership surprisingly increased and his influence on future nartv Policy assured tiaratmers who had criticized his moderate leadership not only failed to make the expected gains within the party but even lost ground.

title: Around the Nation
description: MIAMI, July 11 (UPI)  Despite objections that the state was trying to inflame the passion of jurors, the jury in Theodore R: Bundy's murder trial was shown color photographs today of the bodies of two Florida State University students !leis accused of killing.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy

title: Jersey Turnpike Issue Put Off
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority's $591.5 million bond financing scheduled for sale yesterday was put off until next Tuesday for clarification of its legality.

title: Companies List Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: A Yea to the Neigh
description: WAVERLY, Iowa  The serious consideration of more widespread use of draft horses and mules in American agriculture is regarded in most circles as either a fool's heresy or simpleminded nostalgia. The usual rejoinder to any such suggestion is that we can't go back. This ignores mountains of evidence that mankind does frequently go back to practices, attitudes and methods previously discarded and that not all such steps are backward.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 11 (UPI) Vietnam said today that a Chinese battalion of 1,500 soldiers had struck more than two miles into Vietnamese territory, killing civilians and burning houses and. crops in the worst reported clash since the border war earlier this year.

title: ESSAY All The Help He Can Get
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  At the very moment that Space was tossing our cap back over itY wall, President Carter was listening, nodding and taking notes at one of the meetings of opinion leaders who made the trek up the mountain to Camp David.

title: Design Notebook
description: JONES BEACH is 50 years old this summer, and while the years have brought a lot of, building on a grand scale, this construction by the sea is still capable of inspiring awe. It is an absolutely remarkable public achievement  six and a half miles of beachfront built out of low and shifting sand dunes and filled with structures so elaborate they call to mind courthouses and college campuses, not beach buildings. There have been some changes, some losses to the original plan, but by and large Jones Beach remains what it was when it opened in August 1929  not just a beach, but one of the great pieces of public construction in the United States.

title: The CO
description: No wonder President Carter has been hiding from the energy crisis at Camp David. Most proposed solutions seem to involve untoward, even perilous consequences. The Saudi promise to pump more oil may shorten the gas lines, but it will prolong the nation's as diction to imported oil. Nuclear energy raises nightmares of an uncontrollable accident. And now the two energy sources that have lately been receiving the most political attention  coal and synthetic fuels stand accused of threatening climatic catastrophe. Is there no safe way to produce energy?

title: Theme at Camp David: Need to Lift Nation's Spirit
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  They sat down at 9:20 A.M. at the huge conference table in Laurel Lodge at Camp David, the President in a sports jacket and openneck shirt, his guests in business suits.

title: Iraq Plans to Sell More Oil to France
description: Paris, July 11  The French Government formally announced today that Iraq would sell it more oil next year as part of a new agreement on closer political and economic cooperation. The agreement follows a visit to Baghdad last weekend by the French Prime Minister, Raymond Barre.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The value of the dollar declined yesterday as gold prices also retreated from Tuesday's record levels. Traders said the United States currency fell because of uneasiness over President Carter's extended retreat at Camp David.

title: CONNALLY IS LEADING FUNDRAISING DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  Collecting campaign contributions at the rate of nearly $10,000 a day, John B. Connally has maintained his fundraising lead over rivals for the 1980 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: China Machinery Output
description: PEKING, July 11 (Reuters) China's machinebuilding industry increased production by 9 percent in the first six months of this year compared with the same period last year, the New China News Agency said today. The agency, which did not reveal the value of the machinery, said that emphasis was placed on producing equipment for coal mines, power plants, oilfields and transportation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day reported incorrectly yesterday that Trans World Airlines planned to end service from the United States to Cairo and Tel Aviv. The airline dropped nonstop flights effective June 22 but other service to those cities will continue, a spokesman said

title: Lyon Realty Offer
description: The Lyon Realty Company of Newport Beach, Calif., has extended its offer of $11 a share for Continental Illinois Realty of Santa Monica through July 27. So far, it has acquired 2.9 million shares through the tender offer, for a total of about 90.3 percent of the outstanding shares, including the 125,000 shares the company had already owned.

title: Fuel Output Up Sharply Last Week
description: Output at the nation's oil refineries reached a high point for the year in the week ended July 6, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute, an industry trade association.

title: GEN. BONN LAVALLE, VIETNAM FIGURE, DIES
description: Maj. Gen. John D. Lavelle, who retired after being relieved of his duties as commander of the United States Air Force in Southeast Asia and being demoted for ordering unauthorized air attacks against North Vietnam in 1971 and 1972, died of a heart attack Tuesday afternoon. He was 62 years old.

title: Giant Catfish Has West Germans Hooked
description: BAD ZWISCHENAHN, West Germany  The catfish that may eat Germany lives here.

title: Q & A
description: Q. The mortar between the bricks in the steps leading up to my house is crumbling, and I feel that eventually the bricks thernsetves will come loose. I have tried to remedy this by applying cement to the empty spaces, but this does not last. What do you suggest? A.D., Brooklyn

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Harvard Study Urges Conservation And Solar Use Over Synthetic Fuel
description: The United States can reduce its oil imports much faster by improving the efficiency of the economy  that is, by conservation  and by accelerating the transition to solar energy than by relying on programs to develop synthetic fuels, according to a study by the Harvard Business School.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 11, 1979

title: Oz Scott Translates Poetry to Stage
description: FOR more than three years, Oz Scott has been directing plays based on the poetry of Ntozake Shange. Starting with For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf, which was both an Off Broadway and Broadway success, and continuing with Spell #7, which will open at the Public/Anspacher on Sunday, Mr. Scott has had the task of translating her poetry to the stage,

title: Redesign: A Taste For Drama
description: IT would be hard now to see it as a problem. But in honesty it was. Ronaldus Shamask, an illustrator, theatrical and film designer and, more recently, fashion designer, was not sure what he should do with the space  an unusual triplex coop in a renovated late 19thcentury town house on the Upper East Side.

title: CBS Net Gained 11% In Quarter
description: CBS Inc., the broadcasting, publishing and recording company, reported an 11 percent gain in earnings for the second quarter of 1979, trailing a 21.6 percent rise in revenues. For the first half of this year, earnings fell 11.9 percent from the level of the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Saudi Oil: Secret Deal or Shortage of Cash?
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The decision by Saudi Arabia to increase its oil production over the next three to six months has eased strains in SaudiAmerican relations, but it left open some questions about Washington's Middle East diplomacy. Supporters of Israel are already expressing concern in private that, despite official denials, President Carter might have struck a secret deal with King Khalid to get concessions by Israel to the Palestinians in the future for oil now.

title: Mets Beat Dodgers In 10th Inning by 43
description: In the top of the ninth inning yesterday, with the score tied and runners at second and third, Davey Lopes of the, Los Angeles Dodgers hit a line drive to deep leftcenter field against the Mets at Shea Stadium.

title: 3 Indicted in Plan To Rob Air Shuttle
description: Three men were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn in an abortive plot to hijack a $2 million cash shipment from an Eastern Airlines shuttle plane.

title: Home Improvement
description: UNTIL recently, when the average homeowner thought about putting up new siding on the outside of his house, chances are that the first material he would think about was aluminum siding. However, in the past few years, things have changed considerably as solid vinyl siding  a comparative newcomer to the residing field  has become increasingly popular in many areas.

title: Japan Rate Rise Seen
description: TOKYO, July 11 (AP)  The Bank of Japan plans to raise its official discount rate to 5 percent late this month from the present 4.25 percent in an effort to curb inflationary pressures, the newspaper Asahi will report in tomorrow's edition. The discount rate is the rate at which the Bank of Japan, the country's central bank, will loan to commercial banks. Other shortterm interest rates tend to follow that rate.

title: Texas Jury Convicts Billie Sol Estes On Tax Charge and a Fraud Count
description: DALLAS, July 11 (AP)  Billie Sol Estes, the Texas financier who went to prison on fraud charges in the 1960's, was found guilty today of concealing his assets from the Internal Revenue Service and consairina to defraud investors.

title: When Children Are Houseguests For a Weekend
description: WE descend upon my brotherinlaw's house once a year for a long weekend in the country. We fill his refrigerator with Hawaiian Punch and his good glass bowl with Doritos. The kids know they have to toe the line around Uncle Rick, but somehow they manage to spill something sticky, stuff the wrong things down the disposal system and forget to put TV Guide back where they found it. Uncle Rick survives the summer invasion, determined never to have children of his own.

title: Nehemiah Outraces Casanas in Hurdles
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 11 J This time there was no rolling start, or false start, or hot words, or aiding wind, or even a world record.,

title: No Title
description: Deaths

title: U.S. and China Begin Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (Reuters) China's Finance Minister, Zhang Jingfu, conferred today with top financial officials in the opening round of meetings during a twoweek visit to the United States.

title: An Old CutUp
description: The recent and painful experience of standing on outrageous gas lines for my pitiful share of petroleum distillate has considerably heightened my sense. of the absurd.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: A 2d Lost Case Tied To Fraiman Holiday
description: Arnold G. Fraiman, the justice who was criticized Tuesday by New York State's highest court for improperly ending a 1975 trial because he was going on vacation, did a similar thing eight years ago because he was leaving for a European holiday.

title: Opera: The Impresario And Hassan in Capital
description: WASHINGTON,. July 11The latest Kennedy Center adventure is a season of chamber opera at the 475seat Terrace Theater. Last night saw the first production of the little company  a double bill of Mozart's The Impresario and Weber's Abu Hassan. The little Mozart work  not so little on this occasion is of course relatively well known, and quite recently the New York City Opera staged it. The Weber is a novelty. Martin Feinstein, executive director of Kennedy Center and the director of Kennedy Center Summer Opera, remembered a performance he had heard in New York before World War II. He liked the opera very much, and now it plays a part in his opening season.

title: U. S Will Help Artists Learn Business Skills
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  A federally financed program of national seminars to teach artists business skills in order to better market their efforts was recently announced by Joan Mondale; wife of the Vice President and honorary head of the Federal Council on the Arts and Humanities.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Harnischfeger Corporation disclosed yesterday that a bidder it described only as a major European industrial company had offered to purchase any and all shares of the Milwaukeebased manufacturer of cranes, shovels and other heavy equipment for $27.50 a share, or about $245 million in cash. It said its directors would meet today to consider the proposal.

title: Home Beat
description: NELINDA FLUECKIGER, right, and Barbara Della Bianca, far right, are the two widely traveled partners of the Unica Trading Corporation, a recently established importing company. A native of Florence, Miss Delia Bianca was a fashion photographer in London, did television work in Australia and spent some time in Asia before coming to New York in 1968. Because my friend Nelinda was a collector of Chinese and Philippine antiques, it seemed to make sense to open this business, she said. Mrs. Flueckiger, who is from Manila, trades with some of the tribes that live in remote parts of the Philippines. She brings back the items that the two partners now sell, mainly to decorators and architects. Their stock includes rustic, provincial, oneofakind furniture pieces, priced from $150 for a chair to $2,000 for a large table inlaid with mother of pearl. There are beaded or smoked antique tribal baskets for $40 to $60, while new baskets are $2.50 to $100 each; less than 150yearold brass jars, vases and gongs, inlaid with silver and copper, are $75 to $400. Unica Trading is at 192 Lexington Avenue, near 32d Street. Telephone 6855890 for an appointment. There is a minimum wholesale order of $100.

title: An Abnormal Summer for Films
description: The first wave of summer movies has now rolled into the country's 18,000 theaters with results that Hollywood executives can only call abnormal. Kneedeep in revenues from the July 4 week  traditionally the second or third biggest week of the year for movies  they are nevertheless groping to make sense of a box office that has no clear omens or portents.

title: Tenants Win Access to Autos In Dispute Over Garage Costs
description: Tenants involved in a dispute over parking fees at the Sovereign, one of New York's most expensive apartment buildings, can once again get their cars out of the building's garage, thanks to a temporary order issued yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DESIGN DELUXE The nation's largest and oldest competition in advertising and graphic design is that of the Art Directors Club. More than 1,000 examples, representing all media, chosen from 12,300 entries, are in the 58th annual display at the Union Carbide Building, 270 Park Avenue, at 47th Street. A daily runoff of top television commercials begins at 12:15 P.M. After July 27, the exhibition will tour the UnitedStates and abroad.

title: The Region
description: The conviction of two Long Island officials and the indictment of a former official on charges that they solicited one percent kickbacks from town employees for the Nassau County Republican Party have been unanimously reinstated by the state's highest court.

title: New Head and 5 Deputies Named to Revive U.S. Family Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)  The Carter Administration, seeking to revive its flagging White House Conference on Families, has named five deputy chairmen and an executive director to the panel, which has been mired in controversy for more than a year over appointments to it.

title: To The Lighthouse: A Home on the Sea
description: As far as Boatswain, Mate First Class William M. Wilkinson, 27 years old, is concerned, you couldn't have asked for a greater contrast, His wife, Michelle, 26, agrees.

title: Inquiry Begins Into Stabbing Death Of Fizure in the Bedford Hills Case
description: Police and Correction Department officials began an investigation yesterday into the fatal stabbing Tuesday of Jeffrey Davis in the Brooklyn House of Detention, where he was being held in maximum security at his own request as a suspect in a May 27 robbery linked to four murders in Bedford Hills.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The New York Stock Exchange appointed two executive vice presidents yesterday as part of a revamping of its executive. staff. They are Donald L. Calvin, who will be responsible for market development and public affairs, and Donald D. Kittell, who will be in charge of operations.

title: Tomorrow Is Last Day To Register for Primary
description: The New York City Board of Elections announces that tomorrow is the last day that voters can file mail registration forms to vote in the Sept. 13 primary elections.

title: Construction Slowdown Seen
description: The pace of contracts for new construction will slow by about 5 percent this year, but rising costs mean the dollar value will still exceed that of 1978, according to a survey by the F.W. Dodge Division of the McGrawHill Corporation.

title: I.T.T. Head Quits Unexpectedly
description: Lyman C. Hamilton Jr., prsident and chief executive officer of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, resigned yesterday, stunning New York's business and financial community.

title: Transfers Of Gasoline Authorized Action Aimed at Striking Dealers
description: In an effort to head off threatened strikes by gasoline station dealers, the Department of Energy announced yesterday that it was authorizing governors in all 50 states to transfer gasoline supplies from stations on strike to stations that remain open.

title: Making New York Safe for Big Steel
description: The American steel industry doesn't like foreign competition. In recent years, it has persuaded Washington to block imports by private companies. Now Big Steel wants Albany to keep foreign competitors from bidding on statesupported public works. The move would violate the spirit of the Constitution, which assigns the regulation of international commerce to the Federal Government, and would complicate international trade negotiations. It would also cost New Yorkers money.

title: Books of The Times
description: BADGE of the Assassin begins with a chilling account of the brutal gunshot slaying of two policemen Patrolmen Waverly Jones and Joseph Piagentini  in the Polo Grounds housing project on May 21,1971.

title: Gillette Sells Unit In Trust Settlement
description: BOSTON, July 11 (Reuters)  The Gillette Company said it had concluded antitrust litigation resulting from its 1967 acquision of a controlling interest in Braun A.G. of West Germany.

title: Carrier Disputes F.A.A.'s Report On Crash Blame
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  American Airlines said today that there was no proof that its maintenance procedures were largely to blame for the crash of one of its DC10 jumbo jets in Chicago on May 25. The comnany cited several technical issues it believed the Federal Aviation Administration should resolve before allowing the nation's grounded fleet of 138 DC10's to fly again.

title: Warning on Food Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)  The Carter Administration has told 17 food wholesalers and retailers to roll back some of their prices before Sept. 30 or risk violating antiinflation guidelines, it was announced today.

title: P. & G. Raises Coffee 10 Cents
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, maker of Folger's coffee, the nation's bestselling brand, raised wholesale coffee prices 10 cents to $3.18 per pound yesterday, attributing the rise to continued increases in the price of coffee beans.

title: Safeway Net Increases 2.9%
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 11 (AP) Safeway Stores Inc., the nation's largest supermarket chain, reported today that its profits rose 2.9 percent in the 12week period ended June 16.

title: Koch Seeks BuildingTax Change
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed decreasing tax benefits to owners who convert commercial buildings to apartments and increasing benefits to owners who upgrade existing apartment buildings.

title: Exxon Extends Offer
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it had extended its tender offer for common shares and series A preferred stock of the Reliance Electric Company until tomorrow at 5 P.M. The company also said it would announce the number of shares already tendered at a later date.

title: The Touches That Can Save Old Veneers
description: VENEERING is the process of applying thin sheets of fine or rare quality woods to a groundwork of plainer wood, This allows many beautiful specimens of wood, too unstable In their solid state, to be used for decoration swirls and burls and intricate figuring. Veneers vary in thickness, according to whether they were the products of handsawing, the method used originally, or were sliced thinly with a knife. They are glued to the base wood under, heat and pressure.

title: Coast Blaze Is Contained
description: LUCERNE VALLEY, Calif., July 11 (AP)  A brush fire that scorched about 6,000 acres and destroyed four homes on the outskirts of this desert community was brought under control this morning, fire officials said. The blaze at the northern edge of the San Bernardino Mountains, 90 miles northeast of Los Angeles, was caused by illegal tracer ammunition whose burning trail of phosphorous ignited the tinderdry brush, according to officials.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: GUGLIELMO MARCONI (Italian Line Cruises International). Left Montego Bay July 8; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: NEW EDUCATION UNIT APPROVED BY HOUSE Bill to Create Cabinet Department Is Sent to Conference Panel.
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 The Carter Administration won a narrow victory today as the House voted, 210 to 206, to create a Cabinetlevel department of education.

title: How Scientists Tumbled Craft To Shift Course
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 - A decision made the night before Skylab's final day delayed the space station's reentry, enabling it to fly harmlessly over southern Canada and Maine but aiming it for its ultimate fall over Australia.

title: Moderate Quake Shakes Alaska
description: PALMER, Alaska, July 11 (AP)  A moderate earthquake in the Pacific Ocean shook southeastern Alaska at 3:28 A.M. today. There were no reports of damage or injuries. The earthquake measured 5.8 on the Rickter scale and was centered 120 miles south of Sitka and 150 miles west of Ketchikan, according to John Sindorf of the Tsunami Warning Center here.

title: Joint Chiefs Support Arms Treaty But Urge Higher Nuclear Spending
description: WAMIINGTON, July 11  The Joint Chiefs of Staff formally endorsed the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union today, but added that it might be a net loss Unless the United States embarked on greater spending to modernize its nuclear arsenal.

title: Concert: Soviet  Emgrs
description: WE hear continually about the famous names such as Rostropovich and Ashkenary, but a remarkable number of other Soviet musicians have also left the Soviet Union in recent years to pursue new lives in the West. Orchestras and chamber groups by the dozens could easily be formed from the ranks of these disaffected artists, and even, it occurred to someone, an entire music festival. And so, on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, we had the first program of the Soviet Emigre Music Festival, a series of six concerts that its backers hope will be an annual midsummer event in New York.

title: Congress Unit Sees Recession
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 The Congressional Budget Office reported today that the American economy was sliding into a mild recession, and the Secretary of the Treasury cautioned Congress against hasty adoption of broadgauge, pumppriming measures that would aggravate inflation.

title: Tennessee Pickets Fined , For Defying Injunction
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 11 (AP)  A Federal district judge today levied fines totaling $14,400 against 67 textile workers who are among some 900 workers picketing a Levi Strauss plant in defiance of an injunction. Earlier, he sent their union leaders to jail.

title: 7 Found Guilty In RaceFixing; Jockey Freed
description: BOSTON, July 11 (AP)  Seven defendants in a, racefixing trial were found guilty on a variety of counts, including sports bribery and conspiracy, by a Federal jury today. Norman Mercier, a jockev. was acquitted.

title: Strickland to Try Nets
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., July 11 (AP) Jim Strickland, the 6-foot-1l-inch center for the University of South Carolina, said last night that he would not return to the Gamecock basketball squad next season. Instead, he said, he will try out for the New Jersey Nets of the National Basketball Association, starting July 24.

title: Sound
description: HISTORIANS of science tell us that technical development is usually paced by the booms and slumps of the general economy. Audio seems the exception. Just as the economy is slowing down in the grip of the oil squeeze, innovation in audio seems to be speeding up. Maybe the industry got all its tweeters whistling in the dark, or maybe it counts on people staying home listening to music when they run out of gas. At any rate, audio is heading into the 1980's with all kinds of new wrinkles.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SKYLAB DEBRIS HITS AUSTRALIAN DESERT; NO HARM REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  The Skylab space station, at 77 tons the largest object ever orbited, flashed through the atmosphere and disintegrated in a blaze of fireworks over the Indian Ocean today, showering tons of debris across the Great Australian Desert one of the world's most remote places.

title: Olympic Airways To Buy Two 737's
description: ATHENS, July 11 (UPI)  Olympic Airways will purchase two Boeing 737's for its international fleet, a spokesman for the Greekflag carrier said.

title: Guards at Rikers Stage a Walkout Over Conditions.
description: More than 600 Rikers Island correction officers, angry about forced overtime and other working conditions, staged a wildcat strike yesterday and returned to work several hours later after an agreement in principle was reached.

title: Skylab, From the Start, Had Its Jinxes
description: In the early 1960's, it was a gleam in the eves of space officials.

title: News Summary
description: Endorsement was given the strategic arms treaty by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, but the group said the treaty with the Soviet Union might be a net loss unless the United States embarked on greater spending to modernize strategic weapons. [A1:23.]

title: Hers
description: MAGINE these people: Max Loewe, a lawyer, father of two; the Guttmanns, newly wed; Eva Broeder, an art student, 21 years old, recently engaged; Moritz Schoenberger, a poster artist; Professor Weiler, an aged man, close to death; Max Schlesinger, a comedian. Loewe had a limp, perhaps the Guttmans were squabbling a bit, but decorously, Eva Broeder might have had some doubts about herself, Schoenberger may have occasionally been envious of colleagues, Weiler was often depressed, maybe Schlesinger sometimes despised the audience he was entertaining.

title: Galletta's 207 Takes New York Open by 2 Shots
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., July 11  Mal Galletta Jr., the head pro at the Glen Cove Golf Club, overcame the fatigue of a sleepless night to win the second annual New York State open with a 54hole total of 207 today.

title: State Employees In Jersey Strike Adding Strength
description: TRENTON, July 11 A wildcat strike by state employees grew in strength today as about 13,000 workers stayed away from their jobs in defiance of a court order and their union leadership.

title: North Sea Gas Conversion Bid
description: LONDON, July 11 (Reuters)  An $1.11 billion plan to convert North Sea liquid natural gas into ethane, propane and butane gases was announced today by three Scottishbased companies.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television  Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio WMCA, 8 P.M.)

title: ExConvict Is Arrested To Spur Investigation In Slaying of Officer
description: A former convict and reputed loan shark who the police say is a central figure in the investigation into the murder of Police Officer Robert Soldo was arrested yesterday as authorities attempted to get the stalled, twomonthold investigation moving..

title: Sale of Interest In C.I. Realty Set
description: The C.I. Planning Corporation, a subsidiary of the City Investing Company, the diversified real estate development concern, plans to sell its 20.96 percent interest in C.I. Realty Investors to a nroup of investors at $29.50 a share.

title: London Symphony to Tour
description: The London Symphony Orchestra will celebrate its 75th anniversary with a tour of the United States in October and November 1980. It will visit San Francisco, Los Angeles, San Antonio, Houston, Chicago, Toronto, Washington, Atlanta, Philadelphia and New York. Claudio Abbado will conduct. The 19day tour will be sponsored by the American Express Company.

title: U.S. Provides $2.5 Million For Project at Hunts Point
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 The Federal Government has awarded a grant for the construction of a mammoth $16 million truck stop in the South Bronx that would provide a 250room motel, restaurants and other facilities for truckers serving the fooddistribution center at Hunts Point.

title: Jersey Casinos' Influence Is Challenged
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 11  Following objections that the yearold casino industry may be gaining excessive power in this resort community, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission intervened today in Resorts International's effort to take over cityregulated motorized trams that drive people up and down the oceanfront Boardwalk.

title: Ammonia Producers Ask Relief on Soviet Imports
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 Fearful of a growing Soviet toehold in the American market, domestic ammonia producers today filed a petition for relief with the International Trade Commission, asserting that the lowerpriced imports have disrupted the industry here.

title: NicaraguaBound Plane Detained
description: TUNIS, Thursday, July 12 (AP)  The Tunisian Government impounded an American cargo plane it said had been. chartered for the Palestine Liberation: Organization, unloaded 50 tons of armts, then released the aircraft early today.

title: Knight Charged With Assault
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 11  Bobby Knight, the head coach of the United States men's basketball team in the Pan American Games, was charged today with aggravated assault for allegedly punching a San Juan police officer durine an incident here last Sunday.

title: Phillips Increasing Spending in U.S.
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla., July 11 (Reuters)  The Phillips Petroleum Company said it had increased its 1979 capital authorization budget for its petroleum operations in the United States by $257 million.

title: Song: Piaf Recalled by Juliette Koka
description: SINGERS who devote themselves to the recreation of the work of celebrated performers  of Al Jolson or Frank Sinatra or Billie Holiday  inevitably work within predestined limitations. No matter how accurately they reproduce the vocal texture, the phrasing or the style of a wellknown singer, the vital creative spark that colored the original performances cannot be copied.

title: Like a Roaring Train on Fire in Night Sky
description: PERTH, Australia, Thursday, July 12  The bulk of Skylab fell over the southwestern tip of Australia today and some large pieces rained upon the ground around the goldmining town of Kalgoorlie, a flat, sparsely settled region.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: LIFELINE, a sonic pool alarm, is an extra safeguard for pool owners who have young children, or who live in neighborhood where there are young children. When a pool is unat tended, the device can be set to give off a piercing noise when an object disturbs the water.

title: Carter Tells Muzorewa That U.S. Will Not Lift Rhodesian Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  President Carter received Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa of Zimbabwe Rhodesia at Camp David today and told him that the United States would not lift sanctions against his country at this time.

title: About South Fallsburg
description: SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., July 9  The guru is down the road and around the bend from a lovely summer Catskill scene: a boys baseball game in a cow patch that is a study in leather mitts and black yarmulkes.

title: Obituary 9 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: No Title
description: ROBERT E. HILL

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Jackson, Nettles and MazzililAllStars
description: Reggie Jackson and Graig Nettles of the Yankees and Lee Mazzilli of the Mets were among the players chosen yesterday as reserves for next Tuesday's baseball AllStar Game, to be played at the Kingdome in Seattle. This will be. Jackson's eighth AllStar Game, Nettles's fourth and Mazzilli's first.

title: U.S. Wheat Expected to Set Mark
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  A nearrecord American wheat crop of 2.1 billion bushels this year and another bumper corn crop were forecast by the Agriculture Department today.

title: Shift in Predictions Psh Skylab's Controllers Into a Final Gamble
description: HOUSTON, July 11  Put everyone on hold, one of the women who had been answering inquiries from the public about Skylab said abruptly just before 6 A.M today. Then she rushed outside to a lawn wet with Texas dew. Perhaps a dozen others were there in the cool summer dawn, scanning the inky sky to the south, a sky scrubbed clean by overnight thunderstorms.

title: Profits Up in 2d Quarter At Morgan and Marine
description: J.P. Morgan & Company, the first major New York City banking institution to release earnings for the AprilJune period, yesterday reported net operating income of $69.83 million for the quarter, up 19 percent from $61.28 million in the yearearlier period.

title: Japanese Auto Exports Up
description: TOKYO, July 11 (UPI)  Japan's automobile exports in June were up 7.2 percent from the year before to $1.6 billion, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Advertising
description: ALTHOUGH the buying of primetime network television ad time for the next season has not achieved the frantic pace of 1976, prices are up by about an average of 15 percent over the current season's levels, according to highly placed ad agency media people.

title: Dodders Astounded
description: Am I shocked at being in last place? asked Steve Garvey. There is a certain numbness. We've had the wagons circled. We're trying to grope for answers. When you are the twotime National League champions, it's embarrassing to find yourself in last nlace_

title: Ballet: Bruhn's Coppelius
description: THE National Ballet of Canada presented its version of Copplia for the first time this season at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night.

title: Over50 Buyers Coming of Age
description: If magazine publishers keep it up, everyone will be convinced that the over50 set constitutes a dynamic market.

title: A Spectacular Sky Show
description: Like a meteor shower rocketing down on the dark side of the world, the flaming debris of Skylab produced a spectacular lightandsound sky show for hundreds of awestruck observers in the cities, towns and sparsely populated deserts of southwestern Australia.

title: 20 Nations Set Tariff Cuts
description: Geneva, July 11  The major industrialized nations that participated in the Geneva trade negotiations concluded a program of tariff reductions today.

title: 3 Free Philharmonia Concerts
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia  will present three free outdoor concerts in the borough: Wednesday, Aug. 1, at the Starrett City Amphitheater; Thursday. Aug. 2, at the War Memorial in Cadman Plaza Park, and Sunday, Aug. 5, at the Seaside Park Band Shell, Surf Avenue and West Fifth Street, Brighton Beach. The programs, which David Amram will conduct, will begin at 7:30 P.M.

title: Paper Maker's Profit Up
description: The International Paper Company earned $1.79 a share in the second quarter, up from $1.46 in the same period year ago as sales rose to. $1.12 billion from $1.018 billion, the company reported yesterday.

title: Temperature Test Clarified
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  Officials at the Department of Energy said today that the test of compliance with the new rules on beating and airconditioning would be the actual temperature in a building, not the thermostat setting.

title: Mutual Fund Tax Repealed
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday that he had signed a bill that, in effect, repealed the state's corporate tax on mutual funds.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Grain and soybean futures advanced yesterday, mostly on buying by local speculators before a major Government crop report.

title: Oil. Acquisition Bill Advances
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  By straight partyline vote, Democrats on the Senate antitrust subcommittee voted approval today, 6 to 4, of a bill that would prohibit the 16 largest crude oil producers in the United States from acquiring any company with assets of $100 million or more.

title: Nicaraguan Rebels Soften Stand on National Guard
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 11 Members of the Nicaraguan rebel junta emerged tonight from an allday meeting with a'special United States envoy and issued a statement that appeared to move them closer to American notions of the proper terms for settling the civil war.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Butterick Fashion Marketing Company, a division of the American Can Company, announced that Paul L. Willson Jr. had resigned as chairman and chief executive officer. Thomas F. Pyle, president and chief operating officer, will assume the additionmal responsibilities of chief executive officer.

title: Cracks Found in Two Pylons on a Pan Am Boeing 747
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  Cracks were found Monday and yesterday on two of four engine mounts, or pylons, of a Pail American World Airways Boeing 747 that was undergoing inspection in New York, an airline spokesman confirmed tonight.

title: Executive of South Bronx Group Calls H.R.A.'s Inquiry a Smear
description: An executive in 10 South Bronx community organizations charged yesterday that an investigation of him by the Human Resources Administration was a smear campaign by a group of officials who he said had blocked millions of dollars in Federal funds from his area because of a personality clash.

title: Mortgage Rates Fail to Stimulate Lending in State
description: ALBANY, July 11  Despite last December's increase in the homemortgage interest rate, New York State's savings banks are investing substantially less money in New York mortgages and more money out of state than they did last year, an Assembly watchdog committee said today.

title: TAXI FARES TO RISE BY 15 TEMPORARILY TO OFFSET GAS COSTS
description: Taxi fares in New York City will go up 15 cents next Wednesday to offset the rising cost of gasoline.

title: Rationing of Gasoline: Any Plan Faces a Fight
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  Emergency gasoline rationing is the talk of Camp David, Capitol Hill and wherever there are gas lines.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The news analysis (June 30) of the recent activities of the Rent Guidelines Board presented an inaccurate assessment of the level of attention and concern Mayor Koch and I have devoted to the board, which now sets rents for more than 850,000 rent stabilized apartments.

title: The Other Fallout: Worry, Unclaimed Rewards, Riddle
description: For a while yesterday morning, the state of Maine seemed a candidate for the unwelcome distinction of being the only part of the United States on which Skylab debris would fall.

title: Girl, 12, Charged in Shooting
description: LOS ANGELES, July 11 (UPI)  The district attorney's office has filed assault charges against h junior high school girl who shot and critically wounded an 8yearold playmate. Angela Marie Schenck, 12 years old, remained in custody yesterday in Juvenile court. The wounded boy, Arthur Jackson Jr., was in critical condition at St. Francis Hospital. If convicted, she could be sentenced to maximum term of nine years in custody of the California Youth Authority.

title: Obituary 8 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: FORD MOTOR OFFERS WARRANTY ON RUST
description: DETROIT, July 11  The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would provide a threeyear, unlimitedmileage warranty against corrosion perforation on. all 1979 and 1980 model cars and light trucks sold in the United States. The plan is effective imfnediately.

title: Dow Falls for 2d Straight Day
description: Stocks continued to sink yesterday into a mire of investor disappointment and pessimism, dissolving optimism generated by a recent fourday rally.

title: GARDENING
description: LONDON

title: The City
description: The Board of Education reported yesterday that 950 of 43,000 seniors in the city's high schools did not graduate this year because they failed to pass competency tests in reading or mathematics.

title: Carter Ends Camp David Talks; Believed Drafting New Address
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  President Carter, continuing to work urgently on his energy program, has canceled all his appointments for the next two days and will remain at Camp David, the White House announced today.

title: Windmill Brings Power To Carolina Mountains
description: BOONE, N.C., July 11 (AP)  The world's largest electricitygenerating windmill was dedicated atop a 4,200foot mountain today in a festive ceremony attended by energy officials, townspeople and hundreds of tourists.

title: Bank Earnings Reported
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: The New York Times/George Tames
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) Senator Herman E. Talmadge, his voice firm and his tone defiant, testified under oath today that he had never knowingly conversed public funds or campaign contributions to his personal use.

title: 99% Tax Cut Due for Miami Vote
description: MIAMI, July 11  A clerical error made in drafting a petition to cut Dade County property taxes has given residents a chance to nearly abolish the levies.

title: Limited Carter Energy Choices
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  The Administration's task force on the reduction of oil imports has completed its work and President Carter, with his chief speechwriter at his side, is studying its findings at Camp David in search of a policy and a speech for the American people.

title: Administrator Holds Tax Claims Exceed Value of Hughes's Estate
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 11 (AP)  A cousin who is administering the estate of Howard R. Hughes says that claims from Texas and California and Federal death taxes exceed the estate's value.

title: Physician, 73, Is Missing In Tiny Everglades Town
description: MOORE HAVEN, Fla., July 11 (AP) A cocker spaniel, a pot of burned stew and an unspecified amount of narcotics are among th clues to the disappearance of the only doctor in this tiny Everglades community, according to the sheriff's office.

title: G.M. Plans Car Delays
description: DETROIT, July 11  The General Motors Corporation said today that it was delaying by nearly two weeks the introduction this fall of its 1980 modelyear cars. The new tentative date is Oct. 11.

title: New Bills Set Rules on Classified Documents in Trials
