description: WASHINGTON, July 11  Carter Administration and Congressional leaders sponsored bills in Congress today that are designed to prevent criminal prosecutions from being dropped or weakened by the threatened disclosure of classified information.

title: VHAIIING UNIT CURBS FACTORY SHIPS USE
description: LONDON, July 11  The International Whaling Commission, over the objections of the Soviet Union and Japan, today banned all whaling by factory ships, except for the small minke whale.

title: McEnroe Is Toppled By Pecci, 36, 75, 76.
description: John McEnroe, still smarting from his loss at Wimbledon and the hostility of the English toward him, struggled for three hours last night before an un- friendly hometown crowd and lost to Victor Pecci. 36, 75, 76.

title: Governor Signs Two Bills Designed To End ChildCare Warehousing
description: Governor Carey yesterday signed two bills that would alter the state's childcare system by creating financial incentives to keep children in their own homes or in foster homes.

title: Tate Fight Set Oct. 20 In Pretoria
description: The fight between undefeated John Tate of Knoxville, Tenn., and undefeated Gerrie Coetzee of South Africa for the heavyweight title Muhammad Ali just vacated will take place in Pretoria, South Africa, on Oct. 20, Bob Arum, chairman of Top Rank Inc., announced yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: A strong French squad appears headed for victory in the European championships now being contested in Lausanne, Switzerland. At stake is the right to represent Europe in the world team championship in Rio de Janeiro next October.

title: MALAYSIA PROPOSES NEW REFUGEE PLAN
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 11  The Malaysian Government is circulating a formal proposal among interested nations that offers the first positive Southeast Asian approach to saving the Iives of refugees from Vietnam while easing the burden of the countries flooded by boat ieople.

title: Peking Gives First Details of Economy in 20 Years
description: The Peking Government, ending 20 years of statistical secrecy, has resumed the publication of Its detailed annual reports on the Chinese economy. Some of the data come close to estimates made in the interim by experts in the West.

title: Stage: Men in White By the Quaigh Theater
description: THE years have not been kind to Men in White. Sidney Kingsley's play, which won the Pulitzer'Prize for drama in 1939, still has its moments, but time, has robbed it of its importance, and a legion of imitations has turned it into a clich. Men in White is only a retrospective clich, of course; the clich was made by the imitations that followed it. The play is the progenitor of every hospital drama you have ever seen.

title: Policeman Slain in Brawl
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (UPI) Patrons of a discothque, angered when the establishment was abruptly closed for the night, spilled into the street today and started a brawl that left an offduty policeman stabbed to death and three other persons shot. The policeman, Artis Norris, 34 years old, was stabbed while trying to break up the melee.

title: Priest Sees No Contradiction in His Terrorist Acts
description: CHICAGO, July 11 (AP)  Stevan Kajevich is a priest and a terrorist. He believes in God, a life hereafter and the sacredness of human life. He also believes in killing other human beings.

title: Bill to Liberalize Trade Clears House, 395 to 7
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The House of Representatives, by a lopsided 395to7 vote, today approved a bill implementing the massive tradeliberalization agreement that the United States signed in Geneva in April after five years of negotiations.

title: Another Way of Powering Vehicles:
description: I have seen the future, and it is operating in Europe. In the future, there are n cars on gasoline lines. For city usage there are electric vehicles that work by biberonnage - French for bottlefeeding -- that is, by charging batteries when the vehicle is not being used. There are hybrids for longer trips.

title: Letter: On Federal Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: DESAI FACING A TEST OF INDIAN COALITION
description: NEW DELHI, July 11  With its majority in Parliament erased by defections, the ruling Janata Party was challenged today by a motion of noconfidence in its leader, Prime Minister Morarli R. Desai.

title: Cold Comfort in the Torsney Case
description: On Thanksgiving Day, 1976, Robert Torsney, white policeman, shot and killed Randy Evans, a 15yerold black, on a Brooklyn street. Nothing that has happened since has brought much comfort to those concerned for the victim of this wanton killing or for those concerned that criminal justice be recognized as just. Ultimately, Mr. Torsney lost his police job, and he was tried for murder. But the Jury found him not guilty by reason of insanity, eliciting cries of racial injustice. And each subsequent twist in this bizarre case has brought more anguish and bitterness. Now, New York's highest court has ordered Mr. Torsney released from a mental hospital. For many this may rekindle the outrage, but no amount of disappointment justifies radically revising the insanity law.

title: G.E. Profit Up 19.6% in Quarter
description: The General Electric Company reported a 19.6 percent secondquarter profit Increase yesterday, continuing the strong momentum of the first quarter.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Pilot Reports a Sighting He Thinks Was Skylab
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  We saw what we believe was the reentry of your Skylab, Capt. Bill Anderson, an Australian pilot, told Federal space officials by telephone today.

title: Debating the Treaty
description: Our present strategic forces also provide, by any standard, a credible deterrent. We have today  and will take whatever measures are required to sustain  survivable forces capable of massive destruction of Soviet cities and industry, even after an allout surprise attack on our forces by the Soviets. We also have the forces...to allow selective use of nuclear force to respond to more limited provocations.  Secretary of Defense Harold Brown.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: New Jacob's Pillow Head
description: Liz Thompson, a dancer, choreographer and educator, has been named the new artistic director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Lee,.Mass., effective Sept. 11. She will succeed Norman Walker, who is resigning after five seasons to pursue his own choreo. eraahic career.

title: Big Broadcast of 44 Returning as a Play
description: The Big Broadcast of 1944 is returning  not to radio, but to the stage. A host of wellknown performers from the 40's will be appearing in a stage recreation of the musical variety shows popular on radio in the 40's.

title: Dr. Richard Singer, 85, Specialist In Cardiology in Manhattan, Dies
description: Dr. Richard Sin er, a cardiologist and internist, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Czech Murderer Hanged
description: PRAGUE, July 11 (AP)  The newspaper Rovnost of Brno said today that Lubomir Anerlik, 32 years old, had been hanged for killing a 67-year-old woman. The newspaper said Mr. Anerlik had killed the woman a few weeks after he had been released from his fifth jail term.

title: Technology
description: DETROIT

title: Business Inventories Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) Business inventories rose 1.2 percent in May, following an even sharper climb of 1.9 percent the month before, creating a buildup termed worrisome by a Commerce Department spokesman today.

title: Gas Markups Rise to 17c In Many Service Stations
description: Many gas stations in the city are marking up prices an average of 17.2 cents a gallon, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Bruce C. Ratner, said yesterday.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Bernstein Plans Revival Of West Side Story
description: TOKYO, July 11  More than two decades after its Broadway premiere, West Side Story is about to be revived, according to the show's composer, Leonard Bernstein. We've talked about it over the years, Mr. Bernstein said in a recent interview while he was on the last leg of a fourweek, 19concert tour of the United States, South Korea and Japan.

title: Market Place
description: THE heady and often lucrative game of risk arbitrage, long the private preserve of Wall Street professionals, is attracting more individual investors these days as the merger market has heated up in recent years. Risk arbitrage, in essence, means betting on mergers. It is based on efforts to determine the probability of one company's offering a premium on the going market price for another company's stock. But the word risk carries an appropriate cutting edge.

title: Key U.S. Strategist on Nicaragua
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  In his handling of the Washington aspects of the Nicaraguan crisis, Viron P. Vaky, Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs, has come across as a cautious career diplomat reluctant, to give the press much information or to permit his subordinates to do so.

title: Mariners Rout John And Yankees, 16 to 1
description: SEATTLE, July 11  Embarrassment dissolved into humiliation tonight as the Seattle Mariners did such terrible things to the Yankees the game should be treated as Xrated material too violent for children to view or read about.

title: Goshen Escapees Cells Not Locked
description: Five men who escaped last Friday morning from the Orange County jail in Goshen, N.Y., were able to gain access to a hole in one cell because the cell locks on their row had been broken for five days, the official in charge of the jail acknowledged yesterday.

title: Voyager 2 Heads Toward Saturn After Relaying Pictures of Jupiter
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 11  After sending home spectacular photographs of a brilliant, luminescent ring around Jupiter that was discovered only four months ago, the Voyager 2 probe made its way even deeper into space today on its way to Saturn.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Music

title: Conferees End Threat of Cutback In Welfare and Medicaid Payments
description: WASHINGTON, July 11  A SenateHouse conference committee removed today the threat of an immediate cut in welfare and Medicaid payments.

title: Cosmos Are Beaten After a Shootout, 21
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 11 - The Seattle Sounders, struggling for a decent showing in the North American Soccer League this season, won a shootout and upset the Cosmos, 21, tonight before 40,207 fans at Giants Stadium.

title: Calendar
description: Getting the Most Out of Your Apart- ment, B. Dalton, 666 Fifth Avenue.

title: Iranian Oil Pipeline Is Cut, Reportedly by Arab Group
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 11  In the second oilfield explosion in a week, a pipeline leading to the Abadan refinery was put oat of action last night by saboteurs, and a new guerrilla group made up of members of Iran's Arab minority said today that it was responsible for both incidents.

title: Sadat and Begin End Talks
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 11  The leaders of Egypt and Israel today completed what President Anwar elSadat called one of the most important talks they had held to date, but there were no signs of significant progress. President Sadat and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel announced at a news conference that their talks would be continued at the end of next month, when the Egyptian leader is to visit the Israeli port city of Haifa.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets. Singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates a specially fast-selling record.

title: Four Charged With Kidnapping Of Carlsbad Caverns Employee
description: CARLSBAD, N.M., July 12 (UPI)  A judge has rejected the promises of negotiators who won the release of a woman hostage at Carlsbad Caverns and insisted that four suspects be charged with felonies rather than misdemeanors.

title: 2 Fractures Found in Pan Am's Jet Not the First in 747's, F.A.A. Says
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that cracks similar to those found Monday in the engine mounts of a Boeing 747 belonging to Pan American World Airways had previously been found in two other, older 797's operated by Japan Air Lines and the Boeing Company. The parts were replaced without incident.

title: Help Ordered for Pupils Talking Black English
description: DETROIT, July 12  A Federal judge here, asserting that bringing blacks into the mainstream of society requires more than integrated housing and busing of students, ruled today that in teaching standard English a public school must recognize the existence of a child's home language if it is different from standard English.

title: Back, but Not Home
description: With all the talk about resuming diplomatic relations with Cuba, and with the increasing number of Cuban exiles returning to visit friends and relatives, I am constantly being asked, Would you ever as hack? In turn I have asked myself, Is there any reason forme to go? I have had to think long and hard before finding my answer. Yes.

title: ABC to Start With 3 Movies in New Venture
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12ABC plans to finance and produce three or four theatrical movies a year with an average budget of $8 million each. Brandon Stoddard, recently appointed president of ABC Motion Pictures, who made the announcement, said he expected the first ABC movie to be in theaters in 18 months.

title: McEnroe Is Winner But Out of Semifinal
description: Even if John McEnroe had stayed at Stanford University for four years, he might have had trouble keeping track of his status at the $300,000 Forest Hills Invitational yesterday.

title: Brooklyn to Get Night Trial Courts In Experiment to Cut Case Backlog
description: What may be the country's first night jury trials for felony cases will be established this September in Brooklyn, Governor Carey announced yesterday.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Carter Administration conceded that a recession is unfolding. In a midyear economic review, the White House forecast that the slump would be mild and brief but would nevertheless raise unemployment by 1.3 million people by the November 1980 Presidential election. The risk of a deeper recession and higher unemployment is greater than the likelihood of a milder downturn, acknowledged Lyle E. Gramley, economic adviser to the President. [Page Al.]

title: Nancy Lopez and Babe Zaharias
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 12  As early as 9 o'clock this morning, cars had to be parked on the leafy streets outside the Brooklawn Country Club, where the United States Women's Open was beginning. People had arrived early because Nancy Lopez was teeing off at 9:36, along with Judy Rankin and Donna Caponi Young, and even some late sleepers were up and walking in the gallery. I'm usually just rolling over now, one was overheard to say, but I was up at 7 to see this girl. Despite gray skies and steamy weather, the

title: Carey Approves A Tax Reduction For 2 Categories
description: SYRACUSE, July 12As businessmen and legislators of both parties beamed at his side, Governor Carey signed into law. today a reduction in the state's maximum personalincome tax and a cut in the sales tax on supplies, parts and tools used in manufacturing.

title: Leading Theologian Sees Collusion of Science and Politics
description: CAMBRIDGE. Mass., July 12  The general secretary of the World Council of Churches, the Rev. Dr. Philip Potter, opened an international conference on science and religion today by accusing scientists of collusion with powerful political and economic forces against the interests of the public, especially the poor.

title: The Region
description: Gov. Ella T. Grasso denied reports that she had called the White House to complain that Deputy Mayor Nicholas R. Carbone of Hartford, who opposed her reelection last year, had been invited to the domestic summit meeting at Camp David this week. Mr. Carbone refused to comment on the report.

title: Nixon Is Found Liable to a Suit In Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)  A Federal appeals court ruled today that former President Richard M. Nixon could be sued for authorizing that reporters and Government officials be wiretapped without a warrant.

title: Galante's Image Belied Role He Played in Life
description: Baldish, bespectacled and with a bent walk, Carmine Galante hardly resembled the popular image of a powerful underworld figure.

title: Galante and 2 Shot to Death in a Brooklyn Restaurant
description: Carmine Galante, the reputed organizedcrime leader, was slain in a barrage of gunfire and shotgun blasts in an apparent underworld execution yesterday afternoon as he dined on the patio of a quiet, sunlit garden in a small Brooklyn restaurant.

title: COMMODES
description: Grain and soybean futures fell sharply yesterday after the Government predicted a largerthanexpected wheat crop this year.

title: At the Movies
description: YAN O'NEAL, the classy middleweight in The Main Event, showed a snapping left in reaching for the saltsticks at the Cafe Pierre and tended to bob and weave his way past tricky questions.

title: Joseph P. Routh Dies; Pittston Co. Chairman
description: Joseph P. Routh, honorary chairman of the Pittston Company, died Wednesday at his New York home. He was 85 years old.

title: Toyota Increasing Exports
description: TOKYO, July 12 (Reuters) Japan's biggest vehicle manufacturer, the Toyota Motor Company, said today that it would increase its exports to the United States. Toyota said the exports this year would be near the 1978 figure of 560,000, compared with an original estimate of 500,000.

title: Beckenbauer to Get Test
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 12  Franz Beckenbauer, the heralded midfielder of the Cosmos who hasn't played since April 22, will undergo a medical examination tomorrow to see if he is ready to start here against Vancouver on Sunday night.

title: Senate Panel Ends Its Hearings; Talmadge Denying Wrongdoing
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)  The Senate Ethics Committee today completed its 13month investigation into allegations of financial misconduct by Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, who insisted to the end that he had done no wrong.

title: Gas Shortage Spurs Carter Decline in Poll
description: Spreading gasoline shortages, persistent unhappiness with the economy and doubts about President Carter's judgment under pressure have continued to erode his public support, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: The Pop Life
description: FOR some months the hottest unsigned band on the underground New York rock circuit has been the B52's. Well, this sweetly charming quintet from Athens, Ga., can no longer claim that title, for the simple reason that it is now a signed band. The debut album, called simply The B52's, has just appeared on the Warner Brothers label, and it's one of the very best debut albums of a year already full of promising debuts (the Roches, Rickie Lee Jones, etc.).

title: Firestone Tire Is Indicted.On IncomeTax Charges
description: CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP)  The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of filing false income tax returns in 1972 and 1973 and conspiring to defraud the Internal Revenue Service.

title: RECESSION STARTING, VIIITE HOUSE SAYS, REVISING FORECASTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The Carter Administration said today that an economic recession was unfolding.

title: Debating the Treaty
description: Since qualitative improvements are virtually unrestricted by the treaty, the numerical limitations imposed upon the Soviet Union will not give us any meaningful degree of predictability. That is, the qualitative improvements allowed, because they are more difficult to verify, could afford us less predictability and hence less stability. The ceilings are set at such high levels  again at Soviet insistence  as to be virtually meaningless.  Lieut. Gen. Edward L. Rowny, former military rep resentative to the treaty negotiations.

title: Stevenson Stops Hadley in 1:21; juantorena Loses 400 to Darden
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 12  Bubba Hadley never had a chance  not even a bedsheet waved by a group of women athletes could save him against Tebfilo Stevenson of Cuba tonight.

title: Junk Food Plan Widely Criticized
description: Although many consider it simple common sense to have the sale of socalled junk foods prohibited in school lunch rooms and cafeterias, every attempt to impose such a ban sparks heated controversy. Last week's proposal by the Department of Agriculture that sales of such foods be prohibited until after each day's last lunch period gave rise to protests from nutritionists, consumer advocates, ParentTeacher Association groups and many school food service administrators across the country who felt the proposal was far less sweeping than it should have been.

title: Business Loan DemandStill Strong in New York
description: Commercial and industrial concerns continued to borrow heavily from New York's major banks in the week ended July 11, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Nederlander Rejoins Theater League
description: The Nederlander Organization, one of the nation's largest owners of legitimate theaters, has rejoined the League of New York Theaters and Producers.

title: Art: SelfPortraits  At L.I. s Heckscher
description: SELFPORTRAITURE, like autobiography, is a scary business. Midway between the confessional and a form of ritualized boasting, it is what happens when one human being gets up in front of every other human being and says This is who I am. Like it or leave it.

title: World News Briefs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12 China and Vietnam will participate in the United Nationssponsored meeting in Geneva next week on the Indochinese refugee situation, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP)  About 19.3 million shares of Reliance Electric Company stock have been tendered to a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, it was announced today.

title: Bonn Lifts Key Rates Of Interest
description: BONN, July 12  The West German central bank lifted its key interest rates today to their highest levels since May 1975, rejecting warnings that such an antiinflation move could aggravate a worldwide economic slowdown caused by rising oil prices.

title: Commissioner Agrees on Hardship At Rikers but Disagrees on Strike
description: New York City's Correction Commissioner agreed yesterday with correction officers about onerous conditions at Rikers Island, but disagreed with their tactic of the day before  a wildcat strike that lasted 15 hours.

title: JIM LUKEN
description: CINCINNATI, July 12 (AP)  Jim Luken, a former Mayor of Cincinnati, former State Representative and labor leader, died today. He was 57. He rose to national prominence as president of Milk and Ice Cream Drivers and Dairy Workers Local 98. successfully preventing a takeover by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in the 1950's. Both Mr. Luken and his brother Tom served as Mayor of this southern Ohio city. Tom Luken is now a Congressman from Ohio's 2nd District.

title: The Future of Revenue Sharing: Regional Views Play a Key Role
description: The divergences of views on general revenue sharing on Capitol Hill may not be so wide as the distance between Texas and New Jersey, but differing regional perceptions surely color the views of two legislators who will play major roles in

title: Spanish Fort Site Is Believed Found at Parris Island
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The site of the longlost 16thcentury colony of Santa Elena, once the capital of Spanish Florida, has apparently been found by archeologists digging in the rough at the edge of a golf course on the Parris Island Marine base in South Carolina.

title: Mackintosh Desk Brings a Record Price: $177,456
description: Charles Rennie Mackintosh's imposing desk sold in London Wednesday for $177,456, becoming the highestpriced piece of 20thcentury furniture ever sold at public sale. In fact, the writing cabinet that the Scottish, turnofthecentury architect had made for his own use in 1904 Is the second most expensive piece of British furniture sold at auction. A desk by Thomas Chippendale went for more$195,000 in London last year.

title: Bus Rules Eased by U.S. Pane
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The Interstate Commerce Commission, in an unusual move to provide more seats to intercity bus riders and thus save fuel, granted temporary permission to all interstate bus companies today to serve additional communities without specific Government permission.

title: Turner Reportedly Asks Inquiry Into Disclosure of Data to Times
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The Federal Bureau of Investigation, at the request of Adm. Stansfield Turner, the Director of Central Intelligence, has taken the first steps to determine whether an investigation should be made into the disclosure of alleged national security information to The New York Times, accordng to senior Administration officials.

title: Critic's Notebook: Mozart in the Summertime
description: WHAT is this mania for Mozart in the summertime? Not only is the Mostly Mozart Festival heading into its 13th season next Monday evening with every indication that the pattern of packed houses and enraptured listeners will continue, but also from beyond Manhattan come reports of tendency to link Mozart's music with hot weather. That is partly, one suspects, because Mozart has become brand name, like KoolAid, and is being used as a marketable, shorthand synonym for summer music.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Oil Accident to Cut Nigeria's Exports
description: Oil exports from Nigeria will temporarily drop by up to 600,000 barrels a day because of an accident at one of that nation's major storage terminals, oil industry sources said in New York yesterday.

title: Nicaraguan Rebels Say That Talks With U.S. Envoy Are in Final Stage
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 12  A spokesman for the Nicaraguan revolutionary junta said today that talks between the rebels and a United States envoy, William G. Bowdler, had reached the final stages toward achieving a settlement of the civil war that Washington feels it can support.

title: Builder  Says DC10 Pylon Crack Must Be a Maintenance Problem
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, builder of the DC10 jumbo jet, told a Senate hearing today that the enginemount crack that led to the recent crash of an American Airlines DC10 could have occurred only in manintenance, not in flight.

title: State to Release More Gas Stocks From Its Reserve
description: With the fuel situation apparently continuing to improve, James L. Larocca, the State Energy Commissioner, said yesterday that additional reserve supplies were being made available in the metropolitan area in an effort to further allay fears of a shortaee.

title: Screen: 'The Wanderers,' a Bronx Gangs Story
description: "THE Wanderers" is a hit-or-miss movie full of rambunctious triumphs, terrible gaffes, likable new players and even more vitality than it needs. Based on Richard Price's dazzling first novel, which it loots rather than adapts, the movie never attempts to tell a single story; instead, it settles for a string of boisterous vignettes, which are heaped carelessly atop one another without any consistent scheme. The movie's unflaggingly high energy level and the neon hues of Michael Chapman's cinematography are the only things that really hold it together."The Wanderers," which opens today at Loews State I and other theaters, isn't a gang movie, although it has all the earmarks of one. The Wanderers are sweet, harmless high school kids united by their matching satin jackets, their spirit of fraternity and their very understandable fear of some of the bat-wielding loonies in their Bronx neighborhood. The movie introduces all this in a magical opening sequence, with an overhead shot of the gleaming skulls of the Fordham Baldies, who are hanging around outside Alexander's until a Wanderer has the bad luck to annoy them. The very funny musical accompaniment for this, the beginning of a terrific set of early-60's East Coast rock songs, is the Four Seasons' "Walk Like a Man."The beauty of Mr. Price's novel was its economy and thoroughness in locating the Wanderers' exact place in the world. Without venturing outside a very circumscribed environment, Mr. Price was able to suggest what these characters would aspire to once their adolescences ended, what alternatives they believed life could offer and what sorts of possibilities they were not even able to imagine. The movie, on the other hand, has a lot of trouble figuring out where the Wanderers stand.So Mr. Kaufman and Rose Kaufman, who together wrote the screenplay, introduce a few extra characters and situations to suggest what the climate is like beyond a 10-block radius of the intersection of the Grand Concourse and Fordham Road. Most prominent of these is a friendly beatnik love interest, a girl first seen carrying her guitar and a copy of "Lady Chatterley's Lover." The year is 1963. There is also an amazingly tasteless reference to the John F. Kennedy assassination, with a rock song played over footage of the killing, plus some uneasy attempts to demonstrate that race relations in the neighborhood are implausibly strained and friendly at the same time. These are the least successful parts of a movie that should have stayed closer to home.Home is, in this case, the growing pains of the various principals. The four chief Wanderers  the easygoing leader Richie (Ken Wahl), the group pipsqueak Joey (John Friedrich), the kindly giant Perry (Tony Ganios) and rakish Buddy (Jim Youngs, younger brother of John Savage)  are glimpsed at parties, in school, at a crazy, pointless football game, with their families and with their girlfriends. In the film's best episode, Richie and Joey get involved in a strip poker game with the nice girl they hardly know (Karen Allen) and Despie (Toni Kalem), the nagging girlfriend Richie will wind up marrying, though he is already tired of her at 17. This scene is as affecting, as sweetly played, and as delicately comic as anything the movie has to offer.Although much of "The Wanderers" has a spirit all its own, just as much of it derives from other works as various as "Mean Streets," "West Side Story" and Mr. Kaufman's own version of "Invasion of the Body Snatchers," released last year. This last is perhaps the most out of place, as Mr. Kaufman occasionally lets the principals stray into foreign territory so he can summon up clouds of blue smoke, shadowy figures and scary electronic music.To the extent that this is meant to demonstrate how eerie and frightening the outside world seems to the characters, it's heavy-handed. To the extent that it's heavy-handed, it's peanuts compared to Mr. Kaufman's use of religious statuary. Or, for that matter, to a silly business at the end of the movie that shows Richie watching Nina go into a tiny cafe where Bob Dylan just happens to be on the stage singing "The Times They Are A-Changin'." Mr. Kaufman might better have thrown in an extra number by the Shirelles or Dion and left it at that.

title: Screen: Lost and Found on Campus
description: THE kind of chemistry that exists between George Segal and Glenda Jackson in Lost and Found, which opens today at Loews State and other theaters, is nanny unfamiliar. Here, as in A' Touch of Class, Mr. Segal plays an affable, easygoing guy in love with a woman (Miss Jackson) who's' as personable as a prune. She, however, is smarter and more sensible than he will ever be, and she has the last acerbic word in every argument, which is something he seems to enjoy. Together, they have spats with a serious subtext and generally keep each other sane.

title: Bluegrass Festival All Weekend in Jersey
description: The sound of bluegrass music will fill the slopes of Vernon Valley Great Gorge, Route 94, Vernon, N. J., this weekend, when the second annual Country Pickin Bluegrass Festival nets going.

title: Five Miners Saved in CaveIn
description: CLARKSVILLE, Pa., July 12 (AP) Five miners were pulled to safety yesterday after a cavein trapped them 460 feet underground for nearly five hours, a company spokesman said. They were greeted by their families as they emerged .from the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation's Gateway Mine near this southwestern Pennsylvania community.

title: City Revises Its Contingency Plan in Power Failures
description: New York City officials announced revised emergency powerfailure response plan yesterday, two days before the second anniversary of the 1977 blackout that left parts of the city and Westchester County without power for up to 24 hours or more.

title: Space Engineers to Visit Australia To Pinpoint Path of Skylab Debris
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The space agency will send engineers to Australia in a day or two to identify the remains of Skylab and attempt to pinpoint the track of the debris from the space station that fell across the continent.

title: Jersey and Long Island Offer Plentiful Bluefish
description: AREA A  The bluefishing on the Barnegat Ridge inlet has been so good that the boats have been returning with their fill by 1:30 and 2 P.M., according to Capt. Gus Brindley of the Lighthouse Marina. He also reports that the fluke are gond along the inlet and in the hays hut slow along the beach. Ralph Stark, out of Captain Andy's Marina in Margate, N.J., reports good bluefish, some weighing 12 to 14 pounds.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Report Set On Bank Club Costs
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Nearly twothirds of the commercial banks and savings and loan associations that pay club dues for their executives do so whether or not the clubs discriminate on the basis of race, national origin, religion or sex, according to a survey conducted by Federal bank reeulators.

title: Mets Score 8 in First, Win, 125
description: You could tell last night belonged to the Mets from the very first pitch at Shea Stadium. Dock Ellis, their starting righthander, delivered it, and Von Joshua of the Los Angeles Dodgers belted it to deep center field. Lee Mazzilli stood there as the ball sailed over his head. Then suddenly, he raced back to the wall and made a onehanded catch with his back to the plate.

title: Man Sentenced for Kickbacks
description: BALTIMORE, July 12 (UPI)  The president of a janitorial supply company today received a oneyear suspended jail sentence and was fined $1,500 for his part in the General Services Administration kickback scandal. He is William T. Chester, 34 years old, of the Hue Chemical Company. He must serve 15 days of the sentence in jail.

title: Dow Declines by 7 Points to 836.86As Market Awaits Carter's Address
description: Stocks continued to retreat yesterday as investors awaited President Carter's address on energy, now scheduled for Sunday night. The Dow Jones industrial average fell for the third day in a row, this time by an even 7 points to 836.86 as declines exceeded advances bv2to1.

title: N.C.A.A. Discipline Reviewed
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Officials of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, whose disciplinary practices have been the subject of a year and a halflong inquiry by the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, testified today that they had implemented six of 18 recommendations made by the subcommittee in January and were reviewing or partially endorsing five others.

title: Swede Soling Victor
description: VISBY, Sweden, July 12 (UPI) Joergen Sunderlin of Sweden sailed his Soling Class boat to victory in the fourth race today, but Vincent Brun of the United States retained his overall lead in the world Soling championships. Sunderlin, Olympic 5.5Meter champion in Acapulco, Mexico, in 1968, led from start to finish.

title: Art People
description: IT may not evoke a baseball stadium for you, but there, set on the mistymauve carpeting in the lobby of the World Trade Center (Tower II) is a rambling environmental structure called Ebbets Field. Its creator, a young architectsculptor named Jeffrey Owen Brosk, dubbed it that to commemorate the place where, as a child, he went to see the Brooklyn Dodgers play.

title: 3 Mere Members Leave Janata Party Coalition
description: NEW DELHI, July 12  Three more members of the ruling Janata Party coalition defected to the opposition today as a motion of nocoandence in Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai was debated in Parliament for the second day.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Air Express International, a Stamford, Conn.based airfreight forwarding company, has appointed James M. Cherry vice presidentnational accounts.

title: Fashions of the 1980's: An Accent on Versatility
description: The sketching, draping and stitching go on in the design rooms on Seventh Avenue. Fall collections are already on their way to the stores. The season for which clothes are now being assembled is called resort.

title: Gilbert Islands, Scene Of Bitter Battle in 43, Becomes Independent
description: TARAWA, Kiribati, July 12 (AP) The Gilbert Islands, beautiful coral atolls where the United States Marines fought one of the bloodiest Pacific battles of World War II, became the independent republic of Kiribati today after 87 years of British rule.

title: 71 Persons Are Killed and 47 Hurt As Blaze Sweeps a Spanish Hotel
description: SARAGOSSA, Spain, July 12 (AP) At least 71 people were killed and 47 injured in a luxury hotel here today when a pas try machine exploded and started a fire that swept through the building.

title: Yankees Trounce Mariners
description: SEATTLE, July 12  Perhaps it will not be necessary, after all, for George Steinbrenner, the shipbuilder, to take drastic action to solve the Yankees Seattle problem, such as buying the Kingdome, putting it on pontoons and floating it out into Puget Sound.

title: Justice on Coast Won't Answer Lawyer's Questions
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 12  Justice William Clark of the California Supreme Court told the Commission on Judicial Performance today that he would be unable to answer questions on crossexamination if they were nut to him by Harry Delizonna, one of Chief Justice Rose Bird's lawyers, but would answer readily those put by her other lawyer, Jerome B. Falk Jr.

title: Hermitage Sending Art on U. S. Tour
description: A show from the Hermitage Museum in Leningrad of more than 900 objects, spanning 40,000 years, will embark on a fivecity tour of the United States, beginning at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. next spring.

title: Kathryn O'Day Granahan Dies; A Former Head of U.S. Treasury
description: Kathryn O'Hay Granahan, a former United States Treasurer who was the first woman to be elected to Congress from Philadelphia, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Norristown, Pa., after an illness of many years. She was 83 years old.

title: WEEKENDER CUIRE
description: Alicia Alonso, the Havanaborn ballerina who danced in this country for many years with American Ballet Theater, has just returned to New York with her own company, the Ballet Nacional de Cuba. The troupe has been touring the United States the last two months and has just moved into the Metropolitan Opera House for a threeweek stay. Tonight's program at 8 P. M. is Miss Alonso's new production of Swan Lake. Tomorrow at 2 and 8 P. M. the company will dance a new fulllength work, Night of the Guitar  danced entirely to guitar music with Miss Alonso herself appearing at both performances. Tickets range from $6 to $30, available at the box office or by calling 5809830 for charge reservations.

title: On Seizing OPEC, Guns Blazing
description: There might be reason, someday, for the United States to seize a foreign oilfield. If an oil producer were invaded, for instance, maybe then. But the recent talk about charging, guns blazing, into one or another OPEC country to keep the oil flowing is nonsense. This kind of talk may be understandable, no matter how misguided, from an angry driver waiting three hours for the privilege of paying $1.30 a gallon for OPEC petroleum he has been told costs a quarter to produce. But among supposedly thoughtful people, it is dangerously cynical and inflammatory. It is time to forget about a violent and quick fix for our oil problem and get on with the job of putting our energy world in order.

title: Bank Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Judge Orders $25,000 Daily Fine on Striking Jersey Union
description: TRENTON, July 12  Judge Morton I. Greenberg of Superior Court tonight ordered the State Employees Association to pay $25,000 a day in fines to the state unless union officials made an effort to persuade the members to end their strike against the state government by Saturday.

title: Too Many Negotiators
description: MOSCOW  I have been studying American foreign policy for nearly 30 years now and I know the American system of division of powers, but despite all this, some aspects of American policy defy logical explanation.

title: Bank Loans to Charter
description: The Charter Company of Jacksonville, Fla., has obtained a $300 million letter of credit from a group of major United States and foreign banks to finance crude oil suppliped to a Bahamian refinery. The refinery, which has been in receivership for sometime, was 65 percent owned by the Carey Energy Corporation. Charter acquired Carey in May and has been trying to regain control of the refinery.

title: Daily News to Raise Price by 5
description: The Daily News will increase the newsstand price of its daily issues from 20 cents to 25 cents starting next week, the newspaper announced yesterday. The price of Sunday's News will remain at 50 cents. The paper cited soaring costs of every kind, including increased newsprint and labor costs and the toll taken by last year's 88day strike.

title: Auctions
description: THE Impressionist, modern and contemporary art fields rebounded dramatically this last auction season in what became the best 10month, Septemberthrough June period in art sales in New York in five years. Not since the 197374 season have these areas of the art market registered such high prices at auction and sparked such outright optimism among collectors and dealers. And the dozens of new highs for artists and other records established were strong evidence of surging interest, even when taking inflation into account.

title: Militant Hindus Worry Ruling lnclian Party
description: NEW DELHI, July 12  The squat and paunchy squadron leader shouted commands in Sanskrit to the ranks of men and boys marching imprecisely beneath the saffron banner of their organization, a symbol of HIndu militancy and orthodoxy that hung limply in the thickening air of a Delhi summer evening.

title: Anwar and Menachem Throw Away Protocol
description: JERUSALEM, July 12  It was Anwar and Menachem at the EgyptianIsraeli talks in Alexandria this week, but not without some hesitation on the part of the protocolconscious Israeli leader.

title: SHIFTS IN U.S. RULES ON CAS ALLOCATIONS COULD BAR STATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The Carter Administration said today that it was planning to impose new gasoline allocation regulations that, according to experts, would make it virtually impossible to open new gasoline stations.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: Tommy John of Yanks during Mariners ninerun first inning in Wednesday's game at Seattle. John was knocked out in first as Mariners defeated New York, 161.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar was mixed in foreign exchange trading at home and abroad yesterday amid speculation about President Carter's announcement of new energy measures, now scheduled for Sunday night.

title: New Face: Powers Boothe Stage Cowboy Knows the Territory
description: HE wears a brass State of Texas belt buckle, scuffed cowboy boots and a Stetson  both onstage and off. And on the surface, his life seems to have begun much like that of the character he plays: anniung, chasing women, playing football, hellraising, howling at the moon.

title: Bridge:
description: The title of most talented teenager in the New York metropolitan area belonged for several years to Brian Glubok of White Plains. He is still qualified chronologically, but he is concentrating on studying rather than on playing nudge nowadays ana tus mantle has descended on 18yearold Alex Pollenz of Wantagh, L.I.

title: Newsweek Set to Vault Ahead
description: It has installed a new editor and a new publisher. It has whipped up two new management slots. At the end of the year, it will bid farewell to its chairman.

title: Profits Up 23.5% At McGrawHill
description: McGrawHill Inc., the publishing and information services company, yesterday reported a 23.5 percent increase in profits and 14 percent gain in revenues during the second quarter.

title: Begin, Home From Egypt, Hails Sadat Talks as the Start of Friendship
description: JERUSALEM, July 12  Prime Minister Menachem Begin returned today from two days of talks in Egypt with President Anwar elSadat and said the discussions had improved Israeli-Egyptian relations even though the two leaders continued to differ on maior issues. we nave started to move from the peace phase to the stage of mutual friendship and understanding and cooperation, the Prime Minister said.

title: TV Weekend
description: SUNDAY'S rerun at 8 P.M. on WNBC of Summer of My German Soldier comes on the heels of this madefortelevision movie winning a 1979 Humanitas Award. Set in a small Georgia town during world War II, the story involves a Jewish girl in her early teens, who protects and then falls in love with a young German prisoner of war. Re has escaped from a nearby detention camp.

title: Dr. Rowland A. Egger, 71, Dies; Was Educator and Former Envoy
description: Dr. Rowland Andrews Egger, a professor of politics and public affairs at Princeton University since 1964, died Monday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 71 years old.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, JULY 12, 1979

title: Oil Slick Off Newfoundland
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 12 (AP)  An oil slick of undetermined size and believed to be from the tanker Kurdistan has been found along the south coast of Newfoundland. The ship broke up March 15 off Cape Breton, dumping 6,900 tons of oil at the entrance to Cabot Strait and fouling Nova Scotia beaches.

title: AntiDisco Rally Halts White Sox
description: CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) More than 7,000 fans ran wild in Comiskey Park tonight during an antidisco night promotion and caused postponement of the second game of a scheduled twilightnight doubleheader between the Detroit Tigers and Chicago White Sox.

title: Nationwide Strike Is Threatened Against Westinghouse Electric
description: PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP)  The International Union of Electrical Workers threatened today to strike the Westinghouse Electric Corporation nationwide at midnight Sunday.

title: Qaddafi Gives Syria Pledge on Jets
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 12  The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, said in Damascus today that his counSyria might lose in battles with Israel.

title: Wurf Says Labor Should Seek Alternative to Carter
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Jerry Wurf, the leader of the first major union to endorse Jimmy Carter in 1976 and a visitor at Camp David yesterday, said today that the President had not kept his campaign promises and that organized labor should look at alternative candidates for 1980.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: J.A. Carter calls himself a very small person in the corporate world. But Mr. Carter, president of the Carter Oil and Gas Company of Canada, may not be very small much longer. He is spending about half a billion dollars for the working interest in Canadian oil and gas properties belonging to the Hamilton Brothers Petroleum Corporation of Denver.

title: For Children
description: SNOW WHITE AND THE SEVEN DWARFS, Friday at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M., and Childhood, by the Muna Tseng Dance Theater with Renaissance music, four adult performers and one child actor, Friday at 7:30 P.M. at the annual Queens Council on the Arts Summer Diversions Program. A performance by the American Children's Theater on Thursday at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. will be among those given during the week. All performances are at the Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing MeadowsCorona Park, Queens. Free; donations accepted. Information: 2911100.

title: Money to Prevent Cut In Food Stamps Level Is Approved by House
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Enough extra money to continue food stamp allotments at their current rates has been authorized by the House. The Senate is expected to take the same action next week.

title: G.P.U. to Continue Reduced Dividend
description: PARSIPPANY, N.J., July 12 (AP)  The General Public Utilities Corporation announced today that it would continue its reduced dividend in the third quarter in the wake of the accident that crippled the utility's nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania.

title: Adequate Oil Supply Seen
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger predicted today that heating oil stocks would be rebuilt to adequate levels by next winter without a recurrence of gasoline lines. Commenting on the week's oil statistics, Mr. Schlesinger said that if crude supplies continue to be available at current levels, we should be able to avoid a recurrence of gasoline lines while concurrently rebuilding distillate stocks for next winter.

title: Ballet: Dutch Troupe Offers 3 Jiri Kylian Premieres
description: THERE is no doubt that Jiri Kylian, the Czechoslovakborn artistic director of the Netherlands Dance Theater, is at- tracting more excitement and discussion than any new choreographer has in New York in a decade. He has daring, he has imagination and he is very sure of himself. He impels viewers to rush out during intermission to buy more tickets.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: MANHATTAN

title: Liner Marconi Enioined as Unsanitary
description: The Italian cruise ship Marconi, carrying 525 passengers to the Caribbean, set sail yesterday afternoon from New York, hours after the state announced a temporary court order requiring the line to tell future customers that the ship has been failing its sanitation inspections.

title: Three Men Found Guilty On More Racing Charges
description: BOSTON, July 12 (AP)  A United States District Court jury found three convicted racketeers guilty of 40 additional counts today in a $1 million horse racefixing scheme of bribes and threats.

title: U.S. Oil Consumption Off
description: PARIS, July 12  The United States cut its oil consumption 5.2 percent, or roughly one million barrels a day, below previously expected levels between April and June, the International Enerev Aeencv reported today.

title: $397 Million in Bonds Are Missing
description: A total of $397 million in Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds owned by a New York City pension fund have disappeared from a United States Trust Company vault, city officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Celebrating. a Renaissance Wedding
description: Would you like to celebrate a 440. yearold wedding? Then take a trip to Bronxville today or tomorrow, where A Renaissance Entertainment will be under way for several hours each day as part ot a series called Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence.

title: Carter Panel on Coal Urges Its Use by Utilities and in Making New Fuels
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  A Presidential commission assigned to draft plans for greater use of coal, the nation's most abundant onshore fossil fuel reserve, sent the White House a report today urging an immediate start on a $159 billion investment in coalburning power plants and coalconversion facilities that the panel said could halve oil imports by 1990.

title: South Korea Trade Deficit
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 12 (AP) South Korea's trade deficit almost quadrupled in the first half of this year to $2.93 billion from the yearearlier level of $770 million, the commerce and industry ministry reported today.

title: Soviet Astronauts Nearing Record For Longest Manned Space Flight
description: MOSCOW, July 12  When the Skylab space station came plunging back to earth yesterday, two Soviet astronauts were in their 135th day aboard their own 19ton space station, recently boosted to an orbit high above the drag of the earth's atmosphere.

title: Aides Say U.S. Seeks Faster Upgrading of Its Arsenal
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The United States, in a shift in strategic planning, is making preparations that would make possible a more rapid upgrading of the existing arsenal of longrange missiles and bombers, according to Defense Department officials. until recently, the United States has emphasized new arms programs, such as the MX mobile missile, to bolster strategic capabilities in the late 1980's. However, the officials said, growing concern over the nuclear balance in the next few years is leading the Pentagon, for the first time, to examine quicker remedies.

title: Publishing: The Battle of the Book Awards
description: ALTHOUGH they are scarcely a week old, the American Book Awards, created by the Association of American Publishers to supplant the 30yearold National Book Awards, have already provoked controversy.

title: Restaurants
description: IN the last year or so, we have seen the advent of a number of small restaurants with limited menus that have about them a friendly, informal and personal aspectmuch as though one is dining in a private (or at least a semiprivate) home. Althoueh this phenomenon is cnnsirlereri to be a recent trend, it actually began about 16 years ago, when the Brazilianborn Dona Helma Dellortc opened Casa Brasil on the garden floor of her East Side brownstone house. Floral tablecloths and centerpieces, walls covered with photographs of celebrities who are her fans, and a mixmatch assortment of souvenirs and bricabrac give this place a cheerful and informal charm, and though the service is not crisply professional, it is goodnatured and efficient.

title: Topics Intelligence
description: Finally

title: Film: 'Dance of Death'
description: THIS 1968 film of August Strindberg's "The Dance of Death," which would look forthrightly like a stage production were it not for the occasional shots of seagulls between scenes, should be more noteworthy to admirers of Laurence Olivier than to those of the playwright. As directed by David Giles, the version of the play is shrill and even more claustrophobic than is necessary, populated by characters whose nastiness is asserted and reasserted when it most needs to be expanded upon. Lord Olivier's Edgar is a flexible figure relative to the others. But even he fails to develop in a manner that might help focus the play.Lord Olivier's performance in the film, which opens at the D.W. Griffith today, never fails to be entertaining, nor is it lacking in charm. But it is, if anything, too charming, especially since Geraldine McEwan plays Alice, the wife with whom Edgar has been locked in battle for 25 years, as such an unrelieved shrew. Miss McEwan is giving a stage performance in front of a movie camera, which greatly magnifies its flaws, and she winds up seeming not just a poor foil but a disproportionate one.The play revolves around the interchangeable love and cruelty of these two married characters, yet Miss McEwan and Lord Olivier are very much out of step with each other. The intensity of their viciousness demands that they function as a team.Edgar's monstrousness, which propels the play as it overwhelms the last remnants of his kinder instincts, never manages to become a dominant aspect of Lord Olivier's performance. From the other characters, though, monstrousness is by no means in short supply.Janina Faye desperately overworks the coquettishness of Judith, the couple's daughter; Robert Lang turns Kurt, the man Edgar destroys, into someone whose destruction is entirely too long in coming. Miss McEwan's sniping is so repetitive that the play's final revelation  that a hatred this intense must also be love  becomes the only one it is allowed to offer.

title: Moscow Policemen Seize a Man Trying to Enter Embassy of U.S.
description: MOSCOW, July 12 (AP)  Policemen seized a man here today when he attempted to enter the American Embassy.

title: Toll in Shanghai-Area Earthquake Rises to 41 Dead and 2,000 Hurt
description: PEKING, July 12 (AP)  The toll in the Chinese earthquake rose to 41 dead and more than 2,000 injured in 20 commimes, and minor shocks were still being felt in the area, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: Pop Music: Dan Hicks Returns
description: In the early 70's, Dan Hicks and his Hot Licks managed to carve out a small but endearing niche for themselves in the world of popular music. Blending folk and a comfortable yet witty approximation of swing, they offered original songs that echoed the quirky novelty tunes and droll sophistication of the 30's  a ruralurban fusion that predated such contemporary performers as Ry Cooder and even Manhattan Transfer.

title: IN THE NATION
description: President Carter is in deep political trouble not least because, as the nadon's mostwatched and most visible political leader, the public judges him mostly on what it perceives as his failures. The obvious beneficiary is Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who suffers no such pitiless scrutiny; but the nearer Mr. Kennedy comes to running officially for President, the more he is going to have to worry about his own vulnerabilities.

title: Environmentalists Warn Carter on Synthetic Fuels
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 A group of leading environmental organizations, believing President Carter has opted for a massive development of synthetic fuels, warned him in a letter today that he was on the brink of a disastrous and irreparable mistake in his choice of energy policies. me group said that, by heeding political advice to call for the production of two million barrels a day of these fuels by 1990, the President was In danger of being stampeded by the same panic and ignorance which have driven Congress to impetuous folly.

title: A Walking Tour of the Past and Present on Broady
description: Whether it is thought of as the Great White Way or Sin City's major thoroughfare, Broadway and its densely concentrated theater district remains one of New York City's major attractions, to New Yorkers and tourists alike. Beneath its fitful glitter, the theater district has managed to retain its legends and still reflects the city's history. But really to savor it, one must know where to look. On Sunday, the Museum of the City of New York will point the way with a twohour tour called Theater in New York: Give Your Regards to Broadway, which begins at 2:30 P.M. at the Bryant Park corner of the Avenue of the Americas and 42d Street.

title: Mexican GasSale Talks Resume
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) Negotiations over the sale of Mexican natural gas to the United States have resumed in Mexico, James R. Schlesinger, the Energy Secretary, told the Senate Finance Committee.

title: City Marshal Is Given Suspension
description: A New York City marshal was suspended for six months yesterday for allegedly drawing a gun and threatening the life of a Queens businessman from whom he was trying to collect a judgment. The city's Commissioner of Investigation has also requested the marshal's dismissal from office.

title: Assault Charges Are Filed Against 3 Cosmos Players
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 12 (AP)  A Giants Stadium maintenance worker has filed a complaint against three members of the Cosmos soccer team, including Giorgio Chinaglia, charging them with assault and battery in a brawl at the stadium last week.

title: HEALTH COST FIGHT SUFFERS A SETBACK
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The Administration's proposal to contain rising hospital costs, a keystone of President Carter's antiinflation effort, suffered a serious setback in the Senate today and now faces an uncertain future in Congress.

title: Guide to FleaMarket Country
description: NEITHER rain nor heat nor gas shortage will keep most faithful fleamarket dealers and antiques merchants from their appointed stalls this weekend.

title: Exotic Textile Art From Indonesia
description: THE exhibition called Splendid Symbols: Textiles and Tradi tion in Indonesia, which opened yesterday at the Asia House Gallery, 112 East 64th Street (through Sept. 3), is the sort of show that can be enjoyed simply as an anthology of exotic and enchanting fabric designs. Even where the intricate symbolism of these designs remains closed book to us, the extraordinary beauty of craft, pattern and color provides a considerable pleasure for the eye. This is design of a very high order of invention, and it requires no special ethnographic background to appreciate its visual splendors.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Networks to Broadcast The President's Speech
description: The three major networks said yesterday that they would broadcast President Carter's address to the nation Sunday night. ABC, NBC and CBS radio and television networks said that they would provide live coverage at 10 P.M. The broadcast is expected to last onehalf hour.

title: U.S. Aides Say Afghanistan Army Is Crumbling Under Rebel Pressure
description: WASHINGTON July 12  Afghanistan's army of 100,000 is gradually crumbling under pressure from antiCommunist rebels in all the country's 28 provinces, according to United States officiais.

title: Chile Opens Hearing on U.S. Plea
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 11  Chile's Supreme Court opened hearings today on a United States appeal against the denial of extradition of three Chilean Army officers indicted for the murder in Washington of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader.

title: ARMS PACE FLAWED, CRITICS TELL SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 12Critics of the strategic arms treaty contended today that the agreement with the Soviet Union was seriously flawed and suggested that it be renegotiated.

title: Man in Connecticut Is Accused Of Plan to Prey on Polish Aliens
description: HARTFORD, July 12  A Federal grand Jury in Bridgeport this afternoon handed up a onecount indictment against a Polishborn travel agent under suspicion of preying on newly arrived Polish aliens seeking legal residence here.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: AvantGarde Dance in the Modern's Garden
description: Bodies will roll, fall and lope into a canter tonight and Saturday through the Museum of Modern Art's Abby Aldrich. Rockefeller Sculpture Garden when Mary Overlie, sharing the free Summergarden bill with the experimental choreographer Kenneth King, presents a 25minute piece called The Figure. (Performances begin at, 8 P.M. Seating is limited. Information: 9566100.)

title: Savings BanksReport Drain
description: Savings banks in New York State experienced a net deposit outflow of $491 million during June, the Savings Banks Association of New York State reported yesterday. This compares with an outflow of $166 million in June 1978.

title: Zip F. Szold, 91, Hadassah Leader
description: Zip Falk Szold, a former national president of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan after a brief illness. Mrs. Szold, who was a leader in the organization for four decades, was 91 years old.

title: I.B.M. Net Off 3.4%, First Dip in 4 Years
description: The International Business Machines Corporation reported a 3.4 percent decline in secondquarter net earnings yesterday. It was the first quarterly drop since the second quarter of 1975.

title: 1,192 Questioned In All the Regions
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Monday through Wednesday with 1,192 adult men and women around the United States.

title: Minnie Riperton, 31; Soul Singer Lectured Nationally on Cancer
description: Minnie Riperton, one of the finest black singers of the 70's and a nationally known representative for the American Cancer Society, died of cancer yesterday at CedarsSinai Hospital in Los Angeles. She was 31 years old.

title: Ballet: Night of the Guitar
description: ONE of the admirable things about the National Ballet of Cuba, now at the Metropolitan Opera House, is its willingness to take risks by showing audiences unfamiliar works, whereas it could easily restrict itself to a few old favorites. But an artistic gamble, like any other kind of gamble, can mean that there may be losers as well as winners. On Wednesday evening, it is sad to report, the company gambled and lost.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets settled back yesterday to await the Federal Reserve's moneysupply numbers, and they are likely to remain quiet today as they wait for President Carter's energy address Sunday night. Bond prices yesterday closed little changed from Wednesday, and trading activity continued light.

title: Opera: Postcard Of Arcen to in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 12Having gotten the kitch out of its system at Tuesday night's opening, the Kennedy Center Summer Opera settled down to serious and highly professional business with last night's performance of Postcard From Morocco at the 475seat Terrace Theater. This oneact opera by Dominick Argento has been making the rounds since its world premiere in Minneapolis in 1971, and most listeners at the wellfilled house last night greeted it with sincere applause. There was, however, a contingent that started booing during the orchestral interlude, in which Mr. Argento quoted some Wagner themes from The Flying Dutchman and The Ring, and continued with a few lusty boos at the end.

title: 24 Food Establishments Are Cited for Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health named 24 food establishments this week that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named one restaurant that had corrected earlier violations and three that were closed for failing to do so.

title: Friends Say Schlesinger Has Told President He Wants to Quit in Fall
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  rnenas of James R. Schlesinger, the Secretary of Energy, said today that he had told President Carter that he wants to quit this fall, or certainly by the year's end, to avoid becoming a political liability in the President's reelection campaign.

title: Turning 'em Loose
description: A rapistrobber is going free because Justice Arnold Fraiman of Manhattan, the trial judge, declared mistrial rather than take the risk of having to postpone his vacation. The event occurred four years ago but comes to light now because the New York Court of Appeals has just ruled on the case, with a rebuke to the judge. The Appeals Court held that a retrial following the unnecessary mistrial is prohibited by the ConstituLion's ban on double jeopardy. The criminal must go free.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Wednesday about a murder trial in Litchfield, Conn., incorrectly identified Frank W. Jones Jr. Mr. Jones is an uncle of the victim, Michael Aranow.

title: Music: Emigrs Bach
description: THE Soviet Emigr Music Festival in progress at Carnegie Hall turned its attention to music by Bach in its concert Wednesday night, offering a program of some of his most copular works. It consisted of the tiranaenburg Concerto No. 5, the Concerto in D minor for Two Violins, the Suite No. 3 in D and arias from two sacred choral works  Et exsultavit Spiritus meus from the Magnificat and Erbarme dich, mein Gott from the St. Matthew Passion.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN this analysis of how four of the major news organizations gather their news and present it to the public, Herbert J. Gans may have set himself an impossible task.

title: Screen: Langella's Seductive 'Dracula' Adapted From Stage:Mobile Movie Theater To Play Three Boroughs
description: IN making this latest trip to the screen in living  or maybe it's undead  color, "Dracula" has lost some blood. The movie version, which opens today at Loews Astor Plaza, is by no means lacking in stylishness; if anything, it's got style to spare. But so many of its sequences are at fever pitch, and the mood varies so drastically from episode to episode, that the pace becomes pointless, even taxing, after a while.No expense has been spared: here are all the cobwebs (for the gloomy-castle scenes) and white lace ruffles (for the love scenes) and live bats and ghoul makeup (for the scary moments) and fake-looking matte shots (to suggest Merrie Olde England, circa 1880) that money can buy. What money couldn't or didn't buy, though, was a guiding spirit that might have kept all these flights of fancy from canceling one another out. This "Dracula" is so recklessly flashy that it winds up seeming vague.The director, John Badham, also directed "Saturday Night Fever," which makes him no stranger to sensationalism, or to staging highly overstated material with great success. "Dracula" sometimes achieves a similar pizazz, most notably in its moments of exaggerated courtliness and in one long chasing-vampires-in-the-graveyard interlude. Mr. Badham even manages a sedately comic dinner-party sequence, as Count Dracula is welcomed to Englandafter a long and unsightly shipwreck episode, which the movie doesn't need  by the aristocratic family he will soon be trying to destroy. Frank Langella, as the Count, is at his most entertainingly high-toned in delivering lines like, "No thank you, I never drink . . . wine," or in trying to stifle his keen interest when the butler cuts his finger.Mr. Langella is still playing Dracula as the compleat ladykiller, a dashing and romantic figure who just happens to have one little kink. This works beautifully in those portions of the film that aspire to elegance, and a lot less well when Mr. Badham switches abruptly from glamour to ghoulishness. Mr. Langella creates a Dracula who's seductive rather than scary, only to have Mr. Badham periodically spice up the movie with graphic horror tricks that undermine the performance. Mr. Langella never seems like anyone who would hobnob with a drooling, white-faced zombie, like the one who provides the movie's biggest scare. Nor does he seem capable of head-twisting tricks  la "Exorcist," although he's obliged to try that, too.What does he seem capable of, then? The movie hedges its bets shamelessly when it comes to Dracula lore, never explaining the vampire's habits or nutritional requirements. This reaches a bewildering crescendo in the film's final moments, which provide an ambiguous ending that is nothing but a dirty trick at the audience's expense. Does the vampire die? By all logic of the story, he does. But you never know when somebody might want to make a sequel.The Van Helsing character has been drawn more deeply into the story, to accommodate Laurence Olivier, who is supposed to be Dutch but sounds much as he did in "Marathon Man" and "The Boys From Brazil." Lord Olivier and Mr. Langella meet primarily for action scenes, which are the forte of neither. Lord Olivier has some delightful moments with Donald Pleasence, though, as each plays the father of a beautiful young woman with nasty-looking puncture marks on her neck.The first of these, Van Helsing's daughter Mina (Jan Francis), serves primarily to keep Mr. Langella from going hungry and to draw Lord Olivier into the story. The second, Miss Lucy (Kate Nelligan), becomes the woman Dracula loves. The scene in which he seduces her, which ought to be the erotic high point of a movie with considerable erotic pretensions, is proceeding along steamily until Mr. Badham interrupts it with an amazingly ill-advised special-effects sequence, full of abstract shapes in a stark red-and-black scheme.This is on an overwrought par with all the cobwebs, dry ice, loony-bin scenes and yellowish landscapes Mr. Badham also supplies, in an attempt to leave absolutely nothing to the viewer's imagination. Yet "Dracula" is a story that remains most eloquent at its sparest, and that surely didn't need to be overtold.One of the most impressive things about "Dracula" is its soundtrack. John Williams has contributed yet another ravishing score.

title: Five Die in Kentucky Car Crash
description: BRODHEAD, Ky., July 12 (AP)  A car went out of control today on a highway in southpcentral Kentucky, careened over an embankment and crashed into trees, killing all five people inside, according to the state police. Officers said that the car was apparently traveling at a high rate of speed when the accident occurred on U.S. 150 in Rockcastle County.

title: The City
description: Lower Manhattan has lost 2.2 percent of its population since 1970, according to preliminary results of a special test census released yesterday by the Federal Census Bureau. The count was taken as part of several preparations for the 1980 Census and the portion of Manhattan below Houston Street was chosen because of its polyglot character.

title: Australians Search for Souvenirs of Skylab
description: BALLAD0NIA, Australia, Friday, July 13  A century ago, the prospect of finding gold nuggets brought adventurers rushing into this hot, dry and isolated region. Today, the prospect of discovering some twisted fragment from the fallen 77ton Skylab has produced a similar fever.

title: Notes on People
description: Only 48 hours after his release from Colorado State Prison, Joseph Meyers Corbett Jr., the convicted murderer of Adolph Coors 3d, of the beerbrewing family, was wanted yesterday for parole violation.

title: Economic Scene
description: PREVIOUS column suggested that a longterm solution to our chronic energy problem will be reached only when the Government makes difficult but necessary compromises among energy development, enviromental protection and economic growth. Based on these compromises, consistent policies and regulations can help to establish the market environment in which supply and demand become balanced. The question becomes, what action should the Government take and what may be the result?

title: Justice Fraiman Unsure of Plans For Reelection
description: Justice Arnold G. Fraiman said yesterday that his reputation had been ruined as a result of disclosures this week that his insistence on taking summer vacations on two occasions with trials still in progress had led to the release of defendants accused of serious crimes.

title: Israeli Court Orders Halt of Work On a Settlement in Arabs Lands
description: JERUSALEM, July 12 (UPI)  Arab landowners won a temporary injunction from the Israeli Supreme Court today ordering a halt to further work at a site in the West Bank expropriated for the expansion of a Jewish settlement. It was the second time in a month that the court had ordered work stopped on West Bank settlements pending appeals by Arab landowners.

title: You Bet Your Life
description: BRISTOL, Conn.  State governments today are encouraging their citizens to lose money. That is what the unparalleled, statesanctioned spread of gambling in the form of lotteries, casinos and offtrack betting is all about, once you strip away the political rhetoric. Since the object is to raise revenues, people must lose for the state to gain.

title: Enforcement of 78Degree Cooling Called Unlikely for Several Weeks
description: New York State officials who have been asked to enforce President Carter's order that most commercial and government buildings be airconditioned to no cooler than 78 degrees said yesterday that they would be able to do virtually nothing about it for at least several weeks.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: Profits Scoreboard

title: President to Give Sunday Address On Energy Plans
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  President Carter, who has completed an intensive, weeklong reassessment of domestic problems including energy, will deliver nationally televised speech at 10 P.M. Sunday setting forth Administration goals and policies, the White House announced today.

title: Shootings Recall Other Gangland Slayings
description: Yesterday's murder of Carmine Galante and two other men recalled earlier ganglandstyle killings in New York City.

title: How to Bring Skylab Down
description: So the great Skylab gamble paid off. Just as space agency officials and the odds had predicted, the remnants of America's largest spacecraft fell harmlessly to Earth, swallowed up by empty expanses of ocean and the barren desert of western Australia. No chunks were indiscreet enough to hit a DC10, or Three Mile Island nuclear plant or a fullyloaded oil tanker. No injuries were reported, unless one counts the man in the Philippines who was said to have suffered a heart attack while shouting Skylab! Skylab! during a nightmare, or the American woman who fell off a porch and broke her leg while gawking skywards.

title: Eleanor P. Kilcoyne, Among First On the Brooklyn College Faculty
description: Eleanor D. Kilcoyne, one of the first members of the faculty of Brooklyn College when it was founded in 1930, died Wednesday at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn after a short illness. She was 74 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: 2 Policemen Die as Copter Falls
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., July 12 (AP)  A police helicopter checking on an overdue boat crashed into the Atlantic Ocean 300 yards offshore, killing the two officers aboard, the police said today.

title: HolmesShavers Title Fight Set for Sept. 28
description: Larry Holmes, the only heavyweight champion of the world, has recovered sufficiently from his eye, ear and throat problems for Don King, the promoter, to announce yesterday that the next defense of the World Boxing Council title, against topranked Earnie Shavers, would be held Sept. 28, only two Weeks after its original date.

title: 5 Papers Refuse to Print Some Doonesbury Strips
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12At least five newspapers have refused to print installments of the Doonesbury comic strip because of what editors are calling libelous references to Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. and Sidney R. Korshak, a Beverly Hills lawyer.

title: State Supreme Court justice Under Fire
description: Arnold Guy Freiman says he hates controversy, and for most of his life he has assiduously avoided it. In fact, until the State Supreme Court justice came under attack this week for his handling of two criminal cases in which the defendants went free because he went off on vacations, his reputation had been publicly blemished only once before.

title: Two Share Lead in Open at 70
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 12  The 39th annual United States Women's Open started with two impressive records at the Brooklawn Country Club today as eight golfers shot par or better while 6,700 people attended.

title: Market Place
description: FOR car owners, the price and supply of gasoline have provided a compelling topic of conversation lately.
