Meanwhile, some stock market analysts have been fixing their sights on the General Motors Corporation and pondering how much it will earn and what dividends it might pay to more than one and a quarter million stockholders. The subject is or more than passing importance. As Stan Weinstein, publisher of The Professional Tape Reader, an investment advisory service, recently noted: General Motors is the one most important stock in the marketplace.

title: Broadway
description: GLYNIS JOHNS will star in Harold and Maude next season, and Robert Lewis will direct her. Miss Johns has not been on Broadway since she did A Little Night Music in 1973, while Mr. Lewis has not been on nroaaway since ne airectea on a clear Day You Can See Forever in 1967. Miss Johns is a star, and for Night Music she won a Tony. Mr. Lewis was on the beginning of the Actors Studio and then went on to direct, among other things, Brigadoon, Teahouse of the August Moon and The Happy Time. This makes him a star, too. We wanted a director with an enormous knowledge of music, Frank Milton, coproducer of Harold and Maude, says, and one morning while I was shaving it came to me: Bobby Lewis. Then, after we talked, he said, Frank, there's only one person who can do this play: Glynis Johns.  That was how it began.

title: Letters
description: Now that Alfred Kahn has raised the possibility of gasoline rationing from within the Administration, it would seem wise to reiterate the point made by Professors Scarf and Tobin several weeks ago in a letter published here (June 7). The population need not fear a coupon rationing scheme as long as the coupons can be bought and sold in a white market. In lieu of the free-forall scramble for underpriced gasoline that can be dismissed as the most inefficient and unfair method of allocation, one must choose between price rationing and coupon rationing. A careful comparison of the two can thus prove quite revealing.

title: CARTER ASKS ADVICE OF PENNSYLVANIANS
description: President Carter, who has been conferring with highlevel officials on the energy situation at Camp David for more than a week, left the Maryland mountain retreat for 3 hours last night to seek the advice and opinions of half a dozen middle class couples in Pennsylvania.

title: Advertising
description: LABATT'S BREWERIES of Canada secure as the industry leader in It homeland, is now prepared to con centrate its efforts south of the border.

title: ThreeState Antiques Fair and Bargain Directory
description: The goodweather crop of flea markets, outdoor crafts displays. antiques fairs and other alfresco emporiums are ripe for visitors this weekend, with events scheduled throughout the New York. New Jersey and Connecticut region. Here is a guide to what's happening, when and where, on the fleamarket circuit; admission is free where none is given. (Numbers refer to map on page C1.)

title: South Africa, Plunged Into Oil Crisis, Seeks Ways to Cope
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 12  White South Africans, accustomed to celebrating the country's bountiful reserves of strategic minerals, are faced with pressing problems because of the sudden scarcity of the one crucial resource that nature did not supply oil.

title: Bank Profits Up SharplyAt Chemical and Charter
description: The Chemical New York Corporation and the Charter New York Corporation reported strong increases yesterday in secondquarter operating earnings.

title: Bally ChangesTerms of Offer
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said yesterday that it had changed the terms of its offer to its stockholders of an interest in its Atlantic City casino subsidiary, Park Place Inc., because of questions raised by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Business and the Law
description: IT is not exactly beach reading, but the recently published book, In Defense of the Corporation, has the advantage of being a quick read. It is only. 133 pages long and has lots a white space between chapters. What it lacks in length, it makes up in rage, principally directed toward Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate.

title: Energy Problem Alters Reporters Dress Code
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI)  The energy crisis brought about the demise today of the decadesold requirement that male reporters wear coats and neckties in the House press gallery.

title: Gas Crisis Changing Way of Life But Most in U.S. Are Managing
description: Paul Sowa, a Californian who used to drive 1,900 miles on a weekend of cruising, did not take a single joy ride in May or June. Now the 33-yearold lawyer is considering joining a carpool and giving up his oceanview Santa Monica apartment for one within walking distance of his office.

title: 50% Is Held 3 Months
description: The Arlen Realty and Development Corporation, which lost $129 million in its last fiscal year, disclosed yesterday that six of its top executives had agreed to a deferral of an average 50 percent of their salaries over the next three months to conserve the company's cash.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JULY 13, 1979

title: EARNINGS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday reported a net loss of. $79.1 million in the quarter ended June 30, in contrast to a profit of $74.8 million, or 86 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1978. The deficit was a recult of the extraordinary loss of $170 million in the 1979 settlement of four uraniumsupplycontract lawsuits.

title: Events and Openings
description: DRACULA, directed by John Badham; starring Frank Langella, Laurence Olivier, Donald Pleasance and Kate Nelligan; at the Ziegfeld Theater.

title: Around the Nation
description: TUCSON, Ariz., July 12 (AP)  A company accused of allowing radioactive contamination to spread to people and food has 100 days to decontaminate its plant and ship radioactive materials out of state, the Arizona Atomic Energy Commission ruled yesterday.

title: About Real Estate
description: HIGHLAND PARK, N.J.  Here and there in the vicinity of New Brunswick, N.J., Rutgers University owns undeveloped land. It has identified 300 acres in about six parcels that it considers suitable for development of one sort or another.

title: Rhodesia Leader Ends His Washington Visit
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (Reuters) Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa of Zimbabwe Rhodesia ended his United States visit today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shorn. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the AmerIcan Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Dr. Fred W Kranz, 91; Researcher in Accoustics
description: Dr. Fred W. Kranz, a specialist in accoustics research, died last Sunday in St. Petersburg, Fla., after a short illness. Dr. Kranz, who formerly lived in Pleasantville, N.Y., was 91 years old.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 34.

title: HANOI VOICES HOPES ON REFUGEE PARLEY
description: GENEVA, July 13  Vietnam expressed the hope today that the conference that meets here next week to consider the Indochinese refugee problem will achieve a concrete and realistic solution.

title: Books of The Times
description: In their evolution through the centuries, children have exchanged the burden of work for the burden of love. Although they used to support themselves, they support us now with promises of the future. Once apprenticed to a

title: PennsylvaniaDelaware Strike Shuts Many Stations
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  A strike to protest Federal gasoline regulations closed thousands of gasoline stations in Pennsylvania and Delaware today, and a spokesman for the station operators said the closings would continue until something gives.

title: Greyhound Suit On U.S. Ruling
description: PHOENIX, July 13 (AP)  Greyhound Lines Inc., the nation's largest intercity bus company, said today it would seek to block an Interstate Commerce Commission decision that virtually deregulates intercity bus service for the summer.

title: Canada Raises Price of Gas 20%
description: OTTAWA, July 13  Canada raised the price of the natural gas it exports to the United States by more than 20 percent today. The increase, from $2.30 a thousand cubic feet to $2.80, effective Aug. 11, is intended to bring Canadian gas into line with world prices.

title: Henderson a Spoiler Again
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 13 (UPI)  Rickey Henderson, a rookie whose single was the only obstacle between Luis Tiant and a perfect game last Sunday, singled with one out in the bottom of the ninth inning tonight spoil Steve Renko's bid for a nohitter, as the Boston Red Sox scored a victory over the Oakland A's.

title: Fibak Upsets Gerulaitis, 76, 76; Censures Poor Sportsmanship
description: Vitas Gerulaitis, the defending champion, bowed out of the $300,000 Forest Hills Invitational yesterday, not with a handshake but with a whimper.

title: Giants and Jets Open Camps With Same Refrain: Who's the Quarterback?
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 13  A rookie crop that is joining a nonlosing team for the first time since 1975 had more than 4,000 measurements taken today as the Jets' 20th camp opened.

title: Nixon Pays Shah Visit in Mexico
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, July 13 (UPI) Former President Richard M. Nixon flew back to the Mexican border tonight on his way home from a oneday visit with the exiled Shah of Iran and said the former ruler should be assured that millions of Americans in the U.S. are still his friends.

title: Opera: Maureen Young Sings Bohme in the Park
description: One must admire the courage and ambition of Maureen Young, who sang the role of Mimi in Thursday night's performance of La Bohme on the Central Park Mall. The soprano has been blind from birth, and she was per- forming in a fully staged production by the New York Grand Opera as part of its annual summer series. Curiosity about the singer and the overwhelming popularity of the Puccini opera combined to draw a huge crowd, a good part of which stood throughout the threehour performance.

title: Ordeal of a Famed Buddhist In Ho Chi Minh City Related
description: TANJUNGPINANG, Indonesia, July 12  Vietnam's most famous Buddhist monk, Thich Tri Quang, was turned into a skeletonlike cripple during a year and a half of solitary confinement in Ho Chi Minh City's Chi HOa prison, according to a leading subordinate who escaped by. boat last month.

title: When Japan Reversed Progress
description: THETFORD CENTER, Vt.  Most Americans see progress as some kind of great impersonal force. It's something we can't stop, even if we want to. Once a piece of new technology gets invented  say, the nuclearpower plant  the world is changed, and will stay changed. It's up to us to change with it. So most Americans believe.

title: A Brooklyn Man, 32, Is Held as Mastermind In the Abduction of 3
description: A 32yearold unemployed mechanic was arrested last night and accused of planning and directing the 40hour abduction last week of a Brooklyn woman, her 6yearold daughter and a family friend. All were released unharmed after the woman's husband paid a $10,000 ransom.

title: Union Officials Call for an End To Jersey Strike
description: TRENTON July 13 Yielding to pressure from TRENTON, courts and Governor Byrne, leaders of two unions representing state employees tonight asked an estimated 13,000 strikers to call off their fourdayold walkout.

title: McGrawHill Is Planning To Buy Data Resources
description: McGrawHill Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy Data Resources Inc., an economic forecasting company headed by Otto Eckstein, a Harvard economist, for about $103 million.

title: PHILIP POLLACK
description: Philip Pollack, founder and president of LeedsDixon Laboratories of Moonachie, N.J., a manufacturer of health foods and nutritional supplements, died yesterday at his home in Montclair, N.J., after a short illness. He was 57 years old.

title: Dr. David Bosworth, Surgeon Well Known For Orthopedic Work
description: Dr David M. Bosworth, an internationally prominent orthopedic surgeon known for his research in bone and joint tuberculosis, died Wednesday at his home in Bristol, Vt. He was 82 years old.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Fraiman Offered To Shift Holiday And Finish Trial
description: Justice Arnold G. Fraiman, who was excoriated Tuesday by the state's highest court for declaring a mistrial in a 1975 rape case because of his and some jurors vacation plans, had offered to delay his vacation if that meant the trial could continue. His offer came to light yesterday after an examination of the written brief prepared by the prosecutor.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Theaters for the movies The Wanderers and Dracula were incorrectly identified in Weekend yesterday. The Wanderers is playing at the Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters, and Dracula is at the Ziegfeld and other theaters.

title: Report Says Risks Would Rule Out U.S. Armed Action in Persian Gulf
description: High, possibly unacceptable military risks coupled with severe political and economic consequences In the event of failure, were cited today as arguments. against United States military intervention in the Persian Gulf region, where were would be a distinct possibility of direct Soviet intervention, according to Library of Congress report by the Congressional Research Bureau.

title: Somoza Goes to Guatemala Briefly
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 13 President Somoza flew to Guatemala City today for talks with leaders of Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras amid continuing speculation that he may soon step down from office.

title: Christie Duo Gain In Golf
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 13 Neil Christie, champion of the host club, and his young partner, J.P. O'Hara, survived an upanddown battle to advance to the quarterfinals of the John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament today.

title: Otto Doering, Former O.S.S. Leader
description: Otto C. Doering Jr., a New York lawyer who was second in command in the Office of Strategic Services under Gen. William J. Donovan during World War II, died of a heart attack yesterday at his summer home in Lake Placid, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: U.S. TO SELL SAUDIS $12 BILLION IN ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  Within a week of Saudi Arabia's announcement that it would increase oil production a million barrels a day, the State Department said today that it was recommending the sale of an additional $1.2 billion in military equipment to allow the Saudis to continue modernizing their paramilitary national guard.

title: News Summary
description: Energy

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter indicated that the energy program he will announce Sunday is intended to reduce the nation's oil imports by 5 million barrels a day by 1990. The plan, the most ambitios of four presented by top Presidential advisers, was endorsed by Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger but opposed by most other advisers as unrealistic. It would combine conservation, increased domestic oil production and synthetic fuel production. [Page 1.]

title: U.S. Men's Quintet Wins Final
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 13  The Puerto Rico men's basketball team carried a giant Puerto Rican flag onto the court at Roberto Clemente Coliseum tonight, but it was the United States that left with the gold medal in the Pan American Games.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: About New York
description: Isaac Sroka, a touristrealist from, Belgium, is having a wonderful time ignoring the usual Statue of Liberty snapshot backdrops, and instead posing his wife downtown by a pooperscooping burgher ruled by a ridiculous pet, and uptown by a snoozing, driveling bum,

title: Press Asks Court To Deny Motion To Shut Hearing
description: Lawyers for three newspapers, the New York Civil Liberties Union and the Manhattan District Attorney's office yesterday urged the judge in,an attemptedmurder case in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to deny a defense motion to close a hearing.

title: James Underwood Crockett, 63, Host of a Gardening Show on TV
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 (UPI) James Underwood Crockett, whose popular television show helped millions of home gardeners to grow flowers and vegetables, died Wednesday on holiday in Jamaica. He was 63 years old.

title: O'Dwyer Urges New York Democrats to Dump Carter
description: Paul O'Dwyer said yesterday that President Carter could not carry New York in 1980 and that state Democratic leaders should not let the President intertwine his political future with the party's.

title: Egypt's Embassy In Turkey Seized By 4 Palestinians
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Saturday, July 14 Four Palestinian gunmen seized the Egyptian Embassy here yesterday, killing two Turkish security guards and taking 20 hostages, including the Ambassador.

title: Toyota Taking Foes Seriously
description: TOYOTA CITY, Japan, July 11 We picked up the first Xbody car in Detroit, flew it over the next day  and after the top brass had driven it for a week or two we gave it to the R and D oeonle. They tore it apart.

title: Applause Breaks Out As DC10 Takes to Air
description: BALTIMORE, July 13 (UPI)  The 100 passengers flying here on a DC10 from Chicago applauded today when the plane lifted off, then clapped even harder when the captain thanked them for their confidence.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Following Is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable to the capital shares of dualpurpose Investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices of best overthecounter dealertodealer asked prices for the capital shares of each componv with the Percentage differences (discount or premium) between the net asset va lue and the asked.

title: Gas Potential Seen In Well Off Jersey
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 13 (AP)  A new Federal report on a test well drilled in very deep water 105 miles off the New Jersey coast suggests the area has a good potential for natural gas.

title: In Rockwell Country, U. S. of A.
description: LAKE, Wis.  A lot of people think Norman Rockwell was dishonest because he made his own world to replace the one he had to live with. don't believe it.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: New U.S. Judge From Texas Assailed Over Racial Slur
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)  Mem bers of Congress have complained to the Justice Department about a newly appointed Federal district judge in Texas who has been quoted in a newspaper article as using a racial slur.

title: U.S. and Soviet Swap Land for Envoys Recreation
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) In a swap between the United States and the Soviet Union, a lush, wooded land on Maryland's Eastern Shore that belonged to John Jacob Raskob, the builder, will be turned over to Russian diplomats for tennis, swimming and other recreational use.

title: Ellen H. Bradley Is Bride Of George H. Watson Jr.
description: The marriage of Ellen Havican Bradley to George Henry Watson Jr., a vice president of ABC News and bureau chief in Washington, took place in the Appleton Chapel at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday. The Rev. Lawrence Hill, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Excess Radiation at Middletown
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., July 13 (AP) About 100 workers at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant were exposed in the last few weeks to radiation that exceeded Federal work limits, officials said today. They said the exposures did not appear to constitute a health hazard.

title: Ballet: Cubans Dance Alicia Alonso's Swan Lake
description: The National Ballet of Cuba's Swan Lake, presented for the first time in New York on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is hardly the definitive version of a beloved classic. It has too many stylistic idiosyncracies, not to speak of choreographic changes, for that. But it is certainly strong on curiosity value.

title: Tennessee Gas Truck Hijacked
description: PIKEVILLE, Tenn., July 13 (AP) Gunmen hijacked a gasoline tanker and released its driver unharmed after emptying the truck's 9,000gallon cargo, the authorities said. Johnny Chancey, 25 years old, of SoddyDaisy, was driving to Trenton, Ga., when someone flagged him down yesterday in Chattanooga and proceeded to hijack the truck.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSJack. Of Teaneck, N.J. Beloved husband of Henrietta (Nee Schneider). Devoted father of Carole Goldstein. Adored grandfather of Eliot and Dine Goldstein. Former President of Abrahams Magazine Service, NYC. Services will be held at Gutterman Musicent Kreitzman Corner of Park and Passaic Streets; Hackensack, N.J. on Sunday, July 15th at 9:45am. Memorial week will be observed at the residence. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to Muscular Distrophy Association, Inc., 1200 U.S. Hwy 46, Clifton, N.J.

title: Portuguese Leader Calls Election
description: LISBON, July 13 (Reuters)  President Antonio Ramalho Eanes told the Portuguese people tonight that he had decided to dissolve Parliament and call interim elections because it was the only democratic way out of the present political impasse.

title: Life With Hafizzulah
description: HAMDEN, Conn.  The coup in Afghanistan last year was more than a remote news item to me. It brought back memories of a hot summer in Connecticut in 1957 when my family was host to an Afghan student who needed a place to live for six weeks before he started school in New York City.

title: When Homemaking Becomes Job No. 2
description: Since I had my daughter, work has increasingly become a place you go that takes the entire day and have to leave each evening to go to Job 2  chef, maid, housekeeper and nanny, wrote a woman from Tacoma, Wash. I am so tired all the time that more and more often I wish I were only working a few hours a week, although it would certainly be nice to earn the same amount I now make in a 40hour week!

title: Lethargic Market Is Down 3.33
description: Stock prices eased again in subdued trading yesterday as investor lethargy hung as heavy on the market as the heat of the day. The Dow Jones industrial average, in its fourth consecutive decline, lost 3.33 points as turnover continned to be moderate.

title: Bridge:
description: An exciting finish has developed in the European Bridge Championships in Lausanne, Switzerland, with France, Italy and Denmark fighting for the crown and the right to represent the European zone in the World Team Championship later this year.

title: Nicaraguan Rebels Turn to O.A.S., Call Terms of U.S. Irreconcilable
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 13 Members of the Nicaraguan revolutionary junta said today that the United States had not withdrawn irreconcilable demands and that they were turning instead to the Organization of American States for support in their plan to install a new government in Managua.

title: House Unit to Focus On Telephone Changes
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, chairman of the House communications subcommittee, said today that he would no longer press for complete rewriting of the Communications Act of 1934 but would, instead, concentrate on the telephone industry.

title: Australian Mining Town Roiled By Move to Take Skylab Chunk
description: KALGOORLIE, Australia, Saturday, July 14  This frontier goldmining town, where possession is nine points of the law, believes that it has found a big nugget of Skylab and it is not going to give it up without a fight.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 24.

title: AIRLINES PUT DC10'S BACK IN AIR AS F.A.A. ENDS THE GROUNDING
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  The Government announced today the lifting of the ban that had kept the nation's 138 DC10's grounded for 37 days, and the planes began returning to the air within hours.

title: Mercedes Lifting Price
description: Daimler Benz A.G., maker of Mercedes autos, said in Stuttgart, West Germany yesterday that it was raising domestic model prices about 1.9 percent, effective July 16. There was similar price rise in December 1978.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, July 13 (Reuters)  Britain moved quickly today to grant immunity from prosecution to Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa, Prime Minister of Zimbabwe Rhodesia, when activists opposed to apartheid sought to have the Bishop arrested for treason.

title: 5 INDIANS CONVICTED IN CONSPIRACY TRIAL
description: ST. PAUL, July 13 (AP)  Five Chippewa Indians were convicted tonight on conspiracy and assault charges arising from the May 19 armed takeover of the jail on the Red Lake Indian Reservation.

title: Blumenthal Cites Perils Of Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)  Unless inflation is brought under control, the mild recession now beginning could turn into the much grimmer prospect of a deeper, more prolonged recession, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today.

title: Firefighters Union Head Elected
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association, which represents New York City's 8,900 firemen, has elected Nicholas Mancuso, a 40yearold member of Ladder Company 46 in the Bronx, as its new president. Mr. Mancuso defeated Joseph T. Bonanno of Engine Company 306 in Bayside, Queens, in a runoff election whose results were announced on Thursday. Both men had run ahead of the incumbent, Richard J. Vizzini, in an election on June 22.

title: Bank Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indu cotes stock Is listed on the New York Stool. Exchanoe, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Tiffany Lamp Shades Valued at $1 Million Stolen by Holdup Men
description: Two welldressed men, one armed with a small handgun, stepped into an elegant Madison Avenue antiques shop late yesterday afternoon, handcuffed a saleswoman and left with six dazzling Tiffany lamp shades whose value was put at $1 million, the police said.

title: U.S. Industrial Output Down by 0.3% in Month
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)  Industrial production fell threetenths of 1 percent in June, leaving output for the second quarter of this year below that of the lackluster first quarter, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

title: Cabaret: Rose Murphy
description: Rose Murphy's talents have been unfolding gradually, like the petals of a slowblooming flower, over the last 30 years. brie necame laentiried as the cheechee girl in the late 40's and during the 50's because of the birdlike chirrups and twitterings with which she colored her songs. In the 60's, she went into retirement, and when she returned to activity six years ago at the Cookery, her piano playing, which had previously been secondary to her novel singing style, took a more prominent role. She had a distinctively light and jaunty way of floating through a melody over a strongly stated beat that was emphasized by her heel, pounding on a board that she keeps under the piano just for that purpose.

title: Pockets of Poverty, in Sun and Snow
description: The first genuine urban initiative of the Carter Administration was a program called Urban Development Action Grants, an imaginative scheme to revitalize city neighborhoods by using Federal funds to attract private investment. The program has been a great success. Through it, private developers have been persuaded by city governments to build downtown hotels and to refurbish waterfronts. And they have joined merchants and community groups to rehabilitate commercial strips and stretches of vacant housing. New York City, although slow at first to take advantage of the program, just last Thursday won approval of a $16million motelandtruckstop complex for Hunts Point.

title: Killings Dismay an Area Accustomed to Bad News
description: On Thursday, the day that Carmine Galante and two other men were murdered in a Bushwick restaurant, mem. bers of the RidgewoodBushwick Senior Citizen Center at 319 Stanhope Street spent much of their lunch hour discussing the coming Oktoberfest.

title: Bundy Contracts Virus Infection, So Trial Is Postponed to Monday
description: MIAMI, July 13 (UPI)  Theodore Bundy, accused of killing two Florida State University sorority sisters and savagely beating three other women students, became ill with a virus infection today, forcing a recess until Monday in his threeweekold murder trial.

title: Carey Signs Bill Limiting UnrulyStudent Transfers
description: ALBANY, July 13  Governor Carey said today that he had signed a bill requiring schools to give written notice and offer a hearing before transferring children who are discipline problems to other schools.

title: U.S. Backs Tariff Cuts On Apparel
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 The office of the United States Special Trade Representative said today that the newly agreedupon tariff reductions for apparel imports could potentially cost 7,300 jobs in the New York City garment industry over a period of eight years  far less than leaders of the industry had been maintaining:

title: Carter, Conscious of Risks, Seeks Wider Audience
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  By dramatically canceling his energy speech last week and holding elaborate consultations all this week at Camp David, President Carter has sought a wider hearing for his new energy program. He has demonstrated that no matter how his political fortunes may have sagged, he can still command over

title: StoppardPrevin Comedy At the Met July 30
description: Every. Good Boy Deserves Favour, a comedy for actors and orchestra by Tom Stoppard and Andr Previn, will be performed at the Metropolitan Opera House from July 30 to Aug. 4.

title: INDIAN OCEAN RULED A WHALE SANCTUARY
description: LONDON, July 13 (Reuters)  The International Whaling Commission rejected a proposal today for a threeyear worldwide ban on sperm whaling, but voted to establish a whaling sanctuary in the Indian Ocean for at least 10 years.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: Instructor Gregory Lugano teaching students in a special automobile repair program in Brooklyn how to do a valve and ring repair on a car engine.

title: Victims of Spanish Fire Include Two Americans
description: SARAGOSSA, Spain, July 13 (AP) The toll in Spain's worst hotel fire rose today to 72 dead, 3 missing and 70 injured, officials said. Two Americans and a Canadian were reported among the dead as the Government opened an investigation into alleged safety violations at the 10story building.

title: Art: Millennia's Flowers In 19 Sections in London
description: LONDON  Flowers and plants have inspired artists to record their fleeting beauty since the earliest days of civilization. Documenting the almost limitless subject of floral art is a charming and scholarly new exhibition, through Sept. 9, at the British Museum, Flowers in Art From East and West.

title: Talking Business
description: With the economy veering into a possible recession, many economists both inside and outside government are turning their thoughts to programs for combating recession. There is talk now of tax cuts to stimulate the economy. At the same time, there is concern that whatever measures are taken will push the economy toward higher inflation.

title: House G.O.P. Prescribes Tax Cut to Fix Economy
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) House Republicans unveiled today their cure for a recession that they blame on the Democrats: a $36 billion tax cut, $28 billion of it for individuals, as well as a freeze on Social Security taxes and tax changes to spur capital investment.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: A Loaf of Bread, a Jug of Wine
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 13  Legislative battles under way or pending could end the winesales monopolies that liquor stores have enjoyed in a number of states since Prohibition was repealed in 1933.

title: Temple U. Hospital Strike Ends
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 13 (AP)  Employees of Temple University Hospital have approved a contract agreement to end their 10day strike. Service and clerical workers, technical professionals and pharmacists voted to accept a 6 percent wage rise in each year of a twoyear pact and to return to work today, according to Henry Nicholas, president of District 1199C of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Emolovees.

title: Earnings Rise 1% At First Chicago
description: The First Chicago Corporation, holding company of the First National Bank of Chicago, yesterday reported a secondquarter gain in operating earnings of only 1 percent, in sharp contrast to strong increases announced by other major banks.

title: Mets Take Twin Bill From Giants, 76, 52
description: The New York Mets turned in their annual sweep of a doubleheader last night, defeating the San Francisco Giants, 76 and 52, before 16,110 fans at Shea Stadium. In each of the last four seasons, the Mets have swept just one doubleheader.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: I.T.T. Europe's Head Quits Under Fire
description: Gerhard R. Andlinger resigned under fire as president of I.T.T. Europe yesterday in the wake of Wednesday's surprise resignation of Lyman C. Hamilton Jr. as president and chief executive of the parent International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Gas Dealer Bars Strike For Honest Customers
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 20 (AP) Dick Uber changed his mind about participating in a service station strike because he decided his customers deserved a break for their honesty.

title: Fighting City Hall With Gestures
description: State Senator Vander L. Beatty, of Bedford-Stuyvesant, does not like Mayor Koch. That's his privilege. To express his views, he has embarked on an elaborate, timeconsuming, expensive and probably futile campaign. He has collected enough signatures to ask the city council to put on the ballot in November an amendment to the City Charter that would allow the voters to recall or remove a mayor. If the Council refuses, Senator Beatty promises to submit enough extra signatures to override the Council's veto. Alas, this is his privilege, too.

title: Carter Has Long Focused on Need to Curb Use of Energy
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  Energywatchers first became aware of Jimmy Carter in November 1973, when, as Governor of Georgia, he ordered that thermostats be lowered and flights of state airplanes curtailed. Since then, energy has been one of his principal concerns.

title: Women Predict Gains In Impact on Politics
description: CINCINNATI, July 13 (UPI)  The National Women's Political Caucus opened its biennial convention for 2,000 delegates today with a prediction that women would make quantum leaps in American politics in the next decade.

title: M.T.A. to Cut Back Marginal Bus Routes
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to cut $4.8 million from its $1.2 billion budget by reducing or eliminating bus service on lines where the authority said ridership was low.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON AMETHOD of recovering heavy crude oil from underground deposits developed by two Texas professors is regarded by the company for which it was patented this week as promising greatly increased oil production.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: COAST GUARD SEARCHES GULF FOR SLICK: Airborne oil surveillance system crewmen and oceanographers aboard a special flight yesterday to monitor the 300mile long oll slick produced by 30,000 barrels of oil escaping daily from a well off the Yucatan Peninsula. The slick, which is 25 miles wide, is moving north at about 10 miles a day and could reach the Rio Grande in two weeks. Environmentalists are worried about wildlife damage.

title: DR. M. MARGARET GOERNER
description: Dr. M. Margaret Goerner, a New York pathologist for 57 years, died Wednesday at her home in Palos Verdes, Calif., after a brief illness. She was 80 years old.

title: Arbitrator Backs Limit On Visits to Restrooms
description: MACON, Ga., July 13 (AP)  A Federal arbitrator has upheld a rule limiting the number of restroom visits by the employees of the Cagle Poultry and Egg Company.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: IC.I.A. Is Held Liable in Freedom of Information Suit
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that the Central Intelligence Agency stalled in producing documents under the Freedom of Information Act and should pay legal and court costs to a longtime civil liberties critic of Government policies. The united states Attorney's office has until midAugust to decide whether to appeal.

title: Fed Nomination Backed
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI)  The Senate Banking Committee today approved the nomination of Florida banker Frederick H. Schultz as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board despite objections of William Proxmire, committee chairman, Democrat of Wisconsin. The nomination was sent to the full Senate for a confirmation vote.

title: Dividends
description: x3 for 2 solit, subject to approval, payable date in October

title: Notes on People
description: After she was cut out of the will of Joan Crawford, Christina Crawford wrote an unloving memoir of her bruised life with her adoptive mother, Mommie Dearest, which earned her more than $1 million from the book and movie sales. Now Miss Crawford will collect from the Crawford estate anyway.

title: Gerald Eskenazi
description: Yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT CHOOSES AMBITIOUS PROGRAM TO CUT OIL IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  President Carter indicated today that he had decided upon an ambitious energy program that would reduce the nation's dependence on foreign oil by five million barrels a day by 1990.

title: The City
description: Two Flee Rikers; One Is Recaptured

title: OBSERVER
description: The news from China is that Bob Hope was there and the Chinese didn't recognize him. The news, of course, is wrong, and lest Bob become too depressed by it, I remind him that the same thing happened during my own visit to Yugoslavia in 1966.

title: Fiedler Memorial Set in Boston
description: BOSTON, July 13 (AP)The trustees of the Boston Symphony Orchestra voted yesterday to build an Arthur Fiedler Memorial Wing on Symphony Hall. It would be the first major addition to the building since It was built in 1900.

title: Galante's Body at Funeral Home
description: The New York City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday that the body of Carmine Galante had been taken to the ProvenzanoLanza Funeral Home, at 43 Second Avenue in Manhattan. The home said late yesterday that funeral arrangements were incomplete.

title: EarlyJuly Car Sales Down 19%
description: DETROIT, July 13 (UPI)  United States auto makers sold 19 percent fewer cars in early July than in the corresponding period last year, but a slight improvement over sales in June brought hopes that the industry's slump was moderating, the companies reported today.

title: Peter Nichols Weds Susan M. Patterson
description: Susan Marshall Patterson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Patterson of Vero Beach, Fla., and Erie, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Bulkeley Nichols, son of M. and Mrs. Arthur Boylston Nichols 3d of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony in the Wayside Presbyterian Church in Erie.

title: Your Money
description: THERE is little topquality investment advisory help available for the retired American with savings of up to $100,000. The reason is that advisers, such as bank trust departments or security fins, cannot make enough money on accounts of that size. If they were to charge more, the fees would eat up too much of the hopedfor increase in returns.

title: Chinese Visit NewYork, Seeking American Business Investments
description: With an interpreter gesturing, China's Finance Minister, Zhang Jingfu, second from left, and David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, yesterday took a look at the Jean Dubuffet sculpture Group of Four Trees, outside 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza. Later, at a lunch for 200 American business and financial executives at the bank, Mr. Zhang appealed foi investment in China. He said that his nation's political climate was stable and announced that Peking had approved legislation to foster joint capital ventures for outside investors with China.

title: All Around Town, Bid Belts Are Back
description: On some days, it seems, the city is encircled by wide belts. Blatantly and fashionably wrapped around summer dresses, blouses and jackets and above skirts and pants, broad belts have not been so conspicuous since their love affair with hiphuggers in the late 1960's.

title: Thai Premier Tells Congressmen Of Halt in Cambodian Expulsions
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  Thailand's Prime Minister has assured a group of American legislators that he has suspended the expulsion of Cambodian refugees.

title: Bank of England Issue
description: London, July 13 (Reuters)  The Bank of England said it would issue billion pounds of Exchequer stock due 1984 at a minimum price of 77 percent. The issue carries an interest rate of percent semiannually and proceeds will be used to help refinance maturing stocks.

title: Energy, Not Arms, Captures the Congress
description: WASHINGTON; July 13  This was supposed to be the week in which Congress turned its attention to the treaty to limit strategic arms, the beginning of the most important foreign policy debate in a generation. But it did not quite work out that way.

title: Koch Says Trust Firm Knew Most Bonds Since Early in Winter
description: Some employes of the U.S. Trust Company knew for more than eight months that $397 million in bonds owned by a city pension fund were missing from their vaults, Mayor Koch and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday, and furthermore city officials were not told about the disappearance. Meanwhile, the search for the Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds continued.

title: Senate Rejects Proposal To Weaken Labor Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)  In test vote today, the Senate decisively defeated an amendment that would have exempted certain neighborhood rehabilitation projects from a requirement that they employ a minimum number of skilled workers.

title: East 90's Boutiques Entice the AfterSchool Set
description: The Carnegie Hill section in the east 90's, a familyoriented neighborhood with a preponderance of the city's private schools, has shops where youngsters can spend their pocket money to advantage and where mothers can buy clothes for their offspring without venturing more than a few blocks from home base. And for grandparents, aunts or uncles, a leisurely stroll up Madison Avenue is usually all it takes to find the right gift for a young member of the clan.

title: Phillippe Halsman Rites July 25
description: A memorial service for Phillippe Halsman, the internationally known photographer who died on June 25 after a brief illness, will be held at 5:30 P.M. on Wednesday, July 25, at the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  Responding to a telephone call from Vice President Mondale, Leon Hess has promised the White House that his oil company, the Amerada Hess Corporation, will shrink its profit margin to comply with the Administration's guidelines for price restraint.

title: B.P. Raises Oil Price
description: LONDON, July 13 (Reuters)  The British Petroleum Company said it had raised its North Sea Forties Field oil price to $23.20 a barrel from $20.70 following the recent price increases by the Organlzation of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Police Hunt 2 Galante Associates Who Escaped From Slaying Scene
description: Two men who were eating lunch with Carmine Galante at an outdoor Brooklyn restaurant and escaped unharmed when he was shot to death Thursday were being sought yesterday by the police.

title: Peru's New Constitution Gains Limited Approval
description: LIMA, Peru, July 13 (AP)  President Francisco Morales Bermdez accepted Peru's new Constitution today, but he said some provisions would not take effect immediately.

title: The Truckers and Their Security Blanket
description: Washington is used to the hard sell by lobbyists on behalf of innumerable economic interests. Rarely, though, does it see an effort as big as the trucking industry's current blitz against the deregulation bill that has been offered by the White House and Senator Kennedy.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Events
description: Music

title: Department of Energy Clarifies Cooling Rule
description: The Federal Department of Energy issued a clarification yesterday of President Carter's order requiring most airconditioned buildings across the country to be no cooler than 78 degrees.

title: Ensemble for Wolf Trap
description: The Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts in Vienna, Va., outside of Washington, has established its own chamber ensemble. Called Concert Soloists of Wolf Trap, it is headed by Earl Wild, the pianist, and it will make its debut tomorrow afternoon at 2:30. The idea originated with Mrs. Jouett Shouse, chairman of the program committee and principal private benefactor of the summer festival.

title: Bonwit Bids To Reopen
description: Bonwit Teller, which closed its main store last May after 49 years on Fifth Avenue, is negotiating to reopen on the same site after the building is torn down and transformed into a 60story tower, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Gas for Weekend Is Expected to Be Ample
description: Gasoline supplies are expected to be plentiful this weekend in the New York metropolitan area and Connecticut, but officials warned motorists yesterday to restrict their driving so that fuel would not run out toward the end of the month.

title: Ryan 1Hitter Tops Yanks; Tackson Gets Singlein 9th
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 13  In a game filled with intense drama and punctuated by a heated dispute concerning an official scorer's call, Nolan Ryan lost his chance for a record fifth nohitter tonight when Reggie Jackson grounded a single to center field with one out in the ninth inning.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COME ON IN The torchy nightclub song that Cole Porter wrote for Dubarry Was a Lady now applies, years later, to one of the most invitinglooking oases in all of Greenwich Village. On Saturdays, from 2 to 5 P.M., for the rest of the summer, the public is being admitted to the grounds of the Jefferson Market Garden.

title: CElL CHAPMAN DIES; DESIGNER OF GOWNS
description: Ceil Chapman, designer of glamorous dresses on Seventh Avenue in the 1940's and 50's, died yesterday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 67 years old and had been suffering from lung cancer for two years. She had not been told about the death of her husband, Tom Rogers, of a heart attack on Tuesday.

title: William R. Adams, 72; Ex Head of St. Regis Co.
description: William R. Adams, former president, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the St. Regis Paper Company, died Thursday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 72 years old and had been associated with St. Regis for more than 40 years.

title: Cleveland's CashOnly Plan Skirts Bankruptcy but Speeds Decay
description: CLEVELAND, July 13  When Cleveland failed to pay off $14 million in overdue bank debts last December, a local Tshirt message appearing on the streets asked the question, Is There Life After Default?

title: Perkins Has 5 to Pick From
description: PLEASANTVILLE. N.Y., July 13  Phil Simms sat on a couch in the music room of Pace University Student Center today and said he expected to be sitting on the bench when the first eame comes around.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Around the Nation
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 13 (AP)  To insure that the taint of segregation is removed from Florida's public schools, a Federal district judge today ordered a fouryear delay in making a controversial literacy test a requirement to receive a high school diploma.

title: Miss Britz, on 70140, Leads Open by Two
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 13  Scoring and attendance records continued to fall today during the second round of the 34th United States Women's Open as a dozen players shot par or better before 10,000 people at Brooklawn Country Club. These figures broke the one dayold Open records of eight players at par or less and 6,700 spectators, set in the opening round.

title: The Region
description: CROMWELL, Conn. (AP)  The body of A 4yearold Middletown, Conn., boy was recovered and officials searched for his 1yearold sister after a car plunged into the Connecticut River about 3 A.M. yesterday.

title: JA VIlS AND CHURCH SEE TREATY CHANCES
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 Senior members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that there was an emerging consensus that the panel should recommend that the Senate attach several socalled understandings to the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Galante's Crime Family Called Small but Active in U.S. and Canada
description: The crime organization headed by Carmine Galante, who was shot to death Thursday afternoon, was one of the smallest of the five New York crime families in terms of the number of members. But, according to police intelligence officials, it was one of the most active, with interests that reached from New York to Canada, California, Florida and Arizona.

title: Yiddish Musical to Open At Town Hall on Oct. 16
description: The Yiddish musical Rebecca  the Rabbi's Daughter will open Oct. 16 for a 12week engagement at Town Hall. Mary Soreanu, an Israeli actress who made her New York debut last season in another Yiddish musical, The Girl From Tel Aviv, will star.

title: CETA Seeks Renewal Through PrivateSector Training
description: Until three months ago, Antoinette Mongal, an unemployed 30yearold woman divorced from her husband, had been looking for work that would offer a challenge as well as financial support for herself and her 9yearold son. Today, amid the grease and clattering tools of a garagelike school in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, she is learning to repair automobiles, with a job waiting for her if she successfully completes the course.

title: Letter: On Landmark Designation
description: We agree with you in your editorial of June 30 that Manhattan's Upper East Side is special. But the real question is not only how to preserve it but how to preserve it before uncontrolled change senselessly destroys the architectural richness and detail which your editorial lauds.

title: Ben Bella Free but Out of Sight in Algeria
description: MSILA, Algeria, July 9  It is not difficult to find the handsome, newly painted twostory villa where Ahmed Ben Bella, the first Prime Minister and President of independent Algeria, now lives in this sandblown town of 60.000 on the northern fringes of the Sahara. It's the house with lots of airconditioners, said the first citizen asked for directions, gesturing The Talk of Msila through the baxing neat toward a walled compound on a rough street without a name.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Silver and gold futures fell yesterday as traders prepared for a nationwide Presidential address that may bring new proposals to cure the nation's energy and economic ills.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY JULY 14 DORIC (Home). Left Bermuda July 12; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street. OCEANIC (Home). Left Nassau July 12; Wee A.M. at W. 55th Street. ROTTERDAM (Holland America). Left Bermuda July 12; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Ballet: Copplia by Canadians With Misses Jago and Harwood
description: The moment the curtain goes up on Erik Bruhn's Copplia at the New York State Theater, where the National Ballet of Canada is in residence for the last week of its New York summer season, we are plunged into a fairy tale. Maurice strike's set looks like a popup storybook village, and the first characters on stage are coarsely comical. It is all most agreeable fun.

title: Maree: Nowhere to Run
description: VILLANOVA, PA. ON the night in May when Sidney Maree became one of the first black South African runners to receive the deep green and gold colors of the Springbok national team, he had something he wanted to say. As former Prime Minister John Voerster approached the predominantly white team, smiling and shaking hands, Maree decided to keep silent. I shook his hand, he recalled last week, but deep in my heart I wanted to say, Let my people go. You are the one with the power, let my people go.

title: Music Notes: CETA Orchestra
description: This city has quietly acquired another fulltime orchestra. It has had lots of exposure but almost never in the places that would give it a reputation in the world of music. This coming season should change that. It will give four Monday night programs in the Abraham Goodman Auditorium and a second series of four programs in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: GREENWICH Works by 15 New York sculptors; marble, Plexiglas, metal, clay, wood, stone. HurIbutt Gallery, Greenwich Library, 101 W. Putnam Ave., through July 28. Monday through Thursday 9 to 9, Friday and Saturday 9 to 5. Phone 6227900.

title: Environment
description: PHILADELPHIA  For 280 miles, from its source in upstate New York to the head of tide at Trenton, the Delaware River is a glistening, unpolluted stream that supplies much of the New York metropolitan area with drinking water and sportsmen with some of the best trout fishing in the Northeast. By comparison, the heavily industrialized 85mile lower portion between Trenton and Wilmington  used by Philadelphia and other cities as a principal source drinking water  is a sewer. State and Federal officials met late last week to discuss once again a prominent industrial polluter, the New Jersey Zinc Division of Gulf & Western Industries.

title: Autos
description: Auto repair  and too often misrepair  may be taking a back seat to the gasoline shortage in the minds of moss motorists, but the difficulty of getting a car fixed properly remains the nation's top consumer frustration, according to many surveys.

title: House Hit by Plane Draws Complaints
description: MASSAPEQUA IT has been more than eight weeks since a small, private plane crashed into a home here after taking off from nearby Zahn's Airport, killing six persons, including a couple who lived in that house on Pompano Lane.

title: Riverhead May Vote On Jamesport Plants
description: RIVERHEAD RIVERHEAD TOWN voters may get their first chance to indicate how they feel about the proposed construction of a nuclearpower facility at Jamesport if a townwide referendum scheduled to be held during the general elections in November actually occurs.

title: Jane Lisa Strassberg Bride of James Hall 3d
description: Jane Lisa Strassberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Strassberg of Forest Hind, Queens, was married yesterday to James King Hall 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hall Jr. of New Hope, Va. The Rev. Dr. Theodore F. Adams, pastor emeritus of the First Baptist Church in Richmond, who married the bridegroom's parents 33 years ago, performed the ceremony in the garden at Halltop, the Hall home.

title: Miss Appleton Wed To Jameson Forster
description: Leslie Sidonia Appleton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Appleton of Long Beach, Calif., was married in Philadelphia yesterday to Jameson Forster, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Forster 2d of Haverford, Pa. The Rev. John Scott performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Episcopal Church, Hamilton Village.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ALTHOUGH the double glazing of windows in new homes is reuired under the state building ode, it is not considered a necessity by the Farmers Home Administration, which provides mortgage guarantees for lowincome residents of rural areas such as the Island's East End.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, July 14 (AP)  Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai's resignation was urged today by George Fernandes, his Industry Minister. Mr. Fernandes said, however, that Mr. Desai had refused.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, JULY 115 VOLENDAM (Holland America). Left Bermuda July 13; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Library Cataloguing Teachers
description: MANY good libraries have long kept peopletopeople indexes in their reference rooms  the name of an expert on Westchester Colonial history, for example  representing human encyclopedias, as one librarian put it.

title: ART He Improvises on the Past
description: SOUTHAMPTON ARTISTIC borrowing has a long and venerable history. The Romans copied the Greeks, the Renaissance masters copied the Romans and the academicians of the 19th century copied the Renaissance masters. More recently, such stellar figures as Van Gogh, Cezamie and Picasso were borrowers who in turn became lenders to countless modernists.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE seasonal migration of bigcity people to somewhere east of the QueensNassau line is in full flow, allowing for variations of the fuel pump, and it is time to  ponder once again the relationship between man and nature.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON  Art of Sport; also, group exhibition; noon to 6 P.M. daily, except Wednesdays; Saturday through July 31; Elaine Benson Gallery, Montauk Hwy. Reception 4 to 7 P.M. Saturday; preview to benefit U.S. Olympic Committee 5 to 9 P.M. Friday; donation $15 ; $25 a couple.

title: 22 Injured in Collapse of Porch At Cocktail Party in Newport, R.I.
description: NEWPORT, R.I. Sunday, July 15 (AP)  Twentytwo people were injured, some seriously, when the porch of a historic home collapsed during a formal cocktail party last night, dropping partygoers 11 feet to the ground.

title: Dsire Branch Caldwell Married
description: Dsire Branch Caldwell and William Frank Armitage Jr, were married yesterday at the Kirk in the Hills Presbyterian Church in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The Rev. James F. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: ART The SelfPortiait Psychoanalyzed
description: THERE'S more to selfportraiture than meets the eye; more, but not as much, perhaps, as some art lovers may think. At least, that's what Dr. Charles Sarnoff believes, and when he participates in a Heckscher Museum symposium on selfportraiture on Saturday in Huntington, he will use his dual expertise as a psychiatrist and an art detective to prove his point.

title: Wreck Fishing Lures Night Owls
description: EAST OF MONTAUK AT 10 minutes beyond midnight, at an hour when most of the world is settled down for the night, day begins aboard the Viking Starship.

title: Notes
description: One of the simpler pleasures of summer vacations is the opportunity to meander through old houses and historic places, looking at furniture and objects created in another time.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING Westville's Quiet Transformation
description: NEW HAVEN BEHIND the freshly painted porches of the aging colonials that line the dignified, treeshaded streets of the Westville section of New Haven, a quiet transformation is taking place.

title: Canada's Indians Are Seeking a Voice in Revamping of Constitution
description: OTTAWA, July 12  Chief Noel Starblanket, president of the National Indian Brotherhood, went to London last month to see the Queen. But he and his delegation of 300 chiefs from all over Canada were balked by their own Government and, he said, they were hurt and offended.

title: ART
description: TRENTON THE International Year of the Child has brought us an exhibition called Play and Fantasy Around the World in the State Museum here, made up of hundreds of playthings, most made of natural materials, from 63 countries.

title: The Batters the Players Like to Watch
description: THE major league baseball player must be considered a knowledgeable fan. He has studied the game, plays it better than others and understands its techniques, strategies and frustrations. It is his lob.

title: U.S. Boxers Win Four Gold Medals
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 14  It wasn't a perfect night for United States boxers in the Pan American Games, but four gold medals represented another significant step on the road to the Moscow Olympics.

title: Elizabeth Leys Married to Robert Bostrom
description: Elizabeth Mitchell Leys, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dirck Fisher Leys of Hartsdale and Windham, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Everett Bostrom, son of Angelina Bostrom of New Britain, Conn., and the late Everett Bostrom. The Rev.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Twin Brooks Kennel Club AllBreed, Caldwell College, Ryerson Avenue, Caldwell, N.J.; 1,208 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Poor Showing in Poll A Clue for Carter
description: APOLL by Bergen County Democrats shows Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts running far ahead of President Carter in party sentiment but indicates that Mr. Carter has room for improvement.

title: Energy Audit: Forewarned for Winter
description: FAIR LAWN AS IT turns out, the large attic fan that Benjamin and Renee Halperin bought for $5 at an auction is a particularly effective energyconservation device.

title: Getting Out the Voters
description: WASHINGTON  In 1861, the Englishman John Bright said this about our Presidential elections: We know what an election is in the U.S. for President  to my mind there is nothing more worthy of reverence and obedience  than the authority of the freely chosen magistrate of a great and free people.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: 1 THE WORLD ACCORDING TO GARP, by John Irving. (Pocket, $2.75.) Comic, extravagant novel about the son of a famous feminist mother.

title: The Demise of a Bus Line: Hard Times for Private Carriers
description: Private commuter bus lines serve the urban hinterlands, rumbling into suburbs and outlying districts where public systems can't, or won't, tread.

title: A Museum for Every Interest
description: MORE than 30 museums throughout the state offer a fine way to escape the heat and monotony of summer. Some, like the threelevel State Museum in Trenton, are large and multifaceted; others are small and tend to specialize in subjects such as minerals, old tools, religious artifacts and ethnic memorabilia.

title: What's Doing in EDINBURGH
description: WHY EDINBURGH?  One of the loveliest of European capitals, Edinburgh  it is pronounced EDinburruh  is also one of the easiest to get around in. Almost everything is reachable on foot, though some visitors may prefer to take an occasional taxi.

title: Television This Week
description: 8 P.M. (4) SUMMER OF MY. GERMAN SOLDIER. A rebroadcast of a twohour madeforTV film dramatization of Betty Greene's book about a young, Jewish girl who, during World War II, becomes friends. with a German prisoner of war held, in an American prison camp; starring Kristy McNichol, Bruce Davison and Esther Rolle.

title: Intellectual's Inventory
description: AT the start of the Nixon Presidency, Garry Wills described its protagonist as the last liberal (meaning that Richard M. Nixon retained a sanctimonious belief in the marketplace as a political and moral arena for the selfmade man). That was CONFESSIONS OF A CONSERVATIVE By Garry Wills. 231 pp. New York: Doubleday Be Co. $10. damning with faint praise, of course, although Mr. Wills, in light of Mr. Nixon's subsequent crimes, must have wished it had been fainter: Now, pausing from his stunningly diverse journalistic and scholarly endeavors (from Nixon Agonistes to Inventing America), Mr. Wills takes a look at an undogmatic conservative who is ready to let his experiences influence his conclusions: Garry Wills. He is naturally too respectful of the past to represent himself as the first of his line; and too disposed to find the hereandnow congenial to proclaim himself the last. But he cheerfully resigned to being a singular conservative, renegade in the eyes of others who crowd under that rubric.

title: Broadway Angels: Alive, Well and Multiplying,
description: This year, the Broadway angel is Everyman, which he has become not so much because he decided to, but because producers decided it for him. Traditionally, the Broadway angel lived in New York, and while there were always angels from other places, most of the money was found in Manhattan. There is still money in Manhattan; there will always be money in Manhattan, but even in Manhattan, money is no longer raised only in large amounts; it is raised in small amounts, too. The time of the small investor is upon us.

title: The Sphinx Called Doubleday
description: The top corporate officers don't cotton to prying. They dodge barbed questions posed by shareowners, of which there are so few that the company doesn't have to file any information with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Up until a few years ago, the president would merely chalk the financial results on a blackboard at the annual meeting. Now there is a skimpy annual report that goes only to its 300 stockholders. There is no corporate public relations department, mainly because the company shuns publicity about itself, and it usually succeeds in not getting any. It presumably sees no irony in billing itself as a communications company.

title: Mailbox: Is Scott's Success Ethical?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Loafers Who Wear Sneakers
description: That part of the national fitness phenomenon that takes place on foot has become a phenomenon of its own. Sales of certain kinds of athletic shoes, the evolutionary descendants of what everyone used to call sneakers, have now spread so far beyond running and jogging that they're displacing the loafer.

title: Under the Hood
description: IN preparation for Brain Surgeon, Lawrence Shainberg spent a year with a worldfamous chief of neurosurgery, accompanying his subject on rounds, observing his conferences with colleagues and listening in on often agonizing conversations between the doctor and his patients.

title: BEIBMID TEE BEST SELLERS
description: Many authors of best sellers have a bag full of horror stories that they like to trot. out gleefully whenever they are asked if they had any problems getting their books published. Dr. Lewis Thomas Lewis Thomas is not one of them. It was perfectly painless, he said, smiling, when asked if he had Suffered at all with his current best seller, The Medusa and the Snail. His editor at The Viking Press, Elisabeth Sifton, echoed: We encountered nothing but enthusiasm all the way.

title: Milton Kronheim's, Where the Justices Adjourn for Lunch
description: WASHINGTON  Two, sometimes three days a week, Judge David L. Hazelon of the United States Court of Appeals slips on his suit jacket about noon, takes the elevator down to the basement of the Federal Courthouse here and instructs his driver to head for Mr. K's. A colleague, Judge J. Skelly Wright, often joins Judge Bazelon as the dark blue Mercedes rolls out of the garage.

title: Continuing AvantGarde
description: KATONAH THERE was much brouhaha and ballyhoo in the 60's about the American avantgarde in the visual arts. Now that the noise has subsided and attention has turned in other directions, it is possible to take a saner look at those revolutionary years. The upshot is that the years were not so revolutionary and that many artists who were deified did not deserve a place on Olympus.

title: Film: Diane Kurys Peppermint Soda
description: The only thingmore impressive than the wit and talent Diane Kurys demonstrates in her writing and direction df Peppermint Soda  an expert, utterly charming movie that miraculously happens to be her first  is Miss Kurys's memory. Here is a letterperfect recollection of what it's like to be 13yearold, in this case a French schoolgirl, with skinny legs and a bossy sister and a mother who doesn't understand she may be ruining her daughter's life if she keeps on refusing to let the kid wear stockings.

title: Harmlessly, Skylab Goes Down and Out
description: Balladonia was always on the map, but few could say where. Last week, the tiny desert truck stop in Western Australia was swamped with hundreds of curiosity seekers after the last resting place of some shard of Skylab, the 77ton space station that descended  finally  in an arc of fire that crossed the Indian Ocean and the Australian continent. To the relief of probable majority of the earth's population, there has been no confirmed report of injury to persons or property.

title: I Never Thought of Myself as Sexy
description: ROME To be considered a sex symbol gratifies me, says Laura Antonelli, the longreigning Italian boxoffice queen who in 1979 has flashed across American movie screens with all the subtlety a Roman candle. When Till Marriage Do Us Part has its premiere at the Plaza Theater on Friday, will be the actress's fourth film to open in just seven months, and many ticketbuyers are queuing less for glimpses Miss Antonelli's innocent green velvet eyes and alabaster complexion than of her curvaceous  and liberally displayed  figure.

title: Hal Fales to Wed Lynn Matteson
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William B. Matteson of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Matteson of Northampton, Mass., to Hal Fales, son of Mr. and Mrs. Haliburton Fales of Gladstone, N.J., and New York.

title: GARDENING
description: Scarcely a generation ago, most gardening was of that type. Unless one had sufficient means to hire a gardener, one swung a hoe rather than a golf club or tennis racquet, if the garden was to be tended. Garden work came ahead of the beach or goofing off for most kids over the age of 10 during summer vacations. And evenings after work were often devoted to pushing a reeltype lawnmower through the crabgrass.

title: Piniella s Temper and Talent
description: ANAHEIM, CALIF. THE TEMPER probably has a better wonlost record against majorleague water coolers than any other temper attive in baseball today. It even has a water cooler from the hometeam dugout in the old Kansas City stadium as a trophy in the garage of the Tampa, Fla., home of the man who feeds and cares for The Temper.

title: Mary Shipley Wed on Coast
description: Mary Ann Shipley and Andrew McKay Wilcox were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Paul R. Woudenberg at the United Methodist Church of the Wayfarer in Carmel, Calif.

title: ANTIQUES
description: New England missionaries brought far more than the Christian religion to Hawaii 150 years ago. They came determined to erase all vestiges of what they viewed as heathen. And they succeeded, destroying in the process, part of the Hawaiian folk heritage.

title: Design
description: Frank Lloyd Wright called them inferior desecraters, one of the few printable aspersions an architect has ever cast an interior decorator's DECORATING WITH ARCHITECTURE way. In his day, Wright had a legitimate gripe: Architects then were the sole practitioners of serious modern design; decorators merely gussied things up, then gussied them up some more. Today, however, Wright's professional progeny has far less cause to sneer. In recent years, a hybrid has emerged, the interior designer, who addresses the problems of interior architecture and tackles decoration as well. Interior designers are serious modernists, as concerned with form, light and space as any architect. Yet they are schooled in the elements of decoration  color, texture, fabric and furniture  to an extent most architects are not. When I was in school, it was sufficient to know that a room needed a chair, says Daniel Goldner, the architect who renovated and furnished the Manhattan apartment shown on the preceding pages. But nobody ever suggested that the person sitting in that chair would probably be as affected by the upholstery fabric as he would by the view of the architecture.

title: U.S. Denies a Link With Sale to Saudis
description: WASHINGTON  As the United States, like other consuming countries, has become increasingly dependent on the good will of foreign oil producers, securing oil supplies has grown into a vital foreign policy objective.

title: Jane B. Mauk To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Mauk of Cin: cinnati have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jane. Brittain Mauk, to Peter Franklin Palmedo, son of Mrs. Roland. Palmedo Jr. of Plandome, L.I., and the late Mr. Palmedo.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: How to write a howto. Back in 1973, a time when the book world was still agog over the awardwinning Whole Earth Catalog, Christopher Cerf got what seemed to him a simple, practical idea. As a longtime behindthescenes worker on the television show Sesame Street, he wondered if there wasn't a place for a Whole Earth Catalog of things that interest children. He had no trouble selling the idea to Simon & Schuster, obtained a reasonable advance and set up a corporation called Lonesome Sparrow Press. He enlisted the aid of Elisabeth R. Scharlatt, who had worked at New York magazine's book division and who, as the mother of a young son, had a personal stake in the subject. With some hard work, they were convinced, they could do the book within a year.

title: Parental Duty: A Temperate Way
description: THERE has been much discussed and written in recent months regarding the merits and disadvantages of raising the legal age for drinking alcoholic beverages in Connecticut. Although the Legislature failed to modify the drinking age during this session, it will likely be brought up again, and there appears to be substantial public support in the state for such an increase.

title: STAMPS
description: NAIROBI, KENYA Stamp collectors in the United States, where philately is the ranking national hobby, may find it hard to believe that there are many parts of the world where collecting is nonexistent or minuscule, as is the writing of the letters that would require the use of stamps.

title: Poll on Refugees: Mixed Views
description: Americans have mingled feelings about the rising number of Indochinese refugees being admitted to the United States, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: As Clients Hunt Choice Antiques, Dealers Hunt Choice Quarters
description: Knowing nothing about real estate, subleases or square feet, Virginia Perry spent $9 several years ago on an antique Tudorstyle chair. In a short time she parlayed the profits from selling it and buying other antiques into nine rooms of old furniture, paintings, china and memorabilia.

title: A Turning Point For the L.I.E.  or Is It
description: AN age is coming to a close. As one who has taken the unholy pulse of the great Long Island highway these five long years, I can tell.

title: A Hot Director Breaks Away From the Mainstream
description: Over the past 17 years, Peter Yates has directed a dozen films. Some made money Bullitt, For Pete's Sake. Some didn't Murphy's War, Mother, Jugs, and Speed. In 1977, Mr. Yates's last film made money, and then some: The Deep brought in over $60 million.

title: MUSIC
description: NOSTALGIA will share the stage with fine music when the 21st season of chamber music at Silvermine begins tonight in New Canaan. For most of the year, the Silvermine Guild of Artists is concerned with exhibiting the work of its member sculptors, painters and graphic artists, but summertime is music time in the guild's Gifford Auditorium. This evening's program reunites two erstwhile Connecticut residents: violinist Paul Wolfe, a founding member of the Silvermine Festival in 1959 and now music director of the Florida Symphony, in Sarasota; and pianist Francisco Aybar, formerly of Weston, now a faculty musician at Denver University.

title: Deaths
description: LOOKSTEINRABBI JOSEPH H. The Sisterhood of Congregation Kehllath Jeshurun mourns the passing of our beloved Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein. He and his entire family his dear son, our Rabbi Heskel Lookstein, his adoring wife, Gertrude, and his beloved daughterinlaw, Audrey, who are both former presidents of the Sisterhood, and his cherished daughter, Naftali. Frledman, herself a member of the Sisterhooddevoted themselves tirelessly to the wellbeing of our entire Congregation. He shared our toys and we shared his. He shared our sorrows and now It Is our unhappy task to try to console his family as he and they have always tried to console us In times of tragedy. May they be comforted among all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Sisterhood Congregation Kehllath Jeshurun LOOKSTE INRabbi Joseph H. The Officers of the United Jewish AppealFederation of Jewish Philen. throples Joint Campaign are profoundly saddened at the passing of one of the great Jewish leaders of our time. Throughout his life, he expressed a deep Concern for the plight of oppressed Jews everywhere and was en eloquent spokesman, leader and supporter of our cause. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Gertrude and children Rabbi Haskel Lookstein and Mrs. Nathalie Friedman.

title: A Busy Day in the Energy Office
description: NEWARK THE office of Joel R. Jacobson was an island of serenity amid a sea of madly ringing telephones during the height of the gasoline chaos late last month  a chaos that many fear may come again in the waning days of this month.

title: Land Reform Efforts in Poor Nations Said to Falter
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  Land reform, a matter of intense international interest in the late 1940's, has almost entirely ceased in the densely populated thirdworld countries.

title: PoetPublisher Who Outgrew a Stable
description: NORFOLK JAMES LAUGHLIN, publisher of New Directions since 1936, has shunned the spotlight for most of his 64 years, although his close associates have included flamboyant characters such as Ezra Pound, Henry Miller, Dylan Thomas and Gregory Corso.

title: Northwestern Ontario Is Plagued By 120 Forest Fires in a Drought
description: THUNDER BAY, Ontario, July 14 (AP)  About. 120 forest fires are out of control through thousands of acres of timberland in droughtridden northwestern Ontario, the provincial government said today.

title: TV VIEW
description: Every once in a great while I feel obliged to come to the defense of television. If programs are selected with care, if the machine isn't allowed to hum on endlessly like some mindless monster, the medium can be valuable and, not infrequently, rewarding. Of course, 90 percent of the overall schedule may be garbage, but so is a high percentage, of the plays that men on Broadway each season. And so is an even higher percentage of the movies produced for theatrical release. But there is simply so much more of television. It has high visibility, easy accessibility. It makes a bigger target. On the other hand, however, television's lows, in terms of such intangibles as taste, do have their own special characteristics. In the frantic race to hustle the mass audience out of still another buck, the instinct of some producers for the vulgar and contemptuous seems boundless.

title: On Language Salt Sticks
description: Faced with the need to enliven a dreary subject, headline writers have sprinkled us with almost every possible play on SALT, the acronym for Strategic Arms Limitation Talks.

title: Beauty THAT SUMMER GLOW
description: If you have managed to find enough gas to get to the beach and remembered to use the requisite tanning lotions containing sunscreens, by now your skin should be golden and glorious, at least according to the beauty industry. For those who indeed are perfectly tanned and for those of us who hope to be soon, the beauty people offer some new tricks and words of advice for summer makeup.

title: Pop: Pair Of Differing Acts on Bill
