description: Putting the Pointer Sisters and Kenny Rankin together on the same concert program might, repeat might, have been a good idea back when the Pointers were doing a jazzinfluenced show with a lot of swing tempos and scat singing. But the group recently scored their first gold record with version of Bruce Springsteen's Fire, and the show they brought to the Dr. Pepper Central Park Music Festival Friday night concentrated on hard, danceable, guitardominated rockandroll. Mr. Rankin had to follow them with his soft acoustic popjazz, and at first he didn't seem to have a chance.

title: The Synthetic Solution: The Rub Is in the Cost
description: For almost a decade now Armand Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, has been telling just about anyone who would listen that America could satisfy its voracious appetite for petroleum by wringing it out of the stratified rock formations known as oil shale.

description: STAMFORD THE meeting of the Republican Town Committee here Tuesday night might have been expected to be a convivial gathering. The party is in power and its leaders have every reason to believe it is heading toward the November election as the heavy favorite.

description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Almost twothirds of the Democrats in the House of Representatives say that, as of now, they would support President Carter for another term, according to a survey by The New York Times.

It isn't likely that the 28,yearold Swedish grandmaster has become surfeited with the patient hoarding of minute endgame advantages; his whole career has been based on making mountains out of molehills, and the kind of quiet positional game that often bores his opponents delights hint

description: TOKYO, July 14  The infested areas are not too hard to avoid, a shipping executive said. All we have to do is to steer a bit further off the coast of Vietnam.

description: WASHINGTON  It's a department searching fora role, the old saw goes, a $10billionwear conglomerate that's a lot like Noah's Ark. The difference is that the Commerce Department has just one of everything.

title: This week. invite someone to dinner
description: 1. Place six of the eggs in a saucepan and add lukewarm water to cover. Bring to the boil and simmer 12 to 15 minutes: Drain the eggs and run them immediately under cold water. Drain once more. Peel the eggs and set aside.

title: Mark Gregory Gengras Marries Julia G. Parsons
description: In St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Old Saybrook, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Julia Geddes Parsons, daughter of Mrs. John W. Soper of Old Saybrook and Geddes Parsons of Roxbury, Conn., became the bride of Mark Gregory Gengras, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Clayton Gengras of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Calvin Gengras, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: We have recently seen much governmental backpedaling as laws and regulations passed in haste are revised thereafter to correct unnoticed flaws. The Connecticut General Assembly's modification of retirement legislation is such a case.

title: BRIDGE
description: The psychological insights needed to achieve success at rubber bridge are quite different from those needed in tournament play. In a major championship a player usually trusts his partner and allows for the possibility that his opponents, who are often unknown to him. have erred The converse was true for Michael Becker of New York on the diagramed deal played recently at New York's famed Cavendish Club, which has been home to many worldfamous players for almost half a century. Becker, who, like his famous father B. Jay Becker, has competed in the world championship, was sitting East and had a relatively inexperienced player as a partner.

title: Questions/Answers
description: We have two pyracantha bushes about eight years old. They always start the season looking great, but the flower buds dry up and most of the leaves turn brown. What causes this and is there a solution? Mrs. C.S. F., East Hampton, N. Y.

title: Mormon President Hospitalized
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 14 (AP) Spencer W. Kimball, president of the Mormon Church, was hospitalized today after experiencing dizziness, church officials said. Mr. Kimball. 84 years old, was admitted to L.D.S. Hospital for observation, they said. A statement said Mr. Kimball walked into the hospital shortly after returning here by commercial airliner from California, where he had been since Thursday on church business.

title: Strike by Pennsylvania's Dealers Arousing New Anger Over Gas
description: WAYNE, Pa., July 19  Two young men are the generals at the BP gasoline station at the corner of Eagle Road and Lancaster Avenue here, the only open station for miles around.

Wienslaw of Franklin Square, L.I., has been announced by Miss Marley's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest R. Marley Jr. of Townsend, Mass. The future bride was graduated last year from Endicott College. Her fianc is a student at Northeastern University.

title: ExArmy Officer's Trial Opening In 1970 Killings of Wife and Girls
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 19  The way Jeffrey R. MacDonald told his story to the press, the police and military investigators, the night of Feb. 17, 1970, was carbon copy of the murderous raid on the home of Sharon Tate in California by the Charles Manson group.

title: Around the Nation
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 19 (AP) Federal district judge has given officials of the Columbus Correctional Facility 10 days to integrate prisoners racially and stop shackling inmates to their beds.

title: Street Scenes That Tell Stories
description: BROOKVILLE IN an oil entitled Have You Heard They Crucified Our Lord by Frank Kleinholz  whose paintings are on view at the C. W. Post Art Gallery  a small, nude body is transfixed to a telephone pole. Flanking the pole are two apartment buildings, and in their windows we see the expressionless faces of people, mostly women. The panel is an arresting work with a strong dramatic impact.

title: DINING OUT
description: WE'VE been worrying a lot lately about the fuel we put in our gas tanks, but what about the fuel we put in our motorists? For those using the New Jersey Turnpike and Garden State Parkway, the shortage of honesttoGod food is as chronic as the shortage of gasoline, and the notion of 28 flavors of ice cream is as antiquated as gas for 78 cents a gallon.

title: A LifeSaving Mineral, Once Compulsory, Is Now Nearly Prohibited
description: WASHINGTONThe asbestos issue, like the tiny fibers that lodge in the human body, will not go away. And just as the fibers lie dormant for 20 to 30 years before their carcinogenic effects materialize, so the issue of what the Federal Government can or should do about it has been festering for decades.

title: Linda Sexton, John Freund Set Wedding
description: Linda Gray Sexton and John Gordon Freund, who graduated cum laude in 1975 from Radcliffe and Harvard Colleges, respectively, and were editors of The Harvard Crimson, plan to be married Aug. 19.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Today
description: National Hot Rod Association Summernational championships, at Madison (N.J.) Township Raceway Park. noon.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Resolution establishing within the executive branch of the Government the United States International Development Cooperation Agency, rejected, 51 to 45, July 9.

title: School Buses: A Problem Child
description: FIVE mornings every week between September and June, more than a halfmillion schoolchildren in New Jersey wave goodbye to parents or friends and board vehicles on which, statistics assert, an average of about one passenger a day will be injured in one of more than 500 traffic accidents.

title: Dibbs and Solomon Reach Final
description: Neither Eddie Dibbs nor Harold Solomon has ever won a $100,000 first prize in a tennis tournament. Dibbs had the chance in the World Championship Tennis yearend event in 1978 and lost to Vitas Gerulaitis, taking home $40,000 as the runnerup. Solomon's biggest payday was a $60,000 check for beating Ken Rosewall in Madison Square Garden.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Trisha Brown has been called a postmodern choreographic minimalist and that's a fearsomesounding thing for anyone to be called. The postmodern part of the appellation refers to the fact that she has allied herself with those choreographers who over the past two decades have rejected both the expressionist concerns of an earlier era of modern dance and the codified systems of dance technique developed by several of the moderndance pioneers. And because she disdains theatrical frills and prefers a nononsense kind of movement, she may be called a minimalist. Moreover, like certain minimalists in the other arts, she is fascinated by rigorous structural principles. So., she is, then postmodern and minimalist.

title: With the President Tuned Up, Nation Is Ready to Tune In
description: In one of those small coincidences that might seem less ironic in happier times, Jimmy Carter is coming down from the mountaintop to address the country tonight in airtime that was originally slotted by one national network for Moses the Lawgiver.

title: At Work They Are At Home
description: After 26 years at Lord & Taylor, a fashion buyer starts her own business selling designer clothing by mail order. The office: Her threeroom apartment in Murray Hill.

title: A SUMMER CATCH FOR THE KETTLE
description: If we were to name the 20 best dishes for summer dining, that list would surely include a fish soup or stew. Chances are, particularly it you live on or near coastal waters, the catch in Bouillabaisse is not the only French soup from the sea. Bourride, a cousin of that famed soup of Marseilles, does not include shellfish and it makes an excellent summer dish. your kettle  either purchased or through the largess of friends  will be fresher than at any other season of the year. One of our alltime favorite fish soup recipes, direct from our coastal kitchen in East Hampton, L. I., is listed here. It is called, in French, bourride. Unlike the famed bouillabaisse of Marseilles and environs, it does not contain shellfish. Another distinctive feature is its use of Won, a Mediterranean speciality and a sort of garlic mayonnaise. Part of this abli is stirred into the soup, the remainder is served on the side to be added at will.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: OAKVILLE, Calif.  It was just a simple lunch that Bob Mondavi had arranged at his winery here; a little salad, some cold chicken  and 36 wines. A stranger, wandering out on the terrace and encountering the vast array of bottles and glassware would have been astonished, but not anyone who knows Robert Mondavi. He is not one for half measures.

title: Priscilla C. Collins Bride of Professor
description: Priscilla Catherine Collins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Collins of Roslyn Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Kevin Robert O'Hara, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. O'Hara of Westbury, L.I. The ceremony was performed in Trinity Episcopal Church in Roslyn, L.I., by the Rev. Nils Blatz.

title: Women's Caucus Drafts Strategy for 1980 Election
description: CINCINNATI, July 14  The political activists pulled their chairs into a circle and took up the topic of the evening how to become delegates to the Presidential nominating conventions next year. One speaker warned that aspiring delegates had to start early because the maneuvering begins long before the precinct meetings are held.

title: CAREY SIGNS A BILL TO LET PUBLIC SEE TESTS FOR COLLEGE
description: Calling standardized admissions tests imprecise and open to potential misinterpretation and misuse, Governor Carey announced yesterday that he had signed a bill requiring the services that administer the tests for colleges and graduate schools to open their examinations to public scrutiny for the first time.

title: ANTIQUES
description: COVENTRY WHAT once was a fringe benefit for those attending antiques shows  the opportunity to examine the wares of dealers whose shops are in distant states  now, in this gasscarce summer, has become a major asset. Exhibitors taking part in the ninth annual Nathan Hale Antiques Festival next Saturday represent shops as far north as Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont, as far south as Virginia and Florida, as well as the other New England states, New York and Pennsylvania.

title: Headliners
description: There are easier ways of making a buck than suing Richard Nixon. Morton Halperin should know. In 1969, Mr. Halperin, then a Presidential national security aide, was one of 17 Govt enunent employees and news reporters wiretapped without warrant on Mr. Nixon's authority in an effort to stop information leaks. When Mr. Halperin found out about it, he sued Mr. Nixon on many grounds, among them violation of his Fourth Amendment right to be secure against improper searches, and was awarded $1. But his suit under the 1968 law limiting warrantless wiretaps to national security matters was thrown out on the ground that the President was immune to civil damage suits. Last week, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia disagreed, holding that the President is the elected chief executive of our Government, not an omnis dent leader cloaked in mystical powers, and ruled that Mr. Halperin could sue Mr. Nixon again.

title: Fuel for Thought
description: I enjoyed Russell Baker's article on Dumbness Loves Company (Sunday Observer, June 17), especially his jab at Washington for spending millions to build highways at the same time [it is] reducing gasoline allocations to keep cars from using them.

title: The FastFood Chains Get Indigestion
description: The Jack in the Box restaurant on a busy intersection in the South Bronx is open round the cloe.k. Despite other fastfood restaurants nearby, a steady stream of customers pull up to the drivethrough window for Jumbo Jack burgers and tacos and fill the restaurant's 15 orangeandblack tables at all hours of the day and night. We're doing super, said the <restaurant manager, Mirza Ash.

description: Today  National Hot Rod Association Summemationals, at Madison Township Raceway Park, Pension Road, Englishtovm, N.J. Gates open 7 A.M.; time trials 9; final eliminations at noon.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Anew form of cruel and unusual punishment has been invented; architects are writing as much they are building, and those of us who report on their activities are forced to struggle through masses of pretentious and glutinous prose, seeking the flash of insight, the buried diamond of revelation, the key to the architectural revolution that is rumored to be process now.

title: When Chicago Is in Trouble, It Goes Into a Dance
description: GLEN COVE AN effete and sinister emcee much like the one in Cabaret  welcomes us to a story of murder, greed, corruption, violence, exploitation, adultery and treachery  all those things we all hold near and dear to our hearts.

description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, hoping to attract more heavy industry to the metropolitan area, has selected six potential sites to clear and develop into urban industrial parks.

title: The Sport of Sky Gods
description: CLIMBING to an altitude of 7,200 feet, the Cessna aircraft flew between mountainlike formations of cumulus clouds. Andy Treffs checked his altimeter, adjusted his goggles and put on his helmet. He was about to in dulge in his passion, rw., or relative work  a skydiving term for freeflight jumping in which sky divers join together in formations, such as stars or circles. Sky divers call it getting together with your friends.

title: Senate Raises the Curtain on SALT
description: On the relatively riendly turf of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, the Administration wheeled out its big guns last week, opening debate on the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty. The United States, they testified, would be safer with it than without it.

title: P.L.O. Officials Join Bid to End Siege in Ankara
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sunday, July 15 A delegation from the Palestine Liberation Organization joined Turkish officials yesterday in efforts to help negotiate a settlement with four Palestinians holding about a dozen hostages in the Egyptian Embassy here.

title: Deaths
description: LOOKSTEINRABBI JOSEPH H. The Sisterhood of Congregation Kehllath Jeshurun mourns the passing of our beloved Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein. He and his entire family his dear son, our Rabbi Heskel Lookstein, his adoring wife, Gertrude, and his beloved daughterinlaw, Audrey, who are both former presidents of the Sisterhood, and his cherished daughter, Naftali. Frledman, herself a member of the Sisterhooddevoted themselves tirelessly to the wellbeing of our entire Congregation. He shared our toys and we shared his. He shared our sorrows and now It Is our unhappy task to try to console his family as he and they have always tried to console us In times of tragedy. May they be comforted among all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Sisterhood Congregation Kehllath Jeshurun LOOKSTE INRabbi Joseph H. The Officers of the United Jewish AppealFederation of Jewish Philen. throples Joint Campaign are profoundly saddened at the passing of one of the great Jewish leaders of our time. Throughout his life, he expressed a deep Concern for the plight of oppressed Jews everywhere and was en eloquent spokesman, leader and supporter of our cause. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Gertrude and children Rabbi Haskel Lookstein and Mrs. Nathalie Friedman.

title: Oil on Troubled Waters
description: Fellow calls up and orders world. We make him one. That's our business. Universal World Builders Inc. We build a world faster than you can get radio emissions from a black hole.

title: NICARAGUAN JUNTA SELECTS ITS CABINET
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 14 Nicaragua's rebelbacked provisional junta formed an 18member cabinet today made up mainly of businessmen and technocrats. The list includes only one guerrilla leader directly involved in the fight to overthrow President Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: Boston Tourists Escape Blast
description: BOSTON, July 14 (UPI)  An undergound electrical transformer in the city's Fanueil Marketplace exploded last night and the police said it was a miracle that none of the weekend tourists roaming through the area were injured.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: SPELL NO. 7 Ntozake Shange's choreopoem, directed by Oz Scott. Public / Anspacher, 425 Lafayette SI. (6774350) Opens today.

title: THE STRUGGLE TO RALLY BLACK AMERICA
description: n a muggy evening in June 1971, 2,800 people filled the grand ballroom of the Sheraton Park Hotel in Washington, D.C., for the first annual dinner of the Congressional Black Caucus. Like pilgrims making their way to Mecca, they had come from the big cities and boroughs, from small towns and the backwoods, to pay homage  at S100 a plate  to the advances black Americans had made during the 1960's, and to celebrate the even greater gains they expected to make in the 70's. It was a festive, family affair for beauticians from Memphis, farmers from South Carolina, barbers from Boston, county commissioners from Georgia, state legislators from Illinois, mayors from East St. Louis, Ill., and Gary, Ind., and, the prize of them all, a United States Senator from Massachusetts. And the beaming beneficiaries of the civilrights decade jumped to their feet to cheer and whistle when Ossie Davis, the actor and featured speaker, proclaimed, It's not the man, it's the plan; it's not the rap, it's the map.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The Carter Administration finally acknowledged last week in its midyear economic and budget review that the nation was in the grip of an economic recession, something that private analysts had been saying for weeks.

title: ART VIEW
description: Modernist sculpture is, more often than not, sculpture created for the art museum, or for museumlike sltaations. Which is to say that its intended destination is a special environment an environment consecrated to esthetic experience. Within the boundaries of this environment, our exoectations are altered, our attention is heightened, our minds open and alert to esthetic possibility. We come to the museum, or to museumlike situations, on the qui vive for art. What we see there may disappoint us, of course, for it may not live up to what at that particular moment in our experience we expect art to be. But even if it does disappoint, it disappoints us as art, not as something else. For in the museum environment there is nothing else.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE THIRTIES AND AFTER, by Stephen Spender. (Vintage, $4.95.) A leading English poet and man of letters offers a selection of his previously uncollected essays, reviews and reminiscences, interspersing them with new background pieces so that they form a kind of stereoscopic history of himself and his contemporaries over the past four decades.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: In recent years the stately churches of England sometimes seem to have been filled with as many people kneeling to make brass rubbings as to pray. Wherever the memorials are imbedded in the floors, there is almost sure to be cluster of people hunched over the papershrouded images, sawing back and forth with a piece of charcoal or graphite until the form appears  often a lifesized figure of the deceased.

title: Lurie to Succeed Byrne As Fordham Track Coach
description: Fordham University, whose track and field stature has suffered in recent years, has dismissed Torn Byrne, the track and crosscountry coach. Steve Lurie was named his successor and will also coach Fordham women in those sports.

title: James Mavrogordato Weds Helen Stetson Kathryn Dorothy Kavazanjian Bride of Daniel Leonard
description: Helen Currie Stetson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Winslow Stetson Jr. of Barrington, Ill., and James Michael Mavrogordato, son of Mrs. Ricardo M. Mavrogordato of Rio de Janeiro and the late Mr. Mavrogordato, were married in Duxbury, Mass., yesterday. The Rev. Lewis H. Mills performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Riding in the Middle on the 5:45
description: IDON'T know what Paula Marie McGlynn, who described herself as an administrative assistant for an account that just happens to be a railroad in Riding Up Front on the 8:11 [Opinion Page, July 1], got from riding recently with the engineer in a Long Island Rail Road diesel cab. Better understanding, she said.

title: Sandra Stewart Wed at Stanford
description: At the Stanford Memorial Church on the Stanford University campus in Palo Alto, Calif., yesterday, Sandra Jean Stewart, daughter of Mrs. H. Christian Zweng and Ray Simpson Stewart of Atherton, Calif., was married to John Hollister Stevenson, ton of Anne Hollister Stevenson of New York and J.J. Stevenson Jr. of Cincinnati. The Rev. Robert McAfee Brown, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: IN THE YEAR 2004, Westchester may have two gold coasts of highrise luxury apartments, running west along Long Island Sound from Mamaroneck and Rye and on the Hudson River north from Yonkers.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmoeoheric Administration /UPI

title: Late Traces of Hope for the Refugees
description: Thousands of refugees might laugh bitterly at the words, but some progress has been made in coping with the flow of suffering that has been streaming out of Indochina.

title: Who Am I?
description: ADOPTION is old in human experience  so old that it is entrenched in our mythic heritage. Moses and Oedipus, Betty Jean Litton tells us, were the forefathers of today's adopted children. But LOST AND FOUND The Adoption Experience. By Betty Jean Lifton. 303 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $9.95. in this book, which is a study of everyone concerned with the adoption experience from the children to the caseworkers and is replete with case histories, it Oedipus who casts the longer shadow. We do not know if Moses ever asked, Who am I? We do know what happened when Oedipus asked the question, and what were the consequences of his not knowinguntil it was too late. By that time he had committed murder and incest, and put out his eyes.

title: SHOP TALK East Hampton's Way
description: EAST HAMPTON WHEN you shop in East Hampton, you'll find yourself strolling in a village where the majority of the stores reflect the needs and interests of the local residents, rather than those of the New York City people who inhabit the area during the summer.

title: Ellsberg Fined for Trespassing
description: DENVER, July 19 (AP)  Daniel Ellsberg was fined $1,000 yesterday for trespassing at a protest April 29 at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant.

title: ULSTER, BLOODY ULSTER
description: In the decade since British troops moved into Londonderry to put down an outburst violence, fighting among British, Protestants and Catholics has claimed nearly 2,000 lives.

title: Miss Fitzgibbon, A.G. Watson Wed
description: Margaret Mary Fitz,gib'bon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Joseph Fitzgibbon of Ridgewood, NJ., was married there yesterday to Andrew Graham Watson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Nelson Watson of Columbus, Ohio, formerly of Brouxville, N.Y. The Rev. Vincent J. Quinn performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Our Lady of Mount Cannel Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Latest Mozart Releases
description: Mostly Mozart opens tomorrow night at Avery Fisher Hall, adequate enough reason to take stock of the latest Mozart recordings. Four areas of the composer's output have been especially enriched with new disks: vocal music, the lighter orchestral works, chamber music and the concertos. In the latter category, Murray Perahia offers his third record devoted to Mozart's piano concertos, this one containing No. 20 in D minor and No. 11 in F (Columbia M 35134). The limpid tonal beauty of Mr. Perahia's bejewelled pianism is exquisite and he uncovers some ravishing details in both works. Some might feel that his poetic approach neglects the more tragic undercurrents of the D minor Concerto, a quality that does not escape Eugene List in his new version of that work coupled with No. 26 in D (Turnabout TVS 34747)  a wellplayed if rather bluntedged pair of performances.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE A Slide in Mortgage Rates
description: The economy, even the Carter Administrationnow Concedes, has softened, and now there are signs that the interest rates on home mortgages are beginning to ease along with it. The question is how. far down they'll go; the answer seems to be not very far.

title: Lawyerless At the Closing
description: WE finally moved into our new house  although searching through boxes for everything we needed did not make it feel Quite like home yet. The last month had been extremely hectic with engineer reports, contracts and the closing. And there had also been a slightly uneasy feeling, since we decided to do it all without hiring a lawyer.

title: Tricks of the Trade Materialize at Magicians Convention in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, July' 13  I think I'm being taken, said the physician to the lawyer as they watched a demonstration of the latest in tools of deception and suspension of disbelief mastic.

title: W.E. Brown Weds Patricia Rae Gibson
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington, Conn., yesterday, Patricia Rae Gibson, daughter of Henry vanDyke Gibson of Washington and the late Barbara Housh Gibson, was married to Walter Emerson Brown, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Emerson Brown of Hackensack, N.J. The Rev. Haig Nargesian, assisted by the Rev. Charles Fisher, performed the ceremony.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Magazine photography is the mural painting of modern times. Or it was during the great days of Life magazine, whose first 10 years are the subject of an outstanding exhibition of photographs at New York University's Grey Art Gallery, 33 Washington Place at Washington Square East, through Aug. 3. Selected by Doris O'Neil, director of vintage prints at Time Inc., and Robert R. Littman, director of the gallery, Life: the First Decade includes 200 pictures from the years 1936 to 1995, most of which were published in Life, though some are variants of pictures actually published.

title: South African Trains Collide
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 19 (AP)Two passenger trains collided at a railroad crossing north of Johannesburg today, injuring 30 persons, a spokesman for South African Railways said. It was not immediately known whether any of the passengers had been seriously injured in the collision, at the town of Kaalfontein, 20 miles north of here.

title: Realty News
description: The American Institute of Aeronautics is moving its technical information services offices from 750 Third Avenue to 555 West 57th Street.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: Size: To four inches.

title: Schmidt to Pay Visit to U.S.
description: BONN, July 14 (Reuters) Chancellor Helmut Schmidt will travel to the United States next Thursday for a fourday private visit, a Government spokesman said today. Mr. Schmidt and his wife will stay near San Francisco with former Treasury Secretary George Schultz.

title: ART In Stride With the Horse Through History
description: THE Horse in History, Mythology and Art, a show at the Hammond Museum, is large and engrossing and contains pieces of distinction. Just the same, it doesn't exactly live up to its title. To make matters worse, it is pretentiously billed as a crosscultural, interdisciplinary exhibition that traces the horse as it appears over a span of 3,000 years.

title: EllenMarie Flach Wed to Accountant
description: EllenMarie Finch, daughter of Ellen Finley Flach of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Robert Flach of Fort Lee, N.J., was married in Wyckoff, N.J., yesterday to William James Prendergast, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Prendergast of Wyckoff. The Rev. Claude Lenehan performed the ceremony in St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The John Work Garrett Collection  one of the most important in all of numismatics has been consigned for sale at a series of public auctions. Johns Hopkins University of Haitimore, Md., owner of the storied collection, and Bowers & Ruddy Galleries Inc., of Los Angeles, announced jointly today that the California firm will sell the coins at unreserved auctions starting late this year. The venture is described by Bowers & Ruddy officials as the sale of the century.

title: INVESTING
description: Not all the world's smart money ends up in Switzerland. Some of it, lately, has been drifting over the Alps into neighboring Austria. And because of recent changes in Austria's banking laws, Vienna is beginning to challenge Zurich as a safe harbor for the capital of the taxwary or the inflationweary investor.

title: The Treasury Secretary Is Not Very Popular, but He Is Often Right
description: WASHINGTON  It was a balmy Friday in early June when the 50word memo was distributed without fanfare in the White House press room. What said had been said before, but never quite so explicitly: The Secretary of the Treasury is the Administration's chief economic spokesman. And, it continued, the economic policy steering group that he headed was in charge of economic nolicvmakine.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH rollers and padtype paint applicators are widely used for large, flat surfaces, the brush is still the basic tool for most outside painting jobs  especially for use on trim, shutters, doors and similar surfaces where careful control and neat cuttingin around the edges are reouired.

title: Schmidt Hits No. 31 In Phils 107 Victory
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) Bake McBride's threerun homer and a tworun shot by Mike Schmidt, his 31st of the season and eighth in 13 games, triggered the Philadelphia Phillies to a 107 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

title: DEPTHS OFF ECUADOR YIELD CLUES TO LIFE
description: ABOARD. THE GLOMAR CHALLENGER, off Ecuador, July 14  Researchers on this ship bored far below the muddy sea floor of the Pacific this week to sample the record left by a seemingly limitless variety of life over millions of years.

title: Schnitzlees Vienna As Told to Stoppard
description: LONDON In its search for plays to fill the monumental Olivier stage, Britain's National Theater has turned its sights towards Middle Europe. Several seasons ago the National rediscovered Odon von Horvath and Tales From the Vienna Woods, an epic about Austria before World War II, in a new adaptation by Christopher Hampton. This season the National has pushed the clock back to preWorld War I Vienna, with a production of Arthur Schnitzler's Undiscovered Country ('Das Weite Land'), in a new version by Tom Stoppard, which opened June 20. If anything, the StoppardSchnitzler hyphenate is an even more fruitful crosscentury collaboration than HamptonHorvath.

title: IN THE NATION Jimmy Carter's Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  In the crisis of his Presidency, it is not hard to detect that Jimmy Carter is reaching back to the high points of his brief career in national politics  his successful 1976 Presidential campaign and his Middle East summit triumph at Camp David in 1978.

title: AutoLiability Rates And Death Payments To Rise in New York
description: The cost of compulsory automobileliability insurance in New York State will increase by up to $11 in December, and, under such insurance, maximum benefits for a death in an accident because of negligence will rise from $10,000 to $50,000 as the result of legislation Governor Carey signed into law Friday.

title: Lynnette Buchanan Bride of James Bennett
description: Lynette Margaret Buchanan and James Huntting Bennett were married yesterday at the United Methodist Church in Summit, NJ., by the Rev. J. Paul Griffith.

title: Somoza, Junta Still Balk Over Deal
description: The United States made small progress last week in persuading Nicaragua's guerrillas to make a deal to clinch President Anastasio Somoza Debayle's departure. But for most Nicaraguans, the game was Beat the Clock and they were losing. The Nicaraguan Red Cross estimated that 20,000 people had been killed in six weeks of fighting between the Sandhiists and General Somoza's National Guard. More than 600,000 people are homeless, many close to starvation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Darby Creek Road, with Angel. Cordero Jr. up, took the lead soon after the'start and won the $57,200 Sword Dancer Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. It was Cordero's fourth victory of the day.

title: Alzado Finds a Tarkenton in Ali
description: DENVER, July 14  When the recently retired heavyweight champion of the world stepped into the ring here today, the familiar chant of Ali, Ali, Ali Went up.

title: The Turning Point?; Mighty Decisions Loom for Carter and Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Nine months ago, President Carter came down from the notsoheady elevation of Maryland's Catoctin Mountains bearing a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt. For 12 days he had wrestled unseen with the forces of war and history, and had won. His standing in opinion polls rose, as did spirits in the White House.

title: Garden Teamwork Makes the Difference
description: It takes two to garden, at least the way Mary Ann and Frederick McGourty view it. To them gardening is an adventurous partnership. To visitors, their teamwork is an apparent formula for success.

title: WEEKEND MOTORISTS FIND GAS PLENTIFUL
description: Yesterday was the best Saturday in months for motorists who sought gasoline in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, with supplies plentiful and virtually no lines at filling stations.

title: Details
description: ABRAHAMSSimcn P., M.D., age 59, July 2, 1979, in La Jolla, Calif., born Hartford, CT, ES from CCNY, MS from NYU, M.D. from Middlesex University School of Medicine, Waltham, Mass.;M.P.H. from University of Minnesota, advanced studies In Radiological Health, University of Michigan, 26 years with the U.S.P.H.S. rising to the rank of Medical Director, worked in area of Preventive Medicine and Epidemiology with special reference to TB and Radiological Health, served in Mexico, Puerto Rico and Colorado as Consultant in TB control, served as Director of Special Studies Branch of Radiological /Research Section of U.S.P.H.S., during his tenure there he served as consultant to the Hiroshima Protect of the Atomic Energy Commission and Radiological Monitoring Stations In the U.S., served as Secretary of several Grant In Aid Study Sections of N.I.H., contributed to the literature 9n Radiological Health and Preventive Medicine, survived by wife, Rosalie Abrahams of Rancho Bernardo, Calif., brother. Joseph Abrahams, M.D., of La Jolla, Calif., and sister, Rhoda Sctsoertaum of Hicksville,NY.

title: Police Canvass Bushwick Area in Search for Clues in Slaying of Galante
description: City detectives canvassed Brooklyn's Bushwick section yesterday for clues to the identity of the gunmen who killed Carmine Galante, the reputed underworld leader, and two other men in a barrage of gunfire and shotgun blasts in the backyard patio of a restaurant Thursday.

title: Did You Hear the One About...
description: HY is everyone around me laughing? What is so funny? As more spacecraft are shot into space, others are crashing down; as plans for hydrogen bombs have become public domain, Three Mile Island incidents occur; as World Trade Centers are built, awardwinning auditoriums collapse.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Maybe nobody cares, but I find mapmakers guilty of a great disservice to motorists: I refer to their failure to include the year in which the maps and atlases are published. This is a crime.

title: Karla Harrison Evans Engaged
description: An Aug. 25 wedding is planned by Karla Harrison Evans and Charles Augustus Griswold. Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin C. Evans Jr. of Washington and Middleburg, Va., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Griswold of Greenwich and Old Lyme, Conn. Miss Evans, who graduated from the National Cathedral School, is a senior at Connecticut College; Her fianc, a graduate of the Pomfret School and Connecticut, is with the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection in Hartford.

title: Death of Man in Custody Studied
description: A Yonkers man died of unknown causes while in custody at the 46th Precinct station house in the Bronx early yesterday morning, according to officials.

title: Miss Massey Takes Open Lead
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 14 Debbie Massey missed six greens today, but she saved par each time as she scrambled into a threestroke lead after three rounds of the 34th United States Women's Open golf championship with a oneunderpar total of 212.

title: ork Work Work Work W
description: My father, who is 70 years old, commutes 70 miles daily to earn $70. I write pseudonymously about this fact of these three 70's not because I am embarrassed, but because my father is proud  and gratefid  to be working. He looked long and hard to get the job he has, and I should not like to jeopardize it now. Still, I would like to tell a bit of his story, which I suspect is not atypical. So let us now praise him and all those like him.

title: Indonesia Will Admit Refugees Temporarily
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 14  Although Indonesia has officially closed its borders to Vietnamese refugees, it will not tow boats that do arrive back out to sea, according to officials here.

title: SeldomHeard Show Tunes Revisited
description: It has been slim pickings for followers of the musical theater in recent years when, with the notable exception of the work of Stephen Sondheim, there have been scarcely any new scores that have made noteworthy additions to the Broadway theater's musical memorabilia. So it's no wonder that singers and record producers with an interest in the musical theater are looking to the past for material for recordings, looking to the composers of the 1920's, 30's, 40's and 50's.

title: HOME CLINIC Correct Brushwork Helps Assure a Good Paint Job
description: ALTHOUGH rollers and padtype paint applicators are widely used for large, flat surfaces, the brush is still the basic tool for most outside painting jobs especially for use on trim, shutters, doors and similar surfaces where careful control and neat cuttingin around the edges are required.

title: U.N. Panel Condemns Settlements by Israel; Urges Council Action
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 19 A United Nations commission has recommended to the Security Council that it call on Israel to cease the establishment, construction and planning of settlements in Arab territories occupied in the 1967 war.

title: Drivers Walkout Delays A Times Sunday Edition
description: A walkout by drivers last evening at The New York Times delayed the delivery of the first edition of the Sunday paper for more than two hours.

title: Angela Wheelock Becomes Fiancee Of Stephen Zavell
description: Capt. James Seton Gray, U.S.N., to. tired, and Mrs. Gray of Washington and Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gray's daughter, Angela MariaTeresa Wheelock. to Stephen Zavell. son of Stephanie tartvniiht Zavell of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Arnold S. Zavell of WilkesBarre, Pa. Plans have been made for Sept. 8 wedding in Washington.

title: Rep. Hansen Seized in Speeding
description: AMERICAN FALLS, Idaho, July 14 (UPI)  United States Representative George Hansen, Republican of Idaho, faces a possible fine of $37 for driving 79 miles an hour:He was ticketed July 2. He has until Thursday to appear in Power County Magistrate Court and enter plea. The fine is $37 plus $10 court costs.

title: Threat to Coast Seen in New Rule
description: WASHINGTON A TOP New Jersey environmental official has criticized a new Federal energy rule that, he argued, took away the state's right to protect its coastline and to decide where oil pipelines might be laid offshore.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: HOMOSEXUALITY IN PERSPECTIVE By William H. Masters and Virginia E. Johnson. 450 pp. Boston: Little. Brown &; Co. $17.50.

title: Prague Said to Plan Trial of 10 Leading Dissidents on Subversion Charge
description: VIENNA, July 10  Czechoslovak authorities have detained 10 leading members of the Charter 77 humanrights group and Are reported to be planning a major trial designed to destroy the movement's operations, according to leading dissident sources in Prague and Vienna.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  The Boy Friend. Wednesday to Saturday 8:30 P.M., Sundays P.M. Through July 29. $5.50 to $7.50. Discount available for students, the elderly and groups. Reservations. Country Cabaret, with entertainment and crepe kitchen Fridays and Saturdays after show. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, junction of Routes 6 and 118. 6281169.

title: jets Forming Their New Pincers
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 14  First came the Bookends. And now the Jets have the Pincers. The latest double threat  the No.1 draft choice, Marty Lyons of Alabama, and No. 2, Mark Gastineau of East Central OklahOma  are slotted as ends on opposites sides of the defensive line.

title: Births
description: Richard and Carol (nee Simon) loyfully welcome to the world Pam, born July 6, 1979.

title: LETTER TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Although the gasoline lines in Westchester and the rest of the nation may not be as long now, this is the time to take strong and decisive action to cornbat the energy crisis.

title: Mets Beat Giants for 5th in Row
description: Some of the 69 Mets seems to be rubbing off on the 79 Mets. Whether inspired by the sight of the former World Series champions yesterday at Shea Stadium or whether, as Manager Joe Torre said, We're on our way back, the present Mets won their fifth straight game, a 32 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: DINING OUT
description: BROOKFIELD THE human element provides an important but often capricious influence on a restaurant's preparation and serving of food to the public.

title: How to Get to Courses
description: All thirteen New York City Municipal golf courses are accessible by public transportation.

title: Hundreds Hold Rally At the U.N. in Search Of Help for Refugees
description: Several hundred Chinese, Vietnamese and their supporters demonstrated at the United Nations yesterday to promote help for the boat people and to protest Vietnam's treatment of its ethnic Chinese minority.

title: Pro Football's Joh' Dutton Case
description: As the training camps open, the National Football League's most important player is in litigation instead of in uniform. At a muscular 6feet7Inches and 266 pounds, John Dutton is big enough to be two men. And the former Baltimore Colt defensive end has an opportunity to do for pro football players what two men.

title: TopicsPictorial License
description: President Carter sounded like many other parents when he complained the other day that only motion pictures made in the 1950's were suitable for his 11yearold daughter Amy. To some, the President's concern may seem to reflect pious, smalltown rigor, but such sneers are unwarranted. It is a hatd commercial fact that films made for an unrestricted audience earn a G rating, which has come to be regarded as boxoffice poison. Adult audiences will stay away in droves from movies thus labeled as kid stuff. Hence producers will deliberately add a touch of profanity or a flash of flesh to obtain the more desirable PG rating in which parental guidance is suggested.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The leadership displayed by the United States Government in dealing with the cutoff of the natural rubber supply after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941 is an excellent model for the present energy crisis. At that time, when it became apparent that this country had lost a vital raw material source, the Government moved decisively to replace the natural rubber supplies from the Far East with synthetic rubber made in the United States. Given the present squeeze on oil and gas supplies, the Federal Government needs to undertake a similar campaign to develop alternate fuel sources.

title: Brown Riding High Among Drag Racers
description: No one has won the National Hot Rod Association's top fuel seasonlong championship more than once, and that fact has prompted drag racers to say there is a jinx attached to the title.

title: National Chains Put More Hotels In the Region
description: A few weeks ago, a Manhattan jury was bused to a hotel to be sequestered until it reached its verdict. Nothing so unusual, but for the fact that the hotel was in Red Bank, N.J.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: In the days before airconditioning, when people tried to beat the heat with humor, they used to show newsreels of New Yorkers frying eggs on the sizzling sidewalks.

title: Traditional Party Divisions Over the Economy, Defense and World Affairs Have Healed
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. I The Republican Party has seven Presidential candidates, a party treasury that makes the Democrats envious and a clear idea of where it is going organizationally. Now it even has a lightbulb ioke.

title: Smith and Teacher Gain Hall of Fame Tennis Final
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 14 (AP) Stan Smith, seeded third, had little trouble beating sixthseeded Hank Pfister, 61, 64, today in one semifinal match of the $100,000 Miller Hall of Fame tennis tournament.

title: Engagements
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Muhlrad of Westbury, N.Y. announce the engagement of their daughter, Arlene Beth, to Mr. Howard E.Mayo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Mayo of Baldwin, N.Y.

title: Pope Warns on Utopia
description: ROME, July 19  Pope John Paul told delegates from 150 nations discussing agrarian reform today that it was utopian to expect rapid industrialization to solve an underdeveloped nation's problems.

title: Gulag in the Mind of a Dog
description: GEORGI VLADIMOV is a Soviet writer who remains virtually unpublished in his own country. Until this novel appeared in an migr magazine in Germany in 1975, he had done virtually all his writing for the desk drawer, as the Russians say. To write without an audience must surely be a FAITHFUL HUSLIIN By Georgi Vladimov. Translated by Michael Glenny. 220 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $9.95. writer's idea of hell, yet generations of Soviet writers have drawn a kind of strength from it. This hell has bred a tradition of fierce humanism and hard selfreliance, which treats the act of writing not only as an act of moral survival but also as a form of testimony. The deskdrawer writer writes with his life, as Mr. Vladimov made clear two years ago in his scathing letter of resignation to the Soviet Writers Union. Faithful Ruslan is the story of a guard dog at a Siberian prison camp. It begins in that ambiguous dawn of the mid1950's, when, on Nikita Khrushchev's order, the camps were being emptied of their countless thousands of prisoners. The book opens in the silence of the empty camp, the prisoners gone, the gates swung ominously open. Ruslan is bewildered, afraid he has stopped understanding, which is dogtalk for a senile spooking of the mind, leading inexorably to a bullet in the head. For the camp code is all that Ruslan has ever known, having been trained for it by the ingenious cruelty of his masters. To him, the prisoners are shabby, halfstarved creatures, capable of unspeakable betrayal. The masters, with their godlike eyes and automatic rifles, punish unerringly, but also caress and give food. From them Ruslan has learned the bliss of obedience. He knows that to obey is to belong to the gods, whom he loves.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: IS HEMLOCK BEING SLOWLY POISONED?; Are the people around this tiny Michigan town the unknowing victims of industrial pollution?
description: That something might possibly be askew in the old German farming community of Hemlock, a small Michigan town just southwest of Saginaw Bay, first occurred to Carol Jean Kruger. She lived on one of the area's largest dairy farms in a region of flatlands known for its cider mills and its bluegrass. In 1974, things kind of started, she says. But it took until 1977 for me to put it together. When we did, we could go back to 1969 and see the problem.

title: Joseph H. Lookstein Dead at 76; A Rabbi and Orthodox Educator
description: Rabbi Joseph Hyman Lookstein, a Jewish educator long prominent in Orthodox Judaism and rabbi at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun on the Upper East Side for half of Its more than 100 years, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 76 years old.

title: Gas Dealers Seek Guaranteed Profits
description: WASHINGTON AGROUP of New Jersey gasoline dealers, saying they could be put out of business by the predatory pricing of outlets owned by oil companies, said last week that the Federal Government should guarantee them a minimum profit.

title: U.S. Keeping Up Pressure on the Nicaraguan Junta
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 14  On Friday, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, one of the five members of the Nicaraguan revolutionary junta, said at news conference that the mediation effort of William G. Bowdler of the United States was completely finished. Hours later.

title: RideSharing: Cheaper by the Carload
description: IT'S been goodbye to rugged individualism as many Westchester residents have turned to car pools, van pools and other forms of shared transportation during the gas crunch and have found that the advantages more often outweigh the inconveniences.

title: Costa Rica Has Good Reason to Give Sanctuary To Sandinists
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica  In a parting shot last week a nettlesome neighbor, Anastasio Somoza Debayle said the Nicaraguan people will never forget the treason of their Costa Rican friends against their Nicaraguan brothers.

title: Stephen Goldsmith Weds Martha York
description: Martha H. York, widow of Charles York, and Stephen Price Goldsmith were married yesterday at Evergreen Valley, a resort in EastStoneham, Me. Justice of the Peace Salley B. Ruggles of Portland, Me., performed the ceremony.

title: Texas Jurors Set Death Penalty For Convicted Killer of Policeman
description: FORT WORTH, July 14 (UPI)Jimmy Lloyd Mead, a convicted killer who first said he would rather die thah spend his life in prison but later changed his mind, was sentenced today to die by injection.

title: Alone in The World
description: SAUL FRIEDLANDER was born in Prague the worst possible moment, four months before Hitler came to power. In this harrowing, deeply moving memoir  one part the Gothic tale of a Jeviish orphan alone in Nazioccupied France preparing to become a Catholic priest, the other part the diary he kept many years later in Jerusalem  he undertakes an evocative voyage into his past that likely to leave many a reader shaken. This is not really a holocaust tale. Saul Friedliinder knew nothing of the holocaust until afterward. He knew only a childhood whose calm was continually being shattered, the pieces falling away, picked up and arbitrarily reassembled into new patterns. He tells his tale in wonder, then aweat how it all happened, that in 10 years he changed his identity four times, his religion twice, his name five times.

title: FISHING Tuna Heading North
description: THE season of the bluefin tuna, which travels north in the clear offshore waters along the Atlantic Coast during the summer, is under way. A fine showing is reported in southern New Jersey waters, and anglers should look for schools of this tacklesmashing fighter off Sandy Hook any day.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Three lives, one man  a generation of history can be summed up in the names he has answered to: Pavel, PaulHenri, Shaul, Saul.

title: U.S. Reportedly Wooing City's Albany Lobbyist
description: Peter A. Piscitelli, New York City's chief lobbyist at the State Legislature, is under consideration for a White House post dealing with ethnic affairs.

title: The Region
description: In 1968, New York State established a, special home insurance program to help owners otherwise unable to get insurance because their neighborhoods were considered bad risks. In the years since, however, the socalled FAIR (Fair Access to Insurance Requirements) plan  25 other states also have such plans  has seemed less a help than a hoax to many of those it was supposed to assist.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Theodore M. Purdy, 75; BookPublishing Leader
description: Theodore Martindale Purdy, who had been editor in chief and president of several bookpublishing companies, died Thursday in New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Roxbury. Conn.

title: FILM VIEW
description: According to conventi,nal wisdom, movies  like children  are supposed to be seen and not heard. We routinely talk about the way movies look, but rarely about the way they sound, and even less frequently about the way the sound of a movie affects the look of a movie and vice versa. As always, what we choose to call something governs the way we perceive it. And for much too long, we've referred to this medium as moving pictures, thereby ignoring the fadt that those flickering images are usuallyaccompanied by some sort of sound.

title: Against Hope for Mass Transit, The Stubborn Reality of the Car
description: WASHINGTON  Long lines at the gasoline pump and Administration agonizing over energy have pointed up one of the great ironies of postwar domestic policy. America's public transportation systems, once models of efficient and farreaching service, have shrunk and deteriorated to the point where many travelers, seeking alternatives to the automobile, now have nowhere to turn.

title: New State Energy Code Off to a Hesitant Start
description: After an initial period of confusion over interpretation, the state's sixmonthold Energy Conservation Construction Code is beginning to have an impact on construction projects, state officials and industry spokesman report.

title: U.S. Moves in Nicaragua Rebellion Wonying Paraguay's Dictatorship
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, July 13  The decline of the Somoza dynasty in Nicaragua is sending tremors of insecurity through the oldest dictatorship in South America, the Paraguayan regime of President Alfredo Stroessner.

title: Inns Where Spaniards Stay in Spain
description: Spain's best hotel chain, 50 years old, lost $6 million last year. Even so, to the delight of seasoned visitors who have come to know it, the national network of paradors is still expanding.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Help Save Athens
description: ATHENS  Greeks have always been great travelers and manage to make themselves at home in the farthest corners of the earth. Maybe sheer necessity developed this trait. Until very few years ago, the small, barren country could not feed all its children. A great number of them had to leave to survive.

title: HANOI ACTS TO SEIZE RESOURCES OF SOME
description: KIJANG, Indonesia, July 12  This is not a good time to plant a garden or plaster a wall in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Either act is an invitation for Communist officials, wielding shovels and sledgehammers, to begin a destructive search for freshly hidden gold, money or other forms of escape capital.

title: Mental Health Goals Unmet in Essex, Study Finds
description: EAST ORANGE ATHREEYEAR study of discharged mental patients in Essex County has concluded that the aims of the Federal Community Health Services Acts of 1963 and 1965, which stressed deinstitutionalization, have not been fulfilled.

title: Home Sites for the Retarded Still Raise Fears
description: FROM Mamaroneck on the Sound to Tarrytown on the Hudson and from Yonkers on the south to rural North Salem in the north, few issues have generated greater controversy in Westchester in recent years than the deinstitutionalization of the mentally retarded.

title: Men's Fashion BOUTIQUES FOR MODERN MEN
description: Men looking for clothes and accessories that are sure to set them apart from the crowd can have an adventure shopping at the many boutiques that have sprung up all over town in recent years. Some of these small stores, most of which are geared exclusively to men, offer a variety of clothes from established designers, as well as showcase unknown and sometimes avantgarde designers. Still others feature creations by the shop owners. In addition to those shown in these photographs, the following are just a few of those well worth exploring. Jackie Rogers, 787 Madison Avenue. The atmosphere of this shop is chic but comfortable, which also aptly describes the clothes designed by the owner. Here a man will find such things as an unconstructed jacket in gray wool, $295, or a camelcolored wool sweater with zippered front and pockets, $185.

title: Agence FrancePreen via United Press International
description: FRENCH CELEBRATE BASTILLE DAY: As French citizens celebrated throughout the country, jet fighters flew in formation over reviewing stand during a parade at Place de la Bastille yesterday in Paris. Storming of the in famous prison at the site in 1789 marked the start of the French Revolution.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Summer, when people are said to be reluctant trouble themselves too much, read too hard think too concentratedly, has always been a traditional time for doing Shakespeare. In New York we keep winter for serious things like Platinum and Neil Simon, although the Brooklyn Academy of Music, when it is working, has an alarming tendency to put on frivolities like Julius Caesar and Henry IV, and last season, Christopher Martin's Classical Stage Company played a trilogy of history plays, and the New York Shakespeare Festival did a Julius Caesar and a Coriolanus.

title: Many Are Pronounced Innocent, but Rehabilitation Doesn't Include a Proper Job and Decent Housing
description: PEKING  Wang Jianmin sits by day outside the subway station near Tian An Men Square, weaving holders for glass tumblers out of small strips of colored plastic. At night he spreads a piece of cardboard on the floor of the Supreme Peoples Court building to sleep.

title: CAMERA
description: As s the new and improved philosophy of today's photography bids us buy more and more specialized paraphernalia, it indirectly encourages us to disregard the potential of our existing materials and gradually weakens the inventive spirit that originally brought photography into being.

title: Sarah Parter Bride Of Lee M. Oser Jr.
description: Sarah Kirtland Parter, a vice president of the Vera Companies, was married in Southampton, L.I., yesterday to Lee M. Oser resident of Hampton International Jr.,Communications, publishers of consumer and hobby magazines, and chairman of Audio Mirror Publications, publishers of trade magazines. The Rev. Randall Saxon of the First Presbyterian Church of Southampton performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: Often Called In Civil Crises
description: WASHINGTON  The Army National Guard is in the midst of an advertising campaign to bolster enlistments, but even in this drive the nation's oldest military force seems on the defensive. The slogan, Get Your Guard Up, betrays an uneasiness over manpower and readiness. The budget, $6 million, is less than Guard officials would have liked.

title: GARDENING
description: STAMFORD WOODCHUCKS are wily fellows. They bide by the vegetable patch until the cabbage seedlings are just tall enough to munch, then they move in. When the squash and cucumber vines are beginning to grow nicely, the furry raiders nibble the seedlings down to stubble.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Most writers about music would not like to admit it, but they follow the swings of intellectual fashion as surely as high tide follows low. Not many years ago leading critics considered it beside the point to search for psychological or historical influences on a composer. It was gauche to try to make connections between particular works and specific events in an artist's life. The score itself had its own integrity and had to be studied in a vacuum, as if its author were anonymous. Life and art, for the most extreme of these writers, never did intersect, except on some higher geometrical plane beyond human hope of comprehension. On one side of the line was the composer, with his personal problems, his sorrows and his joys; on the other, the music he produced, separate and unrelated. This notion of a mystic division between the work and the worker was best summed up in Stravinsky's famous words, which he copyrighted in 1961: I am the vessel through which Le Sacre passed.

title: The Urban Development Corporation Changes Course and Survives
description: Anyone who wants to see how far the enthusiastic social activism of the 1960's has given way to the sober economic realities of the 1970's need only look at the current activities of the New York State Urban Development Corporation. Moreover, as a recently released report by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan illustrates, the U.D.C. offers a prime example of how earlier enthusiasms, even after having been abandoned because of their woeful consequences, can continue to prove haunting.

title: Hudson Valley's Cherry Growers Finding 17Year Locusts a Boon
description: HUDSON, N.Y., July 12  The emergence of the 17year locust this spring and summer has proved to be a boon for the cherry growers of the Hudson Valley.

title: Other World Events; How Long for Desai?; Portugal Calls Elections
description: As Indira Gandhi's chances of a comeback have waned, so has the unity of India's ruling Janata Party, a hodgepodge of Hindu, secular and Socialist factions bound together by common hatred of the former Prime Minister. Last week, several Cabinet ministers and more than 50 Janata members in Parliament defected from the party. A vote of confidence, expected this week, could topple Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai. Opposition is focused on Hindu fundamentalists who form the largest bloc within the Janata coalition.

title: More GasolineSaving Tips for the Motorist
description: A company in San Diego is advising Easterners planning an auto tour of the West Coast to save fuel by leaving their cars at home, flying out to southern California and renting a used car there for $7.95 a day and 7 cents a mile.

title: THE MARKETS Waiting to Hear the President
description: It was all down hill for the stock market last week after a Monday that saw hopes as well as prices and volume soar. A sustained rally was not to be as each day the Dow Jones industrial average rang up another decline, while investors apprehensively waited for President Carter to explain to the nation how he planned to deal with the oil crisis.

title: Melville Moves to Oust ExAddicts Center
description: MELVILLE FOR almost two years, nobody on Old East Neck Road in Melville complained about the folks who quietly moved in down the block  not until someone discovered that the newcomers were a group of former drug addicts.

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: Deaths
description: HEIMOWITZRobert. The officers and members of the Board of Trustees record with deep sorrow the passing of Robert Heimowitz, a dedicated and most respected member of our Temple. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Sydelle, and to the other members of his family. He will be missed. Temple EmanuE1 of Palm Beach Alan H. Cummings, Pres.

title: Gov. Byrne Now Enjoys Both Perks and Power
description: TRENTON  A few weeks ago, after lecturing New Jerseyans on the need to use less gasoline and ordering state drivers to cut consumption by 20 percent, Governor Brendan T. Byrne flew to Washington to meet with White House aides on energy problems. But before leaving, Mr. Byrne dispatched his official limousine the 170 miles to Washington to meet him the airport, so he could be chauffeured around the Capital. After the meetings, he flew back to Trenton and the limousine went back empty.

title: From Minister To Midwife
description: NEW HAVEN WHEN Gail Carlo of West Haven gave birth to her first son, Brian, recently at YaleNew Haven Hospital, she was attended by a nursemidwife who is a former football player and an ordained minister.

title: Capital Report
description: LEGISLATIVE sources report that Governor Byrne has relented on his threat to keep the Legislature in session all summer or until it has completed work on his program. He is said to be agreeable now to the Legislature's taking a vacation from its oneaweek sessions after it acts on the bill for the state to buy and operate bus lines and on one to increase the state tax on gambling at Atlantic City casinos.

title: Blue Collars, Purple Prose
description: PLUMBERS, carpenters, electricians and other people who work with their hands used to be strong, silent types, the sort of men who answered your questions in grudging monosyllables, as if you hadn't paid for language, too. But not any more.

title: Lilco UraniumSupply Plan Snagged
description: SANTA FE. N.M. THE New Mexico Environmental Improvement Division has rejected a plan for the discharge of uraniummill tailings submitted by the Bokum Resources Corporation, the New Mexico uranium supplier for the Long Island Lighting Company. However, Bokum's president said that in spite of the decision, the company is not going to stand still.

title: I.T.T.'s New Chief
description: Top officers of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation don't all agree on the virtues of Rand V. Araskog, who was elevated last week as the company's president and chief executive officer in one of the biggest executivesuite shocks of the year.

title: Bonnie Reid Plans Wedding on Sept 8 To Allen Martin
description: The engagement of Bonnie Williams Reid to Allen Martin has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jamieson Reid of Ashfield, Mass., parents of the future bride. The marriage will take place on Sept. 8 in St. Johnsbury, Vt., where the future bridegroom is a lawyer.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Gas's New Station in Life
description: IT was 6 A.M. on a recent Monday morning when Barbara Tiihonen parked her car in front of Mardi and Albert Delardi's driveway on Dedney Way in White Plains in hopes of securing an early position on a gas line.

title: The Prime Minister Proposed New Labor Laws Last Week
description: LONDON  Like two snarling dogs about to leap into battle, Britain's new Conservative Government and the powerful trade union leadership have spent the Government's first two months in power warily circling each other.

title: Poets Romance
description: HILDA DOOLITTLE, daughter of a professor astronomy at the University of Pennsylvania, and Ezra Pound of Wyncote, Pa., son of an assayer at the United States Mint in Philadelphia, met and fell in love in 1905, when they were undergraduates, she at Bryn Mawr, he at the University END TO TORMENT A Memoir of Ezra Pound by N.D. With the Poems From Hi! I's Book by Ezra Pound. Edited by Norman Holmes F arson and Michael King. 84 pp. New York: New Directions. $8.50.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THERE'S been no big rush by the motoring public to purchase the new gold and blue license plates, John A. Waddington, the director of the State Division of Motor Vehicles, reports. The distribution is about normal, he said. New car sales are down and people have been diverted by the gas problem, otherwise we'd be issuing more plates.

title: He Manages Mostly Mozart And Great Performers, Too
description: Ever since P.T. Barnum and Sol Hurok, the image of the impresario has been a flamboyant one. But there are quietly powerful people in the field of arts administration and promotion, too, and one of the more interesting ones is William W. Lockwood Jr. Mr. Lockwood is known  if he's known at all  to patrons of Lincoln Center in general and the Mostly Mozart Festivals in particular as a tall, graciously selfpossessed man who comes forward after intermissions and makes discreet, remarkably inoffensive pitches for money.

title: FOOD Bluefish, Snappy and Fresh
description: THE bluefish is the Island's quintessential summer fish. Other species may be gathered in greater volume (in 1978, the bluefish catch ranked fifth in size), but when the blues are running, excitement is high. The fish of the day will be the fresh, rich flesh of the blue.

title: Courville, Nye Duos Advance
description: MAMA RONECK, N.Y., July 14 The Courvilles, Jerry and his 20yearold son, Jerry Jr., of Shorehaven, and Gerald Nye and Henri de Lozier of Baltimore's Columbia Club, gained tomorrow's final of the Anderson. Memorial golf championship by posting semifinal victories today.

title: An Inside View Of a Refinery
description: LINDEN MERICA'S oil refineries, maligned even at the best of times, are coming under renewed criticism from Government and from consumer groups That are fed up with gasolinestation lines and that seek a focus for their frustration.

title: In Ontario: The Town Is a Big Part of the Show
description: The swans patrolling the tranquil waters of the Avon River in Stratford, Ontario, have grown sleek and fat off the tourists  a sure sign that Canada's annual Shakespearean Festival is now in full swing.

title: State's Tourist Industry Feeling Gas Squeeze
description: MYSTIC

title: TV ProducingNo Longer a Man's World
description: On NBC's program schedule for this fall is a madeforTV film called The Walls Came Tumbling Down. Filmed by Warner Brothers, this twohour special recounts the story of what happens to six former sorority sisters when the skeleton of a Cetus is found inside their abandoned sorority house. Featured is an allwoman cast  Paula Prentis, Tina Louise, Loretta Swit, Cathryn Damon, Stella Stevens and Sondra Locke under the supervision and direction of an allwomen production team, including screenwriter, executive producers, producer and director. While some contend that the allwomen's aspect of the film is merely a gimmick, a hook to. snare viewers, there is no denying that the project's singular character does underscore women's increasing presence as television producers.

title: New Haven Pros Ride SlowPitch Boom
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In your story t Setting a Price on a House is a Dilemma for Sellers, June 10] a Lewisboro woman was quoted as recommending that sellers of a house tell a broker exactly what price they want to net: then if the broker wanted the listing, it was up to him to cut his commission.

title: Beckenbauer Assails Astroturf
description: Franz Beckenbauer thinks he knows the reason he injured his right knee, which kept him out of soccer for 12 weeks.

title: He Squeezes Nuances Out of Jazz Tunes
description: SOUTHAMPTON TONY ZANO is a small, unimposing figure who seems to acquire the stature of a giant as soon as he sits down at a piano.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BEACH HAVEN (Surflight Summer Theater, Engleside Avenue)  The King and I (through tomorrow); Jesus Christ Superstar, opens Tuesday (through July 23). 8:30 P.M. $545.50. (609) 4929477.

title: WESTCHESTEROPINION
description: WESTCHESTER OPINION

title: Redskins Still. Paying for Allen's Success
description: The Over The Hill Gang has gone over the hill, leaving something of a vacuum.

title: Carter Energy Speech On TV at 10 Tonight
description: President Carter will address the nation on energy problems at 10 o'clock tonight in a speech that will be broadcast live by the CBS, NBC and ABC television networks, their radio networks, the Public Broadcasting Service, National Public Radio and the Mutual Broadcasting System.

title: THEATER
description: DARIEN TIME, which is usually the enemy of musical comedy, has turned out to be a friend to Mame. It is not that the musical is so rich or sturdy in content as to withstand the ravages of time, but that its audience has had a breathing space in which to get away from the material.

title: Miss D'Arcy Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Christine Tangney D'Arcy, visual arts director for the Alaska State Council on the Arts in Anchorage, to Richard Duncan Kerst, an architectural designer in Anchorage, took place at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday. . Msgr. Edwin Connors performed the ceremony.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Meeting last week in London, the International Whaling Commission, over the objections of Japan and the Soviet Union, voted for a worldwide moratorium on whaling by factory ships. The commission is a voluntary association of whaling nations, not a legislative body, and its vote is enforceable only by the fear that a breakdown of compliance would lead to the speedy extinction of all whales and all whaling. But if the ban is observed, it is calculated, according to one American conservationist, to save perhaps 10,000 sperm whales from death next year.

title: GARDENING Saving Energy Yesterday's Way
description: AJOGGER passing a gasoline line is a reminder of the time when our daily living involved a much greater expenditure of human energy and less mechanical or electrical power from fossil fuels. Scarcely a generation ago, most gardening fell into that category.

title: Deadline Nears On Garbage Plan
description: A LARGE drawing of a trash container stands outside the office of Edward K. Davies, the Deputy Commissioner of Solid Waste, depicting the progress in signing up Westchester's garbage for the longheralded attempt at countywide recycling, beginning late in 1983.

title: DINING OUT The Freshness Stands Out
description: CATO'S in Bridgehampton is new this season and is a nearly miraculous renovation of what was a local pub. Gone are the dark wood walls whose every pore reeked of beer and booze. All has been whitened and smartened with chic understatement. Polish circus posters splash the walls with color, reflecting a local concentration of families of Polish descent.

title: The Gentrification of Suburbia
description: IN SUBURBAN counties across the country, a housing pattern has been emerging over the last decade for which there is no parallel. The pattern consists of the formation of highincome enclaves on a vast geographic scale  in effect, regional ghettos of the affluent.

title: Yankees Lose, 87; Gossage Bombed
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 14  The bullpen problem the Yankees suffered in Rich Gossage's absence erupted again tonight with Gossage on the mound.

title: White House Staff Also Scores Low in the Polls
description: WASHINGTON After dinner, Jimmy Carter and his guests were sitting on cushions tossed on the floor of Aspen Lodge, the President's rusticplush bungalow at Camp David. Clark Clifford, the perennial guru to Democratic Presidents was there, along with attorney Sol Linowitz and John Gardner. the founder of Common Cause, and several other Washington influentials. The President asked them to speak candidly about their perceptions of his White House staff. There was a moment's pause; then Hamilton Jordan, the top Carter political aide, suggested that he and the other staff members, including Press Secretary Jody Powell and media adviser Gerald Rafshoon, leave the room.

title: The Secret to a Vacation's Success
description: EACH summer just before leaving for a family vacation, I root through closets and drawers and extract nonessentials, much like a squirrel ridding its tree hollow of nut husks in the spring.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: GOVERNOR GRASSO, who had been openly critical of President Carter's energy policy in recent months, was the author of a resolution favoring the President's reelection in 1980 that was passed last Sims ilay by the National Governors Conference in Louisville. Kv.

title: GARDENINGA Pesky Varmint Foiled Well, Partly
description: STAMFORD WOODCHUCKS are wily fellows. They bide by the vegetable patch until the cabbage seedlings are just tall enough to munch, then they move in. When the squash and cucumber vines are beginning to grow nicely, the furry raiders nibble the seedlings down to stubble.

title: Discount Offerings For Older People
description: Sometimes it pays to grow old. More and more Americans are discovering that a wide range of travel bargains are available exclusively to those whc have reached the socalled golden years.

title: Roots of Strike Lie In State's Attitude
description: TRENTON THE strike by about 14,000 whitecollar workers against the state government probably had its genesis in the attitude New Jersey officials have demonstrated against illegal strikes in the past.

title: Upgrading Is in Sight for 5,000 Upper Harlem Line Commuters
description: WHITE PLAINS THE 5,000 daily riders of the Upper Harlem commuter line appeared to have fresh reason for hope earlier this month that their dream of a $45 million modernization of their service was finally going to be realized.

title: Above All, Laughter and Delight
description: I AM occasionally desired by congenital imbeciles and the editors of magazines, a vexed Dorothy Sayers once remarked, to say something about the writing of detective fiction from the woman's point of view. To such demands one can only say, Go away and don't be silly. You might as well ask what is the female angle on the equilateral triangle.
