The remark is characteristic: It has both substance and glitter, it is concise, and it is the product of an irritable intelligence. It's the kind of thing one might expect from a Baker Street Irregular who approached Sherlock Holmes with solemnity or a theologian who approached God with a sense of humor.

title: Swedes in U.N.'s Sinai Force Idled by Peace Treaty
description: CAIRO  A detachment of Swedish peacekeeping troops stationed in northeast Sinai has been overtaken for the last six weeks by the peace arrangements between Egypt and Israel.

title: THE CASE AGAINST A CONSPIRACY
description: In early December 1978, the members of the House Select Committee on Assassinations were reviewing copies of a preliminary draft final report. After nearly two years of work and the expenditure of $5.8 million, they had concluded that Lee Harvey Oswald was the lone gunman who had killed President Kennedy, wounded Texas Governor John Connally and killed Dallas Police Officer J. D. Tippit. There was no conspiracy.

title: Unmarried Couples Win New Rights
description: TRENTON AGENERATION ago, it was called living in sin. Not only did society consider disgraceful, but in some instances it also was against the law.

title: THEATER Mame Is Aging With Grace
description: DARIEN, CONN. TIME, which is usually the enemy of musical comedy, has turned out to be a friend to Mame. It is not that the musical is so rich or sturdy in content as to withstand the ravages of time, but that its audience has had a breathing space in which to get away from the material.

title: Ireland's Catholic Church, Facing Resistance to Authority, Seeks a New Role in Society
description: KILANERIN, Ireland  On a normal Sunday morning, the Rev. Richard Kavanagh expects to see every ablebodied man, woman and child in this farm village of 850 people at one or the other of two masses he says in the Church of Sts. Peter and Paul.

title: The Witches Tale
description: STHER THE WHITE is a beautiful, aging witch. She has a son, Phillip, who is something of a lunatic. Phillip likes to drown. He makes one attempt each year, during the Drowning Season, July and August. Phillip is always rescued by his keeper, a man named Cohen. Cohen loves Esther the White and is loyal to her, but how can he declare his love for the witch, when she has a husband, a dwarf (her brotherinlaw), a crazy son, and a granddaughter, Esther the Black, who all whirl around her at the family Compound on Long Island? Such is the material of Alice Hoffman's second novel, The Drowning Season, a fierce and wicked fairytale of these modern times.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON Connecticut Outpost In Washington, D.C.
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. UPin Hartford the state opens up each morning at 8 o'clock, she says, so down here 29yearold Ann Sullivan arranges to have the state's Washington office open by 8:15 to start catching the calls.

title: Sarah Bates HasNuptials
description: Sarah MacDonald Bates, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Page Bates of Warren, Conn., and David Dickinson Henry Jr., son of Mr. Henry of Belmont, Mass., and Wedgeport, Nova Scotia, and  the late Marie Curren Henry, were married yesterday in the Congregational Church in Warren.

title: Galante Clues Sought
description: Brooklyn's Bushwick area was canvassed for clues to the gunmen who killed Carmine Galante, the reputed crime leader, on Thursday. Page 35.

title: Hooking up for wreck fishing out of Montauk.
description: Photo essay by Barton Silverman

title: Ballet: Josefina Mendez In Cubans Swan Lake
description: If the perfect Swan Lake must boast an Odette and Odile of equal strength, then the National Ballet of Cuba's performance of the classic on Friday at the Metropolitan Opera House should win no medals. But there's heartening news in store for those who've mourned the passing of the ballet diva. Remember Margot Fonteyn's manic third act grin, sent straight up into the balcony? Or Raissa Struchkova's pellmell crossstage jump into her partner's stoic arms in Spring Waters? Josefina Mendez is alive, and well, and the epitome of flashy fun and icy desirability as Odile, the sorcerer's daughter.

title: They Meet, 10 Years Later
description: They didn't exactly march with Montgomery and his Eighth Army in desert pursuit of Rommel. They didn't exactly fly with Armstrong to the moon. But when baseball people gather, as they did yesterday in Shea Stadium, these few men are remembered for their brief but rousing hours on the public stage.

title: ExLeader At CBSTV To Warner
description: John A. Schneider, a former CBS executive, has beep appointed as a fulltime exclusive consultant for the Warner Communications Company. Steven J. Ross, Warner's chairman, made the announcement and said Mr. Schneider would be involved in all phases of the company's entertainment and communications activities.

title: Buckley Plan Divides Town
description: SHARON

title: The Dance: Karen Kai n Is Giselle With Nure.yev
description: As part of its season devoted primarily to standard repertory, the National Ballet of Canada offered Giselle Friday night at the New York State Theater. It was a vivid performance in many ways. for the company's ensemble, which attimes can be tidy but tame, responded wholeheartedly to ballet's great Romantic tragedy.

title: Johnson, Hartsfield, Corrales to Coach AllStars
description: Managers Darrell Johnson of Seattle, Roy Hartsfield of Toronto and Pat Corrales of Texas have been named coaches of the American League AllStar team.

title: Two 2YearOlds Are Asphyxiated By Steam in Bathroom in Queens
description: Two cousins, both 2 years old, died yesterday of asphyxiation in the steamandhotwaterfilled bathroom of the Elmhurst, Queens, apartment where they lived, the police said.

title: Ann Grande Carpenter Bride of G.L. Henderson
description: In the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J., yesterday, Ann Grande Carpenter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Webb Carpenter, was married to Guy Lawrence Henderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fistio Henderson. Both families are from Rumson.

title: Miss Arendsen Blazing Them In
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 14  The water balloon flew into Kathy Arendsen's room in the Pan American Village at 1:15 A.M., fired by male athletes in an adjacent dorm who had rigged up a slingshot with oars.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: In response to the letter to the editor by Marlene Bettman in which she refers to the dog pounds that murder animals:

title: A Thinking Machine Can Think Like a Judge, 99 Percent of the Time
description: CAMBRIDGE The time may not be far off when the prudent lawyer will take each new case to a computer before taking it to court.

title: 15 Killed and 61 Injured in Taipei By Chemical Explosion and Fire
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 19 (UPI)Chemicals stored in the basement of a fourstory building in a heavily populated residential area exploded yesterday, killing at least 15 persons and injuring 61, the police said today.

title: Playland Poll Finds Concern Over a Closing
description: RYE THE number of Westchester residents visiting Playland Amusement Park has increased significantly in the last 10 years, according to surveys conducted by the County Planning Department. The surveys indicate that 59 percent of the county's residents have visited the amusement park this year, as against 46 percent in 1969.

title: U.S. Golfers Shoot For Britain's Open
description: ST. ANNES, England, July 14 Wimbledon is receding into memory now that the British sporting scene shifts to a new venue for the opening Wednesday of the 108th Open Golf Championship.

title: Ruling Favors Public Employees In Dispute on Contracting Out
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 14  The approval that the State Court of Appeals gave last year to the practice of contracting out work, or replacing union employees with those hired, by private companies, was tempered this week with another decision by the same court.

title: Donna Sue Storm, a Hydrologist, Married To Kenneth T. Barrow, Graduate Student
description: Donna Sue Storm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ream Storm of San Antonio, was married there yesterday evening to Kenneth Thomson Barrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Davies Barrow of Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Louis H. Zbinden Jr.

title: Community Gardening Finds Its Place in the Sun
description: BEHIND homes, at apartment houses and on the grounds of large corporations, community gardens are growing like there's no tomorrow. But it isn't too late to take advantage of them.

title: Jazz in Montclair
description: MONTCLAIR ANEW type of jazz club that offers traditional, as well as new, almost experimental, music has opened on a quiet side street near the heart of the Montclair business district.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Borer Alert

title: Some Lessons From China for Suburbia?
description: WESTPORT THER than view the humble, crowded way of life in China as something to be pitied especially since it lacks the American ideals of individual liberty and upward material mobility  a clinical professor of psychiatry at Yale and his wife, who is a regional planner, returning from a recent visit to China, contend that there is a timely lesson to be learned from the Chinese experience in what they feel is a vitally needed reassessment of our wasteful suburban And this reassessment is particularly important right now, say Rita and Paul Kaunitz, in light of the current energy crunch, land shortages, the number of psychiatric disorders resulting from our increasingly rootless ways as well as the loneliness of people who live in isolated affluence on large tracts of land, such as those in Fairfield County.

title: Film: Upcoming Shorts From 9 Independents
description: The term Independent film maker is often synonomous with solemnity, technical crudity and obscure and convoluted subject matter. This is not the case, however, with the 1980 Short Film Showcase of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Helicopter Crash in Philadelphia Is Fatal to 2 Television Crewmen
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP)  Two television crewmen filming a charity jogging event were killed today when their chartered helicopter plunged into a river, the authorities said.

title: In Sale of Liquor, Age Is a Minor Consideration
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. I SET out not long ago in search of an honest liquor merchant, one who would refuse to sell alcohol to minors. Like Diogenes, I failed; three hours and 152 bottles and cans of beer and booze later, I was still looking.

title: Associated Press
description: Steve Renko of Red Sox lost nohitter in ninth Friday at Oakland.

title: POLISARIO TO RENEW RAIDS ON MAURITANIA
description: ALGIERS, July 14  The announcement by the Polisario Front guerrilla movement this week that it had broken off its yearlong ceasefire with Mauritania risks straining the group's already difficult relations witn its Algerian sponsors, and could again bring French fighterbombers to Mauritania's rescue.

title: Suspect Found in Doctor's Office Fatally Shot by Officer in Queens
description: A police officer in Jamaica, Queens, investigating a report of a burglary in progress inside a doctor's office early yesterday, shot and fatally wounded an unidentified man whom he surprised there, the police reported.

title: In Connecticut: A Busy Scene
description: Stratford, Conn., is all Shakespeare. On Main Street this little town near Bridgeport, passersby gossip about the controversial production of Julius Caesar, in which actors wear green fatigues and carry submachine guns. The Bard, a local newspaper, is published near the Shakespeare Travel Agency, and Jerry's Shakespeare Pizza and the Shakespearean Veterinarian are not far away.

title: A Proposal to Play Post Office
description: Private mail delivery systems, in many cases outperforming and underselling the United States Postal Service, have steadily chipped away at the Government's 190yearold monopoly on second and thirdclass mail. Now a small crack may even be developing in the private express statutes, which have forbidden private delivery of firstclass mail since the Articles of Confederation.

title: A GRated Boost for Broadway
description: The tide has turned. Some of the best new movies are showing on Broadway again, and there to make the most of it is Norman W. Elson, a movie theater operator on Broadway since the early 1930's.

title: Works in Progress
description: DON'T work very well in the summer, but I am 210 pages in progress In my fifth novel, The Hotel New Hampshire, which I began more than a year ago. I have There are writers who, when asked how they are, will say something like, Oh, pretty good. My new novel is about incest between mother and son. It takes place on a cruise ship in the Caribbean. The mother is quite young And there are writers who, when asked what their new book is about, will look at you as if you've been opening their mail. The Book Review, aware that the two types exist but uncertain who fell into which group, asked a number of writers to tell us about their worksinprogress. Philip Roth spoke for all those who declined: I find it best to keep my mouth shut about this sort of thing. The road to hell is paved with worksinprogress. The others responded as follows: six finished chapters  and rough draft of an epilogue, which i wrote first. The opening sentence is: The summer my father bought the bear, none of us was born  we weren't even conceived: not Frank, the oldest; not Franny, the loudest; not me, the next; and not the younger of us, Lilly and Egg. Franny, the loudest, is the hero of the novel. Chapter 1 is titled The Bear Called State o Maine ; Chapter 2, The First Hotel New Hampshire; Chapter 3, Iowa Bob's Winning Season; Chapter 4, Franny Loses Fight; Chapter 5, Merry Christmas, 1956; Chapter 6, Father Hears From Freud. (This is not the Freud; this Freud is a Viennese beartrainer.) Chapter 7 will be called Sorrow Strikes Again. (Sorrow is the name of the family Labrador retriever.) Chapter 8 will be called The Second Hotel New Hampshire'; and so on. don't know how far away the end is  only what it is. I know thelast sentence, but I am very much in the dark concerning how to get to it. For example, the end of Chapter 6 is: Like any storyteller, I had the power to end the story, and I could have. But 1 didn't destroy Freud's letter; I gave it to Father, while the vision of the man in the white dinner jacket was still upon him. I handed over Freud's letter like any storyteller, knowing  more or less  where we would all be going. And I seem to be stuck right there, because  as any novelist knows  knowing more or less where you're going isn't Knowing enough.

title: Law Student Weds Katherine Ferguson
description: Katherine Nash Ferguson, daughter of Robert G. Ferguson Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Milton Lummis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lummis Jr., also of Darien. The Rev. Walter H. Taylor performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: An Artist Who Is Doing What He Likes Best
description: RIDGEFIELD THE Olympics had a problem. They needed a mascot for the 1980 Winter Games in Lake Placid. Choosing an official mascot is important, even vital, because it becomes the symbol that is used worldwide in every promotional gimmick, every advertising campaign and every fundraising situation that arises in the three years leading up to the momentous event itself.

title: Alchemy for U.S. Five's Gold: Young Star, Incendiary Coach
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 14  He was the youngest player on the team, 18 years old and fresh out of high school. But when Isiah Lord Thomas 3d arrived at the Pan American Games with other members of the United States men's basketball team, he was the other highschool kid. Ralph Sampson, the 7foot3inch center, was the big man.

title: News Summary
description: Palestinian guerrilla leaders joined Turkish officials in efforts to avoid a showdown at the Egyptiaan Embassy in Ankara, which was seized by four Palestinian gunmen Friday. Members of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which has denounced the attack on the embassy, arrived from Damascus to try to reach a settlement with the gunmen. The Egyptian Ambassador, Ahmed Kemal Ulma, and 14 other hostages were said to still be in the building. [Page1, Column2.]

title: Heading Postal Union Is Now His Bag
description: IT was a quirk of fate, said Vincent R. Sombrotto. I really don't know myself how it happened, he said. To this day I haven't been able tO determine it.

title: Guidelines Get Major Test in U.A.W.'s Talks With 3 Auto Companies Starting This Week
description: DETROIT, July 14  The Carter Administration's hopes of salvaging its battered wage and price guidelines and controlling the rise of inflation face a major test in negotiations starting Monday between the United Automobile Workers and the three major automobile companies.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Glassenclosed, climatecontrolled, built around cascading waterfalls and embellished with exotic plants, shopping malls have sprung up like mushrooms all around the state and offer mass shopping on a colossal scale.

title: Kennedy Primary Plea Reported
description: BOSTON, July 14 (AP)  Senator Edward M. Kennedy has reportedly asked Speaker Thomas W. McGee of the State House not to change the date of the Massachusetts Presidential primary, despite a move by President Carter to have changed to a later date. The Boston Globe said today that Mr. Kennedy in the past has stated his preference to have the Massachusetts primary on March 4, but that his call to Mr. McGee represented a personal lobbying effort that is somewhat unusual.

title: U.S. Attack on Corporate Crime Yields Handful of Cases in 2 Years.
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  The Justice Department has developed only a handful of criminal cases against major corporations in the two years since the Carter Administration promised to crack down on corporate and whitecollar crime.

title: DINING OUT How to Pack a Picnic With Pleasure
description: JULY and August are months to laugh and sing and toss, Frisbees into the air like the carefree people do in softdrink commercials. Summer is the time to pop corks, tap kegs, roast corn and crack claws. It should be a time for fun, but fun seems to be at a premium these days. Long faces and short tempers have been everywhere. Before we all end up with ulcers by Labor Day, we should pack up our troubles in an old picnic basket and gambol on the greensward or sun on the sand.

title: A Bolshevik Affair
description: THERE was something about Vladimir Mayakovsky that was simply physically appealing: his huge stature, his posture of adolescent braggadocio, the boyish moue with which he was forever glaring into cameras, and a voice that could make a cake fall. He exploited this star quality for all it was worth, and since he was a poet of genius into the bargain, it has turned out to be worth at least the status of Bolshevik poet laureate.

title: CRIME

To this day there are those who believe that the prophecies of the 16thcentury astrologerphysician are uncanny anticipations of the future; that everything he predicted has come true.

title: The Price for International Acceptance

Like every other senior official inherited by Bishop Muzorewa, Mr. Smith white. But what made his presence at the Bishop's side noteworthy was not so much the color of his skin as the turn of events that obliged the Bishop to name him secretary to the Cabinet, the top official in the 40,000member civil service.

title: Digging Up Norwalk's History

For several weeks, however, employees of the PeritinElmer Corporation in Wilton shared space with a vigorous team of men and women measuring, digging, add sifting every inch of soil around the bake of a cliff at one end of the parking ax a. With whisk brooms and trowels, pails and strainers, members of a Norwalk Community College program, Archeology as an Avocation, investigated a prehistoric dwelling place.

title: Film: Diane Kurys 'Peppermint Soda':The Cast
description: The only thing more impressive than the wit and talent Diane Kurys demonstrates in her writing and direction of "Peppermint Soda"  an expert, utterly charming movie that miraculously happens to be her first  is Miss Kurys's memory. Here is a letter-perfect recollection of what it's like to be a 13-year-old, in this case a French schoolgirl, with skinny legs and a bossy sister and a mother who doesn't understand she may be ruining her' daughter's life if she keeps on refusing to let the kid wear stockings.Miss Kurys presents details like these, and enough others to span an entire school year, with a flawless understanding of how the events most earth-shattering to a girl in her early teens can mean not a fig to anyone around her. The movie's most memorable quality is its flair for taking things absolutely seriously while never forgetting to take them lightly, too."Peppermint Soda" has the form of a scrapbook, giving separate and even-handed attention to the various events that mark the heroine's and her sister's 1963-64 school year. Miss Kurys, who was herself 13 at that time, has her own little Antoinette Doinel in the character of Anne Weber, played beautifully by the lovely and solemn Eleonore Klarwein. In fact, Miss Kurys is about to start work on a second Anne Weber film, also named for a sort of beverage: "Molotov Cocktail," about Anne and, presumably, her politics in 1968.In 1963, the issues Anne finds most absorbing revolve around fights with her sister, life at a girls' school and her parents' divorce; everything else is so peripheral that Miss Kurys turns each school vacation into a series of cursory  though wonderfully revealing  snapshots. Her older sister, Frederique (Odile Michel), has a boyfriend, whose letters Anne routinely steams open. The math teacher is afraid of her students. The gym teacher wears a fur coat while the girls are outdoors in shorts. The art teacher is a sadistic old bat who picks on her students as they sketch a little statuette of Bambi.One of Frederique's friends, more precocious than the others, is privately but unmistakably in love. Anne is sullen to her mother's boyfriend, but just as sullen to her own father when he comes to visit. Frederique's best friend deserts her, and she suffers and mourns and then finds a better one. Anne, usually estranged from Frederique, grows suddenly loyal during this calamity. Miss Kurys illustrates this as delicately as she illustrates anything else, and as marvelously matter-of-factly. You can tell Anne's sympathies have changed simply by watching the way she sits listening to a conversation in the schoolyard."Peppermint Soda," which opens today at the 57th Street Playhouse, formerly the Playboy Theater, takes its title from a grown-up drink Anne orders in a cafe. Before she can touch it, Frederique barges in and threatens to tattle to the girls' preoccupied, intermittently strict and sometimes unexpectedly fond mother. The French title, "Diabolo Menthe," perhaps does a better job of evoking Anne's slender efforts to live dangerously. By either name, though, the movie is handsomely crafted yet also sweet and buoyant in its innocence  a first film likely to leave audiences eager to see Miss Kurys's second."Peppermint Soda," which is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a few references to adolescent sexuality.

title: The Stagflation Skirt

He was referring to the hemline theory of stock market forecasting credited to Ralph Rotnem, a veteran stock analyst. Mr. Rotnem ob- served that when skirt lengths rose, so did the Dow average - but when skirt lengths dropped, it was time to buy Impressionist paintings.

title: Deaths
description: LOOKSTEIN Rabbi Joseph H. The officers, board members and staff of the Board of Jewish Education of Greater, New York deeply mourn the passing of esteemed honorary board member, Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein. His illustrious career. as educator and Rabbi was highlighted by his pioneering efforts for the Jewish Day School, teacher training and higher Jewish education. We will remember his lifelong concern for all Jewish youth and his brilliant leadership to Klal Yisrael. Our heartfelt condolences to his dear wife Gertrude and to his children Rabbi Haskel Lookstein and Mrs Natalie Friedman and their families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Sporting Gear
description: It doesn't take much to start a new game. In Hacky Sack, which began in Oregon and is spreading across the country, the only object needed is a footbag, which weighs less than an ounce. The footbag, about the size of a golf ball, is made of leather and packed with plastic pellets. Using only the lower part of the body  knees and feet are preferred  the players can develop coordination by practicing alone, or several participants can form a circle, keep the footbag airborne and keep score. In tournaments, an eight-foot-high net is used, and the rules are similar to those of volleyball. For a footbag, rules and a description of the types of exercises and games, send $5.95, plus 50 cents for postage, to the National Hacky Sack Association, Box 2053, Cerritos, Calif. 90701, (213) 9203886.

Squarely laid out, it is marked by wide streets dominated by hotels with long verandas, tin awnings and spacious, cool bars.

title: Jerilyn Britz Captures Open On Final Hole
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 15  Jerilyn Kaye Britz, who perfected her golf game after she was 30 years old, gained her first victory in 5 years as a professional today by winning the 34th United States Women's Open on the last hole.

title: Sports Briefs
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., July 15  Sam DeSantos of the Shore Athletic Club of New Jersey led from start to finish in winning the national Amateur Athletic Union's junior 5,000-meter walk cham- pionship this morning in 24 minutes 10 seconds.

title: MILLIONS HELD LOST ON SALE OF MINERALS
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  The sale of surplus minerals from the nation's defense stockpiles has been so badly managed that tens of millions of dollars in revenue has been lost, auditors for the General Services Administration have charged in reports over the last 10 years.

title: Nevada Presses Its Effort To Regain Disputed Land
description: DENVER, Colo., July 15  Nevada is leading what Westerners call the sagebrush rebellion against the Federal land management bureaucracy. While Westerners have not given up trying to influence and even dominate the agencies, they are now trying the simpler tactic of laving claim to Federal land.

title: PALESTINIAN GUNMEN RELEASE 9 HOSTAGES, SURRENDER TO TURKS
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 15  Four Palestinian gunmen freed nine hostages and surrendered here today after a 45- hour siege of the Egyptian Embassy. Three men had lost their lives in the siege.

title: How Far Should Police Protection Go?
description: When she entered the 43d Precinct station house in the Bronx at 5:30 P.M. on Sunday, Nov. 9, 1975, Josephine Sorichetti was distraught. She was worried about what had happened to her 6-year-old, daughter, Dina, whom she had turned over the previous morning to her estranged husband, Frank, in .accordance with the weekerkd visiting rights granted to him two days earlier in Family Court.

title: News Summary
description: Moraji R. Desai resigned as India's Prime Ministdr. Faced with a vote of no confidence in Parliament today, which he did not have enough votes to defeat, he reluctantly stepped down in response to pleas from his dwindling political allies and to save his Janata Party from collapse. [Page A1, Col. 1.]

title: Linking SALT and the Energy Crisis
description: By what may be a fortunate coincidence, the SALT debate and the energy crisis are coming to a simultaneous head. From one point of view these two issues are of course unrelated. But from another perspective they can be seen as posing the same question in two different forms: the ques- tion of whether the United States will persist in a selfimposed contraction of its own power.

title: The Cost of Health
description: BALTIMORE - The debate over the medicalcare crisis and how to solve it may well have reached a crisis of its own.

title: Lee Salk Children's Series Coming to PBS in October
description: Feelings, a 13-week children's series featuring Dr. Lee Salk, the child psychologist and author, will have its premiere on PBS in October.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows: MONDAY

title: Broad Range of Issues Is Revealed by Arguments
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  For four days last week the Senate Foreign Rela- tions Committee heard witnesses ex- pound virtually all arguments for and against the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union, as well as a

title: U.S. Banks World Role At Issue
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  The Senate Banking Committee is to open hearings tomorrow on three controversial issues: the dramatic increase in foreign purchases of American banks; the proposal to establish an international banking facility or free trade zone. in New York City, and rules permitting bank subsidiaries that conduct international business to branch across state lines and accept domestic deposits.

title: American Boxers Striking Gold
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 15  Three years ago, amateur boxing in the United States was a sport in search of an identity and survival dollars.

title: The AllStar ExManager
description: FOR someone who always had been in the visitors dugout in New York before, Bob Lemon earned the ultimate tribute during his brief tenure as the Yankees manager  instant admiration and affection. When he succeeded Billy Martin nearly a year ago, Bob Lemon was remembered mostly as a consistent 20game winner for the Cleveland Indians, especially in 1954 when they won 111 games  the only year in the decade from 1949 through 1958 that the Yankees did not win the American League pennant. But as the Yankees manager, he was no longer a stranger. He was there to be judged. He could have been resented by all those Yankee fans who adore Billy Martin, but Bob Lemon was not only accepted, he was cherished. The team's comeback to a second consecutive World Series championship helped. But so did Bob Lemon's style. He never comes on like a genius. He hardly comes on at all. And that's the beauty of Bob Lemon  he is always himself. Calm. Friendly. Humble. The night last month that Billy Martin returned as manager and Bob Lemon suddenly found himself kicked upstairs to be the general manager, the Yankees lost again. When that game ended, Bob Lemon turned to Al Rosen, the Yankees president.

title: Dibbs and Heat Overcome Solomon
description: Harold Solomon prepared carefully for what he assumed would be a marathon match in the heavy heat. In the morning, there was a full dose of salt tablets and minerals. In the afternoon, there was a white beach hat to shield his head from the blazing sun.

title: Town Meeting About Armageddon
description: America fared well at the first week of televised debate of the SALT II treaty. The Russians, we suspect, stood in awe of the spectacle; they really can't understand letting the public near such dynamite.

title: TV SPORTS
description: 4:00 (31)Soccer from West Germany: Fortuna Dusseldorf vs. F.C. Co- logne (tape)

title: Deaths
description: DOERING Otto C. Jr., 74, of Scarsdale. NY on July 12, 1979. Survived by his wife Lucy and three sons, Rogers, Paul and Otto III and nine grandchildren. Funeral services private. in lieu of flowers contributions to the International Rescue Committee would be appreciated.

title: U.S. Totals: 127 Gold Among 264 Medals
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 15  The eighth Pan American Games, which began in an air of tension and uncertainty, ended tonight with the United States more dominant than ever but with its role in the future of the Games still uncertain.

title: Agostinho Victor in Tour Race
description: ALPE D'HUEZ, France, July 15 Joaquim Agostinho, a veteran Portuguese bicycle racer, surprised the Tour de France pack today by gaining an easy victory here and demonstrated that there is nothing like a 70mile climb over some of the highest mountains in the Alps to work the kinks out of a bad lee.

title: The Winner Stays Within Her Limits
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 15  It was happening again. With a threestroke lead and four holes to go in the United States Women's Open, Jerilyn Britz began to race inside. Adrenaline flowed. She felt, as she had in situations such as this in the past, that she could go beyond herself. She felt that she could hit a golf ball farther than past experience, and gold sense, said she could.

title: Molire to Be Done In Bryant Park
description: Sidewalks of New York, a nonprofit performing arts organization, will bring free theater to the streets of the metropolitan area.

title: The New York Times/George Tames
description: In Washington, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan watched as the President spoke and called his program promising

title: Smalley, Twins Big Hitter, Is No. 1 in the Player Poll
description: WHO in this highpriced world of professional sports is. Roy Frederick Smalley 3d of Los Angeles? He is the son of a former major league infielder: He is the nephew of Gene Mauch, the manager of the Minnesota Twins. He is a shortstop who now plays for Uncle Gene: who as a rookie hit only .228, and who a year later tied a major league record by striking out eight times in two consecu- tive games.

title: Books of The Tirnes
description: FOR CAPITAL PUNISHMENT. Crime and the Morality of the Death Penalty. By Walter Berns. 219 pages. Basic. $10.95.

title: Wide Criticism Is Aimed At Energy Department
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  A bitter joke here holds that the solution to the energy shortage is to tell half the Department of Energy to stay home on evennumbered days and the other half on oddnumbered days, and then dismiss the half that come to work.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  Passive humanitarianism is not an sdequate response to genocide.

title: Diaz Ordaz, ExMexican President Who Put Down Student Riots, Dies
description: Gustavo Diaz Ordaz, the austere, toughminded judge and politician whras President of Mexico led the bloody suppression of student riots in 1968, died yesterday in Mexico City after a brief illness. Mr. Diaz Ordaz, whose death was reported by members of his family, was 68 years old.

title: Orioles Affiliate Acquires 3 Players
description: MIAMI, July 15 (AP)  The Rochester Red Wings, a minorleague affiliate of the Baltimore Orioles, have acquired three members of the Miami Amigos franchise, the Wings announced today.

title: California, for First Time, Moves Toward CoalFueled Power Plant
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15  For the first time in its 129year history, the state of California is moving toward burning coal to generate electricity. The reasons are the shrinking supplies and rising costs of oil and natural gas and a virtual state ban on new nuclear power plants.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MDAY Those symphonic sounds by the Tshirted musicians seated in Lincoln Center's north plaza starting today at noon can mean only one thing  the traditional midday sampling of the official opening event in the Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPII

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter proposed a sixpoint energy package intended to save 4.5 million barrels of imported oil a day by 1990. In a nationally televised address he described a crisis of confidence that is. threatening American democracy. His energy package called for: the imposition of import quotas, development of synthetic fuels, more solar energy, a shift by utilities from oil to coal, a new Energy Mobilization Board and conservation measures. [Page A1.]

title: CORRECTION
description: The role of some officials affiliated with the C.I. Planning Corporation was incorrectly stated in Business Day on Thursday. The officials resigned from C.I. Realty Investors as part of a transaction in which C.I. Planning agreed to sell its interest in C.I. Realty Investors.

title: Creeping Sloth
description: Mayor Koch has declared this to be New York City cleanup week. After a threemonth tugboat strike, during which the layers of litter and garbage have settled like the strata over Schliemann's Troy, the Mayor is right to tell us it's time to begin polishing the big apple. We'll have to die it out first.

title: Blast Kills 18 in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 15 (UPI)  At least 18 people were killed when chemicals stored in a basement exploded this weekend. The blast ripped through the roof of a fourstory building and toppled adjoining apartment houses, authorities said today. Police said 59 people were injured, many critically, and four missing persons were believed buried under tons of debris.

title: On Jets No. 1 Quarterback
description: AS a Jet rookie Richard Todd got into the elevator at the training camp dormitory. Suddenly, Godwin Turk, a massive linebacker, turned off the lights and picked Todd up and pounded him against the elevator walls. Then he began punching him. Turk pressed the button for the 13th floor. He snared Todd and dragged him into a room and opened the window. Turk shoved Todd's head out the window and Todd, petrified, believed he was going to be tossed out. It was all a big joke to Turk, who began laughing.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 354-3900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 3.3900, WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WIIITE PLAINS 9-5300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470509; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 669-1800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: 3 Westinghouse Unions on Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, Monday, July 16 (AP) Three unions representing about 37,400 workers went on strike against Westinghouse Electric Corporation at 12:01 A.M. today, after a collapse in negotiations, officials said.

title: Dance: Canadians Revive Le Loup
description: ALTHOUGH great ballets are often collaborations between distinguished artists, collabo- rations can go awry, as the National Ballet of Canada demonstrated Saturday night at the New York State Theater by reviving Le Loup as a curtainraiser for Giselle.

title: Dance: Summergarden
description: ONE of the concerns of experimental modern dance, particularly that influenced by the avantgarde Judson Theater movement of the 1960's, is the environment or surroundings of a dance. The Museum of Modern Art has opened its free Summergarden Festival, held on Fridays and Saturdays in its Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden, to a monthlong series of programs by familiar and new exponents of postmodern dance of the last decade, presented under the aegis of the experimental School for Movement Research.

title: Mets Stifled by Giants, 40
description: Yesterday the Mets and San Francisco Giants played one of those hotsummer baseball games in which a big inning threatens but never comes. There wasn't even a little inning for the Mets and there were only dribs and drabs for the Giants.

title: U.S. Modifies Steel Quotas
description: The Government has modified its quotas on imported specialty steels to meet objections raised by Japan, Sweden, Canada and other exporting nations, the Administration's chief trade negotiator, Robert S. Strauss, announced over the weekend.

title: BILL TO SEEK LIMIT ON POLITICAL GIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  A bipartisan campaign to limit the amount of money that a Congressional candidate may accept in campaign contributions from special interests will be opened this week in the House.

title: Desai, After a Long Quest, Won Premiership After Reaching 80's.
description: He had always wanted to be Prime Minister of India, but it was not until he had reached an age at which most men have long been retired that Morarji Ranchhodji Desai achieved his ambition.

title: Holocaust to Be Repeated In September on NBCTV
description: Holocaust, the television drama about families and individuals involved in the Nazi extermination of the Jews and other groups, will be rebroadcast on NBCTV during four nights beginning Sept. 10.

title: Deaths
description: GRABELArthur. The Master. Officers and Brethren of Robert Fulton Paul Revere Lodne z929 F & AM sorrowfully announces the passing of our Esteemed Brother. Funeral service July 16, 1:45 P.M. at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, N.Y.

title: Orioles, Red Sox Triumph
description: While the Boston Red Sox were completing a threegame sweep of the A's with a 32 victory in Oakland yesterday, the Baltimore Orioles were maintaining their twogame lead over Boston in the American League East with 61 triumph over the Seattle Mariners in the Kinedome.

title: Tracer of Those Who Neglect To Turn In Stock Certificates
description: Alexander B. Miller is a self-proclaimed mopup man  the owner and president of the Shareholder Communications Corporation, which exists to assist corporations locate the relatively few shareowners who neglect to turn in stock certificates that are no longer valid and persuade them to do so.

title: Part Homily, Part Piogram
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  Before his inauguration as President, Jimmy Carter remarked that he was determined to reform the nation's energy habits even if it costs me another term.

title: Soviet Astronauts Set Record
description: MOSCOW, July 15 (UPI)  Two Soviet astronauts aboard the orbiting Salyut 6 space laboratory today set a space flight endurance record of 140 days. The mission commander, Vladimir Lyakhov, and the flight engineer, Valery Ryumin, who were launched into space aboard their Soyuz 32 capsule Feb. 25, shattered the old mark of 139 days, 14 hours and 48 minutes set last November by the Soyuz 29 astronauts, Vladimir Kovalenok and Aleksandr Ivanchenkov.

title: Music: Soviet Emigres Play Mozart and Haydn
description: IF calling a summer concert series a festival means anything, it is that the performances are prepared with special care, and there is some element of novelty about the music or the players. Needless to say, many summer festivals aren't festivals at all. But, judging from its penultimate concert Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, the sixday Soviet Emigre Music Festival, which ended yesterday, was a festival in fact as well as name.

title: Notes on People
description: The classified advertisement might have said something like 21 Rms, Riv Vu, but, of course, one doesn't take out such notices for the late Nelson A. Rockefeller's summer home in Seal Harbor, Me.

title: JazzBlues: Sunnyland Slim
description: THE new jazz and blues series at the Squat Theater on West 23d Street got under way Friday, Saturday and Sunday with a rare New York appearance by Sunnyland Slim, a sturdy, twofisted blues and barrelhouse pianist who has been an important figure on the Chicago scene since the 1940's. Reports indi- sated that his hastily assembled back- ing band was having trouble jelling earlier in the weekend, but by the late show on Saturday night it was turning out tight, -first-class music, and Slim was relaxed and sparkling.

title: With Chilling Casualness, Refugees on Indonesian Island Tell of Piracy and Drownings
description: BUTON, Indonesia, July 14  They tell how they got here with a casualness that is chilling. Extortion, piracy, re- jection, payoffs, rapes and drownings were all part of it.

title: Moderate Financing Activity Planned
description: Interest rates rose and bond prices fell last week as the credit markets continued to retreat from the high point of their recent rally, reached on July 3. This week, the fixedincome markets face a moderately active schedule of new financing as they try to analyze the President's message this evening..

title: Carter Speech Scores in a Midwest TV Poll
description: COLUMBUS, July 15  President Carter got good marks on his nation- wide address tonight from Cablevision viewers in the Columbus area, with most of the respondents to an instan- taneous electronic sampling saying that they now felt more optimistic about the country's energy future and more confident in the President's lead- ership.

title: Rules Come Out Today On Raising Gas Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Energy Department officials labored today to complete new rules that are expected to raise gasoline prices 3 to 5 cents a gallon and limit the number of service stations being built.

title: Two Quebec Banks Seek National Rank in Merger
description: MONTREAL, July 15  While the Province of Quebec is trying to decide whether to remain part of Canada, its two large, predominantly French-language banks are setting out to challenge the Britishdominated industry.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Bobby Douglass, the former pro quarterback who signed last week to pitch in the Chicago White Sox minor league system, is but one of a large number of athletes who have tried two sports in a big way. Many, like Donglass, Rick Leach, Kirk Gibson and Brad Van Pelt, have been torn between baseball and football, but there have perhaps been even more in baseball and basketball. In fact, if you wanted to field a baseball team loaded with basketball talent, you would have some good pitchers to start with:

title: 4 Marines Are Wounded, 2 Held In a Shooting at Camp Pendleton
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 15 (AP)  Four marines were wounded by pistol shots at a barracks at this southern California military base, and two marines were taken into custody, officials reported today.

title: Bridge:
description: In one of the most dramatic conclusions to an international championship, Italy won the European championship Saturday in Lausanne, Switzerland, and qualified to play in the world team championship in Rio de Janeiro next October. The winners were Benito Garozzo, Giorgio Belladonna, Arturo Franco, Vito Pittala, S. Di Stefano and Lorenzo Lauria.

title: Players Pick Their Own AllStars
description: DESPITE some heavy sniping at the public voting for baseball's 5Uth AllStar Game, to be played at the Kingdome in Seattle tomorrow night, the players in the major leagues concur to a remarkable degree with the fans selections for the starting teams.

title: INDIAN LEADER QUITS AFTER MANY DEFECT FROM RULING PARTY
description: NEW DELHI, July 15  Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai, faced With a censure vote in Parliament tomorrow, reluctantly bowed today to the pleas of his dwindling political allies and resigned.

title: Leading Merger Managers
description: Morgan Stanley & Company led the investment banking industry for the third consecutive year of the current takeover boom in the dollar volume of completed deals managed, according to an industry tally.

title: Stage: Spell #7 by Ntozake Shange
description: SEEING Ntozake Shange's Spell #7 again, in a revised and somewhat tightened version, strengthens the feeling that this is a most lovely and powerful work.

title: A Nudge for Fathers Who Forget . . .
description: It isn't the title of an old Shirley Temple song, nor is it a new cannedlaughter situation comedy. It's Daddy, Don't Forget and it's the brainchild of three women who describe it as a buying service for fathers who are separated from their children.

title: New York City Stores Report Strong June Sales
description: Retail sales in New York City remained strong during June, despite four store fires and several days of unseasonally cold weather, while suburban store business reflected the adverse effects of the gasoline shortage for the second straight month, according to reports from leading retailers.

title: A Boxing Buff Buys The. Ring Magazine
description: The collector whose rock garden includes a 700pound cornerstone of the original Yankee Stadium and whose hats includes models worn by Andrew Jackson and W.C. Fields has just taken over the greatest collection in boxing the Hall of Fame, Ring magazine and all. In a sense, Bert Randolph Sugar has collected an entire era.

title: Events
description: MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL: ORCHESTRAL CONCERT, Avery Fisher Hall, 8. Precancert, recital, 7.

title: A SIXPOINT PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  President Carter, conceding failings in his own leadership and assailing a crisis of con- fidence among Americans, proposed to- night a sixpoint package of energy proposals intended to save 4.5 million barrels of oil a day by 1990.

title: Nicaragua Rebels Say U.S. Is Ready to Back Regime Led by Them
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 15 Members of the Nicaraguan rebel junta say they have satisfied American concerns over their plans to succeed President Anastasio Somoza Debayle and that a special State Department envoy has assured them of support from the United States.

title: Archdiocese Denies Request for Galante Funeral Mass
description: Invoking a rarely used provision of ecclesiastical law, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York refused yesterday to allow a funeral mass to be offered for Carmine Galahte, the reputed underworld leader slain last week. A funeral mass for. an alleged Galante associate slain with him was approved, however.

title: Khomeini Aide Is Shot in Teheran; Terrorists in South of Iran Kill Nine
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 15  A close aide to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was shot today by unknown assailants here, and at least nine people were killed in terrorist attacks in the southern Iranian port city of Khurramshahr.

title: Beaths
description: ROBINSON--Glare (Wheeler). on July 14, formerly of Elizabeth. N.J.. at the King James Nursing Home, Middletown, N.J., wife of the late Henry Pearson Robinson, mother of William W. Robinson and Mrs. Clarence (Helen) Carter. Also survived by four grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory to the Memorial Fund of the First Presbyterian Church, Broad St. Elizabeth, N.J., would be appreciated.

title: Caramoor: Berlioz's Romeo
description: OVER the years, the Caramoot Festival in Katonah, N.Y., has devoted itself chiefly to the presentation of recitals and chamber music in the Spanish courtyards of the mansionmuseum and of symphonic or operatic works of relatively modest propOrtions in the openair Venetian Theater. By and large, however, big Romantic works customarily associated with expansive symphonic sonorities and effects have been avoided.

title: Yankees Beaten On Homer in 9th
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 15  Lou Piniella was saying before today's game that after the AllStar break the Yankees will have to win the games that are seemingly locked up in the late inninas.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With no outs and a runner on first base, a ground ball is hit to the first baseman. The runner stays on the bag and is tagged by the first baseman, who then steps on the bag. Is this a dou- ble play?

title: Borg Beats Nastase In Davis Cup Play
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 15 (UPI)  Bjorn Borg powered his Swedish team to a 32 victory over Rumania today in the European Zone B tennis semifinals of the Davis Cum

title: Republicans Call Energy Speech Political and Vague; O'Neill Confident Congress and People Will Respond
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Republicans united tonight in attacking President Carter's energy speech, calling it political in purpose, incomplete in scope and uncertain in its forecast of his will and ability to lead.

title: Highway Filling Stations Open, but Not Local Ones
description: Although large numbers of neighborhood filling stations were closed yesterday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, gasoline was readily available at stations along highways and parkways. Travelindustry officials ex- pressed concern that with more motorists- driving again, the supply situation would deteriorate toward the end of the month.

title: Susan Goodman Married to Glenn Goldstein
description: Susan Karelson Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Goodman of Danbury, Conn., was married there yesterday to Glenn Stephen Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Goldstein of Brooklyn. Rabbi Jerome R. Malino, president of tbe Union of American Hebrew Congregations, performed the ceremony at the United Jewish Center.

title: 4,000 March For Rescue Of Refugees
description: Four thousand people, most of them ChineseAmericans, gathered across from the United Nations at noon yesterday to protest the plight of the Vietnamese boat people and to appeal to the United Nations, the United States and the countries neighboring Vietnam to rescue the refugees.

title: Carey Considers Mental Director To Head Prisons
description: Governor Carey has reportedly chosen his Mental Retardation Commissioner to replace Richard D. Hongisto, the Correctional Services Commissioner who resigned last month after a lengthy political battle with the State Senate over his confirmation.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Focusing on Home Video With Original Programs
description: John A. Friede is one of the growing number of businessmen who hope to profit from the anticipated boom in home video cassettes ancl video disks. Mr. Friede, president of the Video Tape Network, already has a group of programs prepared and ready for distribution to the home market.

title: Alfred Werner, Critic and Author
description: Alfred Werner, an art critic and author who wrote extensively on European intellectual matters, died Saturday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Recession Study Maps Regional Effect
description: The Northeast and the Middle West regions of the United States will bear the brunt of this year's expected recession, according to a report today from the Conference Board's Regional Eco, nomic Forum, a gathering of seven economists from different parts of the country. The Western and Southern re- gions will feel relatively little impact, the forum economists predicted.

title: Audit Faults New York an Bus Breakdowns
description: New York City's buses break down alMost twice as often, for the distances they travel, as the buses of 13 other major cities, according to an audit released yesterday by the office of City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Alcoholism

title: Sports Today
description: Eddie Gregory vs. Freddy Brown, 10round lightheavyweight bout, at the 369th Regiment Armory, Fifth Avenue and 193d Street, first preliminary, 7:30 P.M.

title: The Region
description: HADDAM, Conn. (UPI)  One of four steam generators at the 11-yearold Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant was shut down on Saturday night because a primary seal on a reactorcooling pump had malfunctioned, Northeast Utilities said yesterday. The other generators continued to produce power.

title: U.S. Policy On Cooling In Effect
description: Beginning today, the President's order to save energy by limiting the use of air conditioning in the nation's commercial and government buildings goes into effect, and stores are among the approximately five million buildings subject to the rules.

title: Concert: Hudson Series Going On at Lyndhurst
description: SUMMER of Music on the Hudson, at the historic Lyndhurst estate in Tarrytown, likes to style itself New York's Tanglewood, and there pre similarities. As at Tanglewood, the grounds provide both a pleasant setting for outdoor music and generpus space for picnicking before and during the symphony concerts, which are being presented there every Saturday night through Aug.11.

title: Israel Bids U.S.Replace 40,000 Burned Dollars
description: JERUSALEM, July 15 (Reuters) Israel's police force has appealed to America's Federal Reserve Bank to replace 40,000 dollars that were burned in an incinerator because they were mistakenly thought to be counterfeit.

title: As Talmadge Fortunes Wane, Criticism Intensifies
description: ATLANTA, July 15  A city bus chugged slowly past the Atlanta City Hall on Friday. Inside, Mayor Maynard Jackson was plotting the defeat of Senator Herman E. Talmadge in 1980. A block further on, it passed the Georgia Capitol, where Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller was plottine the same thing.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Acuity Systems Inc., a producer of electrooptical systems for the eyecare market and a subsidiary of Simmonds Precision Products Inc., has named Robert A. Carlson president.

title: Anastasio Somoza Debayle
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jul 15 When street riots announced the beginning of serious political unrest here 18 months ago, there were some reports that President Anastasio Somoza De-

title: Boston Bids a Musical Farewell to Fiedler
description: BOSTON, July 15  If there were tears shed for Arthur Fiedler here tonight, they were lost somewhere amid the roar of cannon fire, the hiss of fireworks, the pealing of church bells and the tumultuous excitment of a city bidding a joyous farewell to a man whose grace and charm made him Boston's leading citizen and a worldwide symbol for 50 years.

title: . . . And a Lock for Young TV Addicts
description: Until recently, the routine in the Morton Werner home in Clayton, Mo., could have been duplicated in almost any American household with children. Kenny Werner, 11 years old, would bracket his day with large chunks of television viewing. He would watch it in the morning before leaving for school, in the afternoon after school and some more in the evening.

title: Reports Say Rikers I. Lease Will Increase City's Costs
description: If Rikers Island is leased to New York State, the resulting changes in New York City's prison system will cost the city $73.5 million in added construction expenses and as much as $13 million a year in higher operating expenses, according to two confidential city reports.

title: Bronx Boy, 3, Falls Four Stories
description: A 3-year-old Bronx boy was listed in critical condition at Jacobi Hospital yesterday after falling four stories from his apartmenthouse window while playing with two other children. The police said the boy, Juan Medina of 2376 Webster Avenue, fell at about 10 P.M. Saturday.

title: Radio
description: 8:159, WQXR. Rosamunde: Excerpts, Schubert; Il Trovatore: Act II, Ballet Music, Verdi.

title: Recall Petitions Get Check By Man Obliged to Be Fair
description: Now that New York City has been handed those thousands of petitions to let the voters recall elected officials, the man in the middle is David N. Dinkins, the City Clerk.

title: Business Praises Carter Concept But Awaits Energy Plan Details
description: Business leaders and energy experts reached after President Carter's speech generally supported his tough stance on the need to cope with the energy shortage, but most had questions concerning the specifics of his plans.

title: Deaths
description: ACAMPORAAngelo Anthony, M.O.. on July 14, beloved husband of Anne and dear father of Carol Riechers and Robert, brother of Michael and Mary BeIlone. Also survived by sov on grandchildren. Reposing at Bre. glia Funeral Home, 260 Atlantic Ave., East Rockaway, Lynbrook, until Wednesday, 9:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Raymond's R.C. Church. 10 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Letters
description: The similarity between the current fuel crisis and the production of synthetic rubber during World War II, mentioned in the June 26 article by Richard Halloran, affords a few lessons pertinent to the development of policies in the immediate future.

title: Court Dismisses State's Civil Suit To Oust Esposito
description: A civil suit brought by New York State against Meade H. Esposito, the, Kings County Democratic leader, was dismissed for the second time in, State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday. The suit could have resulted in his removal from the party post.

title: Around the Nation
description: HONOLULU, July 16 (AP)  A, state judge today ordered Hawaii's 1,800 striking police officers to end their walkout and return to work immediately.

title: Experts Say Motivation Counts As Temperatures Rise at Work
description: Workers may feel mildly uncomfortable with the temperature at 78 degrees, researchers and physiologists say, but if it affects their productivity, the explanation is more likely to be found in motivation than in physiology.

title: Giants Like Their Candidates for Fullback
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 16 When Larry Csonka was on his way back to Don Shula in Miami, the player expected to replace him on the Giants had his right shoulder in a sling, carried his left wrist in a cast and was taking an advanced course in anatomy.

title: Audit Finds Misclassifications of Employees at City U.
description: Librarians, counselors and administrators at the City University of New York have been wrongly classified as professors at a yearly cost of more than $500,000 in extra salaries and benefits, an audit by the State Comptroller charged yesterday.

title: U.S. Aides Still Hopeful On Korean Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  North Korea has rejected a proposal by President Carter and South Korea for threeway talks, but American officials do not consider the proposal a dead letter.

title: Lionel Hanover Scores As Roosevelt Opens Meet
description: WESTBURY, N.Y., July 16  Lionel Hanover, driven by John Simpson Jr., and Thats Terrific, with Billy Popfinger in the sulky, posted victories in two divisions of the Sire Stakes last night as Roosevelt Raceway opened a 36night meeting, its third of four for 1979.

title: Bronx Arts Group. Sets Free COncerts
description: Free outdoor concerts will be given by the Bronx Arts Ensemble weekends next month at various locations in the Bronx. On Saturdays, the group will perform on the mall at the New York Botanical Garden. Southern Boulevard and 200th Street. Sunday concerts will be given at Van Cortlandt Mansion in Van Cortlandt Park, Broadway and 246th Street. Performances on both days will be at 3 P.M. If it rains, the concerts will be held indoors at both locations.

title: Ballet: Mary jago As Giselle
description: THE National Ballet of Canada's summer season at the New York State Theater came to a triumphant close Sunday afternoon with a performance of Peter Wright's beautiful  and here beautifully realized  production of Giselle. Rudolf, Nureyev is one of the great Albrechts, and so his glowing performance in that role came as no surprise. What was surprising was that Mary Jago, a small, blond dancer who looks like a soubrette anci dances with a quite contemporary piquant edge, made such a memorable Giselle.

title: Museum Buys Mozart MS.
description: Mozart's Haffner Symphony was played in the opening concert of this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival in Avery Fisher Hall last night, and by coincidence it was announced yesterday afternoon that the holograph manuscript of the symphony had been acquired by the Pierpont Morgan Library.

title: Coalition to Study Effect of Agent Orange on G.I.'s
description: Groups of Vietnam veterans, joined by scientists, public interest lawyers and church organizations, announced the formation of tncoalition yesterday to deal with the unresolved problem of Agent Orange.

description: Robert L. Douglas, the oldest living member of basketball's Hall of Fame and the founder of the barnstorming New York Renaissance team, died yesterday at his home at 45 West 135th treat in Manhattan. He was 96 years old.

title: Market Place
description: COALRELATED stocks were the initial winners in response to the energy program President Carter unveiled Sunday night and amplified somewhat yesterday in his speech in Kansas City.

title: Interest Rates Decline On Home Mortgages
description: Interest rates on residential mortgages continued to drop yesterday in the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation's weekly purchase of home loans.

title: Cost of Repairs At Atomic Plant Is $320 Million
description: PARSIPPANY, N.J., July 16 (UPI) The,General Public Utilities Corporation said today that a study has found no reason so farwhy the company's Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania cannot be detontaminatecU and returned to service.

title: Jersey Legislature Approves Plan for a Transit Authority
description: TRENTON 17  A weary and fraclious New Jersey State Assembly shortly after 2 A.M.. today, approved a coritroversial transportation authority, to Own and run railreads and buses in the state The vote; after 16 hours of Maneuvering, was 42 to25.,The Margin was one Vote more than needed: More than a score of lobbyists worked throughout the day to get the final. Votes for the measure. The bill was sent to Governor Byrne, who has pushed for the measure and was expected to sign it quickly. Aides to the Goveron had to compete with a swltering hot day and a violent thunderstorm for the attention of the legislators.
