description: AllStar Game, in the Kingdome, Seattle. (TelevisionChannel 4, 8:15 P.M. RadioWCBS, 8:25 P.M.)

title: Tornado Strikes Cheyenne, Killing Child and Destroying Many Homey
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., July 16 (AP)  A slowmoving tornado rolled through two subdivisions and a trailer park in northern Cheyenne today, destroying hundreds of homes and causing at least one death and 37 injuries, the authorities said.

title: Debating the Treaty: What They Are Saying
description: It is not in the American interest to have the Soviet leadership conclude that negotiations with the United States are hopeless. The goal should be to supercede SALT II as quickly as possible with a treaty that moves the world to real arms reeduction.  Richard J. Barnet, Institute of Policy Studies.

title: Nation's Newspaper Editorialists Split Over Carter's Energy Talk
description: The Chicago SunTithes: Sunday night; Americans saw a more somber, yet stronger President Carter than they have seen before:. Monday they saw a more determined and more specific, Carter than, they saw Sunday, as he filled in soMeblanks that had been left in his primetime speech. On balance, we think Carter has faced up to the leadership and energy challenges that threaten the coutry. And though questions remain, he has proposed generally vigorous, positive actions that deserve support.

title: Is: What Next After Pet Deal?
description: CHICAGO, July 16  Less than year after its hardfought takeover battle, IC Industries is comfortably assimilating Pet Inc. into its diverse family, says William B. Johnson, IC's chairman and chief executive, in view generally backed.by security analysts.

title: Ford Heir Denied Move Against Father's Will
description: DETROIT, July 16 (AP)  Benson Ford Jr., an heir to the Ford Motor Company, was denied permission in court here today to attack the will of his late father.

title: Somoza Retires 100 Senior Officers Amid Signs His Resignation Nears
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 16 Amid strong rumors that he will go into exile tomorrow, President Anastasio Somoza Debayle retired almost 100 senior National Guard officers today, clearing the way for a ceasefire in the Nicaraguan civil war soon after he leaves the country.

title: Goldin Drops Bank After Bond Loss
description: The bank that lost $397 million in nonnegotiable bonds owned by city pension funds will be replaced as the custodian of $8.5 billion in pensionfund paper, city officials said yesterday.

title: Take Me Out to the Pol Game
description: LANCASTER, Pa.  Tonight we'll watch that familiar midsummer attraction, baseball's AllStar Game. Just as the game is familiar so is the controversy surrounding the selection of the players. The fans who choose them, it is argued, are not always motivated by the laudable sentiment of Why not the best?

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest rates rose and bond prices declined yesterday as the credit markets showed their disappointment with President Carter's speeches on energy.

title: United Technologies Net Rises 40.3% in Quarter
description: The United Technologies Corporation yesterday reported a 40.3 percent rise in secondquarter profits to $79.4 million, or $1.74 a share, from $56.6 million, or $1.36 a share, in the comparable three months last year.

title: Camp for Adults Who Are Young at Heart
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., July. 16. Camp Carefree is something to write home about. Billed as the country's first oldfashioned ldddie camp for adults, it opened last week on a 320acre estate in the Berkshires with a staff of nine counselors and an enrollment of 21 campers, none of whom bothered to sew name tags in their gym shorts.

title: Advertising
description: With all its faults, there is still nothing quite like televikion for Stimulating Censumers to take actien. Of course, it's not always eco nominally efficient to use it.

title: In Brief: The Day's Energy News
description: President Carter, following up his Sunday night call for unity to come to grips with energy problems and a crisis of confidence in the nation, spelled out many details of his energy program yesterday, speaking in Kansas City in the morning and Detroit in the afternoon. Following are highlights of the day's energy developments:

title: More U.S. Corn Sold to Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  The Soviet Union has bought an additional 800,000 metric tons of United States grain for delivery in 197980, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Business Records
description: Involuntary Petition Filed Against:

title: Dr. Louis Brinberg Is Dead at 61; Conducted.Cardiology Research
description: Dr. Louis Brinberg, a cardiologist, who had conducted extensive research in cardiology nt Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 61 years old.

title: TV: Where's Poppa? May Be Series
description: NEARLY 10 years ago, there was a movie called Where's Poppa? The plot involved an aging young man's frantic efforts to get rid of his elderly, dotty mother. The happy ending had the old lady being dumped in a home for the aged. Some found the film an outrageous farde. Others, probably a majority, thought it was simply outrageous, sprinkled with generous pinches of tastelessness.

title: Yastrzemski Is Shifted to First; Ryan, Carlton AllStar Starters
description: SEATTLE, July 16  For the first time in the 50game history ofbaseball's AllStar Game, three outfielders from the same team were voted into a starting outfield, but Jim Rice, Fred Lynn and Carl Yastrzemski of the Boston Red Sox will not be out there together for the American League tomorrow night.

title: 38,000 Cram Biggest Boat People Camp
description: PULAU BIDONG, Malaysia, July 15 No boats carrying Vietnamese refugees have slipped through a Malaysian blockade for about six weeks, and for the first time since this island camp was opened almost a year ago the population is declining.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter put a $140 billion cost on his energy program he campaigned vigorously in Kansas City and Detroit. The entire amount, he said, would be funded by his proposed windfall tax oilcompany profits. The unparalleled peacetime investment needed, he said, so that never again will our nation's independence be hostage to foreign oil. [Page A1.]

title: Carter Proposal Poses Problem for New York On ImportedOil Shift
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  President Carter's energy program is likely to pose a special hardship to the New York area because of the projected high cost of shifting from imported oil, on which the region historically depends, local energy officials said today.

title: NA.S.L. to Review Cosmos Brawl
description: Films of the 14minute fight that marred the cosmos 42 loss to the Vancouver Whitebaps in East Rutherford NJ., on Sunday night will be examined by Ted Pa ha; the North American Soccer League's director...of operations,. and Keith Walker, the supervisor of officials, the league announced yesterday. The Cosmos are contending that Keith Styles, the referee, allowed the game to get out of control.

title: C.I.A. Used Satellites for Spying On Antiwar Protesters in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)  The Central Intelligence Agency used intelligence satellites in the late 1960's to spy on American students engaged in antiwar demonstrations, a series of formerly classified documents disclosed today.

title: Goldin Reports Reimbursing City For Overdue Private Phone Bills
description: After a delay of up to two years, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin has reported reimbursing New York City for personal and political calls that he made on his municipaloffice telephones.

title: Delegate Says She Was Stopped From Questioning the President
description: DETROIT, July 16  A delegate to the convention of the Communications Workers of America alleged this evening that she was prohibited from participating in the questionandanswer session of President Carter earlier today because she had planned to speak against the President.

title: Environmentalists Fear A Retrenching by Carter
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  President Carter has set in motion a major test of priorities between the nation's decadelong commitment to protecting the environment and a new quest for selfsufficiency in enemy.

title: Driver Facing 4 Murder Counts In Five Car Collision Last June 8
description: A 20yearold Queens man was charged with four counts of murder last night as a result of a fivecar collision on the Grand Central Parkway on June 8.

title: Passenger Group Seeks Regrounding of DC10's
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  The Airline Passengers Association told Federal appeals court today that DC10 jets should be grounded again until the plane's design problems are solved.

title: Nixon Is Said to Intend To Move to New York
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) Richard M. Nixon is not going to buy a new home in San Clemente but will move back to New York City at the end of the year, a family friend said today.

title: Start of G.M. Talks Interrupted by Organizing Dispute in Oklahoma
description: DETROIT, July 16  The first day of contract negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation ended on a surprisingly sour note early this afternoon. Union leaders postponed further talks until Friday in protest against what they alleged was company interference with its efforts to organize workers at a key G.M. plant in Oklahoma City.

title: Many New Yorkers Back Carter's Call for National Spirit
description: I think he's, finally on the right Magda Katz said yesterday of President Carter's assertion that Americans were in the throes of a crisis of confidence about their nation's future.

title: U.S. Employment Slips
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  The number of working Americans declined slightly during the second quarter of 1979, the first dip In employment since the 197475 recession, the Labor Department reported today. The Labor Department said that employment totaled 96.9 million during the AprilJune quarter, down from 96.6 million during the first three months of the year.

title: AirConditioners In Offices in City Put at 780 Level
description: New Federal regulations went into effect yesterday.raising theleyels for starting airconditioning in businesses and public buildings to 78 degrees, but enforcement was barely, organized and compliance was mostly voluntary.

title: Dr. Samuel Kutash, Psychologist
description: Dr. Samuel B. Kutash, a clinical psychologist and professor of psychology at Rutgers University, died of cancer Saturday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 67 years old and lived in Maplewood, N.J.

title: Steel Output Down by 3.1%
description: NEW YORK, July 16 (AP)  Steel production fell to 2.68 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 3.1 percent from the preceding week's 2.76 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported today.

title: Carter Comments Buoy Atomic Power's Backers
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) Proponents of atomic power, a topic not mentioned in President Carter's energy address last night, were reassured today by comments from the President and Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger.

title: Revisions Appear Likely
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  President Carter appeared today to have succeeded in rousing Congress to act on energy legislation before recessing for the summer, but the results may not resemble White House proposals too closely.

title: Tracking Down Loose Rocks at Niagara Falls
description: Robert F. Anderson, an instrumentation specialist with the Army Corps of Engineers, leaving Niagara Falls after checking seismic monitoring system he designed for Terrapin Point. Government geologists, noting a reading that indicated rock movement under Horseshoe Falls, warned of a serious possiblility that rock movement might trigger the most massive rockslide in falls modern history, and have closed that area to tourists.

title: Still, Questions About the DC10
description: Air travelers seemed willing to entrust their lives to the DC10 the moment the Federal Aviation Administration lifted its ban on the Jumbo jet. The F.A.A., the airlines and the plane's manufacturer all believe the plane is now safe. Federal regulators do appear to have resolved the specific problem that caused an American Airlines DC10 to crash in Chicago on May 25, incurring more deaths than any other air disaster in this country. But the episode has also raised more general safety issues that have not yet been resolved. The immediate goal of the investigation  the most thorough in two decades  was to pinpoint the reason for the crash and prevent it from happening again. Investigators concluded that improper handling during maintenance caused a bad crack in an enginemount. As the illfated plane lifted off the ground, the left engine and its mount ripped away from the wing, the slats on the wing's leading edge retracted and lost lifting power and the plane rolled to the left and crashed. Warning devices that might have alerted the pilot to take corrective action were knocked out when the engine broke away. Subsequent inspections found damage in the engine mounts of other DC10's as well.

title: Physicist Challenges Theory on Sunspots
description: THE controversial theory that sunspot activity is the probable cause of major climatic changes on earth has been thrown into question by a Princeton University scientist.

title: Indian Politics in Crisis: Personalities, Not Policy
description: NEW DELHI, July 16  In the com mentaries on the resignation of Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai that appeared in the Indian press today, there was almost no mention of such national problems as rising inflation mounting labor unrest and renewed Outbreaks of violence between religions communities.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Gold prices hit record highs and the dollar plummeted against foreign currencies yesterday in reaction to President Carter's energy program.

title: Deaths
description: DOPPELTJacob. The Officers; Trustees, Directors, Administration, Principals, Ladies Auxiliary, Faculty and Membership of the shiva of Flatbush, record with deep sorrow the passing of Jacob DOCPelt, Honorary President and member of our Board of Trustees. It was during his term of office that the ground work was laid for the construction and completion of the Joel Braverman High School building. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Minnie, Honorary President of the Ladles Auxiliary and his children, all alumni of the Yeshiva, Joyce Milts, Sheila Kurtzee and Ira Doppelt.

title: Issue and Debate Soviet Edge in Heavy Missiles Under the New Pact
description: WASHINGTON July 16  With the Senate hearings MI the new strategic arms treaty under way for a week, the debate has begun to turn on a central question: whether the treaty, in giving the Soviet Unlon the right to deploy More than 300 heavy intercontinental Missiles, will provide it with an important military edge in the 1980's.

title: Junta Mapping Its Course
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 16 Members of the Nicaraguan revolutionary junta spent the.day today planning the actions they intend to take in the fmmediate aftermath of the anticipated resignation of President Somoza.

title: Dutchman Gains in Bike Race
description: L'ALPE D'HUEZ, France, July 16 In what was widely regarded as a last hurrah, Joop Zoetemelk of the Netherlands won the leg through the Alps in the Tour de France bicycle race today and took 47 seconds off the overall lead of France's Bernard Hinault, who finished third.

title: EDUCATION Foreign Testing Raises Questions
description: LONG before the recent national controversy over the value of coaching in preparing students for admissions tests, officials at some of the country's leading colleges and universities were concerned about coaching schools abroad, particularly in Taiwan.

title: Washington Ponders Island Description
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 It was the morning after President Carter's speech to the nation, and oneof his advisers was breathing easier, taking his time, stopping for breakfast at a McDonald's on his way to work. The President had said that Washington,. D.C., has become an island, unresponsive to the nation's needs, and now the adviser was explaining what Mr. Carter had meant.

title: City Getting Added Aid For Summer Recreation
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The Carter Administration has agreed to increase funds for the previously threatened Summer. Youth Recreation program, restoring money for services to 470,000 more youths in New York City.

title: Decaying Bodies Found In Mortuary ShUt in '78
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 16 (AP) Thirtyone decaying bodies were found today in an abandoned midtown mortuary, where they apparently had lain since the business closed nearly a year ago, the police said.in the basement there were caskets stacked three high, said Dr. Richard Biery, director of the city health department.

title: Fionnula Flanagan to Play James Joyce's Women

title: Torre's Outlook and Reputation Survive

His team was, as usual, last in war, last in peace and last in the National League's East.

title: Pops Starts Hunt for Fiedler Successor
description: BOSTON, July 16  The search for a successor to Arthur Fiedler as condu& tor of the Boston flops Orchestra began in earnest today following last,night's jubilant farewell concert on the banks of the Charles River.

title: JapaneseSaudi Project
description: TOKYO, July 16 (Reuters)  Japan and Saudi Arabia have agreed in principle to raise to 450,000 tons from 300,000 tons the annual production capacity of their joint ethylene project in Saudi Arabia, Japanese international trade and ministry officials said today.

description: BristolMyers yesterday reassigned all of the brands that were resigned May 21. by Young & Rubi cam, Which, asserted it could not make a reasonable profit on the business, with billing estimated at more than $25 million.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 16  President Ahmed Hassan alBaler of Iraq announced today that he was resigning for reasons of health.

description: WASHINGTON, July 16  While Democrats praised President Carter trying to rally the country on energy, publicans said today that his goals might be all right but his own lack of leadership remained a critical obstacle to reaching them.

title: Doctor Solves a Mystery, Links Tick Bite to Disease
description: WHEN a tick was removed from the scalp of Constantine Paleologos on June 12, the 5yearold boy's family had no idea that a medical mystery involving a rare and potentially fatal disease was about to unfold.more, said, It was my experience with tularemia that made me, think of it. After all, I've had a lot of experience With most of these diseases at age 71.

title: OPEC Releases Views on Plans
description: VIENNA, July 16 (AP) The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today welcomed President Carter's program to reduce oil consumption and said the marketing situation in oil was becoming more stable.

description: The Congoleurn Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had been offered $38 a share, or $445 million, for all its shares.

title: About Education
description: IN the 1960's, New Left educators viewed Maoist Chinese school reforms with admiration and as an example for American action. They pointed to the egalitarian proclamations of the CulturalRevolution as a model of classroom democracy. Student rebels hailed Chairman Mao Zedong's war on academic competition, examinations and grades; revisionist pedagogues hailed Peking's edicts against tracking placing students of similar ability in the same classrooms; radical social reformers admired the Cultural Revolution's alleged preferential treatment of workers and peasants children in university admissions. The end of quality controls appealed to those who, in the United States, urged the deschooling of society.

title: Rivals in India Start Frantic Hunt For Partners to Form a Coalition
description: NEW DELHI, July 16  A Deputy Prime Minister in the ousted Government of Morarji R. Desai crossed over to the opposition today and said he had broad support in Parliament for his bid to become the next Prime Minister of India.

title: Hutton, Paine Webber Quarterly. Results Off
description: The E. F. Hutton Group and Paine Webber Inc., two of the largest publicly owned brokerage firms, both reported yesterday that earnings for the quarter ended in June were somewhat lower than for the comparable period last year.

description: Judah A. Richards, chairman of the Jewish Information Bureau of New York City, a nonprofit agency that provides answers to inquiries on Judaism and Jewish activities, died Saturday at Long Island Jewish Hogpital in .Queens after a brief illness. He was 66 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

The job action was called to protest an interim fare increase of 10 cents a trip approved by the Public Service Commission. The drivers had asked for a 10.5 percent increase. Two cab associations called for the strike today and Tuesday from 6 A.M. to. 7:30 P.M.

title: Cobalt Is Stolen in Brooklyn
description: An estimated $850,000 worth of nonradioactive cobalt and ingots of tin were reported yesterday to have been stolen from a warehouse in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn that had been cicsed for two weeks for vacations. The police said 30 drums of cobalt and 300 ingots of tin had been stolen between June 29 and 7 A.M. yesterday, according to the owner of the cncern, the New Smelting and Re:. fining Company at 269 Freeman Street.

title: West Europe Gives Speech Mixed Reviews
description: PARIS July 16  President: Carter's latest energy stratey won a loyal though qualified welcome from Western; European leaders today but financial Markets turned thumbs down and financial experty: expiessed disappointment with the Sunday night.speech.

title: Power. Failures Afflict Boston
description: BOSTON, July 16 (AP)  More than 36,000 people were without power for short periods yesterday as power outages scattered hlackntits thrmeh the lloonn

title: Deaths

Fond sister of Pauline SteigerwaId, Fred Wolff and Helene Wolff. Services 11AM Wednesday at the John J Fox Funeral Home, 2060 Post Road, Larchrnont. Interment private.

title: Will Nolan Ryan Fan Five, in a Row?; Dave Anderson
description: SEATTLE, July It  He's 75 years' old now, but Carl Hubbell, still slim and listing to the left the way some lefthanded pitchers do, remains the essence of the AllStar Game for what he did 45 years ago. What he did was strike out, in succession, Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Jimmy Foxx, Al Simmons and Joe Cronin at the Polo

title: OPEC Ties In U.S. Held No Threat
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The billions of dollars invested in this country by oilproducing nations pose no immediate danger to the United States or its economy, according to a Congressional study released today.

title: Associated Press
description: BOMBER CRASHES ON WAY TO BEING SCRAPPED: Firemen poured water on ruins of warehouse destroyed by a B57 bomber yesterday in Salt Lake City. The plane, on Its way, to be scrapped, Ignited explosive materials when it hit bullding.:Two crewmen were slightly injured when they ejected from th'e bomber before the crash.

title: Study Urges Conversion Of 6 Power Plants to Coal
description: Six of New York State's oilburning power plants would be converted to coal under a plan to be put forward this week by the staff, of New YorA State's Puplic Service Commission.

title: Nations Seek Cocoa Accord
description: GENEVA, July 16  Cocoaconsuming and cocoaProducing countries resumed negotiations here today on an international pricestabilizing agreement that they were unable to reach at a first session held last February.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: IT began as little more than a lastditch maneuver by a 33yearold engineer to secure admission to the University of California Medical Schoolat Davis. Even before it was completed, however, the case of Bakke v. Regentiof the University of CantorWaled gained, national attention and mushroomed into one of the most controversial issues of the 1970's. The United States Supreme Court decision of October 1978 was a compromise, which superficially settled the controversy. But, according to Joel Dreyfuss, a reporter,.and Charles Lawrence 3d, a lawyer, the dangerously eruptive social problems illuminated by the Bakke case have yet to be resolved or even realistically addressed.

title: Chinese Reveal Antimalaria Drug
description: PEKING, July 16 (Reuters)  Chinese scientists have developed a new antimalaria drug that acts faster and is less toxic than the normal quininebased product, according to an article in the latest issue of China Reconstructs magazine.

title: Boise Cascade, Zellerbach Gain
description: Two major forest products companies  the Crown Zellerbach Corporation and the Boise Cascade Corportion  yesterday reported substantially higher profits for the second quarter, reflecting demand for newsprint, paper and other products along with higher prices and a lower tax rate.

title: U.S. Catholic Church Shows 233,144 Loss
description: The Roman Catholic Church in the United States showed a loss of 233,144 members last year from 1977, according to figures released recently.

title: Human Growth Hormone Is Produced in Laboratory
description: OUT of the laboratories of the genetic engineers, who work on one of the most exciting frontiers science, has come, now a replica of the human growth hormone molecule. This is the latest human hormone to be produced in the laboratory in recent months as a result of widespread and occasionally controversial research aimed at turning some bacteria into tiny hormone factories.

title: Duchess of Windsor Gaining
description: PARIS, July 16 (Reuters  The Duchess of Windsor is slowly recovering from a bacterial infection but is being kept under hospital care, a hospital spokes. man said today. The 82yearold Duchess, who was born in the United States, has been in the American Hospital in Neuilly for two months.

title: World News Briefs
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 16 (Reuters) Four Palestinian guerrillas who seized the Egyptian Einbassy here and held it for almost two days were moved today from a detention center to a closely guarded military prison.

title: Treasury Rates In Large Rise
description: Treasury bill rates showed sizable increases yesterday, climbing to their highest levels since early June in the Government's weekly auction of these shortterm securities.

title: FRANCIS E. JASPER
description: Francis E. Jasper, a former partner of Peat Marwick Mitchell & Company, died after a long illness yesterday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 65 years old.

title: Parliament in India
description: NEW DELHI, July 16 Following is a breakdown of the strengths of Indian political parties in the lower house of Parliament before and after the defections and realignments of the last week. The total membership is 543.

title: Economy Plan Offered ForNew Senate Offices
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)  A $137 million economy plan for completing the new Senate office building was. offered today, but'the proposal came under fire from one Senator who wants to mothball the projectbefore it gets more costly.

title: China Reports Gas Deposits
description: HONG KONG, July 16 (AP)  China has discovered natural gas deposits in the Gulf of Tonkin and in Southern China, John Kean,  chairman of the American Gas Association, said today.

title: Riding Casually to War
description: Once again, President Carter has defined the problem, boldly and correctly. Once again he proposes a war to rescue the country from a crippling dependence. He now realizes that arresting inflation and escaping recession depend on it. He understands that the nation's morale requires it. He finds the people ready to sacrifice to win this War.

title: Time Inc. Net Up 22.6% in Quarter
description: Time Inc. reported sharply higher secondquarter profits yesterday, largely on gains in its magazine publishing, television and paperproducts divisions.

title: Vast Powers, Funds For Energy Agency
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The Energy Security Corporation first proposed yesterday by President Carter would be an autonomous Federal enterprise with an unprecedented mandate to invest billions of dollars of public funds in private companies devoted to the exploitation of virtually all hYdiocarbons.

His dedication to the rabbinic community Was demonstrated through his active involvement in our most Important brograms. His wise counsel and dynamic leadership guided the Beard to greater service to the Jewish commun ity Inspired his colleagues with zeal for their sacred calling and enhanced the image of the American Rabbinate. A trailblazing educator and elo went preachervhe Matchedcreed with deed, words with work. His memory will surely inspire us to'continged sirVice to the Jewish community and

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  State officials said that almost. all state employees who walked off their jobs last week in an unauthorized strike had returned to Work yesterday. Between 6,000 and 14,000 clerical and administrative workers were estimated to have been on strike.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Reliance Group Inc., a leading insurance holding company, announced jointly yesterday with the Gelcp Corporation that the two had reached agreement in principle for the sale by Reliance of CTI International Inc., Its container leasing subsidiary, to Inc.,delco for $250 million. Gelco is a leading transportation renting and leasing company based in Eden Prairie, Minn.

title: Dr. Helmuth Nathan; Professor and Painter
description: Dr, Hehnuth Mahan, professor emeri. tus of Surgery and anatomy at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, died Sunday at his summer home at Southampton, L.I. An accomplished artist as well as a doctor, he was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Clerical Group Urges Americans to Support Carter Call to Action
description: Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders around the country rallied yesterday behind President Carter's appeal for a moral commitment to help solve the energy crisis.

title: Notes on People
description: The Capitol building in Washington is fairly, well, bustin out all over with busts of historic figures, but one of the most intriguing is stuck on top of some filing cases in the Office of the Architect of the Capitol.

title: Cutting Off the World to Spite Hanoi
description: Foreign aid, has no natural constituency in Congress, even though much of the money returns to this country through the purchase of Americanmade goods. Now, with Congress grasping for easy ways to cut spending and frustrated by a series of perceived foreign policy setbacks, sensible and practical aid programs are threatened by senseless and impractical gestures.

title: Gypsy Moths Invadin L. I.
description: BAYVILLE, L.I., July 16  Gypsy moths seemed to be in the air everywhere today an Long Island, from Manhasset to Montauk, as they hatched by the tens of thousands.from their brown cocoons, mated and laid eggs on trees whose leaves had already been eaten nearly bare by the voracious caterpillars, at an early stage of the moth.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Scattered clouds cover the North and Middle Atlantic States, central Florida and portions of the Gulf States. Thunderstorm clouds are Operant over the Northern Plains States, the 4001 Rockies, the central intermountain Region and the Plateau Region.

title: RCA Profit Up Despite Units' Lag
description: Slumping NBC Television earnings and a substantial loss at RCA Records sharply trimmed the RCA Corporation's secondquarter profits, RCA said yesterday.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of preciousmetals and foreignexchange futures shot upward yesterday in reaction to the President's longawaited addresses on the nation's energy problems. The same initial reaction sent prices of all financialinstrument futures tumbling.

title: L1011 Jet Halted by Threat
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 16 (UPI)  A telephoned bomb threat forced apelta Airlines jumbo jet to abort its takeoff last night, causing minor injuries to dozens of passengers who slid down evacuation chutes. A search of the L1011, with 201 passengers and a crew of 14 aboard, found no bomb. The flight was preparing to take off for Atlanta and Detroit when it was called back at 10:10 P.M. at Fort LauderdaleHollywood International Airport. Eight persons were taken to Broward Medical Center for treatment of back injuries and other ailments:

title: Peicival F. Brundage Dies at 87; Budget Chief Under Eisenhower
description: Percival F. Brundage, President Eisenhower's diredfor of the budget from 1956 to 1958 died yesterday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood; N.J. Mr. Brundage had been visiting his daughter, who lives in gidgewood. He lived in Washington and Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: Independents End Gas Strike
description: Many independent service station dealers in Pennsylvania and Delaware ended a threeday strike yesterday.

title: Letter
description: Mankind May Be Better. Off Without SALT II

title: Capital Speech Viewed By About 60 Million
description: President Carter's Sunday night address to the nation on energy was seen by an estimated 60 million people, network sources reported yesterday.

title: Liner America at Rest In Monrovia as a Hotel
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 16  The liner America, once the pride of the United States merchant fleet and more recently the shame of Venture Cruise Lines of New York, is docked at Monrovia.

title: 3 Experts Back Treaty as a First Step
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  Three former American arms control negotiators said today that the only realistic hope of persuading the Soviet Union to agree to deeper arms reduction was to ratify the strategic treaty pending before the Senate and proceed to negotiations on a subsequent treaty.

title: Stocks Rise Slightly in Slow Trading In Wake of Carter's Energy Speeches
description: Stock prices closed slightly higher yesterday as a hopedfor, broadbased rally failed to materialize. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 1.37 points to 839.90 as advances exceeded declines for the first time in five sessiring.

title: Deaths at 71 in Saragossa. Fire; 8 Others Still on the Critical List
description: SARAGOSSA, Spain, July 16 (UPI) Two more persons died today of injuries suffered lull fire in the Hotel Corona de Aragon, raising the death toll to 71, the local government said. Eight'others remained hospitalized in critical condition. The government had reported 72 people killed and 3 missing and presumed dead but lowered the figure during the weekend. The latest fatalities were Spaniards.

title: The Syrian Connection
description: WASHINGTON  A break. throught  exclaimed Ambassador Robert Strauss, after he had helped Egypt and Israel arrange a procedural. compromise for negotiating PalestInian autonomy on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip: He also visited Jordan and Saudi Arabia, two kingdoms whose support for the Camp David process is still considered essential; from all accounts, they seemed to hayed resisted his overtures.

title: News Summary
description: Energy spending of $140 billion in the next decade was announced by President Carter to end United States dependence on foreign oil. He said that the entire cost would be covered by a windfall profits tax on oil companies now before Congress. The President took his new energy program and a newly invigorated campaign style on the road, speaking in Kansas City, Mo., and Detroit and pledging new plans in coming months. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: Lunar Research Thrives In Wake Of Apollo
description: HOUSTON TO Dr. Gary Latham, it must have seemed like killing his own children. Spinning a small dial, he generated a threenumber computer command that, once transmitted, would shut off the last functioning scientific instruments, left on the moon by American astronauts.

title: Koch Considers Car Bans to cut Burning of Fuel
description: The banning of private cars on some city streets, which has met with mixed success in the past as a cleanair measure, may be tried again, but this time tb conserve enemy.

title: IN THE NATION After The Thunder.
description: As late as Friday; President Carterand his advisers were still, debating how.. accusatory his SturclaynighV ipeec to the nation should be. Should he severely Criticise Americans for their profligate energy habits? Or should he be optimistic about the ability of the nation to solve a tough problem?

title: Arena Stage to Perform At Hong KOng Festival
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The Arena Stage, the first American theater company invited to perform at the Hong Kong International Arts Festival, will present two productions at the eighth monthlong festival of Eastern and Western performing arts to be held next February.

title: GERTRUDE WHITMAN
description: Gertrude Wilitmin, a New York City publicrelations specialist, died of cancer Sunday at Sharp Memorial HosPital in San Diego. She was 74 years old and had lived in San Diego since her retirement in 1972.

title: Radio
description: 7.8 A.M., WNYC. Le Corsair Overture, Berlioz; L'Olimpiade, Overture, Pergolesi ; Peleus and Thetis, Overture, Boyce; Concerto No. 5, Vivaldi; Scipio, Overture, Handel.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of The Impresario and Abu Hassan at the Kennedy Center in Washington, published in The Times last Wednesday, incorrectly suggested that the director was Hugh Wheeler. Mr. Wheeler translated and adapted the libretto. The director was Jack O'Brien.

title: 12 Americans Explain Why They Dance Dutch
description: HAT is a nice Rochester girl like Eve Walstrum doing in a place like the Netherlands? Why did KarenTims, leave South Carolina for The Hague and Eric Newton leave the Martha Graham Dance Company for the Netherlands Dance Theater? It could have something to do with cheers, endless curtain calls and the kind of rave reviews that only a mother could find fault with. The 12 young Americans who are performing with the Netherlands company this week through Saturday at the City Center have seldom encountered anything like New York's reception. But for many, the decision to leave New York, dance capital though it may be, was a conscious one.

title: A Meager Clue, Sally, Cited in Galante Killing
description: Witnesses to last Thursday's slaying of Carmine Galante and two other men have given the police a possible lead to the identity of one of the gunmen: an overheard nickname, Sally.

title: Cardinal McIntyre of Los Angeles, Retired Archbishop, Is Dead at 93
description: LOS ANGELES, July 16  James Francis Cardinal McIntyre; the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Los Angeles from 1948 to 1970, died early today at St. Vincent's Hospital, where he had been confined for the last severilyetirs. He Was was years old.

title: OBSERVER
description: Two Mafia men have been assigned to execute Buck Rackets for giving himself airs, making unauthorized excursions to Jersey City:and otherwise getting too big for his britches.

title: Woman Wins uit In DES Case
description: In a groundbreaking verdict rendered yesterday in the State Supreme Court in the Bronx, a jury decided that a pharmaceutical company must pay S,500,000 in damages to a woman for c,ancercaused by DES, a drug given to her mother to prevent miscarriage, even though the victim failed to establish which company had actually manufactured the doses in question.

title: Science Watch
description: A University of Florida zoologist, who has been researching the human aging process for the past several years, believes that if cures were found for heart disease, cancer, kidney. dis ease and diabetes, other illnesses would become relatively bigger killers and man's lifespan would lengthen by only a few years.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the two Florida experts who were expelled earlier this month froth the American Contract Bridge. League declaredlast week that he and his partner had been railroaded.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FRONT AND CENTRAL Something practical has been added to one of the most rewarding walking tours in New York, those free,_ yearround Wednesday. explorations of the mysteries and architectural splendors of Grand Central Terminal. Instead of converging. at an obscure point in, the station's ramp network, the group now meets at the Chemical Bank Commuter Express branch, highly visible in the main concourse, beneath the huge Kodak sign. The hourlong tours depart at. 12:30 P.M., and the only requirements are foot power and curiosity.

title: Executive Demand Drops
description: A study has shown that the demand for business executives declined 9 percent nationwide during the second quarter of 1979 from the level in the comparable quarter of last year. Conducted by the accounting firm of Afthur Young & Company, the study said, that increased demand for general management and administration executives was offset by decreased demand in engineering and the sciences.

title: Hospital Pand Files Suit Over Medicaid Fee Plan
description: Saying its 72 member hospitals could ba Unfairly deprived of millions of dollars a year, the Greatet New york Hospital Asseciation began a court challenge to anew state plan for Medicaid payments In a suit filed in Federal Disrict Court in Brooklyn, the assaciation charged that the program, instituted March 1, violated Soolal Security laws and warned that if the. program were to continue, several hcispitals could be forced to close.

title: Carey Signs Measure Continuing Controls on Car Insurance Costs
description: ALBANY, July 16  Governor. Carey announced today that he had signed a bill extending for two years the requirement that the Superintendent of Insurance give prior approval to any insurance rate increases for private cars, taxicabs and buses. The new law eliminates the prior approval requirement for other commercial ehicles.

title: United Press International
description: FAMILY AFFAIR: Gary Player lining up a putt on the fourth green at Lytham St. Annes, Englmd, with the aid of his sons, Mark, left, and Wayne. Wayne will Join his father tomorrow during first round of the British Open.

title: Swallows Jam Peruvian Plaza
description: IQUITOS, PERU SHORTLY after the bell in Santa Ana cathedral tolls 6 o'clock, the darkening tropical sky begins filling up with birds. By tens of thousands they stream in from the surrounding jungle, soaring high over this Amazon city until they form a huge dark mass that blots out the dying rays of sunlight.

title: F.D.A. Urges Banning Use of Amphetamines For Reducing Weight
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The Food and Drug Administration today proposed to crack down on the misuse of amphetamines as pep pills by banning their use as dieting aids.

title: Reynolds Tobacco Heir And 4 Others Go on Trial in Stock Maneuvers Case
description: RICHMOND,Va.  Smith W. Bagley, a Reynolds Tobacco heir, and four codefendants went on trial today on charges, of fraud and stock manipulation.

title: Concert: Zukerman ripens Mozart
description: THE Mostly Moiart; Festivalry began last:, night in Ave Fisher Hall:which means; that summer in New York is Offidaily declared: There will be.36 perionnances, with Haydn and lights sharing the pnigrams. Those are among the composers to beheard the nest month or So.

title: New. York to. Thank Congress forAid With Fes val
description: New York will send Congress a belated thankyou for its help during the city's fiscal crisis, and city and state officials saidat a news conference yesterday that they had decided on something more elaborate than such traditiqnal tokens of appreciation as a short note, a boil of dandy, or a. bouquet of flowers.

title: San Francisco Election Carnpaign Will Test Power of Homosexual Vote
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 16  As this troubled city's municipal election season opens, the signs point to a campaign that will test the power of the homosexual vote and in which charges of official incompetence or corruption will fly thick and fast.

title: Oil Industry Assails Attacks
description: Oil company officials, after hearing President Carter elaborate yesterday on his latest energy, plan, said Mr. Carter's new goals for holding down.oil imports were tough but attainable. But they balked at what they described as another round of unwarranted attacks on their industry.

title: Tuning Up for Selling MOiart MethOrabilia
description: While the Mostly Mozart Festival was beginning its 13th summer season last night, the staffs at the Lincoln Center's gift shops were tuning up for the seventh year of selling Mozartiana.

title: How Carter Intends to Use Windfall Oil Profit Tax
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) President Carter estimated today that the windfall profits tax on oil would raisemore than $146 billion in the next decade. Here's how he proposes to spend the money:

title: Earnings Rise Sharply At BankAmerica, Chase
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the largest banking concern in the nation, and the Chase Manhattan Corporation, third largest, yesterday reported sharp gains in net operating earnings for the second quarter of 1979 compared with the second quarter of 1978.

title: Trade Surplus in Japan
description: TOKYO, July 16 (Reuters)  Japan had a small trade surplus in June after deficits in the two preceding months, the Finance Ministry announced today. The June surplus was $273.64 million, compared with a deficit In May of $784.57 million and a surplus of $2.35 billion in the June 1978.

title: Aspen Study Group Charges AntiIsraeli Meddling
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies has quietly protested to a corporate foundation that it is interferlim in, a Middle educational program by trying to attach antiIsraeli political strings to its coatibuttons, institute officials said today.

title: United Press International
description: NEW FROM GERMANY:The Volkswagen Jetta as it was introduced to the public in Wolfsburg, West Germany. The fivesent sedan will be offered with a variety of engines, ranging from 60 to 110 horsepovier.

title: For the Energy Plan, Uncertainties to. Overcome
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  In his energy speeches last night and today, President Carter proposed what he called the most massive peacetime commitment of funds and resources in our nation's Ilistory. In its scope the $140 billion proposal dwarfs all previous energy programs including the President's ambitious national energy plan of 1977.

title: HOUSE UNIT BELIEVES KENNEDY AND KING WERE PLOT VICTIMS
description: The House assassinations committee has concluded that conspiracy was likely in the murders of President John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and that neither the Warren Commission nor the Federal Bureau of Investigation adequately explored conspiracy possibilities in either death.

title: Q & S
description: Q. What causes the bands in the atmospheree of Jupiter to be different colors?

title: New Prices Of Gasoline In Effect
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) Gasoline prices will rise as much as cents a gallon at some service stations but will fall at others under new Energy Department rules that take effect today.

title: Business Wary on Carter Plan
description: Some American business leaders expressed apprehension yesterday about the degree to which they could endorse President Carter's broad new energy program.

title: This Winfield Party. Is an AllStar Smash
description: SEATTLE, July 16  For three hours today, approximately 5,000 patient, wellbehaved children climbed up and down eight flights of stairs of a downtown hotel. What kept them going was the quest for the autographs of AllStar baseball players, not to mention the cookies, doughnuts, peaches, plums, nuts and raisins that abounded on tables across the room from the lavers.

title: Deaths
description: ACAMPORAAngelo Anthony, M.D. on July 14, beloved husband of Anne and dear father of Carol Riechers and Robert, brother of Michael anc Mary Bel lone: Also survived by sev en grandchildren. Reposing at Bre Ilia Funeral Home, 260 Atlantis Ave., East Rockaway, Lynbrook, until Wednesday, 9:30 AM. Mass 0 Christian Burial St. Raymond': R.C. Church, 10 AM. Interment Cal vary Cemetery.

title: Deaths
description: LOOKSTEINRabbi. Joseph H. We mourn the loss of a great friend and we exextend our sympathy to beloved Gertrude his wife, and Rabbi Haskel and Natalie. Kiel Israel lost a great lover.

title: Iran Executes 5 Arabs at Oil Site
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 16  Five Arabs were executed last night and this meming in Khurrarhshar by Islamic Revolutionary Guards as tensions rose sharply between the Arab ethnic minority and the Islamic forces of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini throughout the ollproducing province of Khuzistan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AlbertoCulver Company, Melrose Park, Ill., has named Clarence E. Cobbs president of its John A. Frye Shoe Company subsidiary.

title: PRESIDENT URGES $140 BILLION TO INSURE ENERGY AUTONOMY; NUCLEAR POWER VITAL
description: DETROIT, July 16  President Carter, taking his new energy program and a freshly invigorated campaign style on the road today, proposed that the United States spend $140 billion over the next 10 years under his plan to secure the nation's energy future.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ATLANTICATLANTIC CINDERELLA (Atlantic Container Line). LeHavre July 23, Ant warp 25 and Gothenburg 26; sails from Port Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Carter Backed in an Audience Poll
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 16 (AP)  An Associated Press poll of delegates to the National Association of Counties convention indicated that a majority believe President Carter's new energy policies will lead America away from foreign oil dependence and combat inflation.

title: Exxon Tender Report
description: The Exxon Corporation reported yesterday that a preliminary count showed it had acquired 95 percent of the common stock and 72 percent of the preferred stock of the Reliance Electric Company. An Exxon spokesman said the preliminary count, subject to further documentation, showed its Enco Inc. subsidiary was tendered 15.1 million shares.

title: Wheeling, Reynolds Metals Gain
description: The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation reported yesterday that profits for the quarter ended June 30 more than doubled, and the Reynolds Metals Company said that its earnings for the same period rose 34.4 percent.

title: Ranger Is First to Finish
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 16 (UPI)  Ranger, owned and skippered by P. Craig Welch of Newport Beach, Calif., led 283 boats to the finish line today in the 72d annual ChicagotoMackinac yacht race.

title: House Approves $13 Billion Bill To Finish Washington's Subway
description: WASHINGTON, July. 16 (AP)  The House of Representatives authorized a direct appropriation of $1.7 billion today to completes the 100mile Metro subway system for the nation's capital* and its suburbs.

title: Theodore B. Bayles, 68, Arthritis Study Pioneer
description: WALTHAM, Mass., July 16 (AP) Dr. Theodore B. Bayles, a pioneer in the investigation of arthritis and professor at Harvard Medical School, died yesterday at Waltham Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Lack of a Police. Record Allowed Mass for a Companion of Galante
description: Before pelpitting a funeral mass for Leonardo Co'voila, who was slain with Carmine Galante last week, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn ascertained from parish authorities that the police had said that Mr. Coppolla had no criminal record.

title: Taxes
description: THE Internal Revenue Service.is completing its initial round of audits of tax. returns filed in April, and many taxpayers are getting their first brush with the I.R.S. Collection Division.

title: Social Security Commissioner Calls Improvements in Benefits Unlikely
description: WASHINGTON,. July 16  The Commissioner of Social, Security; declared today that a long eta of iaipansidn df Social Sectirity programs and rising benefits had ended and:that the 1 0's must be adecade of reforrn' in which Congress mandgtes painfuladjUstments.reporting on a study of pension systems in Europe and the United States, the Commissioner, Stanford G. Ross said, the optimistic expansionist philosophy that underlay Social Security planning ever since World War II has now changed to one of guarded hope that the best of the past can be preserved while the considerable needs of the future are addressed.

title: Dubious Fed Plans More Study On Banking Free Trade Zone
description: WASHINGTON, July 16  The Federal Reserve Board decided, today that a highly controversial free trade zone for international banking activity in New York City would not produce clear econoMiC advantages and could complicatethe problems of monetary and credit Management.

title: Union Head Attacks Report on City Buses And Defends Drivers
description: The president of the union that represents most of the city's 9,000 bus drivers yesterday attacked the busmaintenance audit Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin released Sunday, calling it a sldnderous smear without any factual basis, a deliberate distortion of true facts and a smokescreen intended to mislead the Public.,

title: Atlas Shows Small World
description: Is a world atlas not a world atlas if it fails to mention Tel Aviv?

title: Television
description: Morning

title: TaxGrievance Day in Islip Attracts 5,000
description: ISLIP, L.I., July 17  We may not have any tea to throw into the harbor, but we've got lots of tax officials to throw into Long Island Sound, said Edith Meuller, who was among 5,000 taxpayers who showed up at the Islip Town Hall today, Grievance Day, to protest against propertytax assessments.

title: Emirates Hint Oil Output Rise
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, July 17 (AP)  Mani Said alOtaiba, the oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, said today that the emirates might increase oil production next year. He was speaking to Japanese journalists accompanying a Japanese trade mission.

title: Deaths
description: ANFANGERBillie R. On July 16, 1979. Wife of the late Dr. Herman Anfanger, mother of Mrs. Barbara J. Clow, John A. and Andrew S. Anfanger; sister of Mrs. Mario (Irene) Zuria and Mrs. Josephine Chandler; grandmother of Stephen D. and James D. Clow and Danielle V. Anfanger. Service will be Wednesday, 1 PM, at BallardDurand Funeral Home Inc. 2 Maple Ave. White Plains, NY. Interment private. Donations to Associated Visiting Nurse Service.

title: Debating the Treaty
description: The Soviets have achieved a treaty structure which conforms to their strategic concept, of attaining a warwinning capability and denying equality to us. We have deluded ourselves that we have achieved a useful arms control outcome.  Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, former Chief of Naval Operations.

title: Girl, 11, Is PitchHitRun Champion
description: SEATTLE, July 17 (AP)  The boys won't laugh at 11yearold Crystal Fields anymore

title: Birmingham Mayor Keeps Policeman; Blacks Irate
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 17  Mayor David Vann refused today to dismiss a white policeman for what a citizen review committee called the unjustified fatal shooting of a black woman, and a coalition of civil rights groups announced a protest march along the route used in the historic 1963 demonstrations here.

title: Lone Star Tender Offer
description: Lone Star Industries said that its shareholders had tendered 2.7 million shares by the expiration time of its offer yesterday. The company said it would buy 1.25 million shares, all of the shares tendered by stockholders owning fewer than 100 shares and a pro rata amount of the remaining shares tendered, at a price of $25.50 a share

title: Coe's Dream: Olympic Double
description: Once he finished his final exams in economics at Loughborough University in England, Sebastian Coe intended to devote a year to preparing for the Moscow Olympics. The 22yearold runner was not wellknown worldwide, and was, in fact, ranitecl below Steve Ovett in Britain. Coe, however, had a dream of duplicating New Zealander Peter Snell's 8001,500meter double victories in the 1964 Olympics.

title: SOMOZA YIELDSPOST AND ARRIVES IN U.S.; FIGHTING CONTINUES
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 17 Besieged by guerrillas and under pressure from the United States, General Anastasio Somoza Debayle finally resigned as President of Nicaragua early today and flew into exile in Miami.

title: Chocolate Chips, a Sloop, Takes Race to Mackinac
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 17 (AP)Chocolate Chips was nine hours behind the first finisher, but was declared the winner after handicaps were computed today in the 72d annual, 333mile ChicagotoMackinac Island sailboat race.

title: Judges Ruling Halts Open Inquiry Into the California Supreme Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 17  The investigation of the California Supreme Court broke up in turmoil today after a state appeals court decision released in Los Angeles upheld Justice Stanley Mosk's contention that the sessions were unconstitutional because they were held in public.

title: Fed Chief Bars Easier Credit
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that the economy had entered a recession that could be somewhat deeper than the Carter Administration had forecast, but he reported that the central bafik would not alter its present degree of monetary restraint.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 17 (Reuters)  The South Korean Government announced today the release of 86 dissidents, most of them university students, and said more would be freed if they promised not to engage in antiGovernment activities.

title: Wine Talk
description: RUTHERFORD, CALIF.

title: Bank Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Gulf Set to Develop Nev Offshore Field
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 17 (Reuters)  The Gulf Oil Corporation said today that it was proceeding with plans to develop a new oil and natural gas field 33 miles south of Venice, La., in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: A Battle of New York in Seattle
description: SEATTLE, July 17  It was, said Lee Mazzilli, 3,000 miles from home, the battle of New York: me against Ron Guidry.

title: Decorum Beats Comfort in House as Capital Feels the Heat
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 When the House of Representatives convened at high noon today, temperatures in some corners of the big chamber were pushing toward the mid80's.

title: Washington
description: Patricia Wald, who has been nominated to become the first woman on the United States. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, is not accustomed to being called antifamily. Not long after launching a promising legal career she dropped out of a law firm and spent ten years raising five intelligent and accomplished children. Returning to law practice, she specialized in the rights of the poor; the handicapped and the mentally retarded. She maintained her reputation for compassion as an Assistant Attorney General for Legislative Liaison in the Justice Department.

title: Senate Rejects a Building Freeze for Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)  The Senate today refused to impose a sixmonth freeze on new construction permits for nuclear power plants.

title: DENNIS VALINSKI, 32, SCULPTOR OF METAL
description: Dennis Valinski, a sculptor known for his aerial and outdoor steel pieces, died Sunday in his studio in Edgewater, N.J. He was 32 years old and lived in Edgewater. An autopsy is being conducted to determine the cause of death.

title: Student Says Bundy Fled Murder Scene in Florida
description: MIAMI, July 17 (AP)  With a slight scowl on her face, a college student today pointed to Theodore R. Bundy as the man who fled the CM Omega sorority house the night two women were killed and three others clubbed senseless.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Remington Arms Company, already 70 percent owned by V.I.du Pont de Nemours & Company, said yesterday that Du Pont had made a merger bid, offering to exchange just over onehalf a Du Pont share for each of the roughly two million Remington shares it does not already own.

title: Latin Americans Cheer End of Somoza Regime
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 17  The end of the Somoza regime in Nicaragua was welcomed in most of Latin America, where even rightwing military governments had refrained from aiding the dictatorship.

title: Books of The Times
description: HOWARD KOCH is the man who wrote the script of Orson Welles's famous 1938 Marsinvasion broadcast. That didn't prevent him from becoming still another victim of the hoax. Having gone to bed early the night of the broadcast, exhausted by the labor of producing a largely original script in only six days, he woke up the next morning unaware of the panic the show had created. Venturing forth for a haircut and overhearing talk of invasion and panic, he jumped to the conclusion that Hitler had invaded some new territory and that the war we all dreaded had finally broken out.

title: Ernst Acquires Baker Sutton
description: Ernst & Whiney, the nation's thirdlargest auditing firm, announced yesterday that it had acquired Baker Sutton & Company, a Londonbased auditing firm that specializes in work for international insurance companies.

title: Patients' Organizations
description: Many hospitals and clinics employ social workers to help couples cope with the stress of a lifethreatening illness. In addition, there are independent, patientrun selfhelp groups whose programs range from informal social gatherings to group therapy sessions. The following is a list of some of the patient organizations active in the New York area.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Ratings Show CBS Gaining on ABC
description: Summer being the offseason in television, with network reruns predominating, the weekly audiencepopularity ratings don't carry the importance they have from September through May. But there have been some developments in the Nielsen reports the last few weeks that could bear significantly on the audience trends new fall

title: Producers Dubious on Coal Target
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The coal industry remains largely unimpressed by President Carter's renewed emphasis on coal as a substitute for imported oil, because he has not tackled the maze of environmental restrictions that hamper its use, a spokesmen for the major producers said today.

title: Notes on People
description: The wife or William Niehous, the OwensIllinois executive who was rescued recently after three and a half years as the captive of guerrillas in Venezuela, filed a secret negligence suit against the company last April.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the pait week (Monday, July 9. to Sunday. July 15), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Advertising
description: N. W. AYER ABH INTERNATIONAL may be one of the world's oldest ad agencies, but it also has one of the freshest approaches to getting new business.

title: Senate Panel Approves 13 Judges
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)  With three Republican Senators expressing opposition, the Senate Judiciary Committee today approved the nomination of Assistant Attorney General Patricia M. Wald to the United States Court of Appeals in Washington.

title: ExTop Officers Split on Arms Pact; Some Call it a Peril, Others Useful
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  A group of retired military officers differed today on whether the armslimitation treaty with the Soviet Union was a sound agreement.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Management Systems Inc., an Arlington, Va.based company specializing in computer services, system development and management consulting, has elected Roderic M. Fredrickson and J. Ernest Loomis vice presidents.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Bores Meet for a Bit of Dull Fun
description: According to Boredom Anonymous, which held its fifth annual convention in Manhattan yesterday morning, on any given day there are 8,436,000 totally bored people in the United States. Yet only 200 have bothered to join the organization. This may be why:

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The recession could be somewhat deeper than the Carter Administration has foreca said Wiliam Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board: He also said th central bank would not alter the present degree of mbnetary,restraint, and he cautioned against a precipitous rush to cut taxes. [Page D1.]

title: Smith Island's Renowned Kitchen
description: EWELL, MD. SUPERLATIVES punctuated the comments on cuisine penned in the hotel register by the front door of the Frances Kitching Inn. A meal in a million, was the written judgment of Charles and Ruth Houston of Ambler, Pa. Other examples were dotted with such words as fantastic and marvelous.

title: Cronkite Newscast Sets Coast Edition
description: CBS News announced yesterday that beginning Aug. 27 it would carry a West Coast edition of The CBS Evening News With Walter Cronkite, with Terry Drinkwater in Los Angeles providing insertions of latebreaking stories. The innovation has been prompted by the problems arising from the, threehour time difference between the Eastern and Western zones.

title: Carey Signs Bills to Expand Programs Spurring Housing
description: ALBANY, July 17  Governor Carey signed today a series of measures designed to improve housing in the state. They included protections for tenants who complain about conditions in their buildings, an expansion of New York City's taxabatement program for building rehabilation, and an increase in the development powers of the state's Housing Finance Agency.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Merrill Lynch Earnings Rose by 7.8% for Quarter
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that its secondquarter earnings were $31.9 million, or 7.8 percent higher than in the comparable period a year ago, while revenues increased 21 percent to $492.8 million.

title: Administration Examines Options On Planned $10 Billion for Transit
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  A White House official said today that specific plans for using $10 billion that President Carter proposed spending on public transportation over the next decade were still to be worked out.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: A SHORT while back, at a reader's request, I outlined the simplest method of seasoning and cooking a fish and at the same time making it appealing. More and more in this day and age, people are learning that some of the simplest dishes have a grand and justifiable appeal. Here are two of the quickest and simplest methods, for cooking lamb chops. In one, the chops are cooked under a broiler flame, and in the other, they are panbroiled, or cooked in a skillet.

title: Speech Lifts Carter Rating to 37%; Public Agrees on Confidence Crisis
description: President Carter has received a sharp increase in approval from a public that overwhelmingly agrees with his warning Sunday night that the nation faces a crisis of confidence, according to the New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Expert Predicts A Big U.S. Gain In Sub Warfare
description: A military expert says that the United States Navy is on the verge of a breakthrough in antisubmarine warfare that would enable it to locate and destroy the submarines of the Soviet Union, including those armed with nuclear missiles, in so short a period that Moscow's ability to retaliate through the use of submarinelaunched weapons would be effectively eliminated.

title: Dance: Martha Clarke Presents Her Crowsnest Trio at Durham
description: DURHAM, N.C., July 17  New wine in new bottles is what the American Dance Festival has put on display this summer during its second year here on the Duke University campus. One of the innovattons has been a weekly public discussion series, called Dance Town Hall, such as the one held last night. Another novelty was the debut of an offbeat new company, Crowsnest, headed by Martha Clarke, formerly, a member of the Pilobolus Dance Theater.

title: A Night's Stress Reflects Plight of Transportation
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  Over the years, a frequent air traveler may endure almost anything. He may rattle into the Peten jungle of Guatemala aboard a DC3 with feet propped on a barrel of gasoline and a peasant woman with two live chickens as a seat mate. He may spend a week flying backward with no windows aboard a Navy Constellation to Antarctica, breaking down only once over the South Pacific and landing on abed of foam in Hawaii.

title: U.S. Fuel Woes Stir Canadians
description: OTTAWA, July 17  Cushioned to some extent against the the direct effects of higher energy costs by domestic production of oil and gas, Canada is nonetheless being strongly affected by what is happening to the United States and by the policies devised by the Carter Administration to meet the problem.

title: Administration Officials Who Offered Resignations
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The following members of the Cabinet and Cabinetlevel officials today offered their resignations to the President:

title: A Round for the Whales
description: Twice in this century, species of whales on the verge of extinction have been saved by war. During World Wars I and II, human beings were so busy slaughtering each other that they had no time to hunt the harmless leviathans who would otherwise have ended up as pet food and cosmetics.

title: 895 Adults Interviewed in Poll
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Monday night with 895 adult men and women around the United States.

title: EARNINGS
description: Philip Morris Inc. yesterday reported a 25.2 percent rise in profits in the second quarter to a record $130.6 million, or $1.05 a share, from $104.3 million, or 87 cents a share, in the comparble 1978 quarter.

title: Japan Maps Its Own Energy Program
description: TOKYO, July 17  Japan is considering plans to invest up to $11.6 billion by 1990 in alternative energy sources, officials said today.

title: Extradition in Bombing Upheld
description: ATLANTA, July 17 (AP)  The Georgia Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its July 7 ruling that J.B. Stoner, a white supremacist, must be extradited for trial. in Alabama in a 1958 bombing of a black church in Birmingham. Attorneys for Mr. Stoner, who has maintained that he was not in Alabama at the time of the bombing, have indicated that they will appeal to the United States Supreme Court. No one was injured in the bombing.

title: It Was the Festival Of the Stinking Rose
description: BERKELEY, CALIF. REMEMBER LSD? said Tom Weller. Garlic is the LSD of the 70's. Mr. Weller, president of St. Heironymous Press, which prints posters designed by his partner, David Goines, was sitting in the garden of Chez Panisse, the French restaurant patronized by the Berkeley elect, waiting for his turn at table.

title: GasStation Operators Say They're Disturbed By New Profit Ceiling
description: Many servicestation operators in the metropolitan area said yesterday they were disappointed and disturbed that the Federal Department of Energy had set a grossprofit ceiling for retail gasoline dealers at 15.4 cents per gallon.

title: Rebel Junta, Its Sendoff Canceled, Plans Trip to Nicaragua Shortly
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 17  The Nicaraguan rebel junta, stymied in its plan to fly to Managua today and take over the leadership abandoned by Anastasio Somoza Debayle, said that it would enter the country shortly.

title: Stocks Off 6.4 Points
description: Stocks fell 6.4 points yesterday, dispelling any optimism generated by Monday's marginal advance. The decline in the Dow Jones industrial average accelerated toward the close, and the average finished the day at 828.5. Analysts attributed the drop to investors concern over the inflationary impact of President Carter's plan to spend $140 billion over the next 10 years to gain energy autonomy for the United States.

title: For ABCTV, Fall Begins in August
description: The ABCTV network Will try, to steal a march on its competitors by beginning, its fall season early in August. Actually the network is not televising any of its September programs, next month. Rather, in what Anthony D. Thomopoulos, president of ABC Entertainment, describes as an effort to establish viewing patterns for the fall, the network is taking reruns'of three of its biggest hits and placing them in their new time slots a month early.

title: Britain Plans to Reduce Regional Corporate Aid
description: LONDON, July 17  In the first of a series of moves to reduce State involvement with industry, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's new Conservative Government disclosed plans today to cut its aid to companies; in depressed areas by 38 percent in the next three years.

title: Mazzilli Stars as Nationals Win. 76
description: SEATTLE, July 17  Lee Mazzilli, who entered the game in the eighth inning, and Dave Parker, who played all nine innings, added their names tonight to the list of National Leaguers who haVe frustrated the American League over a 17year span.

title: Senators Restore Items Cut From Building Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)  Funds for paneling in senators offices, a rooftop restaurant and a fancy hearing room were restored to the plan for the Senate's third office building only hours after they were cut by the commission overseeing the project.

title: Greg Winchell Is In Coma After Motorcycle Accident
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 17 (UPI)  Greg Winchell, a silver medalist in the PanAmerican Games and holder of the United States high school breaststroke record, was in a coma today as the result of a motorcycle crash.

title: Taxi Fares to Rise Today as Owner Group Protests
description: Taxi fares are scheduled to go up 15 cents a ride at 6 A.M. today, but a coalition of independent cab owners has vowed not to charge the increase, protesting that it is not high enough.

title: Gas Find Reported In West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., July 17 (AP)  The Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation announced today that it believed it had found a major natural gas discovery in West Virginia.

title: Bridge:
description: Work, accordiig to.a modem British version of an old saying, is the curse of the drinking classes. It seems to be the curse of the bridgeplaying classes on this side of the Atlantic, judging from an episode a week ago that is likely to subject the Von Zedtwitz double knockout team championship in New York to a twomonth delay.

title: HERBERT W. HUGO
description: MELROSE PARK, Ill., July 17 (AP) Herbert W. Hugo, senior editor of Plaits Oilgram, was found dead yesterday, apparently of natural causes, the authorities said. He was 99 years old.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess:
description: AMSTERDAM, July 14  After three rounds of the I.B.M. International Tournament here in the R.A.I. Building, three grandmasters shared the lead: Gyula Sax of Hungary and Vlastimil Hort and Jan Smejkal, both of Czechoslovakia. Each has scored 2 mints

title: Wendy Yoshimura Starts Serving A Prison Sentence in California
description: CHINO, Calif., July 17 (UPI)  Wendy Yoshimura, Patricia Hearst's former roommate and traveling companion, reported to the Frontera state women's prison today to begin serving a sentence of one to 15 years for illegal possession of explosives.

title: Joint Chiefs Ask Delay Of Korea Pullout to 81
description: WASHINGTON, July. 17 (UPI)  Gen. David C. Jones, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that America's military commanders had advised President Carter against withdrawing more United States ground troops from South Korea until 1981.

title: Cuban Dancers: A Happy, Unruly Family
description: ASTAGEFUL of dancers shifts and preens through a stylized popular dance. Above them colored lights blaze. A man in green, seafoam tatters trailing, watches from the side like some foreboding presence. Suddenly the dancers scatter into the wings. The music stops and vast empty reaches of the Metropolitan Opera House echo with the cry of iMuchachos! It sounds somewhat more affectionate than the American rehearsal director's kids and, indeed, the National, Ballet of Cuba  at the Metropolitan through July 28does resemble a large and cheerfully unruly family.

title: A Son Divided
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y.  My son, 10 years and one day old, waves gamely as the Greyhound pulls out. He is bound 150 miles south to spend the long Fourth of July weekend with his mother. I stand in the hot parking lot, waying back until the bus fades far down into the stream of traffic. My son has made this strange shuttle many times before. He is one of the new legion of suddenly old children, paying in part for their parents failures.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY  A computer match has identified 875 persons who fraudulently collected nearly half a million dollars in benefits, the State Labor Department announced yesterday. It said it had referred 110 of these cases to authorities for prosecution.

title: Allied Chemical Bid For Eltra Extended
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation has extended for two weeks, to July 27, its $588 million takeover offer for the Eitra Corporation.

title: 2 Paper Makers Profits Climb
description: The St. Regis Paper Company and the Scott Paper Company, two major manufacturers of paper and wood products, reported sharply higher secondquarter earnings yesterday.

title: Africans Open Talks In Liberia With Stress On Liberation Goals
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 17  The 16th annual summit meeting of the Organization of African Unity convened here this afternoon.

title: Somoza Says Communist Conspiracy, Not the People, Brought About Ouster
description: MIAMI, July 17  Appearing pained but resolute at the start of his exile, the deposed Nicaraguan President, Anastasio Somoza Debayle, stood in the, sundrenched breezedray of his $500,000 island villa here and declared that it was a Communist conspiracy that cast him from power, not the Nicaraguan people.

title: Best Buys
description: At $1.98 a half pound, butter is hardly a bargain. Unless, of course, it's flown in fresh from France, and tastes smoother, creamier and purer than any domestic butter on the market. Zabar's flew in its first, 500pound shipment last week.

title: Careers
description: COMPLIANCE is a word that Ms been assuming new importance in corporate life, and it is opening a host of Job opportunities.

title: Citing New Law, Medical Schools To Bar Entry Tests in New York
description: Administrators of the tests required for admission to virtually all of the nation's 125 medical schools and all 60 dental schools announced yesterday that they would stop giving the examinations in New York State, rather than comply with the truth in testing law signed by Governor Carey last week.
