title: 3 Elderly Men Vying for Power in India
description: NEW DELHI, July 17  The major contenders who continued maneuvering today in their quest for political power here include an 83yearold man hoping to succeed himself as Prime Minister, a 77yearold man with a heart condition who contemplates an alliance with the pariah forces of Indira Gandhi, and a 71Yearold leader from the untouchable caste who is trying to decide what to do about the support of a 90member bloc that has proven to be an albatross.

title: Licensing Mental Therapists
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  As the Congress moves closer to enacting national health insurance, watch for a ConspicUously uncivil war to break out among psychiatrists, psychologists and social workers. At issue is who will be.certified and entitled to reimbursement for professional services. Billions of dollars in fees are at stake. So is the quality and range of mentalhealth care available to the pubile.

title: Kennedy Feels Chappaquiddick Would Not Rule Out Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  Senator Edward M. Kennedy reaffirmed today that he believed he acted irrationally apdirresponsibly in the aftermath of a fatal automobile accident at Chappaquiddick Island 10 years ago tomorrow. But he Said that he did not believe that his perform& ance In that crisis meant that he could not meet the pressures of the Presidency if he chose to run.

title: Jersey Approves, Agency to Buy Bus Companies
description: TRENTON, July 17 Governor Byrne today signed a bill creating the New Jersey Transit Corporation, which would have the power to buy and operate bus lines as well as passenger railroads in the state.

title: Citicorp's Net Off 8.6%
description: Citicorp, stating yesterday that its net operating earnings for the second quarter had declined 8.6 percent compared with a year earlier, became the only major banking concern to report a decline for the period.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, JULY 17, 1979

title: DoItYourself Butchering Can Trim Fat Off Food Bill
description: PARAMUS, N.J. EMILIE TAYLOR says that Americans don't know beans about beef. There's probably no food we eat more of and know less about, insists the 39yearold woman, who has been teaching meat cutting to New Jersey housewives since the height of the 1975 meat boycott. She believed then, as she does now, that the best defense against high meat prices is not a boycott or a protest, but a wellinformed consumer. Last year, each American consumed more than 137 pounds of meat  84 pounds of that in beef, 49 in pork products, such as hams, sausages, pork chops and roasts. Yet as Mrs. Taylor notes, we buy and prepare the same cuts of meat day in and day out, often passing up good cuts and good buys in the process.

title: Pilots Taxi In to Convention Motel
Film: 'Breaking Away,' a Classic Sleeper:Back Home in Indiana
description: "BREAKING AWAY" was made in Bloomington, Ind., which is perhaps the film world's equivalent of left field. For that and other reasons, it's a classic sleeper. The cast is unknown, the director has a spotty history, and the basic premise falls into this year's most hackneyed category (unknown boxer/bowler/jogger hopes to become sports hero). Even so, the finished product is wonderful. Here is a movie so fresh and funny it didn't even need a big budget or a pedigree."Breaking Away," which opens today at the Coronet and other theaters, has a sense of place that goes hand in hand with its sense of humor. In Bloomington, on the outskirts of Indiana University, four boys endure the confusion of being nonstudents  and pariahs of a sort  in a college town. The college kids, who seem privileged and carefree, instill the Bloomington boys with both an uneasy class-consciousness and a feeling that life is passing them by. As Mike (Dennis Quaid), the angriest of the four, remarks bitterly, "These college kids out here, they're never gonna get old. There'll always be new ones coming along."While his father (Paul Dooley, who gives a fabulous supporting performance) sells used cars with names like Magna Cum Laude and Varsity Squad, Dave (Dennis Christopher) indulges in a form of escapism that's both hilarious and touching. Dave is a first-rate bicycle racer, which makes him an outsider in another way: the really topnotch bicyclists, the royalty who occasionally deign to visit Bloomington, are Italians. Dave, who is nothing if not enterprising, sees no choice but to try to become Italian too.So he sings operatic arias as he rides, and feeds his cat out of a Cinzano ashtray. He uses Neapolitan Sunset cologne. He drives his father wild by crying "Ciao," and by conspiring with his mother (Barbara Barrie) to insinuate foreign dishes  "all them '-ini' foods, zucchini and linguini and fettucine," Mr. Dooley shrieks  into the family's french fry-based diet. Mr. Dooley is finally driven to take out his frustrations on the family cat, whom he warns "Your name is Jake, not Fellini!"The proof of Dave's success in transforming himself comes when he starts serenading a pretty college girl named Katherine (Robyn Douglass), who falls for the act, perhaps because she loves being called Caterine. But, much to the movie's credit, it follows Dave beyond these endearingly transparent efforts. In fact, it even passes the point at which he realizes that escaping his status as a town kid  "cutters," they're calledwill require something more strenuous than whimsy. Halfway through the movie, the cutters begin in earnest to carve out an identity they can be proud of. They pit themselves against the college boys, who are snobs, not fighters, and want a sporting contest, not a dangerous one. The movie culminates in a bike race that left at least one screening-room audience cheering. Screening-room crowds don't ordinarily cheer.The cutters, who make very convincing misfits, are played by a well-chosen ensemble including Mr. Christopher, Mr. Quaid (Randy Quaid's younger brother, though he bears more resemblance to Jan-Michael Vincent), Daniel Stern and Jackie Earle Haley. Mr. Stern's scarecrow manner and offbeat comic timing work very nicely here, as does Mr. Haley's almost dwarfish physical presence. Mr. Haley, who played the little blond androgyne in "The Day of the Locust" and then the most unmistakable juvenile delinquent among the Bad News Bears, has grown into an odd actor and a gifted one too.Peter Yates, the director, has been euphemistically remembered as the director of "Bullitt" while he turned out more questionable offerings, such as "For Pete's Sake" and "The Deep" and "Mother, Jugs and Speed." This time, to anyone who said it couldn't be done, Mr. Yates can say "Hah!" and point to a subtle and imaginative success. Much of the credit undoubtedly also goes to the screenwriter, Steve Tesich, whose keen feeling for Americana belies his childhood overseas. But perhaps his background accounts for why Mr. Tesich, who spent his first 13 years in Yugoslavia and is now 35, can render both the Middle Western settings and the boys' feeling sense of themselves as outsiders so beautifully.As enjoyable as those scenes centering on the young actors are, it's always a pleasure to get back to Mr. Dooley and Miss Barrie, who are at the comic heart of the story, reflecting those aspects of Indiana life that seem most incapable of changing  and yet, by the end of the story, do give way. Midway through the movie, they have a particularly memorable love scene, in which Miss Barrie attempts to seduce her husband with her own wiles plus the Italian music he professes to hate.All of this, not to mention a good dinner, goes to Mr. Dooley's head. And he is charmed beyond all reason when Miss Barrie removes the flower she's put in her hair. In response, he tempestuously rips the plastic pencil case out of his breast pocket. He doesn't know it, but this is the first sign that he'll be eating pizza by the end of the story."Breaking Away" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains one fight scene, not a violent one, and a few mild obscenities.

title: RAYMOND G. FOWLER
description: Raymond G. Fowler, former security analyst for the TriContinental Corporation of New York, a diversified publicly traded investmentfund company, died last Saturday at the Queens Medical Center in Honolulu. He was 76 years old and had lived in Manhattan for many years before moving to Honolulu.

title: Books: Omnibus Volume Of P. D. James Mysteries
description: P. D. JAMES'S first omnibus volume containing three of her mystery novels will make clear why this English writer is cutting such a sure and distinctive way in a crowded field. Her style is what we think of as typically British. Her writing is ample, leisurely and full of loving descriptions of house and countryside. There is, in fact, a certain 19thcentury ease to her books, as if she were inviting the reader to settle down near the fire and enjoy a good long read. Her people are educated, voluble and articulate. They speak faultless English; there is no low life in these pages, no conventional heists take place, no cheap killing merely for gain.

title: Sea Life Studies Research Vessel in Pacific
description: ABOARD.GLOMAR CHALLENGER, off Ecuador, July 17  While most ships.come and go, this one has stayed in almost exactly the same place between South America and the Galapagos Islands for a week, and for thousands of fish and birds it has become a new midocean island.

title: Brooklyn and Long Island
description: Senator Javits is reported ready to recommend that President Carter nominate a distinguished woman lawyer to be a Federal Judge in the Eastern District of New York. That district has never had a woman judge and the departure will be welcome.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE basic inflation rate, measured by the growth of industrial prices, is now more than 10 percent. With the recently announced price rise by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, this rate will soon go even higher, with no prospect of its diminishing in the near future.

title: China Air Gets Credit
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (Reuters) The United States ExportImport Bank said today that it had offered a $126.4 million credit to China Airlines Ltd for the purchase of two Boeing 747200B jetliners, plus spare en??ines and parts

title: Letter,On TouristRelated Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: A Wall Street spotlight was focused yesterday on Byron C. Radaker, chairman and president of the Congoleum Corporation, which announced Monday that a $38ashare tender offer for the company's shares would be forthcoming.

title: Ella Viola Grainger Manville, 90; Artist Was Widow of Composer
description: Ella Viola Grainger Manville, an artist and the widow of Percy Grainger, the composer and concert pianist, died yesterday at her home in White Plains. Death was attributed to complications following surgery. She was 90 years old and had lived in the same house for 51 years.

title: Market Place
description: I HAVE no idea what stock prices are going to do over the next several months, but on a longterm basis my work indicates that the market is approaching an undervalued situation similar to that existing in late 1974.

title: Congressman Murphy Still Somoza Friend
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  Three weeks ago, the newly arrived United States Ambassador to Nicaragua had something of a jolt when he was ushered in for his first meeting with President Anastasio Somoza Debayle. There, sitting next to General Somoza, the man the Ambassador was pressing to resign, was Representative John M. Murphy of New Yoyk.

title: Subaru Credit Line Rises to $185 Million
description: Subaru of America Inc., importer of the Japanesemade Subaru autos, has increased its revolving line of credit with a group of banks to $185 million this year from $130 million last year to meet higher expected sales for the 1980 model year.

title: Big, Merged Union Could Enhance Influence of Service Trade Workers
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  William H. Wynn and the 1.3millionmember United Food and Commercial Workers Union may not be household words yet, but they are representative of changes in the American union movement.

title: Artifacts Saved as Pipe Bursts in Museum
description: Archeologists rescued Egyptian and Eskimo artifacts at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday after a standpipe burst on the third floor. The ruptured pipe, touchedoff a halfhour cascade that drenched two scientific and two exhibition areas on the floors below and sent visitors scampering to escape the water.

title: In Nicaragua, U.S. Hand Was Always Felt
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 17  The resignation of the President of Nicaragua, Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, appears to mark the end of a 46year family dynasty that was installed and sustained by and finally undermined with the help of the United States.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Theprice of gold rose to new records and the dollar's value plunged against most foreign currencies despite huge central hank support yesterday as dealers continued to reject President Carter's energy program.

title: Kitchen Equipment DeepFat Fryers
description: ISENSE a certain amount of fear and disdain among those who have not tried deepfat frying at home. They think of it as dangerous  and so it is, if a cook is careless. They think of it as wasteful to use a quart or two of oil at once, but in fact the oil is ettsily preserved for later uses. They , think of It as greasy which is palpably untrue since deepfried food, cooked correctly, absorbs little oil and results not in some soggy mess but in food so crisp it's almost brittle.

title: Serious Illness: The Spouse's Role
description: ONE day five years ago, while she was sitting at her desk in the middle of work on an ordinary Tuesday, Marcia Leader received a phone call. The unfamiliar voice on the other end of the line identified itself as a doctor at Bellevue Hospital, and Mrs. Leader was carefully, gently told that her 58yearold husband had suffered a sudden, massive and severe heart attack.

title: Nicaraguan Knots to Untie
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  United States policy on Nicaragua is entering an uncertain period that Administration officials concede could be hazardous both for Central America and for President Carter on the home front.

title: For Israelis, From Egypt With Love Is a Slogan of Peace.
description: JERUSALEM, July 17  A young woman, part of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's entourage at the summit meeting in Alexandria, Egypt, last week, turned up at work in Jerusalem the other day wearing a souvenir she had brought back: a white Tshirt emblaioned with the words From Egypt With Love.

title: Simone Veil of France Is Elected European Parliament's President
description: STRASBOURG, France, July 17 (AP)  The newly elected European Parliament opened its inaugural session here today by choosing Simone Veil of France as its first President.

title: American Golfers Are Expected To End Royal Lytham Drought
description: ST. ANNES, England, July 17 The sun emerged from a leaden sky this afternoon, and the breeze that accompanied it made the links of the Royal Lytham and St. Agnes Golf Club the kind of course it is intended to be musing test of chamMonshin golf.

title: Town Learning to Live With Less Energy
description: DAVIS, Calif., July 17  This college town of 37,000 people is. learning to live with less energy. Perhaps more than any other community in the nation, it is working collectively to cut its consumption of gasoline, natural gas and electricity.

title: A Time to Look Beyond Eye Contact
description: IT'S tough to kick a habit you've been addicted to since fifth grade. That's when I was brainwashed on the importance of looking everybody, especially anybody I talked to, in the eye. Gazing directly at the recipient of your remarks was, I was assured, a badge of honesty, a guarantee of integrity, synonomous with being a redblooded, cleanliving toothbrushing American. In brief, looking people in the eye was a certified check to sincerity.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Monday incorrectly identified the hospital where doctors amputated the nearly severed left arm of Vincent Cahill of Queens after he was struck by a subway train. It was the Queens Hospital Center.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Personal Health
description: MY friend Eileen McNutt was near the end of a long battle against recurring cancer. Several times during her illness I had spoken with her and her husband about possible treatments. But now, when I could no longer older hope for cure, I was afraid to see her. Here was a woman, lovely and talented, only a few years older than I, a woman with two young children and a loving husband. There, but for the grace of God, go I.

title: Around the Nation
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 17 (UPI)Gov. Bob Graham today signed a death warrant for a convicted murderer, Howard V. Douglas, the fifth slayer the Governor has ordered put to death in recent months.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 18, 1979

title: U.S. Hails Departure Of Somoza but Assails Decision of Successor
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The United States welcomed the forced resignation of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle of Nicaragua today, but later expressed grave concern that the agreement on ending the country's civil war was being violated.

title: Cosmos File Protest Over Fight
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 17 The Cosmos lodged two protests with the North American Soccer League today about poor officiating add the ejection of two of their players last Sunday night in the 42 loss to Vancouver at Giants Stadium.

title: News of the Theater Perkins to Be Half of Romantic Comedy
description: AFTER months of trying to make an attractive boxoffice match, Morton Gottlieb has finally found one of the consenting adults he needs for Bernard Slide's twocharacter Romantic Comedy. He reports that Anthony Perkins is definite for the male lead, even though the contract is not yet signed.

title: Deaths
description: LOOKSTEINRabbi Josesth H. The Rabbi Jacob Joseph School and the Alumni Association records with deepfelt sorrow the passing of our revered alumnus Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein. He received his basic foundation of Torah knowledge and Yiddishkeitin the Mother Yeshiva. He was a proud and vibrant spirltual leader who always remembered his Alma Mater. May all the members of his illustrious family be comforted with all mourners of Zion. May his memory be for a blessing.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTON  It is the most impossible job in the world., We have often heard this reference to the Presidency from both ordinary Americans and political aspirants, half In jest and in seriousness. It connotes a perception of the office of the President of utmost complexity in an interdependent world. It is a cogent reminder that stong executive leadership has characterized the most creative periods of America's foreign and domestic affairs and is indispensible to the effective workings of our democracy.

title: Sears Store Restaurants To Focus on Fast Foods
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, which caters to more shoppers than any other American retailer, is making an aggressive move to capture a bigger share of the fastfood market by converting most of its 450 instore restaurants to limited menus and selfservice, the company said yesterday in Chicago.

title: Six Oil Concerns In Pact With China
description: CHICAGO, July 17 (Reuters)  The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), known as Amoco, said today that its Amoco China Petroleum ,Company subsidiary and five other companies had signed a contract with China to conduct a geophysical survey in the South China Sea. Indiana Standard said the survey is expected to begin in September.

title: Hawaii's Police Officers Defy Judge in Walkout
description: HONOLULU, July 17 (AP)  Most of Hawaii's 1,800 police officers remained on strike in a contract dispute today, defying a judge who ordered them to return to their jobs.

title: Deaths
description: SALTZMANFay. The Samuel H. Wane Yeshiva High School of Queens notes with profound sadness the passing of Mrs. Fay Saltzman, devoted mother of our benefactress, Mrs. Gloria Wang Sohn. Mrs. Seitzman took pride in her family's involvement with Yeshiva Education and she brought a full measure of spirit and verve to our Yeshiva gatherings. We extend condoiences to her beloved daughters, Gloria Wang Sohn, Ariene Mills. Helen Dimin, and Michelle/Marlowe: to her grandchildren Nathan Wang, Hanlta Rosenbolm, wile of our esteemed board member Yoseph ReSenboim, Devorah Etzion, Daniel Wind. Ira and Ronal Marlowe, Sharyn Miltz, Douglas,Richard, and Demise Dimin, and to her greatgrandchildren Yaron and Eyal Rosenboim. May the Almighty comfort than among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem

title: U.S. Charges the Defendant Let Off by Fraiman Holiday
description: A Federal charge was filed in Manhattan yesterday against Eric Michael, a defendant whose robbery conviction was overturned last week on the ground of double jeopardy by the state's highest court. The Court of Appeals Censured the State Supreme Court justice in the case, Arnold G. Fraiman, for ending the defendant's first trial to accommodate the vacation plans of the justice and some members of the jury.

title: Newly Nominated Corrections Commissioner
description: when Governor Carey was trying to reach Thomas Aloysius Coughlin the other day.to ask him to be his nominee for the post of State Correctional Services Commissioner, Mr. Coughlin was watching stockcar races in Watertown N Y

title: About Real Estate
description: Inc AMee Square Mall, which, in way, will be downtown Brooklyn's an swer to Philadelphia's striking enclosed mall, The Gallery, is now under construction. It will rise on the large irregular block where the 3,600seat AJbee Theater once stood.

title: Booth Opened at Central Park
description: A booth was opened yesterday at the southern entrance to Central Park to dispense information and sell books and postcards this summer. The temporary sales and information kiosk, at Fifth Avenue and 60th Street and manned by the Central Park Task Force and the Urban Park Rangers, will be open seven days a week from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. until Oct. 1. It will offer information about park facilities and events and will sell such items as postcards depicting Central Park, books about the park and souvenirs.

title: Century Ago, Cooks Looked to Mrs.Rorer
description: PEOPLE who think that cooking schools in America are a 20thcentury innovation are about a century behind the times. Shortly after the Civil War there were three wellknown cooking schools in this country. They were the Boston Cooking School, the New York Cooking School and the Philadelphia Cooking School.

title: HOUSE PANEL CLEARS HOSPITAL COST BILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill to contain hospital costs today and gave the Carter Administration a hardfought victory in its struggle against inflation. The vote was 22 to 14, but an amendment that would have crippled the legislation lost by only two votes.

title: Pigarcik Sees a Gain In Giants' Confidence
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 17 Joe Pisarcik appreciates the little things that are different about this year's Giants training camp, things like ice pops during breaks on the practice field and Coach Ray Perkins's im porting a chef from New England to upgrade the team dinners.

title: Closed Hearing Denied Convicted Extortionist
description: NEWARK, July 17 (UPI)  A reputed organizedcrime figure won delay in his sentencing on Federal extortion charges today after the trial judge refused to close the proceeding to the public and the press.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: BILL, a college friend, was visiting David Kleinman and his brother, Louis. Being from Los Angeles, writes David, he found the pace of Gotham to be exhilarating but totally exhausting. One night we decided to drive downtown for some carousing, but Bill insisted that we travel by our fast and furious subway system.

title: Women and the Judicial Calling
description: Knowing what to call female Federal judges didn't used to be much of a problem. There were hardly any. Now that more women are being appointed, male jurists are tonguetied. When Amalya Kearse was sworn in recently as a member of the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan, Chief Judge Irving Kaufman referred to her as our sisterly scholar. No longer, he explained, could he say brethren.

title: MCI v. Bell: From Court Into the Marketplace
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  William G. McGowan, chairman and chief executive officer of the MCI Communications Corporation, fought an expensive court battle with the American Telephone and Telegraph CompanY and won. His dubious prize was the right for his small company to compete with the giant utility in longdistance telephone service.

title: Bonn Oil Strategy Backs Cost Rise and Use of Coal
description: BONN, July 17  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, governing a country more heavily dependent on imported oil than the United States, has taken a radically different course from President Carter in trying to cut oil imports.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Bond prices declined fairly sharply early yesterday, then recovered most of their losses by late afternoon in a turnabout that appeared to be spurred by news that Cabinet and White House staff members had offered to resign.

title: 3 Onandaga Officials Named Conspirators In Scheme to Rig Bids
description: SYRACUSE, July 17  Three Onondaga County officials were named today as unindicted coconspirators in a bidrigging scheme involving truck con racts totaling more than $500,000 in exchange for contributions to the County Republican Committee.

title: Carey Vetoes Measure Giving Sheriff Pension
description: ALBANY, July 17  Governor Carey, who recently got a special widow's pension benefit for the housekeeper of his friend Anne Ford Uzielli, today vetoed a special benefit for the Sheriff of Suffolk County.

title: Bergland Says Fuel Plan Won't Hurt Food Supply
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  President Carter's new energy proposals will not hinder the growing or distribution of America's food this year or next, though there won't be a gallon of diesel fuel to spare, Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland said today.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates Stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: COMMODITIES
description: All gold and silver futures deliveries again soared to record levels yesterday as the dollar's value continued to weaken against key foreign currencies. Traders attributed the advances to the view that the President's energy program would be ineffective in the short term and inflationary when it finally took hold.

title: Republic Steel Net Up 29.3%
description: CLEVELAND, July 17 (AP)  The Republic Steel Corporation reported today a 29.3 percent increase in secondquarter earnings to $40.6 million, or $2.51 a share, on sales of $1 billion and shipments of 1,9 million tons.

title: Business Records
description: TUESDAY, JULY 17, 1979

title: Deaths
description: GROHRobert G. on July 14, 1979 of Little Neck L.I. Beloved son of the Honorable Robert T. and Ann M. Groh. Devoted brother of Kathleen Groh Matyzak. Uncle of Ann Hyacinth Matyzak. Funeral from the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway at Northern Blvd., Little Nk., on Saturday at 9:15am. Mass of Christian burial, at St. Anastasia's R.C. Church 9:45am. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Visting Thursday 710prn, Friday 25 and 710pm. In lieu of flowers kindly contribute to the Robert G. Groh Memorial Fund at Fordham Law School.

title: CARTER OFFERED RESIGNA TIONS BY CABINET AND SENIOR STAFF; SOME GOING IN DAYS, AIDES SAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  President Carter's Cabinet and all the members of his senior White House staff offered their resignations today, and top aides said later that Mr. Carter would accept some of them within the next few days.

title: Garlick
description: This is a menu for Chez Panisse's Garlic Festival: Thursday lunch, $7 Choice of: Aioli with fish and vegetables Garlic soup and garlic salad Real pasta pesto and garlic tomato salad

title: Sketches of the Nicaraguan Junta's Five Members
description: A 36yearold writer, recogniz leader of junta ... He is describe progressive and moderate who be a bridge between establish and leftist members of junta ... Studied law at University of Nicaragua where he graduated in 1964 . . . Married to the former Gertrudis Guerrero, has three children, all of whom were born in Costa Rica.

title: Coe Runs Mile in 3:49 For a World Record
description: OSLO, Norway, July 17 (AP)  Sebastian Coe of England broke the fouryearold world record for the mile run tonight, winning the Dubai Golden Mile in 3 minutes 49 seconds at Bislet Stadium.

title: Puerto Rico Is in Path Of New Tropical Storm
description: MIAMI, July 17 (UPI)  Tropical storm Claudette pulled a train of rain clouds along the Windward and Leeward Islands toward Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic today, but its speed retarded development into any greater weather threat. At 6 P.M., an Air Force hurricane hunter plane found the center of the storm moving westnorthwest at 20 miles an hour.

title: Yankees Upstage Stars
description: SEATTLE, July 17  In the reverse gear that has typified their season, the Yankees upstaged the AllStar Game tonight. Ip the ninth inning, Ron Guidry walked Lee Mazzilli of the Mets to force in the tiebreaking run in the American League's 76 loss. From 3,000 miles away, Al Rosen was reported about to resign as the Yankees president. And on an afternoon flight up here from his Oakland home, Reggie Jackson

title: Meyer and Campbell Are Named To Editorial Board of The Times
description: The appointment of Karl E. Meyer, the television critic for Saturday Review, and Colin Campbell, former managing editor of Human Nature and Sports Afield magazines, to the editorial board of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Max Frankel, editor of the editorial page.

title: Single Trial Asked in 33 Killings
description: CHICAGO, July 17 (UPI)  Attorneys for John Wayne Gacy, accused of murdering 33 boys and young men, have asked that all 33 murder charges against him be consolidated for a single trial. The defendant is confined to Cook County hospital for treament of chest pains and was not at the hearing yesterday before Judge Louis Garippo. The judge did not rule on the request.

title: Ballet: Cubans Marta Garca Takes Turn as OdetteOdile
description: YET another OdeiteOdile took to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday, when the National Ballet of Cuba presented Alicia Alonso's production of Swan Lake.

title: GROUP OF 40 BANKS WILL GIVE CITY HELP IN LARGE NOTE ISSUE
description: New York City officials announced yesterday that a consortium of 40 city, outofstate and foreign banks had agreed to serve as a backup lender for $600 million in shortterm notes that the city will market publicly in the next five months.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Whistling an Approach

title: 4 Bronx Candidates Agree Borough Is in a Bad Way
description: In their first campaign confrontation, four Democratic candidates for Bronx Borough President agreed yesterday that the borough they hope to lead is in bad shape.

title: Kopechnes Say They Don't Have The Whole Story on Accident
description: SWIFTWATER, PA.  The front door of the Kopechne home does not open easily; the hinges move reluctantly after years of little use.

title: Buehning Upsets Orantes In Tennis at Washington
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) Fritz Buehning, a 19yearold amateur from the University of California, Los Angeles, was the lone player to solve the patient games of the claycourt specialists today in the first round of the Washington. Star International men's tennis tournament.

title: Begin Tests Role as Peacemaker In Jerusalem Sports Center Fight
description: JERUSALEM  Amid worries and international disputes in the wake of the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty, Prime Minister Menachem Begin has found time for a personal attempt to achieve peace, or at least a truce, between opponents and proponents of a sports center.

title: Geologists Study Chance Of Rock Slide at Niagara
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 17 Government geologists are studying the rock formation at Terrapin Point, an observation site overlooking the 168foothigh Hor4eshoe Falls, in an attempt to determin0 whether 300,000 tons of rock could plunge to the base of the falls, causing a sudden flood in the lower Niagara River.

title: Events
description: Film

title: Q&A
description: Q. Each summer we go to the seashore. We have always been fascinated by the tiny sand crabs, smaller than a dime, that run around the beach. Over the years we have liked to discover things that we can harvest and make a meal of for free. Is it possible to cook those small crabs?

title: Soviet Will Join Refugee Meeting In Geneva, Waldheim Is Informed
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 17 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union, reversing its previous stand, has decided to attend this weekend's United Nations conference in Geneva on the Indochina refugee problem, Secretary General Kurt Waldheim disclosed today.

title: Search Continues for 2 Who Saw Galante and 2 Killed in Brooklyn
description: Five days after the murder of Carmine Galante, the reputed organizedcrime leader, and two companions, police officials yesterday continued a search for two missing witnesses who were a few feet from Mr. Galante when he was killed in a hail of gunfire.

title: Experts Studying Lung Disorders
description: EAU CLAIRE, Wis., July 17 (AP) Officials from the Center for Disease Control in Atlanta have joined the investigation of an outbreak of lung disorders that has included one death and one confirmed case of legionnaires disease. Three officials from the Atlanta center arrived here yesterday.

title: Utilities See OilGoal Obstacles
description: President Carter's proposal that the nation's electric utilities reduce their use of fuel oil by 50 percent during the next decade is drawing a lukewarm reception from industry representatives and some energy experts.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAINT PRIEST, France, July 17 (AP)  Dietrich Thurau of West Germany, racing to the finish line amid thick pack of cyclers, won the 19th leg of the Tour de France today in a photo finish, beating Jos Jacobs and Marc Demeyer of Belgium and Bernard Hinault of France.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, JULY 17, 1979

title: Deaths
description: NATHANDr. Helmuth. We mourn the death of Dr. Helmuth Nathan. He was an ardent supporter of our nursing center from its inception. As a Director of our Corporations and as a member of the Medical Committee he was always available and ready to help. We are grateful for his wise counsel and his compassionate concerns and shall miss his warmth and his humanitarian spirit.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: LIFE has never been fair and there is no indication that it ever will be. The wrong people are rich, the wrong people are beautiful and the wrong people are rewarded for all the wrong reasons.

title: Charter Corp. Name Change
description: Directors of the Charter New York Corporation voted yesterday to change the bank holding company's name to the Irving Bank Corporation, according to Gordon T. Wallis. chairman.

title: Geography
description: Nicaragua, the largest in area and the least densely populated of the Central American countries, is about 15 percent larger than New York State, having a land area of 57,143 square miles. It is bordered by Honduras on the north and Costa Rica on the south. Its Atlantic coastline is 336 miles long and the Pacific coastline is 219 miles long. The main cordillera, or mountain range, of Central America, rising as high as 7,000 feet, runs through the middle of the country and includes many volcanic peaks. The capital is Managua, a city of nearly 500,000 situated on a lake of the same name. In December 1972 more than 10,000 people were killed in an earthquake that destroyed

title: Rosen's Future With Yanks Is Uncertain
description: SEATTLE, July 17  George Steinbrenner and Al Rosen will meet in the next day, or two to determine Rosen's future with the Yankees, a source close to the club's executive level said today.

title: The City
description: Shamsher Wadud, owner of the Nirvana Restaurant at 30 Central Park South, was indicted for allegedly conducting a scheme to evade United States immigration laws.

title: Presidents Are Now Mayors
description: In the last generation, Presidents have come to act like mayors. They take on the meanest housekeeping concerns of daily existence, matters for which there are no ready answers and in which there is no political paydirt. These concerns were not the business of, Presidents historically, and grappling with them today quickly stains every Administration before it settles into place.

title: C.I.A.'s Saudi Oil Estimate
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The Central Intelligence Agency has lowered its estimate of the maximum amount of oil that Saudi Arabiacan produce on a sustained basis by 500,000 barrels a day, according to the agency's latest data. The July 11 issue of the International Energy Statistical Review, estimates that current Saudi maximum sustainable capacity has dropped to 9.5 million barrels a day.

title: Malaysian Aide Hopes to Reopen Door to Refugees
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, July 17  Malaysia, which is sheltering more Vietnamese refugees than any other country in Asia, is ready to resume admitting them if a United Nationssponsored conference offers a guarantee that eventually all the refugees will be accepted by third countries.

title: Kennedy Plot Theory Is Rejected by Counsel To the Warren Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  The former counsel to the Warren Commission today rejected the conclusion of the House Assassinations Committee that the murder of President Kennedy was part of a conspiracy.

title: Maurice Witherspoon, Retired Navy Chaplain
description: Capt. Maurice M. Witherspoon, a retired Navy chaplain who served in both World Wars, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Veterans. Administration Hospital in Brooklyn.  was 85 and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: 14 Hurt When PATH Train Derails
description: Fourteen passengers suffered minor injuries yesterday afternoon when a sevencar PATH train derailed on the west side of the Hackensack River bridge in Kearny, N.J. The train was traveling from Newark to the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan.

title: Some Senators Say an Arms Pact Loophole Aids Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, July 17  A new issue in the, Senate debate over the strategic arms treaty has arisen with the realization that the treaty would allow the Soviet Union'to deploy up to five intercontinental missile systems it has had under development.

title: Defects Found in Subway Cars Raise Questions About Management of Transit System
description: The subway cars purchased by New York City in 1972 from the Pullman Standard Company were envisioned as sleek, modern vehicles that would whisk New Yorkers into a new era of relatively smooth and quiet travel.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GLAD CAFE Folk City, a music lair at 130 West Third Street, was formerly on the site of the Bottom Line. At its present location, the cafe still continues a flourishing musical tradition of the early 60's, when folk entertainers performed their own new songs, rather than standard nieces.

title: S.E.C. Studies SCM Trading
description: BOSTON, July 17 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange are investigating unusual activity in the trading of the SCM Corporation's common stock, the company said yesterday.

title: The Price of Health for Poor Children
description: The sparring has begun on Capitol Hill over the shape and timing of national health insurance. Far from ringside, unfortunately, sits a modest bill, known as the Children's Health Assurance Act, which would improve health care immediately for millions of lowincome youngsters. Despite White House support and bipartisan backing, the, measure was ignored in last year's rush to adjournment. Unless Congress acts quickly, that will happen again.

title: Ballet: Netherlands Troupe Performs a Pair of Kylian Premieres
description: THE Netherlands Dance Theater offered the American premieres of two works by Jiri Kylian Monday night at the City Center55th Street Dance Theater. The premieres confirmed that Mr. Kylian is an unusually talented young choreographer and that under his direction the Netherlands Dance Theater, always a company worth seeing, has become a compapy worth getting excited about.

title: Gas Rationing Bill Advances
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The House Commerce Committee tonight approved a bill that would give President Carter standby gasoline rationing authority. The bill was supported by a fragile coalition of Administration supporters who overcame attempts to both weaken the plan and to make it easier to put into effect.

title: Prison Head Accused of Using State Workers on Home
description: A New York State prison superintendent and a former maintenance supervisor were charged yesterday with using state workers to reshingle the roof on the superintendent's home on Long Island.

title: Tranquillity Above the Circle
description: WHEN the designer Michael Springer first visiteg the apartment that his client David Russell, a partner in a Wall Street securities concern, was about to move into, Mr. Springer was struck by its possibilities. It hung over space. said the Israelborn designer, who moved to New York nine years ago. There was the Columbus Circle fountain and the park, so I decided to play a little. That meant taking as much advantage as possible of the bird'seye view, which is north on Central Park, and includes an angled, swirling view of the traffic around Columbus Circle. The designer had a wide plank platform built into the living room so that standing or seated, a visitor would have a dramatic view from the cor ner windows. Studying the space, which has windows to the north, and windows to the west, explained Mr. Springer, I decided to cut a line between them at a 45 degree angle. That influenced every other angle in the apartment. Because he found the original apartment plan sterile, the designer decided to place all the builtins and the furniture on the diagonal, as a way of enlivening the rectilinear space. I like taking a conventional space and converting it into something different, said Mr. Springer. Somehow, a nautical theme also emerged.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  In a flurry of speeches and background massages of newsmen, Jimmy Carter accused the American people of being selfindulgent, materialistic and morally dispirited. This from the man who promised to provide a government as good as the people.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Gold closed above $300 an ounce for the first time and the dollar tumbled as the world's financial markets reacted to uncertainties over President Carter's energy program and potential Cabinet changes. Gold was fixed at a record $303.85 an ounce in London in the morning and closed at $301. [Page A1.] Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal, in Congressional testimony about gold's rise and the dollar's fall, stopped short of relating the activity to his resignation offer or those of other Cabinet members, saying, I wouldn't want to personalize it in any way. [D3.]

title: Jets Ryan In Test For No. 3
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 18  When you're No. 3 you have to try harder much harder. Nobody knows that better than Pat Ryan, the thirdstring quarterback of the Jets.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Volatile price swings buffeted the precious metals market yesterday as gold and silver for both immediate and future delivery continued to set historic highs on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Getting the Drop on Us
description: After clogging the city's roads while millions were trying to get to work, the independent taxicab owners have told New Yorkers that they should be grateful that the cabbies massed yesterday only on the park- ways and at the Battery. Had they loved the city less, they would have jammed 42d Street.

title: First Boston Net Gains 1.5%
description: First Boston Inc. said it earned $2.72 million in the second quarter, up 1.5 percent from the $2.68 million it earned in the second quarter of 1978. Revenues declined, to $27.8 million from $28.5 million in the comparable period last year.

title: Hearings Begin on a Bill to Give Congress Veto Over Regulations
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)  Senator Harrison Schmitt renewed his campaign to give Congress a veto over Government regulations as a Senate subcommittee began hearings today on a bill that he failed to get through Congress last year.

title: A Renaissance In Old Linens
description: WHEN dripdry and permanentpress sheets and pillowcases arrived, many women discarded their cotton linens, even the ones embroidered by their mothers and grandmothers. But household linens, like clothes, are subject to the vagaries of fashion.

title: Canada Tells of Plan To Triple Admissions Of Indochina Refugees
description: OTTAWA, July 18  Two days before the opening of a United Nations conference on Indochinese refugees, the Canadian Government today announced a cooperative effort with private groups to increase significantly the number of Southeast Asians that Canada will accept for resettlement.

title: E.P.A. Aides Assert Disposal Rules Exempt Some Highly Toxic Wastes
description: Employees of the Environmental Protection Agency and staff members of the Environmental Defense Fund have charged that the agency's proposed regulations on waste disposal have been rewritten to exempt some of the most toxic wastes in the country.

title: A.M.C.'s Earnings Soar
description: DETROIT, July 18 (AP)  The American Motors Corporation reported today that it had earnings in the third fiscal quarter of $15.1 million, or 49 cents a share, up 147.5% from the $6.1 million, or 20 cents a share, it earned in the third quarter of the 1978 fiscal year. Net sales for the three months ended June 30 were a record $798 million, up 13.5 percent from $703 million a year ago, the company said.

title: Cabby Protest on Fares Ties Up Traffic in City in Morning Rush
description: Thousands of taxi owners, protesting what they said was an inadequate rise in taxi fares, tied up traffic on New York City bridges and streets during the morning rush period yesterday by moving slowly to a rally at the Battery.

title: Caribbean Tropical Storm Loses Its Force as Hurricane Claudette
description: MIAMI, July 18 (AP)  After dumping heavy rain on islands ringing the northeastern Caribbean and causing widespread flash flooding, the tropical storm Claudette weakened today, the National Hurricane Center reported.

title: Koch Puts Price On City Support For Casino Vote
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he wanted the city to receive 12 percent of the profits on table games and 50 percent of slot machine profits as its price for support of a constitutional amendment legalizing gambling casinos in New York State.

title: Libyan Leader Is Said to Promise To Send Syria 10 Advanced Jets
description: KUWAIT, July 18 (AP)  The Libyan leader, Muammar elQaddafi, has promised to send President Hafez alAssad of Syria 10 MIG25 jet fighters, a Kuwait newspaper said today.

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 18, 1979

title: Housing Starts Rose 5.7% in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) Housing construction rose last month to its highest level so far this year, the Government reported today, but the industry, which termed the performance a statistical fluke, predicted a sharp falloff in coming months.

title: Khomeini Is in Eye of a Storm That Seems Out of Control
description: TEHERAN, July 18  They marched again today in Iran, not by the hundreds, not by the thousands, but perhaps by the millions, chanting Unity with Khomeini, the Koran is our way and Death to leftists. Carter, Sadat and Begin.

title: Results on Water Projects Mixed
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  Congress has completed its annual appropriations for water projects, with the environmentalists and President Carter winning on two, losing on one, and drawing on two.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18 (AP)Tiger International and SeaboardWorld Airlines said today that they had agreed in principle to a merger of Seaboard and Tiger's Flying Tiger cargo airline subsidiary.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday incorrectly stated the reason that the Cabinet of President John Tyler, with one exception, resigned. The issue was his second veto of a bill to reestablish a national bank.

title: Guest Stabs a Woman In Nearby Apartment, Then Jumps to Death
description: A house guest in an Upper West Side building gained entrance to a female neighbor's apartment Tuesday afternoon with a gift of a bowl of salad, then threatened torture and rape before stabbing her, in the back and leaping to his death from a 10thfloor window. The woman, naked and suffering a wound that had penetrated her chest, left a trail of blood as she escaped by running to the lobby.

title: SlowStarting Borg Wins In Swedish Open, 64, 60
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 18 (AP) Bjorn Borg dropped his first two service games but came back strongly to defeat Christophe Freyss of France in two sets today in the $110,000 Swedish open tennis championship.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Bridge:
description: An unusual competition was concluded here last month, and the results are now available. It was the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation's Give Us A Hand contest, and the major winners were:

title: Q&A
description: Q. My masonry house has a fireplace and whenever there is a heavy rain, water drips down the inside of the chimney. It seeps past the damper and down onto the fireplace floor. Is this normal and can it be harmful? What should be done to correct it? H.J.L., Silver Spring, Md..

title: GARDENING
description: MONOCHROMATIC gardens are rather a rarity today. In New York City they are almost unheard of; yet it is in vibrant and colorful urban settings that onetone gardens can be most restful and striking.

title: Blumenthal Says Doubt Affects Dollar
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today that the price of gold was rising and the dollar falling because of a climate of uncertainty in Washington, but he stopped short of suggesting that the turmoil in the currency markets was related to his resignation offer or to the offers of other Cabinet members.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, July 18 (UPI)  More than 100 African students demonstrated here today with signs saying Down with racism and We want to go home.

title: Cosmos Win by 43 On Neeskens Goal
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 18  The Cosmos, receiving an excellent performance in goal from Hubert Birkenmeier, rebounded from two losses at home and defeated the Strikers, 43, tonight at Lockhart Stadium.

title: Dalai Larna Asserts That He Will Not End Exile Soon
description: NEW DELHI, July 18  The Dalai Lama, the exiled priestly king of Tibet, has declared in an interview here that there is no question of his returning soon to his Himalayan homeland, now incorporated into China. But he added that he still believed that some accommodation linking Marxism with the traditional religion and culture of his country was possible.

title: BLOOD ON BAT TIED TO ATTACK IN PARK
description: The trial of three young men accused of assaulting and seriously injuring six men in the Central Park Ramble last July opened yesterday with the surprise testi. mony of a witness who said the defendants left her apartment immediately before the attack, returned with a baseball bat and clothing covered with blood, and said that they had committed the assaults.

title: Unions in a Vise
description: SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y.  Labor union leaders are under the gun. Corporations and the Government, with tentative public backing, are prodding them to soften demands while we fight stagflation. Rankandfile union members are pushing them to reverse the recent effects of economic instability: stagnating real incomes, spreading heilthandsafety hazards, and mounting job insecurity. How should union leaders evaluate the critical choices they face? And how should the broader public respond to the unions dilemma?

title: Dow, Allied Profits Up In Quarter
description: Substantially higher earnings for the second quarter of 1979 were reported yesterday by several major chemical concerns, among them Dow, Allied and Celanese.

title: Hers
description: EVERY proper mother's child is given music lessons as part of his entitlement. Seldom does a virtuoso emerge from among children so privileged, but that is not the intention anyway. The intention is to offer music as a gift, along with life's other good gifts. And music, too, in the proper dose, provides just the right degree of restlessness of spirit that could lead to the approved noble aspirations.

title: U.S. Air Traffic Rose 12.4% in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) Traffic on United States airlines rose 15.4 percent in the first half of 1979, and air travel in June was lip 12.4. percent over June 1978, the Air Traffic Association reported today.

title: Original Staging Notes On Fair Lady Lost on Bus
description: The only comprehensive notations of the choreography and musical staging of the original My Fair Lady, were left on a 42d Street bus at 11th Avenue yesterday morning at 9 A.M.

title: The City
description: A 26yearold Bronx man was seized early yesterday in connection with a Harlem gun battle on July 3 that left a police officer partly blind, detectives said.

title: O.E.C.D. Study Foresees OilInduced Growth Lag
description: PARIS, July 18  This year's oil price rise will result in at least 12 months of economic stagnation in the United States, while other industrial countries will also face slower growth, more unemployment, rising inflation and aggravated payment difficulties in the coming year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today in its latest report on the economic outlook.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: KarlOtto Phl, vice president of West Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, appears to have moved from the darkhorse position to the favorite's spot in the race for the presidency. Although a Government decision on a choice to succeed Otmar Emminger, 68 years old, is still at least a month off, sources in Bonn believe that the scales have tipped away from the previous favorite, Wilfried Guth, the forceful president of the Deutsche Bank A.G., West Germany's biggest commercial bank.

title: Parker Is Praised For Hustle
description: SEATTLE, July 18  With his 6foot5inch, 230pound body clothed in a bright yellow uniform, Dave Parker could not quite hide in a corner of the Kingdome during the 50th AllStar Game. On the contrary, the Pittsburgh right fielder was highly visible and served the cause of highly paid players everywhere.

title: Sound
description: JUST going in circles looks easy. But appearances rarely tell the whole truth, and in turntables, as elsewhere, there's more to it than meets the eye. It isn't just a matter of making the platter go around to spin the record. For one thing, the turntable must rotate at exactly the right speed, or else the music will be off key.

title: Oil Officials Deny Price Conspiracy
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) Executives of four oil companies said today that they were prepared to swear under oath that they know of no conspiracy to hold gasoline off the market in anticipation of higher prices.

title: Around the Nation
description: HONOLULU, July 18 (AP)  Hawaii's police officers returned to their jobs this morning, ending their walkout more than 36 hours after a state judge issued a backtowork order.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Thick thunderstorm clouds extend from eastern New England to the South Atlantic States and across to the Gulf Coast. A band bf uniform low and midlevel clouds stretches from the Southern Plains States to the Southwest with thunderstorm clouds centered over the Texas Panhandle. Uniform low level clouds cover the Pacific Coast.

title: Advertising
description: IRVING SONN, who last January quit Ted Bates & Company, where he was president of United States affiliates, is back in the business, this time as founder of Iry Sonn Advertising Inc.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, affected by a weaker dollar, a record price for gold and surprisingly strong housing starts in June, declined yesterday, wiping out the gains they had made Tuesday afternoon.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 18. 1979

title: MacKinnon New Nets' Aide
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 18 (AP)  Bob MacKinnon, former assistant coach with the Boston Celtics, was named today to a similar position with the New Jersey Nets.

title: GILBERT W. LOW
description: Gilbert W. Low, 40, of Arlington, Mass., an assistant professor of management at the Alfred P. Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was killed in an automobile accident Sunday in Mexico while on vacation. He had a major role in developing the System Dynamics National Model, which is used to evaluate alternative economic policies. He is survived by his wife, Uta; parents, Mr. and Mrs. George E. Low of Morristown, N.J.; and two brothers, Dana E. of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Calvin D. of Chatham, N.J.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, July 18,1979

title: JORDAN APPOINTED CARTER STAFF CHIEF; AIDES WILL BE RATED
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  President Carter has made his longtime political aide, Hamilton Jordan, White House chief of staff as the first step in reshuffling his personal staff and Cabinet, the White House announced today.

title: Indian President Asks Desai Foe to Form Government
description: NEW DELHI, July 18  President N. Sanjiva Reddy asked the leader of India's second largest party today to attempt to form a government that would end this country's crisis of leadership.

title: Dentist, Using Photos, Links Bundy to Bites On Victim in Slaying
description: MIAMI, July 18 (AP)  A forensic dentist testified today that the teeth shown in a photograph of Theodore R. Bundy's mouth made the bite marks found on a slain female college student.

title: Winds Push Bus Off Road
description: BUCKEYE, Ariz., July 18 (AP)  High winds pushed a Greyhound bus off the road and on to its side yesterday, injuring 17 of its 24 passengers, the Arizona Department of. Public Safety said. Three persons were seriously injured. The bus was on its way to Memphis when it was struck by winds of 60 to 70 miles an hour on Interstate 10.

title: In Summer, They'll Take Manhattan
description: IT'S a nice view, said Mary Ramond, who is shown (page C1) with her husband, Charles, on the wraparound terrace of her upper Fifth Avenue coop. And so it is. On a clear day, she said, you can see from the George Washington Bridge to the World Trade Center. It's a spectacular, panoramic view of the West Side of Manhattan. Mrs. Ramond, a freelance writer, and her husband, who is president of an economic forecasting company, have lived in their apartment for 13 years. They look down on the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Central Park reservoir. She is the gardener, battling the sun and the high winds. My friends love it, she continued, but they don't seem to be around when it's time to do the planting. Neither is her husband. He enjoys basking in the sun and reading outdoors on weekends, said Mrs. Ramond. Once a summer, she takes him on a tour and briefs him as to what has been planted. This year, there are hybrid tea roses, fuchsias and dahlias and ash, locust, crab apple and oak trees, a herb garden and an espaliered pyracantha.

title: 15 Food Concerns Cited By City's Health Agency
description: The New York City Department of Health yesterday released the names of 15 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code.

title: OneYear Bills Sold at 8.896%
description: The Treasury auctioned oneyear bills yesterday at an average yield of 8.896 percent, up slightly from the previous sale of 8.829 percent.

title: Juilliard to Aid Dramatists
description: The Juilliard School has been given $2 million to help talented young American playwrights.

title: Aoki Wins His Own Boat Race
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J., July 18  In a race marred by heavy rain and thunderstorms, Rocky Aoki of New York City, driving a 38foot Cougar catamaran, churned across the fin ish line off Manasquan inlet today to win the $50,000 Bentham Grand Prix offshore powerboat race.

title: 3 Zoo Monkeys Go Free Briefly
description: Three monkeys  Zachary, Brian and Charlie  escaped from their cage in the Central Park Zoo yesterday by working on a defective padlock until it gave way.

title: GOLD SURPASSES $300 AND DOLLAR SLUMPS ON FEARS ABOUT OIL
description: LONDON, July 18  The price of gold rose above $300 an ounce for the first time today and the dollar fell sharply as world financial markets reacted to uncertainties over President Carter's energy program and potential changes in his Cabinet.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JULY 19, 1979

title: Solomon Upset by Fagel In Washington Tourney
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)  Thirdseeded Harold Solomon, faltering from fatigue, was upset by unseeded Rick Fagel, 63, 26, 6.4, today in the second round of the $175,000 Washington Star International men's tennis tournament.

title: Dalton School's Trustees Report Election of New Board President
description: The board of trustees of the Dalton School yesterday announced the election of Jerry I. Speyer as president of the 25member body.

title: Grand Gazebos On a Small Scale
description: IF you're looking for a small summer place, Ann GattoCimmelli may have just the thing. The New York craftsman makes gazebos that stand one or two feet tall and are a pleasure to look at. Most are fancifully Victorian, but now and then, Mrs. GattoCimmelli does some Gothic styles and customordered designs.

title: Deaths
description: ALBOHNFrances S. Reposing Williams Funeral Home. on Broadway at 232nd Street, Bronx, until Saturday, 9:30AM.

title: Engineers Warned Builder of Danger Year Before Three Mile Island Accident
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  Two engineers for the company that supplied the nuclear reactor that broke down at Three Mile Island said today that they had warned their superiors a year earlier that a serious accident was possible but that the warning had not been passed on.

title: Gabon Executes Two Murderers
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon, July 18 (Reuters)  Two convicted murderers were executed by firing squad here today before a crowd of more than 10,000 people, officials said. The /executions were the first in Gabon since the country became independent from France in 1960.

title: Coe Plans One More '79 Race
description: OSLO, July 18 (UPI)  Sebastian Coe of England, who in the space of 13 days has set world records in the 800 meters and mile, said today he would probably run only one more race this year.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Carey, Citing Existing Statutes, Vetoes Bill on Fraternity Hazing
description: ALBANY, July 18  Governor Carey announced today his veto of a bill that would have made some types of college fraternity hazing a crime, saying that adequate protections already existed and that the bill's provisions were so vague they would be hard to enforce.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar finished lower across the board in Europe yesterday as gold climbed over $300 an ounce for the first time. And in later trading in New York, the dollar's decline continued. Trading was active.

title: Stamford Agrees to Quota System For Hiring Minorities for Fire Dept.
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 18  The City of Stamford agreed in Federal court here today to hire one minoritygroup applicant for the Fire Department for every white applicant hired, until the department has a 17.5 percent minority composition.

title: Senators Fighting Carey On M.T.A. Nominations
description: ALBANY, July 18  Angry Senate Republican blocked two of Governor Carey's nominees to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority today after the Governor Ignored the Senate majority leader's request that he reappoint a prominent Republican to the board.

title: Refinery Production Off in Week
description: The upward trend in the production of petroleum products was interrupted in the week ended July 13 as the operating rate of the nation's oil refineries dropped to 86.6 percent of capacity from 90.3 percent in the preceding week, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum. Institute.

title: Americans Get a Varied Assortment of Moscow Olympic Tickets
description: The Olympic Games in Moscow will start a year from today, and the Americans who hope to be spectators there received a mixed bag of news yesterday.

title: As U.N.'s Sinai Term Nears End, Three Options Are Being Studied
description: CAIRO, July 18  Although the United Nations peacekeeping mandate in Sinai expires next week, Egypt, Israel and the United States have not yet come up with an alternative force to meet the provisions of the peace treaty.

title: The Kalamazoo Sails After Major Repairs
description: After a $13 million refurbishing that took 10 months, the Kalamazoo, a 659footlong Navy supply ship, left yesterday from the site of the former Brooklyn Navy Yard for Norfolk, Va., where the vessel will be reassigned to sea duty.

title: Court to Hear Killer's Plea
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 18 (UPI) The Florida Supreme Court today agreed to hear a request for a stay of execution for Howard V. Douglas, a condemned killer. The request said that the death penalty should not have been imposed because the jury had recommended mercy. The court set the hearing for 9:30 A.M. .Friday, giving the Attorney General until 5 P.M. tomorrow to file arguments opposing the stay.

title: Gas Pipeline Is Canceled By Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 18  Iran has canceled the export segment of an 868mile naturalgas pipeline that it was constructing to supply the Soviet Union, West Germany, France, Austria and Czechoslovakia, officials here disclosed today.

title: OnceinCentury Bamboo Plant Blooms, Tantalizing Botanists
description: One of the most beautiful species of bamboo:called umbrella, has begun to blossom for the first time in 100 years in northern Europe and will soon bloom throughout the United States and the rest of the world. After that, all the world's umbrella bamboo will die.

title: Market Place
description: LEADING domestic oil companies will report their profits for the June quarter next week, and the figures promise to be robust. In fact, Eugene L. Nowak, who follows these stocks for Blyth Eastman Dillon & Company, predicts that secondquarter earnings will be stronger than most analysts expect and that; in turn, should lead to a reevaluation of fullyear prospectis.

title: San Clemente Panel Wants Nixon to Repay $37,358
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)  An interagency panel is recommending that the Government press former President Richard M. Nixon to repay $37,358 for nonprotective security improvements included in the $702,321 that the Government spent on his San Clemente home.

title: Little Harm to OPEC Seen in Carter Plan
description: PARIS, July 18  The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the target of sometimes strong rhetoric from the Carter Administration, is nevertheless facing no practical threat as a result of the West's efforts to deal with the energy crisis.

title: Ammonia Cloud Routs 200
description: EASTON, Md., July 18 (AP)  Some 200 to 300 people were evacuated from their homes for a short time early today when a cloud of ammonia formed over a leaking storage tank near Easton. A valve on one of the storage tanks, owned by the KerrMcGee Corporation and leased to a local distributor, apparently was open or broken, said Alan Smith, a dispatcher for the Talbot County Fire Control Board.

title: Japan Payments in Deficit
description: TOKYO, July 18 (AP)  Increased imports drove Japan's currentaccount balance of payments in the first six months of 1979 into the red for the first time in four years, the Finance Ministry announced today. The ministry said the nation ran a deficit of $1.68 billion through June, a sharp turnaround from the $8.55 billion surplus in the yearearlier period.

title: CBS Alumni Reunite at NBC's Top
description: Recent executive changes at NBC form a pattern that indicates the direction Fred Silverman is taking in the remaking of the National Broadcasting Company.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankers Not Surprised
description: Banking sources hi New York said that they were not surprised that Iran had canceled the pipeline project. And they added that it was doubtful that the new regime in Iran would have been capable of producing enough gas to send through the pipeline even if it were built.

title: Coast Court Is Asked to Rule on Inquiry on Its Conduct
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 18  The California Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether a public investigation of its members conduct was constitutional and was warned that unless it acted the investigation might never be properly completed.

title: Calendar
description: A preview tonight from 5 P.M. to P.M. opens a new crafts show by artists from the Southeastern states that will continue through Aug. 25.

title: Home Beat
description: BARBARA EIGEN, left, had taught ceramics when she was in college at Cornell. But, she explained, I didn't really know much about it then. Now she does. In 1971, she and her husband, Eric, drove to Costa Rica. She learned to speak Spanish and got a job as a consultant in a tile factory, testing glazes, and taught ceramics at the University of Costa Rica in San Jose. The Eigens and their son, Zev, came back to New York in 1976. New York had become a demanding place, explained Mrs. Eigen. But, it was the challenge we were looking for. She started making ceramic vegetables and Lee Bailey, the retailer, liked her work and gave her her first order. She then expanded her vegetable and fruit repertory. One day. I was fooling around with a pattypan squash, which is a white summer squash, and Lee thought it would make a great sugar bowl, expldined Mrs. Eigen. Then came quiche plates and casseroles, cantaloupe dessert bowls, eggplant tureens, and butternut squash containers. Mrs. Eigen studies the real fruit, and makes her own molds. The glazes are sprayed and hand poured and the pieces require two firings. All the pieces are dishwasher, ovenand freezerproof, she insists. At left, Mrs. Eigen holds one of her acorn squash containers ($17.50 at Macy's); the green pear, above, which can be used for sherbet is $18 at BaileyHuebner at Henri Bendel. The cantaloupe bowls are $15 at Dean & DeLuca (121 Prince Street), and a selection of squash, pumpkin, and carrotinspired serving pieces ($6 to $40) will be at Saks Fifth Avenue in September.

title: Two Share Lead at 140 In State Amateur Golf
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 18 (UPI) Four golfers were tied for the lead with scores of 2underpar 140 today atter the second round of the 57th annual New York State amateur golf tournament.

title: Edgy Capital Sifts Rumors
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  An impression is developing among Administration officials that President Carter's current Government shakeup is aimed more at raising White House political control over various departments and agencies than at reorienting Administration policy.

title: Dissarray of Assassination Panel Faded as 2d Counsel Took Over
description: When he was appointed chief counsel to the strifetom House Select Crommittee on Assassinations and assumed the burden of brightening the legislative and investigative reputation ot:that panel, G. Robert Blakey stood before a gathering of reporters and said witlia flinty grin:

title: Youth's Father Pressing Carey On CallIn Vow
description: Edmund R. Gillette of New Hartford, N.Y., a village near Utica, thinks Governor Carey made him a promise, and he expects the Governor to keep it.

title: Model Rooms: Images Of Past and Future
description: I HAVE spent a good deal of time in model rooms. Their evocative, empty spaces have done a lot to shape my life. As a childwanderer in museums, I discovered 18thcentury France in the silent boiserie of the recreated Louis XV salons of New York's Metropolitan Museum. Those rooms worked their magic even though I knew that Fifth Avenue, not France, was outside the false windows through which a, cool gray light filtered evenly, without dusk or dawn, miles and centuries away from the Paris of the ebenistes of the King.

title: Senate Decides to Finish Its Third Office Building
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)  The Senate voted by a narrow margin today to finish its third office building at a cost nearly triple the estimate architects gave when the structure was first authorized seven years ago.

title: 2 Companies to Run Art Shows
description: Watched by the museum world with mixed approval and apprehension, two corporations are taking a plunge into art exhibitions. In the wake of the spectacular success of the museumorganized Tutankhamun tour, Time Inc. and the Control. Data Corporation are stepping well beyond the usual corporate involvement  the mere giving of taxdeductible support money  into active management of the kind of international art extravaganzas heretofore arranged by museums themselves.

title: 2 Grand Jury Indictments Reported In Slayings of Four in Bedford Hills
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 18  A Westchester County grand jury has indicted two men In the May 10 murders of four Bedford Hills residents, a source close to the investigation said today.

title: Geneen Said to Plan Venture
description: Harold S. Geneen, chairman of the board of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, has been negotiating with European and American banks for multimilliondollar loans to start a major venture not associated with I.T.T., industry sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Old Linens Need Careful Washing
description: Old linens should be washed by hand in lukewarm water with relatively neutral detergent, such as liquid Ivory or Orvus WA paste (available at Talas, 130 Fifth Avenue). With anything delicate or collectible, absolutely no washing machines, said Malcolm Delacorte, a textile conservator at the American Museum of Natural History. You can do terrible damage to old things by treating them the wrong way.

title: Longmuir  Leads British Open by 3
description: ST. ANNES, England, July 18  Bill Longmuir, a 26yearold English golfer of modest talent, struck a hot putting streak today and led the windblown, chilly first round of the 108th British Open golf championship.

title: A Memory Of English Gardens
description: FRANCIS AND PAT MASON spent four years in London, where he was a cultural attach at the American Embassy. A year ago, they bought a house in Greenwich Village and Set about making a souvenir of the English gardens they had admired and envied. Flowers, all summer long, is what I remember, said Mrs. Mason. Big, blousy herbaceous borders, spilling out color.

title: Entertainment Events
description: MOSTLY MOZART: CHAMBER MUSIC RECITAL, Avery Fisher Hall, 8. Preconcert recital, 7.

title: Music: Village Festival
description: FOR many years, all the concerts of the Washington Square Music Festival were held in the park itself unless bad weather forced retreat indoors into a hall lent by New York University. Now, however, a new custom seems to be in the making  mat ot presenting the opening event in a Greenwich Village church. Thus, the first concert of the 1979 season, given on Tuesday night, had the lofty and lovely interior of Grace Church as its setting. The church was filled almost to overflowing at the outset of the evening, but the hot, steamy weather took its toll, and at intermission a number of listeners gave up and went off in search of cooler accommodations.

title: World Bank Cut Is Voted
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)  The House voted to slash the'United States contribution to the World Bank by nearly 50 percent and approved cuts of 2 percent in. appropriations for two other international lending agencies.

title: Woman Named By Javits to Get U.S. Judgeship
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  Senator Jacob K. Javits has selected Elizabeth F. Defeis, a law professor at Seton Hall Law Center in Newark, for a Federal judgeship in the Eastern District of New York. If approved by President Carter and the Senate, the Brooklyn resident would become the first woman to sit on the bench in that district.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Ballet: Joffrey's Diaghilev
description: ASTONISH me, serge Diaghilev once told Jean Cocteau. From 1909 to. 1929, Diaghilev's Ballets Russes championed choreographic astonishment.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Michael Baker Corporation, Beaver, Pa., an engineering consulting service, has elected to its board of directors John G. Good Jr., a Beaver County attorney.

title: Hope for HeavyOil Producers
description: Sidney Petersen's ears perked up when he heard what President Carter said in Kansas City, Mo., on Monday morning.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: FOR hard to light areas, for work tables where one doesn't want lamp taking up space, or areas where a permanent light installation is not necessary, clampon lights offer a convenient means of lighting.

title: Technology
description: ELECTRODEPOSITION, an application of the principle that opposites attract, is taking on a rapidly expanding role in the nation's auto industry as a highly effective, fast, anticorrosive method of painting cars.

title: Courville, Green Tie For Hochster Medal
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 18  Jerry Courville Sr., the 44yearold golfer from Norwalk, Corm., who underwent radical surgery to remove a malignancy four years ago, today finished playing 153 holes of winning, competitive golf that he began seven days ago over two of the most demanding golf courses in the metropolitan area Winged Foot and Quaker Ridge.

title: Cleveland City Council President Freed in Carnival Kickback Case
description: CLEVELAND, July 18 (AP)  George L. Forbes, the outspoken City Council president and bitter opponent of Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich, was acquitted by a judge today on all charges stemming from alleged carnival kickbacks.

title: Bonanza at the Meadowlands
