description: With half a mile to go, harness racing's most expensive yearling purchase was pacing fifth and beginning to tire.

title: Wallpaper School Offers New Careers
description: PEOPLE gifted with patience, creativity, a searching mind and a passion for methodology have what it takes to become successful wallpaper hangers, says Stan Warshaw, headmaster and president of the United States School of Professional Paperhanging in Rutland, Vt.

title: Ballet: Cubans Perform Prologue for a Tragedy
description: OFFERING what could be called a truly interAmerican premiere, the National Ballet of Cuba presented a new ballet by a Canadian choreographer Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. To many dance fans, Brian Macdonald's Prologue for a Tragedy will seem both familiar and surprising.

title: But Chinese Have Put End to the Lamaist Theocracy
description: LHASA, Tibet, July 17  They come from all over the high plateau of Chinese Central Asia, pilgrims in black robes, silver daggers at their belts, wearing high canvas boots and carrying chalices laden with yak butter for offerings. It could be a scene from a medieval tapestry.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FRENCH CONNECTION And what have we now at the World Trade Center? Molire, no less. Today at 12:15 P.M. in the plaza, the eightmember Sidewalks of New York troupe will perform the French playwright's comedy classic of the 17th century, The Intended Wedding, updating the work with song and dance, mime, slapstick, improvisation and audience participation. If it rains, the midday entertainment moves inside to the mezzanine of 1 World Trade Center.

title: Bathtub With a View
description: WHEN Vera Rechulski takes a bath in her 23dfloor apartment she luxuriates not only in the bath but in an expansive view of the city provided by a floortoceiling window.

title: Feminists Ask ShakeUp For Private Foundations
description: Feminist groups called yesterday for a shakeup in the organization of the nation's 26,000 private foundations to insure more financing for women's projects that now receive less than 1 percent of their donations.

title: Canahoney and Cranford Take Stakes at Roosevelt
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 18  A pair of 2yearold fillies sired by Songoan, who is now standing at the Pine Hollow Stud Farm's stable in Pine Bush, N.Y., triumphed in rich New York Sire Stakes events at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: Man Convicted of Rape Attacks His Prosecutor
description: When the jury announced in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that it had found Frank Peterson guilty of rape, sodomy and burglary, the prosecutor relaxed and began tidying his court papers.

title: Music: Mostly Mozart
description: THE program for Tuesday night's Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall, the season's second, might have been chosen according to the whims of I Ching. As so often happens, the selection must have been dictated by the accident of which musicians were available, rather than by any compelling programmatic philosophy or logic.

title: Theater: Arturo Ui At Williamstown
description: WILLIAM TOWN, MASS. BECAUSE Bertolt Brecht's The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui is so closely detailed in its satire of the coming to power of Adolf Hitler, a weight of historic emotion is bound to invade us when we see it.

title: U.S. Got Fair Oil Share, Inquiry Finds
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  Energy Department investigators have concluded that American oil companies have not diverted foreign crude oil or gasoline away from the United States, a department official reported today.

title: EARNINGS
description: American Airlines reported yesterday that its secondquarter profits surged 117.1 percent, with a net of $95.3 million, or $3.22 a share, up from $43.9 million, or $1.43 a share, in the quarter ended June 30,1978.

title: Harmony at Africa Talks Eroding
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 18  The surface harmony at the conference of heads of state of the Organization of African Unity, which was disrupted at the opening session yesterday, suffered further blows today from speeches by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and by Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, the Nigerian leader.

title: Rosen-Steinbrenner Talks Continue Today
description: Al Rogen, after daylong meetings With the Yankees principal owner, George Steinbrenner, left Yankee Stadium last night still undecided about his future as president of the team.

title: REFUGEES A STRAIN ON HEALTH SERVICES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 18  Indochinese refugees are straining health services here beyond capacity, but their rapidly increasing numbers pose no health threat to local residents, a senior public health official said today.

title: Israeli Finance Minister May Quit
description: TELAVIV, July 18  Finance Minister Simcha Ehrlich, accused of indecisiveness in dealing with Israel's economic ills, said today that he was considering resigning from the Cabinet.

title: How a President Acts
description: If it's theater that Jimmy Carter now means to give us, the first thing to do is appreciate the performance for what it is. Palm pressed to forehead, atop the mountain: the President thinking. Pad and pencil in hand, in an unfamiliar parlor: the President consulting. Fist pounding the table, on television: the President commanding. Back to the White House then to ask the Cabinet to resign en masse: the people's President in action, hounding the elitists from the temple.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY  The president of the Police Benevolent Association of the New York State Troopers Inc., was arraigned yesterday on charges of thirddegree grand larceny and falsifying business records.

title: The Nixons Extend Their HouseHunting to Greenwich
description: The reports that Richard M. Nixon and his wife, Pat, plan to move back to the New York area to be closer to their children are indeed true.

title: About Fire Island
description: The Sunday daytrippers were waiting at the dock in Bay Shore, L.I., a Dunkirk of quickvisit tourists pent in a perimeter of parked cars, refugees from Manhattan's middle latitudes ; Zabar shopping bags and Sunday papers in hot grasp marking time for the boat that would evacuate them to a carefree, sandswept day on Fire Island.

title: Bank Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (H) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (Q) overthe-counter.

title: Ban on Sharing Car Data Reversed
description: LOS ANGELES, July, 18 (AP)A Federal judge has reversed his 10yearold decision that kept four American auto makers from sharing research information on automobile pollution control devices.

title: Somoza's Bitter Legacy
description: The collapse of the rickety House of Somoza was bound to be followed by uncertainty and even turbulence. But the outgoing tenants themselves, starting with .former President Somoza, now in Miami exile, have been largely responsible for the collapse of an orderly transfer of power to the revolutionary junta. Now, thankfully, the agreedon transition appears to have been accepted even by his diehard supporters in Managua. That outcome is more than the United States might have expected, or perhaps even deserved.

title: Home Buyers Gas Worries
description: The gasoline shortage is tarnishing an American dream: owning house in the suburbs.

title: Celanese Expects I.R.S. Inquiry
description: The Celanese Corporation said the Internal Revenue Service was expected to notify it of proposed deficiencies on Celanese corporate income tax returns filed from 1970 throueh 1973.

title: Bumper Wheat Lacks Boxcars
description: WICHITA, Kan., July 18  Middle Western farmers are bringing in a bumper wheat crop and receiving unusually high prices for their product, but the very abundance is causing severe storage and transportation problems.

title: On the Front Lines Of a Rubbish War
description: WHEN I lived in Greens Farms, Conn., I felt compassion for New York City's poor. When I moved next door to them on West 78th Street and found them throwing garbage in my backyard, my compassion vanished. This was a great lesson in the relationship between one's address and opinions and marked the beginning of my political education.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: Millions of barrels

title: Don't Disable Social Security
description: Some months ago, President Carter asked Congress for modest, sensible changes in Social Security to reduce the need for raising the payroll tax again. The Administration proposed, for example, curtailing some burial benefits and stopping subsidies to affluent student survivors. But Congress is so wary of offending beneficiaries that the House refused to touch even these generous benefits. The Ways and Means Committee did, however, approve the least controversial proposal  a reform of the disability program. But Congressional sensitivity remains; now even that bill seems to be in trouble. For it to tail would be a blow good sense in the short term  and to Social Security recipients in the long run.

title: F.A.A. Seeks $385,000 Fine for Unairworthy Planes
description: The Federal Government said yesterday that it had taken action to fine Pacific Southwest Airlines $385,000 for an apparent pattern of rules violations in maintaining and operating its aircraft.

title: Textile Union Suit Filed
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) An $11.9 million civil suit was filed today by a textile workers union against the J.P. Stevens Company, three other concern and officials of Milledgeville, Ga., alleging they conspired to keep unions out of the area.

title: U.A.W. Rules Out Strike Of Chrysler in Pact Talks
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., July 18 The United Automobile Workers, acknowledging the critical financial condition of the Chrysler Corporation, notified company officials today that Chrysler would not be considered a possible strike target in the union's formal contract negotiations with the nation's three largest automobile malers, which began this week.

title: Nigerian Student at L.I.U: Pleads Guilty to Mail Fraud on U.S. Loan
description: A 30yearold Nigerian citizen who studied at Long Island University in Brooklyn pleaded guilty yesterday to defrauding the Federal Government of studentloan funds available only to United States citizens.

title: Bar Group Backs Judge Wright, Calls Koch Criticism IllAdvised
description: A City Bar Association committee yesterday called entirely appropriate the decision last April by Judge Bruce McM. Wright of Criminal Court to release without bail a man accused of the attempted murder of a police officer.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: With reference to the article by Michael Varese [The Touches That Can Save Old Veneer, July, 12], we would like to make the following comments:

title: 2 Kidneys From Moscow Arrive for Transplant Use
description: The kidneys of a 21yearold Soviet man involved in a fatal accident arrived in New York from Moscow yesterday, less than a month after the United States sent the kidney of a dead Virginia girl to the Soviet Union.

title: No Grain Board, Please
description: WASHINGTON  That countryandWestern tune Cheaper Crude or No More Food has been catching on, probably because of the simplistic premise that we can use our food exports as a lever against the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. A similar song with the catchy title A Bushel for a Barrel is being sung by advocates of a National Grain Board who are trying to use that misleading slogan to get support for selling grain at a jackedup price for oil from petroleumexporting countries. This allpowerful board is embodied in a bill introduced by Representative James Weaver, Oregon Democrat, and others.

title: First Chicago Shares Sold
description: Ben W. Heineman, president of Northwest Industries and a director of the First Chicago Corporation, sold 100,000 shares of First Chicago on Nue 13, the New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday.

title: Dow Inches Up in a Late Rally
description: The stock market was shaken early yesterday by Tuesday's news that the entire Cabinet and senior: White House staff aides had offered President Carter their resignations.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Mondale Stumps for Arms Pact, But Finds Concern Over Energy
description: OMAHA, July 18  For the last two days, Vice President Mondale has been campaigning for public support of the pending SovietAmerican treaty to limit offensive nuclear weapons. But the public, it seems, is more interested In the Carter Administration's proposals for reducing American dependence on foreign oil.

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN a house is built on sloped ground, or when part of the yard slopes sharply enough to cause soil washouts or flooding, a retaining wall can provide considerable help.

title: New City Corporation Joins the Effort to Aid In Economic Recovery
description: New York City yesterday began its latest effort to improve its economy with an organization meeting of the Economic Capital Corporation.

title: Norton Bout Postponed
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18 (AP)  Ken Norton and Scott LeDoux, originally scheduled to fight in San Diego on Sunday, will meet on Aug. 19 in Minneapolis. The heavyweight bout was postponed because Norton suffered a torn cartilage in his rib cage during a sparring session Monday morning.

title: Poll Finds Less Hostility By Public Toward Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)  A new Roper Poll suggests that public resentment toward taxes, such as that that gave rise to California's Proposition 13, is cooling off but that taxpayers would like to see the Federal Government limit spending.

title: TV: Infinite Horizons, Futuristic Pastiche on ABC
description: INFINITE Horizons: Space Beyond Apollo, being broadcast at 8:30 tonight, is not part of the ABC News Closeup series. Instead of dealing with facts of the past or present, this production offers speculations on the future. The occasion, of course, is tomorrow morning's 10th anniversary of the Apollo 11 moon landing.

title: In Summer, Teachers Become Pupils
description: DESPITE the fact that many teachers say they feel that two of the best reasons for teaching are July and August, hundreds of them have sacrificed some vacation time to stay in school and attend the Lincoln Center Institute. They are there in the Juilliard building  all day, every weekday for three weeks  examining the performing arts and new ways of helping their pupils expand their abilities to see and to understand things.

title: Arrest Made in Killing of Girl Who Cried in Holdup
description: An 18yearold Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and accused of murdering a teenage girl because she had cried in uncontrollable terror during a holdup in a Crown Heights grocery on May 30.

title: Chief of Staff For President
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  In President Carter's two and a half years in the White House, one aspect of his stewardship has never wavered: his personal reliance on Hamilton Jordan and the steadily expanding power given the 34yearold politician.

title: U.S., Exerting Pressure, Says Nicaragua Peace Plan Is Taking Hold
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  The United States applied heavy pressure today on Nicaragua's former President, Anastasio Somoza Debayle, and his successor to support a peaceful transfer of power to guerrillabacked provisional govern. ment, and Carter Administration officials reported subsequently that the peace plan appeared to be taking hold.

title: 3 in Sandinists' Junta Fly Home After a Series of Near Calamities
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 18 Lowering clouds, breaches of secrecy, a communications breakdown and a mysterious Jeep beside the airport entrance almost scuttled their plan, but finally early this morning the three members of the Nicaraguan rebel junta based here slipped out of Costa Rica and flew home.

title: Somoza's Successor in Flight to Guatemala
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 18 Faced with the rapid disintegration of the National Guard, Nicaragua's new Government decided today to hand over power to a rebelnamed provisional junta that set up its temporary capital in the northern city of Leon early this morning.

title: Coghlan Takes Swiss 3,000 In 7:40.46
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, July 18 (UPI)  Henry Rono of Kenya finished a disappointing seventh in a 3,000meter race tonight that was won by Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland.

title: Cavaliers to Talk to Reed About Coach's Job Today
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, July 18 (AP)Nick Mileti, the president of the Cleveland Cavaliers, planned to interview Willis Reed, former New York Knicks coach, tomorrow for the coaching position of the National Basketball Association team.

title: Harold Brown Seeks to Assure Senate on Pact Verification
description: WASHINGTON, July 18  Secretary of Defense Harold Brown sought to assure the Senate today that the United States would be able to verify adequately the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union, but his testimony brought to light unresolved issues and disputes.

title: Dance: At Jacob's Pillow
description: BECKET, MASS. DESPITE the depredations of this gasless summer, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival rolls on as comfortably as ever. On Tuesday the festival, now in its 47th season, presented the third mixed bill of its dance. If the blend was a familiar one of ballet and modern dance, there were still a few surprises.

title: 200,000 Ecuadorearzs Share Hope in Future
description: After solemn Quito, the capital that lies high in the cool Andes Mountains, and boisterous Guayaquil, the national commercial center drenched by the equatorial sun and washed by the Pacific in the lowlands, the third largest Ecuadorean city  community memhers are fond of saying  lies on the banks of the East River.

title: Books of The Times
description: TWO things about Joseph H. Hirshhorn are common knowledge. One is that he made a lot of money. The other is that he bought a lot of art, much of which is now in the museum that bears his name on the Mall in Washington.

title: New Subsidiary Set Up By Simon & Schuster
description: For the third time in three years, Simon & Schuster has set up an independent hardcover publishing house, the Linden Press, which will be a wholly owned subsidiary of the parent company.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Stocks Are Mixed as Volume Shrinks
description: The stock market was mixed yesterday as a recovery by the dollar abroad and a Government report on Wednesday that homebuilding was strong seemed to be enough to keep the Dow Jones industrial average on an even keel.

title: Plenty of Catch Looms for Bluefish Tourney
description: AREA A  Blue fishing is reported very good for the $50,000 bluefish tournament beginning tomorrow morning off Captain Andy's Marina at Margate. Umbrella rigs and feathers (a metal head with a chicken feather and a red skirt) are the lures. The Stone Bed is a favorite spot about 180 degrees off Great. Egg Inlet. Weakfish, also are being taken in 15 to 30 feet of water off Sea Isle, Ocean City, Margate and Atlantic City. The Barnegat Light Yacht Basin reported that catching blues by chumming with ground bunker was highly successful off Barnegat Inlet. Bonita also has appeared inshore and offshore.

title: Deaths
description: LAWRENCEGertrude Foos. Be. loved wife of Arthur Brewster Lawrence, devoted mother of A. Brews. ter and the late Dr. Carteret. Loving grandmother of seven grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Services at St. Bartholomew's Chapel, Park Ave. at 51st St, Friday, July 20 at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, a donation to St. Bartholomew's Church, 109 East SO St., N.Y.. N.Y. 10022 or to St. James Episcopal Church, St. James, L.I. N.Y. 11780 or your favorite charity would be appreciated. Interment private.

title: Carter Bids To Curb Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  In an unexpected development, the Carter Administration asked Congress today to restrict, but not absolutely prohibit, mergers of the country's 18 biggest oil companies with other large businesses.

title: Trump Planning A Switch to Gas In 100 Buildings
description: Spurred by rising fueloil costs and the possibility of shortages next winter, owners of many apartment buildings in. New York City are switching their heating systems to natural gas.

title: About Real Estate
description: The problem of communication is one of many that a city confronts when it tries to regulate rents. People find it difficult to follow the permutations of regulation. That has particularly been true among rentstabilized tenants in the last year, and it may become more difficult in the rentcontrolled sector as well.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVINGTOMORROW, July 21

title: Senate Inquiry Is Told U.S. Supplier Paid Off Inspectors for G.S.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  A former employee of Art MetalUSA Inc. said today that it had been common knowledge at the company that company officials paid off General Services Administration inspectors.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JULY 20, 1979

title: Democratic Latin Countries Seek To Block 2d Cuba in Nicaragua
description: LIMA, Peru, July 19  Most Latin American governments are concerned that the fall of the Somoza regime in Nicaragua could lead to another Cuba in the region, but those governments committed to constitutional democracy are prepared to play an active role to prevent this from happening.

title: For Approval Voting
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa.  Each time the Presidential primary season approaches, one (and sometimes both) of our national parties offers a long list of candidates. If a party is to succeed in the general election, the primary and convention process must select from the wide range of available candidates a single nominee who has broad support within his party.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)  Two women from Hemlock, Mich., today gave Congressmen an account of miscarriage, paralysis and other health problems that they blamed on chemical wastes that may have seeped into well water.

title: Al Rosen Resigns Post With Yanks
description: Al Rosen, president of the Yankees for the last year and a half, resigned yesterday.

title: Gastineau Mistreats Giants
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 19  Mark Gastineau was beating up on Giants in the oneonone drills before the scrimmage proper. He was not looking like a rookie who says all he wants to do is make the Jets' roster and play in my first professional game.

title: Cousineau Chooses Canada Over N.F.L.
description: Tom Cousineau is going to Canada. Cousineau, the first player chosen in the National Football League's 1979 draft, has turned down an offer from the Buffalo Bills in favor of a multiyear contract with the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League.

title: Negotiation Set On Vegetables
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The Treasury announced today that its investigation into imports of Mexican vegetables had been terminated because a Florida growers group, under enormous American Government pressure, had withdrawn a petition filed under the Antidumping Act.

title: Dance: Cubans Present 3 Premieres
description: LIKE most companies, the National Ballet of Cuba encounters its ups, and downs among Its contemporary ballets more than within its repertory of 19th  and 20thcentury classics. On Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House it offered still another mixed bag in its newest program, which included several local premieres.

title: Deaths
description: HEYMANJerome (Jerry). Passed away suddently July 17, 1979, beloved husband of Lydia Weiss Heyman, father of Robert. A most dynamic person whose 84 years were filled with joy, love and happiess and who will be missed by all who knew him.

title: State Unit Staff Asks Denial of Lilco Plans For 2 Nuclear Plants
description: The staff of the New York State Department of Public Service has called for rejection of plans by the Long Island Lighting Company to Wild two nuclear power plants in Jamesport, L.I., giving as one of its reasons the lessons learned from the Three Mile Island nuclear accident in Pennsylvania.

title: TV Weekend
description: AMAJOR broadcast premiere features, of all people, the Marx brothers. Animal Crackers, produced nearly 50 years ago, will be shown for the first time on television tomorrow night at 8 on CBS. Rights litigation has kept it off the air until now.

title: Cabby Who Likes People Regrets TieUp
description: Willie Bly is one of those thousands of Independent ent cabdrivers who startled the city Wednesday by slowing down outside bridges and tunnels, creeping up the avenues at 5 miles an hour and refusing to pick up waving stockbrokers who wanted to weave on down to Wall Street by cab.

title: New Faces: Jeffrey Haddow and John Driver
description: JEFFREY HADDOW started out in show business at the age of 3, when his mother dressed him in a white suit and put him down on stage at an insurance convention (his father was an insurance salesman) to sing They Tried to Tell Us We're Too Young, accompanied by a full orchestra. The payoff was wild applause and a piece of cake, and he was hooked.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  The State Assembly passed a bill to set up a commission to compile data on Vietnam War veterans who might have been exposed to Agent Orange, a chemical defoliant linked to a variety of medical problems.

title: Midsummer NightsOn StrawHat Trail A Regional Guide
description: A TOUCH of the 1920's, a flavoring of Shakespeare, an unending affair with the musicalthese are the characteristics of summer theater in this region in 1979. And for those adventurers willing to seek them out, there are also some new plays to see and a growing campus theater movement with young earnest actors.

title: Regulaiors Let A.T. & T. Offer Satellite Services
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The Federal Communications Commission today ended a moratorium prohibiting the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from offering services by satellite. The move freed the company to compete with the Western Union Corporation, the RCA Corporation, the American Satellite Corporation and others.

title: Myron Cohen in the Round at Westbury
description: A woman went to her neighbor's. They're drinking tea, says Myron Cohen, lapsing into his utterly perfect conception of what a New York City garment center accent should, be, lowering his right eyelid and staring owlishly out with his other eve. They're drinking tea, and she says: Tell me the truth. If you found a milHon dollars, what would you do with it? Her friend thinks, then she says: I'll tell you. If it belonged to a poor person I'd give it back.

title: Sonsam Sets Record to Win $750,000 Pace
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 19  On a single, dizzying roll of the dice, Sonsam enriched his owners to the tune of $375,000 tonight by winning the $750,000 Meadowlands Pace in worldrecord time.

title: Yankees Conquer A's, 102
description: Hoping to make a fresh start and gain ground in the American League East race, the Yankees got just what they needed last night at Yankee Stadium, an easy 102 triumph over the Oakland A's.

title: Strength in Change, Mondale Says
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP)  Vice President Mondale said today that the Cabinet changes the President is making will strengthen our government, that he is doing what needs to be done.

title: Jersey Assembly Approves DrinkingAge Compromise
description: TRENTON, July 19  The New Jersey Assembly voted 45 to 17 today to allow teenagers to begin drinking in New Jersey on the July 1 following their 18th birthday.

title: Hirsch Captures 3d Yacht Race
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19 Dave Hirsch won his third straight race at Larchmont Race Week today to remain the only undefeated skipper at this venerable yachting event. Hirsch who campaigns a bluehulled boat of the J24 Class named Ukelele Lady out of Stratford, Conn., was unimpressed.

title: Ad by Mrs. Chiang Asks Aid for the Boat People
description: Mrs. Chiang Kaishek, in an advertisement in The New York Times today, condemns Vietnam for expelling thousands of people, mainly ethnic Chinese, and calls on nations and individuals for help.

title: A Clothes Emporium With a Surplus of Whimsy
description: A shopper entered the Unique Clothing Warehouse recently and said with surprise: It's become a regular boutique.

title: The City
description: Five Bronx teenagers were arrested yesterday and accused of murdering a 61yearold Bronx woman whose body, covered with stab wounds, was discovered last Saturday in her apartment in the Soundview housing project at 1689 Randall Avenue.

title: CasinoHotel Planned
description: The Colonial Commercial Corporation has acquired an option to buy 5.65 acres of land in Atlantic City for a proposed casinohotel. The option was acquired from King International, with which Colonial has plans to merge. The casinohotel complex will cost an estimated $75 million, if financing can be negotiated and approval obtained from regulatory groups.

title: South Africa Will Press Extradition
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 19 (Reuters)  Justice Minister Frederik de Klerk, questioned today about the possible extradition of Eschel M. Rhoodie, said that South Africa was not sure it had an extradition treaty with France. But whatever the position is, he added, extradition can be arranged whether or not there is a treaty. We will use all possible channels to have him returned to South Africa.

title: Where to Find the Best Ice Cream Treats in Town
description: Marcel Proust had his madeleines, but for many New Yorkers the key to the remembrance of things past is a banana split, a hotfudge sundae or an ice cream soda.

title: Dr. Nathan Bailey, 69, Leader of Missionaries
description: Dr. Nathan Bailey, who had served six threeyear terms as president of the Christian and Missionary Alliance, was killed in an automobile accident near Nottingham, England, on July 10, it was learned here yesterday. Dr. Bailey, whose wife, Mary, was seriously injured in the accident, was 69 years old.

title: Questionnaire
description: The reason cannot be a genuine interest in the answers. Mr. Carter must.by now, well into the third year of his Administration, have a pretty good idea of the capacities of his subCabinet officials. Yet distributing such a questionnaire makes it look, damagingly, as

title: Benjamin Gottesman, Yeshiva Trustee, Dies; Held Post Since 1925
description: Benjamin Gottesman, who had served on the board of Yeshiva University since 1925 and was its oldest trustee, died Wednesday while on vacation on Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts. Mr. Gottesman, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 81 years old.

title: Lawrence A. Fernsworth, Author And Newspaper Correspondent
description: Lawrence A. Fernsworth, an author and activist against fascism who gained international attention in the 1930's as a foreign correspondent covering the Spanish Civil War for The Times of London and The New York Times, will be buried on a family farm in New Hampshire where he disappeared two years ago, a family spokesman said yesterday. His remains were recently discovered.

title: Clinic Staffers Suffer Emotional Traumas Too
description: How do the people who help women go through abortions with as much emotional equanimity as is possible feel about the work they do?

title: Windows Shatter at Shop's Grand Opening'
description: More than 50 music fans were injured by shards of glass yesterday afternoon when the plateglass windows of a Queens record store gave way after a mounted policeman rode through a crowd massed outside the store.

title: Gateway Village Growing in Sandy Hook
description: SANDY HOOK, N.J., July 19 Where artillery shells once screamed overhead and thousands of soldiers trained for combat, youngsters now toss Frisbees over the parade ground or search for seashells.

title: 80 Seasons Later, the Menu Remains as Innovative as the Setting
description: WHEN the Four Seasons opened 20 years ago today, its menus and recipes were at least as innovative as its setting. Joseph Baum, then a vice president with Restaurant Associates, and the late Albert Stockli, who was the executive chef, worked out totally new combinations of ingredients and styles of services, borrowing from the cuisines of the world and stressing the freshest and liveliest of seasonal provender. Today's chef, Seppi Renggli, is both faithful to that concept and an innovator himself.

title: E.P.A Prepares to Ban Pesticide Tied to Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  The Environmental Protection Agency will temporarily ban the use of DBCP, a pesticide that has caused sterility in men and cancer in laboratory animals, the agency's deputy administrator, Barbara Blum, said today.

title: Jets Beat Giants in Scrimmage
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 19  Coach Walt Michaels of the Jets and Coach Ray Perkins of the Giants both insisted that the score of today's scrimmage for rookies, free agents and other players reportingearly did not count. But Michaels went home smiling after his club had gained a 1610 victory, watched by a standingroom crowd of more than 3,000 at the Jets' Hofstra University training site.

title: Decade After Moon Trip, Its Value Is Still Disputed
description: Ten years ago tonight, people all over the world watched as an immemorial dream came true. There, in flickering black and white on their television screens, they saw a man at the bottom rung of a ladder extend his booted left foot to touch, tentatively at first, then firmly, the gray powdery surface of the moon.

title: Jazz: Mary Lou Williams
description: SINCE Mary Lou Williams joined the faculty of Duke University two years ago, she is not heard playing in New York as frequently as she was earlier in the 1970's. But this academic turn of her career has done nothing at all to diminish the drive and power that she showed with Andy Kirk's band in Kansas City, Mo., as long as (can it really be?) 50 years ago.

title: Forego, Turcotte, Barrera Voted Into Racing Hall
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 19 (AP)  Forego, a threetime horse of the year, has been voted into the Hall of Fame at Saratoga's Museum of Racing, with Ron Turcotte, the jockey of a Triple Crown winner, and Laz Barrera, the trainer of a Triple Crown winner.

title: Top Democrats Troubled By President's ShakeUp
description: President Carter's efforts to rebuild confidence in his Administration by mass resignations of his Cabinet and senior staff produced the opposite effect yesterday among many of the nation's leading Democrats.

title: Benjamin Richard Civiletti
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The last time Benjamin Richard Civiletti came up for Senate confirmation to a high Justice Department post the process lasted seven weeks as the Senate Judiciary Committee investigated the department's controversial dismissal of David W. Marston, United States Attorney in Philadelphia. Mr. Civiletti became a lightning rod for the controversy.

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY, JULY 19, 1979

title: Reporters' Dress Code Relaxed
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)  The Senate, following the lead of the House, relaxed the dress code today for reporters covering activities in the chamber. The Senate Democratic leader, Robert C. Byrd, granted the change. The request came after Congressional leaders ordered thermostats set at 78 degrees to comply with fuelsaving rules.

title: Fall at Miss Universe Pageant
description: PERTH, Australia, July 19 (UPI)  A platform collapsed at the Miss Universe pageant here tonight, toppling a dozen screaming contestants onto the stage. No one was seriously hurt. The accident occurred minutes after 18yearold Maritza Sayalero of Venezuela won the contest.

title: Broadway
description: THERE are better reasons to revive The Most Happy Fella than there are to revive most musicals. For one thing, it was written by Frank Loesser  book, music and lyrics  and for another it was one of the first shows that successfully, though slyly, established a connection between the Broadway musical and opera. Therefore, The Most Happy Fella will be revived, opening here in late September or early October after nine performances at the Music Hall in Detroit. its star will be Giorgio Tozzi, who mostly has worked the great opera houses of the world, but occasionally has forsaken them for theatrical houses, too. Its director is Jack O'Brien, who also moves between opera and theater. Next season, he will also direct I Oughta Be In Pictures, which is the new Neil Simon offering, while two seasons ago he directed the extraordinarily successful revival of Porgy and Bess. Many Porgy and Bess alumni, in fact, will be involved with Most Happy Fella.

title: I.B.M. Bids to Oust Judge
description: Lawyers for the International Business Machines Corporation initiated major effort yesterday to remove the judge who is presiding over the Government's massive antitrust case against I.B.M.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: TOKYO, Friday, July 20  The dollar opened at 216 yen this morning, up by just over a point after the announcement in Washington that the Federal Reserve Board chairman, G. William Miller, would replace W. Michael Blumenthal, Secretary of the Treasury.

title: How to Get There
description: To reach the Westbury Music Fair from Manhattan by car, take the Queens Midtown Tunnel to the Long Island Expressway, heading east. Take Exit 40 and follow Route 25 West to Bush Hollow Road, which leads to the fair. By train, take the Long Island Rail Road to Westbury; there is a cab stand at the station.

title: Advertising
description: Asit periodically does, the question of a premium charge for bleed in magazine advertising is once again arising as a bone of contention for costconscious advertisers and agencies facing soaring media rates.

title: The Blues Find a Home Ina 23d St. Theater
description: If the people at the Squat Theater have their way, West 23d Street is going to be a major location to hear blues, jazz, new rock and new classical music in the weeks and months to come.

title: COMMODITIES
description: The winterwheat harvest in the United States progressed yesterday, pushing grain and soybean futures lower and ending traders' latest inflationconscious grainbuying binge.

title: 20th Yankee Peddler Day
description: More than 100 dealers in antiques and collectibles will take part tomorrow from 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. in the 20th Yankee Peddler Day on the grounds of the Spring Valley, N.Y., High School, Route 59 and Kennedy Drive. Proceeds will benefit the Historical Society of Rockland County, sponsors of the fair. Admission is $1.25 Information : (914) 6349629

title: Embassy of Nicaragua Is Raided
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Eleven unarmed Nicaraguan students and supporters of the Sandinists took control of the Nicaraguan Embassy today for just over an hour before they were expelled by policemen.

title: Carter Asks For Trade Revamping
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 President Carter proposed today a reorganization of foreign trade responsibilities that would give enhanced functions to the Commerce Department and the Office of the Special Representative for Trade Negotiations and would remove administration of import relief from the Treasury.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS TAKE OVER CAPITAL, ENDING CIVIL WAR
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 19Two days after President Anastasio Somoza Debayle fled Nicaragua, Sandinist rebels took control of Managua today, completing the defeat of the National Guard and ending a sevenweekold war that left more than 10,000 people dead.

title: Money Supply Up $3.2 Billion
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday a $3.2 billion surge in the weekly money. supply. The news came within an hour after it was announced that G. William Miller would resign as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board to accept a notninadon to become Secretary of the Treasury.

title: I.M.F. Credit for Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (Reuters) The International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved a oneyear credit for Turkey totaling the equivalent of about $327 million. The I.M.F. said the new credit replaced one that ended last year.

title: Minimal Art In Ridgefield
description: WHEN the temperature in inland Connecticut climbs toward three figures and a visitor can almost draw Water from the air with a sponge, there is a lot to be said for an exhibition that takes the heat out of art. The Minimal Tradition at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield is an exhibition of this sort, and for the rest of its run (it stays up through Sept. 2) it can be recommended highly, both for its overall intelligence and for the seasonable relief that it has to offer.

title: Pirates 9, Astros 5 Pirates 4, Astros 2
description: PITTSBURGH, July 19 (AP)  Tworun homers by Willie Stargell and Phil Garner in the first game and John Milner in the second game led the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 95, 42 sweep of tonight's twilightnight doubleheader over the slumping Houston Astros.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt is pouring some more Texas oil money into Australia. The 53yearold billionaire, who has had property in Australia for about 10 years, has bought more than 2,500 square miles of grazing land there, marking one of the largest sales of rural land in that nation's history.

title: Deaths
description: BARCLAYGranville Oldfield, age 71 of Palm Beach, Fla, formerly New York, died July 18, 1979. Survived by son, Huntington Barclay, two granddaughters, stepdaughter Joan M. Parker, stepson Edgar L. III and sister Mrs. Fenwick Wall. A memorial service was held July 19, Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Doldrums Becalm The Board
description: The speakers droned, the agenda was long and the afternoon seemed to drag: it was a somnolent midsunimorday in the ornate Board of Estimate chambers at City Hall yesterday, for members (or their standins) and spectators alike.

title: Harriman Says a Soviet HardLiner Might Come to Fore if Treaty Loses
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)  W. Averell Harriman told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that rejection of the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union would increase the chances that a hardline antiAmerican might succeed Leonid I. Brezhnev, the present Soviet leader.

title: The Quilted Giraffe
description: 955 Second Avenue (between 50th and 51st Streets), 7535355.

title: SeaLaw Parley Resumes at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 19 The Conference on the Law of the Sea resumed today amid warnings that the patience of governments was wearing out after six years of negotiations on a treaty on the use of the oceans and their wealth.

title: Post Office Backed On Electronic Mail
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The Carter Administration endorsed today the limited use of electronic transmission of mail by the United States Postal Service.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Can acoustical evidence not audible to the human ear and gleaned from a 15yearold Dictabelt be as convincing as a new set of fingerprints?

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Trans World Profits Rise
description: The Trans World Corporation, the parent company of Trans World Airlines, the Canteen Corporation of America and the Hilton International Company, reported yesterday an 18.8 percent rise in secondquarter earnings to $58.8 million, or $3.92 a share, from $49.5 million, or $2.85 a share, in the 1978 quarter.

title: Two DC10's of National Airlines Forced Down by Engine Trouble
description: Two National Airlines DC10's were forced to return to the ground within 24 hours after experiencing engine problems, according to spokesmen for the airline and for the Federal Aviation Administration. But the spokesmen said that the difficulties were not related to the problems that were the basis of the recent grounding of all domestic DC10's.

title: '80 Race Seen as Factor
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Joseph A. Califano Jr. said today that President Carter had told him he was being dismissed as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare because of friction between the Secretary and top White House staff members and because the President had to get the Cabinet and the Administration ready for the 1980 election.

title: Mobil Says It Will Provide More Gas for Its Dealers
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said yesterday that it was providing more gasoline to its dealers around the country.

title: Bridge:
description: For the EastWest pair on the diagramed deal, which was played at the Great Baldwin Bridge Studio, Baldwin, L.I., the result was doubly sad. And one part of that, as will appear, was a double sadness.

title: George William Miller
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The Cabinet, which will be losing a militant nonsmoker with the departure of Joseph A. Califano Jr., will be gaining a new one in G. William Miller, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who will now move across town to become Secretary of the Treasury.

title: The Shuffle: New Faces, Old Cards
description: At first whack, President Carter's Cabinet cleanout seems to be a boon to the nation's gossip industry, but it betrays no significant policy motives.

title: Report Says Berkowitz Had Aid, But Police Dismiss the Account
description: A group of newspapers in Westchester and Rockland Counties reported yesterday that it appeared that David R. Berkowitz, the confessed Son of Sam killer, did not shoot his last two victims but insead had an accomplice who did the shootings while Mr. Berkowitz may have been only a lookout. However, the report was immediately dismissed by New York City law enforcement officials.

title: Columbus and the Moon
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration's moon landing 10 years ago today was a Government project, but then so was Columbus's voyage to America in 1492. The Government, in Columbus's case, was the Spanish Court of Ferdinand and Isabella. Spay Was engaged In a sea race with Portugal in much the same way that the United States would be caught up in a space race with the Soviet Union four and a half centuries later.

title: Rowboat Concert Set For Central Park Lake
description: Wendy Chambers started her career by writing and conducting music that was played on nine car horns. From there she went on to a celebrated Washington Square concert performed by 200 musicians led by five conductors and accompanied by parkgoers listening to the theme from Close Encounters of the Third Kind on their transistor radios. Tomorrow Miss Chambers will be at sea with her musical experiences, or more accurately, in the lake in Central Park. She has found 22 musicians who will don costumes and will play while aboard rowboats staffed by crews recruited from Columbia University.

title: Protesting Cabdrivers May Face Suspension
description: The city's Taxi and Limousine Commission said yesterday that it would hire more taxi inspectors and make onthe spot suspensions in any future protests by cabdrivers such as Wednesday's clogging of city streets during the morning rush hour.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, trying to figure out what all the shifts in Washington meant, declined quite sharply yesterday afternoon, relinquishing all the ground they had gained earlier after the dollar rose in value in foreign exchange trading. The late decline was also prompted by news of a large increase in the money supply.

title: EARNINGS
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical producer, reported a 22 percent rise in secondquarter net income yesterday to a record $232.8 million, or $1.59 a share, from $190.8 million, or $1.31 a share, for the similar three months a year earlier.

title: Two Suspects in Brooklyn Robbery Charged in 4 Bedford Hills Killings
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 19  Junius Gray and Jimmie Lee Allen were brought to White Plains today to be formally charged with the May 10 murders of four Bedford Hills residents. A 40count indictment also included burglary, robbery and other charges.

title: Dismissals Taken as PreCampaign Move by Carter
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  President Carter's first two Cabinet dismissals were widely seen today as confirmation that he had begun his undeclared campaign for reelection by moving to shore up his standing with important constituencies and replacing those officials he regarded as political liabilities. But the actions prompted an uproar of criticism in Congress.

title: Gold Sales ,Climb in New York
description: Every time there's a crisis, our volume of gold sales rises and we make more commissions. That was the view from Joshua Yedid, a former Lebanese banker who is now executive vice president of the Republic National Bank of New York.

title: Portugal President Names Woman To Form a Caretaker Government
description: LISBON, July 19  Maria de Lurdes Pintassilgo, a 49yearold engineer and diplomat, was named by President Antonio Ramalho Eanes today to form a caretaker government to preside over parliamentary elections this fall.

title: BauschCooper Talks End
description: Bausch & Lomb, the big optical company, said yesterday that it had ended preliminary merger talks with Cooper Laboratories and had no further interest in the matter. Cooper is in the pharmaceutical, dental and medical fields.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: MURRAY OLIPHANT

title: SUN BELT G.M. PLANT ORGANIZED BY U.A.W.
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 19  In major victory today for organized labor's faltering efforts in Sun Belt states, the United Automobile Workers union won the right to represent workers at a new General Motors Corporation plant here by a ratio of nearly 2 to 1. The official vote was 1,479 votes to 658.

title: 9,500 Steelworkers in Alabama Warned of Job Loss
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 18The superintendent for this city's major employer, the United States Steel Corporation, has threatened 9,500 workers at the huge Fairfield Works with employment cuts and even possibly complete shutdown of operations unless their work habits and the plant's profitability improve.

title: Abortion Rights in Peril, Say Advocates at Conference
description: The call to battle was sounded by speaker after speaker the third annual meeting of the National Abortion Federation held here this week. The message: those who support the right of women to terminate their pregnancies must strengthen their efforts to defend that right against recurrent threats to its survival.

title: Racial Bias Is Charged By a Black State Aide Demoted by Hongisto
description: A black deputy commissioner of New York State's Correction Department who was demoted last month filed a $1.5 million civilrights suit yesterday against the outgoing Acting Commissioner, charging that he had been discriminated against because of his race.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Music: Jonah Jones Plays
description: IT has been four years since the Jonah Jones Quintet, with its urgent shuffle rhythm supporting Mr. Jones's crisp muted trumpet, has been heard in New York. But the group, which is playing at the French Quarter of the Sheraton Centre until Aug. 4, seems virtually unchanged (aside from a new drummer) from the last time it was here.

title: Dr. Hiram Phelps Salter Jr., 72, A Gynecologist From Bronxville
description: Dr. Hiram Phelps Salter Jr., obstetrician and gynecologist, died Wednesday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y., after a brief illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: Military Pension Change Offered In Effort to Cut Increasing Costs
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  The Carter Administration proposed a sweeping reform of the $10 billion military retirement system today to cut soaring costs 25 percent and to enhance the attractiveness of military service.

title: Irwin Takes Lead by 2
description: ST. ANNES, England, July 19  It may be premature, but halfway through the British Open golf tournament Hale Irvin is entertaining the notion that he may win two national opens in one season.

title: Personal Income Shows Slowdown
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)The personal income of Americans rose a modest fivetenths of 1 percent in June to continue a slowdown evident since the first of the year, the Government said today.

title: Economic Scene
description: PRESIDENT CARTER'S decision to replace Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal with G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, represents an effort by the President to strengthen confidence in his Administration  not only the nation's confidence but also his own.

title: Letters of Resignation and Acceptance
description: WASHINGTON, July l9 (UPI)  Following are the texts of the letters of resignation today of Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, and W. Michael Blumenthal, Secretary of Treasury, and of the letters by President Carter accepting the resignations:

title: Begin, Ill After a Trip, Hospitalized for Tests
description: JERUSALEM, July 19 (UPI)Prime Minister Menachem Begin was hospitalized today for tests after feeling ill during a trip earlier in the day, the state radio reported.

title: Carey Sets Working Vacation Abroad
description: ALBANY, July 18  Governor Carey will take what hN aides call a working vacation in Europe beginning next week in an effort to bolster the state's economic prospects and possibly his own political fortunes.

title: A Schedule of What's Playing. In Regional Summer Theater
description: A guide to what's doing on the strawhat circuit:

title: Consumer Companies Profit Up
description: Consumergoods companies reported profit gains for the latest quarter yesterday ranging from 22.5 percent for R.J. Reynolds Industries, a holding company in the tobacco field, to 12.1 percent for the BristolMyers Company, a pharmaceutical and healthcare concern.

title: Liberia's Leader Assumes O.A.U. Chairmanship in a Period of Political Crisis at Home
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 19  President William R. Tolbert Jr., the new chairman of the Organization of African Unity, has looked forward to the position he assumed this week as a capstone to his long political career.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, July 19,1979

title: Stage: Five O'Clock Girl
description: EAST HADDAM, Conn., July 19  The Goodspeed Opera House does not really present musicals; it presents productions of musicals, and its production of The Five O'Clock Girl is stunning. The overture, which starts and finishes with Thinking of You, ends, and a black and gold curtain rises on an Art Deco set; a cast in white, beige and tan, and what appears to be a silver bicycle. The bicycle is there only because it looks good; most of Five O'Clock Girl is there only because it looks good. In fact, it looks sensational.

title: World News Briefs
description: WEST BERLIN, July 19  The city government has exchanged a man convicted of spying for East Germany for four West Berliners jailed in the East.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch of The Associated Press published in The Times yesterday reported incorrectly that Curtis J. Watkins, a suspended detective in Cleveland, must remain on trial on nine counts of bribery. Mr. Watkins was acquitted by a jury of all nine counts of forgery. A Judge acquitted him of theft in office, intimidation and presenting forged documents.

title: F.C.C. Dubious on RKO License
description: The Federal Communications Commission has made a preliminary determination that RKO General Inc., one of the largest group operators of broadcast stations in the countrY, may not be qualified to hold a Federal license because of the misconduct several years ago of its corporate parent, the General Tire and Rubber Company.

title: Events and Openings
description: TILL MARRIAGE DO US PART, an Italian film with English subtitles directed by Luigi Comencini; starring Laura Antonelli, at the Plaza Theater.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP)  The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has offered to buy all stock of the Microdata Corporation of Irvine, Calif., for $32 a share, or a total of $73 million, spokesmen for the companies said today.

title: Screen: Comedy Vehicle For Laura Antonelli:Bette Davis in New TV Movie
description: "TILL Marriage Do Us Part" is a five-year-old Italian comedy predicated on Laura Antonelli's delectability and her way of crying "No! No!" when "Si! Si!" is what she means. The plot, designed to make comic use of Miss Antonelli's mock passivity while also exploiting her statuesque frame, has her playing a convent-bred virgin who accidentally manages to marry her own brother.Just as they are about to consummate the marriage  which will presumably take some doing, because Miss Antonelli plays things very, very dumba telegram arrives. It advises the bridgroom to open a certain bureau drawer, in which he will find a letter from his father revealing the bad news, but the drawer is jammed. So he calls for a hammer and chisel. "The bridegroom needs a hammer and chisel!" everybody cries. The movie's jokes tend to be very broad.Fighting what is, of course, a losing battle to preserve her virtue, Miss Antonelli spends her time either swooning or trying to look forbidding. Because everyone knows what's ailing her, and since she in any case couldn't scare a fly, she doesn't scare the chauffeur. He eventually proves most helpful.The resolution of their flirtation is a long while off, though, because Miss Antonelli winds up teasing this poor fellow almost as relentlessly as she teases the audience. The movie, while periodically robbing the leading lady of her turn-of-the-century clothing, steers clear of graphic sex scenes, preferring to keep the actress's allure mysterious. And that's wise: Miss Antonelli is so richly suggestive that she promises things no mere flesh-and-blood creature could deliver."Till Marriage Do Us Part," which opens today at the Plaza, may be dated, but it's still one of Miss Antonelli's later films, made after she had established herself as an Italian star. So it's designed primarily as a vehicle for her, and a funny, relatively classy vehicle at that. Should her earliest films begin to be distributed here, they may turn out to be a lot less distinguished. In cinematic terms, mind you, not even this one amounts to a very large hill of beans. But "Till Marriage Do Us Part," which begins with a sepia montage of old-fashioned pornographic post cards, makes no bones about its limited aspirations.The director, Luigi Comenici, throws in occasional bits of historical perspective  the time span is 1908-20  and makes funny use of the poet D'Annunzio. But he also throws in a brief and completely gratuitous lesbian love scene, not to mention one glimpse of Miss Antonelli taking a bath standing up. Real people are much less likely than sex-movie bombshells to bathe this way.The official biography of Miss Antonelli states that she started off as a gym teacher. If that's true, then quick, everybody into the pool!

title: Patricia Roberts Harris
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Patricia Roberts Harris, the black lawyer, politician and sometime diplomat who was regarded with some skepticism when she became Secretary of Housing and Urban Development about 30 months ago, today emerged unscathed from President Carter's Cabinet reshuffle to become the new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, replacing Joseph A. Califano Jr.

title: Topics
description: Alarms and Excursions

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Somoza Is Planning A Foreign Trip Soon From Exile in Miami
description: MIAMI, July 19  The deposed Nicaraguan President, Anastasio Somoza Debayle, said today that he would soon leave his exile home here, for extended travel in South America and possibly Europe.

title: India's Guardian During Political Crisis
description: NEW DELHI, July 19  In the power vacuum left by the collapse of the Government headed by. Morarji R. Desai, responsibility for guiding and preserving Indian democracy has fallen to one man, N. Sanjiva Reddy, the blunt, strongwilled President.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Picnic House in Brooklyn's Prospect Park has turned into a summer entertainment center. From now until Aug. 19, it will have free programs Thursdays through Sundays at 8 P. M. Tonight's attractions are two dance troupes, Baker's Half Dozen Theater and Capoerias, an AfroBrazilian company. TomOrrow night you can see the International AfrikanAmerican Ballet; Sunday night, Charles Moore's African dances. Other programs will feature music and theater. Tickets are distributed firstcome, firstserved, starting at 6 P. M. The grounds are available for picnics beforehand. Schedule information: 6937116.

title: President Pledges Aid To Vietnam Refugees And Hails Protesters
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  In an impromptu gestute, President Carter went to the front fence of th White House tonight and pledged the United States's support for Vietnamese refugees to about 100 demonstrators arrayed along Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Deaths
description: GOTTESMANBenjamin. It is with deep sorrow that the officers, members of the Board and staff of The Board of Jewish Education of Greater New York mourn the passing of Benjamin Gottesman husband of our esteemed Board member, Esther Gottesman. In his lifetime Mr Gottesman was a dedicated leader in the Jewish community and provided great support to Jewish educationt institutions. May Mrs. Gottesman be consoled by her own vital involvement in enriching Jewish life in America and Israel, and may the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Critic's Notebook: A Composer Effaced by Nazism
description: HAIDY SCHREKERBURES, the daughter of the Austrian composer Franz Schreker, was in New York recently, visiting former pupils of her father's and hoping to raise some interest in his operas, none of which has ever been performed in the United States. During the height of his fame in Europe be: tween the world wars, Schreker was deemed second only to Richard Strauss Prominence and importance. Like Wagner, he singlehandedly devised the plots, words and music of his operas, and they were staged throughout Germany and Austria. Closely associated with the progressive school of Schoenberg, Berg and Wobern, he garnered far more popular success than any of his Viennese colleagues.

title: Treasury Upheaval Concerns Executives
description: Business and financial leaders around the country generally faulted the uprooting of Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal but indicated that the President's choice to succeed Mr. Blumenthal, G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, would have widespread support in their communities in his new post.

title: Robert F. Heizer, an Archeologist
description: Dr. Robert F. Heizer, an anthropologist whose research in Mexico and Central America led to a deeper understanding of ancient civilizations on the North American continent, died Wednesday in Berkeley, Calif., after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

title: Massachusetts Governor Signs Budget
description: BOSTON, July 19  Gov. Edward J. King's bold campaign pledge last fall, to roll back loCal property taxes by $500 million ended in disappointment today as he resignedly approved a state budget that provided only $166 million in new local tax relief and no guarantee that any of that money would be used to reduce bills for property taxes.

title: A Touch of the Duke From Russell Procope
description: When Duke Ellington died May 24, 1974, the Ellington band continued under the leadership of the Duke's son, Mercer. But Russell Procope, who had beenplaaying alto saxophone and clarinet in the band for almost 29 years, dropped out.

title: U.S. Oil Shortage Put at 12% in June
description: Oil companies delivered 9.7 percent less gasoline last month than they did in June 1978, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Since gasoline consumption had been expected to grow 2 to 3 percent this year, the trade association's figure suggested that the actual nationwide shortage of gasoline in June was about 12 percent.

title: Church Demolished
description: The remains of All Angels Church at 81st Street and West End Avenue yesterday as the 90yearold structure awaited the last assault of the wrecker's crane. Above, one of the works of art at the church. The Episcopal congregation, greatly diminished in recent years, had tried to save the church by allowing four other congregations to use the building for worship. Upkeep of the church still proved too costly, and it was sold to a private developer, who plans to construct an apartment building on the site.

title: Angels Top Orioles, 43, In the 11th
description: BALTIMORE, July 19 (AP) Gary Roenicke drove in two runs in support of Mike Flanagan's sixhit pitching as the Baltimore Orioles beat the California Angels, 30, to gain a split of tonight's twilightnight doubleheader between the American League division leaders.

title: CARTER REPLACES BELL, BLUMENTHAL, CALIFANO; MILLER GOES TO TREASURY
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  President Carter dismissed two of the more controversial and outspoken members of his Cabinet today, transferred a third and accepted the longexpected resignation of Attorney General Griffin B. Bell.

title: Design: Four Seasons After 20 Years
description: WHEN the Four Seasons restaurant opened on July 20, 1959, there had been a few attempts to create modern dining rooms in New York. There was the penthouse fantasy of the Rainbow Room atop the RCA Building, for example, and the Art Deco sleekness of Lindy's. But New York had never seen anything like this $4.5 million combination of rich woods, glass, marble and leather in the Seagram Building, with Mies van der Rohe chairs instead of red velvet banquettes and a marble reflecting pool instead of the usual flowers as a centerpiece.

title: South Africa Scandal Figure Held
description: NICE, France, July 19 (Reuters) Eschel M. Rhoodie, the former head of South Africa's Information Ministry and a key figure in a recent scandal involving misuse of Government funds, was arrested by the French police today.

title: Armstrong Recalls Historic Walk And Sight of a Planet Left Behind
description: CINCINNATI, July 19 (AP)  There was a time when Neil Armstrong, like most of us, looked at the moon and saw a flat disk.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter nominated G. William Miller as Secretary of the Treasury after acceptingthe resignation.of W. Michael Blumenthal.. Mr. Miller's shift'to the Treasury will leave vacant the chairnianship of the Federal Reserve Board. The dramatic moves involving the Fed and Treasury followed the resignation earlier in the day of Joseph A. Califano as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare and the nomination of Patricia Roberts Harris, now Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, to succeed him. The President also accepted the resignation of Griffin B. Bell as Attorney General and named Benjamin Civiletti for the post. [Page Al.]

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Iran's Premier Reports Agreement With Khomeini on Sharing Power
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 19  Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan declared tonight that he had reached agreement with Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Iran's revolutionary leader, on the sharing of power between the secretive Revolutionary Council and his embattled Government.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates Stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Alcoa's Profits Rise by 79.7%
description: PITTSBURGH, July 19The Aluminum Company of America today re.parted secondquarter earnings of $134.4 million, or $3.81 a share, up 79.7 percent from $74.8 million, or $2.13 a share, a year earlier. Asa result, directors raised the quarterly dividend to 70 cents a share from 60 cents, payable Aug. 25 to holders of record Aug. 3.

title: Publishing: Scribner's to Issue Hemingway Letters
description: On the eve of what would have been his 80th birthday, which falls tomorrow, Charles Scribner's Sons announced that it would publish The Letters of Ernest Hemingway in the fall of 1980. Carlos Baker, Hemingway's biographer and Woodrow Wilson Professor of Literature emeritus at Princeton, will edit the volume, which will consist of some 800 letters. They will cover the period from the time Hemingway left America in 1918 for Italy and World War Ito the end of his life. Scribners received permission to publish the letters from the Ernest Hemingway Foundation which controls the rights.

title: SINAI PLAN DRAFTED BY U.S. AND SOVIET
description: UNITED NATIONS, July 19 The United States and the Soviet Union have worked out a formula that would permit the United Nations to play a role in overseeing the phased withdrawal of Israeli troops from Sinai, as provided by the EgyptIsrael peace treaty, according to sources close to the delegations.

title: Carter. Mass Transit Plan Stirs Debate on Spending
description: However mixed the general reviews of the President's energy speeches have been, his mass transit proposal  though only a small part of the overall program and so far nothing more than a number with no details  has drawn almost unanimous praise.

title: For Children
description: THE MUPPETS: A CELEBRATION, features the art and history of Jim Hensen's creations on The Muppet Show and Sesame Street, Monday and Thursday, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M., Tuesday and Wesnesday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Friday and Saturday, noon to 6 P.M., through Aug. 11, at The New York Public Library, Amsterdam Gallery, Library and Museum of the Performino Arts at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue. Free. Call 799.2200.

title: Padres, With 4 Hits, Turn Back Mets, 31
description: SAN DIEGO, July 19  Where will we go in the second half? Joe Torre asked tonight as the New York Nets got back to business after the midseason recess. We'll go wherever our pitching takes us. Where that is, I don't know.

title: Restaurants
description: OPENED just seven weeks ago, the Quilted Giraffe, on Second Avenue between 50th and 51st Streets, is the city's newest bastion of the nouvelle cuisine  the lighter, more natural and all too often overly sweet and contrived new cooking developed by French chefs such as Paul Bocuse, Michel Guerard and the Troisgros brothers. . If you forget that fact, don't worry about it; the captain is sure to remind you. On our first visit he said: nouvelle cuisine seven times and a few weeks later a plat du jour was described as not nouvelle but a fun dish anyway.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Clark Oil
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the Clark Oil and Refining Corporation made improper payments to Government officials in Abu Dhabi and the United Arab Emirates in 1975 in exchange for price reductions in its oilsupply contract.

title: Auctions
description: PHOTOGRAPHY is not only the hottest of the new areas in art, but it is also an increasingly important commodity at auction. The numerous sales held this season have all attracted large audiences and wide interest. World records have continued to be set for photographers, periods and categories. The highest price ever for a photographic lot at auction in the United States, $100,000, was paid last May 10 at Swann Galleries, 104 East 25th Street, for a Carleton Watkins album of 19thcentury photographs of the Columbia River. The album was purchased by Hastings Galleries, New York dealers.

title: Cosmetics and Cancer: New Reports
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) Cancercausing agents previously identified as being present in cosmetics can be absorbed through the skin of a person wearing makeup, a report issued by a House subcommittee said today.

title: Deaths
description: ELEFANTSadie. Dear sister of Morris and Beniamin Cohen. And cherished aunt. Services Friday 1:30 p.m. The Riverside, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Pop: Ayers and Mills
description: ROY AYERS and Stephanie Mills were at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night, and although any evaluation of what they were doing must remain tentative because of a sound system that hissed ominously and reduced almost everything to aural oatmeal, both performers seemed to be in the midst of a shift in direction.

title: Brown Group Extends Bid
description: Brown Group Inc., the St. Louis shoe manufacturer, said its offer of $15 a share for Outdoor Sports Industries 1.4 million shares had resulted in 95 percent of the shares being tendered. It has extended the offer until July 27.

title: Delay Seen On Energy Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The Congressional rush to pass at least some parts of President Carter's energy program slowed to a walk today, with relatively little floor action likely before the members take a summer recess early next month.

title: Best Interest to Leave
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal maintained today that he had resigned voluntarily and that there had been no coercion at all.

title: ExM.P., at Doctor's Trial, Describes Murder Scene
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 19 When military policemen arrived at the Fort Bragg home of Capt. Jeffrey MacDonald late on the night of Feb. 17, 1970, they found the album Hair on the recordplayer turntable and a paperback copy of Mickey Spillane's murder mystery, Kiss Me Deadly on the living room floor.

title: Gold Down From Record
description: The price of gold fell back from its record levels of Wednesday, closing in Zurich at $299.125 an ounce, down from $301.125. In London, gold closed at $298.50, off from $300.75, while in New York, gold dropped to $299.40 from $302.40.

title: Screen: Kirk Douglas in 'The Villain':Including a Horse
description: "THE Villain," which is almost as dopey as it is interminable, is a live-action cartoon. Kirk Douglas plays the Road Runner role, as he falls off cliffs or lights the wrong end of the dynamite or glues himself to the railroad tracks, in a series of futile efforts to catch Ann-Margret and Arnold Schwarzenegger, who play the good guys.Catching Ann-Margret, who is done up in Bob Mackie's idea of what Daisy Mae might wear to a formal barbecue, seems like a fine idea. As for Mr. Schwarzenegger, he's more of a weight on the movie than even he might be able to lift. Ann-Margret makes some game attempts to play comedy scenes with him, but she might have had better luck trading smart remarks with the prairie dogs.Hal Needham, who directed "The Villain," is the former stuntman  with 42 broken bones to prove it, the production notes say  who directed "Smokey and the Bandit" and "Hooper," both starring Burt Reynolds. A caricature of Mr. Reynolds turns up on a wall somewhere, and the names of the producers appear on prominently placed signposts. As in-jokes, perhaps these are funny enough to the family members of everyone involved. But they're a waste of energy in a movie that needed out-jokes much more desperately.Mr. Douglas does a lot of stunts, some of them reasonably good; these seem to be the would-be comic backbone of a movie that's not after laughs but heehaws, which in any case it doesn't get. Mr. Douglas's horse does stunts, too. The cleverest thing the horse can do is sit down on cue.The film opens today at Loews State 2 and other theaters."The Villain" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance suggested"). It contains a couple of lewd double-entendres.

title: Palmer Is Placed On Disabled List
description: BALTIMORE, July 19 (UPI)The Baltimore Orioles placed Jim Palmer on the 21day disabled list today because of tendinitis in his right elbow.

title: Vietnam Says It Will Not Tolerate Criticism at Geneva Refugee Parley
description: GENEVA, July 19 (AP)  Vietnam, denouncing what it called an international campaign of lies and calumnies, warned today that it would not stand for crossexamination at the special United Nations conference on Indochinese refugees opening tomorrow.

title: A New Wine Cellar With Vintages at Reasonable Prices
description: Building a wine cellar is no easy task these days, particularly for a restaurant that wants to offer a traditional French list of wines from Bordeaux and Burgundy. Restaurants that built their stocks years ago can hold prices (although not all of them do). but people just starting out have to pass on the stiff prices they are charged. Having said that, it is pleasant to report that The Quilted Giraffe has managed to put together a decent list with some fairly reasonable prices for the East Side.

title: Submarine Races Part of Poughkeepsie Fair
description: Submarine races in the Hudson River will be one of the activities this weekend at a cultural fair in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., sponsored by the Dutchess County Arts Council.

title: Tibetans Find Life Better, if a Bit Colonial, After Two Decades of Full Control by Peking
description: LHASA, Tibet, July 17  The Lhasa electricequipment factory is not of imposing size, a small complex of tinroofed concrete buildings nestled on the northern slope of the Lhasa Valley. Its largest product is a 20kilowatt generator.

title: Art: Works On Paper At Frumkin Gallery
description: FOR the summer season this year the Allan Frumkin Gallery, 50 West 57th Street, has organized an exhibition called Large Scale Works on Paper (through Aug. 17). The show includes the worK of a few outsiders, as well as the artists regularly represented at the gallery, and it proves to be quite an engaging exhibition, especially for the drawings in it. All of the work is being shown for the first time.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE backlash is a predictable phenomenon whenever anybody receives a heavy dosage of favorable attention. This is not to say that backlashes are always to be discounted; sometimes they represent a more accurate assessment than the original enthusiasm. In any event, Devo, the peculiarly robotlike rock quintet from Akron, Ohio, by way of Los Angeles, which will be at the Palladium tomorrow night, is a classic case in point. Whether the group's first disk was as innovative as most people thought or whether its followup reveals the group to be obsessed with gimmickry but lacking in real substance, only time  and perhaps tomorrow's performance  will tell. resent a more accurate assessment than the original enthusiasm. In any event, Devo, the peculiarly robotlike rock quintet from Akron, Ohio, by way of Los Angeles, which will be at the Palladium tomorrow night, is a classic case in point. Whether the group's first disk was as innovative as most people thought or whether its followup reveals the group to be obsessed with gimmickry but lacking in real substance, only time  and perhaps tomorrow's performance  will tell.

title: Israel Says U.N. Force in Lebanon Helps Terrorists
