description: TEL AVIV, July 19  In a strongly worded statement, the Israeli defense forces today criticized the United Nations peacekeeping units in southern Lebanon as cooperating with Palestinian terrorists and allowing them to operate within. striking distance of Israel.

title: The Casinos and Their Town
description: A disturbing sideshow has been running in Atlantic City. The Chamber of Commerce and a few casinoowning companies have been trying to stop Resorts International, the first big gambling concern to operate there, from buying the openair trams that carry tourists along the Boardwalk. For a while it seemed that Resorts had won its trams: there is nothing in present law to stop a casino from moving into unrelated businesses, and the company, now grossing over $700,000 a day, was the highest bidder. Then the Atlantic City Commission postponed a decision to September.

title: Notes on People
description: His poems have appeared in The New Yorker, he has taught college English and two years ago he won a $7,500 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. But James E. Lewisohn is also a prison inmate in Maine, and he will remain one for some time, despite efforts to win his freedom from a life sentence.

title: Market Place
description: THE threesided battle for control of National Airlines has sent the stock of this carrier soaring, to as high as 50 last week from a low of 20 within the last year.

title: At the Movies
description: THE sound stage of the Astoria Film Center in. Queens is the fourthlargest in the country, and its vastness made the only set, a shabby and untidy apartment, seem even smaller.

title: In the Washington ShakeUp, No Tremors for Brzezinski
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  While others in the Government may be feeling insecure this week as a result of President Carter's muchheralded shakeup, aides report that Zbigniew Brzezinski, the national security adviser, is as sure of himself and as ebullient as ever.

title: Woman to Get Kidney Donated By Soviet Union
description: Surgeons at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn prepared late last night to implant into a 43yearold woman one of two kidneys flown to New York from the Soviet Union earlier this week.

title: Short Interest on the Big Board Down in Month
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 100,111 shares in the month ended July 13 to 47.5 million shares. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 36.7 million shares.

description: Morning

description: Monetary Aggregates Daily averages

title: Deaths
description: OLIPHANTMurray. The Officers and Board of Governors note with deep sorrow the gassing of our member.

title: Atomic Waste Shipping Facing Tighter Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that his agency intended to tighten scrutiny over lowlevel radioactive waste that is packaged and, shipped across state lines for storage.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, JULY 19, 1979

title: A Briton's Mideast Advice
description: LONDON  For America's friends in Britain there is a depressing feeling of history repeating itself, as we contemplate the present course of American policy in the Middle East.

title: Three Mile Island Reactor's Builder Concedes Failure to Heed Warning
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  Officials of the Babcock & Wilcox Company conceded today that theyliad faileciltO.take proper heed of warnings last yeafthat their concern's nuclear reactors might be prone to the type of accident that subsequently shut down the Three Mile Island electric generating plant.

title: Books of The Times
description: IS anyone as dumb as I am on the subject of oil? I don't mean just why there isn't enough of it anymore. I mean everything about it, all the way back to how it got into the earth and how they get it out. I need to

title: Borg Wins Easily, Gains Quarterfinals in Sweden
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 19 (AP) Bjorn Borg of Sweden was in top form today, whipping Antonio Zugarelli of Italy, 60, 61, and reaching the quarterfinals of the $110,000 Swedish open tennis championships.

title: U.S. Warns Carey to Act Quickly On Inspection for Car Emissions
description: The Federal Government has warned Governor Carey that the New York metropolitan area is in danger of losing millions of dollars in Federal aid if it does not act quickly to establish a program for annual emission inspections of the region's five million cats.

title: Irvine Heiress Battling Again on Coast Project
description: LOS ANGELES, July 20  When a consortium of 11 persons including 46yearold Athalie (Joan) Irvine Smith gained control of the landrich Irvine Company in 1977, it was anticipated that Mrs. Smith, known as the battling heiress, would be pacified.

title: General Tire Future: Secure Despite Peril
description: The 16 broadcasting properties of RKO General Inc. have poured rapidly increasing profits into the General Tire and Rubber Company's treasury in recent years, but Wall Street analysts harbor little doubt that General Tire could withstand their loss.

title: Woman Gets Kidney From Soviet
description: One of a pair of kidneys flown unexpectedly this week from the Soviet Union to New York was successfully implanted in a 36yearoldGreek woman at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn yesterday, but a suitable recipient could not be found before the second kidney was Judged to be no longer viable.

title: Califano Rejects Offer Of an Ambassadorship
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) President Carter offered the ambassadorship to Italy to Joseph A. Califano Jr. after dismissing him, Administration sources said today.

title: Japanese Favorable To Miller
description: TOKYO, July 20  The appointment of G. William Miller as Treasury Secretary is a welcome personnel change, said Finance Minister Ippei Kaneko. He is fully aware of the Japanese economic situation and friendly to our country, the minister added, in a comment typifying Japan's favorable reaction.

title: City Awarded Pact for 837 Buses. Despite Defects Found in Vehicle
description: New York City's Transit Authority signed an $89 million contract last March for 837 buses although numerous defects had been discovered more than three months earlier in a sample bus sent to the city for testing on express, or cream puff, routes.

title: Blumenthal Policies Likely to Continue With Miller
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Changes at the Treasury Department will be more of style than substance when G. William Miller, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, replaces Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal in perhaps the riskiest of the Administration's current shakeups, analysts both in and out of the Government said today.

title: A Rose Was a Rose
description: First Jerry Ford.

title: BusStop Shelter Company Wins Pacts in Miami and Philadelphia
description: Convenience and Safety Corporation, whose contract to build busstop shelters in New York City has been shelved pending an investigation into the bidding process, this week was awarded similar contracts in Philadelphia and Miami Beach.

title: U.S. Jury Studies Claims On Cost by Tenneco Unit
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  A Federal grand jury in Richmond is investigating the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a subsidiary of Tenneco Inc., for allegedly fraudulent claims resulting from cost overruns for 14 nuclear vessels that the company built for the Navy, according to Justice Department officials.

title: Tankers Collide in Atlantic and Spill Oil
description: Two supertankers collided Thursday night in heavy rain east of the island of Tobago, bursting into flames and spilling large amounts of crude oil into the Atlantic, the United States Coast Guard reported yesterday.

title: Money Grows on Trees
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y.  I live in westem New York, an area appropriately termed a fruit basket. Our hard winters induce restorative dormancy in the trees, enabling them to burst forth with luscious fruit in the few weeks of the available growing season.

title: Senate Vote Keeps Curb In H.E. W. Busing Policy
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  The Senate voted today to retain tight busing restraints on the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, rejecting the charge of Senator Jacob K. Javits that the Senate is interfering with the process of integration.

title: G.M. and Union Clash on Absenteeism and Hiring
description: DETROIT, July 20  The United Automobile Workers laid its nonsalary demands on the bargaining table before the General Motors Corporation today, and the two sides immediately clashed on the issues of absenteeism and the hiring rights of U.A.W. members in new plants in the Sun Belt.

title: An Optometrist Dedicated To Harlem Practice Is Slain
description: From time to time, Oscar Sussman's family and friends urged him to shift his optometrist's practice from East 125th Street in Harlem. He had already been held up several times, and they feared for his life. But Mr. Sussman always refused, saying that he could not abandon the people he had served for 40 years.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Music: Franz, Son of Wolfgang
description: Except for the sons of J.S. Bach, the offspring of great composers have not made much of a mark in their fathers line of work. Siegfried Wagner's feeble scratchings, for instance, went directly onto the compost pile of history, and only our curiosity saves from oblivion the somewhat better music of Franz Xaver Wolfgang Mozart. The son of Mozart was, in fact, a reasonably accomplished though undistinguished composer, as was shown at the Mostly Mozart concert in Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night when Franz's Sonata for Cello and Piano in E (Op. 19) made one of its rare returns from the grave.

title: ADAMS ANGRILY QUITS TRANSPORTATION JOB
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams said today that he had resigned rather than comply with a White. House demand that he dismiss his top aide and that he send another aide to the White House for a disciplinary talk.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JULY 21, 1979

title: Two Carter Choices
description: Shortly after Charles William Duncan Jr., the No. 2 man in the Department of Defense, went to Washington in early 1977, the President's aides began looking for a way to expand the former CocaCola executive's role in the Administration. That search ended yesterday when he was named to replace James R. Schlesinger as Secretary of the beseiged Department of Energy.

title: Unbowed Stabler Shows Up in Camp
description: Ken Stabler, Oakland's disgruntled quarterback, arrived yesterday at the Raider training camp in Santa Rosa, Calif., one week late and unrepentant. I stand by everything I said, he said, referring to his avowed enemy, Al Davis, chief executive and part owner of the team.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, July 20, 1979

title: 180 Rhodesian Auxiliaries Die in Baftles With Army
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, July 20 (Reuters)  More than 180 members of the Zimbabwe Rhodesian maillimy forces, socalled private armies loyal to political parties, were killed in clashes with Government troops today, military headquarters renorted.

title: Arab Fury Against Sadat: The Storm Ebbs
description: ALGIERS  Across the Middle East there are unmistakable signs that the Arab campaign against President Anwar elSadat is running out of momentum and that Arabs who oppose and denounce Egypt's peace treaty with Israel have not been able to agree on what to do next. Algeria, which under Houari Boumediene was the prime factor in forging the socalled steadfastness and confrontation front of Arab militants opposed to Mr. Sadat's visit to Jerusalem, is one of several nations in the region whose antiSadat ardor has cooled or has been rechanneled.

title: Braniff's Net Off in Quarter
description: Operating revenues and airline passenger traffic of Braniff International Airways soared to record levels in the second quarter, but rising operating costs for fuel and largescale route expansion cut secondquarter net earnings to $8.8 million, or 44 cents a share, from $11.2 million, or 56 cents a share, a year ago. The figures were disclosed yesterday by the Braniff International Corporation, holding company for the airline.

title: The Seeds Of Violence
description: When a high school girl was pushed off a subway platform by an unidentified teenager  for no apparent reason  many people wondered what kind of person would do such a thing.

title: Fed Raises Rates to Aid Dollar
description: The Federal Reserve Board acted decisively yesterday to raise interest rates in the United States as part of an effort to stave off an attack on the dollar in the foreignexchanne markets.

title: Shah Reportedly May Buy a New York City Home.
description: Representatives of the Shah of Iran are considering purchasing a New York City town house or a Connecticut estate in anticipation of the deposed leader's establishing residency in the United States, accordinn to sources close to the Shah.

title: MANAGUA WELCOMES REBEL GOVERNMENT
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua; July 20  Es corted by hundreds of heavily armed Sandinist rebels, Nicaragua's new Government drove into Managua today to a tumultuous reception and was immediately sworn in as the successor to the longruling Somoza regime.

title: Begin's Doctors Report Small Artery Blockage
description: JERUSALEM, July 20 (UPI)Prime Minister Menachem Begin has a minor blockage of a small artery that is affecting his vision and balance and has been ordered to rest, his doctors said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALEXANDRA. By Valerie Martin. 180 pages. Farrar Straus Be Giroux. $8.95.

title: For Managua, Joy, Speeches and Reunions
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 20 Tens of thousands of Nicaraguans thronged Managua's main square under a punishing sun this afternoon to celebrate the rebel victory with orotund speeches and earsplitting volleys by automatic weapons.

title: Economic Output Slumps by 3.3%; U.S. Acts to Protect Dollar's Value
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  The gross national product fell at a startling 3.3 percent annual rate in April, May and June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Executive Won't Answer Queries of Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP).  The president of a New Jersey furniture concern refused today to answer questions about alleged payoffs to General Services Administration inspectors.

title: ENERGY HEAD RESIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  James Rodney Schlesinger, one of the most controversial Cabinet secretaries of recent times, made it official today: He will leave the onerous and miscellaneous responsibilities falling to the lot of the energy czar.

title: An Engineer to Get Portugal Moving
description: LISBON, July 20  In the heady, stormy days of 1974, Col. Vasco Gonsalves, the leftwing Prime Minister of the Portuguese revolutionary Government, would greet the arrival of his sole woman minister at Cabinet meetings with a mildly sarcastic: Here comes our flower.

title: Miller Choice Confuses Europe
description: PARIS, July 20  President Carter's abrupt move to replace Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal with the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, G. William Miller, has left European officials and bankers more confused than ever about the outlook for United States economic policy. Some fear the switch could signal relaxation of the Administration's fight against inflation as the next Presidential election approaches.

title: Notes on People
description: It's on again, Billy Carter said yesterday of his onagain, offagain, career as a paid rider on the celebrity cirIt's on again, Billy Carter said yesterday of his onagain, career as a paid rider on the celebrity circuit.

title: Energy Unit's Role
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  The White House outlined a limited operational role today for the proposed Energy Security Corporation, a central component of President Carter's new energy program.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Deaths
description: PALEG Dr Samuel, age 88. Dearly beloved husband of Jeanette. Loving lather of Seena Davis and Leslie. Cherished grandfather of Gail Reiner, Wendy Schwam, Julie, Kim and Robin Pelee and greatgrandfather of Alysla Reiner. Dear brother of Leon Paley. Service Sunday 11:30AM at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Theaters and Cafes Cope With the 78Degree Rule
description: Reactions from New York restaurateurs and theater owners to the first days of the federally imposed 78degree maximum temperature requirements ranged this week from the friendly compliance of some to an increasing anger among others who contend that businesses already hampered by fuel shortages will suffer further losses.

title: The Nuclear Plant: For Some A Threat, for Others Just a Job
description: HADDAM, Conn.  Twice a day this week, Tom Newton put on heavy protection against radiation  overalls and boots, two pairs of gloves and a fullface respirator  and then stepped through a hatch into the Connecticut Yankee atomic power plant's containment building, where the 120degree heat limits Work crews to 30minute shifts, and sometimes less.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON GORDON GOULD, a physicist who was chosen Inventor of the Year for his 1977 las& patent, was granted another this week with wider applications in the technology. He believes it covers all lasers used by industry to manipulate materials, and should bring substantial royalties.

title: Reactor Builder Plans Some Design Changes As Result of Accident
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Officials of the Babcock & Wilcox Company said today that some modifications would be made in the design of their nuclear reactors as a result of the Three Mile Island power plant accident.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WQXR. Ballet Music from Idomeneo. Mozart; Piano Concerto, Clementi; Overture in D, Schubert; Symphony in D, Sibelius.

title: California Court Study Entering Closed Sessions After Legal Snag
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 20The Commission on Judicial Performance moved its investigation of the California Supreme Court into closed sessions this morning after losing an attempt to get the high court to resolve legal questions quickly so that the hearings could continue to a conclusion in public.

title: Western Governors Are Skeptical On Effects of Carter's Energy Plan
description: DENVER, July 20  Six Western Governors who met here today agreed with President Carter's on the gravity of the nation's energy problem but contemplated the possible effects his proposals would have on their home states left them fearful.

title: Events
description: MOSTLY MOZART: FESTIVAL ORCHESTRA, Avery Fisher Hall, 8. Preconcert recital, 7.

title: Prices Up in Uruguay
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 20 (AP)  The cost of living in Uruguay rose 4.2 percent in June and 32.5 percent in the first half of the year, the Government announced today. Food prices rose 5 percent in June, and clothing costs nearly 8 percent.

title: Business and the Law
description: WITHIN the last few weeks, Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons & Gates, a Park Avenue N law firm, acquired from the Department of Labor documents that had been produced by technical consultants concerning the Government's health standards on lead. Shearman & Sterling, a Wall Street firm, received some documents from the Comptroller of the Currency. The Houston firm, Fulbright & Jaworski, obtained information from the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to the Catawba Corporation and eight other companies.

title: A Jersey Woman: Is Reported Held By Kidnappers
description: WEST MILFORD, N.J., July 21  The wife of a Paterson, N.J., bank executive was kidnapped from her home here yesterday morning, according to a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: POWERS OF CABINET WANE UNDER CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  As a candidate for the Presidency, Jimmy Carter made a campaign promise to bring new faces into the Cabinet and restore to the departmental secretaries the power that had been slipping from their grasp for almost a generation.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, July 21

title: COMMODITIES
description: Gold and silver futures rose yesterday on trade and speculative buying, despite Governnient credittightening moves and new reports that the economy is slowing.

title: Cabinet Members Resignations and Carter's Replies
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)Following are the texts of the letters of resignation today of Transportation Secretary Brock Adams and Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger and of the letters by President Carter accepting the resignations:

title: Vietnam, at Geneva Parley, Urges U.S. to Accept More of Its Refugees
description: GENEVA, July 20  Hanoi today called on the world, particularly the United States, to accept larger numbers of Vietnamese refugees, and suggested that airlifts and shipping services be set up to transport more of them from temporary camps in Southeast Asia to permanent asylum in Western countries.

title: Preoccupied Yankees Defeated by A's, 51
description: Winning or losing baseball games seems secondary on the Yankees' list of priorities these days. Though his club had just lost a 51 game to the Oakland A's last night at Yankee Stadium, Manager Billy Martin was laughing. Someone joked that tomorrow was OldTimers Day and it might be Al Rosen's turn to come back to the Yankees.

title: Once in a Lifetime
description: A bamboo plant that blooms once in a century has begun to flower around the world. The phenomenon causing great excitement among botanists, who have been unable to identify properly this particular variety, known as the umbrella bamboo, because the blossoms essential for its classification just haven't been around. Scientists need the information to propagate the species, which is one of the most useful to man.

title: Deaths
description: BERGMANEva. Devoted mother of Murray and None, Irwin and Roberfa and Melvin and Deena. Loving grandmother of Barry, Robert, Ira, Barbara and Michael: Dear sister of Ida Albert and Semuel Cohen. Services at BoulevardPark West 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. Sunday at 10 A.M.

title: Carter Signs Smithsonian Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)  President Carter has signed a bill authorizing an appropriation of $500,000 to the Smithsonian Institution for development of an area south of the Smithsonian, on the Mall, the White House announced today. The area is intended for use by the Museum of African Art, an enlarged exhibition for Oriental art, and for an educational facility for the Smithsonian Associates.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: A move by the Federal Reserve Board to raise key United States interest rates pushed the dollar generally higher on the world's currency exchanges yesterday as the price of gold continued to retreat.

title: 2,000 Blacks March in Birmingham to Protest Killing
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 20  Going 10 abreast in a light drizzle, about 2,000 angry but orderly blacks marched through downtown at noon today to protest Mayor David Values refusal to dismiss a white policeman who killed an unarmed black woman by shooting her three times in the back.

title: Aides Act on Carter's Pledge
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Defense and State Departments are hurriedly trying to catch up with President Carter's pledge to a group of demonstrators in front of the White House last night that the United States Navy will pick up boat people on the high seas.

title: Enid Davis Golf Victor
description: PARAMUS, N.J., July 20  Enid Davis of Baltusrol carded an 85 today and won the New Jersey Women's Golf Assciation's oneday tournament at the Arcola Country Club. Diane Pinkham of Montclair was second with an 88. Adele Rodgers of Navesink had the low net score, 91.

title: British To Sell Part Of Airline
description: LONDON, July 20  A major share of the stateowned British Airways will be sold to private investors as part of the new Conservative Government's plan to reduce its involvement in industry, it was announced today.

title: Van Pelt Arrives; `Lucky in Accident
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 20  Brad Van Pelt, who was lucky to survive an auto accident a week after Troy Archer's fatal crash, arrived at the Giants training camp today with a black eye and still not feeling great.

title: 2 Churches Aiding Tenants in Management
description: An elderly woman and another in her middle years sat on the stoop at 450 West 152d Street and talked of seeing the building fall into disrepair over the years they had lived there.

title: New Insights Into Love in the Churchill Family
description: LONDON, July 18  Mary Soames, who was the youngest of Winston Churchill's fiye children, is also the one who has had the most normal and stable life. In her opinion, that was not a coincidence.

title: OBSERVER
description: The President started the week with a humble confession of inadequacy. Always be humble, especially if you are arrogant, goes the old political maxim. Mr. Carter's display of humility was one in which he could take not only pride but also satisfaction, since his popularity rating in the polls shot up several points almost immediately.

title: Murder Suspect Takes Over Case
description: MIAMI July 20 (AP)  Unhappy with the way a team of attorneys was handling the case, Theodore R. Bundy took over his own defense today midway in his trial on charges of murdering two sorority sisters.

title: Carter Meets Ecuador's Leader
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  President Carter was visited briefly today by Jaime Rolds Aguilera, the Presidentelect of Ecuador, in the White House Oval Office. The two leaders were joined by their wives for a few minutes while photographers took pictures, and Mrs. Rolds was escorted around the White House by Mrs. Carter.

title: Dr. Richard J. Kennedy, Cardiologist, Dead at 72
description: Dr. Richard J. Kennedy, associate director of medicine emeritus and chief of the, cardiographic sections at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York, died yesterday at the hospital, after a brief illness. He was 72 years old.

title: EARNINGS
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. of Canada, one of the two largest primary aluminum producers in the world, reported yesterday a 37.6 percent increase in secondquarter net income to $105.8 million, or $2.62 a share, from $76.9 million, or $1.90 a share, for the comparable period a year earlier. Alcan's results were reported in United States dollars.

title: UnionJubilant Over Key Victory At Sun Belt General Motors Plant
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 20  A mixture of jubilation and resentment prevailed in this conservative Sun Belt city today after last night's decisive victory by the United Automobile Workers in its hotly contested bid to represent workers employed by the new General Motors Corporation car assembly plant here.

title: Nassau Insurance Payments Under Investigation by U.S.
description: Federal prosecutors are investigating the awarding of municipal insurance premiums to politically connected brokers in Nassau County and the role of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican chairman, in those awards. Such awards are also common in otherareas.

title: Fall Fashion Previews: Jumpsuits, Jabots and Luxury Furs
description: As summer settles over the city, fashion people have their sights trained on fall. This week, Lord & Taylor polished up its basic theme, Glamour Today, which will serve as an umbrella for all its fashion departments  and bring in its home furnishings sections as well. Laura Ashley, the British designer known for her demure, 19thcentury cotton fashions, rias expanded into tweeds and crepe de chine styles and Basile, the Italian tailored suit specialist, showed its first collection of furs.

title: Rock: Renaissance in Calm Mode
description: The brand of rock played by Renaissance, which was at Radio City Music Hall on Thursday night, and by Yes, Genesis and other such groups, represents a taming of rockandroll's anarchic Americanism Although English groups nice the Rolling Stones revel in the very American energy and nearhysteria that accompany their performances and often reflect a concern with things American in the imagery of their songs, Renaissance and similar groups are more oriented toward their European heritage. This emphasis is evident in their tendency to write songs that are like fairy tales or fables and in their music, which deemphasizes or entirely eliminates the raw sound of rockandroll guitar in favor of a more homogeneously orchestrakeyboard texture.

title: Padres Beat Mets, 21, on Home Run in 9th
description: SAN DIEGO, July 20  The New York Mets lost their third straight game tonight when Jerry Turner hit a ninthinning home run off Craig Swan for a 21 victory for the San .Diego Padres and their senior citizen, Gaylord Petry.

title: CBSTV Making Documentaries Available to PBS
description: CBSTV is making available to the Public Broadcasting Service, without charge, its archive of vintage news documentaries for unlimited use by the noncommercial network at its discretion. WNETTV. New York, is to be the originating station for PBS.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: TORONTO, July 20 (Reuters) Rio Algom Ltd. said today that it had been informed by the Tennessee Valley Authority that the T.V.A. was taking action in the United States to void a supply contract under which Rio Algom was to supply 17 million pounds of uranium to T.V.A. from 1979 to 1990.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, JULY 20. 197Q

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Shortterm interest rates climbed and yields on longterm bonds declined yesterday following the Federal Reserve's decision to lift the discount rate and the Federal funds rate.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FUNNY GIRLS Three notable comediennes of the early Hollywood years, Mabel Normand, Marion Davies and Marie Dressler, are the subjects of tonight's lecture and screening with Leonard Maltin starting at 8 o'clock at the Museum of Modern Art. The program will show The Nickel Hopper and Mack Sezinett'a Muddled in Mud with Miss Normand; and King Vidor's The Patsy, with Miss Davies and Miss Dressler.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  The Carter Administration won a Federal district judge's support today for its cancellation of $36 million in contracts with Uniroyal Inc. in a sex discrimination case.

title: A Bill on Pill Labeling Is Killed by Its Author After Albany Passage
description: ALBANY, July 20  A bill that would have required drug makers to mark each prescription pill or capsule for fast identification has been recalled by its sponsor, who said he feared it would sabotage efforts to encourage the use of lowerpriced drugs without brand names.

title: Envoy to Managua Asks Patience
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  The United States Ambassador to Nicaragua appealed to Americans today to resist the temptation to label or judge the provisional government of the country until it had settled into its new responsibilities.

title: Mandel's Conviction Reinstated
description: BALTIMORE, July 20 (AP)  The convictions of former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five codefendants for political corruption were reinstated today by a sharply divided United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

title: Civiletti Is Said to Lack Close White House Ties
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  When Benjamin R. Civiletti was introduced yesterday as President Carter's choice to become the new Attorney General, he made a small but revealing blunder. Asked about his relationship with the White House chief of staff, Hamilton Jordan, who has made it well known that he prefers to pronounce his name JERdun, Mr. Civiletti talked about Mr. JORdan.

title: Family Panel Gets Pep Talk From Carter
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Carter took time out today from shuffling his own Cabinet family to plead fora strengthening of the American family.

title: Your Money
description: HIBERNATION is usually for the bears. But now, because of fuel uncertainties, it may become popular among humans of the suburbanite species this coming winter.

title: The Editorial Notebook Confidence
description: President Carter's words about a deeper American malaise than the energy crisis evidently hit home. According to the New York Times/CBS poll, threequarters of a nationwide sample feels there really is a moral and spiritual crisis, that is, a crisis of confidence, in the country today This is disturbing news. But before people get to the bottom of it  and maybe before the President resorts to the word confidence much more than the 15 times he did last Sundayit may be useful to record some of its meanings and connotations.

title: Carter Appoints Watson Ambassador to Moscow
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)  President Carter will nominate Thomas J. Watson Jr., former chairman of I.B.M., to serve as Ambassador to the Soviet Union, the White House announced to day.

title: Rep. Leach Accused of Purchasing Votes in Louisiana House Election
description: ALEXANDRIA, La., July 20 (AP)  A Federal grand jury indicted Representative Claude (Buddy) Leach, Democrat of Louisiana, today on charges of conspiring to buy 440 votes in the runoff election he won by 266 votes last fall.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, July 20 (Reuters)  The National Party of Nigeria won a 57seat majority over its nearest rival, the United Party, in the elections Saturday to the HouSe of Representatives, the official Lagos radio reported today in a broadcast monitored here.

title: Stock Advance Slightly
description: The stock market managed a narrow gain yesterday as a report of a significant decline in the gross national product was counteracted by a rise in the discount rate.

title: NO STAFF SHIFTS YET
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  President Carter concluded his Cabinet reorganization, and perhaps the most tumultuous week of his Presidency, today by forcing Transportation Secretary Brock Adams to resign and accepting the resignation of Energy Secretary James R. Schicilippr

title: Spain Will Get The Guernica From the U.S.
description: MADRID, July 20 (AP)  The executor, of Pablo Picasso's estate plans to bring the painter's masterpiece Guernica, now in New York's Museum of Modern Art, back to Spain by the end of next year or early in 1981, sources close to Spain's DirectorateGeneral of Artistic Patrimony said today.

title: Investing in Nuclear Plant
description: The Vermont Public Service Board said it had authorized two Vermont utilities, the Central Vermont Public Service Corporation and the Green Mountain Power Corporation, to invest a total of $54 million in the Public Service Company of New Hampshire's Seabrook nuclear plant. Under the order, each concern will invest $27 million and will each acquire a 1 percent interest in Seabrook.

title: Mrs. Harris Is Expected To Alter H.E.W. Subtly
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  Though Patricia Roberts Harris and Joseph A. Califano Jr. are Democratic social liberals of the same mold, it is expected here that Mrs. Harris will bring some subtle changes in emphasis when she takes over from Mr. Califano as Secretary of Health, Edducation and Welfare.

title: Bavarian Seeking Image for National Stage
description: MUNICH, West Germany, July 17 The pleasant young man with the John Dean look of reliability seemed to think he was letting his guest in on a secret. You know, he said, in certain places the chief has a bit of an image problem .

title: Dance: Dutch and Cuban Companies Present Premieres
description: On Thursday night, it was very possible for a dancegoer shuttling within 10block area to have caught premieres by both the Netherlands Dance Theater and the National Ballet of Cuba.

title: ALFRED DELLER, 67, COUNTERTENOR, DIES
description: Alfred Deller, the British countertenor who almost singlehandedly revived the art of solo male alto singing in modern times, died Monday in Bologna, Italy. He was 67 years old.

title: The Region
description: VALHALLA, N.Y.  A walkout on Thursday by correction officers on the last shift at the Westchester County Jail and Penitentiary continued yesterday, with supervisors and county police officers manning the facilities.

title: Surprise: Ousted Officials Don't Return Evaluations
description: WASHINGTON, Ally 20 If there is a lesson for the White House on evaluating highlevel Government officials, it is, don't discharge bosses at the same time you ask thern to fill oat performance reports on theirsubordinates.

title: About New York
description: Tribal movement in the city is a layered thing, and there is a litany of immigiation that almost every New Yorker can intone, with due reverence for who came first and who came late.

title: Oil Man Negotiating for Interest in 21 Club
description: Partners of the 21. Club said yesterday that a Texas oilman, Baron Enrico di Portanova, was negotiating to buy a substantial portion of the restaurant in Manhattan and of three subsidiaries of the closely held corporation.

title: William Graham Claytor Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) Navy Secretary W. Graham Claytor Jr., a seasoned railroad man, will be back on familiar ground when he transfers to the Transportation Department as the temporary. replacement for Brock Adams, the outgoing Transportation Secretary.

title: Step in Riglit Direction
description: A few hours before the big race, the word reached the press box at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J., that Al Rosen was out as president of the New York Yankees. Once again, George Steinbrenner had upstaged a major sports event that might otherwise have received top billing. Even without Yankee interference, though, Thursday night's third running of the $750,000 Meadowlands Pace demonstrated harness

title: Queens Man Is Held in Slaying
description: A31yearold Queens man was arrested yesterday and charged with shooting to death his wife's first husband. The police said Jacob Walter, of 13111 Kew Gardens Road; and his wife, Goldie, had been harassed for two years by the victim, Louis Armhold, also 51, who apparently had tried to visit the couple on numerous times.

title: Irwin Retains Lead By 2 in British Open On a 75211 in Rain
description: ST. ANNES, England, July 20  With rain and devilish pin placements added to the wind and cold on an awesomely difficult course, the best golf professionals could not handle the par 71 at the Royal Lytham and St. Armes Golf Club today. The third round of the 108th British Open was played on the kind of day on which a 73 gained ground.

title: Israelis Land in Lebanon by Boat, Fire on Guerrilla Car and Wound
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20  An Israeli force using rubber dingies landed on the coast of southern Lebanon at dawn today and attacked Palestinian guerrillas driving along a road, seriously wounding three and a Lebanese member of a leftist militia force.

title: Bad News on Rent Stabilization
description: The resignation of Frances Levenson as chairman of New York's Rent Guidelines Board came as doubly bad news. First, the city lost the services of an effective citizen who has devoted a lifetime to the improvement of housing and the battle against residential segregation. Finding her successor will be difficult. Second, the continuing conflicts that surround the board challenge its future effectiveness.

title: U.N. Appeals to Israel To Halt Its Settlements
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20The Security Council approved a resolution today calling on Israel to cease on an urgent basis the establishment or planning of Jewish settlements on Arab land occupied since the 1967 war.

title: Police Paddle Around Manhattan to Aid Injured Fellow Officer
description: Police Officers John Chapman, left, and Harry. Grant paddling a kayak under the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday in an effort to raise funds for Michael Mullick. Officer Mullick, of the 10th Precinct, was injured in the line of duty last month and lost a leg; his other leg was successfully reattached by microsurgery team at Bellevue Hospital.

title: Capital Turmoil Saddens And Confuses U.S. Aides
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  The man had come into Government with Jimmy Carter, and as late as last Tuesday he was defending the President's legislative program on Capitol Hill. But today, with the Administration in turmoil, the official was a sad, shaken figure.

title: Gas Dealer Finds Oil and Dream Don't Mix
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  In a hot and airless gas station at the corner of Bloomfield Avenue and Orange Road, 45 minutes from New York, sits a short, rounded, redfaced man whom life has struck in the face with a thick cream pie.

title: Bridge:
description: Leading extra rounds of trumps after the enemy trumps have been extracted is usually the mark of a beginner or an expert. Consider, for example, the diagramed deal, which contributed to a double victory in a New Jersey tournament last weekend.

title: No Passage in India
description: India's huge democracy is not a very good advertisement for itself these days. No matter who finally proves able to form it, a new government in New Delhi is unlikely to dispel the malaise that has demoralized the country since it regained its political freedom two years ago. At least in part, the explanation is generational. Thirty years after independence, the reins of power are still being passed among the tired hands of men who owe their prominence to association with Gandhi and Nehru, the outsize founders.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Skylab Bounty Awarded To an Australian Youth
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 (AP)  An Australian teenager today was awarded $10,000 by The San Francisco Examiner as the first person to arrive here with piece of the Skylab space station.

title: Button and 2d Victim Testify About Injuries In Park Clubbing Case
description: Richard Button, the twotime Olympic gold medalist in figure skating, and Reuel Lownes, a surgical technician, testified yesterday that they were still suffering from injuries they received from baseball bats wielded by young men in Central Park one year ago.

title: Seaver Wins 8th Straight
description: ST. LOUIS, July 20 (UPI)  Tom Seaver pitched his 50th career shutout and won his eighth straight game tonight, pacing the Cincinnati Reds to a 30 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. Johnny Bench and Dave Collins horndied for the Reds.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter completed the reorganization of his Cabinet dismissing Brock Adams as Transportation Secretary and accepting the resignation of James R. Schlesinger as Energy Secretary. The White House said Deputy Defense Secretary Charles W. Duncan Jr. would be nominated as the new Energy Secretary, while the Transportation Department would be turned over to Secretary of the Navy W. Graham Claytor for an interim period of up to 30 days. [Page 1.]

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, JULY 20, 1979

title: U.S. Halts Pullout of Combat G.I. 's From South Korea Till at Least '81
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  The withdrawal of American combat soldiers from South. Korea, temporarily suspended last February, was halted today by President Carter until at least 1981.

title: Apollo Project's Veterans Savor Past Lunar Glories
description: WASHINGTON, July 20  On the 10th anniversary of man's first landing on the moon, the engineers and managers and astronauts who made possible that giant leap for mankind gathered today for an Apollo family reunion.

title: HomosexualLiberation Statue Is Planned for Sheridan Square
description: Ten years after the police raid on Greenwich Village bar that led to formation of the homosexualrights movement, plans are being advanced for a homosexualliberation monument to be placed in Sheridan Squate.

title: The Big Orange
description: SAN DIEGO  It's another subzero day in Anywhere, N. Y. Snowdrifts up to 20 feet are common. The streets are impassable and the populace hunkers down for the duration. The weatherman is apologetic as he delivers the latest bad news: There's another snowstorm on the way and another one right behind that one and ...

title: REFUGEES SAY HANOI REACTS TO PRESSURE
description: TEREMPA, Indonesia, July 20  The refugees who recently arrived here in the isolated Anambas Islands from Vietnam say that Communist authorities there sharply curtailed their profitable expulsion of ethnic Chinese last month as the Geneva conference on Indochina refugees was being organized.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 44.

title: 2 Concerns Plan Office Complex In Town of Rye
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 20  Ladbroke's, Britain's largest gambling company, announced today that it had signed a deal with the Largo Corporation of Stamford, a major Connecticut developer, to build an office complex on 77 acres in the town of Rye, adjacent to the Westchester County airport.

title: The City
description: Five of the seven recent tires in midtown department stores are believed to have been set  accidentally or intentionally  the Fire Department's chief uniformedUfficer said yesterday. But he said that the fires, including Thursday's at B. Altman & Company, had not been declared arsons and that he did not believe they were the work of any organized group.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Surveys Show Manhattan Office Space Scarcer
description: The city's inventory of available office space in Manhattan continues to be diminished and rents continue to climb, according to the latest reports of several surveys.

title: Broadway Opening? Matter of Economics
description: Sarava, which never officially opened, closed after 177 performances. Theoretically, the musical had been in previews since March; when it left Boston after two weeks of tryouts, moved onto Broadway, and then postponed its opening night three times. Theoretically, Beatlemania, although it has been two seasons on Broadway, is still in previews, too. An opening night happens when a producer says it happens. The producer of Beatlemania has said it never happened.

title: Act 2: The Chase
description: SAN DIEGO, July 21  Dave Winfield of the San Diego Padres stepped into the batting cage and asked, What is this, the last half of the season or the last twofifths? Then he hit a ball in the general direction of Tijuana and replied, Well, whatever it is, here goes.

title: Around the Nation
description: RED LAKE, Minn., July 21 (AP) The police at the tense Red Lake Indian Reservation traded shots with gunmen for three hours early today, the authorities said. No one was reported injured.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Carter Counts On It
description: President Carter's crash program to produce synthetic fuels as a replacement for imported oil will in many respects be a thrust into the dark, made all the more uncertain by the departure of Secretary James R. Schlesinger from the incompletely organized Department of Energy.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sunday, July 22 (AP)  A South Korean naval vessel sank a North Korean spy boat during a machinegun and rocket duel about three miles offshore, the South Korean Defense Ministry said today.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SALISBURY, ZimbabweRhodesia  Two important summit conferences are are on Africa's mind. The Organization of African Unity is convening in Liberia, and early next month the British Commonwealth will meet in Zambia. Immediate African problems are high on both agendas.

title: On the Beaches, There's a Changing of the Guard
description: ROBERT MOSES STATE PARK LET'S go, Dick Neagle screamed in midair as he leaped the 10 feet from his lifeguard chair to the sand. Landing on the run, the veteran lifeguard snatched up a life buoy as he sprinted toward the surf, where a young boy was being pulled out to sea by an offshore current.

title: LURE OF THE WHITE WATER
description: Now we could hear in the dis tance the first of the rapid we would face. The rumbling sound wa?? like that of a freigh train rolling across the countryside.

title: What Has the Tristate Agency Done for New Jersey?
description: ALTHOUGH Edward Cornell of Park Ridge became assistant commissioner in the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs in 1976, not until this year was he appointed  as Commissioner Joseph A. LeFante's surrogate  to be one of the five New Jersey members of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission.

title: A Fusion of Traditions
description: ISAAC ROSENBERG was killed in battle at the age of 27, on April 1, 1918, while fighting in the British Army on the Western Front. The child of East European Jewish emigrants to England, Rosenberg did not have time to mature, whether as a poet or painter. His fragmentary but authentic achievement is gathered together definitively in this new edition of his Works, skillfully edited and beautifully produced.

title: SELECTION: From The Old Patagonian Express
description: The Brass Plaque Said Borges

title: Bus Service Still a Maze, State Finds
description: LAST October the State Department of Transportation began what seemed like a simple project. For the first time since 1972, the department was going identify all bus routes in Connecticut, compare the numerous private and public bus systems, find out where bus service needed to be improved and how to coordinate buses with each other and with the trains.

title: A Sport That's Off the Beaten Path
description: HIKERS are people of limited visibility  hard to identify, blending into the background and doing their hiking in the deep woods, state parks and backwaters of civilization. They wear no ritual clothing, as joggers do, and tend to shy away from advertising themselves. The sartorial effect is that of wellworn, comfortable, expendable and anonymous clothing. Only one item demands careful attention: boots. A good pair of hiking boots can save a life.

title: Vilas, Pecci Gain Final In Tennis
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, the topseeded player, and Victor Pecci of Paraguay gained tomorrow's final of the $175,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament.

title: Barbara Holz, Hospital Aide, Betrothed to Theodore Reiss
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Holz of Millburn, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Holz, to Theodore Feld Reiss, son of District Court Judge and Mrs. Sidney Reiss of Passaic, N.J.

title: Dr. Kathryn M. Jason Engaged to Dr. Warren J. Kaplan
description: Dr. Kathryn Mary Jason, a neuropharmacologist, and Dr. Warren J. Kaplan, a dentist in Harriman, N.Y., plan to be married Aug. 31 in New York.

title: GARDENING
description: OF all the vegetables grown in the garden, the tomato is undoubtedly the most rewarding and the most productive. A single plant of a largefruited variety, supported in an upright position, will produce as many as 10 pounds of fruit while taking up little more than two and a half square feet of space. This makes it an ideal plant where space is limited, and especially when containergrown.

title: Sort of Immortal
description: FRANCIS PICABIA (18791953) is in every history of modern art. Sometimes he is there as a rearguard man: someone who was painting middleof-the-road Impressionist pictures in 1905, more than 20 years after the founders of pure Impressionism had given it up for dead. Sometimes he is there as an avantgarde man: as the friend and ally of Marcel Duchamp, for instance, when the two of them were in New York during World War I. Sometimesahe is there as one of the liveliest and most provocative members of the international Dada movement from 1917 onward. He is also in the history books as an editor, a controversialist, a poet and the maker in the first half of the 1920's of some of the most beguiling of all collages. He is there as a phenomenon, too: someone who had so many ideas that he never liked to stick with any one of them for long. (The thing about ideas, he once said,is that you should change them as often as you change your shirts.)

title: Restaurant Deals Reported
description: First 21, now La Cte Basque and the Italian Pavilion.

title: Religious Broadcaster Murdered in Teheran; Army Chief Is Ousted
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 21 (AP)  An unknown assailant shot and killed a prominent Teheran religious leader early today.

title: The Grande Dame of Antique Clothes
description: Cora Ginsberg was 30 years old in 1940, when she bought her first antique dress on upper Park Avenue in what is now Spanish Harlem.

title: Deaths
description: HOROWITZElihu, on July 21, 1979, husband of Florence, father of Mark, Jed and Julia. Service at Jewish Community Center, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains, Monday, 11:30AM. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to American Cancer Society, Westchester Division.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: REMOVING an old fence post or gate post that has been in place for years is often a frustrating and backbreaking job. Regardless of whether the post is being taken out because it has started to work loose, has started to rot or is badly cracked and split and thus needs replacing, once the attempt is made to get it out the post seems to be reluctant to let go its grip in the soil. The problem is even more difficult when the post has been set in concrete.

title: Tied Up
description: YOU may have noticed, in the shop windows of Garden City and Huntington, that men's ties have once again become narrow. Naturally, I was delighted to see this because everyone knows that narrow ties require less material, and we shall no doubt see prices reflecting this saving any day now.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: I found the article Legislators Feel L.I. Gained in Albany [July 1] to be most interesting. As usual, our elected officials such as Senator Caemmerer and Assemblyman Hannon think highly of themselves in terms of what they have accomplished. Unfortunately, from a taxpayer's point of view, this past session was a disaster.

title: Sunday Observer Walking Ads
description: Ever since sex became as commonplace as spearmint gum, the theories of Dr. Freud don't seem half so interesting as they used to. As a matter of fact, now that we can examine them with the clear eye of the new enlightenment, they don't even seem very sound.

title: Blues: Hutto With Craig
description: Why, that's the National Anthem, declared a listener at the Squat Theater on Friday night as J.B. Hutto hit the ringing introductory guitar figure from Dust My Broom. Like a national anthem, which theoretically remains stirring no matter how often one hears it, the instrumental pattern from Dust My Broom rarely fails to rouse an audience, and the Squat Theater's entire Friday night show was like that familiar but inspiring.

title: The Galante Murder Is a Case Study of the Frustrations
description: If it has done nothing else, the murder of Carmine Galante has pointed up the frustrations of law enforcement officers in trying to penetrate organized crime and demonstrated how little they know with certainty about the underworld hierarchy.

title: For 78 Degrees, Mood's Temperate
description: WHITE PLAINS MORRIS ELLENBERG'S stationery shop in the White Plains Shopping Mall has central airconditioning, but last week Mr. Ellenberg brought a fan to work. The fan, he explained, was to help make life as comfortable as possible for coworkers and customers.

title: The Politics of Repentance
description: Viewed through a publicrelations prism  and what other way is there to look at modern media politics?the new beginning undertaken by Jimroy Carter in recent days is nothing new.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Stock prices seesawed in a narrow range last week, reflecting investor indecision over how to interpret a plethora of political and economic events. The Dow Jones industrial average finished the week at 828.07, down 5.46 points from the preceding Friday, as solid positive news continued to be elusive.

title: TomorrowA Video Supermarket
description: For most of its life, cable television has been a medium without a message, an industry whose chief concerns were technology and marketing, not programming. But now, as cable nears 30 percent saturation of all homes in the United States  the point at which it can command national advertising, which industry experts expect cable to achieve sometime in 1981  there is frenzied interest in the medium among those who hope to provide it with original program material. If current claims can be believed, cable viewers will soon be offered an entire network designed for persons over age 50; a 24hour news network featuring a twohour newscast in prime time; an allsports network; an allSpanish language network; a network providing electronic material for those equipped to play videocomputer games, and a cornucopia of other specialinterest programs.

title: The Strange Case Of Edwin Moses
description: MOSCOW, July 21 (AP)While Edwin Moses was losing in a 400meter hurdle heat here today, the real Edwin Moses was winning several thousand miles away.

title: China Reports Record Harvest
description: PEKING, July 21 (Reuters)  China's state farms and communes sold 9.66 million metric tons of grain to the state by July 15 this year, which was 6.1 percent above the goal, the official press agency said today.

title: Egyptian Palace Links New Hotel Towers
description: The 110yearold Omar Khayyam Palace in Cairo is being restored to its originial condition as part of a new hotel. The palace will link the two towers of the 1,260room Cairo Marriott, which is scheduled to open in September next year on Ghezira Island in the Nile River.

title: POLITICS
description: STAMFORD STATE Senator Richard H. G. Cunningham refuses to be discouraged. He prides himself on pushing forward in the face of adversity and refers often to Abraham Lincoln's setbacks.

title: DINING OUT An Eating Club in Princeton
description: LAHIERE'S, now in its 60th year, is less a restaurant than a Princeton eating club. Both the founder, Joseph Christen, and his son Leon, the current manager, belong to Princeton University's class of 1949, one as an honorary member, the other as a graduate. From the beginning, Lahiere's has been a special meeting place for town and gown, with tables for regulars staked out and kept inviolate.

title: Pop: Moriarty At New Boltax
description: Although Michael Moriarty is known primarily as an actor  he was last seen on Broadway this last spring in G.R. Point  he has been pursuing an intermittent career as a nightclub singer and pianist for more than five years. During all those years, Mr. Moriarty sat at the piano playing his own accompaniment and occasionally drifting through a gentle jazz solo.

title: Energy Audits Find Many Houses in Red
description: CLINTON B. BUSH climbed a ladder in Daniel Brovey's closet, carefully examined the length and breadth of the attic crawl space and pocketed his flashlight like a doctor pocketing a stethoscope.

title: Charan Singh Becomes Indian Coalition Leader
description: NEW DELHI, July 21 (Reuters)  Former Deputy Prime Minister Charan Singh, who defected from Morarji R. Desai's Janata Party after its government's fall last week, emerged today as the leader of Indian opposition parties trying to form a new government.

title: GARDENING
description: OF all the vegetables grown in the garden, the tomato is undoubtedly the most rewarding and the most productive. A single plant of a largefruited variety, supported in an upright position, will produce as many as 10 pounds of fruit while taking up little more than two and a half square feet of space. This makes it an ideal plant where space is limited, and especially when containergrown.

title: Elizabeth A. Chew Sets Fall Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter T. Chew of Washington have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Aldridge Chew, to Allen Burr Rider 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rider Jr. of Boston. An early fall wedding is planned in St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, Washington.

title: Mailbox:. The U.S. Should Apologize For BobbyKnight
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Is There a Doctor in the House?; Physicists Devise a New Profession for Energy Saving
description: American houses, according to scientists who study home heating, leak oil from almost every pore. President Carter's call last Sunday for cutting the nation's oil imports in half by 1990 was a call for sacrifice as well, asking Americans to resign themselves to being hotter in the summer and colder in the winter.

title: Sallie M. Shuping Engaged to John Russell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hampton Shuping of Greensboro, N.C., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sallie Murrill Shuping, to John Spotswood Russell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Russell, also of Greensboro.

title: Deaths
description: KENNEDYRichard J., M.D. The Medical Staff of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York expresses profound sorrow and sympathy to the family on the passing of our distinguished colleague and valued friend, Richard J. Kennedy. Dr Kennedy has served the hospital devotedly for 43 years, including positions of Secretary and VicePresident of the Medical Board and Associate Director of the Department of Medicine. His unwavering and highly principled dedication to his family and profession has been exemplary and a constant source of Inspiration. William F. Penke, M.D. President, Medical Board

title: Fire Is Out of Control on Supertanker Off Tobago
description: Fire raged out of control for the third day yesterday aboard a crippled Greekowned supertanker that was drifting slowly westward 15 miles northwest of the island of Tobago after colliding with another supertanker in heavy rain Thursday night.

title: Casinos Changing Smithville
description: SMITHVILLE THE beginning of the casino era in Atlantic City is having a major impact on nearby municipalities, which must absorb the thousands of new residents attracted to jobs in the gambling resort.

title: BRIDGE
description: Recent attempts by the International Olympic Committee to solve its ChinaTaiwan problem serve as a reminder that the bridge authorities have political difficulties and generally resolve them rather well.

title: Mary Alexander Married to Nathaniel Smith
description: Mary Hadden Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Quentin Alexander of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, was married yesterday afternoon to Nathaniel Tyler Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Ware Smith of Gates Mills, Ohio. The Rev. William D. Shively, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Eutrophia Farm, the Alexander home.

title: A Book of Changes
description: JUST who does Stanley Ktmitz think he is? The question is not put derisively, but in a spirit of honest inquiry that the poet should appreciate. It is a question that he must, like any poet, have asked himself repeatedly during a lifetime of writing. No simple answer to it can be had; but tantalizing clues emerge from this collection covering 50 years. One of the earliest lyrics, Change, speaks of man as Dissolving in the chemic vat/ Of time . . ./ Becoming, never being, till/ Becoming is being still. The deep pun that reverberates in the last word expresses the paradox of identity somehow persisting amid flux. One of the latest poems, The Layers, surveys this philosophic idea in its most personal aspect: I have walked through many lives,/ some of them my own, / and I am not who I was,/ though some principle of being/ abides ... .  The Roem ends, I am not done with my changes. The self is protean, plastic, and the successful poem is one that glimpses the hidden order governing its transformations.

title: She Takes Her Computers Home
description: WASHINGTON  The honest working woman is entitled to the respect of all honestminded people, said the first Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Carpi Davidson Wright, back in the days of President Chester A. Arthur. She should be welcomed into the churches of the cities and drawn into the best associations.

title: Janet Herbert Becomes Bride
description: St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Noroton, Conn., was the setting last evening for the marriage of Janet Ann Herbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Herbert of Darien, Conn., to Charles Louis Glazer, son of Mrs. Bernard Mellitz of. St. Louis and the late Charles S. Glazer. Msgr. John Yates performed the ceremony.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: NOW that President Carter has put the country's energy problems on a war footing, the rest of us can sit back and cast a glum eye over the battlefield, knowing that we have, in fact, been here before.

title: JAPANESE STRSSING USE OF SOLAR POWER
description: CHOFU, Japan, July 18  Machiko Kimura opened the orange metal door of apartment 206 in the experimental solarenergy apartment house here. She led the way into an apartment with rugs, a piano, a record player and a sofa, the properties of the new middle class in Japan.

title: C.A.B. to Reject Merger Of Two Airlines in West
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board moved today to reject a merger of Continental Air Lines and Western Airlines, saying it would threaten competition on some routes in the West.

title: Reshaping of Carter's Presidency: 16 Days of Shifts and Reappraisal
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  Sixteen days ago, while the capital and the nation puzzled over Jimmy Carter's sudden, mystifying cancellation of the energy speech he had been rushing to complete, the President's inner circle of advisers sat down with him in the woodpaneled conference room of Laurel Lodge at Camp David.

title: Musical Vision
description: MOST music in the world is no longer heard in the presence of the performer but is electronically transported to some other time and place. As the historian Jacques Barzun points out, the phonograph has done for music what the printing press did for literature: it has made music a vital part of everyday life for countless people who otherwise would have had little or no access to it.

title: Miss Reighley And a Banker Plan Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. Ward Reighley of New Canaan, Conn.; Nantucket, Mass., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Elizabeth Reighley, to John Howell Cavanaugh, son of Mrs. Jere H. Cavanaugh of Houston, and the late Mr. Cavanaugh.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Sales Drop in Gas Shortage
description: THE gasoline crisis, coupled with wider economic concerns, has resulted in a drop in the volume of home purchases around the state. Moreover, there are early indications that fears of a continued gasoline famine plus rises in the cost of home heating oil may be having a fundamental impact upon patterns of demand.

title: The Wealth of Anastasio Somoza
description: MIAMI  Before Nicaraguan president Anastasio Somoza Debayle was cast out by force from the country his family held like a feudal fief for 42 years, a classified United States Government intelligence report put the family financial holdings  largely controlled by Mr. Somoza  at $900 million.

title: Border Patrol Searches Assailed As Exceeding Power Over Aliens

title: Patrol Uses Nose Tests
description: FALFURRIAS, Tex., July 18 After finding marijuana in a car at a checkpoint, Border Patrolmen frequently testify in court that they smelled pot before searching the vehicle, an assertion that defense lawyers have come to call probable smell.

title: KILLINGS IN FLORIDA OVER DRUGS ON RISE
description: MIAMI, July 21  One afternoon 10 weeks ago, a delivery van, bearing the inscription Happy Time Party Supply, drove to the crowded Dadeland Shopping Mall here. Two bearded men, apparently.

description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas, July 21 In an emergency Coast Guard command center on the sixth floor of a downtown office building here, all eyes are turned south.

description: To the Business Editor:

title: ANTIQUES
description: ESSEX UNTIL a few weeks ago, whenever a prospective visitor considered attending an antiques show, the first question asked was, What kind is ita country show, a formal show, a pretty show? Today, of course, that question is superseded by the inquiry, Will I be able to buy gas to get home?

title: At $300, a Thoroughly Respectable Investment
description: LONDON GOLD. The word used to evoke all kinds of negative images in the American mind.

description: PATERSON, NJ., July 21  A New Jersey bank executive repeatedly appealed today for instructions on how to deliver a $300,000 ransom in the kidnapping of his wife and to plead for her release unharmed.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: IN 1979, a young anthropologist began a year living in an impoverished Neapolitan neighborhood called Fontana del Re. Thomas Bejmonte got to know the young men who drift by day and steal by night; he spent evenings with families of overworked husbands and wives jammed into squalid apartments with too many children. He watched people steal from their best friends in a world where almost no deed, however foul, justified the summoning of the despised police.

title: Barbers Hang Loose to Survive
description: ALFREDO PALIANI has been getting into people's hair for 50 of his 59 years, and most of them consider him a friend, confidant and master barber.

description: Diana Margaret Welsh, an art director with Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc., and Noel Vietor, a sculptor, plan tobe married Aug. 18.

title: THEATER Bottom's Up at Drew
description: MADISON ODAY, when Shakespearean productions are no longer ruled by the theories of Jan Kott, we are not compelled to see the playwright as an existentialist, an absurdist or, for that matter, as a contemporary in tune with our random doctrines. If we imbue Shakespeare with the freshness he warrants, we insure his continuing life.

title: Headliners
description: Guilty, not guilty, guilty. The metaphysical question is, when Marvin Mandel is not guilty, where does the guilt go? No matter, it's back again. Last week the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit reinstated the former Governor of Maryland's conviction for racketeering and mail fraud, overturning a 2to1 ruling by a threejudge panel of the same court last January. The reinstatement was based on a 3to3 vote of the court  one member abstained  which, according to Assistant United States'Attorney Daniel J. Hurson, has the effect of automatically defeating the threejudge panel's earlier finding.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: CONNECTICUT received more dollars in defense contracts on a percapita basis than any other state in New England last year, according to a statistical repprt compiled by the New England tongressional Caucus.

description: Gerry Driscoll arrived in Newport, R.I., last week with a duffle bag full of dreams. It was almost like old times, with Rod. Stephens up in the rigging, beginning the long process of finetuning a 12Meter yacht.

description: WASHINGTON, July 21  Garry Davis, the erstwhile world citizen who renounced his American citizenship in 1998 to dramatize his belief in world government, is finally trying to come home.

title: The Oil Stain in Academe
description: Arab oil money, like every other kind, talks  and in the accent of its donors. The sound of that money talking can be heard on Wall Street and even along Pennsylvania Avenue. Now it echoes through the halls of academe. American educational institutions that accept funds from the Arab trade, or Arab nations, for the study of Arab affairs are being directed, or expected, to demonstrate a decent respect for the politics and prejudices of their benefactors.

description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The United States should help China achieve its goals in economic and social development but should treat Peking and Moscow evenhandedly and work to enhance the political stability of Taiwan, a report by a United Nations Association panel said today.

title: A Big Collector
description: THE subtitle of this book makes me wince given the subject, I would prefer something more in the American grain, a simple Tom Swiftlike handle such as Joe Hirshhorn and His Big Collection. Yet the Medici comparison is not all that inapt. Both Joseph Hirshhorn and the Florentine dynasty began in obscurity and, as the author points out, he and they made a good deal of money from money, not always in lovable ways.

title: Air Travel Reported Up Over' 78
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Traffic on United States airlines increased 15.4 percent in the first half of 1979, and air travel in June was up 12.4 percent over a year ago, according to the Air Traffic Association. Planes flew with 64.5 percent of their seats filled in the first six months this year, as against 60.5 percent in the first half of 1978, the association said Wednesday.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE BEST OF SHOLOM ALEICHEM, edited by Irving Howe and Ruth R. Wisse. (New Republic Books, $12.50.) Twentytwo pieces by a writer whose humor derives from his understanding of the madness that lies beneath the apparent order of the universe.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WASHINGTON  The Commerce Department's, report that the gross national product, the sum of all business activity, dropped in the second quarter at an annual rate of 3.3 percent, the largest decline since the depths of the 197475 recession, has directed the attention of policy makers and politicians toward unemployment, which economists expect to climb rapidly this summer and autumn.

description: CRETE, Ill., July 21 (AP)  A fire that raged through a horse barn killed 22 horses last night at the Balmoral Race Track in this suburb south of Chicago, authorities said. Arson was suspected.

title: He Managed His Job With Gusto and Zeal  and Probably Too Much of Both

He holds season tickets to Washington Redskins football games, eats lunch on Saturdays at Duke Zeibert's and has brunch on Sundays at Doc Dalinsky's drugstore. He is on a firstname basis with every important Congressman, lawyer and columnist in the city and spent eight years in private law practice between the Johnson and Carter Administrations earning a fortune pulling strings in the capital for corporate clients.

title: U.S. Opens Its Sports Festival on Friday
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 21 (UPI)  The National Sports Festival, the United States Olympic Committee's ambitious, midsummer competition featuring 2,300 of America's top young athletes, opens here Friday.

title: Baghdad Has the Arms, Wealth and Size to Aggressively Pursue the Goal
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Amid the jostling that accompanied the resignation last week of President Ahmed Hassan alBakr of Iraq, another prominent Iraqi also fell from power. Abel Hussein Mashhadi was expelled from the ruling Baath Party and the top Government body, the Revolutionary Command Council. He is a member of the Shiite Moslem sect that is a majority in Iraq but lacks commensurate political power. More ominously, Mr. Mashhadi was said to have had dealings with Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Shiite leader of Iraq's troubled and troublesome neighbor, Iran.

title: An Ordinary Wild Flower Has an Uncommon Charm
description: The common milkweed, despite its ordinary name, has much to commend it. Common because it is the most free. quently encountered member of the Milkweed Family, this wildling crops up almost everywhere in unmown sidewalk patches or behind anchor fences of town dumps. While waiting in gas lines, I have seen milkweed growing in little patches on the fringes of gasstations. Many tend to ignore the plant, but I feel it deserves to be appreciated.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Anyone visiting a London record shop this summer can scarcely fail to be impressed by the numerous disks on display devoted to the art of Sir Thomas Beecham. This year marks the conductor's centenary, and the British are marking the occasion in a big way much of the musicloving public in England still considers him the greatest performing musician the country has ever produced.

title: ANEW BLACK THEATER
description: In 1816 a black man, known to history only as Mr. Brown, rented a house on the north side of Thomas Street in lower Manhattan and offered Sunday entertainments for the colored populace. Within five years he had prospered so well that he built a theater at the corner of Mercer and Bleecker Streets on a site called The African Grove. This was much farther uptown, in what later became known as Greenwich Village which was by then, New York's chief black neighborhood. The theater held between 300 and 400 seats and was usually packed on the weekends. And what sort of entertainments did Mr. Brown put on? Well, there was an occasional vaudeville (that is, any play of a light or satiric nature) as well as antislavery classics of the 17th and 18th centuries, such as Oroonoko and Pizarro. But The African Grove's primary attraction  indeed, what made the theater famous  was its productions of Shakespeare, notably Richard III

Its sponsors say some of the aerial bombs will ascend 1,500 feet and burst into chrysanthemum shapes 1,000 feet in diameter.

title: The Many Ways Of Buying Gold
description: Whatever the reasons people buy gold  for investment, speculation or just to wear  New York has become the world's biggest market for the metal In recent years. And the market only really began a short time ago, on Dec. 31, 1974, when Washington lifted a fourdecadeold ban on public ownership of gold bullion.

title: Energy Corp: How It Looks
description: WASHINGTON  One week ago, President Carter's war against dependence on foreign sources of oil escalated from a mere moral equivalent to what he described as a fullfledged offensive. While details of his general strategy may still be uncertain, and the identity of the nation's enemy ambiguous, what was clear is that President Carter has proposed a most unusual flagship to lead the campaign.

title: The World

title: Nguyen Luong Bang, 75; Vietnam Vice President
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 21 (AP) Vice President Nguyen Luong Bang of Vietnam died in Hanoi at the age of 75 after a long illness, the Vietnamese radio announced today.

title: Capital Report
description: TRENTON SEVEN months ago, with considerable fanfare, the State of New Jersey submitted a new plan for airpollution control to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Political PreSsures Damage Independence of UN. Staff
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 21 The United Nations international staff, conceived in the organization's days of heady idealism as a highcaliber civil service insulated from national politics, finds itself 34 years later with its independence threatened and its image tarnished.

title: Versailles And SALT
description: Sixty year ago this month, in July 1919, the Senate began to debate a treaty of overwhelming international importance.
