Ratification or rejection of the treaty would have vast significance for future peace: It was the eve of a Presidential election year, and a sitting President's prestige was on the line. To the treaty in question the President had .given his best efforts, his skills as a negotiator, his Christian ideals. It was a compromise hammered out with bitter antagonists, and was the best he believed he could get.

title: The Life and Times of Reggae
description: In 1973, an album entitled Burning was released in the United States by a Jamaican band called Bob Marley and the Wailers, the leading purveyors of a loping, hypnotic blend of calypso, soul, rhythmandblues, rock, Latin and indigenous Jamaican rhythms, termed reggae. As with the group's preceding Catch a Fire (1972), the music was angry and ominous, full of apocalyptic visions and the quirky beliefs of the Rastafarian religion, whose devotees worship the late Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia as a diety.

title: Jersey and WhiteCollar Workers Reach Tentative 2Year Contract
description: TRENTON, July 21 (UPI)  Union and state negotiators agreed today to a tentative twoyear contract covering 32,000 whitecollar workers that was little changed from a proposal rejected during a fourday strike two weeks ago.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE New York City subway system is often singled out for its dirty cars and stations by Long Islanders. But some of the grimiest subway cars are still not as dirty as many Long Island Rail Road cars.

title: Tag Is Telling Othello: Don't Think About Elephants
description: The actors were not quite walking through their parts; they were beyond that, and Othello was emerging in bits and pieces. The play, which will open in Central Park on Friday, was being put together with a sword thrust here, a speech inflection there, and a kind of mutual exploration. The actors were learning; the director was pondering, and in rehearsal there was the possibility of all things. Now don't worry, Wilford Leach, the director, would tell the actors. We'll just do this to see if you know your lines. Mr. Leach was like a benevolent, but somewhat abstracted, counselor at summer camp, and since he was tall and wore a floppy hat, he looked like one, too. You expected an actor to call him Uncle Wilf.

title: DINING OUT
description: WESTPORT VIVA ZAPATA has evolved slowly in the 10 years it has been open, even as public taste perhaps has changed. When the restaurant opened, its greatest link with Mexico seemed to be its name and the pleasant informal alfresco style of dining that is so popular south of the border.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Since this year is the 80th anniversary of the late Duke Ellington's birth, the Lincoln Center Library and Museum of the Performing Arts has turned over its major exhibition space to A Celebration of Duke Ellington, with material never publicly displayed before. The centerpiece of the exhibit is the Duke's sevenfoot blueandgold grand piano, surrounded by original music and book manuscripts, a rough draft of his autobiography and part of the Second Sacred Concert jotted on paper toweling (the Duke was known to scribble his thoughts on whatever was at hand) and other memorabilia. (See Art)

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: WASHINGTON  Once, in the heady days of Apollo, when men were taking those first steps on the moon a decade ago, there were many high hopes for great new space adventures. The next natural step, as Space Agency planners saw it, involved new rocket transportation systems with fleets of reusable spaceships, permanent manned space stations in earth and lunar orbits and a manned flight to Mars, possibly in the 1980's. But last week's celebration the tenth anniversary of the lunar landing took place in a far less optimistic atmosphere.

title: INVESTING
description: With the passage of the $100,000 exclusion as part of the Revenue Act of 1978, taxpayers 55 years of age and older have had an improved opportunity to hold on to more of the profit they may realize from the sale of their houses. The exclusion is available once in a lifetime to taxpayers 55 or older on sales completed after July 26, 1978.

title: Storrs Campus: Banal Isolation
description: JOHN BREASTED'S article [Is Storrs Too Far From Real Life? Opinion Page, June 24] reminded me of things that have been bothering me about the University of Connecticut at Storrs for many years. My feelings about the physical environment as it stands are pretty much coincidental with Mr. Breasted's, but my conclusions differ greatly.

title: An Outing on an Austrian Lake Has an Operatic Finale
description: The most beautiful lake in my world Is the Wolfgangsee in the Salzkammergut of Austria. Its capital is the 100yearold White Horse Inn, which inspired the operetta White Horse Inn, and its shrine is an aweinspiring 500yearold Gothic altar. The season I love best runs from late spring to early autumn  in other words, a long summer  and, while it lasts, I would like to take you there on an outing from Salzburg.

title: IT'S TIME TO STOP AMERICA'S RETREAT
description: There is a rhythm to the ideas of men. Thus, for an extended moment  call it from Tet to the Ayatollah there seemed to be a growing sense that America's experience in Vietnam had repealed many of the old precepts of statecraft.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Northport has a history. And to prove it, the local Historical Society has mounted an exhibition called Generations  Part I, which details the village's development by tracing the roots of seven important local families. With photographs, antique furniture, period clothing, paintings, tools, personal documents and artifacts, the exhibit concentrates on a prominent member of each familyfrom a Revolutionary heroine to a turn-ofthecentury Polish immigrantmerchant  and recreates the last 200 years of life in the area.

title: An Official Scorer Who Has Lived To Tell About It
description: LAST month the editors of Pittsburgh's two daily newspapers, The Press and The PostGazette, withdrew the services of their baseball reporters who doubled as official scorers at Pirate home games. For Bruce Kison, the Pirate righthander who suggested that he had been cheated out of a nohit game by one of the scorers, the executive orders came a few days too late.

title: P.E.N. Ends Congress With Protest to Latins Over Abuse of Writers
description: The 44th International P.E.N. Congress ended last night in Rio de Janeiro after adopting resolutions accusing governments of mistreating writers in many South American countries.

title: Anne D. Post Plans Bridal in September
description: The Rev. Dr. Avery D. Post, national president of the United Church of Christ, and Mrs. Post of Tarrytown, N.Y., and Randolph, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Denison Post, to Robert D. Proudman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry B. Proudman Jr. of Middletown, Conn.

title: 9 of 10 Biggest Oil Spills Have Involved Tankers
description: Nine of the world's 10 largest oil spills have involved tankers, according to the Center for ShortLived Phenomena in Cambridge, Mass., which publishes the Oil Spill Intelligence Report.

title: FOOD; Smoking Out the Barbecuers
description: GREAT NECK SUMMER brings the cook out of doors. The meat is in the marinade and the barbecue is lighted. Recognizing the universal popularity of the outdoor grill, the Great Neck schools this year added an outdoor cooking course to their summer adult program.

title: CAMERA
description: Every profession stages periodic conferences and gatherings that include seminars and exhibits  and photography is no exception. One of the youngest of these photography gatherings is the Visual Communications Congress (VCC), which has held only two annual meetings thus far, yet has turned out to be one of the most stimulating events for photographers and others who are involved with visual communications. Held last month in New York City the 1979 conference attracted thousands of people who jammed the exhibit halls and attended daylong seminars focusing on filmmaking, videotaping, still photography, and slidemaking.

title: Deaths
description: BOSWORTHDavid, MD.The Medical Staff of the former FrenchPolyclinic Hospital records with profound sorrow the passing of Dr. David Bosworth, Long time and well respected staff member and Director/Director Emeritus of the Department of Orthopedics. He will be sorely missed by his colleagues.

title: SHOP TALK Finds in Water Mill
description: WATER MILL UNTIL the Water Mill Markel Square was completed three years go, a shopping trip into this Hamptons village usually consisted of the general store on Main Street, the newsstand and the post office. But now you can spend most of the day browsing the shops that have moved into Market Square, a welldesigned openair minimall.

title: Dr. Vivian T Thayer, Retired Educator, 93; John Dewey Follower
description: Dr. Vivian T. Thayer, who was educational directoi of the Ethical Culture Schools from 1928 to 1948, died Thursday at his home in Winter Haven, Fla. Dr. Thayer, who had retired to Florida, was 93 years old.

title: FloodControl Plan Criticized
description: HACKENSACK ONSITE water detention and retention is the latest program introduced in Bergen County in an effort to solve flooding problems in the southern part of the county.

title: Eckstein Sells Out
description: Something's amiss in the house that Otto Eckstein built. Only a few weeks ago, five senior officers, including vice presidents, Stephen Brown and Alan Cody, both vice presidents, resigned their posts with Data Resources Inc., the highly regarded economic forecasting firm that Mr. Eckstein founded 10 years ago. A few days later, two top economists also quit. And then last week, the former member of President Lyndon B. Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers, bailed out, too  in a sense. He announced he was selling his firm to McGrawHill Inc.

title: Reports From Washington
description: When President Carter unveiled his newest energy package last week, most eyes were on the reassuring pledge that the $142 billion program would cut American oil imports in half, to a modest 4.5 million barrels a day by 1990. What fewer people focused on was that the most massive peacetime commitment of funds and resources in our nation's history, as the President described it, would have substantial economic effects in the next decade.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Poetry is as contagious as poison ivy though less prevalent. Look at the response these days to the dramatic poems in Ntozake Shange's remarkable Spell No. 7. When I went to see the new revised version at the Public Theater the other night, the sketches  lyrical, wry, painful and comically prosaic by turn  lapped over the Anspacher stage and invaded the audience. The place was alive with response, but it wasn't the ordinary applause or laughter of an audience that is pleased or moved. There was a kind of rumination, a repeating of lines, even a few tentative essays at embroidering them.

title: Mets Use Pitching Trio to Stop Padres, 21
description: SAN DIEGO, July 21  The San Diego Padres took note of the wideopen race in the National League's West tonight, called a meeting of 10 senior players to infuse pennant fever into the team and then got only three hits while dropping a 21 decision to the New York Mets.

title: Calendar
description: Friday July 29. Essex antiques show. Town Hall. Take Exit 69 from I95. Friday and Saturday 12 noon to 9 P.M.; Sunday, 12 noon to 5 P.M. 30 exhibitors.

title: Food Coops Ease Rising Costs
description: SOME Scarsdale businessmen use stocks and bonds as their hedge against inflation. Further up county, large landholders bank on real estate. Minna Immerman and her friends in Larchmont use fruits and vegetables.

title: Local Magazine Series Planned by WNBCTV
description: WNBCTV will present Now! a halfhour magazine program, for five Monday evenings starting July 30.

title: France to Canada to Louisiana
description: ADILIGENT jaunt across America would confirm that no other ethnic community dating to pioneer days has remained so close to the early way of doing things as have some of Louisiana's Cajuns. They frog and shrimp and turtle, fish for crawfish, catfish and oysters, and trap the swamps and marshes with all the rigamarole of cousinhood and their own loving language. Of course, nearly million people cannot be so pigeonholed  there are plenty of oil millionaires and realestate developers among them  but William Rushton goes into older, specialized matters such as splitoak baskets, palmettoweaving and finfish gumbo, brown cotton, bousillage, Mardi Gras and accordion music in the French Triangle, which stretches from the wide Gulf shore to an apex at the centralLouisiana city Alexandria.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Author's Query
description: For an annotated list of John Steinbeck's literary reading and personal library holdings, I would appreciate information about books (or individual poems, plays, esays) he owned, borrowed and read.

title: An Exercise in Apologetics
description: HANS KUNG wears the undeserved halo of a heretic too generously bestowed by a suspicious Rome. This slight book, the text of his Terry Lectures at Yale, is an exercise in oldfashioned apologetics, that form of intellectual imperialism that appropriates to religion everything that is worthwhile in the critics of religion. This is a shame, because Freud's challenge to religion is one of the things that has stood up best, as other aspects of his thought date or show that they were culturedetermined.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Audrey Hepburn is the star of Bloodline.

title: Lawyer for Gallo Men Slain
description: A 46yearold lawyer who the police said had defended associates of the late Joseph Gallo, a reputed underworld leader, was found shot to death in a car parked on Manhattan's Upper East Side. The lawyer, Robert Weiswasser of 6 East Eighth Street, had been shot twice in the back of the head, the police said. A police spokesman said the police were investigating as a possible motive reports that the lawyer had outstanding debts to loan sharks.

title: Libraries Tighten Book Security
description: EAST MEADOW BORROWING is on the increase at your public library  and, unfortunately, so is theft. Taking a clue from their appliedscience sections, library officials on the Island are using modern electronics in an attempt to stop what some estimate is a 10 percent pilferage rate.

title: Ching Johnson, Star for Rangers In the 20's and 30's, Is Dead at 81
description: Ching Johnson, a star with the New York Rangers during their first years in the National Hockey League and a member of hockey's Hall of Fame, died June 16 in Silver Spring, Md., at the age of 81.

title: Housing: Change in New Canaan
description: NEW CANAAN EXCEPT for the landscaping and interior work that will be completed over the next few weeks, the rows of garden apartments on a hill off Route 123 in this rurally elegant town are almost finished. In about twd months, the first tenants are to move into the 60 one, two and threebedroom apartments that are contained zigzag groupings of 10 twostory structures with stainedcedar siding, surrounded by trees and overlooking a lake back.

title: Women's Hall of Fame
description: SENECA FALLS, N.Y., July 21 (UPI)  Amid calls for continued advancement toward political and economic equality for women, the Women's Hall of Fame was dedicated here today on the 131st anniversary of the convention that signaled the start of the women'srights movement. The Hall of Fame houses memorabilia of 23 American women honorees, including Elizabeth Cady Stanton, the Seneca Falls resident who called the 1848 convention.

title: Commuters Rail Over Rush Hour
description: THE transportation situation seemed to brighten somewhat for commuters last week, but only in terms of the future. For those packed into rushhour trains often without airconditioning, lights or enough space for comfortable standing - prospects for immediate relief remained dismal.

title: Suit Opposes Credits for Religion
description: A coalition of civic, education and other groups has filed a fawsult in Federal Court in Brooklyn to prevent public high school students from earning credit for religious instruction received in religious schools or institutions.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Thriving Concern May Leave City
description: A thriving manufacturing business in Washington Heights may be forced socin to move to New Jersey for lack of suitable space, taking 120 jobs  and a potential for many moreout of New York City.

title: Concert Audience Evacuated In Lincoln Center Bomb Scare
description: Approximately 2,600 concertgoers were evacuated from Avery Fisher Hall last night after an anonymous caller told police a bomb would go off inside the Lincoln Center building.

title: Bedford Hills Slaying Suspects Sue Prosecutor and Detectives
description: Two men charged with the May 10 murders of four Bedford Hills, N.Y., residents have filed Federal lawsuits accusing the Westchester County District Attorney and three police detectives of violating their civil rights during the investigation of the slayings.

title: Atlantic Beach Seeks Zoning Power
description: ATLANTIC BEACH THIS beachfront village is unique among all 556 villages in New York State, but it is not proud of its distinctiveness and it has been pressing a campaign in the State Legislature to end it.

title: Plan for Women's Panel Stirs Ire
description: HAUPPAUGE WHEN Jane R. Devine, Suffolk County's only woman legislator, made her proposal for a Suffolk County Woman's Advisory Commission, she did not think the idea would stir up controversy. Now, some weeks later, several groups are accusing her of undermining family life, supporting homosexuality, promoting radical feminism and being a political opportunist.

title: When Life Seems Absurd
description: SOMETIMES life seems meaningless. At such moments, says Thomas Nagel, we are experiencing the absurdity of life. Talk absurdity may conjure up the image of existentialists gathered around cafe tables in Paris in the 1950's, but Mr. Nagel's explanation of life's absurdity is far removed from the Left Bank. For Mr. Nagel absurdity cannot be attributed to man's small size and brief existence. Were I to increase to the size of the universe, my life would not be filled with purpose. Nor does absurdity exist because nothing I do now will matter in a million years. For how could I know that nothing I do now will matter in a million years unless I already know that nothing I do matters at all?

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Although Toad Hall has long been leveled and its grounds turned into a garden suburb peopled by ferrets and weasels, country places still bring a good price on the literary real estate market. Country places are not healthy graves. Instead, they are gravely and tediously healthy. In his Stone Book quartet, Alan Garner traces the lives of four generations of a workingclass family in Chorley, a Cheshire village. Sentimental primitivism pervades Mr. Garner's books. His characters are by place possessed, and nostalgia for lost occupations and identities weighs heavy.

title: Eanes, Soares Are Duelists
description: LISBON  Portugal got its first woman Prime Minister last week, Maria de Lourdes Pintassilgo, a Catholic of the left who will serve until parliamentary elections expected in October. Rightist politicians immediately charged that the 49yearold ambassador to UNESCO would give their Socialist and Communist rivals an edge. But, as the novelty of a woman caretaker Prime Minister began to wear off, the Portuguese were left with a deep institutional crisis that elections may not resolve.

title: Pat Meyers Takes Lead By a Shot
description: LUTHERVILLE, Md., July 21 (UPI)  Pat Meyers carded a fourunderpar 69 today and took a onestroke lead after the second round of the $75,000 Greater Baltimore golf classic.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: LIKE many homeowners I live in a house built long before the days of energy conservation and a fuel crisis. It was put up 25 years ago, in the heyday of cheap oil and minimal concern for insulation or siting for maximum exposure to the warmth of the sun and protection from the elements.

title: Finding a Home After Divorce
description: DIVORCE is rarely simple, but one of its more unexpected problems is the very basic question of where to live afterward. For divorced women, particularly those with young children, or those in their 60's, for whom alimony or child support (or both) may be the only source of income, the housing picture is especially bleak.

title: Donors Aid the Fresh Air Fund With Cash and Ballpark Tickets
description: A New York executive, a thirdgrade class from Brooklyn and a group of naval reservists have all donated something to help needy innercity children through the Fresh Air Fund.

title: Some Facts on Basic Filters for Camera Buffs
description: There are so many types of photographic filters available that an imprudent enthusiast could easily become weighted down with them. Here are the essential ones.

title: No Free Lunch Seen In Synthetic Fuels
description: WASHINGTON THE syntheticfuel bandwagon is rolling full speed here, with the vocal and energetic backing of many New Jersey Congressmen. But some private groups and Government agencies are warning that synthetic fuels may cause serious publichealth and environmental side effects.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: BROOKVILLE  Works on Paper, photography, photographyinfluenced paintings; noon to 5 P.M. weekdays; 2 to 5 P.M. weekends; through July 30; Hutchins Gallery, C. W. Post Center.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: For C. P. Snow, it must seem as though he has come full circle. His first book, published in 1932, was a murder mystery, Death Under Sail. This October. almost halt a century later, Charles Scribner's Sons will be publishing A Coat of Varnish, a novel again centering on a homicide.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: NORTHPORT GIVE me a B1 began a sideline cheer from some American teenagers heard amid this endless soccer summer. And the demanded letters of the team name went on until: Give me an 0 with a slash in it!

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Elizabeth Sadowski, in her article opposing passage of the Equal Rights Amendment [Opinion Page, July 8] makes the case for masculinists rather than feminists. The traditional childbearing role under the patriarchal system has limited the lives of women in all societies, primitive as well as contemporary.

title: Settlement Is Reached In Carey Bus Dispute
description: A tentative agreement to end a 23day teamsters' strike that has halted Carey Transporation Company bus service between Manhattan and the city's major airports was expected to be ratified today, clearing the way for a resumption of service at 5 A.M. tomorrow.

title: The World
description: To complain about SALT II, a Senate committee witness wisecracked last week, is to look a small gift horse in the teeth. In Foreign Relations Committee hearings, both liberal and conservative critics attacked the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty's gifts as niggardly.

title: ART
description: GALLERIES in beautiful areas have to vie with the setting for attention. The public, given a choice, generally prefers nature to art, especially in fine weather.

title: Indian Claims BOlstered in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Me., July 21 (AP)  Rulings this month in separate cases involving fires have touched off new doubts about Maine's ability to defend itself against Indian claims to more than half the state's territory.

title: Bring On the Troubadours
description: A BRUNNHILDE Gargantua! A monolith torso tied into waistlines! declared my brother, Finbar, on first sighting the health science building at the State University's Stony Brook campus. Finbar is an expatriate who has lived in Rome, Paris, London and even Shiraz in the good old preAyatollah days of art festivals and easy access. Now his dwelling is in Rome for the most part, where he writes art, opera and ballet reviews for assorted publications, and is celebrated in small select circles for his uncompromising stand and pithy insight.

title: Loss of Cousineau to Montreal Slows Bills' Rebuilding Plans
description: Tom Cousineau's defection from the National Football League to the Canadian Football League last week was more of an individual blow to the defensive unit of the Buffalo Bills than to the dignity and prestige of pro football within the United States. Cousineau, the Ohio State linebacker from Cleveland who was the N.F.L.'s first draft pick this year, chose the Montreal Alouettes over the Bills for economic considerations chiefly and also because the Buffalo management failed to fawn over the athlete and his attorneyagent, Jimmy Walsh.

title: Form of Meningitis Found Contagious, but Antibiotics Can Limit
description: Contrary to previous scientific belief, the most common form of bacterial meningitis is contagious and warrants precautionary doses of antibiotics in susceptible children, according to a study reported last week.

title: ART
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE Central Hall Gallery is offering a group show through next Sunday that features a sampling of the latest works by the cooperative's 23 women artists. It provides a chance to assess the achievements of the membership as group and to judge if the gallery is indeed fulfilling its promise to present wide range of creative expression.

title: POLITICS
description: THE action by members of President Carter's Cabinet in tendering their resignations last week was a grand gesture, but it shows how far our political leaders have slipped.

title: A Vast Range of Special Claims Has Helped Stymie Leadership
description: In his address to the nation on energy last Sunday night, President Carter spoke repeatedly of crisis of confidence in the United States. The phrase seemed to have struck a responsive chord among many Americans who feel there is something fundamentally wrong in the body volitic.

title: Hong Kong Merchant Contends Trade Aides In Canton Seek Bribes
description: HONG KONG, July 21  I won't do this again, said a local businessman who has recently visited Canton to conclude a deal. When I do business in Hong Kong, I don't even have to pay that much commission.

title: CETA Helps Them Work at Their Art
description: It was the most exciting performance we've ever given, Rachel Lampert exclaims about her modern dance company's CETAsponsored appearance last year at Arthur Kill Correctional Facility on Staten Island. There were 600 men in the gymnasium. The most dangerous criminals were placed in the front row. But we danced better than we'd ever danced before.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: REMOVING an old fence post or gate post that has been in place for years is often a frustrating and backbreaking job. Regardless of whether the post is being taken out because it has started to work loose, has started to rot or is badly cracked and split and thus needs replacing, once the attempt is made to get it out the post seems to be reluctant to let go its grip in the soil. The problem is even more difficult when the post has been set in concrete.

title: Letters TO THE EDITOR
description: My initial reaction to your Ted Kennedy articles (The Kennedy Mystique, June 17 and Kennedy: Time of Decision, June 24) was: Will yet another takeoff on an all too hackneyed topic really prove enlightening? Anne Taylor Fleming answered that question most emphatically. Her incisive analysis, sprinkled with telling anecdotes, presented readers with an unusually accurate reflection of the interplay between the political and personal issues affecting the senior Senator from Massachusetts.

title: Wider Copter Noise Rules Asked
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  Helicopters would be required for the first time to comply with noise standards imposed on other civilian aircraft under a rule proposed this week by the Federal Aviation Administration of the Transportation Department. The proposal would initially apply only to newly certified helicopters and would later extend.to all new helicopters.

title: SheepRelated Death Reported
description: ATLANTA, July 21 (AP)  The National Center for Disease Control has reported one death among at least 11 confirmed and 30 apparent cases of Q fever, an influenzalike illness that occurred among employees working with sheep used for reseach at the University of California at San Francisco early this year.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: The Seattle Mariners are at Yankee Stadium this afternoon at 2 and tomorrow night at 8. California comes in for games Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 P.M. and Thursday at 2 P.M.

title: New Light on First Governor
description: AMAJOR discovery of Revolutionary War documents has cast new light on the leadership role of New Jersey's first elected Governor, according to Carl E. Prince, chairman of New York University's history department and editor of The Papers of William Livingston.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: A WOMAN OF INDEPENDENT MEANS, by Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey. (Avon, $2.50.) The 80 years of Bess Stead Garner, an enthusiastic, stubborn Texan who engineered her own courtship and marriage, her rapid social climb and her husband's business success, reported entirely through her letters to relatives, friends and employees. Our reviewer, Anne Tyler, found her story so credible that she became more concerned with appraising the heroine than the novel.

title: Stroke Victim Wins $2.5 Million From Maker of Contraceptive Pill
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., July 21 (UPI)  A woman who asserts that a birth control pill caused her to suffer a stroke and paralysis has won $2.5 million in damages from the manufacturer.

title: Local Wines More Than a Flight of Fancy
description: NORTH SALEM AVINEYARD in Westchester is for the birds. At least that's what the birds seem to think. The only vineyard of any note in the county, here in North Salem, is owned and operated by Dr. George W. Naumburg Jr., who, over the years, has become accustomed to sharing his grapes with feathered intruders. Recently, they have begun to share with him. In fact, they .have left so many grapes for him these last couple of years that he is about to open his own winery, the first in the county's recent history so far as anyone can determine.

title: SPORTS
description: WESTPORT THE 5:02 express from Grand Central rolls into the Westport station at 5:58 P.M. Businessmen, perspiring in their city clothes, pour out of the train, thankful for a breath of Connecticut air. Carrying their attach cases in one hand and their jackets in the other, they pile into their cars, kiss their wives and roar off to their homes. In five minutes, they're all gone, and the station resumes its summertime torpor.

title: Food
description: The food of the Basque country of France is not nearly as well known to the average traveler as, say, that of Paris and Marseilles. And yet some of that nation's most tempting foods come from the Basque region. The food, naturally, has a bit of the Spanish flavor because of the proximity to the Basque area of Spain. The gastronomic capital of the Basque territory in France is Bayonne, and jambon or ham of Bayonne is universally admired as one of the great treasures of the French table.

title: Caroline Chambers To Be Wed Sept. 22
description: The engagement of Caroline Dolbeer Chambers to Gerald Thomas Mulligan, Massachusetts Commissioner of Banks, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. H. Wick Chambers of New Haven, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Mulligan of Boston.

title: Auto Talks: A Breather for Chrysler
description: When laborcontract time rolls around in the auto industry, the United Auto Workers union forces the three major companies to play Detroit roulette by pointing a strike threat at each one. Last week, though, as talks got under way, the Chrysler Corporation received an unexpected exemption from the war of nerves at the bargaining table. Douglas Fraser, the union president, said Chrysler had enough problems without the added uncertainty of labor disruption.

title: Yanks Beat A's, 124
description: What does it take to make the Yankees smile and relax? They scored 10 runs in one inning yesterday at Yankee Stadium and routed the Oakland A's, 129. An OldTimers' Day crowd of 50,084 watched Ron Guidry win his seventh game, Willie Randolph hit his first grand slam and Reggie Jackson wallop a threerun homer, his 18th.

title: MUSIC
description: WHEN the Torrington Arts Festival gets under way a week from today, it will herald a remarkable convocation of performing talents: opera singers, ballet dancers, vaudeville hoofers, jazz and symphonic musicians, actors and even a barbershop chorus.

title: The Region
description: For sheer enjoyment, most commuting in the region ranks right up there with sunburn. Now, if a new bureaucracy in Trenton lives up to official expectations and Washington keeps the cash coming, the plight of the commuter could improve in New Jersey. Governor Byrne quickly signed a bill passed last week that sets up a transportation authority empowered to buy and operate bus lines and passenger railroads. With obvious belief that an existing $55 million state subsidy was producing guaranteed profits for private bus company executives but precious few comforts for passengers, officials began at once to take over the largest bus company, Transport of New Jersey, whose 1,600 buses haul nearly half the state's

title: Albany Gets U.S. Funds For FuelSavings Project
description: New York State has received the first funds in a projected $50 million Federal grant to begin a threeyear energyconservation effort in public and nonprofit buildings. State officials say the program will save as much as three million barrels of oil a year.

title: New Ways Sought to Pay for Sewer District
description: ISLIP THE Southwest Sewer District project, proposed more than a decade ago as the first step in a countywide publichealth project, continues to soar in cost, from $291 million approved by taxpayers in a referendum to $928 million today, including interest.

title: Woodstock: A Hip Country Town
description: A decade later, the mystique lingers; the name still draws. Even now, superannuated hippies and flower children, Rolfers, rockers and runaways, bikers, downandout skidders, artists, curiosityseekers and daytrippers still find some need to make their way to the Ulster County, N.Y., village and art colony that gave its name to a generation.

title: REACTOR'S DESIGNER ASSAILED ON SAFETY
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  The head of a Presidential commission investigating the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island has indicated that he is not satisfied by the excuses offered by the company that designed the crippled reactor.

title: Russian Who Fixed U.S. B17 Is Thanked, Finally
description: MOSCOW, July 21  A Soviet airplane technician whose Moscow ground crew repaired the wing of an American B17 Flying Fortress got thanked this week, 38 years later.

title: Martin's Power
description: The departure of Al Rosen from the Yankees means that Billy Martin now possesses the power he has always coveted  virtual command as general manager as well as dugout manager. Billy Martin has to answer only to George Steinbrenner, the principal owner. But the question is: will Billy Martin use that power wisely or abuse it selfdestructively? The lesson is there for Billy Martin to learn. George Steinbrenner runs the Yankees, nobody else. Al Rosen did not run the Yankees and neither did Gabe Paul, his predecessor as president. And if Billy Martin ever starts thinking that he is running the Yankees, especially if they don't climb into contention in the American League East, that's when George Steinbrenner will let Billy Martin know that he's no longer needed.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: It was delivered to the switchboard at Bayonne Hospital in New Jersey, as gifts from grateful patients to nurses sometimes were. This package, addressed to the head nurse on the third floor, exploded when opened last Feb. 5. Safety lenses on the head nurse's eyeglasses saved her eyes. Four nurses, in all, were cut and burned.

title: The Origin of the Origin of Species
description: IF Loren Eiseley was right: Charles Darwin's contribution to making the theory of evolution was to put in place the final piece in a vast intellectual jigsaw puzzle; that piece was an idea he took from someone else, the obscure Edward Blyth; Darwin knowingly used this idea and deliberately concealed his indebtedness to Blyth; Charles Darwin was a deceitful plagiarist and Edward Blyth was his victim. If.

title: ANTIQUES
description: OLDWICK THINKING of staying closer to home this summer? Maybe you can rediscover New Jersey. On far less than a tankful of gasoline, families can combine tours of parks and historic areas with antiquing, dinner and an overnight stay in a motel in sections away from the bustle of more heavily populated areas.

title: Births
description: SARN

title: Westchester's Representatives Review President Carter's Energy Proposals
description: LAST SUNDAY, Jimmy Carter came out swinging at the energy crisis. It would be most unusual, in any fight, to have all your blows strike home. The President; in his talk, was no exception.

title: Dispute Cuts Off Parkland
description: A Governmental tugofwar has blocked the only direct roadway from Interstate 80 into thousands of parkland acres at Worthington State Forest and the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area in North Jersey.

title: After the Mountain, Carter Encounters Valley of Doubters
description: Washington had just begun to digest Jimmy Carter's sixcourse energy program last week when there came great clanging and banging from the kitchen, followed by an important management announcement: The entire staff was suddenly put on notice, and from now on, everyone would answer to the proprietor's trusted lieutenant, Hamilton Jordan.

title: Learning How to Preserve History
description: LAMONT GREEN, an apprentice at the National Trust Restoration Workshop, is a young man of definite convictions. He is against television, against nuclear power and is profamily. And he is convinced that his work at the workshop is important.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE State Department of Transportation is trying to devise a plan to save rail freight service in Hudson, Bergen and Passaic Counties now that a Federal judge has ordered the liquidation of the bankrupt New York, Susquehanna, and Western Railroad, the only localized carrier in the three counties.

title: In Defense of Residential Colleges
description: STORRS IWOULD like to comment upon the article by John Breasted [Is Storrs Too Far From Real Life?, June 24] regarding destruction at the University of Connecticut.

title: In London, Plays On Adultery Take A Cynical Turn
description: LONDON The London theater is a vivarium full of unhappy people, to borrow a phrase from James Saunders's Bodies (at the Ambassadors Theater), one of the most stimulating new plays of the current season. A vivarium is defined as a place artificially prepared for keeping animals in their natural state. The animals in this case are modern, married and mutually adulterous couples. Naivete and innocence have been replaced by cynicism and selfgratification. She knew that I knew she knew is an observation that echoes through Bodies, Simon Gray's Close of Play and Harold Pinter's Betrayal (both in repertory at the National Theater). Plays about adultery are never out of fashion, as we can see when the subject is raised in works as diverse as Mikhail Bulgakov's The White Guard at the Royal Shakespeare Company and Tom Stoppard's adaptation. of Arthur Schnitzler's Undiscovered Country at the National. In this season's crop of plays on the subject, the infringement of the marital bond is made by best friends and close relatives. The questions most often discussed on the London stage are those of deceit and betrayal.

title: Hirsch Best Larchmont Skipper
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 Dave Hirsch of Stratford, Conn., competing in his first Larchmont Race Week, sailed for hbme this evening with the event's major prize, the Cullen Memorial Trophy, awarded to the skipper with the week's best record.

title: Apiarists Expect A Honey of a Crop
description: IF Connecticut is not a land flowing with milk and honey, blame the cows. More than a billion bees, divided among the 8,000 hives that the United States Department of Agriculture lists for the state, are producing the natural golden sweet in plenty.

title: Bonnie Butcher to Marry in Fall
description: Willard Carlisle Butcher, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and Mrs. Butcher of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mr. Butcher's daughter, Helen Catherine Butcher, to John Stebbins Bennet of Hadlyme, Conn., son of Douglas Joseph Bennet of Lyme, Conn., and the late Phoebe Benedict Bennet.

title: Who Will Make Giants Among Rookies?
description: It takes at least three years to evaluate properly a National Football League club's draft. Fewer than three months after the Giants startled their fans by choosing Phil Simms in the first round, it is time for a progress report on the overall draft. A complete evaluation will come later.

title: CHESS
description: How does a tactician go about winning a game? It is impossible for him to ignore longrange plans, for his play would lack overall direction, but he is likely to search out tactical solutions to strategic problems.

title: Paul Bransom, Illustrator, Dies; Called Dean of Animal Artists
description: Paul Bransom, called the Dean of American Animal Artists, died Thursday in Quakertown, Pa., where he had been visiting. He would have been 94 years old next week.

title: Antitrust: I.B.M. Goes After the Judge
description: After four years of balky, if not tedious, legal manuevering in an antitrust case involving millions of pages of documents and the testimony of hundreds of witnesses, the International Business Machines Corporation droppped a bombshell in court last week, by requesting that the presiding judge disqualify himself because of a personal bias and prejudice against the company and for the Government.

title: Deaths
description: TOMESElizabeth W. on July 19, 1979. Beloved wife of the late Alexander M. Tomes, devoted mother of Elizabeth H. Tomes and Alexander H. Tomes Jr. Burial service later at convenience of family. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Tuxedo Memorial Hospital, Tuxedo Volunteer Ambulance or other charities at Tuxedo, Friends of Her. yard Baseball or other sports at Harvard.

title: The Nation
description: Last week's economic news might have led President Carter to reflect that while Cabinet members may be suddenly switched, economies can't. If any doubts lingered that a recession had begun, the Commerce Department report on the gross national product in April, May and June erased them, and did more besides.

title: Belden and Dietz Capture Double Sculls Trial Final
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 21  Bill Belden and Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club led from start to finish today in winning the United States final in trials for the world heavyweight double sculls championship.

title: Fast Tracking Gets Buildings Up and Revenues In
description: To most people it probably seems normal that a building the size of Citicorp Center in midtown Manhattan should take three and a half years to build. What may be astonishing, however, is that there is a building going up in Atlantic City now that, while somewhat smaller in square footage, is scheduled to be finished in just one year.

title: ARTFUL THIEVES
description: The hour is 6 A.M. and the sun has not yet broken through a chilly London mist. The New Caledonian Market in Bermondsey Square, Southwark, has been active for hours, for today is Friday, Market Day. Hundreds of an tique aficionados  visiting foreigners as well as dealers from Bond Street or Portobello Road  have assembled here. Among them, too, are six plainclothes men from New Scotland Yard.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Amendment to provide for a state emergency plan for responding to nuclear accidents, passed, 64 to 19, July 16.

title: Guidry Gropes for Answers to Setbacks
description: RON.GUIDRY sat in front of his locker on Friday, an off day for him, spitting tobacco juice and tossing envelopes into the same large rubber trash can. In 1978 the slightly built lefthander was the best pitcher in baseball, with a 253 wonlost record, after having been 131 at the AllStar break. At that point this season, his record was 67, and there was some question about how well he'was throwing the ball. There was no question that his fan mail was different.

title: The Executive Route to the Airport
description: Ponder this: Late on a rainy afternoon, a Manhattan couple and their two small children leave for Kennedy Airport to begin a twoweek vacation. They have fowl heavy suitcases, three tennis rackets, scuba diving equipment, a case with two cameras and accessories and a tote bag full of toys.

title: Rx for Health Emergencies Far From Home
description: The smart traveler is the one who counts health protection and planning as important as plane tickets and hotel reservations. Nobody plans to have accidents or illnesses on a trip. They just happen. Health risks are, in most cases, no greater for the traveler than they are for the stayathome: they are about the same. which is risk enough.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: One Liberian tanker can be bad news all by itself: consider the Amoco Cadiz, which fouled the beaches of France last year with 1.3 million barrels of oil, the biggest spill ever. Or the Torrey Canyon off Britain in 1967, or the Argo Merchant near Massachusetts in 1975. Late last week, two supertankers collided off the Caribbean resort island of Tobago, creating a spill that, for a time, threatened to exceed the Amoco Cadiz disaster. In financial terms, it was worse, with Lloyd's of London estimating damages up to $150 million.

title: Cookies Are New Entry On Quick Food Circuit
description: New shops selling nothing but freshly baked chocolate chip cookies, pecanchocolatechip cookies, peanutbutterchocolate chip cookies, and the rest of the cookie repertoire are rapidly opening up in smallspace retail locations.

title: Carter Asserts He Has No Apologies to Make Over Cabinet Changes
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  President Carter told visitors to the White House today that the furor created by his Cabinet reshuffle would quickly pass and that Congress would enact some elements of his energy program before its August recess.

title: Elizabeth Simons Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William A. Hebert Jr. of South Yarmouth, Mass., of the engagement of Mrs. Hebert's daughter, Elizabeth Baldwin Simons, to Michael Anthony Ficalora, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Ficalora of Irvington, N.Y. Miss Simons is a daughter also of Richard L.F. Simons of Springfield, Mass. The future bridegroom is vice president and executive producer of Ficalora Productions Inc., New York, film and tape productions. A September wedding is planned.

title: Spartakiad Begins in Moscow As Prelude to Olympic Games
description: MOSCOW, July 21 The Soviet Spartakiad games, with 2,500 foreign athletes taking part, began today as a test of Moscow's ability to handle the 1980 Olympic Games. American officials said the first signs were encouraging.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: NOW that President Carter has put the nation's energy problems on a war footing, the rest of us can sit back and cast a glum eye over the battlefield, knowing that we have, in fact, been here before.

title: FISHING
description: RISING water temperatures are reshaping ocean fishing along the New Jersey coast. The large schools of bluefish that have been hanging off Atlantic City and Ocean City for the last two months. were expected to start moving northwards.driven away by the water temperature, which has reached 77 degrees.

title: TRUDEAU REAPPEARS AFTER LONG ABSENCE
description: OTTAWA, July 21 Pierre Eliott Trudeau, who was defeated in the election May 22 after 11 years as Prime Minister, roared off to an undisclosed destination in a Mercedes convertible after resigning June 4 and was not heard from again until this week.

title: The Tradein Deal: How It Goes in Housing
description: Last summer, Leo Fagan, a restaurateur, and his wife, Alanna, an artist, had an unexpected opportunity to buy a riverfront home only yards from their restaurant, but they hesitated. They were afraid that their 1820 Colonial farmhouse in Monroe, Conn., might have only a limited appeal among a few oldhouse buffs.

title: Marriages
description: MANOWITZPACHTER Edward Lawrence Manowitz, son of Mr. & Mrs. Robert Manowitz married to Marla Sherry Pachter, daughter of Mr. & Mrs. Joseph Pechter, July 15, 1979, Old Westbury Hebrew Conarega. tion, Old Westbury New York.

title: Concert: Mostly Mozart
description: It can hardly be denied that a ticket to the Mostly Mozart Festival is sometimes a very good deal, at least as far as gross tonnage of music for dollar spent is concerned. Friday night, for instance, the program began at 7 if one availed oneself of the bonus preconcert recital  and ended three hours and 15 minutes later. All for $6.

title: More Gas For State? Not Likely
description: THE longawaited modifications in Federal gasoline allocation and pricing regulations announced last week by the Department of Energy are not likely to result in significantly more gas for New Jersey, according to state and oilindustry officials.

title: Cosmos Beat Fury, 10, as Neeskens Stars
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 21  Johan Neeskens, the tireless midfielder from the Netherlands, led the Cosmos to victory for the second time in four nights tonight.

title: Full Fathoms Five Furnishes a Home
description: BRIELLE UNLIKE most people, George and Myrna Roffman do not go to novelty stores or antiques show for their trinkets, knickknacks or wall hangings.

title: Chiefs Change, but Anger Remains in N.Y. Prisons
description: ALBANY  When problems stop getting difficult, I tend to move on, Thomas A. Coughlin said last week, after Governor Carey nominated him to be the state's new Commissioner of Correctional Services. If that is the case. Mr. Coughlin may have found a permanent home. New York's prisons have long been a source of difficulties  an exploding population of mean and angry prisoners, labor unrest and low morale among guards, racial tensions among and between guards and inmates  each of which waxes and wanes but never seems to disappear.

title: Wine
description: Joe Heitz is showing a visitor through his handsome little winery near Saint Helena, Calif. This is routine stuff and he fields the usual questions while his mind is on other things. Then, out of the corner of his eye, he spots two octagonal steel nuts on the winery floor.

title: Growing Up and Working Out
description: HE experience of reading Ella Leffland's engaging, minutely observed novel of growing up in smalltown America during World War II is like stepping into a Norman Rockwell painting. One catches a glimpse of a longago, homespun idyll  hazy summer afternoons by the creek and afterdinner family gatherings around the radio. The pervasive feeling is of detailed coziness, the resolute unsophistication of what was once known as the American way of life: scrubbed children, nylons, Thanksgiving, crewcuts and pledging allegiance. But more emphatically than Rockwell allowed himself to, Miss Leffland shades the nostalgia of her evocation with dusky, anxious touches  a brother gone off to war, the unwitting cruelty of adolescence  that emphasize the imperiled nature of even this most snug of worlds. dinner family gatherings around the radio. The pervasive feeling is of detailed coziness, the resolute unsophistication of what was once known as the American way of life: scrubbed children, nylons, Thanksgiving, crewcuts and pledging allegiance. But more emphatically than Rockwell allowed himself to, Miss Leffland shades the nostalgia of her evocation with dusky, anxious touches  a brother gone off to war, the unwitting cruelty of adolescence  that emphasize the imperiled nature of even this most snug of worlds.

title: NEW YORK CITY GETS FISCAL REASSURANCE
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  The White House today sought to reassure New York City that this week's ouster of W. Michael Blumenthal as Secretary of the Treasury would not alter the Carter Administration's policies toward the city's finances.

title: Mrs. Gehrig Asks Yanks a Question
description: When Eleanor Gehrig arrived at Yankee Stadium for yesterday's OldTimers Game ceremonies, she said, to no one in particular, Does anyone around here have a permanent job?

title: Yale Hospital Disputes Role Of Regulators
description: NEW HAVEN IN a dispute that could have farreaching effects on hospitals across the nation, the YaleNew Haven Hospital and two regulatory agencies have filed an appeal Superior Court challenging the authority of the Con necticut Commission on Hospitals and Health Care to impose restrictions on new construction at the institution.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: I've read with interest the debate among several readers on whether or not a fulltime Legislature would serve Connecticut better than the current parttime system (five months one year and three months the next). I'm a proponent of the fulltime system for the folloWing reasons:

title: Many Billions of Dollars Lie Asleep in the Deep  But Beware!
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.  In 1970 a United Nations resolution declared that the resources of the deep sea were the common heritage of mankind, not just happy hunting grounds for great powers armed with bigbore technology. Now, after negotiating for nearly six years over security and economic interests beyond price, diplomats sailing the precarious waters of the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea think they may be approaching shore at last.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: REMOVING an old fence post or gate post that has been in place for years is often a frus trating and backbreaking job. Regardless of whether the post is being taken out because it has started to work loose, has started to rot or is badly cracked and split and thus needs replacing, once the attempt is made to get it out the post seems to be reluctant to let go its grip in the soil. The problem is even more difficult when the post has been set in concrete.

title: Design
description: The undone look is to decorating what baseball is to sports: deceptively easygoing and long on nonchalance, with lots of extraneous bits of business contributing immeasurably to its charm. Moreover, this type of decorating exudes a certain sandlot democracy, a sense that anybody can play. And many do, with varying degrees of success, but the ones who do it best are, of course, the pros.

title: State to Get $100 Million For Transit
description: WASHINGTON ONE of the most successful lobbying efforts by the Byrne administration and longtime New Jersey legislators on Capitol Hill apparently will result in the pouring of close to $100 million in Federal funds into Jersey commuterrail projects this year. That is nearly double the amount anticipated until a few days ago. Furthermore, the Carter Administration has given New Jersey a commitment to grant at least as much in 1980 for transportation projects  that is, construction and equipment  as it is giving in 1979.

title: Deaths
description: STEADMANKathleen C. (nee Goss) on July 19,1979, loving wife of the late David, beloved mother of David, Martin, and Sister Kathleen Thomas, dear sister of Mae, Matthew, and Joseph. Also survived by four grandchildren. Funeral from Woodside Memorial Chapel, Inc., 4145 58th St., Monday July 23, 9 AM. Mass of Resurrection, St. Sebastians R.C. Church, 9:45 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today Association of American Motorcycle Road Racers program of 10 eightlap sprint races, at Bridgehampton (L.I.) Race Circuit; I P.M.

title: Tune in Soon for Best of Yesteryear
description: There is a Manhattan museum where the competition to sample the wares has caused a backlog as exasperating to management as it is to visitors who flock there to sit in solitude and contemplate their own electronic nostalgia, nodding to the voices and images that accompanied their growing up.

title: Dr. Patricia Glowa Fiance of Resident
description: Sally Todd Nelson of Montreal and Fair Harbor, Fire Island, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Patricia Todd Glowa, to Dr. Donald O. Kollisch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen T. Kollisch of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Plague Tied to Squirrel Deaths
description: SAN DIEGO, July 21 (AP) A state investigation has confirmed that bubonic plague was elated to widespread squirrel deaths in the Warner Springs area, San Diego County health officials reported yesterday. People in the area have been warned to avoid contact with rodents and their burrows because of the possibility of plague, the authorities said.

title: CHIEF OF CITY BUSES IS REPORTED LEAVING
description: The officer in charge of bus operations for New York City's Transit Authority has reportedly been asked to step down as part of an effort to reorganize and improve the city's masstransportation system.

title: Dance: Alicia Alonso Projects Wraith Giselle
description: What become a legend most? Certainly not the demanding legend demanding leaps and furbelow of Giselle, if you are a legend with some 40 years of dancing behind you. But then any student can do an arabesque penche. All the ingredients of mythmaking were present at the National Ballet of Cuba's performance Friday at the Metropolitan Opera House: a great ballet classic, an audience with long memories and strong lungs, and a great ballerina named Alicia Alonso.

title: Black Leader Criticizes ShakeUp
description: CHICAGO, July 21  The issue of President Carter's leadership appears likely to dominate the National Urban League's 69th annual conference, which starts here tomorrow, as it has in other national, regional and state meetings held by blacks in recent months.

title: ART
description: BROOKFIELD THE Brookfield Craft Center is presenting, through Sept. 11, a show of work by 69 of the nearly 400 specialists who have taught there. It is a beautifully mounted display of weaving, pottery, glass, metal work and so forth, which is catalogued by cards bearing reproductions of the objects and statements by their makers.

title: Running Against Himself
description: It is said that John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson each hoped to run against Barry Goldwater in 1964 and that Richard Nixon relished the idea of taking on George McGovern in 1972; but no Presidential candidate has had the luxury of actually choosing his opponents. Now Jimmy Carter has decided whom he wants to run against: himself.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: ESSEX  Essex Art Assn. show through Saturday, North Main St. Daily 1 to 5. Admission 50 cents. 7678996.

title: U.S. FEARS UNREST IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: WASHINGTON, July 21  On the day that President Anastasio Somoza Debayle resigned and left Nicaragua, Guatemala's Deputy Foreign Minister was kidnapped on the way home from his office.

title: GARDENING
description: OF all the vegetables grown in the garden, the tomato is undoubtedly the most rewarding and the most productive. A single plant of a largefruited variety, supported in an upright position, will produce as many as 10 pounds of fruit while taking up little more than two and a half square feet of space. This makes it an ideal plant where space is limited, and especially when containergrown.

title: Jim Smith Society: Where None Go Incognito
description: ALLENBERRY, Pa., July 21 (AP)  With no need for name tags or introductions, the Jim Smith Society held its 10th annual festival today.

title: Carter's Property Value Increases in Reappraisal
description: AMERICUS, Ga., July 21 (AP)  The assessed value of President Carter's business, fields and home increased substantially in a justcompleted overhaul of Sumter County's property tax digest.

title: He Computed His Way to the Top
description: THE turnaround was obviously an exciting moment for the company, said Raymond P. Kurshan.

title: Correction
description: An article on skyscraper construction in the July 8 issue gave an incorrect age for Carl Morse, chairman of the board of Morse/Diesel construction. He is 73 years old.

title: Notes
description: Sooner or later most travelers find themselves on a quest for a different kind of journey. Perhaps they feel that the annual vacation to New England or Florida is getting to be hohum. Or that the family's weekend outings to the lake have lost their old spark.

title: Currency: Why Blocs Can't Work
description: President Carter had barely finished his call to arms last week when another spate of selling struck the dollar. The world's money markets clearly weren't impressed with the Carter energy plan, but they were sending another message, too. The state of the international monetary system is bad and getting worse.

title: A TrendSetting English Musician
description: The English rock group Brinsley Schwarz disbanded in March 1975, having recorded five albums in a little more than five years without ever advancing beyond their status as cult favorites. Their only American tour was something of a disaster, and in England, despite occasional work that opened for name groups, they were most closely associated with the new pub circuit that emerged around 1972. Their music had become harderedged by the mid1970's, but it was still rooted in American countryrock, heavily influenced by performers like The Band and Neil Young. So, it has been somewhat astonishing to watch various former members of the group and their associates emerge as leaders and trend setters in the English new wave. Probably the only thing Elvis Costello, Graham Parker and the Rumour, Nick Lowe, Dave Edmunds, Ian Gomm, and the ownership of the influential Stiff label have in common is some association with Brinsley Schwarz or spinoffs thereof.

title: Article 7 -- No Title
description: U. S. BASEMENT WATERPROOFING

title: Satisfaction Is Spur For Tennis Seniors
description: Aging tennis players don't just fade away. Despite growing paunches and groaning feet, they value their United States Tennis Association membership cards and keep hitting the tournament trail.

title: Correction
description: The lithograph The White Knight: Dorothy Series which appeared in the June 17th issue is the work of June Wayne.

title: Shorter Takes 10,000
description: DENVER, July 21 (AP)  Frank Shorter, the former Olynipic marathon winner, triumphed in a field of more than 3,500 runners in a 10,000meter race here today. The 31yearold Shorter, who lives in Boulder, Colo., finished in 29 minutes 17 seconds. Bill Rodgers, the Boston Marathon champion, was third. The top woman finisher was Cathy Twomey of Minneapolis with a time of 35:25.

title: Engagements
description: INSELEGLES

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IN ALL the years. I've lived in New Jersey nothing very dramatic or exciting has happened that would bear retelling. After all, Oradell, where I live, is a quiet little town, and there isn't that much happening.

title: Gas Squeeze Affects The Housing Market
description: FEW househunters drive around looking for a home these days unless they are serious about buying. If they come from New York City to Westchester County and to other nearby areas, they often don't drive at all  they take a train and ask the real estate brokers to pick them up at the station.

title: The Whole Truth About Life Insurance
description: Would you put your money in a savings account paying 1.3 percent interest? According to a new Federal Trade Commission report, that's just about what many Americans do in purchasing life insurance. Life insurance companies hold more than $140 billion of the public's savings  roughly the amount held in passbook savings and loan association accounts  and generally pay returns far below the rate available in equally secure investments. The only plausible explanation is that policyholders don't realize how raw a deal they're getting. By the commission's reckoning, and ours, the most sensible solution is tough disclosure rules for life insurance companies.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BEACH HAVEN (Surflight Summer Theater, Engleside Avenue)  Jesus Christ Superstar (through tomorrow). The Unsinkable Molly Brown. Opens Tuesday (through July 30). 8:30 P.M. $5$5.50. (609) 4929477.

title: Who's on First? Why, New Jersey, of Course
description: FROM banks and boardwalks to revolvers and submarines, New Jersey has contributed a long lists of firsts in the nation's and world's history.

title: Indian Miniatures Dazzle the Eye
description: SOUTHAMPTON IF it hadn't been for certain strains of modern art, we might not have been able to appreciate other types of art. One need only think about how Cubism opened our eyes to African, Oceanic and other forms of art. Without abstraction. types of primitive and decorative art might have escaped us. Expressionism, as we know it in the 20th century, with its heavy emotional doses, helped reveal aspects of alien and exotic cultures that no longer seem so alien and exotic.

title: Marriage Announcement 1 -- No Title
description: Peter A. Kearney Fiance Of Joan Mitchell Casey

title: `Deathtrap Casts Murder as Metaphor
description: EAST HAMPTON THE appearance of Deathtrap as a summer theater item is perfectly misleading. It is misleading because Ira Levin's diabolically clever comedy mystery is in its second year on Broad. way, where John Cullum just last week became the third star to assume the lead. So don't expect to see it around the strawhat circuit just yet, though it will surely be a staple some years hence.

title: Fashion
description: People were dressing themselves by draping rectangles of fabric around their bodies long before such words as toga, sarong and sari were born. This inventive mode of dress remains very much in style, especially during the steamy summer months when a leotard and a few large scarfs  with strings attached  can supply the makings of an array of cool dresses.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, July 22 VOLENDAM (HollandAmerica). Lett Bermuda July 20; due at 8 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Ballesteros Wins British Open by 3
description: ST. ANNES, England, July 20  Severiano Ballesteros, a 22yearold Spaniard with the face of an altar boy and the style of a bladeswinging corsair, came from two strokes behind today to win the 108th British Open by three shots.

title: Unrest
description: WHEN E. Leon Higgenbotham, a black man, was a student at Purdue University in 1944, the president of,that institution told him that the law does not require us to let colored students in the dorm.

title: Pop: Night of Aznavour
description: Charles Aznavour gave what amounted to half a concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening at the opening of a series of three performances that will end tonight. Mr. Aznavour was there for the entire evening, but during the first half of his program the. amplifying system buried his singing in a sea of muffling echoes that made it virtually impossible to disentangle anything he sang or said from the ominous reverberations.

title: Peruvian Ruins Older Than the Inca
description: As we drove up the twisting, rutted landslidethreatened road in the Cordillera Blanca of Peru we wondered whether the preIncan ruins of Chavin de Huantar were worth the effort. A cliff face rose several hundred feet on our right; the ground fell away, on our left, 2,000 feet to a patchwork of green fields in the valley below.

title: TV VIEW
description: Leaving the future aside, what can be seen on cable television today? So far, the answer ranges from occasionally very interesting programming to frequently ordinary farevery ordinary. The cable subscriber is afforded access largely to variations on familiar themes more sports, of course; more movies, which are shown uninterrupted and uncut (at least on the pay channels), retaining sex scenes and street language that are inevitably edited for commercial television; some classy foreignproduced series featuring subtitled French films or British documentaries; Congressional hearings; targeted audience series on subjects such as architecture or weight control; the works of experimental video artists; and lots of talking heads  interviewers such as Alison Steele, Barbara English, Don Gray, Effrom Allen and Steve Gruberg (with his lunatic fringe following), discussing everything from the artistic to the sexually kinky. In other words, standard television has been expanded and made slightly

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Thirtytwo nature and environmental activities will be offered Saturday and Sunday, rain or shine, from 8:30 to 5:30 under the supervision of 40 authorities at the 600acre Sharon Audubon Center on Route 4. The 12yearold festival is sponsored annually by the Housatonic Audubon Society of northwest Connecticut and eastern New York, to benefit the educational activities of the Sharon center.

title: HANOI SAID TO AGREE TO ATTEMPT TO HALT EXODUS OF REFUGEES
description: GENEVA, July 21  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations announced today that Vietnamese officials had told him they would try to stop the flow of refugees from Vietnam for an unspecified period.

title: The Reselling Of the DC10
description: The ads, conceived by the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, will begin appearing early next month in major magazines and in newspapers published in 70 American and foreign cities. We're going to reassure people that the DC10 comes from a company skilled in technology and in building an advanced product, said John Bickers, director of advertising for the the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of St. Louis. We'll tell them that the DC10 carries more than 100,000 passengers a day to 160 cities in 88 countries.

title: How Pure Is Pure?
description: The value of objects made of gold, especially jewelry, cannot be determined solely by weight. The purity of the gold used is an essential criterion as well. The purity varies with the amount of alloy, usually silver and copper, blended with the gold to give an object strength and durability.

title: They United to Defeat Somoza and Now Disparate Forces in the New Government Coalition Need a Program
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Anastasio Somoza Debayle was ousted last week because he succeeded in uniting almost all sectors of Nicaragua against him. In the heat war, he even inspired the strangest of bedfellows to join a provisional government of national reconstruction. But can this potpourri of classes and ideologies work in government as it worked in opposition?

title: IN THE NATION Carter's Different Road
description: WASHINGTON  President Carter has rid himself of a political liability in H.E.W. Secretary Joe Califano, but also of one of his most independent and liberal advisers. In demoting Federal Reserve Chairman G. William Miller to replace Treasury Secretary Michael Blumenthal, he.has opened himself to the charge of playing politics with the Fed  whose chairman is supposed to have a 12year term and independence.

title: Jennifer McCartney, Editor, to Be Bride Of Joseph Wright Rumbough 3d Sept. 22
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Ward Bishop McCartney Jr. of Kalamazoo, Mich., of the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Sanford McCartney, to Joseph Wright Rumbough 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rumbough Jr. of Glen Head. L.I.

title: Prose Narratives
description: HAT is a book? Pages, usually with words on them, bound between covers. What makes a book a work of fiction? Some assurance that the events described by the words on the pages (if events are described) didn't actually happen, or not precisely in the way or the order set down, or not to the people (if there are people in the pages) to whom they are supposed to have happened. Often, these days, it seems that all other bets are off  that the short story, for example, has become no more than a short prose narrative that has something wrong with it, to vary slightly Randall Jarrell's definition of the novel.

title: THEATER
description: BOTH the event and the purpose are of major theatrical importance. Next Sunday at 8:30 P.M., Liv Ullmann and John Lithgow will appear at Grace Church, at Main and Church Streets in White Plains. They will perform, On Such a Night as This, an evening of love scenes and sonnets from Shakespeare.

title: Timeless Salesman Stuns in Any Setting
description: DEER PARK WHEN Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman opened on Broadway in 1949, the New York Times theater critic, Brooks Atkinsono pro claimed it a rich and memorable drama . . . a rare event in the theater . . . a suburban epic that may not be intended as poetry but becomes poetry in spite of itself.

title: Many Share Responsibility for Sewer Financing
description: THE Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein, did the unusual when he publicly acknowledged responsibility for the Southwest Sewer District problems. But he has plenty of company to share responsibility for at least the authorization and financing of the huge project.

title: ART VIEW
description: BUFFALO Richard Artschwager's Theme(s) is the title of an exhibition that has just opened at the AlbrightKnox Art Gallery in Buffalo. It is a puzzling form of words when you first see it in big letters outside the gallery, but it establishes from the outset the first fact about Artschwager, which is that he works within a climate of ambiguity.

title: Events Today
description: Bethesda Fountain Art Exhibition: Art, handcrafts and music; 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Bethesda Fountain and plaza walls, center of Central Park at 72d Street.

title: Wife of Rock Musician Arrested in Suicide Case
description: LEWISBORO, N.Y., July 21 (UPI) The commonlaw wife of Keith Richard, guitarist for the Rolling Stones rockmusic group, was arrested on weapons charges yesterday following the apparent suicide of a 17yearold youth in the 12room Westchester County house that she and Mr. Richard share.

title: Just Hit the Ball and Run Like Hell
description: DON'T know anything about Paul Hemphill except what the publicity flier on this book tells me and some bits and pieces of his I have read and liked. Long Gone is his first novel, and I found it so good, so true, so funny, so full of tolerant cynicism about palpable villains, so full of love for people who deserve better than they get and so knowing in its delineation of whatever he chooses to deliheate ... Enough! It is impossible to predict what people will pick up to read  computers or no  but I think Long Gone will be read. Lordy, lordy, it sure ought to be.

title: Creatures Wild and Tame
description: THIS is a provocative work, in which Jack Rudloe considers some of the more difficult questions bearing on man's treatment of wild animals and the nature of the concept of endangerment. Mr. Rudloe juxtaposes the behavior of sea turtles  hawksbills, greens, leatherbacks, ridleys and loggerheads  with that of humans. The efforts of a group of graduate students to fend off marauding raccoons and opportunistic ghost crabs in an attempt to protect turtle eggs on a South Carolina beach seem selfless. Other people, whose attitude toward sea turtles is sharply commercial, are less admirable. In one of the most moving scenes in the book, .Mr. Rudloe confronts a group of Floridapanhandle fishermen who are crassly butchering a 780pound leatherback turtle  an endangered species. Mr. Rudloe rescues the animal's heart and returns it respectfully to the Gulf waters, and then ponders why he didn't turn the fishermen in for committing a Federal crime.

title: PRAGUE RAISES COST OF FUEL AND GOODS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 21Czechoslovakia, acknowledging prob. lems with energy and inflation, today sharply increased prices for a broad range of consumer goods and fuel.

title: Susan Heffner Married To Charles E. Monnier
description: Susan Mary Heffner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Heffner of Cincinnati, was married there yesterday to Charles Edward Monnier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Monnier of Bottmingen, Switzerland. The Rev. Paul Miller performed the ceremony in the Wyoming Presbyterian Church.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: If you've ever seen a fuzzyhaired, darkeyed woman ambling thoughtfully down midManhattan streets murmuring strange names with abstracted intensity, it might very well have been Rona Jaffe working on one of her bestselling novels.

title: All  Shook Up
description: WASHINGTON  It was the week when Jimmy Carter started to save his Presidency, and the week when he started to throw it away again.

title: Joe Sambito's Streak Ends at 40 Innings
description: PITTSBURGH, July 21 (AP)  Bill Robinson and Phil Garner each clouted basesempty home runs in the eighth inning to end the long scoreless streak of Joe Sambito and lift the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 65 victory over the fading Hpuston Astros today.

title: Alydar Retired; Member Is Victor
description: Even with Alydar out of the race and headed for retirement, State Dinner failed at Belmont Park yesterday in his bid to sweep New York's handicap triple.

title: Anglicized American Song
description: Robert Burns said it for us all when he wrote Oh wad some power the giftie gie us/To see oursels as others see us! Since that gift has never been forthcoming, we must gain the desired information as best we can from relections of other peoples' visions.

title: Junta Moves to Feed Nicaraguans And Bids Civilians Surrender Arms
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 21Nicaragua's new Government spent its first full day in power today addressing the emergency needs of an overarmed and underfed population.

title: A Theater Troupe for the Many
description: MONTCLAIR DRAMA is a democratic art, since it is meant not to be read by the few but to be played before the many, wrote George Jean Nathan, and Gerry Fierst of the Whole Theater Company here agrees.

title: He's a Fury on the Airwaves
description: FORT WORTH  The radio commercials often begin with a voice asking: Eddie Chiles, are you still mad? To which Mr. Chiles replies: Yes, I'm still mad! I'm mad about ...   and off goes Mr. Chiles on another tirade.

title: A Dowager Hotel Struggles Back From Bankruptcy
description: BRETTON WOODS, N.H.  When delegates to the International Monetary Conference gathered here 35 years ago last week to set the gold standard at $35 an ounce and stabilize the world's currencies, the hotel in which they signed the treaty had just been sold for $1.5 million. (See article on Page 14.)
