Today, with the price of gold soaring above $300, the Mount Washington Hotel is for sale  at a bargain basement price of about $2.5 million, but only to a buyer who promises to make a major capital investment in one of the proudest dowagers among the nation's resorts.

title: CRIME
description: The third Mongo mystery is here  AN AFFAIR OF SORCERERS by George C. Chesbro (Simon and Schuster, 9.95). Mongo is a dwarf, an excircus headliner, a Ph.D. in criminology, a blackbelt karate man and a private eye. Also a musiclover. As An Affair of Sorcerers opens, Mongowhose real name is Dr. Robert frederickson  is taking timpani lessons and is hoarsely pumpumpumming the main theme of the third movement of Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony. This is quite a trick, especially since the main theme has no pumpum at all. Indted, the timpani are largely absent in this movement until the coda. musiclover. As An Affair of Sorcerers opens, Mongowhose real name is Dr. Robert frederickson  is taking timpani lessons and is hoarsely pumpumpumming the main theme of the third movement of Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony. This is quite a trick, especially since the main theme has no pumpum at all. Indted, the timpani are largely absent in this movement until the coda.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Purity, elegance, eloquence, verve, clarity, precision and perfection. These are the words to which one has consistently returned when writing about Helgi Tomasson's dancing for more than a decade. He is, quite simply, one of the few male classical dancers in ballet who could be termed truly great  a fact brought into relief again in the particularly brilliant season he has had with the New York City Ballet this spring and summer.

title: POPE TO VISIT U.S. AND IRELAND IN FALL
description: ROME, July 21 (AP)  The Vatican announced today that Pope John Paul II would fly to the United States and Ireland in late September and early October on journey that will probably make him the first Pope to call at the White House. He will also address the United Nations General Assembly in New York on Oct. 2.

title: Ex-Member of Afghan Assembly Reports That 125,000 Have Fled
description: QUETTA, Pakistan, July 21 (Reuters)  About 125,000 Afghans fleeing the proCommunist Government of President Noor Mohammad Taraki have crossed into Pakistan and more are arriving every day, a former member of Afghanistan's National Assembly said.

title: Senate Votes Export Bill With Alaskan Oil Curb
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The Senate today approved an exportcontrol bill that sets tight restrictions on the sale of Alaskan oil and gives the Defense Department greater power over strategic exports to Communist countries.

title: J. D. Landauer, Realty Executive
description: James D. Landauer, retired presideni and board chairman of James D. Landauer Associates Inc., a major New Yorkbased realestate consulting concern, died Friday at his Manhattan home. He was 76 years old.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: Aproject is being developed at the Westchester County Penitentiary at Valhalla to train shortterm women inmates for jobs they would not normally be offered after their release.

title: Miss Whittington And Brett Angney To Be Wed Sept. 29
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Carolyn Dale Whittington to Brett Ray Angney. They plan to be married Sept. 29 in Baltimore.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: NOW that President Carter has put the nation's energy problems on a war footing, the rest of us can sit back and cast a glum eye over the dj vu, knowing that we have, in fact, been here before.

title: Gas Pinch: Could Be Serious for Real Estate Brokers
description: Real estate brokers in the tristate area say the gasoline shortage threatens to cut into their home and land sales because buyers do not have enough extra fuel in their tanks to make trips to real estate agency offices or to properties for sale.

title: Judith Mapes, F. A. Metz Jr. Are Married
description: Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Suffern, N.Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Judith Ann Mapes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Marvin Mapes of Suffern, to Frank Andrew Metz Jr. of Saddle River, N.J., a widower and son of Mr. Metz of Sebago, Me., and the late Mrs. Metz. The Rev. Donald Jette, former pastor of St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Hanson Has Nuptials
description: Elizabeth C. Hanson and Edward F. Lawlor, magna cum laude alumni of Bowdoin College, were married at the Bowdoin Chapel in Brunswick, ., yesterday. The Rev. James E. Knox of St. Charles Roman Catholic in Brunswick performed the ceremony.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, JULY 22, 1979

title: Tchaikovsky Winners
description: The Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow has come to be regarded by many observers as the pinnacle of international performance contests and the gold medal winners gain a decided edge in the race for being considered, this year's wunderIcind. Just about the last thing that would occur to anyone in the postcontest rush for prestige and publicity is a collaborative effort  for instance, a concert at which the prizewinning artists form a chamber ensemble and play together as equals.

title: CORINNE GRIFFITH, SILENT MOVIE STAR
description: Corinne Griffith, a prominent actress in the early years of Hollywood movies, whose muchheralded b..auty led to her nickname as the orchid of the screen, died July 13 at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 73 years old.

title: Dembowski: Hitter, Hittee
description: Steve Dembowski is finally convincing people that he is more than just a human target.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: REMOVING an old fence post or gate post that has been in place for years is often a frustrating and backbreaking job. Regardless of whether the post is being taken out because it has started to work loose, has started to rot or badly cracked and split and thus needs replacing, once the attempt is made to get it qut the post seems to be reluctant to let go its grip in the soil. The problem is even more difficult when the post has been set in concrete.

title: Wendy's Water Music in Park Brings Boats and Fun Together
description: You could call it a conceptual art event, a somewhat eccentric concert, a goodnatured gag, sonorous athletics, a video circus or an amiable mess.

title: What's Doing on UPPER CAPE COD
description: THE SETTING  The Upper Cape is where Daniel Webster came to hunt and fish, where President Grover Cleveland had his summer White House and where the naturalist Thornton Burgess wrote of Old Mother West Wind and Reddy Fox and the Brier Patch. It may not be where the typical Cape Cod action is, but there are graygreen moors, sheltered inlets and sandy beaches and four towns: Sandwich, Bourne, Falmouth and Mashpee. There are also villages with Indian names like Pocasset and Cataumet and English names like Hatchville and Woods Hole. It confounds many a traveler to have this section of Cape Cod, which lies closest to the mainland and starts about 58 miles south of Boston, called the Upper Cape, but that is the way it has been since the Pilgrims landed at Provincetown and used to explore up cape.

title: Sharing a House: It Can Work
description: MARCIA LANE was paying $135 a month for her single room and shared bath when she read an ad run by a group of young adults renting a house in Franklin Township. They were seeking a fifth person to share their house and its $350 monthly rent.

title: 3 Shoot Postrnan, Take Key to Midtown Mailboxes
description: The shooting and robbery of a postman making his rounds on the West Side yesterday touched off an extensive manhunt for three assailants who took only $9 from their victim but got away with a master key for thousands of indoor and outdoor mailboxes in midtown Manhattan.

title: Amid Our Crises, Church Silence
description: ST. PAUL, Minn.  In a moment of immense national crises, inflation and energy in particular, America's churches are thunderingly silent. I do not for one moment suggest that religion has or should have an instant solution to such problems. Nor is their content so compelling moral that church reticence is a mortal sin. But it's an eitheror proposition: Either churches are relevant to society or not; they can't have it both ways. Either they ,retreat to their steeples and speak only platitudes about socio. political issues, or, in facing overwhelming national crises, they roll up their sleeves and pitch in with the rest of us.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: There was a fleeting architectural event in Saks Fifth Avenue's windows last week. From July 5 12, the chic mannequins shared space with sleek models and renderings of five very large new buildings either in construction or about to be built midtown. The most interesting structure in the group was being publicly unveiled for the first time  a 46story office building that will replace 101 and 103 Park Avenue, from 40th to 41st Streets, for one of the most substantial new additions to the city. That's right. The two older brick office buildings there now will be torn down for the replacement; such is the economics of the real estate market today. (By a quirk of architectural fate, 101 Park, long the home of architects offices and building product displays, is a particularly undistinguished structure.)

title: Is Pro Tennis Turning Its Back on an Early Supporter?
description: JUST when it looked as though the volatile world of pro tennis was settling down into some sense of order and rationality, there is some new disruption. The focus now is a dispute between the management of the Association of Tennis Professionals and the United States Pro championships at Longwood Cricket Club in Chestnut Hill, Mass. Longwood was the first facility to accept the principle of pro tennis tournaments. In the first Longwood event, in 1964, Rod Laver beat Pancho Gonzales in the final and woil $2,200.

title: Ideology Takes
description: NEW DELHI  Once again, the institutions the world's largest democracy are being challenged. The major political coalitions have lost cohesiveness. Ambitious leaders scramble for power. Instability at the federal level spreads to state governments. And seemingly there is no one at the helm. But what looks like chaos to an outsider, say Indian politicians and academics, may prove to be a realignment of forces according to characteristic political conventions of the country.

title: Jane C. Reade Will Be Bride
description: The engagement of Jane Crowell Reade to Nordo Mauro Nissi 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nissi Jr. of Bradford, Mass., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Reade of Rye, N.Y., and West Falmouth, Mass., parents of the future bride.

title: Leon Fleisher's Other Careers
description: Leon Fleisher, who will conduct the same program twice Friday and Saturday as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall, might seem on the surface to be leading an enviably wellbalanced life. Aside from his conducting he appears periodically as a piano soloist, he leads a venturesome chambermusic series in Washington called the Theater Chamber Players, and he teaches  fulltime at the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore and one month a year at the University of Kansas.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Picture stories. Someday, historians of American pop culture may celebrate an evening in 1976 when two young men found themselves chance tablemates in crowded Los Angeles restaurant and eventually got around to discussing something they'd observed abroad for which there seemed a need in this country. The men were Herbert Stewart, the son of a Hollywood producer who was just getting by as a concert guitarist, and Laszlo Papas, an Argentinian trying make it as an actor. What they agreed the United States needed was Yankee versions of the fotonovelas so popular throughout the Latin world  books that would recount the story of a current film or television feature by superimposing words on still photographs from the show. Such photonovels would delight generation of youngsters weaned on the little tube.

title: Marriage Announcement 4 -- No Title
description: S.E. Dietz Is Fiance Of Martha F. Bakos

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Copper Gate Farm, Lyons Road, Basking Ridge, N.J.; limit, open, maiden, novice, nonthoroughbred, adult, junior and children's working hunter; open end green jumpers, pleasure horses, adult horsemanship, equitation; 8:30A.M.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Catholic Church Backing Debates on Land Reform
description: SAUK CENTRE, Minn., July 20  On a warm summer evening this week, about 75 farmers gathered in the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Morris, Minn., and held a lowkey discussion on a radical subject Who should own the land?

title: STAMPS
description: ARUSHA, TANZANIA Once German East Africa, and once called Tanganyika, Tanzania plus Zanzibar and the Seychelles  are places that evoke for collectors the r mance of distant climes that few will ever see, plus a sense of the sweep of history. Except for those who invest in stamps solely as a hedge against inflation, philately has always been more than a hobby of merely collecting little bits of colored postal paper.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 9 A. M. (Channel 2) Sunday .Morning : Refugees of Southeast Asia.

title: Doctors Practice, Athletes Play
description: IN 1973, Charlie Waters of the Dallas Cowboys played a football season with a 19inch rod in his arm to hold together a bone he had broken in a game months before. In 1979. Tommy John of the Los Angeles Dodgers had a tendon transplant in his pitching arm. Also that year, Denis Potvin of the Islanders had a lightweight cast inserted into his skate boot to allow him to play about 30 games with, a broken bone. For years, Earl IVIcinroe. of the Knicks took a powerful antiinflammation drug, Indocin, to help him lessen the pain when he ran up and down the basketball court.

title: MUSIC; Pianist to Celebrate 75th at Caramoor
description: FAMILY MATTERS usually are not discussed in this column, but since my mother happens to be Nadia Reisenberg, the noted pianist, and since she further happens to be celebrating her 75th birthday month with an appearance at the Caramoor Festival in Katonah next Sunday, I decided that a few of her reflections on music might not be out of place here.

title: ANTIQUES
description: The sophistication and sumptuousness of textiles from the Orient should now be well known to New Yorkers. In recent seasons, we have been treated to one museum exhibition after another that presented panoramic or indepth views of the exotic weaving and stitchery that evolved in the costumes and ceremonial hangings in different Eastern lands from the ancients onward. And now we are given the most provocative show of all  Splendid Symbols: Textiles and Tradition in Indonesia, on view at Asia House Gallery, 112 East 64th Street, through Sept. 3.

title: The Washington Massacre: A Bad Time for Mistakes
description: Who's minding the Fed? And the Energy Department? And the Transportation Department? The swift changes in Washington last week fostered disarray at the top  and the uncertainty is likely to last as the new leaders await Senate confirmation and then try to get their sea legs in their new jobs. In many respects, the period ahead is like the beginning of an administration, when the excuse for mistakes is that people are new to their jobs in a time of transition.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: All coins are not created equal. Many suffer from what might be called birth defects  incomplete or offcenter striking, for example  and when they leave the Mint, they present both opportunities and problems. Some have unusual features which make them attractive to specialists in error coins. In such cases the defects enhance the coins value in the eyes of true believers.

title: Marriage Announcement 2 -- No Title
description: Dr. John Paul Schosheim Fianc of Dale Samelson

title: Police. Check Runaway And Apprehend a Killer
description: A 20yearold California woman convicted of slaying her adoptive parents and burning their remains in a barbecue pit was picked up Thursday In midtown Manhattan by police who thought she was a teenage runaway.

title: The Threat of Foreign Banking
description: Banks wield enormous economic influence in our country. Their leveraging position and their allocation of credit play a pivotal role. In our economic system. Yet the. fact that foreignowned banks have become a major new, force in the New York banking system, indeed in all the major money centers of our nation, have elicited little attention or concern from Federal bank regulatory agencies.

title: The Final Days of the Watergate Books
description: John W. Dean 3d's Blind Ambition is selling for $1, and there are reports in publishing circles that thousands of copies of H.R. Haldeman's The Ends of Power have gone to a pulping mill. RN: The Memoirs of Richard Nixon is still selling at $19.95, but with its paperback counterpart due out in October, the clothbound version is certain to be quickly remaindered  bought up by discounters who mark them down to firesale prices.

title: Dance: Roadrunners By Merce Cunningham
description: DURHAM, N.C. THE Merce Cunningham Dance Company made its first ap: pearances at the American. Dance Festival's new home at Duke University over the weekend. The moderndance Innovator provoked some furrowed brows and nervous titters. But there were alto gasps of delight and warm applause. Best of all, there was animated discussion during intermissions  surely a sign that Durham dancegoers are finding festival performances a stimulating part of their summer, cultural life.

title: O.A. U. 's Unity Loses Appeal
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 22  With three walkouts in as many days, with boos, shouts, cheers, the slamming of hands and stony silences, the 16th summit meetine of the Oreanization of Afri-

title: Dr. ROBERT R. LINTON
description: BOSTON, July 22 (AP)  Dr. Robert  R. Linton, a retired internationally known vascular surgeon, died Saturday at his West Newton home after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Associated Press
description: UNITED AGAINST SEABROOK NUCLEAR PLANT: Antinuclear demonstrators joined hands In song as more than 4,000 people gathered for the second day of a weekend of sneakers, workshops and folk music at the site of the hotly contested New Hampshire nuclear power plant. Rally was sponsored by the Clamshell Alliance, a loose confederation of antinuclear organizations that has led past demonstrations against the construction of plant.

title: Riding the Latin Winds
description: Now that Nicaragua is under a revolutionary flag, some see only the Red in it. Forget the pledges to restore democratic rule, they say, because the Sandinists will dishonor them and install a Castroite regime. After all, it happened in Cuba. And with leftists in control of Nicaragua, revolution will spread like a tropical hurricane through Central America, eventually turning the Caribbean into a Red sea.

title: The City
description: The body of a New York City police officer missing since Wednesday night, when he began a trip home after an upstate outing, was found yesterday afternoon by the police in the Jerome Park reservoir in the Bronx.

title: Man and Woman Are Arrested In Shooting of a Guard Captain
description: A man and a woman were arrested yesterday in connection with the Saturday shooting of a a guard captain in the New York City Correction Department at a gasoline station on the Major Deegan Parkway. the police said.

title: Dance: Alicia Alonso In Spartacus
description: VERY rarely, and usually one hears about them only through legend, there are moments in the theater that go so far beyond the. leyel of ordinary experience that they can barely be described.

title: Snead, 67, Posts a 66; Weibring Wins by 2
description: COAL CITY, Ill., July 22 (AP)Sam Snead, one of golf's legends, shot a 66 today in the final round of the $200,000 Quad Cities open to become the first man ever to shoot below his age on the PGA Tour. He finished the tournament at three under par, well back of D.A. Weibring, who held off a charging Calvin Peete to gain his first tour victory.

title: Youngsters Dance Up a Storm at Waldorf
description: Putting their best feet forivard at the 15th annual Dance Educators of American national competition, childten from around the country performed yesterday in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria. Above, a group of youngsters tried to get it together in Curtain Time for the New York regional competition. At left, Lori Werner danced her way to first place in musical comedy, and Chris Smith, right, was a runner up with his rendition ofIn the Navy.

title: New Age For the Jets
description: THIS is the way things are now with the Jets and the Giants: the biggest news in the Jets camp is that a 6-foot-6-inch, 265pound defensive end has quit because he would rather be an artist. The biggest news in the Giants camp is that a whole bunch of people have not shown up in the first place.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: The Despair in Auto Repair
description: Getting an automobile repaired has become the nation's prime consumer frustration  and an enormously expensive one, too. A recent Federal survey found that drivers spend some $50 billion a year for car repairs and more than half that sum is wasted on faulty work or outright fraud. Many states are finally responding with programs to train more mechanics and to try to assure that drivers get the repairs they pay for many states, that is, other than New York.

title: Women Held Back by Their Sex, Not Personality, Study Suggests
description: An abrasive personality is not necessarily a bar to a woman's advancement in academia, business or politics, a study by Dr. Florence, L. Denmark, presidentelect'of the American Psychological Association, has concluded.

title: Modern Museum's Leaders Peer at Future
description: AS the Museum of Modern Art celebrates its 50th anniversary this year, its leaders are trying to think ahead  if not to the next 50 years, at least to the next decade.

title: Tbatuba
description: A twoton granite sculpture that was toppled from its pedestal and smashed by vandals on a sidewalk at 77th Street and Madison Avenue last May, causing an outcry in the neighborhood, has been restored and will be remounted Sept. 15. Special clamps are expected to assure its security this time.

title: A New

title: A Constitutional Right to Walk?
description: The opponents of busing schoolchildren to overcome racial segregation will charge up Capitol Hill again this week. They seek House approval of an amendment that would declare it a constitutional right for pupils to attend the public school nearest their homes. For all the understandable sentiment in favor of neighborhood schooling, we dearly hope the amendment is rejected. As social policy, it flies in the face evidence, validated by the Supreme Court, that deliberate school segregation persists and that busing is the only suitable remedy. Worse, it is an artlessly drafted and illconsidered attempt to alter the nation's fundaMental charter of governance.

title: Film: Trio Cavort in 'Pourquoi Pas!':Bohemia's Last Gasp
description: THE threesome who make up the menage a trois in "Pourquoi Pas! (Why Not!)" which opens at the Paris Theater today, are occasionally seen in bed together, but their arrangement apparently has little to do with sex. The sight of these characters asleep as a group  peaceful, carnal and comfortable  merely suggests that theirs is a stable household, in spite of all the vicissitudes the movie sees them through. The movie is by no means as continuous or satisfying as the characters' design for living is supposed to be. But it has its share of warmth, and offers a few amusing glimpses of the bohemian frontier, or what's left of it these days.If "Pourquoi Pas!" has any particular point to make, it's that nonconformity isn't what it used to be. Fernand (Sami Frey), Louis (Mario Gonzalez) and Alexa (Christine Murillo) may be a bit more daring than the bourgeois husband Alexa ran away from, or the wife who won't let Fernand see his children because of his bisexuality. But they have the same chores to attend to as anyone else might, and much of the film's interest lies in the tiny details of their communal plan.Fernand is the tidy one, the one in charge of getting the vacuum cleaner fixed. Alexa brings home the bacon, so to speak; she has a job reading to a bedridden woman who, unfortunately, likes to hear the same book over and over again. Louis's contribution is less apparent, and he's a more weakly drawn character than the other two. This is a curiously uneven film, vivid one moment and terribly sketchy the next.The writer and director, Coline Serreau, has a much easier time staging individual episodes than she does in stringing a story together; the film is almost amateurish in its timing, with an abruptness that clashes with the disarmingly offhanded performances of Miss Murillo and the glamorous Mr. Frey. Another discordant note comes from Mr. Gonzalez's more feverish acting, as he plays a character with a family history of madness that is explained awkwardly and confusingly. Miss Serreau's script incorporates a lot more tangential information  like a tiny subplot about Louis's mother  than her film can easily encompass.Midway through the story, the film introduces pretty, very nave and relatively straitlaced Sylvie (Nicole Jamet), whom Fernand tries to incorporate into the menage. Her presence is appealing but somehow airy, insofar as it neither disrupts nor enhances the domestic arrangement. Like the movie; she seems pleasant, often interesting, capable of great tenderness and yet not as involving one might hope her to be.

Harris of Tiverton, R.I., and Daisy LeB. Bishop, Columbus, N.J. Also survived by nine grandchildren and 16 greatgrandchildren. Services and Interment private. Memorials may be made In her name to The National Society of the Colonial Dames of America, 1630 Latimer St., Philadelphia, Pa. 19003 or The Heart Foundation.

title: Cain, Cardinal End, Dies
description: ST. CHARLES, Mo., July 22 (UPI)J.V. Cain, a tight end for the St. Louis Cardinals, died following cardiac arrest tonight during a practice at training camp.

title: Midwest Temple Offers Funerals by Its Members
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 20  When death comes to a member of the Adath Jeshu. run Synagogue, survivors have a choice available at no other synagogue in the United States: a funeral performed by congregation members.

title: FurukawaFlour Deal
description: TOKYO, July 22 (AP)  The Furukawa Company, a Japanese copper smelting concern, announced that it had concluded an agreement to sell its copper smelting technology to Fluor Mining and Metals Inc. Furukawa officials said their company would market the technology worldwide through Flour Mining, a subsidiary of the Fluor Corporation.

title: Music: Mozart's Tito, Is First at Monadnock
description: OVER the last 13 summers, Monadnock Music has developed into one of New Eng larld's more enterprising and unusual festivals. This year's season got under way last weekend and will continue until Sept. 2, presenting concerts, many of them free; in meeting houses and churches that spread over 12 towns in the southern New Hampshire region.

description: 57 A.M., WBAI. Reggae Music. Beaumont Small, host.

The crime problemhas; also broukht/ many eldetly citizeriaini0 the streets to protest for the first time intliefr lives.

title: Union Oil Ends Suit With U.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (UPI) The Union Oil Company of California has paid the United States Government $12,500 as a compromise for civil penalties from alleged overstatement of imported crude oil costs of about $1.3 million in 1979 and 1975, it was disclosed.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Leading executives remain sanguine about the economic outlook, despite last week's report of a drop in the gross national product, spurt in the money supply and upheaval in the Administration. Many continue to expect that the recession will be mild, and so far have felt only limited effects. [Page Dl.]

title: Women's Groups Assail. Low Level of Grants From Foundations
description: Even those who had expected the worst seemed startled by the actual figures. For when the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy released a study last week on the financing of women's programs by grantmakers, the results were arresting.

title: Group of New Delhi Street. Performers .Goes Legit
description: NEW DELHI, July 22  Beneath an overpass in the heart of this city there is a squatter village of 2,000 itinerant entertainers  jugglers, puppeteers, animal trainers, traditional balladeers and magicians.

title: Associated Press
description: WASHED ASHORE AT CONDOMINIUM: Tom Ramsey, a forestry engineer, inspecting car, partially buried in rock and sand, that was swept into the living room of home near Palm Desert, Calif. Area has been drenched with torrential rains for two days. Flooding has killed at least one person and caused

title: Kidnapped Woman Freed Unhurt
description: WEST MILFORD, N.J., July 22 Fortytwo hours after she had been kidnapped, .and five hours after. a $300,000 ransom had been paid, the 46yearold wife of a Paterson bank executive was released unharmedearly this morning at a gasoline station in Teaneck. N.J.

title: John Wayne's Life Subject Of Movie for CBSTV
description: LOS ANGELES, July 22  The life of John Wayne, who died of cancer six weeks ago, is being turned into a threehour CBSTV movie. It will be based on Shooting Star, an authorized biography of the actor by Maurice Zolotow, and will include the actor's final battle against cancer.

title: Executives Undaunted On Outlook
description: Despite the unexpectedly sharp drop in the economy reported for the second quarter, following on the heels of the spurt in the money supply and the sudden changes in President Carter's Cabinet, the business community remains surprisingly sanguine about the outlook for the economy.

title: Dogs Killed in Outbreak of Rabies
description: EAGLE PASS, Tex., July 22 (AP)Thousands of stray dogs have been destroyed by the authorities here and Piedras Negras, across the Rio Grande in Mexico, since an outbreak of rabies took the lives of three children. They were bitten by pet dogs that had not been vaccinated and that may have been infected by skunks or other wild animals_

title: The Nuclear Future
description: It is ironic that the very same newspapers that devoted many columns to Three Mile. Island that first day devoted one paragraph to an air crash in Quebec that killed 70 people.

title: Events Today
description: POURQUOI PASI directed By Wine Seireau, Paris Theater, 58th Street westot Fifth Avenue.

title: LowSulfur Oil Prices Rise, and Con Ed Says Rates WillGo Up, Too
description: The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that the price of lowsulfur oil had increased and that the increase would be automatically passed on to customers.

title: Valdez, 25 Choice, Wins Swaps Stakes
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 22 (AP) Valdez, who missed the Triple Crown races because of a viral infection, scored an impressive victory in the $214,250 Swaps Stakes at Hollywood Park today.

title: W.L. Dempsey, 84, Ex-President Of Merck Sharp &
description: William L. Dempsey, retired president of Merck Sharp & Dohme, one of the nation's largest drug concerns, died Saturday at Chestnut Hospital in Philadelphia. Mr. Dempsey, who lived in Philadelphia, was 84 years old.

title: Niagara Falls Endures Tourism NonCalamity
description: NIAGARA; FALLS, N.Y., July 22The story of the single greatest disaster never to happen atNiagara Falls began with a warning from an-out-ofstate OsyChic: She appeared on television in Connecticut, and predicted

title: The Painkiller Controversy
description: WHEN Willis Reed of the New York Knicks was injected with 250 milligrams of an anesthetic called Carbocaine in order to play against the Los Angeles Lakers in the final game of the 1970 National Basketball Association playoffs, the shot was heard round the sports world.

title: Skirmish at Grant's Tomb Over Benches
description: Are playful colored mosaic benches and arches, executed by community volunteers in shapes ranging from freeform to animals and taxicabs, an offense to the Greekcolumned sobriety of Grant's Tomb?

title: Peter Sutter, 86, Bakery Owner; Ran Well-Known Shop in Village
description: Peter Sutter, owner of Sutter Bakery and Confections, at 2512 Grand Concourse in the Bronx, died Sunday at White Plains General Hospital. Mr. Sutter, who was a resident of White Plains, was 86 years old and had been retired for nearly 10 years.

title: Super Sandlot On Cape Cod
description: ORLEANS, MASS. OUTSIDE the locker room, another batch of uniforms worn by the Orleans Cardinals thumped around in the washing machine.

title: ExPartner in a Major Law Firm Is Spared Disbarment
description: One of the few Partners in a major Manhattan law firm ever to spend time in prison was spared disbarment last week by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Loose Welds in the Social Compact
description: The tacit agreement between citizens and government about the conduct and duties each owes the other the social compact is in trouble.

title: Big Cities
description: LOS ANGELES, July 22  In downtown Los Angeles, whose moribund condition was for years a source of jokes for talk show hosts, more than $700 million worth of office buildings, motels, apart, ment buildings and stores are either under construction or under contract to start within two years.

title: Deaths
description: AARON-Sam. Yeshivi Ohel Moshe mourns with profound sorrow the sudden passing of the Chairman of the Board of Trustees, congregant, and devoted benefactor. His sincereconcern and deeds on behalf of our Yeshiva will long be cherished. Our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Ruth. children Barbara, Rabbi Joel and Elliot, brothers and sisters. Rabbi Leon Machlis Alex Lebwohl, President

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GOING OUT

title: Jordan Says Carter Will Widen His Circle of Advisers
description: WASHINGTON, July 22  Hamilton Jordan, the newly designated White House chief of staff, said today that he and President Carter intended to broaden the circle of advisers inside and outside of government to whom Mr. Carter listens.

title: 3,000 Afghans Reported Executed
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)United States officials have received reports that more than 3,000 political prisoners have been executed by the revolutionary regime in Afghanistan, the State Department said today.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Moore McCormack Bid
description: Moore McCormack Resources Inc. said that about 587,364 shares of the outstanding common stock of the Florida Mining and Materials Corporation had been tendered to its wholly owned subsidiary, Moormack Merger Inc.

title: Canada Lifts Bank Rate
description: OTTAWA, July 22  The Bank of Canada said it was raising the bank rate to a record 113/4 percent from 111,4 percent, effective tomorrow. Gerald Bouey, bank governor, said the immediate reason for the move was the increase on Friday in the United States discount rate to a record 10 percent. He added that Canada's payments deficit continued to be large and that Canadian interest rates must be high enough to encourage capital inflows and discourage capital outflows.

title: Guideline Revisions Expected
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)  The Carter Administration is considering cumulative, twoyear wage and price goals that would reward workers and business people who complied with the first year of the antiinflation program, according to highranking officials.

title: One Office For All
description: WASHINGTON  Casework. Constituent, services. Ombudsman work. Whichever term one prefers, is a concern in all Congressional offices. Muchtime is expended in both House and Senate offices in an effort to cut red tape and explaintheactions of Federal agencies to constituents, thereby creating an image of responsiveness for the member. Few people see harm in humanizing the impersonal governmental process by,- say, expediting a widow's Social Security benefits or facilitating a soldier's hardship discharge. Is this ..not what equity and fairness are all about?

title: Japan's Trade Figures: A Matter ofAccounting
description: TOKYO, July 22  Last week, the Japanese Government published figures that showed Japan's troublesome trade surpluses of lastyear vanishing in the first six months of 1979. A surplus

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: HOUSTON, July 23 (UPI)  The Tenneco Oil Company announced today that it had agreed to buy all the oil and gas properties of UV Industries Inc. for approximately $135 million.

title: Burroughs Mitchell, Chief Editor At Scribner's and Jones's Mentor
description: Burroughs Mitchell, who retired in 1977 as editor-in-chief of Charles Scribner's Sons died Saturday of heart failure at Doctors Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 390 West End Avenue.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: broken tnenberclouds are scattered over the Middie and South Atlantic States, and over the Central Plain's States. Large spiral clouds associated with the tropical depression Claudette are visible over the Gulf States and the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Gwen Verdon Keeps Them Dancin
description: REMEMBR, lift on 40  and then 41, 42, 43, and we go like this  The instructor is Gwen Verdon, who is suspended three feet off the floor at the rehearsal studio, her legs jackknifed backward and around the torso of fellow dancer Christopher Chadman. But her pupil, Bryan Nicholas, is less mindful of Miss Verdon's spectacular position  roughly that of a 19th-century ship's figurehead  than of how Mr. Chadman is counterbalancing her.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Whatever happened to the Mo hole Project?

title: New Press Code Adopted by Iran Limits Foreign Reporters
description: The revolutionary Government of Iran adopted a new press code for foreign correspondents yesterday that prohibits them from traveling outside Teheran without permission and from interviewing Iranians without the presence of representative of the Ministry of National Guidance.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 8 P.M. RadioWINS, 7:50 P.M.)

title: IN THE NATION Speaking For Carter
description: Virtually every informed report on what has recently been going on in the Carter Administration confirms one point: among the most influential voices in its policy councils is that of Rosalynn Carter. She may be the most powerful First Lady since Edith Bolling Wilson virtually took over for a stricken President.

title: Notes on People
description: When sne was a little girl, Colleen Neary used to hang around backstage at the New York City Ballet, where her sister, Patricia Neary, was a featured soloist. Colleen studied at the School of American Ballet, and that led to children's roles with the ballet company, and finally she, too, became a City Ballet soloist, as her older sister went off to become artistic director of the Zurich Ballet.

title: Counsel for Senate Ethics Panel Said to Ask Censure for Talmadge
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  The special counsel for the Senate Select Committee on Ethics has urged members to recommend that Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, be censured by the Senate for engaging in financial misconduct, according to sources close to the committee's inquiry.

title: Associated Press
description: CAUGHT BY A TRAIN: Jessie Dean Johnson watched as rescue workers pried off roof of his car Sunday to free him and his wife, Helaine, after their car was struck by a 100w.ar freight train in San Bernadino, Calif. Train, traveling at 15miles an hour, struck car midsection at a railroad crossing and dragged it 540 feet before hitting a bridge and stopping. The couple escaped with minor injuries.

title: Occidental Bullish on Shale Oil
description: GRAND JUNCTION, Colo., July 19  The shafts beneath the gray concrete monoliths are being sunk at the rate of about six feet a day. Costs are running around $3 million a month. By the time commercial production begins, probably in 1986, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation will have spent nearly $1 billion transforming a 5,120acre tract of sagebrush and pion pine near here into an energy resource capable of producing up to 200,000 barrels of shale oil a day.

title: Khomeini Bans Broadcast Music, Saying It Corrupts Iranian Youth
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini banned all music from Iranian radio and television yesterday because, he said, it is no different from opium.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) over-the-counter.

title: Money Unrecovered In Jersey Kidnapping
description: Federal agents disclosed yesterday that they had not recovered the ransom paid to kidnappers of the wife of a West Milford, N.J., banker even though they had trailed two of the suspects from the site the money was dropped off Saturday night.

title: Associated Press
description: GASOLINE STORAGE TANK GOES UP IN FLAMES: Fire and smoke shot over 100 feet into the air yesterday at the British Petroleum terminal in Baltimore, where a tank holding 420,000 gallons of gasoline burned for more than two hours. About 180 firefighters fought the blaze, attributed to gasoline overflow from pipes above the tank. Three employees were injured, one seriously.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Podiatric Medicine

title: Trade Liberalization Clears Senate, 90 to 4; Bill Goes to President
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  The Senate voted 90 to 4 today to approve the tradeliberalization pact that the United States negotiated with 98 other nations in Geneva last April.

title: Deaths
description: CHRISTY  Francis T. The Trustees and Employees of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences mourn the passing of Francis T. Christy, who served as Chairman of the Brooklyn Museum Governing Committee from 1954 to 1960, as President of the Institute from 1960 to 1967, and as Chairman of the Board from 1967 to 1971, and express their Profound sympathy to his wife, Catherine, and to his family. The Trustees and Employees of the Brooklyn institute of Arts and Sciences.

title: FIVE PENSION FUNDS SELLING M.A.C. BONDS
description: For the first time since New York City's five pension funds began buying Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds to help the city recover from its fiscal crisis, the funds announced yesterday that they planned to resell part of their taxfree certificates through competitive public bidding.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter and his top aides continued their search for a new Federal Reserve Board chairman as the outgoing chairman, G. William Miller, offered assurances that last week's Cabinet changes would not disrupt the Administration's economic policies. The White House announced that the President would hold a nationally televised news conference at 9 P.M. tomorrow. [Page A1.]

title: 6 Die as a Lebanese Cargo Plane Crashes During a Training Flight
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23 (AP)  A Boeing 707 cargo plane belonging to Lebanon's TransMediterranean Airways crashed during a training flight at Beirut airport today, killing its sixman Lebanese crew, airport security officials said.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Prices Decline in Slow Trading
description: Reacting both to the discount rate increase by the Federal Reserve and to continued declines in value for the dollar in foreign exchange trading, the credit markets moved toward lower prices and higher interest rates yesterday.

title: Son Delbert McClinton
description: DELBERT McCLINTON, who was at the Bottoni.Line over the weekend, is the definitive honkytonk. entertainer. He isn't flashy or dramatic, but he sings soul, blues and country.music in a thoroughly believable manner and he can sing all night without repeating himself. His band covers the requisite stylistic bases with admirable versatility and spirit.

title: First Chicago Lifts Prime Rate
description: CHICAGO, July 23, (Reuters) The First National Bank of Chicago, the country's ninthlargest bank, raised its prime lending rate, the interest rate it charges its best customers, today to 11.75 percent from 11.50 percent.

title: In One Night, 2 Triple Plays
description: A triple play is supposed to be a rarity in baseball. But last night two triple plays were executed, by the Pittsburgh Pirates in the National League and by the Boston Red Sox in the American.

title: 12 Small Towns to Keep Threatened Post Offices
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)  The Postal Service's plans to save money by closing 12 smalltown post offices were reversed today by the Postal Rate Cornmission, which ruled that not enough consideration had been given to how the closings would affect the communities.

title: U.S. to Change 194 Mail Locks On Street Boxes
description: The postmaster of New York City ordered yesterday that locks be chanted on all 194 sidewalk letter boxes in the area of midtown Manhattan in which holdup men made off Saturday with a master key after shooting a mailman.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allstate Insurance Companies, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, has named David S. Murphy senior vice president in charge of Japanese operations.

title: Three Gestapa Aides.Go on Trial In West Germany Next October
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, July 23 (Reuters)  Kurt Lischka, a deputy chief of the Gestapo in France in World War II, and two of his colleagues will go on trial in October for their role in the killing of 33,000 Jews, the prosecutor's office here said today.

title: Concert: Monteverdi At Ipswich
description: PREBAROQUE music has become increasingly popular with. audiences over the last decade, and the field has even begun to produce its own superstars. Three of them made a rare joint appearance last weekend at the Castle Hill Festival in Ipswich, Mass., a summer series that over the last six years has Developed into something of a mecca for early-music fans.

title: Gas Crisis Cuts Crowds in U.S. Parks
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., July 22  Jerry Cohen, a Chicago salesman, and his wife, Dorothy, went rock climbing above the spectacular Yosemite Valley this morning and in three hours of hiking did not encounter another person.

title: East German Loses Animal
description: WEST BERLIN, July 23 (Reuters) An East German court has rejected an appeal by Robert Havemann, dissident scientist, who was fined $.5,400 for currency violations, informed sources here said today.

title: Begin's Sight Impaired By Artery Obstruction
description: JERUSALEM, July 23 (AP) Prime Minister Menachem Begin has lost 25 percent of the vision in his right eye and 10 percent in the left as a result of an obstructed brain artery, his doctors reported today.

title: Market Place
description: CHARLES J. NICOLOSI Is one of the more successful and enduring members of a breed known on Wall Street as the special situation analyst. As a vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. he closely follows 50 companies, typically of moderate size  averaging $150 million annually in sales volume  and monitors 400 others.

title: Senate Votes FoodStamp Funds
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  The Senate today provided an additional $620 million to continue full food stamp allotments for August and Seutember.

title: City Announces. Delay in Decentralizing of Services
description: New York City announced yesterday that some departments would not fully meet a 1980 deadline for reorganizing city services to decentralize them and make them more accessible to community boards.

title: U.S. Will Withdraw Most of Staff From Afghanistan as Strife Grows
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Most United States Government employees in Afghanistan and their dependents will be withdrawn in the next few weeks because of the increasing intensity of the civil war. there, the State Department announced today.

title: Behavioral Scientists Argue Guilt's Role
description: ONE psychoanalyst, Dr. Theodore Isaac Rubin, calls a destructive form of selfhate. Another, Dr. Willard Gaylin, characterizes it as a guardian of our goodness.

title: Home Loans Decline in Yield
description: Moving lower for the fifth consecutive week, the average yield on conventional home mortgages dropped yesterday in the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation's weekly purchase of home loans, bringing the cumulative decline since midJune to nearly onethird of a percentage point.

title: Lawyer, 80, Is Murdered In West Side Apartment
description: A 80-year-old lawyer was found stabbed and beaten to death early yesterday in his apartment near Carnegie Hall. The police called it a robbery attempt.

title: Oil Slick Off Trinidad Expected to Disperse From Natural Causes
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, July 23 The oil slick from Thursday's collision of two supertankers is now a very thin, patchy sheen, according to Hugh C. Hinds, national controller of the National Oil Spill Contingency Plan for the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Japan Lifts Discount Rate 1% in Drive on Inflation
description: TOKYO, July 23  The Bank of Japan announced today that its discount rate would go up by 1 percent to 5.25 percent tomorrow in an effort to slow inflation.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARGONAUT (Farrell Lines). Cadiz August 1, Naples 3, Palermo 4, Leghorn 5, Genoa 6, Fos 8 and Barcelona 9; sails fromHowland Hook, Staten Island.

title: U.S. Coach Criticizes Wait at Spartakiad
description: MOSCOW, July 23 (AP)  Bart Williams of the United States pulled hamstring muscle while leading the 400meter hurdles race in the Spartakiad Games today and limped away in pain. His coach then criticized the Soviet organizers for making athletes wait 30 minutes between warmups and their events.

title: Drivers in City Warned To Clear Intersections
description: Trafficenforcement agents invaded crowded intersections in midtown Manhattan yesterday in the first skirmish of a new effort to stop motorists from blocking intersections and crosswalks.

title: Refugee Parley: Diplomatic Gain for Hanoi?
description: GENEVA, July 23  A senior Vietnamese official was asked what Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations meant when he announced at a 65nation conference here on Indochinese refugees that Vietnam would try to stern

title: Times Co. Elects New President
description: Walter Mattson was elected president and chief operating officer of The New York Times Company yesterday, and Sydney Gruson and James C. Goodale were elected vice chairmen.

title: Manhattan Paces City Economic Gains
description: Two years after it began, New York City's economic upturn is still most conspicuous in midtown and lower Manhattan, with the economic situation in the rest of the city so uneven that it is fueling sharp disagreement about the real extent of the recovery.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JULY 23, 1979

title: Deaths
description: Beloved husband of Henrietta 0. (Boil). Loving uncle of William L. Boll. High Requiem Mass to be held Wednesday 11AM at Grace Episcopal Church, White Plains. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Letter: On New Environmental Gambles
description: Your editorial of July 8 observes that NASA elected to live with the risk that someone, somewhere, would be injured when Skylab fell, as we knew would when it was launched six years ago without costly reentry rockets. The adds paid off: Skylab is down, apparently without injury to human life.

title: U.S. Navy Tells Ships Of the Seventh Fleet To Watch for Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)  The Navy has directed all of the Seventh Fleet's ships and planes operating in the South China Sea to be particularly alert to refugees and to render all possible assistance for vessels in distress, a Pentagon spokesman said tonight.

title: OBSERVER Why Not the Best?
description: Since the oil problem is the gravest menace facing the Republic, the White House fired the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Concerto in E flat, Haydn; Sonata a Quattro, Fux; ScherzoWaltz, Chopin; Summer Night on the River, Delius. 8:154, WQXR. Violin Concerto in F sharp minor, Vieuxtemps; My Country: The High Castle, Smetana.

title: Alberta Gas Seeks Permit
description: CALGARY, Alberta, July 23 (Reuters)  PanAlberta Gas Ltd. said today that it had applied for a new permit to export additional natural gas to the United States. The permit. if approved by regulators, would be for the export of 4.3 trillion cubic feet. The company already has a permit for 3.37 edition cubic feet.

title: Head of First Pennsylvania Resigns
description: John R. Bunting Jr. resigned yesterday as chief executive officer of the First Pennsylvania Corpqration and of its primary subsidiary, the First Pennsylvania Bank.

title: Body and Psyche: New Gurus Aid Creative People
description: They are the new Wise Ones in the community. To them, the Creative Ones are turning for help in daily living. Daily living has become so stressful, so perilous and so complex that it can no longer be left to the amateurs. Anyway, that is what the Creative Ones say.

title: Music: BernsteinTennstedt Weekend
description: TBE mechanics of orchestra conducting are no mystery. They are available to anyone who can read a textbook on the craft and can count up to three without getting confused. And yet no one has ever quite resolved the mystery of how certain conductors draw superior, inspired performances from musicians, while others, apparently with as much talent and as much baton skill, must settle for dutifullyobedient readings of the score. Two concerts ty the Boston Symphony OrcheStra last weekend at Tanglewood, one led by Klaus Tennstedt and the other by Leonard Bernstein, let one obsetve in action a pair of Conductors for whoni musicians found it possible, perhaps: even easy, to make magnificent music. Mr. Bernstein, conducting Haydn and ShoStakovich on Sunday, seemed in many ways to be riding the crest of his remarkable career as an interpreter, having struck a bargain between youthful abandon and mature control.

title: Treasury Bills Climb Sharply
description: Treasury bill rates climbed sharply yesterday, pushed upward by the Federal Reserve's increase in the discount rate last Friday.

title: Science Watch
description: A new technique for discovering minute amounts of airborne sulfuric acid, a major air pollutant, has been developed by a chemist at the University of California at Los Angeles. Sulfuric acid is a colorless and corrosive liquid which occurs in the atmosphere when waste gases containing sulfur oxides are combined with oxygen and moisture.

title: Padres 6, Phillies 5
description: SAN DIEGO, July 23 (AP)  Dave Winfield, who hit a tworun homer in the eighth inning to tie the game, stroked a runscoring single in the ninth to give the San Diego Padres a 65 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

title: California Party, Rebuffing Brown, Seen Damaging His Political Hopes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 23  Gov. Edmiuid G. Browri Jr. has once again suffered several jarring setbaCks within California's Democratic. Party, the power base.;on which he is expected to open a formal campaign for the Presidency withiiithe next few weeks.

title: Deaths
description: BENDER  Samuel, beloved father of Ann Cooperman and Sidney, adored grandfather and greatgrandfather. Dear friend of Josephine Andrews. Services Tuesday 1 pm The Riverside Brooklyn, Ocean Parkway at Prospect Park.

title: Bundy's Defense Rests After Disputing Testimony of Dental Expert
description: MIAMI, July 23  The defense in Theodore R. Bundy's trial for murder rested without calling any witnesses today after a lastminute attempt by the defendant to refute what he termed the strongest part of the state's case against me.

title: Victim Tells of 42Hour Ordeal With No Food and Much Worry
description: WEST MILFORD, N.J., July 23 Joan Dedrick recalled today that she prayed continually during the 42 hours she was held by kidnappers over the weekend. She was also worried about an iron she had left plugged in when she was abducted from her family's secluded ranchstyle home here Friday.

title: When the Bench Is Adjudged in Contempt
description: An appeal, said Mr. Dooley, the legendary saloonkeeper of Finley Peter Dunne's fiction, is where ye ask wan coort to show its contempt f'r another coort.

title: Gold Price Surges to New Peak
description: The price of gold hit a new high yesterday amid anxiety among investors over President Carter's political difficulties, the falling dollar, inflation, the energy problem and the world's economic outlook.

title: Youth Describes BaseballBat Attacks in Central Park
description: Michael Riley, a 16yearold Manhattan youth who said he participated in an unprovoked attack on six men in the Central Park ramble last summer, told tense courtroom yesterday that he had personally witnessed the wielding of baseball bats and other weapons against their victims by each of the three defendants now on trial.

title: Niekro Brothers Each Win 14th
description: The Niekro brothers, Phil of the Atlanta Braves and Joe of the Houston Astros, kept pace with each other last night by recording their 14th victories, high in the major leagues.

title: $600,000 Transit Authority Theft At a Guarded, DoubleLocked Safe
description: The weekend theft of $600,000 in $10 bills from a guarded safe, protected further by a combination requiring two men to open the safe, was disclosed yesterday by the New York City Transit Authority.

title: Vietnam Agrees To Visits by U.S. To Process Visas
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  The United States and Vietnam have agreed in principle to allow American consular officers into Ho Chi Minh City to process people wishing to come to the United States, State Department officials said today.

title: Front Page 1 -- No Title
description: The New York Times/George Tames

title: Burger Wants Competency Test For Lawyers in Federal Practice
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger proposed today that lawyers who have been admitted to their state bars be prohibited from practicing in the Federal courts unless they pass a second examination and demonstrate trial competency.

title: Tories Planning to Sell Part of British Aerospace
description: LONDON, July 23  In another contentious denationalization move, the Conservative Government that swept to power in May said today that it would place in private hands about half of its 100 percent interest in British Aerospace, the country's dominant plane and missile producer.

title: Party Drops Company Tied to Kennedy Draft
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)  The Democratic National Committee has dismissed a fundraising concern that was mailing letters for a movement to draft Senator Edward M. Kennedy at the same time it was working for the party.

title: Dr. Percy Phillips, 81, ExNational President Of Dental Association
description: Dr. Percy T. Phillips, a past president of the American Dental Association, died Sunday at White Plains General Hospital after a brief illness. He was 81 years old and resided in White Plains.

title: National and Bally Dominate Trading
description: Torrid trading in National Airlines and Bally Manufacturing, along with price gains in takeover situations, dominated interest on Wall Street yesterday.

title: Orangeco Stake Bought
description: The Southeastern Public Service Company said it had bought 222,900 shares, or about 5.5 percent, of the stock of Orangeco Inc. as an investment. Orangeco, based in Columbus, Ohio, processes citrus fruits and juices and operates the Arthur Treacher's Fish and Chips chain of restaurants.

title: S.E.C. Cites Caesars
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had charged Caesars World Inc. and Clifford S. Perlman, the company's chairman and principal stockholder, with violating anuiraua, reporting ana proxy provisions of the securities laws. The S.E.C. simultaneously announced that both defendants had settled the charges, while neither admitted nor denied them.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, July 23 (AP)  The American Medical Association is losing duespaying members, and is contemplating what to do about it.

title: Poll Says 36 Percent See Benefit in Carter Shifts
description: A Gallup poll of 539 Americans shows that 36 percent believe that changes in President Carter's Cabinet and senior staff will help the country, while 42 percent said they would make no difference.

title: Events Today
description: MOSTLY MOZART: CHAMBER MUSIC RECITAL Avery Fisher Hall, 6.

title: MILLER SEES NO SNAG IN ECONOMIC POLICY FROM CABINET MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  G. William Miller, the departing chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, sought today to provide assurances that the Carter Administration's economic policies would not be disrupted by last week's Cabinet changes.

title: Deaths
description: ROSS  Samuel Bernard, M.D.On July 13, 1979. Survived by loving wife Adele and two sons, S. B. Ross, Jr., of Green Chimneys. Brewster, N.Y. and Thomas M. Ross of Danbury, Ct. and five grandchildren. Contributions may be made to the Green Chimneys Health Center, Brewster, N.Y.

title: Jesse Jackson Takes Spirited Messav to South Africa
description: CAPE TOWN, July 21  I may be poor but I am somebody!

title: No, OPEC Isn't An Enemy
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  President Carter in his energypolicy address was wise to avoid stigmatizing the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries as clear enemy  to use the language of his chief domestic adviser, Stuart Eizenstat. Such an approach would have been an unsound basis on which to build national policy. On the other hand, a desire to recapture control over our energy destiny is fundamental in our political and economic life. How then should we look at OPEC?

title: The City
description: Eric Michael, who was released from state prison yesterday because his robbery conviction had been recently overturned, was immediately arraigned on a new Federal charge involving the same robbery.

title: News Summary
description: Wastrington deplored Israel's attacks with jets against Lebanon and criti. cited Israel's rejection of a compromise plan for a United Nations force to oversee the IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty. In blunt language, the State Department charged that the raids on coastal areas were carried out when the roads were filled with motorists returning from excursions and it said reports indicated that women and children were among those killed and wounded. [Page Al, Column 4.]

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of William L. Dempsey yesterday. in The Times contained several errors. A corrected article appears on Page D15.

title: Yanks Turn Back Mariners, 62; Chambliss, Figueroa Standouts
description: Billy Martin saw his Yankees win their third straight game last night, by 62 over the Seattle Mariners at Yankee Stadium. He also saw Ed Figueroa come off the disabled list and pitch five good innings for his, first victory since May 9. And he'saw Chris Charnbliss. the first baseman, bit the 100th home run of his career and star in the field.

title: Going Out Guide
description: KEYBOARD FLAVOR Jorge Rios, the personable pianist and singer who recently held forth at the Cafe Reginette, has moved across Midtown as the second entertainer of the new livemusic policy at Dawson's (6888228), the restaurant at 206 East 52d Street. The Chileanborn musician, whose repertory .ranges from show tunes to songs in six languages, performs in the publike atmosphere of the downstairs dining room, which has an entrance bar, and no cover or minimum tabs at the tables. He appears from 8 P.M. to midnight Tuesdays through Saturdays.

title: Chemical Bank Wins Court Plea
description: A Federal appeals court panel ruled yesterday in Philadelphia that the Chemical Bank had not violated its fiduciary duty to customers in deciding to help one client take over another. The threejudge panel overturned a lowercourt decision arising out of efforts by Talley Industries to take over the Washington Steel Corporation. Both companies were Chemical clients.

title: Opiates of the People
description: One piece of news out of Iran concerns music. was Marx who said religion is the opiate of the people. The devout Ayatollah Khomeini thinks music is the villain. Like opium, he says, it stupefies persons listening to it and makes their brain inactive and frivolous. For radio and television to broadcast music is treason; he insists it must be banned.

title: United Press International
description: TRIPLE PLAY: Pirates Phil Garner relays to first base complete triple play after forcing Braves Since Benedict second base during second inning last night in Pittsburgh. The third baseman, Bill Madlock, started the play by fielding Phil Neikro's grounder and stepping on the base. Pirates won, 71.

title: Stage: Satirical Musical By the Duo Ensemble
description: DUO THEATER, a Spanish-English ensemble, is presenting The Beggars Soap Opera, which is based on The Threepenny Opera, which, in turn. was based on The Beggars Opera. It is cheerful and innocent, and its cynicism is not so much bitter as it is saucy. It owes as much to WNJUTV, Channel 47, which shows soap operas in Spanish, as it does to Bertolt Brecht.

title: Letters
description: During President Carter's search for energy initiatives, The Times reported that he was considering a conservation plan requiring utilities to invest in home conservation measures to be included in rate base investment. Unfortunately, this idea did not emerge in the final Carter package.

title: Dodgers Beat Mets, 31; Mazzilli Hurt in Mishap; Mets Bow; Mazzilli Injured
description: LOS ANGELES, July 23  In a season riddled with injuries, the New York Mets suffered a spectacular one tonight when Lee Mazzilli was sent to the hospital after a collision with Dan Norman in the outfield in Dodger Stadium.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD Rabies Requires Weighing of Risks
description: AT least three children along the United StatesMexican border have died recently of rabies from dog bites, one in Mexico and two in Texas. This insidious disease, dreaded since ancient times, is quite rare humans in this country.

title: Commonwealth Oil Files Plan Involving Takeover
description: The troubled Commonwealth Oil Refining Company Inc. filed a plan with the Bankruptcy Court in San Antonio yesterday whereby the management of the company hopes to emerge from reorganization proceedines.

title: 4 Airports Placed on Spray List In Bid to Limit Japanese Beetles
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)  Four more airports have been added to the Government's spraying effort against Japanese beetles, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Guitar: Frank Christian
description: YES, young folkies are still searching for their own identities in Depnessionera blues recordings, and one of them, Frank Christian, has been performing at Gerde's Folk City, where he will be next Friday Saturday and Sunday. Mr. Christian's song list includes the obligatory blues classics, some guitar ragtime, some cabaret blues, and some originals in approximations of vintage styles. Yet he's obviously, too young to remember the early and middle 60's, when young white pickers were swarming to Greenwich Village from all over the country with similar lists taped to their guitar cases.

title: Justice Refuses to Close Hearing Despite Defense Attorney's Plea
description: A Manhattan judge yesterday denied defense motion to exclude the press and the public from a hearing in an attemptedmurder case.

title: No Heart Attack in Cain Death
description: ST. CHARLES, Mo., July 23 (UPI). An autopsy today ruled out a heart attack as the cause of the death of J.V. Cain, the tight end who collapsed yesterday during practice at the St. Louis Cardinals training camp.

title: Golsteyn Released By Giants
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 23 Jerry Golsteyn, once the Giants future quarterback and twice their seasonopener starter, was placed on norecall waivers today as Ray Perkins made the first roster cuts of his career as a head coach.

title: The Region
description: SYRACUSE  Thousands of dead fish were found in Onondaga Creek yesterday following a break in an Allied Chemical Corporation pipeline about seven miles south of here spilled tons of salt water into the freshwater stream.

title: Civiletti Hearings Are Set
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI)  The Senate Judiciary Committee will open confirmation hearings Wednesday for Deputy Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti, President Carter's nominee to be the next Attorney General. Committee sources said that Mr. Civiletti's nomination is not too controversial and should bring little opposition from committee members.

title: Koufax and Mays Return
description: LOS ANGELES, July 23  Sandy Koufax, trim and 43, bounded into the dugout in Dodger Stadium And said, Hey, Old Folks, you on my side for a change? And Willie Mays, trim and 48, replied with relief, It's about time.

title: Advertising
description: NEW campaign for Maverick jeans from Blue Bell Inc. of Greensboro, N.C., will break on Sunday in newspaper supplements in 80 markets. The agency behind it is Tucker Wayne & Company of Atlanta, one the first nonNew York agencies to do Blue Bell advertising and an agency that is making every effort to escape the regional mold and become a nationa ad agency.

title: FaintHearted Helpers Assist Junior Frisbee Ace
description: With eyes closed, and a HulaHoop at arm's length, two girls helped their playmate yesterday as she competed a Junior Frisbee Tournament in Central Park's Sheep

title: Dip in Demand For Petroleum
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (Reuters) United States demand for all petroleum products, in the four weeks to July 13 fell 5.8 percent from the comparable yearearlier period to 16.9 million barrels a day, the Department of Energy said.

title: Bear, Stearns Disciplined For Supervisory Failures
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  The Securities and Exchange Commission censured Bear, Stearns & Company, a prominent brokerage firm, today for failing to supervise a broker in its Chicago office and accused the firm of supervisory failures in its San Francisco office as well.

title: About Education
description: IN 1867, New Jersey became the first state to abolish corporal punishment in the public schools. No other state followed its example until 1972, when Massachusetts took the plunge. The situation has not changed much since then. Today, 46 states allow the use of corporal punishment.

title: About New York
description: As crime goes, this one was a nothing affair, but it was a first for the woman who was the victim and she was shocked. It was only a pursesnatching, the sort of infraction that is typical and traditional New York, antedating modern crime waves. Yet since it was first for her and for the man she was walking to lunch with, it impressed them with the speed of its transaction and the fidelity to fiction of the settings of its aftermath.

title: Milwaukee Road Trustee
description: The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad announced yesterday that Judge Thomas R. McMillen of Federal Bankruptcy Court had named former Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie of Illinois as reorganization trustee to succeed Stanley E.G. Hillman, who retired June 14.

title: Wrong Signal on Air Bags
description: Congressman John Dingell of Michigan hopes deflate the push for air bags in future cars with a mischievous piece of legislation. It would bar the Department of Transportation from spending any money to implement or enforce any air bag requirement. The practical effect would be negligible; there won't be anything to implement or enforce until the 1982 model year, and research and development could continue. But the Dingell amendment would send out the wrong signals. It would undermine public confidence in the air bag, raise questions among manufacturers about the worth of air bag investment and, if renewed in future years, eventually make it impossible for the department to enforce its safety standard.

title: Drill Hole Yields Clues To Structure Of Ocean Bed
description: IN search of clues to the remarkable diversity of rocks found in the earth's crust, scientists have used a hole drilled deep into the floor of the Pacific as the laboratory for the most extensive experiments ever conducted beneath an ocean.

title: Rexford Tugwell, Roosevelt Aide, Dies
description: Rexford Guy Tugwell, one of the three original members of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal brains trust, died Saturday at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara. Calif.

title: Free Legal Aid On Housing Issues
description: A Federal grant of $249,000 will allow the city to give free legal advice to tenants and community groups and to owners of residential buildings in upper Manhattan who want to improve them.

title: Up to 7.22% Yield Set on Municipals
description: Investment bankers set tentative terms yesterday on more than $640 million of taxexempt bonds that they plan to sell this week in an unusually active schedule of negotiated local-government financing.

title: Shot Went Awry? Blame a Vibration Node
description: THE average tennis player is aware that his racquet has a handle, a frame and strings,and he knows which those to grasp when he starts to play. He buys a racquet that feels good and hopes it will make him another Tilden on the court even if he hasn't any idea how it works.

title: Sophie
description: LOS ANGELES, July 23  Over a lunch at Laurent on Friday, June 22, it was decided that Sophie's Choice the bestselling novel in America this week, according to The New York Times Book Review  could be made into a $10 million to $12 million movie by Lord Grade's Marble Arch Productions.

title: Bridge:
description: Players representing the United States, Canada and Mexico in world championship competition receive more financial support from the national organization than they would from any other country In the world.

title: A Con Job, They Felt
description: The large corporations that supply us with our energy needs are suffering from a crisis of their own  public credibility. There is no exemption from that malaise for the firm I work for, Consolidated Edison of New York.

title: Mets Box Score
description: DP- Los Angeles 2. LOB.- Mets 5, Los Angeles 6. 2B.- Montanez, Stearns. HR- Lopes

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Martin Horwitz seems intent on selling himself out of a job. The chairman of UV Industries, a company that has embarked on a plan of liquidation and dissolution, announced yesterday that UV had entered into an agreement to sell its oil and gas properties to Tenneco Oil Company for about $135 million. [Page D3.] Earlier, UV had sold its Federal Pacific Electric holdings to Reliance Electric Company for $345 million.

title: Exxon's Profits Up 20.3%
description: The Exxon Corporation, the largest domestic oil company to announce quarterly profits since the beginning of the current oil shortage, reported yesterday that it had a 20.3 percent rise in net income to 8830 million, or $1.88 per share, from $690 million, or $1.55 per share, in the similar period last year.

title: Rebels Abduct 40 Rhodesians From a Mission
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, July 23 (AP)  Black nationalist guerrillas have kidnapped about 40 Roman Catholics from a remote jungle mission and marched them 15 miles into Mozam bique, church and security sources said today.

title: Taxes
description: THE private sector and Government regulators have increasingly been taking up the battle cry for some sort of inflation accounting, and now the Internal Revenue Service has entered the fray. In a move that should gratify the business community, the I.R.S. has quietly opened the door to more corporate disclosure about the impact of inflation on inventories and profits.

title: Senate Armed Services Panel Takes Up Treaty Debate
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Senators critical of the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union today attempted to pick holes in the Government's case for the accord as discussion shifted to the Armed Services Committee.

title: Nicaragua to Ask Extradition of Somoza and Aides
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 23  The revolutionary Government of Nicaragua announced today that it would move to extradite former President Anastasio Somoza Debayle, members of his family, associates and other unnamed military and civilian workers whom the rebels accused of illicit enrichment.

title: EDUCATION Study Indicates Why Some Schools Succeed
description: LONDON WHAT makes a child learn? What keeps him from it? Is it the school building or the pupilteacher ratio? The mood of the classroom? The way the lessons are taught? Or, in the long run. do things like that really not Matter much, and is a child's academic fate determined instead by such factors as his race, his family's social class and the condition of his neighborhood?

title: Deaths
description: HIMELSONMax. Beloved husband of Bertha and the late Pauline. Father of the late Rudolph. FatherInlaw of Blanche Greenhut. Loving grandfather and greatgrandfather of Caren Cummings, Lois and Nicole Baron. Services today, 9:45 am at The Riverside', 1250 Central Avenue, Far Rockaway, Long Island.

title: Politics Is News in Peru as the Army Beats a Slow Retreat
description: LIMA, July 21  Here it is, read now, the new political Constitution of Peru, shouted a street peddler with an armful of booklets, at 50 cents each, containing the text of the charter adopted last week.

title: Cubs 9, Reds 8 Cubs 2, Reds 1
description: CHICAGO, July 23 (UPI)  Dave Kingman's tworun homer with none out in the bottom of the ninth inning today gave Chicago a 21 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. Earlier, the Cubs won the completion of a game that was suspended on Mav 10.98. in 18 innings.

title: Why Soime Athletes Play in Pain
description: Pain is an occupational hazard in professional sports. Players accept it, doctors treat it, and fans seem to admire those who endure it.

title: Objection from Mrs. Reagan
description: LOS ANGELES, July 23 (UPI) Nancy Reagan, the wife of former California Gov. Ronald Reagan, released a letter today that she wrote to Gov. Brown to protest his appointment of Mr. Miller, the former prisoner of war.

title: Books of The Times
description: ON a scale from 1 to 10, Tinsel rates about a minus 3 as lit7 erature. But I doubt if William Goldman was aspiring to literature.when he wrote it. The queition he would want us to ask is, Will Tinsel keep us awake at the beach? And the answer to that question is: probably. Some pretty awful things usually happen at the end of Mr. Goldman's novels, the most recent of which have been Marathon Man and Magic. And some pretty awful things happen at the end of Tinsel.
