title: TV: CBS News Takes a Look at Progress of Blacks
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago  the exact anniversary was in May  the Supreme Court of the United States outlawed, in unanimous decision, racial segregation in public schools. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 o'clock CBS News is attempting to measure the educational, political and social changes stemming from that historic decision. The first hour of Blacks in America: With All Deliberate Speed? returns to the rural South, to some small towns in Mississippi. Ed Bradley, the correspondent, describes the area as somewhere I never could have gone 25 years ago, as a reporter who is black, adding pointedly, even if CBS had hired me. The second program goes to Philadelphia, where Mr. Bradley grew up. That was 1954, he notes about the court decision, I was 13 years old then.

title: STUDY TIES OIL GIFTS TO VOTING IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Congressmen who received large campaign contributions from oil industry sources voted heavily for an amendment fast month that could save the oil industry more than $8.8 billion, according to a study released today by Congress Watch, a public affairs lobby associated with Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate.

title: Garner Cited for Hitting
description: Phil Garner of the Pittsburgh Pirates has been named the National League player of the week for the period ending July 22. Garner batted 409 during the week, shortened by the AllStar Game, collecting nine hits in 22 times at bats, including. three home runs.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, July 23  President Ferdinand E. Marcos named 10 new members to his Cabinet today and swore in 26 new generals in an apparent attempt to strengthen his regime as he wrestled with economic problems that he attributed to the world energy situation.

title: Pentagon Official Reports a New Racism
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)  The Pentagon's civil rights chief is concerned about a dramatic increase in manifestations of K.K.K. activity among offduty service personnel.

title: Leader of Reservation Takeover Gets 26 Years
description: ST. PAUL, Juiy 23 (AP)  The Indian leader of an armed takeover on the Red Lake Reservation in May was sentenced today to 26 years in prison for what al judge called a revolution of blatant lawlessness.

title: Kennedy Courts Blacks In Urban League Speech
description: CHICAGO, July 23  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, addressing a convention of the National Urban League today, aligned himself with black Americans on several issues of special importance to them.

title: Pan Am Increases National Holdings
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it had purchased 920,000 more shares of National Airlines. Pan Am is vying with Texas International Airlines and Eastern Air Lines for control of National.

title: U.S. CONDEMNS RAIDS BY ISRAELI PLANES ON LEBANESE COAST
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  The United States today condemned Israel's air attacks on the coast of Lebanon yesterday and also criticized the Israeli Government's rejection of a compromise proposal for a United Nations force to oversee the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty.

title: A Plan to Ship Caged Chimps To Texas by Truck Protested
description: Plans to ship a group of young chimpanzees from New York to San Antonio packed into small cages for 40hour truck trip have prompted protests from animalwelfare groups and from the scientist who has supervised the animals.

title: EARNINGS American Express Net Climbs
description: The American Express Company reported yesterday that it posted a 12.4 percent gain in secondquarter net income to $91.6 million, or $1.29 a share. from last year's net of $81.5 million, or $1.14 a share. Revenues advanced 12.7 percent to $1.15 billion from $1.02 billion, also reaching a new peak.

title: Carey Airport Buses Roll Again
description: Bus service provided by the Carey Transportation Company between Manhattan and Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports resumed yesterday as the drivers accepted a raise and ended their monthlong strike. The buses started to roll at 6 A.M. The company's general manager, Jim Giblin, said that parallel strike by 40 mechanics and other personnel had also ended.

title: John Bonanni, 72, Businessman And Yonkers Civic Leader, Dies
description: John Bonanni, a civic leader and businessman in Yonkers, died yesterday at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. He was 72 years old and a native of Philadelphia.

title: State Democrats
description: A reduction of black and Puerto Rican representation in the New York delegation to the Democratic National Convention next year nas been recommended by a subcommittee of the Democratic State Committee after it concluded that earlier statistics inflated the minority representation.

title: Takeovers Lift Standing Of Largest Black Bank
description: CHICAGO, July 23  Top officers at the Independence Bank of Chicago, the country's largest blackowned bank, are still beaming over the distinction bestowed on them a couple of weeks ago when they were asked by state and Federal regulators to make a takeover bid for two failing South Side banks.

title: Italian Communists Visit China; Possible Step to Renew Relations
description: PEKING, July 23  A delegation of journalists from the Italian Communist Party left China today at the end of a IS. day unofficial visit that sources here say may be the prelude to the re-establishment of normal relations between the Chinese party and the Italian party.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3544900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33903; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 94300; NASSAU CO. (516) T470500; SUFFOLK CO. (S16) 6591000; CONNECTICUT (203) 3467767.

title: MORATORIUM URGED ON NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 23  After long debate, participants at the World Council of Churches conference on science and religion called tonight for a fiveyear international moratorium on the construction of nuclear power plants.

title: The Inscrutable Steeplechase
description: MOSCOW, July 23 (UPI)  Some unintentional humor was injected into the Spartakiad Games today by two African runners from GuineaBissau, formerly known as Portuguese Guinea.

title: Deaths
description: ELLENBOGEN  Molly, We are grieved to record the passing of out devoted congregant and we extent heartfelt condolences to the be reaved family. NORMAN I. SCHAFLER, Pres. RABBI GUNTER HIRSCHBERG Congregation Rodeph Sholon

title: Couture Comes Alive As Fall Showings Open
description: PARIS, July 23  First, he sent down the runway the mannequins in the winecolored coats belted over narrow pants. Then Gerard Pipart moved into velvet suits and, at the end, bouffant dresses in rustling taffeta with big, puffed sleeves and taut bodices. The couture collections for fall 1979 were off to a brilliant start.

title: Truth in Testing
description: The intemperate responses of some academic testers to New York's truth-in-testing law are certain damage their cause more than the law itself. The associations that administer admission tests for medical and dental schools have threatened to pull out of New York, and the Educational Testing Service, the nation's biggest testing enterprise, has said it might curtail services. Doubtless, the law will require'more work on their part, and there will be added costs. But their complaints are overstated. In fact, the law is welcome; it's time to take the mystery out of college testing.

title: W. L. Dempsey, 84, ExPresident Of Division of Merck &
description: William L. Dempsey, retired president of Merck Sharp & Dohme, a division of Merck & Company, one of the nation's largest drug concerns, died Saturday at Chestnut Hill Hospital in Philadelphia. Mr. Dempsey, who lived in Philadelphia, was 84 years old.

title: COMMODITIES Bullion Futures at Highs; Other Key Products Slip
description: Gold futures prices again swept to record levels yesterday, but most other key commodities moved nervously up and down. closing with sharn declines Trading of Comex gold futures opened to the news that the dollar had weakened further in overseas money markets, that the open interest had increased and that the second London bullion fixing had left the metal at a record level of $304.90 an ounce, up $6.15 on the day.

title: Guilt Is a Recurring Theme in Literature and Drama
description: GUILT is the oldest theme in literature, a singular drama enacted in the soul of each person. Every enduring writer from Aeschylus to Mailer has at one time or another made guilt the center of a panoramic work.

title: Letters
description: President Carter's July 15 speech to the nation, to the extent that it dealt with the energy crisis, was riddled with inaccuracy and evasiveness, despite his assertion that the American people want honest answers, not easy or evasive ones. His view that we can substantially reduce our use of foreign oil over the next several years is highly misleading.

title: 200 Youths Hired to Aid Elderly in Crime Sectors
description: New York City has hired 200 young members of minority groups to operate a street patrol to protect elderly persons in highcrime areas during the summer by quickly reporting incidents to the police.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Contran Extends Its Tender Offer
description: The Contran Corporation, a diversified company in the farming and financial business, has extended to Aug. 17 its offer to buy its common shares at $50 each.

title: Deaths
description: MOR I SEY  A. Alexander. The Board of Directors and Officers of The Wlltwyct School mourm the loss of Alexander Morisey, husband of Dr. Patricia G. Morisey, long time Director on our Board. We express our heartfelt sympathy to her, the children and the family.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, JULY 24, 1979

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Beaths

title: RollCall on Busing Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)  Following is the rollcall vote by which the House today voted 216 to 209 to hill a proposed constitutional amendment that would have prohibited the use of busing to end racial segregation in schools. A yes vote is a vote in favor of the amendment. The amendment fell 75 votes short of the required twothirds majority in favor of it. An `xxx means not voting.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Peter the Great drank 21 glasses every morning before gulping down 12 figs and six pounds of cherries; Gloria Swanson not only drinks it but claims to have bathed in it; Alice Cooper serves it to his pet boa constrictor. Bottled water, that is, and the information was gleaned from an effervescent new book entitled The Book of Waters, which has hundreds of such facts and is lay-

title: Scientists and Theologians in Call For a Joint Effort to End Discord
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 24  Scientists and theologians today ended a twoweek World Council of Churches conference with a plea for a common effort to overcome discord between their two fields and to embark together on a broad search for truth.

title: Music: Spivakov's Violin
description: VLADIMIR SPIVAKOV is a violinist of a type that for an older generation of music listeners summons up the name of Leopold Auer. It was Auer, the great Russian teacher, who impressed his ideals of style and musicianship on Jascha Heifetz and Nathan Milstein, to name only two of his illustrious pupils, and whose approach to the instrument continues to epitomize the Russian school of violin playing.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Radio WINS, 8 P.M.)

title: Jay McShann at Michael's Pub
description: Jay McShane, a jazz pianist and singer who is an exponent of Kansas Citystyle blues, will begin a fourweek engagement at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, next Tuesday. The first of Mr. McShann's three nightly sets will start at 9:15.

title: SINAI OBSERVER PLAN IS DEFENDED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The United States defended its compromise plan for an interim United Nations force in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula today and denied that it was backing away from a pledge in March by President Carter to Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel.

title: MRS. GANDHI BACKS OPPONENT OF DESAI
description: NEW DELHI, July 24  A breakthrough in India's governmental impasse appeared closer today as key parties and independent members of Parliament announced commitments to the two men seeking to become Prime Minister.

title: Bail Reform:
description: WASHINGTON  The public is rightly concerned about current bail practices. Our bail procedures pose an unnecessary threat to community safety. Most Federal and state bail statutes now specify that in deciding whether to permit a suspect's release on bail, judges must consider only wnat is necessary to secure the suspect's appearance at trial. Flight is the only stated test. The law does not permit a judge to consider the defendant's potential danger to the community in reaching the bail, decision.

title: ABCTV Gaining on Other Networks in News Field
description: ABCTV has been the most popular entertainment network for three years, but has not been able to claim overall leadership in television because it continues to run last in news and public affairs, as it has for 25 years.

title: Barnard Hughes Offers Advice on Craft of Acting
description: Barnard Hughes, the lovable old codger of Doc and Da fame, met with an auditorium full of young actors yesterday at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts and emerged, as he is wont to do, with the audience in the palm of his hand.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ON a recent sunny weekday, writes Silas Snider, a brand new truck with a completely white paint job stopped momentarily at 28th Street and Park. Avenue South. Despite its apparent newness, it was already suffering the indignity of defacement by the spraycan gang.

title: Andrus Assails Senate Bill Easing Curbs on Land Irrigated by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The Carter Administration today attacked a Senate proposal that would remove most restrictions on the ownership and use of land irrigated with cheap Federal water.

title: Books of TheTirnes
description: AGOOD first novel makes us feel patriotic. What a fine country this is, we say to ourselves after finishing it. Crammed with talent, one generation after the next, in spite of everything. If we can inspire a book like this, we can't he all bad

title: How to Stop Ducking the PAC Problem
description: Most people have no trouble recognizing the PAC problem: political action committees for special interests have been contributing increasing millions to Congressional campaigns  and amassing increasing political wallop. The hangup has been over how to solve the problem.

title: June Orders Of Durables Down 1.1%
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) New orders received by the nation's factories for durable goods sluMped 1.1 percent in June from a month earlier, with much of the decline attributed to poor auto and truck sales, the Goverment reported today.

title: Associated Press
description: OUTLESS TAG: Mets JOhn Stearns colliding with Giants catcher, Marc Hill, as he scored during second inning last night in San Francisco. Stearns was safe when umpire ruled that Hill did not have possCsion of the ball long enough after he made the tag. Hill was injured in the play and left the game in the third inning.

title: Gulf Oil Raises Net By 65.3%
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, the nation's fifthlargest oil company, reported yesterday that it had a 65.3 percent profit rise for the second quarter, and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) reported a 70.1 percent increase.

title: Best Buys
description: ANEWLY imported French wine vinegar has made Its way to Manhattan from the factory of Martin Pouret in Orleans and is on sale through Sunday at all Pottery Barn stores. The ambercolored white wine vinegar has the aroma of freshpicked green peppercorns, and it is a perfect companion for thinly sliced salmon, smothered in dill.

title: U.S. Was No. 8 In 1978 Wealth
description: ZURICH, July 24 (AP)  The decline of the dollar in 1978 caused the United States to drop to eighth place last year in a list of the world's wealthiest countries, a Swiss bank said today. The Union Bank said Switzerland moved into the top spot in the ranking by gross national product per capita, passing oilrich Kuwait. last year's leader.

title: Liberia: More Akin to U.S. Than to O.A.U.
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 22 Some delegates to the Organization of African Unity meeting, which wound up its business here Saturday, were amused by such Liberian peculiarities as the fact that the American greenback, limp and brown from use, is the national currency, or that Monrovia's finest wear castoff New York City police uniforms. Until a few years ago, George Washington was the police chief.

title: S.E.C. Censures Blyth
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The Securities and Exchange Commission censured Blyth, Eastman, Dillon & Company today and suspended the prominent Wall Street brokerage firm from marketmaking activities in three over-the-counter stocks for five days.

title: Beaths
description: ACKERMAN-Charles. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Paul and Lynne. Dear brother of Ruth, Robert and Boris. Adored grandfather of Douglas, Jody, Wendy and Kevin. Services Wednesday 12 Noon The Riverside, Bklyn. Ocean Pkwy at Prospect Park

title: Urban League Links Blacks
description: CHICAGO, July 24  Five national recessions in the last 2.5 years have helped widen the economic gap between white and black Americans, according to studies made by the National Urban League.

title: TV and Radio to Carly Carter'sNews Session
description: President Carter's news conference at 9 o'clock tonight in the East Room of the White House will be carried live by the three television networks, their affiliated radio networks, National Public Radio and the Mutual Broadcasting System. The Public Broadcasting Serv- ice will transmit a videotape at a later hour to public television stations.

title: PRESIDENT ACCEPTS A DELAY UNTIL FALL ON ENERGY PACKAGE
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  President Carter told Congressional leaders today that he would be satisfied if his energy legislation package was not approved until fall as long as the proposals were not seriously weakened.

title: British Unemployment
description: LONDON, July 24 (AP)  Britain's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate this month was unchanged at 5.3 percent of the nation's work force, the Department of eMployment said today. The number of jobless totaled 1.3 million.

title: Beekeeper Settles For Hive's Queen
description: Spurred into action by a nonprofit private group known as the Central Park Community Fund, the city moved in yesterday on a giant swarm of bees in Central Park.

title: Israel Reports Its Troops Strike Deep in Lebanon
description: TEL AVIV, July 24  The Israeli military command announced today that a troop detachment drove five miles into Lebanon last night and blew up a building used by Palestinian terrorists. The raid was at Majdal Islim, in the area of operations of the Irish battalion in the United Nations peacekeeping force.

title: About Real Estate Commercial Abatements Debated as Market Improves
description: About Real Estate Commercial Abatements Debated as Market Improves

title: Algae Are Found Thriving Under Lake Ice in Antarctic
description: Divers exploring for, the first time the underice environment of two freshwater lakes in Antarctica have discovered algae growing near the bottom that thrive on less sunlight than any other known plants, the National Science Foundation has announced.

title: Pay Limit Exception Considered
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The Council on Wage and Price Stability said today that it was leaning toward granting an exception to its voluntary limits on wage increases to employees who raise their productivity by additional work effort.

title: Joseph Kessel, Author And Newspaperman; Was a de Gaulle Aide
description: Joseph Kessel, the French journalist and author who wrote the novel Belle de Jour, died Monday at his home outside Paris, his family announced yesterday. He was 81 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed.

title: Citicorp Auction Rate Up
description: Citicorp reported that the average rate on its 91day auction paper rose yesterday to 10.354 percent  the highest level since Jan. 23  from 10.133 percent last week. The bank holding company received $720 million of bids for the $150 million of notes that it sold, with those accepted ranging in rate from 10.295 to 10.360 percent. Citicorp said it would auction $150 million more next Tuesday.

title: The Faith of a Planner
description: Rexford Guy Tugwell, one of the three original braintrusters of President Franklin Roosevelt's first Administration, died last weekend at the age of 88, not having written a controversial book since he was 81. A professor of economics at Columbia when called to Washington, Mr. Tugwell never relinquished his faith in solving problems by longrange planning. In a time when planning has come to mean listening constantly to what people say they want and then constantly modifying plans to accommodate their disapproval, that faith in central direction seems almost quaint.

title: An Airport Kennel
description: The A.S.P.C.A. operates an Animalport at Kennedy International Airport for pets whose owners are in transit. The animal may be dropped off at the kennel any time of the day or night, seven days a week, or at an A.S.P.C.A. shelter in one of the five boroughs from 8:30 A.M. to 4 P.M., six days a week. There is no charge for transporting . the animal from the shelter to the Animilport. The A.S.P.C:A. will pick up and return an animal to its home for $15 each way.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Price Rises Again; Dollar Continues Down
description: Gold prices continued to move up yesterday, hitting a record of more than $307 an ounce at one point in European trading, while the United States dollar sank further in skittish foreignexchange activity around the world.

title: Hardee's Gets Financing
description: Hardee's Food Systems Inc. has concluded a $69 million longterm financing agreement with a group of large banks and insurance companies. The company said the proceeds would go to development of companyoperated restaurants and remodeling of existing restaurants.

title: Mets Score 2 in 12th To Defeat Giants. 65
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 24  Lee Mazzilli left the hospital today with lingering amnesia, a headache, a cut cheekbone and a black eye  mementos of his spectacular outfield collision with Dan Norman  and flew home to New York to await the return of the Mets.

title: The Conversion of Bookmasters
description: ONE day, it seemed, what had been the somewhat familiar Bookmasters chain of mainly paperback stores suddenly acquired the name Barnes & Noble.

title: F.B.I. Criticizes Television Crew In Ransom Drop
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and William Dedrick, husband of the New Jersey woman kidnapped last weekend, both charged yesterday that the woman's life had been endangered by the actions of a New York television crew that followed and filmed Mr. Dedrick's movements before he dropped off the $217,000 in ransom money that bought the release of his wife.

title: Finances Snarl Alaskan Gas
description: LOS. ANGELES, July 20  The huge effort to develop and distribute natural gas from Alaska's North Slope to ease the nation's energy pinch has gained important encouragement from President Carter.

title: Joint Chiefs Affirm Pact Support, But Stress Need for More Spending
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The Joint Chiefs of Staff reiterated today their support of the arms treaty with the Soviet Union. But one of them, the Chief of Naval Operations, said that, if the United States did not have the will to match Soviet military spending, he saw no value in the treaty and would not recommend its approval by the Senate.

title: Maxwell Geismar, Book Critic, Author and Editor, Dead at 69
description: Makwell Geismar, literary critic, author and editor, died of a heart ailment yesterday at his home in Harrison, N.Y. He would have been 70 years old next Wednesday.

title: News of the Theater Kert Determined: Jolson on Broadway
description: LARRY KERT is determined to play Al Jolson  again. He has already portrayed the legendary entertainer once this year. He starred last spring in a shortlived musical called Joley, which had what was billed as a preBroadway run on Long Island at the Northstage Theater. When it became apparent that Joley had no chance of leaving Long Island, Mr. Kert and his producer, Jeff Britton, started over with a different set of collaborators and have now come up with a new production tentatively called Al Jolson Tonight.

title: JobTraining Schools Grow AlongWith Cries of Abuses
description: New York State's 385 licensed private vocational schools  known for their subway and latenight television advertisements promising a key to the exciting world of computers or personal security as an executive secretary  are growing rapidly. And with that growth has come increased controversy over how they should be reaulated.

title: Economic Scene
description: THROUGHOUT his long career as an economic adviser, John Maynard Keynes sought to demonstrate that the government, faced with an economic crisis, need not stand by helplessly. A correct analysis of the problem, he believed, would always suggest some effective course of action the government could take.

title: Music in Art on Display At 42d Street Library
description: More than 80 woodcuts, engravings, etchings and lithographs depicting the world of music during the last five centuries, will be on view through October in the thirdfloor Print Gallery of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: House May Reduce Amtrak Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The House of Representatives defeated tonight a move to postpone for a year any reduction in Amtrak service, but appeared poised to enact tomorrow a bill that would reject the deep cuts advocated by the Carter Administration.

title: U.N. to Pull Out Sinai Peace Unit; Unarmed Officers to Oversee Pact
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24 The Security Council agreed today to withdrawal of the United Nations peacekeeping force separating Egyptian and Israeli forces in Sinai, but it acted to insure that a corps of military observers would .stay on to monitor Israel's withdrawal from the peninsula.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: DESPITE claims coming from the direction of Madison Ave. nue, we all know full well that freshly squeezed orange juice

title: Advertising3M Adds Stagni Unit From Italy
description: THE Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, or at least its Italian subsidiary, has just acquired Stagni Comunicazioni Visive of Bologna, once again proving the 3M theory that one thing leads to another.

title: Prints Are Lifted at Vault Where $600,000 Vanished
description: Investigators into the weekend disappearance of $600,000 in subway receipts at New York City Transit Authority headquarters reported yesterday that fingerprints had been taken from the vault area, which is guarded around the clock by transit policemen.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Profits Scoreboard in Business Day on Friday incorrectly named the Continental Group Inc. instead of the Continental Corporation as having reported a 24.8 percent drop in secondquarter earnings. The Continental Group reported a 4.5 percent decline for the quarter.

title: Piano: Dick Wellstood
description: DICK WELLSTOOD bemoans the fact that he is the man with the shrinking repertory. For concert purposes, the pianist once learned a lot of the 1920's piano compositions of Zez Con- Frey, Roy Bargy, Rube Bloom and others, becoming something of a specialist in this postragtime piano style. But, because he has not played that program in some time, he finds that each year I remember less and less.

title: Alexander Morisey, 65, Times ExPublicity Aide
description: A. Alexander Morisey, a former manager of public relations for The New York Times, died of cancer Monday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AFRICAN SUN (Farrell Lines). Dakar August 3, Monrovia 6, Buchanan 10, Abidjan 12, Tema 14, Lagos 17, Matadi 21, Douala 25 and Abidjan 29; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: GOING OUT Giude
description: FREUD ON 42d Six years ago, an adaptation of Edgar Lee Masters's Spoon River Anthology, which recreated the lives in a small turn-of-thecentury New England village, launched the South Street Theater Company in its downtown pier setting, under the auspices of the Seaport Museum. The play drew acclaim and ran for 12 weeks, surpassed only by the company's waterside staging of Herman Melville's Moby Dick.

title: Business Records
description: DOROTHY L. GRAVES, 333 Bronx River Road, Von. kers. Liabilities, 527,691; assets, 53,275.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: To Philadelphians at least, the resignation this week of John R. Bunting Jr. as head of the First Pennsylvania Corporation has substantial meaning beyond his leadership of the citys largest bank.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Broken Clouds, including widely scattered thunderstorm clouds, extend from the East Coast to the Rockies and the Texas Panhandle. Spiraling clouds associated with tropical storm Claudette are visible in the northern Gulf of Mexico and along the Gulf Coast. Mostly clear skies are apparent elsewhere.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: RYE, N.Y., July 24  John Gentile of Birchwood shot a two-under-par 70 over the west course of the Westchester Country Club today to win the pro honors In the 36th annual Hoffhine Memorial golf tournament.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings jumped 19.7 percent in the second quarter on a 13.3 percent increase in revenues.

title: MidJuly Car Sales Down By 9.7%, but G.M. Gains
description: DETROIT, July 24 (UPI)  Domestic auto makers sold 9.7 percent fewer cars in midJuly than a year earlier, although the General Motors Corporation, the industry leader, managed to escape the downturn.

title: An 8-Year-oldTruant And a Family's Despair
description: The way Diana, who is 8 years old, knows it is summer is that the fire hydrant on the corner is open and from her Window she can watch it splash relief onto the hot pavement. Other than that, Diana's life is very much the same as it is the rest of the year.

title: U. S. Completes Appeal in Chile For the Extradition of 3 in Killing
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24  A Chilean criminal lawyer representing the United States today completed a forceful appeal before the Supreme Court for the extradition of three Chilean Army officers linked to the murder of the exile leader Orlando Letelier in Washington.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have used the same wok for about eight years. Recently I have noticed that when I dry it, a black rusty residue appears on the paper towel. This stain disturbs me and I assume that it goes into the food during cooking. Should I reseason it or replace it? The wok is obviously not stainlesssteel.

title: Wuxtry! The Story No One Dares to Tell!
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 24  Almost everybody seems to be wondering these days why President Carter lost his way recently, but the answer is fairly obvious.

title: 2 File Pleas of Not Guilty In Bedford Hills Murders
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 24  Two suspects in the May 10 murders of four Bedford Hills residents pleaded not guilty in Westchester County Court today to a 40count indictment charging them with murder, robbery and burglary.

title: HUNT FOR SUCCESSOR TO MILLER NARROWS
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  President Carter has received a short list of recommended candidates for the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve Board and is expected to choose one soon, White House officials said today.

title: TV: Echoes of 60's,
description: ECHOES of the 60's is a scrapbook posing as an anthology. Subtitled A Musical Trip, the twohour tour of a tumultuous decade can be seen tonight, beginning after President Carter's 9 o'clock speech, on NBCTV.

title: Defendant's Screaming Outburst Interrupts Trial on Park Assaults
description: The trial of three men accused of assault in Central Park was interrupted yesterday when one of them jumped out of his chair and started screaming obscenities about homosexuals. The out, burst was apparently caused by his mother falling to the floor in the courtroom during the reading of his confession.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ALTHOUGH avocados are no novelty today in the metropolitan areas of France, they were a rarity in my youth there. The first time I recall seeing an avocado  they are known in French avocats  was after my arrival in America during the New York World's Fair in 1939, and they seemed wholly exotic.

title: 2 Synanon Members Are Ordered To Trial Over Rattlesnake Attack
description: LOS ANGELES, July 24 (UPI)  Sufficient evidence exists to try two members of the Synanon organization on charges that they conspired to murder .a lawyer with a rattlesnake, a Municipal Court judge ruled today.

title: U.S. Urges OPEC Role In Court
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (Reuters) The Federal Government urged the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today to appear in a United States court and defend its interests against charges of illegal price fixing.

title: Deaths
description: MARKSRobert G., M.D.The doctor's Alumni Association of Beth Is rael Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of one of its valued members. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his family.

title: U.S. Judge Gives Public Access to Nixon's Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)  A Federal judge today approved the Government's plans to make public former President Richard M. Nixon's White House tapes, including those dealing with Watergate, at up to 11 listening centers lacross the country.

title: Bundy Guilty of Murders Of Two Florida Women
description: MIAMI, July 24  A Jury of seven men and five women found Theodore R. Bundy guilty last night of firstdegree murder in the slayings of two sorority, members at Florida State University. They had deliberateCsbc and a half hours.

title: Lois Burpee,
description: IT'S not surprising that Lois Burpee has achieved a reputation as a cook. She's the wife of a scion of the seed company Whose sprouts have nourished more than a couple generations of Americans. The name Burpee is to seeds what Ford is to automobiles and Heinz is to ketchup.

title: F.C.C. Ending Gannett Study
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)  The Federal Communications Commission says it plans no further action in connection with its study of the consolidation of the Gannett Company and the Combined Communications Corporation.

title: Explosion on Damaged Tanker Spills Burning Oil Into Atlantic
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, July 24 An explosion described by salvage experts as moderate ripped open a rear compartment of the supertanker Atlantic Empress last night, spilling burning oil onto her deck and across the sea's surface for more than half a mile.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  The New Rochelle office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun a preliminary investigation into the fatal shooting of an 18-year-old man from New Rochelle last Thursday by a police officer in the neighboring village of Pelham Manor.

title: McGrawEdison to Make Cash Bid for Studebaker
description: In what would be one of the biggest allcash transactions in recent years, the McGrawEdison Company and StudebakerWorthington Inc. announced jointly yesterday that McGrawEdison planned to acquire all the outstanding shares of Studebaker for about $724 million.

title: The Agony of Vietnam Refugee Boat 0105
description: PASIR BAYAT, Indonesia, July 19 They threw their dead overboard with enough regularity to attract a constant escort of sharks.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (Reuters) The Atlantic Richfield Company today settled antitrust charges brought by the Federal Trade Commission involving its purchase of the Anaconda Copper Company in 1977. Under the settlement, which had been under negotiation since earlier in the year, Arco agreed to divest an estimated $473 million to $573 million of its copper interests.

title: Yanks Win, 65, On Piniella's Hit
description: On the first anniversary of his tearful resignation as manager of the Yankees, Billy Martin suffered some anxious moments last night, but Lou Piniella and Ron Davis combined to make this July 24 much happier than last July 24.

title: Eastern Net Up 7.9%
description: Eastern Air Lines reported yesterday that it posted record second-quarter profits of $26.1 million, or 99 cents a share, up 7.9 percent from the former high of $24.2 million, or $1.15 share on fewer shares outstanding, reached in the comparable 1978 period.

title: Scientists Predict That Big Oil Slick In Gulf of Mexico Won't Hit Texas
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., July 24 Government scientists, having completed their first detailed survey of the huge oil slick from a runaway well in the Gulf of Mexico, said today that they expected the slick's leading edge to reach United States waters in 10 to 14 days. They predicted, however, that the oil would remain offshore.

title: Braniff Orders 747
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex., July 24 (UPI) Braniff International said today that it had ordered a Boeing 747 SP airliner for $55.5 million for delivery in September 1980. Braniff is to take delivery of another 747 SP in October and has on order more than 32 large Boeing aircraft at an outlay of $808.5 million.

title: Edwin Lanham, Writer of Novels
description: Edwin Lanham, a novelist, mystery writer and former New York newspaperman, died yesterday at his home in Clinton, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: Ford's Net Off in U.S., Up Abroad
description: DETROIT, July 24  The Ford Motor Company's domestic earnings for the second quarter were cut in half, the company reported today, while its profits from operations outside North America leaped by more than 57 percent. Ford earned more.than twice as much abroad as it did at home.

title: Jackson Decries Cabinet Upheaval And Says Kennedy Will Run in 80
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  Senator Henry M. Jackson, asserting that last week's Cabinet shakeup had given an image of instability to the Carter Administration, predicted today that President Carter's chances for renomination by the Democratic Party would be very, very difficult.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, July 16, to Sunday, July 22), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS. After Caramanlis
description: ATHENS  Five years have come and gone since the Greek regime disintegrated and left to the politicians the task of bringing the country, back to normality. This was achieved . in record time, thanks principally to the maturity of the Greek people who welcomed back democracy in a peaceful and forgiving mood.

title: Nijinsky's Diary Is Sold
description: LONDON, July 24  The handwritten, partly suppressed diary of Vaslav Nijinsky, perhaps the greatest ballet dancer who ever lived, was sold to an Oxfordshire book dealer for $104,692 in a packed Sotheby Parke Bernet auction room today.

title: Kennels: Can a Pet Feel at Home?
description: Olly, an English sheepdog, clutched Scott Berger at the waist with his front paws. Mr. Berger, trying to extricate himself, made reassuring sounds. 01ly was not reassured, and made troubledanimal sounds. 01ly well knew he was about to be boarded while Mr. Berger, a mens clothier, went on a combination vacationbusiness trip.

title: Ransom Search Pressed in Kidnapping
description: PATERSON, N.J., July 24  The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today it still had not found the $217,000 in ransom paid for the release of the wife of a New Jersey bank executive held for 42 hours by kidnappers.

title: Maine Island Jilts Central Electricity After Mild Flirtation
description: MONHEGAN, Me., July 22  Perhaps the biggest news out of Monhegan this century came earlier this year, when it was reported that the residents of this tiny island 11 miles out to sea were flirting with the idea of electrification.

title: Three Hurt After Fiery FiveVehicle Collision
description: Tractortrailer trucks burned on a roadway linking the George Washington Bridge and the Alexander Hamilton Bridge early yesterday morning after they slammed into a disabled station wagon that had collided earlier with a motorcycle. Flames were fed by gasoline: from the ruptured fuel tanks of the vehicles. Rushhour commuter traffic was disrupted for several hours.

title: 7th Fleet Ship Saves 19 Refugees
description: HONOLULU, July 24  An oiler assigned to the United States Seventh Fleet rescued 19 Indochinese refugees from a small open boat in the South China Sea yesterday about 370 miles west of Subic Bay in the Philippines, the Pacific Naval Headquarters in Hawaii announced today.

title: Reds Get an Out on 2d Try
description: PITTSBURGH, July 24 (UPI)  The Cincinnati Reds left the field for 34 minutes in the bottom of the fourth inning of their game with the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight, claiming that they had retired the side in a confusing baserunning sequence at second base.

title: Minimizing the Blackmail in Graymail
description: Sometimes the demands of national security clash with the demands of justice. Suppose the Government wants to prosecute a suspected spy but the defendant claims he can't get a fair trial unless the Government agrees to expose certain secrets. Graymail, the C.I.A. calls it. It's not blackmail, exactly, but it certainly involves some painful pressure. Thus prosecutions that would strengthen security by deterring espionage sometimes have to be abandoned because keeping secrets is even more important than convicting spies.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter said a fall timetable for approving his energy legislation would be satisfactory, provided the measures were not. weakened. At a breakfast meeting with Democratic Congressional leaders, he stressed that the windfall profits tax on which financing for the entire program depends'ought not be reduced. [Page A1.]

title: Youth of 14 Being Tried in Murder, Youngest Such Defendant in State
description: As he has since his trial began a week earlier, the youngest person ever prosecuted for murder in New York State sat impassively through the procedings yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: Careers
description: FROM the spirituality of nuns at the College of St. Elizabeth, Convent Station, N.J., to the fine art of war seems an unlikely switch. But that is exactly what Jacquelin J. Kelly did. She earned a B.A. degree from the col- lege in 1953 and now is Lieutenant Colonel Kelly, professor of military science at West Virginia University, with a staff of 12 Army personnel reporting to her.

title: A Right and a Wrong Jab at Israel
description: The United States took two swings at Israel this week, denouncing its indiscriminate air raids against Lebanon and deploring its refusal to let an element of the United Nations monitor the peace with Egypt. In ways that the State Department apparently failed to understand, one reproach undercut the effectiveness of the other. You do not dissuade an anguished nation from committing rash acts on one front by urging them on another. The first objective of the United States in the Middle East these days must be,to prepare the Israelis for further accommodations with their neighbors. That is hardly served by facile American accommodations to Soviet obstruction of the peacemaking.

title: Bridge:
description: A bridge player does not need a poker face, and nor indeed does a poker player. What they both need is a uniform demeanor that will not give useful information to the opposition, or in the case of the bridge player, improper information to a partner.

title: Traveling Panel Hears Discharge Appeals by Veterans
description: Hunched forward in his chair, his back muscles tense under his vested blue suit, James A. Long, a 41-year-old mailman from Brooklyn, appealed to the five Army officers facing him to understand the circumstances that had led to his undesirable discharge from the Army 19 years ago.

title: REV. W. WALLACE SPIEGEL
description: The Rev. W. Wallace Spiegel, assistant to the pastor of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., died Sunday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital after being injured in an automobile accident several weeks ago. He was 40 years old and lived in New Canaan.

title: Oil Racketeering Charges Dismissed
description: HOUSTON, July 24 (AP)  A Federal judge has dismissed a second indictment in Which oil companies were charged with violating the Federal racketeering statute

title: 3 Men Charged in Gambling Raid; $1-Milliona-Day Handle Alledged
description: Three men convicted and fined for booking bets from a Manhattan office building two months ago were arrested last night on charges of conducting a similar operation in a midtown buildine.

title: Amendment to Ban Pupil Busing Is Defeated by House, 216 to 209
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The House of Representatives today defeated a proposed constitutional amendme4. that would ban busing as a way of desegregating public schools.

title: Rhodesian Election Is Challenged By Party That Won Only 12 Seats
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, July 24 (AP)  The Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, whose party finished second among black parties in April's elections for parliament, formally asked the High Court yesterday to rule the results invalid.

title: Cabbies Hostile as Mayor Initiates. Sharing of Taxis From La Guardia
description: Group taxi riding to Manhattan froni La Guardia Airport began yesterday with a mixed reception from riders and open hostility from cab drivers.

title: Periled Chesapeake Bay
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md  The fate of the aquatic resources of Chesapeake Bay, which constitutes the largest and most productive estuary in North America, is now up to the Secretary of the Army, Clifford L. Alexander Jr. He must decide whether to issue or. deny a permit for a proposed .Portsmith, Va., oil refinery; the Brit such facility to be situated on the bay.

title: Francis Christy, Retired Attorney
description: After graduating from Dartmouth College and the Harvard Law School, Mr. Christy began his career with the firm of Murray, Aldrich & Webb, predecessor of the Manhattan firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy. In 1929 he wrote The Transfer of Stock, an authoritative book on how corporate stock transfers are made. The book is now in its fifth edition.

title: Toon Says He Supports Strategic Arms Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (Reuters) Malcolm Toon, the outgoing Ambassador to the Soviet Union, said on the NBC Today television show that he was satisfied by explanations he has been given on verification of the arms treaty and would support it.

title: 2 Company Officials Testified They Made Cash Payoffs to Scotto
description: Two waterfront company officials in New York City have secretly pleaded guilty to conspiracy and have sworn they gave illegal cash payoffs to Anthony M. Scotto, a top leader of the International Longshoremen's Association, who is awaiting trial on Federal racketeering charges.

title: Partners
description: Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, a leading New York law firm, was reported yesterday to be facing a minor revolt by some younger partners seeking a larger share of the profits.

title: Annette Lummis, Aunt Of Howard Hughes, 88
description: Annette Gano Lummis, an aunt of Howard Hughes and coexecutor, with her son, of the Hughes estate, died yesterday at the Diagnostic Center Hospital in Houston. She was 88 years old and lived in Houston.

title: Market Place
description: THE Itel Corporation, which had been a Wall Street favorite on success achieved in part through the aggressive use of other people's money, is finding that the leverage pendulum swings both ways.

title: Eyeing What Goes
description: Contrary to what most concerned consumers tend to believe, everything that artificially keeps processed foods looking or tasting fresh does not cause cancer. Nor does every chemical concoction that substitutes for natural food additives.

title: Merzei Named President At Occidental Petroleum
description: An abrupt change in the line of succession at the Occidental Petroleum Corporation occurred yesterday with the announcement that the vice chairman, Zoltan Merzei, had been elected nresident and chief oneratinv officer

title: The City
description: Richard L. Herriott, 90 years old, and Donald Irwin 3d, 39, both of Dover, Mass., were indicted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on charges they had bilked New York banks out of more than $1 million.

title: Israeli Border Life: Vigilance Is Routine
description: QIRYAT SHEMONA, Israel, July 18  Darkness comes swiftly in the stony hills of Upper Galilee. The guard towers and the rolls of barbed wire that surround every town and kibbutz in this, region near the Lebanese border begin to lose their ugliness at dusk:Strings of lights go on along the perimeters of settlements, and from a . high distance, they look like bracelets scattered across waves of black velvet.

title: Stocks Advance, With Airline Issues Leading Way
description: Airline stocks helped to lead the market higher yesterday as more than a million shares changed hands for the second consecutive day in National Airlines. The stock price of National, a carrier that has been wooed by three corporate suitors, was unchanged at 491,4.

title: Wine Talk
description: FOR a lot of people, myself included, a wine doesn't truly come to life until they know something about the region where it is produced and the people who make it. The Rioja is a good example. Thanks to an aggressive public relations campaign _and everincreasing French wine prices, these excellent Spanish wines have become fairly well known in the United States. But aside from the little map on the labels of most of the bottles, no one knows much about the region or the people who make wine there.

title: Olive Oil That's Made The Old Way In Provence
description: ALTHOUGH olive oil is made and used in almost every country that faces the Mediterranean Sea, the world's moat delicate and subtly elegant is produced in southern France, in that sundrenched flower garden that is Provence. Even here, however. the making of olive

title: Around the Nation
description: SOLEDAD, Calif., July 24 (AP)  Sirhan B. Sirhan was granted a fourmonth reduction in his life prison sentence today after the convicted assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy told a parole board that he had been offered asylum in Libya.

title: Five Funds Sell M.A.C. Bonds, Turning a Profit
description: New York City's five pension funds sold more than $53 million of their Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds yesterday to Citibank, making a profit of nearly $1.5 million.

title: CBS Tops in TV Ratings
description: The Major League AllStar Game last Tuesday night was the No. 1 television program of the week, averaging 95 percent of the audience for the four hours of its broadcast. Nevertheless, NBCTV, which carried the game, finished third for the week. The network averages were CBSTV 14.7, ABCTV 14.5 and NBC 13.9:

title: Events Today
description: FILMMOBILE, Glen Oaks Oval, 260in Street and 74th Avenue, Queens, after dark.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Beaths

title: Polaroid Earnings Down
description: Despite slightly higher sales, net earnings of the Polaroid Corporation in the second quarter fell 49.2 percent to $13.3 million, or 40 cents a share, from $26.2 million, or 80 cents a share. earned in the similar three months last year, the photographic equipment producer reported yesterday. It was the worst showing since the 1974 second quarter when earnings fell to 7 cents a share from 26 cents a year before caused by heavy costs for the introduction of the SX70 during that recession period.

title: Vocational Schools First Licensed by State in 1937
description: Owners of private vocational schools like to point out that long before the advent of public higher education, profitmaking English schools (in contrast to Latin schools) were offering practical vocational training.

title: Fashion Fuels the Eyeglass Business
description: Some say the trend started with the wirerimmed granny glasses popular in the late 1960's and with the oversized aviator glasses worn by Gloria Steinem, the feminist advocate, among others. Others believe that it started with the bigeyed sunglasses worn at the beginning of this decade by such public figures as Jacqueline Onassis.

title: For Somoza's Envoy to the U.S., End of Party as Diplomats
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)  For Guillermo SevillaSacasa, the Somoza dynasty's Ambassador to the United States, the party is over.

title: Pop: The Asbury Jukes
description: SOUTHSIDE JOHNNY and the Asbury Jukes, who appeared Monday night at the Dr Pepper Music Festival in Central Park for the third consecutive year, have a strone local cult. and they resnond to that cult with a real brio. Even with a new record label and the addition of a permanent horn section, the Jukes remain rather a known quantity. They make crisp, enthusiastic music in a rock and rhythm-and-blues vein, and like any good bar band, they convey the impression they are having an unqualified good time.

title: COMMODITIES Gold Futures Still Climb, But Some See Softness
description: Although gold futures advanced a further $1.10 to $1.50 an ounce, with the near months strongest, on New York's Commodity Exchange yesterday, several brokers detected a weakening of the market. In London, cash prices rose another 35 cents to a new high of $305.25, based on the second and final fixina there.

title: Soviet Press Studiously Ignoring Hearings on Arms Pact
description: MOSCOW, July 24  The Soviet press is giving scanty coverage to Senate committee hearings on the strategic arms treaty. Knowledgeable Soviet sources say the Kremlin does not want to appear to be trying to intervene. Americans and adding an occasional reminder that the treaty has its opponents. But the give-and-take in the Senate committee hearings goes largely unreported.

title: Deaths
description: STERNLewis. Warmest memory to our colleague and friend. A noted philologist and semanticist. Your children Richard, William and Tamara are desolate with your loss.

title: HERBERT A. NICKEL
description: Herbert A. Nickel, former vice president of the Marine Midland Bank in Manhattan, died yesterday at the Flushing Medical Center in Queens. He was 77 years old and lived in Flushing.

title: A Chinese Is Killed in a ClaA on the Soviet Frontier
description: MOSCOW, July 24  China and the Soviet Union said today that a Chinese was killed in a border clash on July 16, but each accused the other of having violated the border and caused the incident.

title: U.S. Accepts Nicaragua Regime By Agreeing to Let Ties Continue
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  The United States and Nicaragua agreed today to continue diplomatic relations, with Washington in effect recognizing the new Government in Managua exactly a week after President Anastasio Somoza Debayle left for exile in Miami.

title: Peasant Leader Vying for Poiver in India
description: NEW DELHI, July 24  In Indian political life, where. undisguised ambition and aloofness are not political handicaps, Chaudhury Charan Singh is one of the stars.

title: House Passes A Delay of Ban For Saccharin
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)  The House voted today to allow diet beverages and foods containing the artificial sweetener saccharin to remain on the market for two more years.

title: The Best of Cookies, the Worst of Cookies
description: WITH the introduction of Famous Amos in 1970, there developed a market for expensive chocolatechip cookies. The luxury nackaeed cookie has lately given way to the seemingly more homespun, freshbaked variety. In New York, cookies have become almost as ubiquitous as the bagel; storefronts are cookie dispensaries, cookie wagons ply the avenues and department stores are getting into the fresh cookie business. One conservative estimate put cookie sales at hundreds of thousands a week. The cookie war is on - but, in most cases, we are not being bombarded by taste or quality.

title: Track and Field
description: 400-Meter Run  1, Marisa Kulchonova, Soviet Union, 49.77 seconds; 2, Nine Zyuskova, Soviet Union, 0:50.42; 3, Tatyana Galshik, Soviet Union, 0:50.49; 1, Irina Bagrl. anceva, Soviet Union, 0:50.52; 5, Tatyana Prorochenko, Soviet Union, 0:51; 6, Marina Sidorova, Soviet Union, 0:51.17; 7, Sharon Dabney, U.S..0:51.88.

title: Kelley of Giants Ends Holdout, but Is Bitter
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 24 Brian Kelley ended his holdout, signed a contract for a 10 percent raise and then held out hope today that the Giants would tear it up and give him a new one.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 25, 1979

title: Carter Receives British Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)  President Carter today accepted the credentials of Sir Nicholas Henderson, the new Ambassador from Britain. In a brief exchange of remarks in the Oval Office, Mr. Carter joked that United States ties to Britain were so well known it would be a waste of my time to tell everyone here about them.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: IT was the way these things are always done  a fashionable gathering place, some weighty names, a bit to drink, a few nibbles of food, and then the rah, rah announcement. Another charity benefit had taken off.

title: Paris: A Peplum and Puffed Sleeve Revival
description: PARIS, July 24  The shape that Paris couturiers seem to have agreed upon for fall is the tightly fitted jacket with a small peplum flowing over the hips. With its puffedtop, leg-of-mutton sleeves, it casts a Victorian glow over the couture openings, which started Sunday night and continue through Thursday.

title: Treehouse Spared Eby Ridgewood
description: After a 14-month legal battle, a building permit has been issued for a treehouse in a Ridgewood, N.J.: backyard.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Sells $3 Billion In Notes at a 9.41% Rate
description: The Treasury sold $3 billion of two. year notes yesterday an at average rate of 9.91 percent as interest in bidding for the securities ebbed to the lowest level since January

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 24 (AP)  The Iranian radio played Persian folk music, classical pieces and themes of the revolution today, ignoring a call by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini for a ban on music, which he described as an opiate.

title: 1 Westinghouse Union Settles
description: PITTSBURGH, July 24 (UPI)  The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, undergoing a strike by 38,000 employees, announced last night a tentative contract agreement covering 12,000 whitecollar workers. The announcement did not specify the terms of the threeyear agreement reached with the Federation of Westinghouse Independent Salaried Unions, which has not honored the strike by three other unions that began July 16.

title: Chess:
description: AMSTERDAM, July 22  Grandmasters Jan Smejkal and Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia and Jyula Sax of Hungary shared the lead with 51/4 points each after eight rounds of the I.B.M. International Tournament here.

title: New Crisis For Dollar Is Feared
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  International monetary specialists both in and out of Government see a new dollar crisis taking shape and are warning that it may deepen and lengthen the recession that most analysts believe has already begun.

title: Sweepstakes: Some Do Hit the jackpot
description: ALL those sensational sweepstakes -- do they really pay off? Do real people really win $125,000 homes, $50,000 pots of gold, $40,000 college educations, $25,000 MercedesBenzes, $2,500 wine cellars and guest appearances on television shows? Just by sending in an entry with- out even buying TV Guide or Johnnie Walker Red or White Cloud toilet tissue or anything? Come on now, really and truly?

title: Saying Goodbye to Alydar
description: Charlie Rose had a problem. In about an hour, around noontime, the van would be coming to get Alydar.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicafes stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) over-the-counter.

title: Notes on People
description: One of the most prestigious acting awards in the nation is presented not in New York, but in Chicago, and it will go thi's year to Jessica Tandy for her performance in the Pulitzer Prizewinning play by D. L. Coburn, The Gin Game.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Associated Press
description: BOSTON, July 24 (AP) Carl Yastrzemski, the Boston Red Sox star slugger, reached another milestone tonight, belting the 400th home run of his career and leading the Red Sox to a 73 victory over the Oakland A's.

title: Sellers Get Premiums In Spot Oil
description: Even though the world crude oil supply is improving and prices on the open market are stabilizing, a few producing nations have been able to command sizable premiums on their oil recently by selling their output on the snot market.

title: Walter Andrew, 79
description: Walter M. Andrew, senior partner in the New York law firm of Alger, Andrew and Rohloff, died Monday at his home in Clearwater, Fla., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and had lived in Clearwater forthe last three years.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Whose Job To Draw The Line?
description: Professional sports have made sports medicine glamorous. Physicians are quoted in newspapers and interviewed on television. They seem inextricably linked with their famous patients, like starlets in a gossip column: Dr. James A. Nicholas and Joe Namath, Dr. John L. Marshall and Larry Csonka; Dr Frank Jobe and Tommy John.

title: 59 to Decide Their PriceRule Status
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) In an effort to reduce the backlog of applications, Federal inflation monitors granted permission today to 59 companies to determine for themselves whether they qualify for an exception to the Administration's price standard.

title: Personal Health
description: IT was moving day at the office; everything was out of place, and Alfred got impatient waiting for the porters to properly position the desks. So he moved them himself. He felt a wrenching pain in his groin, followed a few days later by a distinct bulge, and he knew he'd done a bad thing. His physician confirmed his suspicions. Alfred had a hernia  his second one and like the first, it had to be surgically repaired.

title: A Correction: UNTSO and UNEF
description: In attempting yesterday to explain the difference between the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization (UNTSO) and the United Nations Emergency Force (UNEF), we confused the two in one important respect. So once again:

title: Yonkers Investigators Suspect Arson in Fire Fatal to a Woman, 86
description: YONKERS, July 25  An 86-year-old Yonkers woman died early today in a threealarm blaze that city fire officials have linked to four other suspected cases of arson in the same neighborhood in the last four months.

title: Israel Relinquishes More of Sinai; Dayan Assails U.S. Over Policing
description: JERUSALEM, July 25  Israel returned another segment of the Sinai Peninsula to Egypt today as controversy continued over what kind of international force would monitor compliance with the IsraeliEgyptian peace treaty.

title: John Larkin, 56
description: John L. Larkin, who resigned this month as an associate justice of the Appellate Divisidn of State Supreme Court, died yesterday in Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y., following surgery for a brain tumor. He was 56 years old and lived at 224 Manor Avenue in Kingston.

title: Bid to Put Out Tanker Fire. Grows
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, July 25 Firefighting and salvage experts said today that the Atlantic Empress, one of two supertankers involved in a collision

title: Ryan Hurt and John Routed As Angels Defeat Yankees
description: Outraged by several of Fred Spenn's ball-and-strike calls in the first inning, George Steinbrenner severely criticized Spenn's presence behind the plate last night in a dream game at Yankee Stadium that matched Nolan Ryan versus Tommy John.

title: 3 Court Workers Seized at Desks As Ticket Fixers
description: A court clerk and two other employees in the Summons Part of New York City Criminal Court were arrested at their desks yesterday afternoon at 346 Broadway and charged with taking bribes from undercover agents.

title: Home Improvement
description: IF there is one thing that every home and apartment seems to run short of in time, it is easily accessible storage space. All too often, closets are not large enough to

title: Captivated By a Magic Wave
description: THIS summer our son bodysurfs. He says it's his job and rises each morning at 5:30 to catch the bus to Sandy Beach. I hope that by September he will have had enough of the ocean. Tall waves throw surfers against the shallow bottom. Undertows have snatched them away. Sharks prowl Sandy's. The ocean pulls at the boys, who turn into surfing addicts. At sunset you can see surfers waiting for the last golden wave.

title: Dow Rises On Volcker Nomination
description: Stock prices surged yesterday to their best gains in nearly three weeks in response to Paul A. Volcker's nomination as the next Federal Reserve Board chairman. The selection of Mr. Volcker, currently president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, was applauded by both the Wall Street and business communities.

title: Bridge:
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 25  Some 5,000 card players will converge on the Las Vegas Hilton Hotel here during the next 12 days, but very few of them will

title: Market Place
description: BALLY'S PARK PLACE INC., a company which is planning to build a casino in Atlantic City, has dozens of gamblers on the run already.

title: Music: Moscow Winners at Newport
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 25The builtin lure of this city in summer is such that it scarcely needs concerts to attract visitors, but it provides them in abundance nonetheless. It has not just one, but two festivals that present musical events in the gilded settings of mansions that were formerly the summer homes of the rich  they called them cottages  and that are now museums.

title: Deaths
description: BENJAMINCelia. The Board and staff of the Associated YMYWHAs of Greater New York records with deep sorrow the passing of Cella Benjamin, wife of our esteemed ho. norary Vice President, Judge A. David Benjamin. Mrs Benjamin was loVing and helpful wife who support. ed and encouraged her husband's distinguished career in public service and voluntary philanthropy. She was a devoted mother and grandmother. She was herself an outstanding leader in the Federtiom Women's Division, and her chart. table interest were a source of in. soiration to her family. We extend heartfelt sympathy to Judge Bentsmin and to the members of the family.

title: Associated Press
description: WESTERN STATES BATTLE FOREST FIRES: A firefighter working to contain flames near Omak, Wash., where the state's largest fire this year has burned about 6,500 acres of rangeland and timber. In neighboring Oregon, more than 780 firefighters were assisted by 10 planes in the Deschutes National Forest as they fought a blaze covering 4,300 acres in the Cascade Mountains. Smaller fires in both states and in Idaho were halted earlier.

title: Paper Hints Concorde Halt
description: PARIS, July 25 (AP)  The French Government is considering grounding Air France's Concorde supersonic airliners because of mounting operating costs resulting from the latest oilprice increases, the business newspaper Les Echos reported today.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Surges and Gold Dips on Volcker Naming
description: The dollar rose sharply on foreign exchange markets at home and abroad yesterday following President Carter's nomination of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Ford Plans Layoffs
description: ATLANTA, July 25 (Reuters)  The Ford Motor Company said today that it would lay off indefinitely one of two production shifts at its Hapeville, Ga., plant, which produces midsized LTD cars, to reduce inventories.

title: 2 of Charlotte Three. Are Paroled After a Reduction of Their Terms
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 25 (AP) James Earl Grant and T.J. Reddy, the last members of the Charlotte Three still in prison for the 1968 burning of a horse stable, were paroled today after their terms were reduced by Gov. James B. Hunt Jr.

title: Consummate Master of Monetary Tactics
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  When he visited Paris, there was only one bed big enough for Paul A. Volcker, the bed that General de Gaulle had specially made for himself and that later went to the Crillon Hotel.

title: Summer Crowds Return After a Pause for Gas
description: Cultural attractions throughout the summer circuit have recovered from a slow start, and attendance is increasing as the halfway point in the season approaches.

title: Defendant Who Lost On Press Ban Is Ruled A Persistent Offender
description: A man who pleaded guilty to the attempted murder of .an actress and then asked that the press be excluded from a hearing to determine whether he was a persistent felony offender was declared such an offender yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice.

title: ESSAY Return From Elba
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 25 Make no mistake about it: Richard Nixon is looking forward to returning to New York City or its environs this autumn and to pursuing a more visibly active life.

title: Real Refugees, Candygram Words
description: The recent conference in Geneva on the expulsion of hundreds of thousands of mostly ethnic Chinese from Indochina let pass as many problems as it answered. was good, certainly, that more money was pledged and more places were found for the refugees to live. It was good that the Philippines and Indonesia promised to set up large holding camps. It may be useful that Vietnam and the United States have agreed to establish a temporary American consulate in Ho Chi Minh City to process a few thousand special immigrants. And it is good, in general, to be talking with Vietnam, whose cooperation is mandatory if lives are to be saved.

title: Bloom Is Off Toronto Exchange
description: TORONTO, July 25  Uncertainty about the United States economyand about President Carter's ability to steer the United States out of its major problems  has helped put a damper on the highflying Toronto Stock Excharpge.

title: Casinos Not Opposed To 12% Levy by City If All Else Is Positive
description: A spokesman for Resorts International, which is grossing more than $700,000 a day at its yearold Atlantic City casino, said yesterday that the 12 percent tax Mayor Koch wanted on casino revenues would not be too high if other terms were favorable to the casino industry.

title: Carter Absolves Cuba Of Nicaragua Meddling
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  President Carter said tonight that he did not feel that Cuba was responsible for the revolution in Nicaragua.

title: Nigeria Oil Cut Hinted
description: Nigeria, the secondlargest source of crude oil for United States refineries, is discussing with its customers the possibility of cutting production at least 10 percent, several oil companies said yesterday.

title: Mobil Paces Increases in Oil Profits
description: The Mobil Corporation, parent of the nation's secondlairgest oil company, announced yesterday that it had raised its secondquarter net 37.9 percent to $404 million, or $1.91 a share, from $293 million, or $1.38 a share, adjusted for a recent 2-for-1 stock split. Revenues advanced to $10.6 billion from $8.8 billion.

title: Battle Seen On Energy Agency
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  A major struggle is shaping up in Congress over President Carter's request for a new White House agency to speed construction of synthetic fuel plants by cutting governmental red tape.

title: Wisconsin Dropped As Atomic Plant Site
description: The Northern States Power Company and its partners have scrapped plans for a 1,100megawatt nuclear power plant in western Wisconsin.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Adrien Arpel Inc., an operator of spas and cosmetic boutiques and a subsidiary of Seligman & Latz Inc., named as executive vice president and general manager Omar R. Adame, former vice president of WarnerLambert Inc.

title: Home Beat
description: THE invitation read Virginia's surprise. And so it was. Virginia Saladino planned a party at Shezan, the Indian restaurant, asking friends, fellow designers, relatives and- clients to celebrate the 40th birth-

title: Radio
description: 8:159, WQXR. Concerto No. 3, Haydn; Suite in G Theme, and Variations, Tchaikovsky.

title: Hound
description: Tom Stoppard's The Real Inspector Hound, first staged Off Broadway 11 years ago, will be given a 12day revival at N.Y. Stage Works, 15 West 18th Street, beginning Aug. 14. For information, call 2423967.

title: The Mets
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 25  Herb Caen, the wit and sage of San Francisco, wrote a trivia tease in his column the other day that read: Earlier this year, the Oakland A's played to 653 fans in one game. Can you name them?

title: German Money Growth Swells
description: FRANKFURT, July 25 (Reuters) West German monetary expansion accelerated in June, with bank lending to the private sector again providing the biggest stimulus, the Bundesbank said today.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: STRIFE GROWS IN AFGHANISTAN: An insurgent views the ruins of a village in Kunar Province bombed by Government planes. A guerrilla war against the Sovietsupported Government of President Noor Mohammad

title: CIVILETTI IS PRAISED AT SENATE HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The Senate Judiciary Committee today paved the way for quick approval of Benjamin R. Civiletti as Attorney General by praising his nomination in the opening day of confirmation hearings.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 25, 1979

title: In Lithuanth, Too, Catholics Look Hopefully to New Pope
description: VILNIUS, U.S.S.R.  The Roman Catholic priest sat in the sacristy, at battered desk on which lay a crucifix and a breviary. He talked about the recent visit of Pope John Paul II to Poland, just across the border from Soviet Lithuania.

title: Straight and Narrow With Mr. Volcker
description: There were sighs of relief from Zurich to Tokyo yesterday: President Carter maybe shuffling economists, but he is not shuffling economic policies. The nomination of Paul Volcker to replace G. William Miller as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board assures that moderate, independent leadership for the agency, which controls interest rates and the supply of money, will continue.

title: Hercules Increasing Its Polypropylene
description: Hercules Inc., a chemical maker, said it planned to more than double the capacity of a polypropylene plant it operates as a joint venture in Taiwan. The capacity will be increased from 50,000 metric tons a year to 110,000 metric tons upon completion in early 1981.

title: The Coffeehouse, New York Style
description: NEW YORKERS are heavy on coffee. They like the real thing; they like the imitation thing; they like the thing that dare not tell its name. They like it before meals and during meals and after meals. Sipping and slurping, they lay waste their days. Not even in Cairo or Damascus can there be a greater consumption per head of the concoction that came to western Europe early in the 17th century and has been a favorite with everyone everywhere ever since.

title: About Mineola
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  The quest for new energy spans the generation, gap at the Nassau Children's House Inc., where Rebecca J. Gilmer, whose years number something more than 60, has been recycled from a useful career that led only to retirement into an instant grandma for 25 teenage boys with problems.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ATLANTIC COGNAC (Atlantic Container Line). LeHavre August 3, Rotterdam 4 and Southampton 6; sails from Port Elizabeth, N.J.

title: A.M.A. Softens a Policy Critical of Chiropractors
description: CHICAGO, July 25 (Reuters)  The American Medical Association, altering its longstated view that chiropractors are an unscientific cult, has adopted policy suggesting that its members consider referrals to chiropractors whenever the physician believes that this will benefit the patient.

title: Nabucco
description: Verdi's Nabucco will be performed this evening by the New York Grand Opera Company on the Central Park Mall, beginning at 8:30. It is the last of the company's free summer concerts.

title: U.S. Loan Guarantee Sets Record for Women
description: WASHNGTON, July 25 (UPI)  The largest Federal loan guarantee ever made to a business owned and operated by a woman was announced today by Commerce Secretary Juanita M. Kreps.

title: The Region
description: ATLANTIC CITY (AP)  On the assumption that everyone should have a chance to win, or lose, the Caesars Boardwalk Regency casino is offering 23. slot machines with instructions in Braille for blind people.

title: Jersey Election Official Wins Senate Approval
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)  The nomination of Frank Reiche to a Republican seat on the Federal Election Commission was approved today by the Senate after a sevenhour filibuster by conservative Republicans collapsed.

title: Energy Program Risks Losing Momentum as Congress. Poses Obstacles
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  Just as President Carter was making a renewed appeal to the nation tonight for his energy proposals, there were signs that his program was in danger of losing momentum in Congress.

title: Deaths
description: PALLENVincent. Born April 12. 1896 in Russia. Died July 9. 1979 in New York City; imminent flutist. Studied music at the Alexander III Institute of Musical Arts in Petro. grad and the Institute of Musical Art in New York. Studied flute with George Barrere. Mr. Pallen played with maior symphony orchestras including Cleveland, Hollywood. Indianapolis and North Carolina Orchestras and the Chicago Ooera. He concertised with Fedor. Challapin, laurItz, Meichoir. Victor Borge and Fallen Woodwind Quintet. He was twice. decorated by the French Government for musical activities while serving with the United States Marines In France. He Is survived by his wife Lucile Calvert Palien. Memorial services and burial were in Muncie, Indiana.

title: Oil Spokesmen See Tax As Curb on Production
