description: With at least one major exception, oil industry spokesmen asserted last night that the windfall profits tax sought by President Carter would not encourage increased production.

title: Insider Reports for Exchanges
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VA, PENSIERO Tonight's free performance of Verdi's Nabucco is the season's final concert presentation of the New York Grand Opera Company on the Central Park Mall, starting at 8:30. Unlike Aida, Rigoletto, La Traviata and Il Trovatore, Nabucco is rarely performed on the New York scene. It was a highly significant work in the composer's career.

title: King Hoping to Fill a Spot on Giants
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. July 25 Gordon King, the Giants offensive tackle and No. 1 draft choice of last year out of Stanford, seemed as eager as Coach Ray Perkins about the prospect that Jim Clack and Ron Mikolajczyk, two veteran holdouts, will report to training camp soon.

title: U.S. Business Leaders Express Enthusiasm About Volcker Choice
description: Business and financial leaders responded with quick and enthusiastic approval yesterday to President Carter's nomination of Paul A. Volcker to succeed G. William Miller as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: COMMODITIES Precious Metals Drop; Copper Futures Advance
description: Gold and silver futures edged mostly lower yesterday, partly on the appointment of a new Federal. Reserve chairman who is expected to be a staunch defender of the dollar.

title: U.S. EXPECTS ACCORD ON SINAI OBSERVERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The United States expressed confidence today that solution could be found in the next few weeks for its dispute with Israel about United Nations force in. Sinai. The dispute has strained relations, between the two Rovernments.

title: Cosmos Set Back Kicks by 41; Chinaglia Registers Two Goals
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 25  The Cosmos displayed glimpses of brilliance at Giants Stadium tonight, defeating the Minnesota Kicks, 41, before a crowd of 57,223, the largest since opening day.

title: House Votes to Reject Many Proposed Cuts in Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The House of Representatives, in the first test of Congressional support for Amtrak since the. current gasoline shortages began, voted 397 to 18 today to reject many of the cuts in rail passenger service that the Carter Administration had proposed.

title: Hers
description: So wiry are we killing each other? I put it my neighbor. Two ordinary women chatting on a front porch, a squirming baby riding the hip of each, the odd number of three

title: Nominee Pledges to Fight Inflation And Restore Confidence in Dollar
description: President Carter nominated Paul A. Volcker, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and a leading figure in international financial circles, to be chairman of the Federal Reserve Board yesterday.

title: Head of Highway Safety Agency Plans to Stay Despite ShakeUp
description: DETROIT, July 25  Joan Claybrook, the Government's chief antagonist of the nation's automobile industry, said today that she had no plans to leave her post as administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration despite the dismissal of her boss, Transportation Secretary Brock Adams, in the recent Cabinet shakeup.

title: EARNINGS Kodak Net Up 16.1%; Goodyear Off 30.3%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were up 16.1 percent to a record $222.7 million, or 61.38 a share. from $191.8 million, or $1.19 a share, for the June quarter last year. Sales totaled $1.8 billion, or 14.6 percent higher than $1.57 billion a year earlier.

title: SEMINAR FOR POLICE TO DISCUSS KILLINGS
description: CHICAGO, July 25  The Department of Justice will sponsor a seminar for police officials on the use of deadly force as a result of policemen killing nonwhites in controversial circumstances in several American cities in recent months.

title: John Loring: Unconventional Collector
description: IF he seems reticent at first, the impression passes quickly. This broadshouldered man in the pale linen suit is too tall, the cant of his chin too definite. What might have passed as shyness, on second glance appears to be a natural formality of manner, an inclination toward restraint, coupled with a barely repressed impatience to get on with the business at hand.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Paul A. Volcker was nominated by President Carter to succeed G. William Miller as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Volcker, currently president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and an authority on international financial matters, stressed the need for economic discipline. [Page A1.]

title: Alexander Federoff, Novelist, 52, Who Did The Side of the Angels
description: Alexander Federoff, a novelist and playwright whose themes were often religious, died of heart failure Monday following an operation. He was 52 years old and lived in New Orleans.

title: G.M. Profits Climb 72% On an 11.6% Sales Gain
description: DETROIT, July 25  The giant General Motors Corporation, acknowleding that its foreCast of another record year for auto industry sales In the United States is now under review, reported today that it had a 7.2 percent increase in secondquarter profits on an 11.6 percent sales gain.

title: Lynn Dally &
description: Lynn Daily & Dancers of Los Angeles will perform two programs of new works at the American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street, Aug. 912. Included will be one world premiere and five New York premieres. For information, call 6916500.

title: Mets Top Giants, 30, On 6Hitter by Swan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 25  Craig Swan pitched the New York Mets to a 30 victory over the San Francisco Giants today, sending the Mets home with two straight victories after a week of too many injuries and too few runs in California.

title: On the Nuclear Altar
description: WELLFLEET, Mass.  When I interviewed Hiroshima survivors some years ago, they repeatedly described themselves as guinea pigs. They sometimes used that phrase to describe their participation in Americansponsored research on delayed radiation effects. But their basic feeling was that they had been made into historical guinea pigs  had been victimized by a weapon so new, powerful, and mysterious that its effects could not be known until it had been tried on a particular population. One survivor put the matter bitterly: There exist no words in any human language that can comfort guinea pigs who do not know the cause of their death.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Energy, Oil Tax and Other Issues
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference in Washington tonight, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: Television
description: 5:55 (4) Podiatric Medicine

title: Finding of $4 Million Stocks Is Its Own Reward
description: Thomas Wahlman, a 26-year-old clerk with the Depository Trust Company, was walking along the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive during his lunch break on June 27 when a black vinyl suitcase fell from a passing taxi onto the roadway.

title: Japan Sets Auto Mark
description: TOKYO, July 25 (UPI)  Japan's automobile production in June rose 5.2 percent from the yearearlier level to a new monthly high of 851,570 units, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association announced today.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Schedules A $7.25 Billion Sale
description: The Treasury announced yesterday that it plans to sell $7.25 billion of notes and bonds next week to refinance Government securities maturing Aug. 15 and to raise $2.42 billion of additional cash to help finance the Federal budget deficit.

title: Orchestra Rehearsal
description: Orchestra Rehearsal, Federico Fellinl's film, in which he uses an orchestra as a metaphor for a crumbling society, will have its American premiere at Cinema 2 on Aug. 17. Last winter in Italy, the film, financed by the Governmentowned RAI television network, created a controversy that extended into that country's parliament.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Day Tours, The Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JULY 26, 1979

title: Natt, Top Nets
description: MOONACHIE, N.J., July 25  Kevin Loughery, the New Jersey Nets coach, described him as a little Willis Reed.

title: A Conservative Choice
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  In naming Paul A. Volcker to be the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, President

title: Judge Wright Terms His Attack On Officers Possibly Excessive
description: Bruce McM. Wright, the often controversial Criminal Court judge, said yesterday that his criticism of white police officers in April  called unseemly by a Bar Association committee last week might have been excessive and that he did at times exaggerate for emphasis.

title: A Leader of P.L.O. Shot in France
description: CANNES, France, July 25 (AP)  Zuheir Mohsen, military operations chief of the Palestine Liberation Organization and head of the Syriansupported As saiqa guerrilla faction, was shot in the head last night as he approached the door of an apartment in this Riviera city, the police reported oday.

title: Protesters Call the Film Cruising
description: Several hundred demonstrators staged a noisy protest against the filming of an allegedly antihomosexual movie last night and then marched on a Greenwich Village police station after one of them was seized on charges of attacking two police officers.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Technology
description: ONE of the fundamental problems associated with electrical energy is that it must be used as it is generated: There simply is no efficient method of storing it.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Catches of Atlantic salmon have dropped drastically this year and no one really knows why.

title: Mozart: Church Sonatas
description: TUESDAY'S Mostly Mozart Festival concert at Avery Fisher. Hall was superb, or more Properly, the second half was. It is a sign of Vladimir Spivakov's unusual sensibility that once again, given a New York showcase, he selected a repertory that revealed his venturesome musical mind and his willingness to submerge himself into chambermusic situations rather than spread his virtuosic wings in a more demonstrative violin repertory.

title: Asarco to Buy Shares
description: Asarco Inc. said yesterday that its board of directors had authorized the repurchase of up to one million shares of its common stock in the open market for general corporate purposes. As of last June 30, Asarco, a metals producer, held 961,258 shares in its treasury and had 30.5 million shares outstanding.

title: Peltier, Indian Activist, Is Recaptured on Coast
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 25 (AP)  Leonard Peltier, the American Indian Movement activist, who escaped from a Federal prison five days ago, was found hiding in a tree and was captured today, the police reported.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO LET CONGRESS VETO PLAN FOR GAS RATIONING
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  The House of Representatives voted tonight to give either house of Congress veto power over any standby gasoline rationing plan proposed.by the White House. The amendment to the Administration bill, passed

title: Around the Nation
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa., July 25 (AP)  A county judge today threw out a $3 million libel suit against F. Lee Bailey in which the criminal lawyer was accused of conspiring to frame another man in connection with a murder.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: United Press Intemational

title: Execution Stayed in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 25 (AP) The State Supreme Court gave Thomas Milton Wilson a twomonth stay of execution today, less than 48 hours before his scheduled electrocution. The execution was postponed until Sept. 21 to permit further appeals in behalf of Mr. Wilson, a convicted murderer.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Joseph E. Baird, who was suddenly replaced this week as president of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation by Zoltan Merzei, is not the first president of Occidental to find out that he would not eventually succeed Dr. Armand Hammer, the 80-year-old chairman and chief executive officer. The irrepressible Dr. Hammer will remain at the head of the company and has no plans to retire, Occidental said this week.

title: CARTER VOWS A MAJOR BATTLE FOR HIS WINDFALL
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  President Carter pledged tonight to resist a massive struggle to gut the windfall profits tax bill and defended the sudden overhaul of his Cabinet as providing a united. and forceful team to confront the problems facing him.

title: Earnings Climb At Interpublic
description: In the first of the second-quarter's earnings reports by a publicly held agency, the Interpublic Group of Companies announced yesterday a 38.4 percent rise from last year's second quarter, while the half showing a 14.5 percent increase.

title: Citizens Nuclear Panel Is Disbanded
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  Several weeks ago, the Presidential commission that is investigating the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island decided that it would

title: Letter: On Social Security
description: Your editorial, Don't Disable Social Security, (Thursday, July 19, 1979), was based on erroneous information. The bill under discussion, H.R. 3236, would not  save about $1 billion a year by 1989  without costing beneficiaries a cent. That would be the neatest trick of the week. On the contrary, according to the bill's sponsors, the amendments would reduce benefits an average of 15 percent for those disabled in the future who

title: Most of $217,000 Ransom Is Recovered in Paterson
description: PATERSON, N.J., July 25  The bulk of the missing $217,000 ransom that bought the release of a bank executive's wife  small bills carried by her husband from downtown Paterson into midManhattan and to a final drop site in Fort Lee, N.J.  was found here early today in a rusting, lopsided trash container only 400 yards from the bank where it had been prepared last Friday night for the kidnappers.

title: VOLCKER SELECTION PRAISED IN EUROPE
description: PARIS, July 25  European monetary officials and bankers welcomed today's nomination of Paul A. Volcker; president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, to be chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and the battered dollar moved slightly fiigher.

title: SurfaceTransit Chief Announces Retirement
description: Hyman Feldman, executive officer of the Transit Authority's surfacetransit division, has told an authority meeting that he is retiring. His departure is expected to be announced today.

title: Reporter's Notebook: For Tibet, a Thin Chinese Veneer
description: LHASA, Tibet  In a fresco in the Potala Palace honoring the 13th Dalai Lama, there is a scene in which the high priest of Tibetan Lamaism appears to be riding in a goldencrusted Packard sedan of the 1930's. The Dalai Lama, resplendent in an orange silk robe and high yellow conical hat, is portrayed beaming graciously to a welcoming crowd.

title: 10 Food Establishments Cited As City Health Code Violators
description: The New York City Department of Health yesterday released the names of 10 food establishments that it said had violated the health code.

title: French Economy Up 0.4%
description: PARIS, July 25 (Reuters)  France's real gross domestic product grew fourtenths of I percent in the first quarter of 1979 from the fourth quarter of last year, when it rose an upwardly revised 1.7 percent from the third quarter, the Statistics Institute announced today.

title: U.S. Is Collecting Refugee Reports on Mistreatment by Malaysia's Navy
description: LETUNG, Indonesia, July 21  United States officials, with the help of Indonesians and United ,Nations workers, have been accumulating evidence from Vietnamese refugees here on drownings, rapes and other incidents caused by the Malaysian Navy and coastal guards since Malaysia began towing refugee boats back out to sea.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Harold F. Reindel, 84, A Lawyer Specializing In Corporate Finance
description: Harold F. Reindel, a lawyer who specialized in international corporate finance, died Tuesday at his home in Essex Fells, N.J., after a long illness. He was 84 years old and also had a home in Lake Wales. Fla.

title: The City
description: The City Council appointed five members to committee chairmanships yesterday amid charges that the appointments favored organizational politics and shortchanged the Borough of Manhattan.

title: The Stars Shine For a Clean City
description: The I Love a Clean New York campaign. was pressed with renewed vigor yesterday by Broadway stars who gathered on the steps of the New York Public Library.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, July 25 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union has agreed to a Chinese pro: posal to hold talks in Moscow in September on improving relations between the two countries, a Chinese Government spokesMan said today.

title: Donovan of Time Brings President Economics and Management Skills
description: Hedley Donovan, the former editor in chief of Time Inc. who was named senior adviser to President Carter yesterday, has a solid background in journalism, world affairs, economics, administration and how to be a senior adviser.

title: GOV. BROWN SETS UP CAMPAIGN APPARATUS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 25  Gov. mund G. Brown Jr. is raising money, picking staff and seeking supporters for Presidential campaign while portraying himself in recent speeches and statements as a catalyst needed to turn the Democratic Party into a force for investment and growth, not consumption.

title: Diaghilev Inspires Saint Laurent
description: PARIS, July 25  Yves Saint Laurent may or may not_put tutus and pantaloons on the disco set this fall. That is not the point. What he accomplished today was to put fashion back on the map as a serious undertaking.

title: Advertising
description: IN their continuing battle with the truckers of the nation for their share of the freight market, America's railroads have not always had a really

title: Refinery Output Off In Week
description: Production at the nation's refineries fell slightly in the week ended last Friday, but the level of diesel fuel and gasoline inventories continued to improve, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Steel Profits Showing Strong Gains
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported a 21.6 percent jump in secondquarter earnings yesterday, and its board of directors voted to raise the company's quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share from 35 cents.

title: ERNEST D. KENNEDY
description: Ernest D. Kennedy, a lawyer and aeronautical engineer, died Saturday at Central General Hospital in Plainview, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 50 years old and lived in Massapequa, L.I.

title: FRANK C. DAVIDSON, A PROFESSOR, DEAD
description: Dr. Frank C. Davidson, professor emeritus in the speech department at the City College of New York and an authority on the history of the city, died Tuesday at the age of 71 in the Hospital for Special Surgery. He was a native of Kentucky and lived in Manhattan.

title: Queen Elizabeth in Botswana
description: GABORONE, Botswana, July 25 (UPI)  Queen Elizabeth II flew here today and was welcomed by tribal dancers and a 21gun salute. The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh and her second son, Prince Andrew, arrived from Malawi on the fourth leg of a tour of former colonies in Africa in advance of the Commonwealth conference in Zambia next week.

title: Israeli Court Opens Way For a West Bank Project
description: TEL AVIV, July 25  The Israeli Supreme Court today dismissed Arab objections and lifted a temporary ban against the establishment of a new Israeli settlement in occupied Jordanian territory.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Music

title: Nature Group Takes Option On 2,037 Acres on Shelter I.
description: The Nature Conservancy has taken an option to buy one of the largest tracts of privately owned undeveloped land in the metropolitan area, a 2,037acre parcel on Shelter Island, at the eastern end of Long Island, as part of a $10.625 million agreement.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have a serious water problem in my basement. Whenever there is a sustained rain (two to three inches), water seeps into my basement through the joint between the floor and the wall, and this was exceptionally severe during the heavy rains that we had in late winter and early spring of this year. have obtained four different opinions from professionals, with each differing from the others. I wonder if you can offer any suggestions for this problem? M.L.W., Harrison, N.Y.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: IT is a tricky highwire act that Peter Steinfels performs in The Neoconservatives. His bias is essentially unsympathetic, which

title: U.S. Approves Exxon Search Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus announced today that he had ordered approval of an offshore petroleum exploration plan that he had sharply criticized earlier in the week.

title: CrackProne Grumman Bus Tested On Jarring Runs for Design Defects
description: The prototype for 837 new Grumman Flxible buses ordered by the city, on which initial testing turned up defects, was equipped with sensitive stressrecording instruments and run the last two nights on city routes that have particularly jarring road conditions.

title: Cabaret: Linda Langford
description: AFTER six years as half of a singing team called Jade and Sarsaparilla, Linda Langford is feeling her way into a solo career at Reno Sweeney, where she appeared Tuesday evening and last night with Steven Oirich at the piano. Miss Langford has a healthy, vital, girlnextdoor appearance and a voice that has the potential to encompass a wide range of material.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: Profits Scoreboard

title: L.I.R.R. Delayed Up to 70 Minutes
description: Tens of thousands of Long Island Rail Road commuters were delayed for up to 70 minutes during yesterday evening's rush hour when service out of Manhattan was virtually knocked out, as a railroad spokesman put it, by two unrelated mishaps occurring at about the same time.

title: Ballet: Pulsations, Cubans
description: THE final premiere of the National Ballet of Cuba's season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night turned out to be another of those classroom ballets that so many companies feel compelled to include in their repertories, usually with mixed results.

title: Joseph DeFrancisi, 89, Led Machinery Concern
description: Joseph DeFrancisci, president of the DeFrancisci Machine Corporation in Brooklyn, died Tuesday of cancer at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 89 years old and lived in Brooklyn and Jupiter Island, Fla.

title: Japan's Premier Weighs Decision on Early Election
description: TOKYO, July 25  With the latest opinion polls showing increased public support for the governing Liberal Democratic Party, Japan's cautious Prime Minister, Masayoshi Ohira, is weighine his most crucial decision since he took office last December: the timing of the first general elections under his leadership.

title: UAL Reports Loss In Second Quarter
description: UAL Inc., the holding company of United Airlines, reported yesterday a secondquarter loss of $47.4 million, compared with net income of $97.9 million, or $3.93 a share, a year earlier. Revenues fell 53 percent, to $465.2 million.

title: Deaths
description: ADELSONIsidor, beloved husband of the late Rose, devoted father of Florence Powers and Murray Adelson, adored grandfather of Robert Powers. Lynne Mayes, Jack & Mark Adelson. Services will be held at Gutterman Musicant Kreitzman corner Park & Passaic Sts. Hackensack, NJ on Thursday, July 26 at 12 noon. The Memorial week will be observed at the Adelson residence.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: OTTAWA, July 25  The Asbestos Corporation lost a monthlong court battle today to bar expropriation by the Quebec government.

title: Library Pickets Block Removal of an Old Furnace
description: Normally, the presence of an aging furnace might be expected to stir wrath over a landlord's failure to replace it. But yesterday, at the Ottendorfer Library in the East Village, citizens blocked a doorway to keep the city from replacing the building's 75-yearold coalfired boiler.

title: Boston Housing Authority Is Placed in Receivership
description: BOSTON, July 25  The Boston Housing Authority, landlord to nearly onetenth of this city's residents, was placed in receiyershia today by a state judge who called the move a lastditch effort to improve indescribable conditions that he said had caused incalculable human suffering.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE A Lightweight Substitute For Glass Mirror
description: MIRROR glass is often used functionally in bathrooms, bedrooms and dressing rooms and frequently as part of decorative schemes, where reflected light and a heightened sense of space are needed. But, generally, mirror glass is heavy, and when used in large pieces, it must be installed by a professional.

title: Trans World Corp. To Buy Century 21
description: The Trans World Corporation, parent company of Trans World Airlines, and the Century 21 Real Estate Corporation reported jointly yesterday that directors of both companies had reached tentative terms for the real estate office franchiser to become a Trans World subsidiary. The announcement came a day after a $4-a-share jump in the shares of Century 21.

title: Alternative Energy Supermarkets
description: ENERGY supermarkets have arrived. Stocked with hundreds of products to create and conserve energy and staffed with people who can make sense of the

title: Dance: Gail Conrad Tap Troupe on Staten I. Ferry
description: LAST June a group of Greenwich Village residents unsuccessfully sued Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis and assorted politicians for granting a permit to Gail Conrad, a 26-year-old tap dancer, to perform with her company in Sheridan Square. No one was complaining yesterday afternoon, when Miss Conrad took to the Staten Island Ferry with four other dancers and three musicians.

title: DR. HARRY WEXLER
description: Dr. Harry Wexler. a pediatrician in Brooklyn for many years, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Letters
description: There would be an uproar if the Government agencies charged with reducing risks to the life and health of citizens were liquidated. One may. believe the Federal Aviation Agency has done a lousy job in preventing passengerloaded aircraft from dropping their engines. But few believe Government agencies should abandon inspection of aircraft, nuclear reactors, elevators, or similar potential killers.

title: EX-LEADER IN LISBON SEES PLOT BY RIGHT
description: LISBON, July 21  Once,again, Mario Soares, is fighting for his political life, and, to hear him tell it, fighting for the future of democracy in Portugal.

title: Amoco to Develop Field in North Sea
description: LONDON, July 25 (Reuters)  The Amoco Exploration Company announced plans today to develop the North West Hutton Field, about 80 miles northeast of the Shetland Islands in the British sector of the North Sea.

title: World Borrowing Detailed
description: PARIS, July 25 (Reuters)  Borrowing on international capital markets totaled the equivalent of $26.42 billion in the second quarter of 1979, with international bank loans totaling $17.40 billion and bonds amounting to $9.02 billion, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. In its financial statistics bulletin, the O.E.C.D. also revised downward its figure for total borrowing in the first quarter to $23.03 billion.

title: Dance: 10 Houston Ballet Soloists at Jacob's Pillow
description: BECKET, MASS. THERE'S certainly no energy crisis in American ballet dancing. Fine classical dancers can now be found in cities across the nation. Judging from Tuesday night's program at the Jacob's Pillow Mance Festival, one df those cities may be Houston.

title: Split Decision on Arkansas Herbicide Ban
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 25  The growing controversy over herbicides emerged in Arkansas today as a riddle of inconsistency, a serious scientific effort and something of a publicity effort, all at the same time.

title: Counsel at Yale Ribicoff Choice For U.S. Judge
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  Jose A. Cabranes, general counsel at Yale University, and chairtnan of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, was recommended today for a Federal judgeship in Connecticut by Senator Abraham A. Ribieoff.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's ft Weather at 1 P.M. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Notes on People
description: One of the few hit series last season on the ratingstroubled NBCTV was Different Strokes, and its chief asset was a pudgy, dumplingcheeked 11yearold named Gary Coleman. Naturally, the network looked forward to a new season of the show, but work on new episodes has been held up because young Mr. Coleman now wants more money and added benefits, including a bodyguard.

title: United Press International
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 25 (AP)  The revolutionary Government nation. alized the country's seven private banks today and ordered four foreign banks to stop accepting deposits from the public.

title: Gardening: New Plants From Cuttings
description: THE next time you are served a cool summer drink flavored with sprigs of mint, instead of asking for the drink's recipe, request the mint. If you take it home and put it in a glass of water, the sprig will develop roots. Transplant the young mint plant to a pot of soil or a cool garden nook and you will have the start of a mint patch.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, July 25 (UPI)  John Powell, the former world recordholder in the discus throw, gave the United States its first gold medal of the Soviet Spartakiad Games today, breaking the meet record for the event with a heave of 206 feet 10 inches.

title: Campaign, 1979
description: We were deeply relieved by the fate in the House a proposed amendment to the Constitution to ban busing for purposes of school desegregation. Though needed to win a twothirds vote, the proposal did not, finally, summon even a simple majority. But there was also something else to be gratified about, in some views expressed on the House floor by Representative John Anderson of Illinois:

title: Donna Summer Has Begun to Win Respect
description: NOT too long ago, Donna Summer was havinglit disco singles (Love to Love You Baby, I Feel Love) but was still roundly Iignored by most of the general public and press. No more. The 30-year-old singer, who is scheduled to give two soldout concerts tomorrow and Saturday nights at the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium, is about the hottest single figure in presentday popular music, with No. I singles and albums on the pop, disco and soul charts. Furthermore, she's begun to win the respect as a singer she's long thought she deserved.

title: The Afghans See Red
description: It can no longer be denied that Moscow sponsored and participated in the 1978 coup that established the Communist regime of President Noor Mohammed Taraki in Afghanistan. What is not known is why it intervened and established a Communist regime when no threat to its interests existed in Afghanistan and the surrounding region.

title: Cable and Disk Programs Not for NBC
description: Fred Silverman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, said his network would not follow the example of ABCTV and CBSTV in attempting to produce programming for video disks, cabletelevision and other new technologies.

title: Deaths
description: BENJAMINCelia. The Medical Staff of the Jewish Hospital & Medical Center of Brooklyn records with Profound sorrow the passing of Celia Benjamin, wife of the Hon. A. David Benjamin, an esteemed and distinguished member of our Board of Trustees. Our sincere sympathies are extended to the bereaved family.

title: JobPlacement Figures Provided by Beauty Schools Are Questioned
description: Beautyschool students, who spend more than 1,000 class hours learning the arts of cutting, coloring, setting and straightening hair, expect to get jobs when they graduate. But do they?

title: PetroLewis Units Offered
description: Blyth, Eastman Dillon & Company is heading a group that is offering two million units of the PetroLewis Corporation. Each unit, priced at $15, consists of one share of cumulative preferred stock and 0.11 share of common, bringing the total offering to two million preferred shares and 220,000 common shares.

title: Passages
description: There is land in central Illinois that is as flat as the floor. It does not roll and ripple into hills, nor does it fill, lift, and erupt like sails into mountains the way some land does. The most it grants, and this begrudgingly, is to warp and buckle where rare and subtle sorts of lumps appear; but these lumps are not hills and this land is very flat.

title: SAKS PLANS TOWER BEHIND MAIN STORE
description: Saks Fifth Avenue is planning to build tower of about 50 stories just behind its flagship store on Fifth Avenue between 99th and 50th streets.

title: Deaths
description: KINGHORNFlorence A. on July 23. 1979 in Brooklyn, NY. Wife of the late John Reidie, sister of Mildred Reckmeyer. Mrs. Kinghorn was employed by Coudert Brothers, 200 Park Ave., New York. for 61 years. Graveside services Wednesday, July 25 at Hillside CeMetery. Lynhurst, NJ.

title: Career Schools: Who Enrolls and Why
description: In 1969 Michael Joyner, a 50-year-old Mexicanborn factory worker, saw a television advertisement offering training for a highsalaried career as a computer

title: Sound
description: TO casual audio fans, a tone arm seems a stick on a swivel  a device too simple for critical concern. They are only dimly

title: Why Retirees Pick An Adult Community
description: WE'RE all from somewhere else, said one of the residents of Heritage Village, Conn., so we all have a lot in common. Her comment helps explain the appeal of an adult community, as developers and residents prefer to call retirement villages. Large and small, they are proliferating across the American landscape and offer a relatively new solution to an ancient dilemma: The angst of aging is best muted by the company of one's peers.

title: Nunn Links His Support for Pact to Arms Budget Rise
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 Senator Sam Nunn, an influential figure among Southern Democrats, threatened today to vote against the arms treaty with the Soviet Union unless, President Carter made firm commitment to increase military spending substantially.

title: DC10 in Emergency Landing
description: CLEVELAND, July 2.5 (AP)  A United Airlines DC10 with 172 passengers aboard made a safe emergency landing today after its left wing engine was shut down because of excessive vibration, the airline said. A spokesman for the airline said Flight No. 4, which was bound for Newark from Los Angeles, landed safely at Hopkins International Airport here. The passengers were rerouted onto other flights.

title: Deaths
description: DAMMArthur J. on July 24, 1979. Beloved husband of Margaret (nee Bush). deariether of Nancy, Peggy Buckley, Arthur and Sister Rosemary D.P., loving brother of Frank. Charity Muller. Anne, Robert, William. Florence, Rose Mary and Frances, dear grandfather of seven. Funeral Friday 10AM from the Mc Laughlin & Sons Colonial Home, Third Ave. at 97 St.. Brooklyn Mass of Christian Buriel 10:30 AM St. Patrick's Church. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Rose's Home. 71 Jackson St., Hew York City, NY 10002 would be appreciated.

title: ForeignHeld U.S. Debt
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (Reuters) Foreign holdings of United States public debt securities fell $14.4 billion in the second quarter of this year, the Treasury said today. The decline followed a $5 billion drop in the first quarter and a net increase of $18.4 billion in the second half of last year, it added.

title: Pop: Kiss, Safe Cartoon for the Family
description: A KISS concert is a little like a circus, a little like a Saturday morning cartoon show on television, a little like an exhibition of parlor magic improbably blown up to arena proportions and a little like rock n roll. It's loud, but otherwise it's safe family entertainment, and the audience that packed into Madison Square Garden on Tuesday for the first of two evenings with the group included numerous groups of father, mother and children, all clapping their hands on the beat with cotton stuffed in their ears.

title: The Unrelenting Search for Etan Patz
description: Every day Detective William Butler retraces the route that 6-year-old Etan Patz should have taken on that Friday morning two months ago when he disappeared.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report on July 16 incorrectly quoted Senator Ralph J. Marino as saying the Governor is entitled to have whoever he wants in the post of New York State Commissioner of Correctional Services. Senator Marino was referring to the possible appointment of Richard D. Hongisto to the post of deputy commissioner at the Division of Criminal Justice Services, which does not require Senate confirmation.

title: Railroads Seek Rate Increases
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)  The nation's railroads asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve selective increases in their freight rates that would average 8 percent nationwide.

title: Market Place
description: WITH a recession looming, the outlook for the steel industry is becoming increasingly cloudy and thus analysts are sounding a cautious note with regard to generally sparkling secondQuarter earnings.

title: The Pop Life
description: PEOLE sometimes talk as if the world of Los Angeles popfolkrock had passed, superseded by disco and newwave rock. Well, there are still plenty of worthy disks being released within that stylistic camp, even if the superstars of the scene (Fleetwood Mac, the Eagles, Linda Ronstadt et al.) have been relatively quiet lately.

title: SAC Is Concerned Over Aging of Bombers
description: OFFUTT AIR FORCE BASE, Neb. The Strategic Air Command, the United States primary weapon to deter or to fight a nuclear war, appears to have reached a critical point at which its obsolescent bombers and increasingly vulnerable missile force are balanced only by the high morale of its personnel.

title: Jets, Apollo Settle Dispute Involving Hofstra Stadium
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 26  The New York Jets of the National Football League and the New York Apollo of the American Soccer League settled their dispute today over the use of Hofstra University Stadium tomorrow night, but they needed the help of State Supreme Court Judge Thomas Pantano.

title: U.S. Navy Task Force Picks Up 49 Refugees In the South China Sea
description: SUBICBAY, Philippines, Thursday, July 27 (Reuters)  A United States Seventh Fleet task force, looking out for Vietnamese refugees in the South China Sea, yesterday made its second pickup, this one of 49 boat people, an American spokesman said here today.

title: Renaissance Festival At Sterling Forest
description: For the next six weekends, visitors to Sterling Forest Gardens in Tuxedo, N.Y., will be transported back in time with the second annual New York Renaissance Festival.

title: A Backgammon Set With a Prince's Imprimatur
description: Naef Orfaley, who is known primarily for his animal sculptures that combine ostrich eggs or shells with gemstones and precious metals, has just completed his first backgammon board and it's one fit for a king. Or at least for a prince. It was commissioned by Prince Moulay Abdullah, who is the brother.of King Hassan II of Morocco.

title: BUSINES; Digest
description: Textron made $13 million in improper foreign payments while G. William Miller was the company's senior officer, a staff investigation by the S.E.C. has concluded. But it found no evidence that Mr. Miller, the Federal Reserve chairman whom President. Carter has nominated as Treasury Secretary, knew of the payments. [Page A1.]

title: Film: Devil's Legacy In 'Amityville Horror':A Family in Peril
description: GEORGE LUTZ (James Brolin) has begun to look shaggy and pink-eyed, and now he has a terrible gray pallor. He communicates with his formerly happy family in monosyllables, and spends too much time sharpening his ax. One night, Kathleen Lutz  played by Margot Kidder, who stubbornly remains the bright-eyed life of the party in "The Amityville Horror," despite signs that plenty is amiss  finds George sitting in the livingroom alone. He is screaming that he is about to crack up, and he has fresh toothmarks on his legs. Kathleen studies the situation, then asks sweetly, "Honey, are you O.K.?"There isn't nearly enough of this sort of inadvertent merriment in "The Amityville Horror," which isn't horrifying enough to do without a few laughs. Still, so many horror-movie clichs have been assembled under the roof of a single haunted house that the effect is sometimes mind-bogglingly messy. There is apparently very little to which the director, Stuart Rosenberg, will not resort. But he still can't come up with anything more hair-raising than the trick of having one Lutz experience a severe start when he or she doesn't realize other Lutzes are in the room. Whenever Mr. Rosenberg stumbles upon an idea as good as this one, he's bound to repeat it over and over again.Scary things do happen in the movie, but they're always telegraphed in advance and make too little sense to have a cumulative effect. The Lutzes, you see, have moved into a house where a man murdered his entire family a year earlier, and the house doesn't want the Lutzes around. "Get out!" the house cries. The house works in very literal ways.It also causes members of the clergy to vomit whenever they visit the place, and has toilets that spew forth black goo. So much for the niceties. There are also mechanical difficulties, like a telephone that severs the connection every time Kathleen tries to call her priest, played by Rod Steiger. Mr. Steiger bellows and weeps and overdoes absolutely everything. He won't even pick up the phone before it's rung 12 or 15 times.However  such is the logic of this story  the clock radio always works perfectly. And whenever it reads 3:15 A.M. something terrible happens. Eventually, it turns out that the house's problem is in the basement, and that behind the basement wall are the gates of hell. This will come as a great surprise to any fans of "The Sentinel," a movie of several years ago that definitively located the gates of hell on the top floor of a Brooklyn Heights brownstone, guarded by John Carradine, Burgess Meredith and Sylvia Miles."The Amityville Horror" opens today at the Cinerama and other theaters. It was also screened at the Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday, to introduce the museum's tribute to the movies made by American International Pictures. The A.I.P. festival will include "The Amityville Horror," but it's too lifeless to be on a par with the fast, funny, deliberatly slapdash movies that have made A.I.P. such a B-movie bastion. This one is a B-minus.

title: Moscow's Afghan Mess
description: Since the time of Alexander the Great, Afghanistan has been warred over and wooed by East and West while obdurately going its own way. There was alarm in Washington a generation ago when Nikita Khrushchev, following in the Czarist tradition, pressed an elaborate Soviet assistance program on Kabul. An astute British journalist predicted at the time that the tangle of Afghan tribalism and the national gift for dissimulation would baffle the Soviet Russians as completely as they baffled the Imperial British.

title: EARNINGS Schlumberger Profit Up 22.3% for 2d Quarter
description: Schlumberger Ltd., a major oilfield services company, reported a 22.3 percent surge in secondquarter earnings yesterday, on 19.6 percent increase in revenue.

title: It's Gilda Radner, Live From Broadway
description: The star of television's Saturday Night Live opens tonight in previews at the Muter Garden in a series of skits and songs. See page C24.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Excess supplies of overweight cattle helped push livecattle futures sharply lower yesterday. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle prices fell by 1.15 cents to 1.5 cents a pound, the daily trading limit.

title: Restaurants
description: AFTER cooking at several New York restaurants during the last 11 years, the Frenchborn chef Claude Baills seems finally to have found the right home. Claude's sevenweekold restaurant on 81st Street just east of Third Avenue, is already cause for celebration among gas. tronomes, even at so early a datg with several flaws still to be ironed out. After working as a saucier at LUteCe, ana, Melly as tie chef at The Four Seasons, Mr. Baills was the chef at The Palace for two years. Late last year, he and two partners opened Claude's on Lexington Avenue, a venture that was shortlived primarily because of a clash of personalities. (It continues as Le Plaisir operated by the remaining partners.) Although Mr. Baills has always exhibited considerable promise as a chef, this is the first time his talents have come together with so high a degree of style and consistency, as five meals at the new Claude's indicate.

title: Mohsen, P.L.O. Aide, Dies of Gun Wounds; Retaliation Is Pledged
description: CANNES, France, July 26 (AP) - Zuheir Mohsen, a high official in the Palestine Liberation Organization, died in Nice hospital today of a head wound, inflicted in an apparently wellorganized ambush here by two men. He had been in a coma for 36 hours.

title: S.E.C. Acts on Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new disclosure requirements today to help protect minority shareholders when companies go private, or buy up their own stock and return to private ownership.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Podiatric Medicine

title: Screen: 'Nighthawks':Documentary Tone
description: "NIGHTHAWKS" is so realistic, or at least so intimately close to its main character, that it has the feeling of a documentary. A London schoolteacher named Jim (Ken Robertson) is seen cruising homosexual bars by night and at work in the daytime, with the camera watching him almost as impartially and guardedly as he seems to be watching the world. The camera works so passively, in fact, that it never establishes anything about Jim directly. And since Jim is quite taciturn, "Nighthawks," which opens at Quad 1 today, sometimes suffers from a dearth of information. But the character is intriguing and well-played, a fellow about whom one would want to know more. And the film, though it's overlong and aimless at times, presents a vivid if mysterious portrait.Certain things can be deduced about Jim from his tendency to choose elusive younger men, from his impenetrable politeness, from the tiny differences between his behavior in homosexual surroundings and his manner at work. He makes no attempt to conceal his homosexuality from his colleagues, nor does he announce it; consequently, a lot of them assume he is heterosexual. There's a very delicate scene in the film between Jim and a woman co-worker who has become his friend, an unhappily married woman who seems to have designs on him. She complains about domestic life with her husband, and Jim talks about his difficulties in living with anyone, too.Jim avoids pronouns for a while, but when he finally refers to a lover as "he," the woman can barely control her disappointment and surprise. But control it she does, because she doesn't want to jeopardize a good friendship. Meanwhile, Jim does the kindest possible thing by staring into his drink to give her time to compose herself.The only other episode that stands out from the film's deliberate pattern of repetition is the moment when a few budding juvenile delinquents in Jim's class taunt him with rumors that he is a homosexual. Jim handles this beautifully, explaining matter-of-factly that the rumors are true and answering a patient "No" each time they ask whether he wears women's dresses or carries a purse. Ron Peck and Paul Hallam, who collaborated on writing, producing and directing the film, almost make the episode look like cinema vrit, and in fact much of the kids' rude catcalling becomes a jumble of noise. So Jim's evenness stands out all the more, as the one constant element in a heated, chaotic scene.There surely must be more to Jim than meets the eye, or than Mr. Hallam and Mr. Peck bother to explain. In the interests of depicting London's homosexual nightlife honestly and accurately, they've short-changed the character to a certain degree, generalizing his experience more than they needed to. They have also sacrificed any shapeliness the film might have had to this same desire for verisimilitude. Still, "Nighthawks" is gentle and believable, and Mr. Robertson gives a performance that's as touching and consistent as the circumstances allow.

title: Notes on People
description: It was back in 1977 that Walter H. Air oenberg offered the Metropolitan Mut.eum of Art $40 million for the construction of a Fine Arts Center. But when some city officials examining the bffer seemed to him to be looking a gift horse in the mouth, an offended Mr. Annenberg summarily withdrew his pledge and looked instead into putting the money into a Fine Arts Center at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Pop Music: A Look Back
description: ASINGING trio, SRO, that seems to have taken its billing style from Hyman Kaplan, has developed its performing style as a survey of the pop singing groups of the last 50 years.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Phelps Dodge Net Up 237%
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's secondlargest copper producer, reported yesterday that its secondquarter net income soared 237 percent to $39.7 million, or $1.60 a share. Sales and operating revenues of $339.8 million, increased 73.9 percent. The largest producer is the Kennecott Copper Cornoration.

title: Murdoch Seeks Permit For Australia TV Outlet
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 26  Rupert Murdoch, publisher of The New York Post and other newspapers, declared today that he was an Australian citizen, if not a fulltime resident of the country, and was therefore qualified to acquire a Sydney television station.

title: He Spelled It Racewya
description: Your real sports fans, the Press agent was saying, are getting shortchanged. They're looking for heroes, but what they're getting are mostly sterile, unreal athletes who can't be reached.

title: Big Apple Games on Weekend Schedule
description: Competitions in the Big Apple Games continue this weekend at locations around the city. Winners of the matches, which include soccer, athletics, swimming and wrestling, will compete in statewide finals next month in Syracuse.

title: I.R.S. Plan on Segregated Private Schools Threatened
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)  The Senate Finance Committee declined today to oppose an amendment, passed by the House, that prohibits a crackdown on the taxexempt status of racially segreeated private schools.

title: Psychiatric Test Due for Suspect In Shooting of Boston Policeman
description: BOSTON, July 26 (UPI)  A former city custodian arrested on charges that he held six members of his family hostage and shot a deputy police superintendent in the chest was ordered today to undergo Psychiatric observation.

title: A Living, Minimum Wage
description: WASHINGTON  The minimum wage remains a controversial piece of social legislation. It is repeatedly blamed for a host of problems including high teenage unemployment rates and costpush inflation; while others bless the minimum wage for saving millions from dire want.

title: Resorts Concern Plans 2d Casino In Atlantic City
description: NILANIIC CITY, July 26  Resorts International Inc., which opened the nation's first legalized gambling casino outside Las Vegas 19 months ago here and has since set earnings records, said today that it would spend more than $120 million to build another larger Boardwalk casino and 1,000room hotel on 56 acres of oceanfront property just north of the Steel Pier.

title: Bonn Trade Surplus Off For June
description: BONN, July 26  West Germany recorded a trade surplus in June of $919 million, the smallest monthly surplus since August 1976 and one that gave the country its lowest firsthalf trade surplus of any year since 1973.

title: 5 Japanese Dead in Gas Blast
description: TOKYO, July 26 (UPI)  An explosion caused by leaking propane gas blew up a twostory apartment house early today, killing at least five people and injuring eight in Chiba City, east of Tokyo, authorities said.

title: ExMayor Who Left an Imprint
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 26  In recent days Moon Lapdrieu has been engaged in one of his favorite activities, ringing doorbells and canvassing for votes.

title: News Summary
description: Formation of a new Indian regime was started as President N. Sanjiva Reddy asked Charan Singh to head it. Mr. Singh, who led the move that ousted Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai 12 days ago, said that the major priorities of his government would be to eliminate unemployment, fight poverty and narrow differences among India's classes. [Page Al, Column 1.]

title: About Real Estate
description: The conversion of rental apartment buildings to cooperative or condominium ownership is rarely accomplished without a degree of acrimony as the tenants and the owners, or sponsors as they are known, negotiate over prices and possible evictions.

title: The City
description: Voiceactivated firealarm boxes throughout Manhattan were back in operation after malfunctioning for several hours Wednesday night, authori, ties said.

title: Mariners Lose, 121, To Stone of Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, July 26 (UPI)  Lee May hit a grandslam homer, Ken Singleton drove in five runs and Steve Stone pitched a fivehitter to lead the Baltimore Orioles to a 121 rout of the Seattle Mariners tnnirrht The Orioles opened a 30 lead in the third inning when Singleton hit his 29th homer following Al Bumbry's single and Kiko Garcia's fielder's choice grounder. Baltimore then erupted for nine runs in the fourth, all coming after two were out.

title: Textron Outlays In Miller's Years QueriedatSE.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 - A Securities and Exchange Commission staff investigation has concluded that the Textron Corporation made more than $13 million in improper and questionable payments abroad while G. William Miller, nominated by President Carter to be Treasury Secretary, was the company's senior officer.

title: PRESIDENT'S CHOICES FOR TRANSPORTATION AND H.U.D. REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  President Carter has selected Moon Landrieu, the former Mayor of New Orleans and an early Carter supporter in 1976, as the new Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, White House officials reported today.

title: Panel to Assess Radiation Claims
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  President Carter has established a highlevel task force to recommend a fair way of dealing with claims for compensation filed by persons who say they became ill as a result of exposure to radiation from atomic weapons tests.

title: Civiletti Choice Criticized Anew; Two Othei Nominations Backed
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)  President Carter's nomination of Benjamin R. Civiletti to head the Justice Department ran into more opposition from Hispanic groups today, but two other nominations were quickly accepted by Senate comittees.

title: Deaths
description: ADELMANLucille. The Hospital Family of Long Island JewishHill. side Medical Center Is deeply saddened by the death of Lucille Adel. man, who had served as Dental Services Manager. She was a woman of great humanity, tremendous courage and remarkable humor, who touched the lives of thousands during the 20 years she worked here. We will miss her a great deal. War. most condolences are extended to her family. Robert K. Match, M.D., President

title: Companies Have Employees on the Run
description: For a moment the muggy Central Park stillness was broken. A breeze was gathering, blowing harder and faster down the drive. With the breeze came the runners who created it, about 3,000 of them in a dense pack, pounding out a furious rhythm on the hot pavement.

title: Ford and Chrysler Delay 1980 Model Introductions
description: DETROIT, July 26  The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, their dealer inventories swollen with unsold 1979 model year cars and trucks, have decided to delay by as much as two weeks the introduction of their 1980 model cars, officials of both companies disclosed today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: President Carter ducked the question when he was asked at his news conference if he might withdraw from the campaign next year and devote himself exclusively to governing the nation. But Mr. Carter probably will stay in the race at least until events take him out, in Senator Henry Jackson's phrase. And they might.

title: Capital Politics at Urban League Talks
description: CHICAGO, July 25  The Federal people came in waves this week to participate in the 69th annual conference of the National Urban League. They ranged from such worldclass notables as Rosalynn Carter and Senator Edward M. Kenneay to such unknowns as the C.I.A. man who was once a social worker in Cleveland and the two ladies from the Defense Mapping Agency.

title: At the Movies
description: WHEN you think of Goldie Hawn, or at least of the roles she has played, you don't automatically think of a woman completely in command of her destiny, a mover and Shaper of business affairs. Rather, indeed, of a fragile yellow flower blown hither and yon by the gusts of chance.

title: President Signs Trade Bill in Rose Garden Ceremony
description: President Carter shares a laugh with Robert S. Strauss, special trade representative, after Mr. Carter signed into law a trade liberalization pact reached after years of negotiations with 99 nations.

title: ArmsPact Debate Points Spotlight At a Handful of Senate Staff Aides
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Traditionally, Congressional staff aides have labored in the shadows beyond the limelight that their elected bosses seek. But in the complex debate over the new strategic arms treaty Wan tne soviet union, handful of Senate staff specialists on nuclear weapons are achieving a position of influence and prominence that such aides rarely occupy.

title: Associated Press
description: PAPAL DELIGHT: Pope John Paul H holding a baby aloft after seeing her in the crowd at his weekly audience on Wednesday in Vatican City.

title: Panel Rules Admonition For Yonkers City Judge
description: The New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct has determined that Judge John D'Apice of the Yonkers City Court should be admonished for misconduct.

title: Northwest, Delta Show Profit Gains
description: Northwest Orient Airlines reported yesterday that its secondquarter net income rose by 66.3 percent to $34.1 million, or $1.58 a share, from $20.5 million, or 95 cents a share, in the quarter last year. The company said the rise reflected a 119 percent gain in revenues to $343.8 million, from $160.3 million in the quarter last year.

title: City to Lose Animal Affairs Chief
description: Dr. Alan Beck is leaving his post as head of New York City's Bureau of Animal Affairs to take a position at the University of Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Reinaldo A. Ferrer, the city's Health Commissioner. Dr. Ferrer said Dr. Beck would become director of the university's Center for the Interaction of Animals and Society. Dr. Beck, the Commissioner said, will be missed by both the people and animals of New York City.

title: Hybrid Ape, Born in Atlanta Zoo, Is Linked to New Evolution Idea
description: The chance mating of two species of ape in an Atlanta zoo has led to the birth of a healthy offspringthe first reported ape hybrid.

title: When It's Summertime, The Listenin Is Easy
description: IN summertime, it seems, the urban outdoors, suburbia, exurbia and the plain old countryside become concert halls. The tradition of the village band playing in the local square has expanded to include symphony programs of the most sophisticated character and chamber music of a decidedly subtle nature. People walk to Lincoln Center's Dam rosch Park to listen to the Guggenheim Concerts given by the Goldman Band under sycamores and red maples that soften the marble and concrete surroundings. Or they drive to Tanglewood in the Berkshires hear the Boston Symphony while sitting on the old Tappan estate's great luxurious lawn.

title: Stocks Post Token Advances
description: The stock market posted a token gain yesterday on the heels of Wednesday's broadbased rally. Investor enthusiasm was restrained by the Labor Department announcement that consumer prices in June rose 1 percent, bringing the annual rate of increase for the first half of the year to 13.2 percent. This reminder of the continuing high rate of inflation counterbalanced the nomination of Paul A. Volcker as the next Federal Reserve Board chairman, which had helped to send stock prices briskly ahead Wednesday.

title: Commissioner Sees End of L.P. G.A. if 2 Men Gain Entry to Tour
description: Quebec, July 26  Two men who have been refused permission to play on the women's golf tour are threatening to sue the Ladies Professional Golf Association for discrimination in what Commissioner Ray Volpe of the L.P.G.A. said could probably be the biggest legal threat to women's sports in our lifetime.

title: 5th Man Is Held As a Kidnapper In Paterson Case
description: PATERSON, N.J., July 26  In an unexpected development in the investigation into the kidnapping of a bank executive's wife, a fifth suspect who had been sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation walked into Police Headquarters here at 9:50 this morning and surrendered to the desk officer.

title: Mikolajczyk Returns to Sign Giant Pact
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 26  Of the four new faces at the Giants training camp today, Ron Mikolajczyk's was the most familiar and the most welcome.

title: Lax Auditing Leads to Fear Of RevenueSharing Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Auditing requirements enacted in 1976 to prevent misuse of general revenue sharing funds have been so widely flouted by state and local governments that a considerable amount or corruption may well have been concealed in the $7billionayear program, according to a new study.

title: Panama Pact Passed By the Senate, Sending Measure to Conferees
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (Reuters) Legislation to carry out the Panama Canal treaties was approved by the Senate today by a vote of 64 to :10.

title: Country Cousins Pay a Musical Visit Of 71/2 Weeks in Broadway Opry 79
description: ROADWAY theaters have been the sites of increasingly diverse fare in recent years, from ballet to pop concerts and all manner of oneperson revues. But tonight's opening of Broadway Opry 79 at the St. James Theater 9dR west 44th Street, represents a first seven and a half weeks of countrymusic concerts, with some of the bestknown names in the field.

title: Tuna Being Taken Off Southern Jersey
description: AREA A  Ralph Stork of Captain Andy's Marina at Margate, N.J., reports the yellowfin tuna have appeared in the Atlantic about 28 miles southeast of Great Egg Inlet. The favorite spot is 28mite wreck, wnere tne water nas warmed to 7077 degrees. Cedar plugs, green machines and soft heads, all highspeed trolling lures, are being used to catch the tuna. Inshore, about two to three miles from Great Egg Inlet, the bluefish are still plentiful and daily catches are reported as outstanding. Blues and flounder are being taken about three miles off Barnegat Light Inlet. Ten miles farther out bonita up to 10 pounds have been trolled successfully while the tuna, some weighing 250 pounds, have been caught in the Canyon, some 30 miles out in the Atlantic.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Prices Stage Modest Rise
description: The credit markets rose modestly yesterday in a mildmannered continuation of the rally that was touched off Wednesday after Paul A. Volcker was nominated to head the Federal Reserve Board. Bond prices generally moved up an eighth or a Quarterpoint.

title: Ballet: Cuban Changes
description: THERE wasn't a great deal for dancer to do Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, but the National Ballet of Cuba did freshen the troops in several of this season's short ballets.

title: Stage: Maugham Comedy in VVestport
description: THE drawingroom comedy did not begin with W. Somerset Maugham's The Circle, although its appearance probably settled the shape of the genre once and for all. Maugham wrote it in 1921.

title: 2 Nazis Bound Over in Rape Case
description: VINELAND, N.J., July 26  Two men, one an acknowledged leader in the American Nazi Party and the other a Ku Klux Klan leader as well, as a Nazi, were bound over to a Cumberland County grand jury today on charges of handcuff.. ing and raping a 19yearold Philadelphia woman whom they suspected of spying on them for the Jewish Defense League.

title: State Seeks Tighter Control of Vocational Education
description: Five years ago, New York State's Education Department decided that the Recording Institute of America in Manhattan was offering a vocationaleducation program in the field of sound recording and ordered it to apply for a license.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, July 26,1979

title: Art: Time for OldMaster Prints
description: IT is not often that dealers galleries offer us the equivalent of beginners course in high art. They are not there to provide freshman orientation, in the first place. And in the second place, with rents as high as they are, no dealer can afford to hang pictures that cost as little as $25 or $30 a time.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: It was encouraging to hear, during the President's news conference Wednesday, how strenuously he promises to support Patricia Harris, his replacement for Joseph Califano as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, in her efforts to protect the nation's health and to work for equal opportunity. The President didn't talk that way on Mr. Califano's behalf when the outgoing Secretary was battling North Carolina over smoking and desegregation.

title: Economic Scene
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT CARTER and his top advisers feel that the Presidnt had absolutely no choice, as Ambassador Robert S. Strauss put it, but nominate a tough and independent monetary conservative like Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The Huntington Arts Council is presenting an Evening of Swing at 8:30 tonight as part of its summer arts festival. The Charles Nostrand Quartet will perform, with the leader on clarinet, Hap Gormley on drums, Don Bain on vibraphones and Gerry Manecke on piano and saxophone. Jerry Verme, an other pianist, will make a guest appearance. The concert will be presented at the new band shell in Heckscher Park, at Prime Avenue and Route 25A, east of the village of Huntington, CI. The folding chairs, blankets or cushions you bring will add to your comfort. Rain places the event in the Toaz Junior High School Auditorium on Nassau Road. Admission: $2; $1 for the elderly and those 12 and younger. Information: 2718923.

title: August Gas Allocations Expected to Equal July's
description: The first reports of gasoline allocations for August indicate that supplies at the retail level will be at least as good then as in July.

title: Business and the Law
description: IN the genteel days before airconditioning, lawyers and judges in Manhattan would take long, leisurely summer breaks. That has changed now, especially  in Manhattan's Federal courts, where many of the country's most important business cases are tried.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio  WMCA, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee. (Television  Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio WINS, 8:30 P.M.) GOLF

title: Japan's Soft Persuasion Cuts Energy Use
description: TOKYO, July 26  For the first time since the oil crisis in 1973, the lights of Tokyo have been turned down.

title: Events and Openings
description: BROADWAY OPRY 79: A LITTLE COUNTRY IN THE BIG CITY, with Tanya Tucker, Floyd Cramer, Don Gibson and Mickey Newberry, at the St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street, 8, through July 29.

title: Book Says British Ignored Jews War Plight
description: LONDON, July 26  A book published here today states that Britain, absorbed in a war for survival against Nazi Germany, turned its back on the millions of suffering Jews in Europe.

title: 7 Injured in Cable Car Collision
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP) Seven personS were injured yesterday when a cable car failed to stop in a busy downtown intersection and struck two automobiles, the authorities reported. The accident halted service for 45 minutes yesterday on the PowellMason lisle, between Market Street and the Fisherman's Wharf area.

title: For Children
description: THE MUPPETS: A CELEBRATION, features the art and history of Jim Hensen's creations on The Mupbet Show and Sesame Street, Monday and Thurs. day, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M., Tuesday and Wednesday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Friday and Saturday, noon to 6 P.M., through Aug. 11, at the New York Public Li, brary, Amsterdam Gallery, Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, I11 Amster. dam Avenue. Free. Call 7992200.

title: Washington Post Earnings
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)  The Washington Post Company reported yesterday that secondquarter earnings were slightly below the 1978 quarter when there was a special, nonrecurring gain of $3.8 million from sale or a radio station. Earnings for the period ended July 1 were put at $15.4 million, or 98 cents a share, compared with $17.2 million, or $1.06 a share, in the yearago quarter. Revenues for the latest quarter were $152.3 million, up from $135.1 million in the 1978 period.

title: SIR CHARLES CLORE, FINANCIER, DIES AT 74
description: LONDON, July 26 (AP)  Sir Charles Clore, one of the richest men in Britain, died in the London Clinic today. He was 74 years old.

title: Cubs Beat Mets, 92
description: The Mets started out so well last night against the Chicago Cubs. Xrays showed Richie Hebner's thumb was not broken, so he started at third base. Lee Mazzilli said he felt fine, though Manager Joe Torre held him out, so he could have an extra day to recuperate from Monday's collision.

title: Innovation From Per Spook, Classics From Gres
description: PARIS, July 26  It took a Norwegian to give a contemporary feeling to the couture. Today,,on the last day of the week of fall fashion openings, Per Spools, who has headed his Own house here for a few seasons, sent a fresh Scandinavian wind rustling through the collections, clearing the air of all those musty, charming, Victorian echoes that have pervaded the salons. His lines are neat and crisp and his angular shapes are emphasized by geometric prints, mostly dots and stripes and some zigzag lines.

title: Karl Krueger, 85, Dies in Chicago; Founded Orchestras in U. S.
description: Karl Krueger, American conductor, died last Saturday in Chicago after a brief illness. He was 85 years old.

title: New York Area Shows Increase Of 1% in Prices
description: Rising costs of gasoline, heating fuels and other energy supplies paced consumer prices in the Metropolitan New York and northern New Jersey area to another sharp 1 percent increase in June, the Federal Government reported yesterday.

title: SolarEnergy Appointee
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) Seeking to underscore its commitment to solar power, the United States Department of Energy. today named Denis Hayes, chairman of the Solar Lobby, as director of its Solar Energy Research Center. The Solar Lobby has been a persistent critic of what it regards as inadequate Government financing for solar development.

title: Whamo Draws Post One For $862,750 Wilson Pace
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 26  Whamo, owned by Beverly Kristal of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., drew the No. 1 post position for the nation's richest event for either thoroughbreds or harness horses, the $862,750 Woodrow Wilson Pace scheduled for next Wednesday at the Meadowlands.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Decolonization Committee's Subcommittee on Small Territories10:30 A.M.

title: 10 Rikers I, Doctors Are Indicted On Charges They Falsified Bills
description: Ten Rikers Island doctors who allegedly bilked the city of more than $30,000 by falsifying their time sheets were indicted by a Bronx grand jury yesterday on grand larceny charges.

title: Associated Press
description: UNDER THE TAG: Phil Garner of Pirates sliding under tag of Ray Knight of Reds in second inning of 97 Reds victory last night. Umpire Paul Runge watches play.

title: Kathleen E. Harrity Bride Of S.I. Feinstein, Auditor
description: Kathleen Elaine Harrity, daughter of Muriel, P. Fishman of Short Hills, N.J., and Peter C. Harrity of Denver, was married yesterday to Steven I. Feinstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Feinstein of Parsippany, N.J. The Rev. Alan Reading performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Society of Plainfield, N.J.

title: New Face: Patti D'Arbanville Coughing Her Way to Stardom
description: THE cough appears to come up from her very toes, such booming, basso bark from tiny body that it convulses audiences seeing The Main Event. The critics called it the funniest thing in the film that stars Barbra Streisand and Ryan O'Neal.

title: Finding Where the Music Is And When It's Playing
description: Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center. Today and Sunday at 8 P.M. The Goldman Band, conducted by Richard Franko Goldman. Saturday at 7:30 P.M. The New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra; (raindate, Monday). Admission free to both concerts. Information: 8678290.

title: California Inquiry: Who Is to Judge Judges?; News Analysis
description: Several months ago, in a magazine article, Rose Elizabeth Bird, the Chief Justice of California's Supreme Court, spoke of why judges must end their insularity. She concluded the article, which appeared in The Judges Journal, a publicaLion of the American Bar Association, with a quotation from a 1949 speech by Associate Justice William 0. Douglas of the Supreme Court.

title: SINCH ASKED TO PICK A CABINET IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, July 26  President N. Sanjiva Reddy of India asked Charm) Singh today to form a new government, upholding the 77yearold maverick politician's claim to the support of a majority of Parliament's 538 members.

title: Screen: 'Just You and Me, Kid':Nice, Nice, Nice
description: BROOKE SHIELDS plays a foster child nobody wants in "Just You and Me, Kid," a movie with a sense of reality that is, at best, a little dim. George Burns finds her in the trunk of his car, where she is dressed in nothing but an inner tube, looking too coquettish for a film as clean-cut and cheery as this one means to be. Her involvement in a drug deal and her habit of swearing don't add anything to the fairy-tale atmosphere, either. But by the end of the movie she does give Mr. Burns a new lease on life, which is the second most important thing he needs here. The first is a script full of jokes. A very few mild chuckles are all this screenplay has to offer."Just You and Me, Kid"  which opens today at Loews State and other theaters  is utterly benign, less like a movie than like a warm bath. There are no strong sentiments except nice ones, nothing unpleasant to look at. Not a chair is out of place in the overdecorated, expensive, brightly colored house where Mr. Burns is supposed to live. When a villain knocks down a frosted-glass door in one scene, the door is magically intact a moment later.This house, carefully geared to the character's vaudeville history, has an alarm clock that wakes him with the sound of applause and later in the day plays "Swanee." The ingenuity and efficiency of the place are meant to testify to this old fellow's unimpaired competence, to take the sting out of the aging process. The effect of this is so antiseptic that a relatively hard-edged subplot, involving Mr. Burns's daughter (Lorraine Gary) and her attempts to have him declared senile, is nasty but welcome. And anyway, Miss Gary is a much better sparring partner for Mr. Burns than Miss Shields is.Goodness knows, Mr. Burns can go it alone; he seems more at ease when talking or singing or dancing a soft-shoe by himself than he does in anyone's company. In fact, by teaming him with Miss Shields the film effec-tively bogs him down. She can't match his wit, or even converse with him comfortably. She can only look pretty, admire his geriatric spunk and give off a sentimental glow. Mr. Burns doesn't benefit from being enshrined in this way.Ray Bolger turns up briefly as one of Mr. Burns's old vaudeville pals, and John Schuck and Andrea Howard play the couple next door who spy on him and alway wear matching outfits. Burl Ives has the film's most dismal chore, that of making a miracle recovery from catatonia thanks entirely to the kindly advice of Mr. Burns's young friend, who in a movie of this sort is bound to be wise beyond her years."Just You and Me, Kid" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") because of some of Miss Shields's language.

title: Effects of Storm Are Felt From Texas to Indiana
description: A tropical storm pounded the Texas coast yesterday, sending hundreds of people fleeing, scrambling communications and transportation and shutting down the nation's training base for astronauts.

title: INFLATION IS RISING BY 13.2% ANNUALLY; JUNE PRICES UP 1%
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 - Inflation ran at a blistering annual rate of 13.2 percent in the first half of 1979, the Government reported today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DORIC (Home Lines). Left Bermuda July 26; due at 8. A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Useful Lead in Theft of $600,000
description: Some useful, helpful information has been turned up in last weekend's theft of $600,000 in subway receipts from a Transit Authority headquarters safe, a spokesman said yesterday, without offering details. The New York City police, the Brooklyn District Attorney and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are helping in the investieation.

title: What's on Tap at Modern's Retrospective
description: Following is the schedule of films from American International Pictures to be shown this weekend at the Museum of Modem Art Retrospective:

title: 'Abductor Gets $20,000 Payoff From a Banker
