description: The 96yearold manager of an East Orange, N.J., bank appatently fell victim to a kidnapping hoax yesterdaysand paid a ransom of more than $20,000 before discovering that his two daughters  the purported, victims  had been safe all along.

title: ExIm Bank Guarantee
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (Reuters)The ExportImport Bank said it had ap proved a guarantee covering part of the financing of a purchase by British Airways of two Lockheed L1011200 planes worth $69.96 million. The guar. antee covers $19.3 million of a private financing, it said.

title: Boy Wins $4.1 Million Damages
description: CHICAGO, July 26, (Reuters)  A 14yearold boy who suffered brain damage at birth when the drug Pitocin was administered to hasten delivery has been awarded $4.1 million in damaees. his attorney said today. The settlement is to be paid by the insurers of the Augusta Hospital where the boy, Luis Lopez, was born. The hospital is now suing the manufacturer, Parke Davis, charging that failed to warn of potential dangers of the drug when used in births involving complications.

title: Publishing: Last Chapter in Biblo &
description: THE shelves were virtually empty, the customers few, and the occasion was melancholy. Biblo & Tannen, for two generations a gathering place for booklovers, was going out of business after 51 years of partnership, more than half that at the present address, 43 Fourth Avenue. The ill health of one of the partners, Jack rannen, triggerea the move, though on the morning a visitor dropped by to see him, Mr. Tannen was his usual ebullient, dynamic and enthusiastic self, discoursing on the antiquarian book business today, on some of his experiences and the pleasures and pains that come with the profession.

title: Attitude of Dubuque Voters On Carter Is Wait and See
description: DUBUQUE, Iowa, July 26 President Carter has tapped a reservoir of good will in this most Democratic of Iowa cities with what voters generally seeas belated but earnest efforts to deal with major problems facing the nation and his Presidency.

title: Guidry Hurls 3Hitter As the Ailing Yanks Conquer Angels, 20.
description: Ron Guidry's pitching was about the only healthy aspect of the Yankees 20 victory over the California Angels yesterday at Yankee Stadium.

title: Radio
description: 9 A.M.Noon, WFUV. Excerpts from Coppelia, Delibes; Twelve Waltzes, Schubert; Choral Fantasy, Beethoven; Theme and Variations, Schoenberg.

title: Books of The Times
description: HISTORY'S CARNIVAL. A Dissident's Autobiography. By Leonid Plyushch. With a Contribution by Tatyana Plyushch. Edited and translated by Marco Carynnyk. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book, 429 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: Business Loans Climb At Big New York Banks
description: Commercial and industrial loans at the major New York banks climbed by $193 million in the week ended Wednesday, in contrast to a $207 million decline in the comparable week last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Junta Allows 199 to Leave Nicaragua
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 26 Nicaragua's revolutionary Government gave its permission today for 199 persons who took refuge in a foreign embassy after the overthrow of Anastasio Somoza Debayle to leave the country.

title: Art People
description: If HAT bright, magical occasion, writes Gore Vidal of a soire at the art patron Peggy Guggenheim's apartment in the mid1940's: I still think that somewhere, even now, in a side street of New York City, that party is still going on.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bearings Inc., a Clevelandbased maker and distributor of bearings, has named Joseph M. Bruening chairman, a post that had been vacant since the death of Harold C. Schott in 1977.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Heavy clouds associated with showers and thunderstorms extend from New England through the Ohio Valley, the Mississippi Valley and into the Texas Panhandle. Another area of thunderstorm clouds is visible over the Northern Plains States. Skies are clear in the western half of the country.

title: Reporter's Notebook: At the White House, Jeans Are Out and Neckties Are Cinched Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  The most conspicuous symbol of the revamped Carter White House  the new, improved 1980 model, as one staff member described it with a smile this week  is the necktie.

title: Pan Am Acquires Stock Majority In Contest for National Airlines
description: Pan American World Airways, vigorously pursuing a bid to take over National Airlines, disclosed yesterday that it now holds more than 51 percent of National's stock.

title: New Face: Mary D'Arcy
description: SHE was Miss New Jersey of 1977, she finished third in the Miss America Pageant the same year, she's in love and engaged and she's now Marian the Librarian, the darling of audiences in her professional debut in The Music Man at the Jones Beach Theater.

title: Mayor Set to Give Council a Raise as Debate Continues on Its Role
description: They range from a corporate lawyer who makes more than $50,000 from his practice to a onetime social worker whose only outside income is child support, from a former school teacher who says she works 80 hours a week at her elected office to businessmen whose public service hours are half that.

title: Robbery Suspect Shot After Fleeing on Bike
description: A man who allegedly robbed a grocery and a delicatessen in Astoria, Queens, last night and then fled on a bicycle was shot in the head by a police officer after a struggle in which he shot an offduty policeman in the hand and then took a woman hostage, the police reported.

title: Puerto Rico: Home
description: Ironically, my stepfather died in a veterans hospital. The sad day we went to claim his body, I could not help wondering that to his last day the man never truly was assimilated into the American mainstream. He passed away an American (indeed, he was born into citizenship), a survivor of World War II and the Korean confict. Yet, he rarely spoke English, considered American food bland, and he could never understand football.

title: New Vote Set on Gas Rationing
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  House Democratic leaders, chagrined after losing a key floor battle on behalf of President Carter, today scheduled another vote on standby gasoline rationing for next week.

title: BUSINES PEOPLE
description: A pair of new leaders, neither of whom has had any experience in options trading, will take over the Chicago Board Options Exchange before the end of the summer - just as it appears that the Securities and Exchange Commission might be close to lifting its moratorium on expansion in the options field.

title: Broadway
description: Ausual, Wynn Handman says, he is excited; also confident, enthusiastic and optimistic.. Mr. Handman runs the American Place Theater, which has had its difficulties, as anything dedicated to the new and experimental must, but Mr. Handman is going on and so is the American Place Theater. It will oven its fall season with Letters Home, which was hatched from its Women's Project of last season, and which is the dramatization of the letters by Sylvia Plath to her mother. Then it will do Americans in Paris, which Mr. Handman calls a musical celebration, and which will be made up in part of the words of the prominent literary expatriates of the 1920's. The composer is William Russo. Pieces of Americans in Paris appeared elsewhere, when it was called The Alice B. Toklas Hashyudge Revue. Americans in Paris will also be a revue, although its exact form. Mr. Handman says, is still unknown. The new and experimental also means the ad hoc.

title: Museum Celebrates DriveIn Movies
description: THAT Samuel Z. Arkoff and his teenage werewolves, dragstrip riots, beach parties, mad scientists, deformed ghouls, blood beasts, and shark gods should end up in a museum is, he says, gloriously ironic and deliciously funny.

title: The C.I.A., and Honor
description: SOUTH ROYALTON, Vt.  A veteran of the Central Intelligence Agency's clandestine service  now retired after playing a line officer's role in just about every major American foreign policy disaster of the last 20 years  summed up the problem presented by the agency when he said: A secret intelligence service can only support a government's initiatives in the world; it can't take the lead. When an intelligence service gets pushed out in front, and is asked to do secretly what a government can't bring itself to do openly, then your're just looking for trouble.

title: JOHN MAYHER
description: John Mayher, professor emeritus of Phillips Exeter Academy, died yesterday at the Rose Haven Nursing Home in Litchfield, Conn. He was 76 years old.

title: Plastic Surgery for Women in Prison: It Can Mean a New Life
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25  All her life, Maria had avoided mirrors. The 20yearold br'nette didn't want to see the scar above her eyebrow or the protruding nose that had earned he tithe nickname Beak. Because she felt she wasn't attractive enough to be friends with the popular children at school, she joined a gang that terrorized the East Los Angeles barrio where she lived.

title: Learning About Wildlife in a Sylvan Setting
description: If you are interested in birds, mushrooms, wild edibles, snakes, turtles, wildflowers or just a walk in the woods, the annual Sharon Audubon Festival this weekend in Connecticut offers a wide variety of short courses and supervised field trips.

title: 1,000 in Village Renew Protest Against Movie on Homosexuals
description: About 1,000 persons marched through a muggy Greenwich Village last night, protesting the making in New York of the movie Cruising after Mayor Koch had turned down the demand of homosexualrights groups that the city withdraw its suoport of the filming.

title: World News Briefs
description: N'DJAMENA, Chad, July 26 (AP) Interior Minister Goukouni Oueddei, strongman of the Provisional Government, said today that his troops had routed a Libyan invasion force of more than 2,500 in a series of battles in the Tibesti Massif, in Chad's northern desert.

title: House Defies Carter and Backs Breeder Reactor Project
description: WASHINGTON. July 26  The House of Representatives defied President Carter on energy again today, voting to continue the Clinch River breeder reactor that the President vowed to kill.

title: T:WU. Urges C.A.B. To Revoke the Permit Of Argentine Airlines
description: Charging Argentina humanrights violations againstwith striking employees of Argentine Airlines in the United States, the Transport Workers Union yesterday asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to revoke the airline's operating permit.

title: Times in Pact For TV Station
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to purchase WHNTTV, the CBS network affiliate in Huntsville, Ala., from North Alabama Broadcasters Inc. The purchase price for the cash agreement was not dislosed.

title: Dance Notebook: The Uses of Virtuosity
description: One reason why Jul Kylian is one of the most interesting young ballet choreographers in the dance world is his ability to combine choreographic seriousness with choreographic abandon.

title: Name of Mudd Sullied in Lincoln Slaying Gets a Cleaning
description: SAGINAW, Mich., July 26  The name of the doctor who helped Abraham Lincoln's killer escape is still Mudd, but thanks to a determined descendant, it is at least a little cleaner today.

title: Bright Side of the Energy Crisis: Gas Guzzlers Donated to Charity
description: A doctor in Los Angeles wheeled his 1970 Cadillac Coupe deVille into Salvation Army center and handed over the title to a surprised charity worker.

title: McGovern for Kennedy As Democratic Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)  Senator George McGovern said today that Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts was the most logical candidate for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: U.S. Urging Moscow Not to Cancel Permit Of American Reporter
description: MOSCOW, July 26  The United States Embassy has urged the Soviet Government not to withdraw the accreditation of an American journalist representing The Financial Times of London.

title: Deaths
description: GOLDENDr. Maurice A. Beloved husband of Frances, devoted father of Susan and Skip, dear brother of Clara, and brother in law of Irving and Robert. Services today 10AM at Nassau North Chapels 55 North Station Plaza (opp RR sta), Great Neck, LI. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Sadat Says He Plans Cautious Review of Arab Ties
description: CAIRO, July 26  President Anwar elSadat, denouncing opponen's of Egypt's efforts on behalf of Palestinians, said tonight that Egypt must reassess its future relations with other Arab countries very, very cautiously.

title: Advertising
description: GERARD PIEL, president and publisher of Scientific American magazine, went to China as a tourist and returned last week as a partner in a publishing venture with the Chinese Scientific American In China.

title: New York Fed Seeks New Chief
description: The nine directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York have chosen three of their members to serve as a search committee to nominate a new president of the bank to replace Paul A. Volcker, who was named by President Car ter on Wednesday to become the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Vendors Jam 5th Ave. On Summer Sundays
description: Fifth Avenue. Two words that on any wordassociation test would probably evoke elegance or glamour or wealth. They would evoke, too, images of Rockefeller Center, the great department stores, pigeon'sblood rubies glittering in a velvetlined jeweler's window, chic women, a particular kind of sparkle.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Merck &; Company, the chemicals and pharmaceuticals concern, and Alginate Industries Ltd., a British company, announced yesterday an agreement under which a wholly owned British subsidiary of Merck would acquire all the outstanding shares of Alginate for about $52.8 million.

title: Mr. Carter's Diplomatic High Note
description: President Carter sounded exactly the right note his news conference remarks on the devil theory of the revolution in Nicaragua. It gives Premier Castro far too much credit to assume that any abrupt change Latin America must be due to secret Cuban machinations. As Mr. Carter said, the fact is that the Somoza regime lost the confidence of its own people and was opposed by a broad range of forces. And the President was right to emphasize that the American aim was work with Nicaragua's Latin neighbors for an orderly transition, short of intervention.

title: Breths
description: PAGE  George T.B. of Welleslev. Mass, Jul 25,1979, brother of Polly Butterbaugh of Kenosha, Wis. Memorial service Burtt Chapel of Welleslev Congregational Church (Village Church), Welleslev Square, Sat, Jul 28 at 10 o'clock. Relatives & friends invited. In lieu of flowers gifts in his memory may be made to Welleslev Congregational Church Memorial Fund, Church St, Welleslev, Mass 02181. Services by. WatermanBrown & McDonald of Welleslev, Mass.

title: 14th St. Holds a Fiesta
description: A bull will charge a matador on West 14th Street this Sunday and, if the matador prevails, he will slice off the bull's ear and tail before the contest is over. But those queasy of heart won't have to hide their faces  there won't be any blood. The bull, although lifesize, will be electronically controlled from the sidelines by its Mexican engineer.

title: CORRECTION
description: In The Living Section on Wednesday, an incorrect address was given for the Well Bred Loaf. The correct address is 1742 Second Avenue (90th Street).

title: Vietnam Says the Pol Pot Forces Beat 26,000 Prisoners to Death
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 26 (Reuters)  Vietnam charged today that 26,000 people were massacred over a threeyear period at a Cambodian concentration camp set up by the former regime of Prime Minister Pol Pot.

title: New York Review of Books Plans London Edition to Fill Strike Gap
description: The New York Review of Books, which began during the long 1963 newspaper strike in New York, is planning to publish a literary supplement in London in the fall. The project is a result of the absence of The Times Literary Supplement, a weekly that has not appeared since The Times of London and The Sunday Times were shut down nearly eight months ago in a complex labor dispute.

title: Art: Polish History Through Photos
description: DESPITE the multitude of photography exhibitions that are now a regular and quite popular part of every New York season, the number of shows that brings us something really new in photographysomething we have neither seen before nor read ahnnt in books nor even heard rumors of  is actually quite small. It is therefore special pleasure to welcome a new exhibition called Fotografia Polska (18391979), which opened this week at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue at 94th Street (through Sept. 15). This is a marvelous show. It upholds a very, high esthetic standard, it is rich in historical interest, and there is virtually nothing in it that anyone here has seen before. It is a show that will enthrall the professional and amateur alike.

title: Around the Nation
description: RICHMOND, Iuly 26 (AP)  A Federal appeals court said today that the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company had provoked a strike of 1,200 marine designers and ordered the designers reinstated with back pay.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Carries Out Pledges; Trims Budget and Role in Industry
description: LONDON, July 26  Margaret Thatch er's Conservative Government ended its 12th week in office today by announcing a plan to curtail the activities of the British National Oil Corporation and make some of its assets available to private investors.

title: The Region
description: CARMEL, N.Y.  A 29yearold unemployed caretaker of estates was arrested and charged with seconddeagree murder in Connection with the death of 15yearold Jill Garrett, a Carmel resident. Her bludgeoned body was discovered in a creek several miles from her home Tuesday morning.

title: Cathy Sherk. at 69. Leads Tackson Golf by 3 Strokes
description: Quebec, July 26  Cathy Sherk, a 29yearold Canadian, shot a fourunderpar 69 today to take a threestroke lead in the opening round of the 72hole Peter Jackson Classic Six golfers were tied at 72  Judy Rankin, Sylvia Bertolaccini, Judy Clark, Kathy McMullen, Mary Dwyer and Pam Higgins. Hollis Stacy, winner of the 1977 and 1978 United States Women's Open championships, was one of 11 players deadlocked at par 73 in the first round of the $150,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tourney on the 6,934yard Richelieu Valley Golf Club course.

title: Harold Burke, 81, Dies; ExNew York Fire Chiel
description: Harold J. Burke, who was chief of the Fire Department in the late 1940's during the administration of Mayor William O'Dwyer, died in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 81 gears old.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday despite President Carter's announcement that he would not take any special steps to support it. It was a very confusing day, said one trader. The dollar was swinging up and down.

title: Prospects Are Good for Weekend Gasoline Supply
description: Most service stations in the New York metropolitan area are expected to have ample gasoline supplies this weekend, but motorists planning trips to resort areas have again been urged to call ahead to make sure that local stations are not experiencing spot shortages.

title: Sleek, Vintage Yachts to Parade at Mystic
description: The parade at the Mystic Seaport Museum in Connecticut tomorrow will have many of the ingredients of parades elsewhere; crowds of cheering spectators; proudly smiling participants, prizes for the best entrants and a dash of flourish alone the route But Mystic's parade is a little different; like most things at the Seaport Museum, everything in its parade is old and floating.

title: Jury Given Case Of Park Assault On 6 in Ramble
description: The case of three young men accused of assaulting and seriously injuring six men in the Central Park Ramble last summer went to the jury last night after the prosecutor urged their conviction for this sordid series of vicious and unprovoked crimes. The jury deliberated for nearly four hours, retiring at 10:30 without having reached a verdict.

title: Bridge:
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 26  Death is normally irreversible, but in a bridge context there can be some rare exceptions. Six weeks ago a group of players from Arkansas and Memphis headed by Al Childs of Little Rock, Ark., lost in a Grand National Team zonal semifinal by more man 100 international match points. But when two of their Florida opponents were detected cheating, and later expelled from the American Contract Bridge League, the Childs team was reinstated in the event and is still alive and well.

title: While the Slick Spreads
description: The highest price the world pays for its reliance on petroleum may turn out to be the environmental damage caused by oil spills. A new record is almost certain to be set this year for the amount of oil disgorged into the seas through spills, blowouts and tanker collisions. And while the slick spreads, remedial legislation languishes in Congress.

title: TV Weekend
description: SUMMERTIME, drenched in reruns, provides an unusual Oppoitunity for flipping the dial and sampling programs outside the predictable borders of commercial prime time. Sunday. for instance. at 11 A.M., NBC's Religious Programi Unit is offering Visions of Film and Death. There is a panel of questioners, consisting of Charles Champlin, film critic of The Los Angeles Times; the Rev. Robert Lauder, a writer, and the Rev. James Wall, editor of The Christian Century.

title: C.I.T. Likes to Take Its Time
description: The C.I.T. Financial Corporation, the $5 billion diversified financial company that earlier this month came close to merging with RCA, has been likened to a lumbering giant. But a better likeness might be the tortoise: slow but steady.

title: Associated Press
description: SKYLAB FRAGMENT RETURNS TO U.S.: At San Francisco Airport, a Customs inspector views a part of the Skylab spacecraft that was brought to the United States from Australia. A private concern plans to exhibit the oneton fragment throughout this country. It passed through Customs dutyfree.

title: House Acts to Limit Aid From Special Interests
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)  More than 120 members of the House introduced legislation today to cut the amount of money that special interest groups can contribute to candidates for the House. Supporters predicted that the legislation would be acted unon auicklv.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: There is considerable irony in the acronym chosen by consumer organizations lobbying against a bill designed to keep at least part of our sugar industry alive. As Representative Peter Peyser, D.N.Y., noted in an argument against the bill (OpEd July 11) they call them. selves CASH  Citizens Against Sugar Hikes. What these earnest people do not see in their zeal is that if they succeed in defeating the sugar bill, the cash will be spent by consumers in a few years  when American production has been drastically reduced and the next tightening of the volatile world sugar market sends prices to four or five times current levels.

title: Tourism Crippled by Fears About Gasoline
description: BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., July 23 This is the season of their dismay, these people who make their living selling fried clams and snocones, parking cars, renting rooms and boats and bicycles and selling Tshirts that tourists will be ashamed to wear when they get home.

title: L.I. Dealer Puts A 30Day Limit On Bills for Oil
description: Several thousand homeowners on Eastern Long Island have been informed by their fueloil dealer that, effective Wednesday, customers who did not pay their bills within 30 days would no longer receive deliveries.

title: Auctions
description: WHETHER in the form of weathervanes, paintings, stoneware, furniture or quilts, Americana continued to thrive in the auction rooms this season, rewriting many records set in the Bicentennial boom year of 1976.

title: Elderly Regain Benefits In Food Stamp Program
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)  A HouseSenate conference committee approved a compromise today to restore food stamp benefits for elderly, blind and disabled persons with high medical and housing costs.

title: Screen: Len Cariou Stars in 'One Man':Crusading Newscaster
description: THERE may be a good performance by Len Cariou buried in "One Man," but this is such a poorly made movie that it's hard to tell. When the director, Robin Spry, wants to show two characters conducting a conversation, he cuts so often that no one sentence ever seems to have been completed in a single take. The shots seldom match. The locations are sometimes confusing. Too often, all one sees of Mr. Cariou is the back of his head.Mr. Cariou's success in "Sweeney Todd" on Broadway, and certain plot resemblances between "One Man" and "The China Syndrome," are enough to explain why this slightly dated Canadian film is now being released; it opens at the Sutton Theater today. In addition, this is obviously a well-intentioned effort, seriously concerned with the effects of environmental pollution. But its story is predictable, and its characters disagreeable, and in any case good motives don't guarantee a good movie.Mr. Cariou plays, a television newscaster, and though he's supposed to seem a crusading man of conscience by the film's end, he comes across as an ambulance-chaser much of the time. He finds out about the leakage of chemicals that have poisoned children and realizes that a very large factory in the area is to blame. The factory wants him to keep quiet about this and threats are made against his family. Meanwhile, he has a love affair with the whiny girl who first alerted him to the story and this upsets his whiny wife. These two women seem like too much for any man to put up with. Certainly they're too much for the movie.In a heated confrontation, set in the vegetable department of the supermarket, the wife screams that she knows her husband has been unfaithful. She embraces him, then draws away, maintaining that he smells like his mistress. Since this drama is staged right beside the onion counter, it's impressive in its way, if only on account of the wife's formidable nose."One Man" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains some strong language and a plot involving extramarital sex.

title: Texaco Net Up 132.1%; Others Also Rise Sharply
description: Texaco Inc., the nation's thirdlargest oil company, announced yesterday that its secondquarter earnings climbed 132.1 percent to $365.4 million, or $1.35 a share, from $157.4 million, or 58 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year ago. Consolidated gross income expanded to $8.53 billion from $6.83 billion, the company said.

title: Haig Urges Delay on Arms Treaty In Senate Till Flaws Are Resolved
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the recently retired Allied Supreme Commander in Europe, today urged the Senate to delay acting on the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union until flaws in the agreement have been resolved and the Senate can assess President Carter's future military spending programs.

title: Italian Economy
description: ROME, July 26 (Reuters)  Italy's gross national product is expected to grow by 4.7 percent this year, but the inflation rate is expected to average about 15 percent, a Government economic institute said today.

title: Auto Exports Rise in Japan
description: TOKYO, July 27 (AP)  Japan's motor vehicle exports in June totaled 381,650 units, up 5.3 percent from 362, 406 units in May and up 3.9 peitent from 367,415 units in the same month last year, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said tndav It is the first time in 10 months that Japan's motor vehicle exports for r month rose from the same month in 1978.

title: 45 Indochinese Saved By Seventh Fleet Ship Off Southern Vietnam
description: SUBIC BAY NAVAL BASE, the Philippines, June 27  A Seventh Fleet carrier task force rescued 45 Indochinese refugees today, including a teenage boy found floating semiconscious off the southern tip of Vietnam.

title: Bonn Hopeful On Economy
description: BONN, July 27 (Reuters)  Despite rising energy costs, the Economics Ministry said today that it was still optimistic about the prospects for West German economic growth.

title: Mrs. Sherk Is Tied for Golf Lead
description: STE. JULIEDEVERCHER ES, Quebec, July 27  Mary Dwyer and Cathy Sherk, both nonwinners on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, were tied for the lead today at threeunderpar 143 after the second round of the $150,000 Peter Jackson Classic.

title: 6 Who Beat the Summertime Blues
description: Good summer jobs are scarce and it took me year to find this one, said Daria Aponte, as she fed a peanut to Romeo, one of the New York Zoological Park's prize parrots. Miss Aponte, who is 18 years old, is a parrot trainer at the zoo, and like most other teenagers, she had a hard time finding an interesting job this summer.

title: Notes on People
description: One of the most famous advertising trademarks is Little Miss Coppertone, showing a pigtailed, wideeyed little girl whose panties have been pulled down by a mischievous puppy, revealing her suntan line.

title: House Panel Favors Extra Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reuters) The House Foreign Affairs Committee unanimously approved more than $400 million in emergency funds to aid Indochinese refugees today. It took just 10 minutes to approve a Carter Administration reauest submitted Wedneseday.

title: Sports Festival Results
description: SWIMMING Women's Finals

title: Grumman Stock Offering
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reuters) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the Grumman Corporation had filed for an offering of two million shares of cumulative preferred stock to be underwritten by Dillon Read and Company. The company said proceeds of the offering would be used to reduce debt.

title: Dam Break Investigated; Radiation of Spill Easing
description: GALLUP, N.M., July 27  When the tm of a tailings pond at the United Nuear Corporation's Church Rock Mill broke, 100 million gallons of radioactive Water and 1,100 tons of uranium tailings toured into the Rio Puerco. The flash flood carried lowlevel radioactive material about 80 miles downriver before petering out about 45 miles past the Arizona line.

title: Miss Makeyeva Sets Record in Hurdles
description: MOSCOW, July 27 (AP)  Marina Makeyeva of the Soviet Union. set world record of 54.78 seconds in the women's 400meter hurdles at the Spartakiad tonight.

title: Boy, Tried in Murder as Adult, Guilty of Lesser Crime
description: A 14yearold Bronx boy  the youngest person ever tried for murder in New York State's adult courts  was found guilty yesterday of the lesser charge of manslaughter in the fatal shooting of a teenager who had refused to hand over his portable radio in a South Bronx tenement last October.

title: Ambition Fulfilled
description: When I was nine years old, I read Christopher Morley's Parnassus On Wheels, the story of a man who traveled around the countryside in a horsedrawn wagon selling.books. It fired my imagination. What an admirable way to earn a living! I never did get around to it, however, until half a century later when I attained my lifelong ambition in a somewhat different fashion.

title: Stage: Molineaux, True Story Of Slave Who Became a Boxer
description: In Molineaux, John Chodes has heaped clichs, historic and otherwise, high atop one another, and somehow has written an interesting play. Mr. Chodes does not fear purple passages, and he has used them to tell the true story of Thomas Molineaux, once a Virginia slave, who was jobbed when he fought for the world boxing chamninn. ship in London in 1810, and then fell dead of drink in Ireland two years later. The picturesque production is at Theater Row.

title: Music: Quintet For Clarinet By Stoltzman
description: Ordinarily, if you hear one chambermusic performer singled out for lavish praise, you are right to suspect that something may be wrong. The great works in this genre, from Haydn's time on, have stressed unity, homogeneity, equality of parts and other democratic virtues. It is perfectly all right. howver, and in fact mandatory, for player to stand out in a concerto, even if that concerto happens to be called clarinet quintet. So all hail to Richard Stoltzman, who performed with flagrant virtuosity in Carl Maria von Weber's Clarinet Quintet in Bflat (Op. 34) in Thursday night's Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Koch, Undaunted by Jeers, Signs PayIncrease Bill
description: After a public hearing complete with jeers, catcalls and accusations of greed and corruption, Mayor Koch yesterday signed into law a measure increasing the salaries of the city's elected officials.

title: Publicity on Kindness to Refugees Disturbs Jakarta
description: TEREMPA, Indonesia  Someday, when there is an airport and a hotel or two, vacationers will pay a lot of money to escape from their hectic lives for a while to the pristine isolation of Indonesia's Anambas Islands.

title: Litter Tale: Containers Just Vanish
description: Every two hours, a litter basket disappears from New York City's streets.

title: Between Expression and Suppression
description: Many homosexuals work hard to overcome the frightening and hostile social images that plague their lives. Like other civil rights advocates, they struggle against discrimination and unprovoked violence. So it's not surprising that the fear of stereotypes being reinforced by a forthcoming movie has spurred these groups to demonstrations.

title: SAC Intensifying Security for Its Nuclear Weapons
description: OFFUTT AIR FORCE BASE, Neb. The Deadman Alarm, a device the size of a cigarette package that transmits alarms when a sentry is knocked off his feet, is the latest device to be tested in the Strategic Air Command's program to guard against terrorist attacks on nuclear bases.

title: Man Held in White House Crash
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  A Baltimore man was arrested early today for allegedly trying to ram a car through the southwest gate at the White House, the Secret Service reported. John M. Poling, 28 years old, was charged with colliding and destruction of Government property.

title: A Peculiar Mix Of Challenges Face Managua
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 27 In this, the first full week of the victorious Nicaraguan revolution, the newly arrived rebels undertook the task of looking for prisoners rumored to be hidden in secret dungeons. They also tried to find the 700 MercedesBenz cars that the regime of Anastasio Somoza Debayle reportedly used.

title: Dissent Splits Italy's Red Brigades
description: ROME, July 27  Members of Italy's Red Brigades terrorist organization have become embroiled in a bitter internal dispute, with the leaders being attacked by dissidents as dictatorial Stalinists who misjudged the mood of the country, mishandled the kidnapping and murder of the former Prime Minister Aldo Mom and let false successes go to their heads.

title: Building Black Voting Power
description: CHICAGO, July 27 Vernon E. Jordan Jr., president of the National Urban League, expressed a popular theory among blacks this week when he said that it was too early for them to join the prePresidential campaign maneuverines of the nation's two major political parties. Instead, he said, blacks should hang loose and make the Presidential hopefuls come to the black voters.

title: U.S. Fines Of Tenneco Top Million
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  A Federal judge fined Tenneco Inc. more than $1 million today for illegally transporting natural gas from Texas to Louisiana.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI Petition for an Arrangement Flied by:

title: Books of The Times Poverty in Naples
description: At a time when we have so much difficulty understanding poverty in our own country, it is interesting to look at some other country's poor, to examine their anger and frustration, the feeling in their families, the forms taken by their aggressions and their defenses, the configurations of their pride and their sense of self, the degree to which they fall back on love for consolation, or on friendship.

title: Deaths
description: JACKSONSamuel, M.D., Loving husband of Elaine. Devoted father, grandfather, brother. Services Sunday, 10AM at Guttcrman's, Long Beach Road North, Rockville Centre, N.Y.

title: Phillips Opens North Sea Field
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla., July 27 (Reuters)  The Phillips Petroleum Company of Norway said today that it had begun oil and gas production from its second platform in the Albuskjell Field in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea.

title: COMPLACENCY FOUND ON NUCLEAR MISHAPS
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  Emergency planning for coping with nuclear accidents is chaotic and inadequate at all levels, despite lessons learned from the accident this Spring at Three Mile Island, according to a new Congressional report.

title: F.T.C. Seeks Curbs on Mergers
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reuters)  The Federal Trade Commission said today that it wanted legislation to limit the growth of large conglomerates through mergers.

title: Sanitationmen Seek to Clean Image
description: Leaders of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association said yesterday that they would begin a $100,000 advertising campaign to counter recent allegations from various citizens groups that laziness and abuses by their members accounts for the filth in New York City streets.

title: Copter Blades Hit a Locomotive In California, Leaving Four Hurt
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., July 27 (AP)  The pilot of a Forest Service helicopter that was sitting next to a railroad track tried to lift his craft out of the path of an approaching freight train, but the whirling blades struck the locomotive,, leaving four persons hurt.

title: Deregulation of Airlines Causing New Concern for Traveler Safety
description: LOS ANGELES, July 27  Deregulation of the nation's airlines is shifting growing numbers of air travelers to small commuter carriers whose safety records are far inferior to those of conventional airlines.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 2 P.M. (Television Channel 9, 2 P.M. Radio  WMCA, 2 P.M.) Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee. (Television  Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio WINS, 8:30 P.M.)

title: Davidson Taylor, Who Headed Columbia's School of Arts, Dies
description: Davidson Taylor, a former broadcasting executive who helped found Columbia University's School of the Arts in 1966 and served as its director and dean, died yesterday at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 345 East 57th Street.

title: Purposeful And Prankish
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Neil Edward Goldschmidt, nearly all of his friends and acquaintances agree, is at once one of the brightest, most prankish and most purposeful of men.

description: FOODS

title: Italy Selects New Face In Its Attempt to Form Coalition Government
description: ROME, July 27  Filippo Maria Pandolfi, a Christian Democrat serving as. Minister of the Treasuryin the caretaker Government of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, agreed today to a request from President Sandro Pertini to try to form a cabinet.

title: Uniroyal Plea Over Ban Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) Federal appeals court yesterday denied motion by Uniroyal Inc. to temporarily block a Government ban on contracts with the concern because it had refused to cooperate in a sex discrimination investigation. While denying the motion, the threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia did accept a Uniroyal request for expedited consideration of its appeal.

title: McDonnell Net Gains by 51.1%
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation reported big gains in profits, sales and orders for the second quarter, in spite of the May 25 crash of one of its DC10 jetliners that killed 273 persons and the subsequent grounding of all domestically operating DC10's for 37 days.

title: News Summary
description: Morarji R. Desai quit as head of the Janata Party, the largest party in India's Parliament, and was replaced by Jagjivan Ram, the leader of India's 100 million untouchables and a Deputy Prime Minister under Mr. Desai. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Judges Support Artist's Claims To Stolen Work
description: TRENTON, July 27 In a decision that could have significant implications in the art world, a New Jersey appeals court ruled today that Georgia O'Keeffe, the artist, could reclaim three small paintings stolen more than 30 vpars ago.

title: ECONOMY IS CAUGHT IN MILD RECESSION, MILLER TELLS PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  G: William Miller, nominated by President Carter to be Treasury Secretary, said today that the United States was now in a mild recession, but he urged Congress not to approve tax reductions or other measures to stimulate the economy at this time.

title: Algeria Said to Cut Oil Exports
description: Algeria, which supplies about 10 per. cent of the crude oil imported by the United States, was said by oil industry sources yesterday to have cut 20 per. cent of the 1.1 million barrels of oil has been exporting daily.

title: India's Tumultuous Governmental Scene: Gossip and Politics and Politics and Gossip
description: NEW DELHI, July 27 For this city, which thrives on political speculation and gossip, the uncertainty of the last few weeks has been a bonanza.

title: Seiko Introduces New Slim Watches
description: The Seiko Time Corporation, the world's largest watch maker, announced yesterday that it was introducing two new watches as slim as a 25cent coin.

title: Your Money
description: Wedding costs, with the reception the main item, are currently at least twice as much as they were four or five years ago. Tradition puts the bulk of the costs invitations, transportation for principals and attendants, floral decorations, music, photographs, bridesmaids gifts and the receptionon the family of the bride.

title: Takeover Offers Spur Rift at Bodcaw
description: A battle among shareholders of the Bodcaw Company erupted yesterday. as one faction went to court to block a Tuesday shareholders meeting in Dallas scheduled to consider a takeover bid from the International Paper Company. A rival bid from the Weyerhaeuser Company is also pending.

title: Israeli Envoy Summoned by Vance To Discuss Conflict on Sinai Force
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, described as furious about what he regards as Israeli distortions of Washington's position on a United Nations force for Sinai, summoned Israel's Ambassador today.

title: Alaska Airlines In Wien Air Bid
description: SEATTLE, July 27 (AP)  Alaska Airliqes Inc. said today that it had offered to acquire the outstanding common shares of Wien Air Alaska Inc, for $6.50 a share in cash.

title: Gold Price Spurs 2d Rush Out West
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A second gold rush is under way in the historic gold fields of the West, spurred by the metal's rapidly rising price.

title: Bettine Berg Is Married To Arthur B. Blackett Jr.
description: The marriage of Bettine Berg, daughter of Celia Babcock Berg and Peter Van Dyk Berg of Newicanaan, Conn., to Arthur Badger Blackett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Blackett of Millis, Mass., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's mother Bishop John B. Coburn of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts performed the ceremony.

title: Lineup of the Cabinet Secretaries
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  Following is the lineup of department heads in President Carter's 12member Cabinet. New nominees are subject to Senate confirmation.

title: Tropicana Hotel of Las Vegas, Subject of Crime Inquiry, Is Sold
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 27 (UPI) The Tropicana Hotel and Country Club, linked in recent months to figures in organized crime, has been sold to Ramada Inns for an undisclosed price, it was announced today.

description: 6:00(4)Agriculture U.S.A. (5) Pattern for Living

title: Armed Forces Personnel Rose 5,385 Last Month
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  The strength of the allvolunteer United States armed forces rose slightly last month after sliding to its smallest size in 29 years, according to a Pentagon renort. An increase of 5,385 men and women in uniform in June probably marks the beginning of a seasonal upturn in recruiting after the end of the high school year. However, in June 1978 the armed services grew by more than 11,000,. better than twice the increase in June 1979.

title: Moore McCormack, Florida Mining Link
description: Moore McCormack Resources Inc. said yesterday that 657,633 shares of common stock of the Florida Mining and Materials Corporation had been tendered to its subsidiary, Moore Mackmerger Inc.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  Many major corporations are failing to follow recommendations on safeguarding personal information about employees, the head of a Federal study commission On privacy said today.

title: The Invitation Said Informal, But Fashion Was the Byword
description: PARIS  What do American women wear when they're invited to a dinner party and the hostess specifies that the dress is informal? When they're fashion enthusiasts here to see the couture collections, and the hostess happens to be Louise Rouet, whose husband is the director of the House of Dior, they tend to wear the same thing they would to a blacktie dinner. And they tend to fuss about it.

title: Mitsubishi Adding 20% of Fletcher
description: TOKYO, July 27 (AP)  The Mitsubishi, Corporation, a major Japanese trading house, and its American subsidiary, the Mitsubishi International Corporation, said today that they would acquire 20 percent of the Fletcher Oil and Refinine Company.

title: Dr. Jacob Furth, a Pathologist, 83
description: Dr. Jacob Furth, professor emeritus of pathology and a special lecturer at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died Tuesday at his summer home in Surry, Me. He was 83 years old and had been retired since 1966. He also maintained a residence in Manhattan.

title: Top Banks Lift Prime To 11%
description: The nation's major banks increased their basic lending rate from 11 percent to 11% percent yesterday on the apparent belief that the growth of the money supply will be restrained.

title: EARNINGS 20th CenturyFox Profits Down Sharply in Quarter
description: The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation reported yesterday from its Beverly Hills, Calif., headquarters that its profits fell sharply in the second quarter. Net for the period ending June 30 plunged to $7.8 million, or 91 cents a share, from $15.5 million, or $1.95 a share, in the 1978 quarter. Revenues were $147.1 million against $149.2 million.

title: Columbia Pictures To Sell Record Unit
description: Columbia Pictures Industries Inc. has agreed in principle to sell its Arista Records division for $50 million to West German concern, AriojaEurodisc G.m.b.H., a subsidiary of Bertelsmann A.G.

title: Officer Takes Father to Court
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 27  The head of the Westchester County Police Department's sexcrimes unit has gone to court seeking a ruling that her father is unfit to possess a pistol permit. Her father is asking the court to find his daughter similarly unfit.

title: General Motors Lays Off 12,600 As Sales Slump
description: DETROIT, July 27  The giant General Motors Corporation, its dealers showrooms and lots filled with unsold new cars and trucks, announced today the indefinite layoff of 12,600 hourly workers at plants across the country and sharp cutbacks in its planned production of 1980 modelyear large and midsize cars and light trucks and vans.

title: OBSERVER
description: You men have been handpicked for the most vital mission any American soldier has ever undertaken for his country. I know there's been a lot of grousing about the secrecy, but when you hear where you're going, you'll understand why we couldn't have lips flapping in every saloon in town.

title: FREDERICK BRADDON, ENGINEER, INVENTOR
description: Frederick Braddon, retired director of marine engineering for the Sperry Gyroscope Company, now Sperry Rand Inc., died Thursday at his home in Babylon, L.I. He was 72 years old.

title: About New York
description: Let the economicdevelopment experts do as many takeouts as they can on New York's economic situation the stroller in the city knows that the Chineserestaurant boom has gone through the sound barrier of popularity.

title: Miss Woodhead Triple Winner
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 27 Cynthia (Sippy) Woodhead, who won five gold medals in swimming at the Pan American Games earlier this month in San Juan, P.R., won three more today at the National Sports Festival.

title: The City
description: Advocates of homosexual rights marched through Greenwich Village for the third consecutive night yesterday to protest the filniing in the city of the movie Cruising.

title: India to Keep Nuclear Options
description: NEW DELHI, July 27  While the broad foreignpolicy orientation of the Indian government that Charan Singh will head remains vague and undefined, one hint emerged today in a report that the Prime Ministerdesignate intended to keep nuclear options open.

title: Lightning Hits U.S. Fuel in Japan
description: TOKYO, July 27 (Reuters)  Lightning set fire today to a United States Navy fuel tank holding 2.4 million gallons of jet fuel and cut power to more than 18,000 homes in and around Tokyo, the police reported. A golfer was killed during the storm when lightning struck his iron, and lightning also hit an aviation communications tower in suburban Tokyo, leading to flight cancellations and delays.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  A state grand jury has subpoenaed financial records at the Jersey City Medical Center relating to a $6 million state assistance grant, to determine whether the state was billed for charges that should have been paid by private patients or insurance companies.

title: Letters Energy Reforms Ignored by President Carter
description: To The Editor: Despite his claims of urgency, President Carter has failed to propose a program that will solve our energy problems without sacrificing our environment or fundamentally reducing the ways in which we waste energy. We are dependent on OPEC because we are dependent on automobiles. And we are dependent on autos (and trucks for freight) because of decades of corporate and government policies that encouraged auto use while simultaneously destroying rail and public transit systems and sprawling out cities in ways that made excessive driving (and congestion) a necessity.

title: Drug Seller Gets 8Year Term
description: An eightyear prison sentence was imposed on Rudolph Craig of Manhattan for the sale of 16 ounces of phencyclidine, commonly called PCP or angel dust. Judge Charles L. Brieant imposed the sentence in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Regents to Put High Schools on Probation If CompetencyTest Failure Exceeds 15%
description: ALBANY, July 27  The New York State Board of Regents voted today to put public high schools on probation if their students do not meet certain minimum academic standards.

title: Bridge:
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 27  Three Westchester County, N.Y., experts Marty Bergen and Chuck Lamprey, both of White Plains, and Warren Rosner of Hartsdale  together with Allan Stauber of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., are competing today in the semifinal stage of the Grand National Team ChampionSpecial tome New York Times snip, Winch opens a door to world championship honors. The Bergen team led by 77 points at the halfway stage in play against a team from Arkansas and Tennessee.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON AMAGNETIC bubble memory invented for the Bell System is regarded as the first in a new generation of such devices  faster, smaller and with greater informationstorage capacity.

title: Knowlton Chief Steps Down
description: William A. Durbin, chairman of Hill & Knowlton Inc. the nation's largest publicrelations firm, said yesterday that he was stepping down from his top post, and that he was disbanding the threeman office of chief executive. It was also announced that Loet A. Velmans, president, would add the title of chief executive.

title: Civiletti Hearings End
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) Benjamin R. Civiletti's nomination to be Attorney General drew criticism from Hispanics but no public opposition from members of the Senate Judiciary Committee as the panel ended three days of confirmation hearings today.

title: 2 NOMINATIONS END SHUFFLE OF CABINET
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  President Carter filled the last two vacancies in his Cabinet today, completing the shakeup he began 10 days ago and clearing the way for an intensive campaign in behalf of his energy program.

title: G.A.O. Advises Immediate Cuts In City's Budget
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  The General Accounting Office, charging that New York City had failed to face up to its fiscal problems, called on the Koch administration to make immediate new cuts in its budget.

title: The New D.O.E. May Be D.O.A.
description: Reports of the approaching birth of a Department of Education have been greatly exaggerated. Although former Gov. Jerry Apodaca of New Mexico is rumored to be the Administration's choice to head the proposed department, the indications are that House and Senate conferees will not get together before September compare their different bills for setting it up. When they do, agreement may be elusive indeed. The delay  a symptom, really, of the bill's many flaws  is just as well.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times yesterday on expected appointments to President Carter's Cabinet stated incorrectly the present status of a bill to create a Department of Education. House and Senate versions of such a bill still await resolution by a conference committee.

title: Schlesinger Sees Ample Fuel Oil
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger said today that he expects the nation's energy situation to continue to improve over the next several months and that there will be ample heating oil by winter. There is a recognition, Mr. Schlesinger said, that if crude oil availability continues as it is, there should not be a problem with availability next winter.

title: Gasoline Allotment Lifted by Exxon
description: HOUSTON, July 27 (Reuters) Exxon U.S.A., a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, said it would supply its dealers and customers with more gasoline in August than in July.

title: Letter: On the Insanity Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Tells Curran to Repay Funds to Maritime Union
description: Joseph Curran, a retired president of the National Maritime Union, was sharply criticized yesterday by a Federal judge who ordered him to give back substantial amounts of pay and benefits that he had received from the union over a period of years.

title: The Costs of Growth
description: In the 1950's and 1960's, most economists were convinced that economic growth could and would rid the world of wretchedness and oppression. We were taught that nations evolved from economic underdevelopment to economic maturity. from tradition to modemity, and from reduced to expanded political participation. In short, economic growth was seen as the means whereby poor nations would become wellbehaved representational democracies with the normal menu of social and political rights.

title: ExMayor of East Chicago Draws 18 Months for Thwarting Justice
description: HAMMOND, Ind., July 27 (UPI)John B. Nicosia, a former Mayor of East Chicago, has been sentenced to 18 months in Federal prison and fined $5,000 for obstructing justice.

title: Braila
description: POTTERDr. Elizabeth Mackey. The faculty of the Department of Medicine of the New York University School of Medicine mourn the loss of our colleague and fellow faculty member. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, Dr. Jacobus L. Potter, Associate Dean of the School of Medicine, and to her daughters and son. Dr. Potter served as an Instructor In clinical medicine for nearly fitteem years, bringing to her students an understanding of patient care that will long be remembered and appreciated by all who knew her. Saul J. Farber, MD. Frederick H. King, Professor,and Chairman, Departmental Medicine New York University School Medicine.

title: Long Wins Golf Final By 3 and 2
description: ARDSLEYONHUDSON, N.Y., July 27  The turning point of the Ardsley Country Club course also proved to be the turning point of the final match today as Nelson Long of Century won the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMOFFArl, M.D., beloved husband of Doris, devoted father of Albert, Tamara, and Rose. Loving brother of Helene. Adored grandfather and greatgrandfather. Services 9:30 Sunday, July 29, 1979 at Schwartz Brothers Forest Perk Chapels Queens Blvd & 76 Rd, Forest Hills.

title: Militia Leader in Lebanon Vows To Hunt Guerrillas in U.N. Zone
description: MERJ 'UYUN, Lebanon, July 27  The commander of the Israelibacked Christian militia forces in southern Lebanon, Maj. Sand Haddad, said today that his units would no longer treat areas guarded by United Nations forces as offlimits. He said he would pursue fleeing Palestinian terrorists across United Nations lines and attack any United Nations soldiers who tried to intervene.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DORIC (Home Lines). Left Bermuda July 26; due at A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Media Corporation Holds Meeting With Creditors
description: The Media Corporation of America, one of the country's oldest and largest media buying services, held a meeting of creditors yesterday in hopes of avoiding bankruptcy. It acknowledged owing $9.5 million to newspapers, magazines, outdoor advertising companies and broadcasters.

title: Cubs Top Mets on 2 Kingman Clouts
description: The new Dave Kingman destroyed the Mets last night, hitting two long homers, driving in three runs, and leading the Chicago Cubs to a 42 triumph, their second in a row at Shea Stadium.

title: GOING OUTGuide
description: Bel product are Karl Ohlig, potter, and his wife, Helga, an engraver, from the company's branch in Merkelbach; and Gerd SchelerEckstein, a painter, for Goebel. Visitors will watch handcrafting of the delicate art objects, such as the shaping of saltglazed stoneware on a potter's wheel and its final preparation before baking in a kiln, and the intricate handpainting of the figurines and other collectibles.

title: Arkansas Inquiry Finds Two Wrong Death Rulings
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 26  A spe4ial task force assigned to investigate unsual procedures and erroneous autopsy reports of the State Medical Examiner's dffice has found that the death of an innate at Cummins Prison, ruled accidenMl, was the result of strangulation and a broken neck.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 22.

title: Shipbuilding Subsidies Backed
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  The House today sharply rejected a proposal. to reduce Federal subsidies for the nation's shipbuilders. The proposal was part of a $438.5 million authorization bill for the United States Maritime Commission for the fiscal year that will begin Oct. 1. The House voted 246 to 129 to reject the plan to cut $69 million from a proposed $101 million allocation designed to keep American shipbuilding competitive with lesscostly foreign construction.

title: Dow Firm
description: Weakness in aluminum issues and certain takeover situations highlighted activity in the stock market yesterday as prices generally posted small gains.

title: Owner of W. &
description: The City Stores Company, parent of W.&J. Sloane and Franklin Simon, filed for court protection yesterday under the voluntary provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act so that it could continue operating while it works out a plan to pay its creditors.

title: Music: Joan Armatrading Sings
description: Joan Armatrading hadn't played New York City for a while before her Beacon Theater concert Thursday night, but her cult greeted her as if she'd been here all along. Aside from an adoring live audience, Miss Annatrading reached a still larger public through a live broadcast of her set we lust or tnree consecutive live broadcasts Thursday night by A & M Records artists in Manhattan.

title: Fishermen Protesting Salmon Curb Shift Fight to Land
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 27 (UPI) Plans to fight on land instead of at sea forestalled another foray today into salmonfishing waters off the Oregon and Washington coast by commercial fisherman who are protesting an agreement intended to improve Indian fishing.

title: Jackson Ejected as Yanks Lose in 9th
description: MILWAUKEE, July 27  Cecil Cooper, Milwaukee's slugging first baseman, hit three home runs, including the gamewinner with two outs in the ninth tonight, but that barrage was only part of the fireworks that took place in County Stadium.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: 1. Radio and television music, saying it stupefies persons listening to it and makes their brain inactive and frivolous. 2. Hedley Donovan, who will become senior adviser to the President, and Zbigniew Brzezinski, the national security adviser.

title: Nixon Acting to Buy Penthouse at Corner Of 72d and Madison
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon has made a down payment on a penthouse apartment in a cooperative building on the northwest corner of 72d Street and Madison Avenue, a person with knowledge of the coop's affairs said yesterday.

title: Oloods Recede In Texas Area; Toll Rises to 7
description: HOUSTON, July 27 (AP)  Receding waters allowed some residents to return to their homes on the Texas coast today, but flooded streets kept thousands more stranded. The number of persons killed in the state's worst floods in nearly 20 years increased to seven.

title: On Getting Ejected From the Stadium
description: Andy Biengardo had met Chris Chambliss once before: three years ago the Yankee first baseman was at the teenager's upstate hometown of Newburgh and had signed Andy's Yankee Yearbook. In fact, so had Chambliss's wife.

title: Queen Is Met by Protests as She Arrives in Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, July 27 (AP) Queen Elizabeth II was welcomed to Lusaka today by thousands of Zambians, including some waving banners hostile to her Government's position on the regime in neighboring Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

title: U.S. Asks Court to Bar Exxon Bid
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  A Federal judge will decide tomorrow whether to grant a request by the Federal Trade Commission to block temporarily the Exxon Corporation's proposed $1.17 billion takeover of the Reliance Electric Company.

title: Oceanic Contractors Forming Dutch Link
description: AMSTERDAM, July 27 (Reuters) The Netherlands Offshore Company and Oceanic Contractors Inc., a. subsidiary of J. Ray McDermott and Company, said today that they had reached agreement in principle for Oceanic to take over the Dutch company's assets.

title: New Owner for La Cte Basque
description: La Cote Basque, the 20yearold French restaurant at 5 East Fifth Street, is being sold to Jean Jacques Rachou, the chef and owner of Le Lavandou at 139 East 61st Street. The sale is expected take effect in August.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Mixed in Trading;. Gold Posts Small Gains
description: The dollar was mixed on the world's currency markets yesterday despite news that the United States trade deficit narrowed in June.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The economy is in a mild recession, G. William Miller told the Senate Finance Committee, but an acrosstheboard tax cut now would be unwise because it would unleash a new round of inflationary pressures. Mr. Miller, the Federal Reserve chairman whom President Carter has nominated to be Treasury Secretary, said at confirmation hearings he had not known of improper payments made by Textron, which he formerly headed. [Page 1.]

title: Reports From Iraq Indicate Crisis in Its Leadership
description: PARIS, July 27 Diplomatic and intelligence officials of several Western countries have received reports about trouble in the top echelons of the Iraqi leadership since Saddam Hussein took over as President last week.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, July 27 (AP)  Two of Spain's mostwanted terrorists have been arrested and have confessed to 16 killings, including the bombing of a Madrid coffee shop that took eight lives, the police said today.

title: P.L.O. Asks U.N. Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 27 The Palestine Liberation Organization and its supporters sought Security Council endorsement today for the right of Arabs to return to homes they lost in the 1948 ArabIsraeli war.

title: Westinghouse Plans to Connect TV and Other Units by Satellite
description: The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company has arranged for its five television stations, Washington news bureau and Hollywood production company to be interconnected by Western Union's Westar satellite. The setup is being regarded as possible prelude to a changed structure for commercial television.

title: Itel Suit Names Marsh &
description: The Itel Corporation has filed a suit seeking $1.6 million in damages and $25 million in punitive damages aginst Marsh & McClennan Inc., the Americas Insurance Company of New Orleans and other defendants for an alleged failure to honor an insurance policy that was to protect Itel against losses in the residual value of leased computers.

title: Jordan's Beautiful, but Who's Jerdun?
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Hamilton Jordan called it his debutante party, his comingout on the Washington social scene as President Carter's new chief of staff. It was a modest affair, a small cocktail buffet held last night at the'State Department. Its purpose was to give the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., and 20 other members of Congress a chance to meet Mi. Jordan, Frank Moore and other White House aides.

title: Free Air Versus Free Speech
description: The principles of free competitive speech and free competitive markets in broadcasting, sad to say, still seem too radical for a lot of people to accept, including most members of Congress. So our solace will have be that the Federal Communications Commission still chugging along, as fast as it legally can, toward decontrol of the hobbled communications industry.

title: Westinghouse Sale
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell its Security Systems Inc. to Certified Security Services Inc. for more than $3 million.

title: Castro Pledges to Send Doctors And Teachers to Aid Nicaragua
description: HAVANA, July 27 (Reuters)  With members of the Nicaraguan junta in his audience, President Fidel Castro said last night that Cuba would send as many doctors and teachers to Nicaragua as that country might need in the aftermath of its revolution.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Weekended Friday. July 27, 1979

title: West Virginia Judge Bars Press but Not Public From Court Hearing
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., July 27 (AP)A judge's order this week barred the news media from proceedings in a kidnapping case while allowing the public to attend. The order has aroused criticism both here and nationally by advocates of freedom of the press.

title: Airco Has Ended Ferroalloy Operation
description: Airco Inc., a subsidiary of BOC International Ltd., said that it had divested itself of all its ferroalloy operations with the closing of the sale of its Swedish subsidiary, Airco Alloys AB.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Gold futures were steady, but silver fell sharply yesterday, following a general decline in futures prices for livestock, grains and many other major commodities.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Cut In June
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  The United States foreign trade deficit narrowed to $1.9 billion in June from $2.5 billion in May, even though the nation spent more to import oil than in any other month since March 1977, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Major League Baseball Standings
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES Milwaukee 6, Yankees 5. Baltimore 8, Kansas City 0 Cleveland 7, Chicago 2. Detroit 9, Toronto 3 (11 inn.). Minnesota 3, California 1. Seattle 1, Oakland 0. Texas 11, Boston 2.

title: Watchtower Convention of Jehovah's Witnesses
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Francis Jr. of Matawan, N.J., being baptized at a convention of Jehovah's Witnesses at Giants Stadium. About 125 people were baptized in a ceremonmy yesterday, the second day of a fourday meeting of 117 New Jersey and Pennsylvania congregations. About 18,000 followers are expected to attend by Sunday.

title: Care Varies for Horses Pulling Carriages in Central Park
description: There are yankers who yank as hard as they can on the reins, cutting into the horse's mouth to make him go faster. The yankers are carriage drivers who want to complete the circle through Central Park as quickly as possible so they can get back to Central Park South to pick up another fare.

title: The Ballet: Paso a Tres, Farce By Alberto Mendez fOr Cubans
description: Apparently, one thing ballet dancers enjoy almost as much as ballet dancing is making fun of ballet dancing. Choreographers have devised innumerable sixxifs of classical ballet, and one can Understand why. Because ballet deends on convention and artifice, it is an easy target for satire. Should convention be violated, should the sheen of artifice fail to disguise perspirationdrenched effort or outright blundering, then ballet can easily seem absurd.

title: Cuomo, Prepared to Serve, Is Just as Ready to Advance
description: ALBANY  Ask any of the leading state politicians if they want to be Governor, and they will tell you how they want to be a good Assembly Speaker, or Comptroller, or Attorney General.

title: Three Mummenschanz Mimes Speak
description: Their names are Dominique Weibel, Roger Reed and Jakob Bentsen, but Broadway audiences know them as the voracious pea, perambulatory hassock and balloonthrowing giant slinky toy of Mummenschanz, which passed the 1,000performance mark at the Bijou Theater on Thursday. True. a wellturned metatarsal arch and errant cowlick are visible at times, beneath the bizarre masks, outfits and props. It comes as something of a shock, however, when the actors faces are revealed in curtain calls.

title: Patricia W. Johnson Bride of H.R. Cliff
description: Patricia Warburg Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. McDermott of Plantation, Fla., and. Munich, West Germany, was married at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday to Halbert Reid Cliff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Asa Cliff of Schenectady, N.Y. The Rev. Charles Amstein performed the ceremony.

description: AETNA LIFE & CASUALTY (N)

title: Booming Sales in U.S. Pose Problem for Honda
description: TOKYO, July 27 That company is crazy, said Akio Mikuni, a business consultant here. They're allowing their cars to sell at $1,000 premiums in the United States.

title: 3 Convicted of Assault In Beatings Last Year Of 6 in Central Park
description: Three young men were convicted of assault and conspiracy charges last night for their role in the attack in the Central Park Ramble last summer that seriously injured six men.

title: Evian and Geneva
description: Some tragedies defy the imagination. Some misery so surpasses the grasp of reason that language itself breaks beneath the strain. Instead, we grasp for metaphors. Instead, we speak the inaudible dialect of the human heart.

title: Alydar's Rainbow
description: Although much of last week's news seemed to be rooted in the fantasies that grip men in high places, one newsworthy item was simply the result of fractured bone: Alydar, the only horse to finish second in all three Triple Crown races, had been retired to stud after injuring himself in a morning workout.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Film

title: Reporter's Notebook: Drilling Voyage Nears End
description: ABOARD THE GLOMAR CHALLENGER, off Panama  As this ship steams toward Panama after drilling 1,114 feet into the Pacific floor and reaping a rich scientific harvest, her instruments are looking both up and down. Antennas are tuned to satellites overhead while air guns probe the sea floor far below.

title: Best Sellers
description: Last Weeks Week On List

title: Position Paper
description: PORNOGRAPHY seems to encourage the worst intellectual qualities in nearly everybody who writes about it. This is doubtless because it's extremely difficult to maintain a disinterested, reflective attitude toward imaginative work whose chief, indeed only, purpose is to cause sexual excitation.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: How to Charter a Bus for Your Group
description: Among Americans accustomed to vacationing by family car, it is not easy to sell the idea of going by bus. But with gasoline prospects uncertain and the public being implored to conserve, there may be strong advantages to leaving the car at home and chartering a bus.

title: THE MARKETS Dow Boosted by Fed Change
description: A strong rally Wednesday, touched off by the nomination of Paul A. Volcker to be the next Federal Reserve Board chairman, enabled the stock market finish with gains last week.

title: Dexter Cup Trot Victory Goes to Chiola Hanover
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 28  Chiola Hanover once again proved his dominance over the 3yearold trotting field tonight by winning the $175,225 Dexter Cup at Roosevelt Raceway. It was the ninth victory in 10 starts for the brown colt and his fifth in a row.

title: Image Agencies Thrive on Crises
description: The executive begins by defending his company against charges of pollution before a skeptical city council. Then he rushes to meet with angry representatives of minority groups who complain of employment discrimination. After that, he fields rumors that his plant is about to lay off hundreds of workers. Just as a horrid day is about to end, an explosion hits the plant and in the resulting chaos the executive must deal with TV cameramen and reporters clamoring to cover the story.

title: William C. De Koning Jr., Chief Of Operating Engineers Union
description: William C. De Koning Jr., a former president of Local 138 of the International Union of Operating Engineers and'a frequent target of criminal indictments, died Thursday at his retirement home in Palm Harbor, Fla. He was 60 years old.

title: Foreign Concerns Look to County For Expansion
description: THE weakening of the dollar and rising foreigntrade deficits may spell difficulties for the American economy, but ironically they are making Westchester County an increasingly attractive place for foreign businesses, according to the New York State Department of Commerce and members of the local business community.

title: August Supplies Are Short, but the Region's Energy Chiefs See No New Panic at the Pumps
description: With August on the horizon, state energy officials in the region once again are gathering figures from the oil companies, trying to forecast how much gasoline will be available for motorists during the heaviest driving month of the year. They also are trying to apply the lessons they learnedsometimes through embarrassing error  during the crunch earlier this summer, by making adjustments in the systems they set up to end the panic. New Jersey used all of those devices in various combinations during the worst of the JuneJuly gasoline crunch and apparently to good effect. The long lines at stations disappeared and the panic subsided.

title: TV VIEW
description: There is nothing quite like televised sports for getting people exercised. A few weeks ago, I wrote weekday column criticizing the habit of American sportscasters of talking themselves and their listeners into utter exhaustion. The occasion was NBC's coverage of the Wimbledon Lawn Tennis Championships. The response from readers was immediate, heavy and passionate. Essentially, what I had commented on was the fact that in the course of six hours, beginning at 9 o'clock one recent Saturday morning, the announcers managed avoid the slightest hint of linguistic subtlety or restraint. The men's final between Bjorn Borg and Roscoe Tanner proved to be superb tennis, but the NBC crew seemed determined to make it something else. Evidently concerned about the network's usual audience on that day of the week and that early hour, one announcer assured viewers: O.K., you don't have Saturdaymorning cartoons, but you do have the Angelic Assassin [Borg] against Bullet Man [Tanner]. In frenzy of pointless chauvinism, Borg, a model champion, became the cold inhuman Swede. Tanner emerged as the temperamental but folksy hillbilly from Tennessee. Aided and abetted by dizzying flurries of instant replays, the talk spewed forth mercilessly.

title: DINING OUT
description: IF YOU like the Tarragon Tree on the road to Meyersville, you'll love Le Delice on the road to Whippany. Apparently, John and Dennis Foy are determined to bring a firstrate French restaurant, nouvelle style, to central New Jersey, and they're on the road to succeeding.

title: Deaths
description: MILLERHortense Fox, 65, df Hollywood, Fla, formerly of NYC and South Orange, NJ. Passed away July 26. Survived by husband, Allan E., children James Fox and Barbara Miller, Richard and Pat Passon, A. Matthew and Andrea G. Miller, grandchildren, brother Maurice Fox, Funeral services were held Sunday, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Hollwyood Fla.

title: Fashion
description: Drifting white anklelength nightgown right, is silk georgette with slivers of silver stripes. By Lore. $130. Second floor, Bergdorf Goodman. Garnet necklace by Esther Gallant. Lilac sheets and pillow shams from Wamsutta Mills. Far right: Bed jacket of pale pink taffeta covers an ivory satin charmeuse gown trimmed in lace. Both by ShuBa. Jacket is $120; nightgown, $150. Available on the fourth floor, Saks Fifth Avenue, in midAugust. Peach sheets from Springs Mills.

title: Diana G. Haring Married To James Frederick Billip
description: Diana Gillmor Haring, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Gillmor Haring of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to James Frederick Billip, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon K. Billip of Jaffrey, N.H. The Rev. John Hossan performed the ceremony in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Georgetown, Conn., where Pamela Haring Brody was her sister's matron of honor and Jake Ehlers was best man.

title: U.S. Navy via Associated Press
description: Vietnamese children having dinner aboard U.S.S. Wabash after being picked up from a small boat in the Gulf of Siam

title: UpsandDowns for Degnan
