description: JOHN J. DEGNAN, the state's Attorney General, has just had one of those upanddown weeks that are difficult to define. When the week began Mr. Degnan found himself in the job of acting Governor, probably the first State Attorney General to hold that job. Governor Byrne was in Europend Senate President Joseph P. Merlino and Assembly Speaker Christopher J. Jackman were both attending a national legislative leaders conference on the West Coast.

title: Decorative Fern Fronds Can Be Cooling
description: There is something cooling about leafy fern fronds. In spite of humidity and relentless summer temperatures, the soft textures of ferns provide relief.

title: Robert N. Chatigny And Stacey Savin To Be Wed Aug. 26
description: Stacey Lynn Savin and Robert Neil Chatigny plan to be married in Bloomfield, Conn., on Aug. 26. Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Savin of Bloomfield and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Jean Chatigny of Rochester and Joseph V. Chatigny of Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Anne Thompson, F.M. Seifert Wed
description: Anne Cleland Thompson and Frederick McClure Seifert were married yesterday in the Presbyterian Church in Bridgehampton, L.I., by the Rev. Jon D. Freeberg.

title: Hempstead Renewal Plan Advances
description: HEMPSTEAD AREVITALIZATION program for this economically depressed village, which is expected to help restore some of the health that at one time made it Nassau County's retail hub, has been approved by the Village Board and its Urban Renewal Agency.

title: Deadline Near to Collect Syphilis Study Payments
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 28 (AP) The Federal Government has more than $250,000 that belongs to 17 black men who were the unsuspecting test subjects of a 40year study of the effects of untreated svohilis.

title: A Paroled Killer Is Held On Claim of 20 Murders
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 28 (AP)  A 50yearold paroled murderer, who says he committed as many as 20 other murders from Maine to California in the last year, was being held in the Dutchess County Jail here today, the New York State Police reported.

title: Crompton is Campus Casuals velveteen.
description: Velveteen separates. Jacket, about $68. Skirt, about $46. Sizes 414. At all fine stores. Crompton Company, Inc., 1071 Avenue of the Americas, N.Y. 10018.

title: Legislators in Special Session Tomorrow
description: IN the tradition of summer reruns established by the television networks, the General Assembly is coming back to the Capitol tomorrow to replay some debates that were first aired during the regular, season last winter. There is also some new business, although it is not expected to occupy the lawmakers attention for long.

title: The Two Lives of Dr. Klecatsky
description: IT is 4:45 A.M. when the man in Pelham, whose house is halfway between New Rochelle Hospital and the New York Athletic Club boathouse, wakes up. Shortly after A.M., he is gliding across the waters of Orchard Beach Lagoon in a slender scull. He is the only man to be inducted into Rowing's Hall of Fame while still competing; the winner of more than 400 races, 38 United States rowing championships and 42 Royal Canadian Henley championships; a past, and perhaps future, member of the United States Olympic, World and Pan American teams. This is Larry Klecatsky.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: TENANTS in about 55,000 Westchester apartments in 13 commumties will begin paying rent increases this week of 9 percent on a oneyear lease, 11 percent on a twoyear lease and 13 percent on a threeyear lease. In addition, they must pay the increases retroactive to July 1 Besides the increases to tenants, landlords will be allowed to add 6 percent to the basic rent when an apartment becomes vacant and to add a percent passalong in about 2,000 apartments where landlords pay Consolidated Edison electric bills.

title: Design
description: The bed, indeed the entire bedroom, has become a fashion statement. In recent years, domestic manufacturers have been introducing new coordinated collections  sheets, comforters, pillow cases and shams, dust ruffles, towels, even draperies  every six months.

title: Nation's Biggest Transport Pool Is Operated by T.V.A. for 5,000
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 28 (AP) Kay Martin lives 17 miles from work and makes the trip for less than 75 cents because her employer, the Tennessee Valley Authority, was a pioneer in organizing transportation pools.

title: Istvn Orkny, 19121979
description: Istvn Orkny, author of Catsplay which had a successful run at the Manhattan Theater Club in 1978, died late in June in Budapest at the age of 67. He was the leading Hungarian dramatist, the first of his nation since Molnar to win a reputation in the world theater. Originally trained in his father's profession as a pharmacist, he earned a degree as a chemical engineer and then belatedly began his literary career, only to have it interrupted when the Fascist Hungarian government pressed him into service in a labor battalion, along with other political undesirables. During the Second World War, he was captured and spent a year in a Soviet prison camp. On returning to Budapest, he resumed writing fiction and criticism, but, after the Hungarian uprising of 1956, he was sent off to be rehabilitated by working in factory for a year. At last, the writing that had been so long postponed made him a world figure.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: Well Past Age 65, Theyre Still Boss
description: LOS ANGELES  When you have more money than you can spend in a lifetime, says 72yearold Justin Whitlock Dart, the chairman of Dart Industries Inc., you have other reasons for working.

title: DC10 Flight Returns
description: LISBON, July 28 (Reuters)  A DC10 of the KLM, Royal Dutch Airlines returned here safely shortly after taking off for South America today when a fault was discovered in one of its engines, an, airport spokesman said. The plane, carrying 250 passengers, was scheduled to fly to Lima, Caracas and Curacao. KLM officials said passengers were transferred to other flights.

title: Gwen Alison Rowden Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marcus A. Rowden of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gwen Alison Rowden, to John David Carton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvyn Carton of New York.

title: L D. C. TAYLOR, 76, AUTHOR AND EDITOR
description: Lois Dwight Cole Taylor, an author and editor with leading book publishers, died at her home in Manhattan on July 20. She was 76 years old and had lived in Upper Montclair, N.J., for many years.

title: Shedding Light On Repair of Blinds
description: IN most cases when a Venetian blind starts to jam or otherwise becomes hard to raise and lower, the first thing you should suspect is a problem with the cord that raises and lowers the slats or the cord that tilts them. Sometimes one of the cords has become kinked or knotted and thus jammed in one of the pulleys over which it passes. Fixing this is simply a matter of removing the kink or knot (or sometimes removing an accumulation of lint from the cord).

title: Barging Through the Netherlands
description: To know the Netherlands one should see it from its greatest altitude which is to say from sea level. The best way to do that is to drift along the country's ubiquitous waterways  as I did, on the hotel barge Lys  looking down on green acres that not long ago lay beneath the waves. Now, all that is left of water in these rescued fields trickles through the irrigation ditches that mark off the grazing land, separating one farmer's blackandwhite Frisian cows from another's fat and shortlegged sheep.

title: New Finery for the Capitol, Inside and Out
description: THESE days, Nathan Hale finds himself surrounded by scaffolding and bags of mortar mix, his peace disturbed by hammer and drill. Alt this is as it should be, for like the rest of the State Capitol, the east entrance, near where the bronze statue of Hale stands, is being restored in the building's Centennial year.

title: Realty News,
description: Eptas Equities, a limited partnership headed by Michael Hirschfeld, the chairman of GarrickAug Associates Store Leasing Inc., has taken a a longterm leasehold on the threestory commercial building at 558 Seventh Avenue, which is also known as 200 West 40th Street.

title: If You Go
description: to Virginia's Eastern Shore by car from the New York metropolitan area, you can get there quickly by heading straight down U. S. 13, 120 miles south of the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Faulkner Fragments

title: Long, Indefinite Tours of Duty Are Part of the Friction in Pekin's Civilizing Mission
description: LHASA, Tibet  Wu Chaoyung works in a small woolspinning factory here. Like 70 percent of the personnel in the plant, he is Chinese. When Mr. Wu was assigned to Tibet 1966 from his home in Shanghai, he was told his tour would be about 10 years. Now he doesn't know how much longer he will have to stay; it could be indefinitely.

title: When Reinhardt And Strindberg Met Almost
description: There is a story told that the first time Winston Churchill stayed at the White House during World War II, President Roosevelt, impatient to.

title: BRIDGE
description: One who understands the habits, culture and lapguages of many people can travel the world much more smoothly and happily than someone whose horizons are more limited. The same is true of the world of tournament bridge: Although it is not essential to understand languages and methods other than your own, it can be very helpful in some situations.

title: Tanker Rumors Difficult to Trace
description: One of the most widespread reports during the gasolind shortage has been that oil has been held back on tankers to await higher prices  a report as hard to verify as is determining the causes of the shortage.

title: China's Elderly Find Good Life In Retirement
description: PEKING, July 28  EVery morning at 6:30, several hundred elderly men and women gather in a park near the ornate Nationalities Palace to perform China's ancient form of calisthenics, tai ji. They glide through the movements as if in slow motion, stopping now and then to chat with a neighbor or a new acquaintance.

title: Israeli Skepticism Rising On PeaceKeeping Machinery
description: JERUSALEM  To much of the world there has always been something appealing about the idea of United Nations force moving gallantly into a battle zone to keep the peace, as if the collective conscience of the community of nations had risen to strike a blow for the common good. But it is not quite that way close up, at least not in the view of Israel, which has probably been more intimately involved with United Nations observers and peacekeepers for longer than any other country.

title: Remembrances of Bocce Past
description: MAYOR Angelo R. Martinelli of Yonkers was practicing his bocce in Hartley Park in Mount Vernon last week, recalling both the city and the game as part of his youth.

title: Sporting Figures
description: SPORTSWRITERS memoirs are almost always livelier than their original stories; this time around, old scores can be settled and the record finally set aright. When two such stylists as Heywood Hale Broun and W. C. Heinz are retelling the tales, the results are winning.

title: Congress May Act This Week on Control of FederallyIrrigated Lands
description: WASHINGTON  The struggle over control Federally irrigated land has sometimes been pictured as a battle between family farmers and agribusiness giants, but it was clear last week, as the issue neared a showdown in Congress, that things are not nearly as simple as they might seem or as simple as the Carter Administration might wish.

title: Congress Revives. Urban Aid Plan
description: WASHINGTON AN urbanaid program that once  seemed doomed by an antispending mood in Congress was revived last week in the Senate Finance Cominittee, raising the prospect of immediate Federal help for New Jersey communities struggling with high unemployment.

title: SENATE REPUBLICANS OFFER TAX CUT PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  At a time when economic troubles loom as a major obstacle to President Carter's reelection hopes, Senate Republicans have offered an alternative economic plan that features large tax cuts for individuals and businesses.

title: MERGER OF PAN AM AND NATIONAL GAINS WITH SALE OF STOCK
description: Pan American World Airways attempt to merge with National Airlines made a major advance yesterday when the carrier announced that it was acquiring a substantial block of National shares from Texas International Airlines. The Texas line announced that it was withdrawing, subject to certain conditions, from competition with Pan Am and Eastern Airlines to take over National.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)  The Supreme Court today cleared the way for lower courts to end racial imbalances by ordering the busing of as many as 35,600 children to schools in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Gas Lines Are Scarcer In Metropolitan Region
description: Gasoline was readily available in the New York metropolitan area yesterday, and there were virtually no lines at filling stations.

title: G.M. Furloughs Stun Auto World
description: Detroit was rocked by the announcement late Friday by the giant General Motors Corporation  its dealer showrooms and lots filled with unsold new cars and trucks  that it would layoff indefinitely 12,600 hourly workers at its plants across the country and sharply reduce its production of 1980 model year large and midsize cars, lightduty trucks and vans.

title: Bobby Wadkins Leads By a Stroke on 67203
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (UPI) Bobby Wadkins carded a fourunderpar 67 today and took a oneshot lead after three rounds of the $250,000 Philadelphia Golf Classic.

title: For Benny Hill, Vaudeville Still Lives
description: LONDON An old man in a wheelchair is watching the girls go by. Suddenly, a gust of wind whisks off their outer garments so they are reduced to brassiere and panties. Instantly rejuvenated, the old man sheds his rugs and inhibitions and goes chasing after them with the highspeed abandonment kilf a Keystone Cop.

title: Kennedy Nomination Predicted
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 28 (AP) Former Gov. John B. Connally of Texas said today that he thought Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, not President Carter, would win the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination. President Carter has difficulties and will continue to have difficulties, Mr. Connally, a candidate for the Republican nomination, said at a news conference here.

title: Food
description: Dining preferences are curious. Some people enjoy finger food and prize, above all, attacking a lobster by hand. Others find any form of finger food offputting and, when bereft of knife and fork, suffer a mild attack of table depression. They like their lobster clean of shell.

title: Master Sgt. J. D. Andrew Marries Emily H. Boyle
description: Airman 2d Class Emily Hamilton Boyle and Chief Master Sergeant Joseph Dixon Andrew, who are stationed at Malmstrom Air Force Base in Montana, were married yesterday in the Keene Valley (N.Y.) Congregational Church. The Rev. Everett Gassett performed the ceremony.

title: Pirates Beat Expos To Gain First Place
description: MONTREAL, July 28 (AP)Dave Parker homered and Bill Madlock drove in the winning run on his fifthinning sacrifice fly tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates moved into first place in the National League's East Division with a 53 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BOMBAY, IndiaThe world's largest democracy is in very poor shape.

title: Dealing With Baseball's Injury Problem
description: In the first few weeks of the National Football League's exhibition schedule a year ago, some of the game's most prominent quarterbacks suffered injuries, one, after another, as if they were falling dominoes. Bob Griese, Ken Anderson, Bert Jones and Joe Ferguson became disabled faster than you can say Pete Rozelle.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Grucci clan of Bellport, manufacturers of fireworks, left last week for Monaco, where they will compete for the first time in the principality's world fireworks competition.

title: CAMERA
description: Modern photographic equipment depends on electronics for controlling such things as exposure, flash automation, and even focusing, but no transistor has yet been devised to work out depthoffield problems. Depth of field is a basic phenomenon that may still baffle some camera enthusiasts, but it's not really that complex and understanding how it operates can help any photographer gain considerable control over his or her pictureAaking opportunities.

title: Jets Coach Pleased By Team's Offense
description: When training camp opened two weeks ago, Walt Michaels said that the only New York Jet with a guaranteed job was Wesley Walker, the allprd wide receiver timed at 4.35seconds for 40 yards.

title: Notes /Europe Pursues Rail Modernization
description: Europe is leading the way, as it has for many years, in utilizing railroads as a means of rapid mass transportation. As the United States continues to debate the role of trains in its energyconservation plans, Europe continues to modernize its rail service.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Many authors of best sellers filld themselves at a loss for words whefi asked what inspired their book. Carl Sagan, the astronomer whose current best seller is Broca's Brain, is not one of them.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: THE first time there was a thunderstorm Peter and Patricia Schulz knew they were in for big trouble. Water began leaking in through gaps in the windows, doors and two chimney stacks of their brandnew fourbedroom colonial house in Tolland, bought last August for $75.000.

title: Nicole D. Reinsberg To Marry in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kurt E. Reinsberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nicole Deborah Reinsberg, to Michael Ernest Kubin, son of Lilly Kubin of New York and the late Alexander Kubin.

title: The New York Times /Steven E. Sutton
description: Greg Louganis competing in threemeter springboard diving yesterday at National Sports Festival

title: His SoftDrink Post Isn't All Bubbles
description: SOFT drinks, the commercials tell us, are the accompaniment to a myriad of summertime pleasures: a day at the beach, a softball game, a picnic. Everywhere you look, a delighted someone is hoisting a frostbeaded can or bottle of soda.

title: Melissa McCarthy To Be Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. Barry McCarthy of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Saunders McCarthy, to Victor Kiarsis Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Kiarsis of South Dartmouth. Mass.

title: Cardinal Cody of Chicago Weathering Complaints About Leadership
description: CHICAGO, July 26  John Cardinal Cody of Chicago appears to have weathered the most recent series of complaints about his leadership of the largest Roman Catholic Archdiocese in the United States.

title: Suffolk Police Aim To Attract Minorities
description: WITH its neighbor, the Nassau County Police Department, involved in a lawsuit brought by minorities, the Suffolk Police Department is starting a program to quadruple the number of black, Hispanic and women members of the 2,500member county police force.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Ox Ox Ridge Hunt Club, Middlesex Road, Darien, Conn. Amateurowner, local, junior and children's working hunters; open jumpers, equitation; 8:30 A.M.

title: Carter Evokes Little Enthusiasm at Lawmakers' Parley
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 President Carter's supporters among,about 900 Democratic state legislators here say he is trying, he is sincere and he needs to be given a while longer to prove he is a leader.

title: Events Today
description: Orange County Fair: Agricultural, scientific and animal events, games, food, music and stage shows; 10 A.M. 10 P.M.; Fairgrounds, off Route 122, Middletown, N.Y. Bethesda Fountain Art Exhibit: Art, handicrafts and music; 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Bethesda Fountain and plaza walls, center of Central Park at 72d Street.

title: In Search of the Big Bucks
description: HIS is a book to gladden its publisher's heart, not only because it treats his favorite hobby  Lyle Stuart has written a successful howto book about casino gambling  but also because it does not flinch from commercialism.

title: R. C. Stewart, Janet Swanson Wed in Boston
description: The marriage of Janet Chace Swanson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Swanson of Brooklyn Heights and Williamstown, Mass., to Richard Charles Home Stewart took place in Boston yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Stewart of Wellesley Hills, Mass. The Rev. Jean Curtis performed the ceremony at the Old South Church (Congregational). The Rev. Charles H. Harper assisted.

title: Coping With Alcoholic Parents
description: MOST young people who live with a parent who drinks too much think they are alone in their predicament, but they are not. It is estimated that at least 90,000 young people in Westchester live in homes where there is at least one parent with a drinking problem.

title: ANTIQUES
description: NORTH BRANCH MOST drivers going west from Somerville on Route 22 sail right by the little turnoff for North Branch. But taking this turn can lead to a barn tour that will cover five antiques shops in the space of a half dozen miles, plus a nice stop for lunch.

title: For All Ages, a MiddleAges Festival
description: LOYAL subjects of Westchester will be saluted with medieval pomp and pageantry next weekend at the second New York Renaissance Festival, which opened yesterday, at Sterling Forest Gardens in Tuxedo.

title: Biggest Score
description: MONDAY, July 19, 1976, was a great day for all connoisseurs of true crime. That was the morning when French officials of the Societe Generale in Nice discovered that during the weekend thieves had tunneled their way into the bank and rifled the vaults and some 1,000 safedeposit boxes. The full extent of the robbery will never be known with complete accuracy, but it was estimated the yeggs got away with some 60 million francs ($12 million) making it the biggest score in history.

title: ART
description: THE Artist's View is an outdoor show of sculpture at Wave Hill, a mansion on 28 landscaped acres in Riverdale. The exhibition is meant to help viewers discover new ways of looking at sculpture in landscape. Most of the viewers oteerved on a recent visit, however, seemed to be muddling through using the old ways  lounging onthe grass and on benches or strolling anInng the magnificent trees. On sunny summer days, art education doesn't stand much of a chance.

title: Erica Schonberg, Bond Seller, Sets Bridal for Oct. 13
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth C. Schonbbrg of Cincinnati have announced the engagement of their daughter, Erica Schonberg, to Kevin Robert McDonnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. McDonnell of Houston.

title: After a Wife and a Ford Torino
description: HARLES PORTIS is fond of sending his fictional characters into the field on strange odysseys.

title: Music: Donna Summer Performs at Forest Hills
description: Donna Summer was blessed by a fine New York summer evening for the first of her two soldout shows at the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium Friday night. And she made the most of the setting and the weather, with a solid, entertaining, vital show. Best of all, she suggested that her already demonstrated capacity for growth may not be exhausted yet, and that for all the pop pleasure she gives now, she may one day be able to become something deeper and more important.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BEACH HAVEN (Surflight Summer Theater, Engleside Avenue)  Where's Charley? Opens tomorrow, 8:30 P.M. (through Aug. 6). $545.50. (609) 4929477.

title: Liner's Passengers Trade Punches Over Cruise Cut by Fatal Accident
description: The liner Rotterdam docked in New York yesterday morning after a Bahamian cruise amid some angry pierside scenes over her captain's decision to skip a final stop in Bermuda. He had acted because of time lost in an unsuccessful effort off Florida to save the life of a gravely injured passenger. ne passenger, a 66yearold Pennsylvania woman, died in a Miami Hospital last Thursday, two days after she had been airlifted to Florida for intensive care and the Rotterdarti had turned around for an extra day ashore in Nassau instead of steaming on to Bermuda as scheduled.

title: TaxSaving Program Imperiled
description: WASHINGTON APROGRAM that has saved New Jersey taxpayers more than $60 million and has kept families off the welfare rolls may be doomed because of a Congressional squabble.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Summers past. Nothing important ever happens along Publishers Row during the dog days, when every ablebodied soul is at the beach or counting the minutes until he can get there. How true is that ancient truism? We've just flipped through our file of old snapshots to see what paperback folk were up to in bygone summers. Herewith a random sampling: 1939. Europe is teetering on the edge of war. John Steinbeck's The Grapes of Wrath ($2.75) is fiction's biggest seller. And four men  Robert F. de Graff, Richard Simon, Max Schuster and Leon Shimkin are working overtime to make a fullpage ad they've placed in this newspaper come true: OUT TODAY! THE NEW POCKET BOOKS THAT MAY REVOLUTIONIZE NEW YORK'S READING HABITS.

title: How the Civil Service Strike Was Ended
description: TRENTON TWO weeks ago, when many of the 32,000 clerical and administrative employees of the state were on strike, Governor Byrne let it be known that he was willing to have a showdown on illegal work stoppages.

title: Sally Woolworth to Marry in Fall
description: The engagement of Sally Kingsley Woolworth to Alexander Parsons Lynch has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Griswold Woolworth of Lancaster, Pa., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Rose Parsons Lynch of New York and R. Vincent Lynch of Dallas.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Had they met in the forests of Southeast Asia, where they normally live, they would have swung by each other with hardly a backward glance. But tnrown together in a shared cage of an Atlanta zoo, the male gibbon and the female siamang mated and seemingly defied the laws of nature by producing a healthy offspring  a siabonthe first reported ape hybrid.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Here is what I once considered the world's most mortifying story. It took place when I was 13, forbidden to wear stockings to school and therefore determined to wear them on principle, although had only the dimmest notion of what the principle might be. My knowledge of stocking lore, similarly limited. Included nothing more helpful than the names of the first three girls in my class to own any. So when I bought a pair on the sly and tugged them on behind a hedge one morning, never occurred to me that anything other than the sheer glee of the moment would be required to hold them up. In fact, got to the corner and onto the school bus without running afoul of gravity. But by the time I got off the bus, those stockings had fallen down on the job, so to speak; they lay in miserable little heaps around my ankles. My classmates couldn't help but notice, and notice rather noisily at that. thought my life was over.

title: New York State Changes LotteryNumber Prefixes
description: ALBANY, July 28 (AP)  The New York State Lottery Division has changed the prefixes of possible winning numbers for those Olympic Lottery tickets bearing a drawing date of Nov. 15. 1979.

title: As He Rose to the Majors, No One Who Saw Him Play Doubted He Would Be a Star
description: WILLIE MAYS joined the New York Giants on May 25, 1951, fora a game in Philadelphia. He hardly came unheralded.

title: Checkers Visiting Brokers Spot Exclusionary Practices
description: The Brooklyn real estate broker, a pleasant, middleaged man who runs a successful agency, grabbed some folders from his files, pulled up two chairs and sat down to begin an interview at his office recently with a prospective home buyer.

title: George Seaton, Director, Dead; Got Two Oscars for Screenplays
description: George Seaton, a versatile director, producer and screenwriter whose 40year Hollywood career included winning two Oscars, died yesterday at his Beverly Hills home after an illness of two years. He was 68 years old.

title: Reagan and Ford Hold G.O.P. Lead, Poll Says
description: Ronald Reagan and former President Gerald R. Ford continue to be the top choices among Republicans for their Presidential nominee in 1980, with John B. Connally, former Governor of Texas, and Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee their third and fourth choices, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Klansmen Are Taunted At a Birmingham March
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 28 (UPI) Ku Klux Klansmen and blacks, separated by police lines, exchanged jeers and taunts today as the Klansmen marched 11 blocks in the downtown area.

title: Dorothy Y. Morgenstern Bride of Harris Thomas
description: Dorothy Young Morgenstern of Princeton, N.J., widow of Oskar Morgenstern, former professor of mathematical economics at Princeton University, was married Monday to Harris Henderson Thomas of Castine, Me., who was for many years on the faculty of the Phillips Exeter Academy and director of the School Year Abroad Program in Rennes, France. The Rev. Frederick Buechner, former chaplain at Phillips Exeter, performed the Presbyterian ceremony at his home in Pawlet, Vt.

title: Rock Is Edging Into Video
description: Not everyone may be aware of it just yet, but we're teetering on the edge of the videodisk era. Warner Brothers recent release of the first rock digital disk, Ry Cooder's Bop Till You Drop, indicates that digital recording is already upon us, This new technique  in which sound is reduced to the computer's binary numerical system, or quantified, in technical terminology, thus eliminating conventional distortion  is in itself a significant phenomenon, to judge from the remarkably clear and airy sound Of Mr. Cooder's record.

title: The Golden Arm, Unitas, Is Enshrined
description: CANTON, OHIO WHILE Bill Dudley, the president of the National Football League Alumni Association, intoned the statistics, the milestones of 18 marvelous years in pro football.

title: Practical Applications Are Far in the Future But Not Out of Reach
description: Electrical devices that could restore hearing and sight to the deaf and blind are finally becoming feasible after 200 years on the drawing board. Although Benjamin Franklin first suggested the possibility of using electricity this way 1751, when he described the results of his lightning experiment to the Royal Society of London, researchers warn that the devices are in the experimental stage, with any practical use still many years away.

title: MRS. GEORGE WEISS
description: Hazel W. Weiss, wife of the late George Weiss, who was general manager of the New York Yankees and the first president of the New York Mets, died Friday in a Greenwich, Conn., nursing home. She was 78 years old. Mrs. Weiss, who was born in Brookline, Mass., lived for many years in Greenwich.

title: A Social Inquiry
description: FROM time to time in history, human reason is discovered and made an object of veneration. Ours has been such an era. We were told to honor intelligence. Formal education stressed evidence and analysis. A vocation called research became our highest calling.

title: List of Environmental Organizations: Part I
description: Following is the first part of a list of environmental organizations in New Jersey.

title: Energetic Proposals
description: ANOTHER book about the energy crisis? Two, actually, and both worth the effort as counterpoint to the President's latest call to action. Barry Commoner bludgeons with a powerful, if not totally convincing, attack on the Carter Administration's failure to focus on solar energy. Robert Stobaugh and Daniel Yergin offer a cooler appraisal of how we got into the energy mess and how we might get out.

title: Historical Park Recalls Birth of Industrial Era
description: The birthplace of the American Industrial Revolution is preserved in the nation's newest national park Lowell, Mass., where farm girls and immigrants worked in mills to produce textiles that were the basis of New England's economy in the laSt century.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  The Boy Friend. Toat 8. Jesus Christ Superstar. Wednessday to Saturday at 8:30 P.M., next Suiday at 8 P.M. Through Sept. 3. $5.50 to $9t50.Discount available for students, the etletly and groups. Reservations. Mahopac Hann Playhouse, junction of Routes 6 and 148. 6281169.

title: Deaths
description: HINESHelen G. On Saturday, July 28, 1979. Resident of New Windsor, N.Y. Formerly of NYC. Devoted mother of Mrs. Helen Bounty. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday July 31 at 10 AM at St. Thomas Church, New Windsor. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Greenwich, Ct. For information contact Horn & Thomes Funeral Home, 83 East Main St., Pawling, N.Y.

title: Refugees Rescued by Seventh Fleet Say Carter's Directive Spurs Exodus
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. WABASH, off Thailand, July 28  President Carter's decision to send United States Navy ships into international waters near Indochina to look for refugees has prompted new departures, according to refugees picked up in the Gulf of Siam by an American ship.

title: In Nicaragua's Second City, Sandinists March to Different Economic Drummer
description: LEON, Nicaragua, July 28  While the ninedayold revolutionary Government in Managua continues to map Nicaragua's future, the fiveweekold Sandinist government here in the country's second largest city has installed a tightly controlled administration based on communally shared property.

title: GARDENING
description: MUCH of the productiveness that characterizes American agriculture and horticulture was developed Through the science of genetics, which origirtated when Gregor Mendel, a monk, discovered the basic laws of inheritance while hybridizing sweet peas.

title: Dwyer Leads Golf By 2 Shots
description: STE. JULIEDEVERCHERES, Quebec, July 28  Mary Dwyer of Geneva, N.Y., who traces her ancestry to Ireland's counties of Mayo and Cork, and who says she has never Shad the luck of the Irish in nine years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, made her own good fortune today and took the thirdround lead in the Peter Jackson Classic. Miss Dwyer has not won a tournament in her pro career.

title: The Topiary Art: Cultivating Live Statues in a Garden
description: In earlier times, when the cost of human labor was the least of the rich's worries, elaborate decoration was the rule. Furniture was built with cluttery curlicues, buildings were given fancy friezework. If such frills took a lot of time in the making, it did not matter; after all, the price was only a working man's hours.

title: The World
description: The cost of a new strategic arms limitation treaty appears to be rising, and so do pressures on the Carter Administration's willingness to pay. In hearings last week before the Senate Armed Services Committee, Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is influential on military matters, said he could not in good conscience vote for the treaty unless the Administration spent 4 to 5 percent more a year, not counting inflation, for at least five years to improve the United States nuclear and conventional arsenal.

title: Admiral's Cup Boats Gather Off England
description: Fiftyseven of the world's fastest oceanracing yachts, all manned by top crews, are gathering in Cowes, England, for the start Wednesday of the international Admiral's Cup sailing competition off southern England.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: At Large on Virgine's Eastern Shore
description: The 200milelong Delmarva Peninsula casually outlines a water muskrat swimming north, its nose buttoned on Wilmington in the Delaware River, its arched back taking the brunt of the Atlantic Ocean, its feet paddling the eastern marshes and estuaries of the Chesapeake Bay, and its tail trailing south toward Norfolk and the Virginia mainland.

title: CHESS
description: AMSTERDAM The world champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, has this advantage over his rivals: While they rely heavily on opening innovations to defeat each other, he performs so well in routine quiet positions that he need not look for anything special out of the opening.

title: Brewers Beat Yanks With a 6Run Fifth
description: MILWAUKEE, July 28  The Milwaukee Brewers may make a strong run at the top spot in the American League East, but the New York Yankees do not appear to be going anywhere.

title: Racket Law Is Used to Convict Lawyer
description: AFEDERAL appeals court has affirmed the conviction of a Newark lawyer on a racketeering charge involving a scheme to defraud several hospitals, but the court added a warning that prosecutors should avoid undue prosecutorial zeal in enforcing the controversial racketeering law.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Saturday  Triumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey 45mile gimmick rally; start at Arlington Plaza shopping center, Route 46 Westbound, Parsippany, N.J. Registration: 7:30 P.M.; first car off 8. Information: Don or Anna Andrews (201) 2564397.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: The nostalgia will flow like root beer today at the Museums at Stony Brook, where at 2 P.M. graduates of oneroom schoolhouses are invited to share their reminiscences during a showandtell session that will be recorded at the museum complex's own 19thcentury Nassakeag Schoolhouse. To help the participants remember, from 1 to 4 P.M., a blacksmith apprentice, Matthew Cerveilo will ply his craft at the Blacksmith Shop, the ponydrawn governess dart will offer rides on the museum's gieen, and the nearby Grist Mill will be in: operation. Admission to the museums, on Route 25A, is $2; students, the elderly, $1.50; children 6 through 12, 31. 7510066.

title: Fresh Air Fund Gives the Needy Jobs
description: Loretta Gravino and Maria Garcia, both 16 years old, recently discovered that they had more in common than their age and an underprivileged background. Last week through the Fresh Air Fund  they were offered their first parttime jobs, aside from summer work, and both picked the nursing field.

title: Calendar
description: Today. Essex Antiques Show. Town Hall. Noon to 5 P.M. Take Exit 69 from I95.30 exhibitors.

title: A Manhattan Prisoner Is Discovered Hanged In a Cell Shared by 12
description: A 29yearold man apparently hanged himself yesterday in a detention cell he was sharing with 11 other men at the Manhattan Criminal Court a spokesman for the Department of Correction said.

title: Opera: The Magic Flute in Sante Fe
description: SANTE FE, N. M., July 28  Mo zart's The Magic Flute has been subject to various indignities since its premiere almost 200 years ago, and the latest took place last night at the Santa Fe Opera. But since the production turned out to be a minor crime rather than grand larceny, nobody seems to be taking it very seriouslyAnyway, all attention is focused on tonight's event  the American premiere of Alban Berg's Lulu, with the newly completed last act by Friedrich Cerha that was unveiled last February at the Paris Opera. The 1979 Santa Fe Opera season contains, in addition to the Mozart and. Berg, Offenbach's La Grande Duchesse de Gerolstein, Donizetti's Lucia and Strauss Salome.

title: East Germans Report a Big Move Of Rhodesians Into Mozambique
description: EAST BERLIN, July 28 (AP)  About 30,000 refugees have fled into Mozambique since the April elections in Zimbabwe Rhodesia, bringing the total to 150,000, the East German press agency ADN has reported in a dispatch from the Mozambican capital, Maputo.

title: Auditing New York Tax Returns For the City Falls Short of Goals
description: A plan by New York State to intensify its audits of tax returns filed by New York City taxpayers is producing less money for the city than state officials had originally hoped fol., according to estimates by the state's Department of Taxation and Finance.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I don't question Drew Middletoh's opinions in his grotesque sazeup of the Bay of Pigs operation (as recorded in my book, Bay of Pigs: The Untold Story (June 10). I do question titre way he shoves facts into the shredder and substitutes fantasies.

title: Susan Kay Barnard Will Wed on Sept. 8
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Clifford Barnard Jr. of Devon, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Kay Barnard, to Taylor Mitchell Vincent of Rowayton, Conn., son of Mrs. Edwin Serre Murphy of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Samuel Mitchell Vincent, also of Fairfield.

title: Lori Kantrowitz Is Engaged To Wed Charles G..Ludnier.
description: The engagement of Lori Kantrowitz to Charles G. Ludmer has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. S. Edward. Kantrowitz of Teaneck, N.J. parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Lionel Ludmer, also a Teaneck.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IT was Sunday, and we had just driven two hours up and back to deliver our older son to camp. The younger one had tearfully boarded a noisy camp bus in New York City at dawn the day before. I was free, apd I felt as if a steamroller, had.flattened me.

title: Andre-Michel Schub May Be Emerging From the Shadows
description: Last February at Hunter College, AndreMichel Schub put on a sizzling display of cultivated virtuosity, but he didn't attract much attention, and for obvious reasons. For one thing. Mr.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The President's energy program announced on July 15 is deserving of support.

title: Times Ran a Comic in 1906
description: When Adolph S. Ochs bought the failing New York Times in 1896 with the intent of turning into a major newspaper, comic strips were considered a good gimmick to increase a newspaper's circulation. Mr. Ochs, however, would have nothing to do with them  at first.

title: Leading Iraqi Officials Accused of Conspiracy Backed by Foreigners
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 28 (Reuters) At least five highranking members of the ruling Revolutionary Command Council and Baath Party have been arrested for involvement in a conspiracy involving a foreign power, the official Iraqi press agency reported tonight.

title: ELIZABETH MACKAY POTTER
description: Dr. Elizabeth Mackay Potter, an instructor in internal medicine for nearly 15 years at the New York University School of Medicine, died Thursday evening at her home in White Plains. She was 54 years old.

title: Deaths
description: BANKSMurray. Beloved husband of Viola. Devoted father of Cynthia Dogin and Ralph Banks. Adored grandfather of Michele and Jennifer. Services Sunday July 29, 11:45AM at The Riverside', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Bonvin --Restored to His Rightful Place
description: French painting of the 19th century has long been so familiar, so popular and so genuinely beloved adored with equal fervor by the public, the critics, the scholars and the artists (parties who otherwise disagree about so much else in the realm of art) that it always comes as something of a shock to have our mental picture of this halcyon period even a little bit modified. Despite all the attention we have lavished on the French painters of that era, might we still be overlooking a significant figure? Are there still discoveries to be made, and reputations to be rescued from an unearned oblivion?

title: ANTIQUES
description: Forty years ago Larry Zim, New York designer, ran away from home to attend the New York World's Fair. He has been haunted ever since by memories of that 1939 event and consumed with curiosity about all the World's Fairs that preceded and followed it.

title: Strike Avoided by Western Union
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 28 (AP)  Negotiators for more than 8,000 technicians, operators and clerical employees of Western Union reached an agreement on a new threeyear contract 15 minutes before a strike deadline at midnight yesterday, a union leader said today. The tentative contract calls for increases in wages and fringe benefits of more than 28 percent, according to spokesman for the United Telegraph Workers. In New York City, a spokesman said Western Union also reached agreement with 1,000 members of the Communications Workers of America on a threeyear contract for a 27 percent increase in wages and benefits.

title: Engagements
description: LogonWilder Dr. & Mrs. Walter Llewellyn Wilder of Edina, Minn. announce the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Lynn Wilder to William Ward Logan, son of Mr. & Mrs. Edwin Ward Logan of Boothbay Harbor, Maine. A September 22nd wedding is planned. Miss Wilder graduated from Edina High School and Vassar College and completed a Masters degree in lournalism at the Univ. of Minn. last March. She Is a freelance writer and researcher In Boston. Mr. Logan graduated from Phillips Academy at Andover, Mass. and Vassar College. He Is an Investment and Insurance broker In Boston.

title: RELIANCE TAKEOVER BY EXXON IS HALTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The proposed $1.17 billion takeover of the Reliance Electric Company by the Exxon Corporation was blocked at least temporarily today by a Federal judge.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE 57 American Legion posts in Bergen County surprised the nation when they elected woman, Marilyn C. Carrig, as commander for the next year at their annual convention two weeks ago in Lodi. It was the first time in its 59year history that the county organization had selected a woman as leader.

title: New N.B.A. Pact Talks to Open
description: The National Basketball Association and its players association will open two days of initial bargaining for a new contract today at the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles. The last threeyear contract expired last month. Larry Fleisher, the general counsel of the players association, will present the group's demands at the'meeting.

title: World Criticism Is Remote, and Irrelevant, to the West Bank Settlers
description: ELON MOREH, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, July 24  The land here is hard. It is covered with sharpedged rocks and jagged boulders that nearly crowd out the scanty brush, and it does not yield easily to new roots. Fifteen Jewish families who have settled here, deep in Arab territory, hope that their settlement may nourish ancient Jewish claims.

title: A Dog's Identity Crisis Is Solved by the Wave Of His Master's Hand
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 28  Two Doberman pinschers, strikingly friendly and playful, recently made a run for it when someone left the gates open in their fenced yards.

title: Childish Delights In a Bean Patch
description: When I was five and six years old, I spent many summer twilights in my father's garden. I can still see the huge footprints indented in the dark brown soil. With all my childish enthusiasm, I took big giant steps trying to put each red sneakered foot where my father's foot had been as I followed him through the rows of vegetables.

title: Carter Shakeup: Mixed Reviews
description: Carter Shakeup: Mixed Reviews

title: Duncan Hearings on TV
description: The Senate hearings on the nomination of Charles W. Duncan Jr. to be Secretary of Energy will be televised tomorrow from 8 A.M. to 1 P.M. on WNETTV.

title: Rosanne Mayer Married to John A. Siliciano
description: At Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Lake View, N.Y., Rosanne Mayer, daughter of Mrs. Edward A. Mayer of Lake View and the late Mr. Mayer, was married yesterday to John A. Siliciano, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert V. Siliciano of Elmira, N.Y. The Rev. Patrick Ellis performed the ceremony.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The Netherlands Dance Theater has just presented two extraordinary ballets in New York by its artistic director, Jiri Kylian. Both were set to music by Mr. Kylian's countryman, the Czechoslovak composer Leos Janacek. In their sweep, power and vigor, in their exaltation of nature's processes, and their folklike sturdiness of broad gesture, these two works, Sinfonietta and Glagolitic Mass, had a great deal in common. Both even had a similar and beautiful colorfield type Of backcloth by Walter Nobbe, suggesting a landscape mountains and rivers. In Sinfonietta, the dancers jubilantly turned their backs to the audience at the end to begin an implied trek toward this horizon. In Glagolitic Mass, nearly all the dancers were swept along a cascade of movement into the wings, leaving behind a man who symbolically died and was instantly mourned by a female figure.

title: If Black English Isn't a Language, Then Tell Me, What Is?
description: ST. PAUL DE VENCE, France The argument concerning the use, or the status, or the reality, of black English is rooted in American history and has absolutely nothing to ao with the question the argument supposes itself to be posing. The argument has nothing to do with language itself but with the role of language. Language, incontestably, reveals the speaker. Language, also, far more dubiously, is meant to define the other  and, in this case, the other is refusing to be defined by a language that has never been able to recognize him.

title: Giants' Defense Tames Offense
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 28A week before their first exhibition game and five weeks and a day before the regular season, the Giants showed that they were in midseason form today during an intrasquad scrimmage.

title: SINGH TAKES OFFICE IN INDIA AND PLEDGES NONALIGNED POLICY
description: NEW DELHI, July 28  Charan Singh was sworn in today as the fifth Prime Minister of India, and declared that his Government would continue to follow the policy of nonalignment which will not lean on any superpower.

title: Near Mishap Reported On Kennedy Runway
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has impounded airtraffic controllers tape recordings and begun an investigation of reports of a near collision between a Lot Polish Airlines jet and a Braniff International aircraft on a runway at Kennedy International Airport on Friday night.

title: Cever: Photograph by Stanley Tretick/ Sygma
description: Jimmy Carter was furious. He sat in the Oval Office on this chill November day, staring at the note paper before him. Riots were sweeping Iran. The Shah had just been forced to impose a military government on his nation. And the President of the United States hadn't even known a revolution was coming  had, in fact, been assured all along by the American intelligence community that there was no such danger. Mr. Carter lifted his pen and wrote: I am not satisfied with the quality of political intelligence. The notes were addressed to Cy, Stan and Zbig  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, Director of Central Intelligence Stansfield Turner and National Security Adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski.

title: Music Notes: Opera Companies on Parade
description: Not even the massive Edinburgh Festival has ever had as many opera companies in attendance as the Newport Opera Festival will have this year. A spinoff from the Newport Music Festival, which closed last Tuesday, the Opera Festival takes over the resort's great houses on Saturday night with the American debut of the Tresors Retrouves de Paris. The latter is one of five operatic ensembles represented in the two weeks of activities that will follow.

title: Satisfying the Cookie Monster Cravings
description: The humble cookie has arrived. From Bloomingdale's to Greenwich Village, any New Yorker can see that cookie vendors are doing a monstrous business. Stores such as We Got Your Cookie, David's Cookie Kitchen and Absoiutely the Best Chocolate Chip Cookie In New York City are proliferating. But it's not just a Manhattan phenomenon. The Commerce Department estimates that cookiecraving Americans will buy 88 billion worth of the goodies annually by 1985.

title: Why Middle Age Isn't the End
description: MIDDLE AGE is a package dial Along with blurry eyesight,. gray hairs and an often agonizing but necessary reassessment of our lives comes a surprise: Freedom. It is pure gold to realize your life is opening up. You have freedom from and freedom to  just when you thought it was all but over.

title: An Embattled Utility in Cleveland Reports $301,987 Profit for 1978
description: CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP)  The Cleveland Municipal Electric Light System, the cityowned utility that was the focus of a bitter dispute over its ability to earn money, has reported a profit for 1978.

title: East Germany Tightens Curbs on. Foreign Contacts
description: EAST BERLIN, July 25  On Aug. 1, the East German Government is to put into force strict laws aimed at tightening controls and silencing potential critics.

title: Once More, With Feeling
description: Finally, the Cabinet shakeup that even Robert S. Strauss, Democratic Party professional and Administration troubleshooter, conceded was debilitating, at best was done with. In a sense,. the Carter Presidency started over last week, with Mr. Carter setting high standards, that his midterm record makes only more difficult to meet.

title: IN THE NATION
description: What will it take to impart to Congress a sense of urgency about the energy crisis? As loudly as its members complain about President Carter's supposed lack of leadership, at least he has tried to awaken them and the country to the necessity of breaking American dependence on OPEC oil. But Congress bickers and delays.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Fionnula Flanagan of Dublin's Abbey Theater is best known to American audiences for her performance as Molly in James Joyce's Ulysses in Nighttown, shown both off and on Broadway in 1974.

title: When the Mill Pulled the Rug Out From Under Yonkers
description: TWENTYFIVE. years ago this summer, Yonkers found itself at a crossroads. Its biggest industry, the Smith carpet mill, had decided to pull out and head south, threatening the city economically and wrenching its character. In that same year outer xorces of cnange were oper ating. The Cross County Shopping Center opened and the New York State Thruway was completed through the city. The metamorphosis to modernday Yonkers was beginning.

title: The English Lakes: A Diverse Journey
description: There is such beauty in the English Lake District that one can easily understand how Wordsworth and other Romantic poets looked at the region and found inspiration for a religion of nature. The beauty is so imposing that visitors from all over the world are drawn to one or another of the 100 lakes in the north of England to sail or perhaps hike on paths where Wordsworth once walked, tramping through woods or climbing to the tops of peaks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a followup to David Binder's article Exploring the Danube Delta (Travel Section, July 1), I would like to tell you about the trip by riverboat I took this past winter with my mother and my girlfriend  from Tulcea to the tip of the Delta at Sulina, the easternmost portion of Europe.

title: The Nation
description: Washington may be the political class act in America but, as the host of the revamped Jimmy Carter Hour noted last week, there are plenty of other places to try out material. Chicago, for instance, where the Rosalynn Carter Road Company crossed paths with the Ted Kennedy production of Who, Me? Or California, where Jeri'y Brown was seeking angels for an experimental work (One Character in Search of the Presidency) that aspires to nothing less than a redefinition of the Democratic Party.

title: The Rodino Career: A Life in Congress
description: WASHINGTON PETER WALLACE RODINO JR. watched another conservative attack on school busing fail in the House of Representatives last week and then mentally girded himself for the next fight

title: Long Island /This Week
description: BELLPORT  New works by Bell Street Artists; 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Mondays through Saturdays; Saturday through Sept. 1; Souwester Bookstore Gallery, 137 Main St. Opening 7:30 P.M. Friday.

title: Carter Has to Start Running If He Wants to Stay in Place
description: WASHINGTON  If there was a touch of political war cry in President Carter's attack on the oil lobby Wednesday night along with his smiling reluctance to announce his candidacy for reelection, it is because the campaign has already begun. Mr. Carter is banking heavily on his energy program and his dramatic government reshuffle to buy enough time to rescue his ailing presidency and to put life into his fragile candidacy. It's a staggering job and there's not much time, commented an independent Washington political consultant with ties to the Carter camp. The one thing you know about elections is that they end upon time.

title: Snag Delays Suit Against L.P.G.A.
description: STE. JULIEDEVERCHERES, Quebec, July 28  One of two male professional golfers who have threatened to sue the Ladies Professional Golf Association for discrimination against men may not be able to take any immediate legal action because his current lawyer of record has refused to take his case.

title: Actor's Desire Turns Into a Play
description: STONY BROOK IT came to Rich Rand while he was performing a street corner in San Francisco  juggling, riding a unicycle, doing mime to support his acting habit. He would go back East and try to get together with some of the people he had worked with as an undergraduate theater arts major at the State University at Stony Brook.

title: A Wilton Homeowner's Pungent Tale
description: WILTON WE have a skunk living under our house. Again.I suppose I should't have been surprised when moved in. After all, three others have previously denned up in the space in the two years since we moved here from Kentucky.

title: Is Recession Upon Us? Er, Uh, Maybe.
description: Has a recession begun? Clearly the nation has arrived at a crucial stage a point where as a rule slowdowns do or do not become recessions. But what has happened to date, in terms of the principal measures of economic performance, Goes not yield a firm conclusion. Those who have concluded that a recession is here are either placing great weight upon a single measure of performance or relying upon a forecast of what is still to happen.

title: A Commuter Cries Hold That Spray!
description: ALTHOUGH James Flanigan is concerned enough about the environment to use no chemical pesticides at his home in Ridgewood, he belongs to no environmental organizations.

title: 61 Shot Triumphs On Grass
description: Terpsichorist took the lead from Late Bloomer in the stretch yesterday and scored by a nose in the $112,000 Sheepshead Bay Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Love Street Wins Sorority At Monmouth, Pays $41.80
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 28  Dan La Sater's Love Street, one of four supplementary starters in the race, closed with a rush today to capture the $126,205 Sorority Stakes before 16,844 fans at Monmouth Park.

title: Rookie Gets Pole at Pocono 500
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 28  Harry Gant, a rookie driver who has not finished in the top five in his 12 starts on the Grand National circuit, won the pole position today for tomorrow's CocaCola 500mile NASCAR race.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BROOKLYN Contemporary art from China, woodblock prints, needlepoint tapestries, watercolors on silk, oils and embroidered silk paintings. New England Center for Contemporary Art, through Sept. 3. Rte. 169. Free. 774.8899.

title: LETTER FROM BOSTON
description: BOSTONIANS have deplored the dimming of their city's literary splendor ever since William Dean Howells migrated to New York in 1888. Until then, Boston had sanctified its writers, according various Lowells and Longfellows the honor normally conferred upon artists more gifted than they ever were. Seventy years after Howells had taken the literary center of the country with him (as Alfred Kazin wrote in On Native Grounds) Elizabeth Hardwick scolded the city in her essay Boston: The Lost Ideal for spending and spending her inflated bills of pure reputation, decade after decade. Hardwick and her husband, Robert Lowell, fled Boston in 1960. Now, she declared, one supposes it is all over at last.

title: Itel Corporation Is At the Brink Again
description: By surviving more than its share of disasters, the Itel Corporation has earned a reputation for being adept at brinkmanship. Now, once again, the San Franciscobased computer and equipment leasing company is struggling to stay alive.

title: Baltimore Harbor Buoy Is for Francis Scott Key
description: BALTIMORE, July 28 (UPI)  Visitors to Baltimore Harbor can now see flashing starspangled buoy bobbing near the Francis Scott Key Bridge, commemorating the 200th birthday on Wednesday of the author of the national anthem.

title: DieselFueled Automobile Fails To Live Up to Claims onMileage
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 28 (UPI)Government tests on the Shetleymobile show that the dieselpowered car gets less than halt the 110 miles per gallon that its builder said it would get in a nationwide publicity tour. me Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday that the modified diesel car also exceeded antipollution exhaust standards and could not be certified for production.

title: Just Like Olde Times
description: JUSTICE Isaac Rubin of State Supreme Court said last week that the request by Jimmie Lee Allen, a defendant with Junius Gray in the Bedford murder case, for a courtappointed female Jewish attorney was surprising, perhaps, but not unique.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: It is only about 30 miles south, through expensive countryside, from the Williamstown Theater in northeastern Massachusetts to the Berkshire Playhouse in Stockbridge. These are probably the two preeminent summer playhouses in New England, aside from the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn. ; and they could hardly be more different.

title: On language
description: In The Industry (formerly The Business, which replaced Hollywood, once called Movieland), a jargon has been developed that offers a sentence like this: He packaged a worldclass director and a bankable gross player, aimed at rolling it out to Yumpsville in 60 situations, was greenlighted after he took a meeting  but another element was a mouthbreather, and the writer phoned it in, and suddenly it was Tisha b'Av Nellietime.

title: Energy: Subsidies Are Not the Answer
description: Evewbefore the President's address to the nation on July 15, a bandwagon had been forming to launch an enormous government syntheticfuels program as a means of solving our energy problems. By any rational economic criteria, subsidy programs such as those proposed by the Administration are wasteful to the utmost, unlikely to contribute significantly to solving our energy problems, even by 1990, and furthermore may be detrimental to the economic health of the country.

title: Caldwell Says His Pitch Slipped
description: MILWAUKEE, July 28  Reggie Jackson, the Yankee outfielder, touched off a benchclearing melee last night in County Stadium, but it failed to spark the Yankees to any great heights. They lost to the Milwaukee Brewers, 65, because of Cecil Cooper, the Brewers first baseman, who smacked a twoout home run  his third homer of the game  in the ninth inning to cap a glorious night for him and the 47,928 fans.

title: Spy Swap: All in a Day's Work
description: NEWARK APRIL 27, 1979, was cold and drizzly, Robert J. Del l'ufo recalled, a perfect day for the final act in one of the great spy dramas of our time: the exchange of Soviet spies here for Soviet dissidents there.

title: Ellen Treacy Galway, Account Executive, Fiancee of John R. Owen, Audit Manager
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Vincent Galway of Glen Rock, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Treacy Galway, to John Russel Owen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Hall Owen of Providence, R.I.

title: Perry Is Now 2d. In Strikeout List
description: SAN DIEGO,July 28 (AP)Gaylord Perry of the San Diego Padres fanned Dennis Littlejohn of the San Francisco Giants for the 3,118th strikeout of his career tonight and took over secondplace on baseball's alltime strikeout list.

title: Museum of Modern Art To Show Peter Ellenshaw
description: Models, sketches, matte paintings and stills by Peter Ellenshaw, a mo. tionpicture artist for Walt Disney Pro. ductions, will be on display from Sept. 15 to Dec. 23 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: Music: Broadway Opry Starts Series
description: Broadway Opry 79, the ambitious new country music series that opened at the St. James Theater on Friday night, Is presenting a broad spectrum of Nashville styles and a generous assortment of talents in its first installment. There's a world of difference between Tanya Tucker's country rock, Don Gibson's weathered honkytonk, Mickey Newbury's sensitive ballads and Floyd Cramer's glossy piano playing, and one suspects this variety may turn out to be the point of the whole series.

title: G.S. Stewart, Lawyer, Weds Miss Boyle
description: In the Houghton Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College yesterday, Marybeth Norton Boyle, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clifford H. Boyle of Westwood, Mass., and Geoffrey S. Stewart were married. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon D. Stewart of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Robert F. Healey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Kingman Clouts 3 Homers, But Mets Conquer Cubs, 64
description: Even when the Mets win a game, they are upstaged. They beat the Chicago Cubs, 64, yesterday at Shea Stadium, but the big hand was for the Cubs Dave Kingman, who hit three home runs in three successive appearances and tied for the major league lead at 35 with Mike Schmidt of the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Mail Campaign for Kennedy Brings Both Positive and Negative Replies
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Early returns from a direct mail campaign intended to inspire a grassroots draft of Senator Edward M. Kennedy as a Presidential candidate next year are showing the expected enthusiasm for the Massachusetts Democrat, but also an almost equal number of negative resnonses.

title: CALIFORNIA CREATES ATLAS OF ITS WATER
description: LOS ANGELES, July 28  The state of California's first copyrighted work, a volume a foot and a half square titled The California Water Atlas, is a staggeringly detailed graphic accounting of virtually every drop of water that lands in California and what becomes of it, possibly the first such state compilation ever prpduced. At 124 pages,, it cost $500,000 and involved 66 persons.

title: Clarence Manion, a Conservative And ExLaw Dean at Notre Dame
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., July 28 (AP) Clarence E. Manion, former dean of the University of Notre Dame Law School and founder of the conservative Manion Forum on radio and television, died today at St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 83 years old and has suffered a stroke two weeks ago.

title: Music: Miss de Larrocha
description: Many instrumentalists have been closely associated with the Mostly Mozart Festival over the 13 years of its existence, and none more so than Alicia de Larrocha. These summer concerts are almost invariably sold out, but when Miss de Larrocha plays, tickets seem to be at an extra premium.

title: The New Man at the Fed Will Chart His Own Course
description: WASHINGTON  Paul A. Volcker isn't going to be another G. William Miller, or Arthur F. Burns, or William McChesney Martin Jr. in his new post as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board  even though, on the surface, all Fed chairmen seem to sound alike.

title: 2 KLEIN CHALLENGES IN SUFFOLK PRIMARY
description: John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, was confronted by primary challenges on two fronts yesterday, while Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader who has been losing Civil Court judgeships to antiorganization Democrats in recent years, faced a mass challenge from six Democratic organization Civil Court nominees that could jeopardize,his leadership.

title: Carter Says Amtrak Rider Surge Changed His Views on Cutbacks
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  President Carter said yesterday that a change in Administration position on cutting back Amtrak service had accommodated the increased patronage of the national rail passenger service resulting from the gasoline shortage.

title: The Washington Dust Settles, But Inflation Headache Persists
description: President Carter gave out some strong medicine last week to counter the negative Washington reaction that had at first greeted his Cabinet shakeup  and the nation's investors at first reacted strongly in the affirmative. on Wednesday, the day after Mr. Carter named the conservative Paul A. Wicker to head the Federal Reserve Board and spoke out forcefully in defense of his energy program, prices on the New York Stock Exchange made their best gains in three weeks, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 9.73 points.

title: Barbara Brundige and Thomas Decker Wed
description: Barbara Lynn Brundige, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Brundige of Dayton, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Thomas William Decker, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Decker of Chatham, N.J., and Westport Harbor, Mass. The Rev. Robert Fenwick performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: City Rents Houses To Potential Buyers
description: In the living room of their sixroom house on 140th Street in South Ozone Park, Timothy and Jean Aiken described the Crown Heights apartment that they had left gratefully nine years ago. Mr. Aiken, who drives trucks for living, recalled the discomfort of a cramped apartment where he and his wife reared three children. Not much room  no place to turn, Mr. Aiken said. His wife nodded in silent agreement.

title: IDEAS &
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex.  Any day now, Ixtoc 1, the runaway oil well off the coast of Yucatan, will have produced the biggest oil spill in history  more than 68 million gallons, or enough to heat the homes of 60,000 Bostonians for a year.

title: Sri Lanka Bans Taking Lobsters
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, July 28 (AP) The Government has announced a ban on lobster catching in its coastal waters in an effort to conserve endangered species. The ban takes effect Sept. 1. A restriction against undersized lobsters has been on the books for some time but officials have found enforcement difficult.

title: If You Go
description: to the Lake District, which is 250 miles northwest of London, there is a modern highway, the M6, providing fast access from the south. However, a leisurely drive is mere fun, with stops perhaps in north Wales and Chester, a city built by the Romans and now celebrating its 1,900th anniversary.

title: GETTING IN TOUCH WITH GURDJIEFF
description: This littleknown mystic from the Caucasus was a prime mover of today's selfawareness movement. Now a Peter Brook film will introduce Americans to his search for the miraculous.

title: Europe Seeks Quick Slowdown Of U.S. Economic Engine
description: PARIS The dollar was in trouble again last week, possibly bad trouble, as financial markets caught a whiff politics coming out of the upheavals in Washington.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Yellow spots on needled evergreens could be spider mites; use kelthane Leaf miners make white tunnels in leaves of columbine, beets, spinach and Swiss chard. Hot weather has made late planted lettuce bolt and form seed stalks. Set mowers to cut lawns high, two inches or more

title: News Summary
description: Charan Singh was installed as India's new Prime Minister and head of a threeparty coalition Government. He said in a nationwide broadcast that he would continue to follow the policy of nonalignment which will not lean on any superpower. His 15member Cabinet was drawn from three political groups: his Janata Party, the Congress Party and the Socialist Party. The other major group supporting the coalition, the rival CongressI Party of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, was not represented. [Page 1, Col. 6.]

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: BUT NEVER JAM TODAY  A musical, loosely based on Limit Carroll's Alice in Wonderland, with a book by Vinnette carroll and Robert Larimer and lyrics by Mr. Larimer. Longacre, 220 W. 48th St. (2464639) Opens Tues.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE GLAMOUR of fish is a recent restaurant phenomenon. There have always been fish restaurants and clam and oyster bars, but these were rareties, and fish and other seafood have generally been relegated to the bottom third of menus in what were largely meatandpotatoes restaurants. But fish became expensive, and lobsters and crab meat became food for all of the people. And the Modern seafood restaurant  cornplete with nautical motifs and atmosphere  was created.

title: New Racevision System Puts an Eye in the Cockpit
description: Tom Spalding believes his Racevision system will do for the presentation of auto racing on television what the instant replay did for professional football.

title: Summertime: Getting Away From It All
description: Through the open window N ear the foot of my bed The twitter of a bird is name not contained In my citified vocabulary) Drifts into my sleep. As if it is a snoozealarm, I turn over for Another 15 minutes.

title: Homemade Dispute Left Up to Outsiders
description: AFTER keeping out of a dispute between Westport and Norwalk over a proposed park, the Grasso administration now finds itself in the awkward tiosition of having New York and New Jersey play the decisive role in settling the argument between the Connecticut neighbors.

title: Margaret Keady Fiance of Writer
description: Judge George Cregan Keady Jr. of the District Court of Springfield, Mass., and Mrs. Keady of Longmeadow and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Drake Keady, to Harold Vincent Zehner Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., son of Mrs, Zehner and the late Mr. Zehner.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: CHICAGO Almost every year and for close on a century, representatives of the Art Institute of Chicago have been beating the bushes for what seems to them the best and liveliest in current American art. Their findings have culminated in the American Exhibition, an anthology ciesigned to Keep the visitor to the Art Institute informed of trends in art as to which he might not otherwise have firsthand experience. Number 73 in the long series is now on view in Chicago (through Aug. 5) and it was the responsibility this year of James Speyer, curator of 20thcentury painting and sculpture, and his associate curator Anne Rorimer.

title: What's Doing in BORDEAUX
description: REVIVAL  In the last couple of years the French press has been speaking with respect of Bordeaux's deuxierne souffle, its second wind. Historically, this is probably its fourth or fifth wind, but never mind. Bordeaux is in the midst of a renaissance: an ambitious urban redevelopment coupled with a fullscale restoration of its old buildings and museums, which gives credence to the view that it is the most beautiful 18thcentury city in Europe, and therefore the world.

title: GARDENING
description: MUCH of the productiveness that characterizes American agriculture and horticulture was developed through the science of genetics, which originated when Gregor Mendel, a monk, discovered the basic laws of inheritance while hybridizing sweet peas.

title: New York Area Players Threats For 2 Bridge Titles at Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, NEV., July 28  Two major contract bridge titles were within the grasp of players from the New York metropolitan area at the. American Con tract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here today.reaching the Grand National Finals. They arrived in an aggressive slam contract because Stauber, as South, fell in love with his heart nine in the bidding. When his partner's oneclub opening attracted a oneheart overcall, Stauber bid three notrump because he was likely to receive a heart lead and the heart nine would serve as a third stopper.

title: The Desert Creeps Up on the Rang elands of the West
description: DENVER, July 28  Creeping desert afflicts the American West.

title: We're What We. Eat?
description: ONE of anthropology's inadvertent roles, at least in its popular forms, is to feed us scientific pictures of those others  savages, barbarians, primitives, preliterates; it doesn't seem to matter much what we call them  who attest to our cultural superiority or, in times of doubt, inferiority. Nineteenthcentury anthropology, with its concern for primitive sexual promiscuity, incest, infanticide and marriage by abduction, often reads like a contreroman to Victorian propriety. Twentiethcentury anthropology, with its emphasis on intensive field work, has tended to be more cautious, but the old generalizations, now in scientific disguise, have still taken hold from time to time. Early on, anthropologists traced all culture to ancient Egypt; Geoffrey Gorer traced the Russian temperament to the custom of swaddling; the new sociobiologists look to genes to explain man's aggression, imperialism and possessiveness.

title: PORTUGUESE FACING A RASH OF ELECTIONS
description: LISBON  The Portuguese have been plunged into what is likely to be a fatiguing 18 months of elections that may do little to provide badly needed stability and could further discredit their young democratic institutions.

title: The Region
description: To most visitors, New York City is Manhattan. And to residents of the other four boroughs who have heard about New York City's economic recovery and wondered when it would reach them, the visitor's mistaken impression may well seem correct.

title: Indian Activist Is Paroled
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., July 28 (AP) Russell Means, the Indian activist leader, was paroled yesterday from the South Dakota Penitentiary a year to the day after he began serving a fouryear sentence on a conviction involving a riot. Mr. Means was convicted of charges stemming from a 1974 clash between the police and American Indian Movement supporters at a Sioux Falls courthouse. He is expected to be released Tuesday.

title: Sports Today
description: Highlights of the German Grand Prix, at Hackenheim, Germany. The celebrity offroad races, taped at Los Angeles and the National A.A.U. indoor diving championships, taped at Austin, Tex., will also be included. (Television Channel 2, 4 P.M.)

title: Alexander McKown Weds Pamela H. Brigg
description: The marriage of Pamela Hughes Brigg, a doctoral candidate in economics at Columbia University, to Alexander Pendleton McKown, a Bankers Trust Company vice president, took place in Riverton, N.J., yesterday. The Rev. Alan K. Salmon performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: The Event of the Season
description: THE oysters came from New Orleans. The band came from New Orleans. Even some of the guests came from New Orleans. The party was in Westchester.

title: Births
