description: MEISELS Mr. & Mrs. Allen Melsels of New York, New York, announce the birth of their daughter Blair Lynn, on July Mrs. Melsels Is the former Peggy Silfen of Harrison New York.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The American Numismatic Association, largest coin club in the world, raises the curtain today on its 88th anniversary convention.

title: U.S. Urges Public Health Crusade
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)  The Government reported today that Americans, although generally healthier than ever, were killing themselves needlessly through smoking, drinking, poor diets and preventable accidents.

title: Accept a U.S. School Grant? Wethersfield Voters to Decide
description: VOTERS in Wethersfield will decide on Tuesday whether to accept or reject a Federal grant of $178,700 to aid handicapped pupils in three schools. Some officials anticipate a negative vote in the referendum because of apprehensions that the grant has strings attached.

title: A Wave of Shows
description: PORT WASHINGTON IT is a general rule of thumb that art activities in most places slow down to a languorous pace in summer, if they don't come to a complete standstill. Unaware, it seems, that such a rule exists, or should be observed, the Island hastens the pace at this time of year.

title: Local Energy Group Formed
description: LAST month, Daniel Flohr, a Westchester architect, won a nearly yearlong fight with the Village of Larchmont and was granted a permit to install a solar hotwater unit on a home there. Village officials had opposed the installation on esthetic grounds, citing an old local ordinance that prohibited unsightly appurtenances to dwellings.

title: Over 250 Comic Strips Are Alive and Read in Most Papers
description: When the editors of The Orlando (Fla.) SentinelStar needed to make way for a new comic strip, they chose to drop Fred Bassett, one about lovable hound.

title: Lettre  TO THE EDITOR
description: I read The Hidden Met and The Once and Future Met (by William H. Honan, July 1 and 8) with great interest. As a former New Yorker and frequent museum visitor, however, I have not been impressed with the access to the Met's permanent exhibits. I have had many disappointments while visiting the Met this past year. In particular, I have wanted to visit the Islamic wing. But, though a guard kept assuring me that that superb collection would be open tomorrow, it was closed for all of the three days I tried to visit it. As were most of the permanent collections of Egyptian, classical and Oriental art. (It was gratifying, however, to find that the fine collection of Impressionist art which my late father, Sam Lewisohn, had donated was still on view.)

title: Mailbox: U.S. Athletes Are Poor Losers
description: To the Sports Editor: Wojtek Fibak's forthright views (The New York Times, July 19) on Vitas Gerulaitis's behavior at Forest Hills serve to underscore his broader condemnation of American athletes poor sportsmanship.

title: Births BATANSKY
description: Arthur and Carole Stone Batansky joyfully announce the birth of Alexandra Lauren on July 15th, 1979.

title: U.S. Seeking Opinions On a Radio Frequency With Less Interference
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)  The Government is asking the public whether it should create a new personal radio service in the 900 megahertz band, which would interfere less with television and other home electronic equipment than the current citizens band.

title: ClosedDoor Hearing for Justices In California Is Recessed 10 Days
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 (AP)  A closeddoor hearing into alleged wrongdoing by Justices of the California Supreme Court was recessed yesterday until Aug. 6.

title: DINING OUT
description: NEW PRESTON DESPITE its handy location near New Milford, Washington and Litchfield, Lake Waramaug has managed through the years to keep a delightfully low profile.

title: Miss Schwartzman Will Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allen L. Schwartzman of Sands Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ann Schwartzman, to Walter August Malmquist 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Quentin A. Malmquist of Post Mills, Vt.

title: Added Gas Seems Unlikely
description: THE longawaited modifications in Federal gasoline allocations and pricing regulations announced recently by the Department of Energy are not likely to result in significantly more gas for Connecticut, according to state officials and oilindustry representatives.

title: The Other Eastern Shore, in Maryland
description: While the Maryland part of the Delmarva Peninsula is larger than the whole state of Delaware, Maryland's Eastern Shore is actually minuscule. To most tourists the Maryland Shore is that part facing the Atlantic Ocean, specifically the beach and brightlight attractions of Ocean City and the ruegeder but also popular Assateague State Park and National Seashore. (The Assateague Island park complex is split between Maryland and Virginia and is under three bureaucracies: Assateague State Park is run by the Maryland Park Service; the two National Seashore areas, one in each state, are run by the National Park Service, and the National Wildlife Refuge section, in Virginia, is run by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.)

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IT'S three Republicans to two Democrats on the letterhead of one of the state's newest law firms, the membership of which demonstiates that there are many paths, and thorns, in the thicket of politics.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF.
description: This story cannot be told often enough. Feelings about America seem faint and confused in these days of gas crisis, inflation and opaque leadership. But for many Europeans, anyway, America's great call to share in her riches at the turn of the centurystands as a gesture unequaled in our time.

title: Airlines and Passengers Have Discovered the Area's Third Major Airport
description: NEWARK  O.J. Simpson isn't the only traveler dashing through Newark International Airport these days. The modern terminal, backdrop for the football star's sprints in television rental car commercials, is gaining favor with airlines as a place to operate and with passengers as an alternative to crowded Kennedy and LaGuardia airports.

title: Capital Report
description: TRENTON THE State Civil Service Commission has voted down a proposal that new policemen be required to have college training. Some local officials had urged that the commission go so far as to require a college degree for new police officers.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I intended to write something trenchant today, but the trenchancy generator wasn't working. The only thing coming down from the mind was static. When commanded to emit something trenchant, it gave me only nonsense, such as a lion trenchant on a field of gules and a trenchant mensch with a penchant for wenching.

title: A Festival of Russian Ballet Scores
description: Russian ballet music will be very much in the air during August when the Bolshoi opens a fourweek engagement at the Stat6 Theater on Wednesay night. Virtually every major Russian composer of the past 100 years has made important contributions to they ballet repertory  far more than opera or symphony, the dance seems to have, inspired the Slavic muse to produce its very best, from Tchaikovsky to Schchedrin. As if to herald the Bolshoi's arrival, the record companies have prepared a Russian ballet festival on disk, and the results in most CAM prove to be eminently listenable.

title: Work on Henry Hudson Begins
description: RIVERDALE ONE day last spring residents of this Bronx community on the Westchester border awoke to find a highway construction crew painting large, fluorescent X's on trees to mark them for axing as a preliminary to an $11 million, twoyear reconstruction project on the Henry Hudson Parkway, used daily by 90,000 Commuters traveling between Westchester and Manhattan.

title: ANTIQUES
description: HOMEOWNERS today who want to get rid of furnishings theyno longer find useful hold tag sales. And those in charge of government buildings who must dispose of used office equipment sell it off at welladvertised public auctions.

title: At First Pennsylvania, a Resignation
description: John R. Bunting Jr. is not one to make a rash move. So his resignation as chief executive officer of the First Pennsylvania Corporation last Monday stirred up some rumors: Is the former golden boy of banking toying with the idea of a political venture? Did he really leave of his own accord or was he asked to go? If the latter, is something amiss at Philadelphia's largest bank?

title: Paperback Sales In First Decline Since the 1940's
description: The number of copies of massmarket paperback books sold in the first five months of 1979 declined 10 to 15 percent compared to the same months last year, according to an estimate by the chairman of the Association of American Publishers. He said that the downturn was the first since that sector of the book industry began flourishing after World War H.

title: Suspect Held in Campus Killings
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 28 (AP)  A 21yearold Goleta man has been arrested in connection with the slayings of three young women that terrorized the University of California campus in 1976 and 1977. Thor Nis Christiansen, a former service station employee, was booked for investigation of murder, Santa Barbara County Sheriff John Carpenter said. Mr. Christiansen was being held in the county jail on $500,000 bond.

title: Michael Evans/Gammalialson
description: Ronald Reagan is all smiles amid admiring Iowa women who call themselves Dutch's Dollies (after his college nickname, Dutch). Reagan toured the state in June toRun, will you please, so I got someone decent to vote for, implored a burly Chicago cop on duty at O'Hare International. He had been watching passengers board a plane when he spotted a handsome, blackhaired man with a tanned, deeply lined face, and felt he had to speak to him. A few minutes later, two aircraft mechanics, whose union is as loyal in its way to the Democrats as is the Chicago police force, offered Ronald Reagan the same kind of greetine.

title: THEATER
description: BRIDGEPORT 'THE SEVENTIES, at the Downtown Cabaret Theater, completes Claude McNeal's decade series. While I have said in the past that each person probably will select his favorite decade pastiche according to his own memories, must now proclaim that The Seventies represents Clau'e McNeal's best work.

title: Abortion Looms as Issue In Suffolk Executive Race
description: ABORTION a subject that cuts across religious, economic, social and political lines  appears to be shaping up as pivotal issue in this fall's race for Suffolk County Executive. In the last several years, no subject, not taxes or the Southwest Sewer District, has produced a more heated, emotional response in public debate in the Suffolk County Legislature.

title: A Sort of Passacaglia
description: IF one were to entertain a European visitor from the 19th century in contemporary New York City, the best way to make him feel at home would be to take him to a concert. In that familiar swine. he would probably not hear anything earlier than late Haydn or anything later than early Stravinsky. And if by some programmer's insistence any more recent works were heard, the surrounding audience would be as disoriented as its visitor from the past.

title: River Museum Unites Nature With History
description: SMITHTOWN WHEN the Nissequogue River Museum opens Saturday after more than a year of preparation, visitors will see a carefully researched portrait of a river that still bears the signs of man's impact on the North Shore environment.

title: Saltwater Flyfishing A Difficult Challenge
description: The fascinadon of what is difficult continues to attract new devotees to saltwater flyfishing.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Consumer product recalls have become fairly common in the United States. But when the American Pacemaker Corporation announced that 552 of its products might have defective transistors that could need replacement, the problem was unusually awkward: all 552 pacemakers had already been implanted in heart patients.

title: INNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Driving a coachandfour is an expensive pastime, and those who can afford it will be doing it Friday through Sunday, when the Fairfield County Hunt Club in Westport is host to the Eighth Annual Fairfield Driving Show. Vehicle entries must be antique  that is, pre1920  according to Harry B. Glass, an organizer of the show.

title: Associated Press
description: NO MAIL DELIVERY HERE: A woman in Marengo, Ind., using a walker steady herself as she made her way through floodwaters of the Blue River the southern part of the state. Heavy rains on Thursday caused the river overflow, leaving hundreds of area residents homeless.

title: Giving Roller Skaters the Boot
description: SOUTHAMPTON IF you're trying to save some gasoline, get a little exercise and have some fun by making the rounds of your favorite stores on Job's Lane on roller skates, be careful  it may soon be illegal.

title: A School Finds Fertile Ground In India Desert
description: PILANI, India  Out in the wilderness of the Rajasthan desert a school modeled after the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has blossomed into one of India's most important centers for teaching science and technoloev.

title: Gambling Control: Evening the Odds
description: TOMORROW the General AssemblY, in special session, will vote on whether to confirm Governor Grasso's five nominees to the new Gaming Policy Board.I believe that the Governor has chosen an excellent team of gaming regulatom, and I hope the Legislature will vote in favor of these five appointees.

title: The Uses Of Gender
description: CHANGING OF THE GODS

title: Elena Wilson, Editor of Letters Of Edmund Wilson, Her Husband
description: Elena Wilson, widow of the writer and critic Edmund Wilson and editor of a posthumous collection of his letters, died Friday at the couple's longtime home in Wellfleet on Cape Cod. She was 72 years old.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: MONTCLAIR is an old town, conveying more of the past than of the future. It seems an unlikely and improbable place to be a spaceage town.

title: Dr. George Harrison; Expert in Spectroscopy Was M.I.T. Professor
description: Dr. George Russell Harrison, retired dean of science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an expert on the use of optical spectroscopy used in studying the complexities of the atom, died Friday at Emerson Hospital in Concord, Mass. He was 81 years old.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: I read with great concern your article entitled A Step Toward Curbing Brutality in School Sports, by Parton Keese [Connecticut Weekly, July 8]. Brawls, dirty play, senseless injuries and general brutality have become commonplace. Could that be referring to interscholastic sports? State Senator Michael L. Morano was quoted as saying, after viewing a brawl at hockey game, That made me real mad. Simply, your article made me real mad.

title: Walter Sedgwick Planning to Marry Jeanne Campbell
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David A. Campbell of Plandome, L.I., of, the engagement of their daughter, Jeanne Warren Campbell, to Walter Cabot Sedgwick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellery Sedgwick Jr. of Cleveland.

title: Ann Cushing Shakeshaft Affianced to NU. Tobey
description: Ann Cushing Shakeshaft, art director of Mademoiselle magazine, and Michael James Tobey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Mercer Tobey of Wilsonville, Ore., will be married next September.

title: Wedding Planned By Rosemary Wolf
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Wolf of Huntington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosemary Wolf, to Edward F. Chase Jr., a group product manager with Johnson & Johnson, maker of surgical dressings and other medical supplies, in Milltown, N.J. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chase of Belmont, Mass.

title: A Cache of Norwalk's History
description: NORWALK ATREASURE trove of Norwalk history has come to light in the attic of an old home in Minneapolis. Books, letters, maps and charts, daguerreotypes and other early photographs, silverware and homespun clothes were found piled in old trunks and boxes when Mrs. Stephen Edwards Keeler, the owner of the house, died, in her eighties. There were no heirs.

title: STAMPS
description: On stamps, as in nature, flowers are in full bloom. Birds are in flight, parading their colors. Fish abound in the waters.

title: The Front Widens in Environmental War
description: BEFORE last March, the Safe Energy Alternatives Alliance was relatively unknown, and many of those who did know about it looked upon its members as a bunch of borderline fanatics.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Elm City Kennel Club allbreed and obedience, Airport, Route 63, Bethany, Conn.; 990dogs; 9A.M.

title: U.S. Court Orders Bilingual Programs for 2 Suffolk School Districts
description: A Federal judge has ordered a Suffolk County school district to adopt a bilingual SpanishEnglish program starting In September for eligible pupils. The ruling covers the PatchogueMedford District on Long Island.

title: Can Truck Stops Thrive in Cities?
description: Truck stops, ranging from a crude shack attached to a fuel pump all the way to modern multibuilding complexes, have traditionally interrupted the expanses of western plain and southern piedmont to provide food and frequently lodging for truckers and fuel for their rigs. Now a new development, the urban truck stop, is appearing in the $10 billionayear industry.

title: Experts Offer a Host of Reasons For Gas Crisis in New York Area
description: Government and oilcompany officials and motorists themselves  nearly three months after long lines started forming at gasoline stations in the New York area  have put forth a host of reasons and possible reasons for the fuel crisis and why it affected the New York area more severely than the rest of the country.

title: Beaths
description: DOLANJames Raymond, of Garden City on July 27, 1979, devoted husband of Mildred, loving lather of Patricia Nolan, James and John Dolan, dear brother of Catherine Trombly, also survived by 7 grandchildren. Retired General Sales Manager for C. H. Masland and Sons. Friends may call at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave of 12 St, Garden City, Sunday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Mass of the Resurrection, Monday, 10AM at St. Joseph's Church, Garden City. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Memorials to the Committee to Combat Huntingtons Disease and the Society of Jesus.

title: For Example, Should the Poor Be Allowed to Buy Junk Food?; As It Grows, Food Stamp Program Sprouts Debate
description: WASHINGTONBack in the sunshine days of the New Frontier, a modest program was started in eight communities to aid farmers who could not find markets for excess produce. The Government bought the food, then gave it to poor families.

title: ART
description: HARTFORD LIKE so many museums, the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford cannot afford to put all that owns on permanent display. So its patrons should find Visions of the  Sea: 15501971 a special treat, for it is an exceptional show, about half of works normally kept in storage.

title: Late TV Listings
description: Noon (Channel 2) Newsmakers: Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York.

title: Free S.I. Outdoor Concerts
description: A series of free outdoor musical concerts Is being presented outside Borough Hall in St. George, S.I., on Tuesday and Thursday afternoons. The alfresco programs, which run from noon to 1:30 P.M., catering to the lunchtime crowd, will continue through Aug. 30. Staten Island Borough Hall is at Stuyvesant and Hyatt Streets, across from the ferry terminal.

title: Carter's Choice For Energy Czar
description: WASHINGTON  Charles William Duncan Jr., nominated by President Carter to be the new Secretary of Energy, got his start in energy 32 years ago with the Humble Oil Company in Texas digging ditches for a pipeline.

title: SPORTS
description: IF you have a baseball player in your family, you might almost feel sorry for him. From the time he begins to walk  and maybe before  he has probably been nursed, rehearsed and conversed on the game. Father hits him fungoes, brother throws him fast balls, friends talk of batting averages and uncles take him to ballgames.

title: A Clash of Interests In the Pinelancls
description: FEW people would argue against the need for environmental conservation or against the need for decent, affordable housing for the state's growing population of retirees. But what happens when these needs clash?

title: 600 of Hiroshima Blast Survivors To Get 6 Days Off for Health Care
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, July 28 (AP) The state and city governments here will give six extra days off a year to 600 civil servants who are among survivors of the atomicbomb attack on Hiroshima, officials haVe announced.

title: MUSIC
description: HOW gorgeous it is at Lyndhurst just before dark: the rolling lawns and tall, shadowing trees dwarf the huge music tent, and in the distance, a view of the Tappan Zee Bridge spanning the Hudson adds to a landscape that is at once majestic and serene.

title: Miss Archbold Plans Nuptials
description: The engagement of Cassandra Kendrick Archbold to John Beckley Wright 2d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Cornell Archbold Jr. of West Chester, Pa., parents of the bridetobe. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Morton Wright of Rosemont, Pa.

title: A New Dean at Princeton
description: PRINCETON WHEN Theodore J. Ziolkowski, who on July 1 became the 10th dean of Princeton University's Graduate School, speaks of the small Alabama town in which he grew up, he is analytical.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: IN most cases when a Venetian blind starts to jam or otherwise becomes hard to raise and lower, the first thing you should suspect is a problem with the cord that raises and lowers the slats or the cord that tilts them. Sometimes one of the cords has become kinked or knotted and thus jammed in one of the pulleys over which it passes. Fixing this is simply a matter of removing the kink or knot (or sometimes removing an accumulation of lint froth the cord).

title: GARDENING
description: MUCH of the productiveness that characterizes American agriculture and horticulture was developed through the science of genetics, which originated when Gregor Mendel, monk, discovered the basic laws of inheritance while hybridizing sweet fleas.

title: Shorter, on Comeback, Wins 10,000 Meters
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 28 Frank Shorter is back, with the help of his former college coach.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: IN most cases when a Venetian blind starts to jam or otherwise becomes hard to raise and lower, the first thing you should suspect is a problem with the cord that raises and lowers the slats or the cord that tilts them. Sometimes one of the cords has become kinked or knotted and thus jammed in one of the pulleys over which it passes. Fixing this is simply a matter of removing the kink or knot (or sometimes removing an accumulation of lint from the cord).

title: Teletrack Downs, the Horseless Track
description: NEW HAVEN  From the outside, it looks a little like an oversized oilstorage tank. Inside, the layout suggests a balconied opera house.

title: Stewart M. Casper, Lawyer, to Marry Laura Markowitz
description: Laura Markowitz, manager of benefits and personnel research at R.H. Macy & Company in New York, and Stewart M. Casper, a lawyer with McAnerney & Miller in Darien, Conn., will be married next fall.

title: The Great Music Debate: Emotion Versus Intellect
description: Yin and Yang. Apollo and Dionysus. Classic and Romantic. The extremes have always been with us, often coexisting uneasily at the same time and snarling at each other.

title: Questions/Answers
description: Is there any way to renew my Boston fern? It is nearly 20 years old and has a brown center. Can I cut off the top to revive it? Mrs. E.W.B., Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Deaths
description: CAR DOZOConstance M., on July 27, 1979, in her 84th year, at home. Daughter of Constance and Beniamin Mordecai. Survived by her sister. Lucille Lebair, her daughter, Nancy Cardozo Cowles, her son, Danforth Cardozo, Jr., also her grandsons, Nicholas and an Egleson, Danforth III and John Patrick Cardozo, and four greatgrandchildren. Services private.

title: Bans on Canvassing Pit Right vs. Right
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK CAN towns and villages officially slam the door on all housetohouse canvasses? If they do so, are they protecting their own privacy at the expense of someone else's freedom of speech?

title: Summer Hours
description: We woke up in a pool of sweat the other morning. I..b.ss of confidence? Don't be impertinent. Busted air conditioner? No. The night hadn't been hot enough turp on the machine. The reason was that the sun had been up for some time. It was already past 7 and after that the day quickly grew warmer. It was 80 by the time most people got to work and of course by then they needed the air conditioning to dry their soaking clothes.

title: Deaths
description: EINGOLDAtice (nee Gottlieb), beloved wife of the late Meyer, devoted mother of George and daughterinlaw Rae, dear grandmother, survived by brothers and sisters. Services Sunday, 2:15PM, Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapels. Queens Blvd and 76 Road, Forest Hills.

title: We Just Ran Out Of Technology
description: IN some not so far distant time, grandmother sits in front of a but on a bluff overlooking Lung Island Sound. She is carving rude cuneiform on a large flat rock. She speaks to her tribe:

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Bill to improve and implement the trade agreements negotiated by the United States in the Tokyo Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations, passed, 90 to 4, July 23.

title: Major League Baseball Standings
description: Milwaukee 9, Yankees 2 (n.).

title: Wall St. Image Facing Change As Apartments Replace Offices
description: The conversion of older office buildings to apartments in the Lower Manhattan financial district  the city's traditional boardroom and backoffice bastion  is picking up pace even as the area's office space market has recovered sufficiently in the last year, according to some brokers and owners, to warrant the development of several new office towers in the near future.

title: He Had the Same Quality As the Game He Mastered: He Made Time Stand Still
description: IF historian's of the future ever unearth a time capsule containing the 1972 baseball results, specialists may have to be called in to interpret the evidence. The record will show that the 72 Mets finished 13 games behind in a lackluster National League East. Yet those same Mets that same year led both major leagues in both home and road attendance.

title: Ticket Deal for Mets
description: The New York Mets, in an attempt to draw more fans, have announced that a halfprice ticket deal for youngsters will be offered during August. All box and reserved seats for August games sold to youngsters 12 years old and younger will be sold at half price. Box se/its will cost the youngsters $3; reserved seats can be bought at $2.50.

title: Getting Designer Clothes Wholesale. Well, Almost.
description: Many of the best American and foreign clothing brands  bearing such names as Calvin Klein, Pierre Cardin and Geoffrey Beene  may have been signed with the wellheeled in mind, but theyre being snapped up these dhys by the masses. What's making that possible is a trend now sweeping retailing  price cutting on wellknown brands of men's, women's and children's clothing.

title: Raiders Win Fame Game, 2013
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 28 (UPI)David Humm's passes to Raymond Chester set up Oakland's first touchdown today, and Henry Williams, a cornerback, returned a blocked field goal 63 yards for a touchdown shortly before halftime to spark the Raiders to a 2013 victory over the Dallas Cowboys in the annual Hall of Fame game at Fawcett Stadium.

title: Leif G. Soderberg, Consultant, to Wed Julia Gross in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Argyle Gross of High Point, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julia Anne Gross of Boston, to Leif Gallup Soderberg of Cleveland, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Richard Soderberg Jr. of Minneapolis and Nantucket, Mass., formerly of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Missing Girl,12,Is Found Slain Near Her Home in Connecticut
description: BURLINGTON, Conn., July 28 (Ap)The body of a 12yearold girl who disappeared yesterday while riding her bicycle was found this morning in a wooded area less than a mile from her home, the state police said.

title: Photographs by Denis Piel
description: In recent years a bath has become far more than just a tub full of water. In contrast to an invigorating and timesaving shower, the bath is now viewed as a leisurely ritual of relaxation, soothing the psyche as it pampers the body. As a result, products to use during and after the bath have become big business, and that business truly is booming.

title: Saving Youth From Demon Rum  A Futile Exorcise?; A Pint Replaces a Joint
description: HARTFORD  A modified experiment in prohibition banning sales of liquor to young people taking hold across the nation, and legislatures in both Connecticut and New Jersey are pondering whether to join. Although this temperance parade led by respected child psychologists, school administrators, and public health officials, many of the experts seem to be marching in different directions.

title: Wine Cafes Are for the Words
description: COMMACK HAVING finished a wellcrafted version pf the Beatles Rocky Raccoon, Sky Livingston, a singerguitarist, looked down from the stage and scanned the crowd of young couples who were drinking, talking and playing board games at the Tiffany Wine & Cheese Cafe here. The blond, pleasantvoiced entertainer paused before beginning his next song and waited for applause.

title: Energy Is Still the Problem
description: Almost half of last month's troubling increase inflation is directly traceable to rising energy prices. The message, therefore, should be clear: the energy and inflation problems are inseparably bound. No one is going to solve the inflation problem without first solving the energy problem.

title: Robert vanDusen Weds Kamalah Mansury
description: Kamalah Mansury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Husain Mansury of Kabul, Afghanistan, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Bruce vanDusen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips Buick vanDusen of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Christopher R. Martinson, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the garden at the vanDusen home.

title: Ballet: Miss Garcia Fine
description: Alicia Alonso's oneact production of La Fille Mal Gardee is enchanting enough on its own, but it received a performance to cherish with Marta Garcia leading the National Ballet of Cuba at the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday. This was a highlight of the season, and probably many more seasons at that.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE FAR PAVILIONS, by M. M. Kaye. (Bantam, $2.95.) An English boy, orphaned in India during the Sepoy Mutiny of 1857, grows up as a Hindu in a )princely court, discovers his true origins and, as a sahib, gets in and out of countless adventures. A long, romantic novel, a bit tedious in the middle but in the end exciting and absorbing. To document her story, the author has just published THE FAR PAVILIONS PICTURE BOOK (Bantam /Peacock Press, $7.95), an album of illustrations, many of them photographs and Ilrawings from hendamily's collection. The pictures lAre interesting, but the layout is drab to look at and the text is confusing.

title: Headliners
description: It's not the size of the boat in the sea that counts, it's the size of the sea in the boat. Gerry Speiss kept the ocean on the outside of his 10foot sloop Yankee Girl for 54 days, starting at Virginia Beach, Va., and concluding at Falmouth on the Cornish coast of Britain.. When he was through, Mr. Speiss had sailed singlehanded across the Atlantic Ocean in the smallest boat (by two feet) ever to make the voyage. Of his boat, he said Yankee Girl is good enough to go around the world. But wouldn't want to be the bne to do it. It's too dangerous.

title: Can the Bolshoi Ballet Match Past Glories?
description: Moscow In the haunted backstage rooms of the Bolshoi Theater, in a handcarved, 19thcentury armchair, sits a slight, worn man in workmanlike slacks and openneck shirt, his aquiline face alight with the intensity of his discourse. Now and then, words seem inadequate, and he jumps from his chair to make his point with a dancer's gesture or stance.

title: GARDENING
description: MUCH of the productiveness that characterizes American agriculture and horticulture was developed through the science of genetics, which originated when Gregor Mendel, a monk, discovered the basic laws of inheritance while hybridizing sweet peas.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ONCE upon a time, in fact until 1976, the New York State Department of Commerce maintained a regional office in White Plains. It was the thirdbusiest district in the state, and the reason for its closing was never made clear, although it came after John S. Dyson was named Commissioner.

title: Hospital Is Evacuated In Willingboro, After Power Failures1
description: Rancocas Valley Hospital in Willingboro, N.J., was evacuated yesterday after power failures Friday night and yesterday morning that disrupted lighting and airconditioning, according to nursing supervisor.

title: After 4 Months, Three Mile Island Plant Isn't Cool Enough for a Cleanup
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa.,July 28  Four months after the worst accident in the history of this country's nuclear power program, the broken No. 2 reactor at Three Mile Island remains sealed within its radiation containment building, still a major problem and a mystery for the nation's best scientists and engineers.

title: Student of the Kabbalah
description: IT is impossible to popularize the work of Gershorn Scholem, the contemporary historian of the Kabbalah, that body of Jewish mystical doctrine formulated in the Middle Ages that was eventually accepted as an authoritative theology of Judaism. Scholem's achievement, to put It simply, has been to restore mysticism to.

title: Science and Religion Explore New Grounds for New Meetings
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  A World Council of Churches conference on science and religion drew to a close last week at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on a note that shows how much has changed since bishops debated Darwinists and theology fought empiricism over which system better grasped at Truth. By contrast, the sharpest debate here among the 350 participating scientists and theologians concerned the future of nuclear energy.

title: Miniature Castle Moved
description: The miniature castle shown in a photograph on page one last week is no longer at Great Adventure amusement park. It was removed, along with other miniature buildings, by the owner after Great Adventure's lease on the buildings expired.

title: Dear Mrs. Adams: About Your Grandson
description: Claudia Adams's article certainly struck home with me. I, too, have a Robbie, just like hers. However, my Robbie is nearly 19 and has been through a school career I wouldn't wish on my worst enemy.

title: PhotoSecessionists To Be in Whitney Show
description: An exhibition of 225 black and white photographs made by 40 American photographers early in this century will go on display at the Whitney Museum of American Art on Sept. 11.

title: South Africa Pays Full Settlement to Biko Family
description: CAPE TOWN, July 28  The South African Government has paid the equivalent of $76,700 to the family of Steven Biko in an outofcourt settlement of the family's $106,200 claim for the young black leader's death in detention nearly two years ago.

title: U.S. Envoy Goes Back to Nicaragua With Planeload of Aid Supplies
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 28  The American Ambassador, Lawrence A.  Pezzullo, returned to Nicaragua today for the first time since a revolutionary Government took power 10 days ago.

title: U.N., Usually Hostile to Israel, Now Even More So
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.  Israel's standing in the United Nations, never very high, has slipped further as traditional friends have joined longtime adversaries objecting to Israeli policies on West Bank settlements and its military attacks in Lebanon.

title: NOME CLINIC
description: IN most cases when a Venetian blind starts to jam or otherwise becomes hard to raise and lower, the first thing you should suspect is a problem with the cord that raises and lowers the slats or the cord that tilts them. Sometimes one'of the cords has become kinked or knotted and thus jammed in one of the pulleys over which it passes. Fixing this is simply matter of removing the kink or knot (or sometimes removing an accumulation of lint from the cord).

title: Nancy Ambler Becomes Bride Of Consultant
description: The marriage of Nancy Morison Ambler, daughter of Mrs. Harold Ambler of Norfolk, Va., and the late Mr. Ambler, to Steven McLeod Bedford of New York and Barrington, N.H., took place at Shelter Island, L.I., yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clay P. Bedford Jr. of Oakland and Newport Beach, Calif., and Portsmouth, N.H. The Rev. Peter D. MacLean performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Episcopa; Church.

title: California Suite Plays It Safe
description: MINEOLA SINCE Neil Simon appears to turn every corner of his life into a play, the result of his move to California in 1975 was a 1976 Broadway hit, California Suite.

title: Stoppard's Intellectual Cartwheels Now With Music
description: LONDON With the opening tomorrow night of Every Good Boy Deserves Favour at the Metropolitan Opera House New Yorkers will have an opportunity to see the political and musical side of that acrobatic English playwright Tom Stoppard. This play for actors and orchestra by Mr. Stoppard and Andre Previn, the conductor and composer, is about a Russian dissident who is confined in a hospital room with a madman who thinks he has a symphony orchestra at his disposal. Right now Londoners have a choice of four Stoppards. Night and Day, now starring Maggie Smith, who is scheduled to head the cast when the play comes to Broadway next season, is a current success on the West End. Mr. Stoppard's adaptation of Arthur Schnitzler's Undiscovered Country is a major production in the repertory of the National Theater. The author's political cartoon, Dirty Linen, is a longrunning comedy hit. A new play, Dogg's Hamlet, Cahoot's Macbeth, a combination of two short Stoppard works, has just opened to generally positive reviews, inaugurating the new British American Repertory Company (BARC), which plans to tour the package to America.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: PORT WASHINGTON THIS is the story of an old New York Met from Syosset and young man from Port Washington and how they met at Old Timers Day at Shea Stadium this summer.

title: James Bond's Car in a Convertible Model Arrives in the States
description: Prince Charles, King Hussein and the deposed Shah of Iran each drive one. And if you've got a little extra cash, you might want to invest in an Aston Martin, too.

title: Television This Week
description: 12:30 (4) MEET THE PRESS. Former Secretary of Transportation Brock Adams is the scheduled guest.

title: Byrd Says It's Too Soon To Count Out President
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)  Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Senate majority leader, said today that it was too soon to count President Carter out as the 1980 Democratic nominee, although he declined to endorse the President now.

title: Finishing Touches: Still Witty
description: PEMBERTON LIKE many basically sane people, Jean Kerr's characters often go a bit mad. They smoke or drink too much, bicker a lot, fret about the financial and moral price of divorce, feel the pangs of aging and suffer the involuntarily cruel, wisecracks of youth. ('You know, Mom, your neck looks fine from the front. But from the side it looks like sort of twisty.')

title: State Begins Task Of Merging Colleges
description: THE Board of Higher Education has taken the first steps toward consolidating the state's tangled network of 27 public colleges and branches. If the tenor of the first round was any iadication, the proposals will move slowly through the Legislature, with results that are any. thing but certain.

title: PENTAGON IS CALLED LAX ON ARMS SALES
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Defense Department's foreign military sales program is riddled with financial management problems and may have left the United States liable for billions of dollars worth of arms contracts canceled by Iran, according to a Government study.

title: No Matter Who's President, the Use and Abuse of the Chief of Staff Is Similar
description: WASHINGTON  The Carter people have never seemed particularly impressed by what happened before them in the White House, by the lessons of the past. Even so, Hamilton Jordan, when he was named chief of staff a few. days ago, must have had a feeling akin to being placed in charge of the Confederacy immediately after Gettysburg.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: The Mets are in Pittsburgh tomorrow and Tuesday night and return to Shea to meet the Philadelphia Phillies at 2 P.M. Wednesday afternoon and 8 Thursday night.

title: Catherine O'Neill Bride of Richard Reeves
description: Catherine E. O'Neill, editorial director of radio station KFWB in Los Angeles, and Richard Reeves, national editor of Esquire magazine and a nationally syndicated columnist, were married at the bride's home in Pacific Palisades, Calif., yesterday by Judge Diane Wayne of the Los Angeles Municipal Court.

title: Martha Burns Plans To Be Wed Dec. 1
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Lincoln Burns of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Perry Burns, to Michael John Marlette, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Newton Marlette of Buffalo.

title: SAFETY BOARD LISTS 60 DC10 INCIDENTS
description: In December 1976, a Venezuelan DC10 had a tire blowout while taking off from Madrid. Chunks of rubber ripped through hydraulic lines inside the wings, causing the loss of two of the three hydraulic systems that control the aircraft. Although facing certain disaster if the third system failed, the crew was compelled, because of the weather, to fly on to Lisbon to make an emergency landing.

title: A Legal Activist Takes on a National Role
description: THE lawyers at Koskoff, Koskoff and Beider in Bridgeport often find themselves representing clients other firms might avoid: discrimination cases against the Bridgeport Fire Department and Police Department, a factory worker accused of murdering her neighbor, a paraplegic in a medical malpractice suit against a prominent doctor  because they share Ted Koskoff's vision of issue oriented legal cases.

title: DINING OUT
description: PASCAL'S PASCAL in Quogue is a recent cloning of Robert Pascal's stylish and successful Bistro Pascal in Manhattan. brings attractive, expensive and wellprepared French food to the Hamptons and has become a magnet for the summer chic.

title: On the Way
description: T HE ROCKET TEAM follows something of the path of a guided missile. It gets off with a bang as it describes the surrender of Wernher von Braun and most of his *team to the Americans in 1945; it wobbles a bit as it does a nashback to the early days of rocketry in Germany, discussing the Verein filr Raumschiffahrt, or Society for Space Travel, which von Braun joined in 1929 at the age of 19 and which performed often erratic experiments at a site in Berlin knownas the Raketenflugplatz; and it concludes with something of a crash landing, out of fuel 50 pages before the end, where it discusses the American space effort, the outcome in no small measure of the doings at the Raketenflugplatz a half century before. In between, however  that is to say, for about 90 percent of the book's trajectory  it crackles right along, arcing smoothly into space and back. It is as good a way as any we are likely to be offered of putting man's first landing on the moon  which occurred 10 years ago this summer  into a somewhat larger context.

title: New YorkMiami Flight Diverted After Line Receives Bomb Threat
description: An Eastern Air Lines jet bound for Miami from Kennedy International Airport with 306 persons on board was diverted to Philadelphia yesterday because of a bomb threat.

title: Virginia Watermen Undergo Test For Evidence of Toxic Pesticide
description: NORFOLK, Va. July 28 (UPI) Watermen along the James River and their families are being tested to see if they have been contaminated by Kepone, a toxic pesticide that was flushed into the river for many years before its production was banned in 1975.

title: CALENDAR
description: Thursday through Saturday  26th annual show and sale at the Schoolhouse and Firehouse, Route 512, Pottersville. Admission is $1.75. Hours are 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. An attractive show in a country setting. 33 dealers, refreshments, lunch and dinner served. For information call (201)6279271.

title: Jazz: Dill Jones Presents Piano In Swing Style
description: When Dill Jones, the Welsh pianist, plays at such clubs as Eddie Condon's or Jimmy Ryan's, he usually shows off his talents as a stride pianist in the Fats Waller tradition. But in the Hors d'Oeuvrerie at Windows on the World on the 107th floor of 1 World Trade Center, where he is playing through next Saturday, Mr. Jones is emphasizing a different aspect of his jazz piano talents.

title: Homage Paid to South Fork Reflections
description: EAST HAMPTON ARTISTS have been attracted to East Hampton for more than a century, and many have paid homage to the region in their work. Two exhibitions currently at Guild Hall through Aug. 26 focus on some contemporary pilgrims and their expressions of that attraction.

title: To Understand Inflation: Exploring Money Supply
description: WASHINGTON  With the appointment of Paul A. Volcker, the soundmoney president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, to the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve Board, the nation's top monetary post, attention focused on the ailing dollar, which rallied simply on the news that an internationally respected conservative had gotten the job.

title: A Cruise to New England's Shoals
description: The Isles of Shoals are odd and fascinating piles of greencrowned treeless granite off the coast of Portsmouth, N.H. : nine small islands, nine miles out, some of them surrounded by additional exposed rocks, all of them accounting for only a few hundred acres. Capt. John Smith first recorded and described them in 1614: The remarkablest isles and mountains for landmarks are these, he wrote, a heape together, none neere them  a many of barren rocks. He named them for himself  Smith's Isles  on his map of New England.

title: Anne R. Brazeau, Artist, Fiance of George Orton
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Willoughby F. Brazeau of Garden City, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Anne Richardson Brazeau, to George Stuart Orton, son of Virginia Slate Orton of Burlington, Vt., and the late Dr. Foster Orton.

title: COST OF EDUCATING HANDICAPPED JUMPS
description: The cost of educating handicapped children is rising twice as fast as the cost of educating other children, according to the National School Boards Association, which has issued a report questioning the fiscal ability of school districts to support programs for the handicapped.

title: Lev, Kopelev, a Soviet Dissident Who Does NotWant to Emigrate, Speaks Out
description: MOSCOW, July 28  Many dissidents despise the oppression of the Soviet political system and wish to emigrate. Lev Z. Kopelev, one of the most respected and admired figures of the movement, fears more than anything else that his protest might force him to leave his homeland forever.

title: The Consumer Credit Spiral
description: Sometimes it seems that the consumer cant do anything right.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE CITY OBSERVED: NEW YORK, by Paul Goldberger. (Random House. Cloth, $15. Paper, $7.95.) A highly informative, entertaining, even passionate guide to the architecture of Manhattan.

title: Kurdish Rebels Are Said to Kill 20 Iranian Soldiers
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 28 (AP) Rebels in western kurdistan have killed 20 Government soldiers and wounded 30 in a battle for control of a road leading to the Iraqi border, reports from the area said today.

title: Machines Cutting Into Farmhand Jobs
description: KING CITY, Calif., July 26  The giant machine rumbled over the verdant Salinas Valley, huffing and puffing. There were 20 farmhands aboard the machine, and today they harvested 100 tons of tomatoes, an average of 5.5 tons for each worker.

title: The Matriarch of the. Maillot
description: TEL AVIV  They call her Lady Gottlieb, an incongruous title for a 60yearold Jewish immigrant from Hungary who speaks English and Hebrew with a Yiddish accent and is the epitome of the Jewish mama.

title: BornAgains on the Rise
description: CENTEREACH THE summer night was warm. Some of the people who live on Rustic Road in Centereach were on their patios, sipping cool drinks or tending to lawns that were beginning to turn brown. The strains of Amazing Grace and, soon, upbeat rhythms, handclapping and singing, pierced the early evening air.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, July 28 (UPI)  At least 26 jailed former officials of the Government of the late Emperor Haile Selassie have disappeared in prison in Ethiopia and may have been executed, Amnesty International said today.

title: Galimore, Black Gymnast, Bent On Attaining Major Objectives
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 28 The bubblegum card was a surprise Christmas present from the fiancee of his college roommate and was mounted handsomely on a wooden base. Each time Ron Galimore studies the card with the picture of his late father in a Chicago Bears uniform it brings back warm memories.

title: Theater Helps Youths on Life's Road
description: Ablue 7.nd yellow truck pulls up to a street corner, and within minutes children from the neighborhood have materialized and are scrambling over it. An hour later, the truck has become stage 20 feet square, and a Street Theater performance by a group of teenage players is about to begin. It will receive rave notices trom its audience and win then fold itself into the truck and be on its way to preparations for the next day.

title: Cosmos Switch Tactics
description: Franz Beckenbauer, Giorgio Chinaglia and Dennis Tueart, three of the Cosmos who most severely criticize their team, have insisted throughout the season that the club should play with a goalkeeper, four fullbacks, four midfielders and two forwards.

title: T'Oplcs Coming to Terms; Citizen?
description: Garry Davis wants to return to the bosom of American citizenship and an unthinking Government of the United States won't let him. Worse than maddening, this is mad.

title: EAST GERMANS MOW A MOOD OF MALAISE
description: EAST BERLIN, July 25  The streets of this city of a million are bustling with newish automobiles, the restaurants offer tasty dishes at tolerable prices and many empty blocks that had been rubblestrewn monuments to World War II bombing raids are giving birth to impressive modern buildings.

title: FOOD
description: WHEN locally grown corn begins to appear at farm stands in late July, there is ample cause to celebrate. Unlike the corn from Southern states available earlier in the year, the local corn is usually picked the same day it is to be sold. This freshness is crucial because in no other vegetable is the flavor as perishable as it is in fresh corn.

title: Walton: Working Things Out in San Diego
description: SAN DIEGO HIS hair is no longer swept back into a ponytail. It has been three weeks since he made an antinuclear talk in public, longer since he led a symphony orchestra of young people. It has been nearly a year since he was seen at the pyramids of Egypt on the road with the Grateful Dead. And it has been 15 months since he played a game of professional basketball or was voted the most valuable player in the business.

title: Betty J. Katen Will Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Katen of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their,. daughter, Betty Jeanne Katen, to William John Narveil, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. John Narveil of Atlanta.

title: CRIME
description: John Crosby's PARTY OF THE YEAR (Stein and Day, $9.95) is, among other things, a book that attests to the development of a writer. Mr. Crosby, the former radio and television critic, of The. New York Herald Tribune, started writing mysteries in 1975, and Party of the Year is his fourth. A man of sharp intelligence (as those who remember his critiques well know), Mr. Crosby from the beginning was determined to get something a little different into his books.

title: Cafe Menu Best Bets
description: STRICTLY informal. That describes the food as well as the mood the wine and cheese cafes that now dot the Island. From the Back Barn and Tiffinanny's in Valley Stream or Le Cafe in Port Washington clear to the new Village Vineyard in East Hampton, unpretentious, everyday wines are paired with a basic assortment of sturdy cheeses, neither of which require a taste for the esoteric.

title: SHOP TALK
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON ARELAXED atmosphere prevails along Main Street in Bridgehampton despite the traffic that winds its way through the village en route to the other Hamptons, and makes shopping pleasant here on a summer afternoon.

title: Inshore Waters Teem With Fish
description: A SURPRISINGLY large influx of weakfish as well as the arrival of all sizes of bluefish is producing some of the finest angling in recent years, in northern New Jersey inshore waters.

title: Dusseldorf -Recalling a Great Art Center
description: The latest facet of 19th century academicism to emerge from the mists of neglect is The Dusseldorf School of Painting, the subiect of an imoortant exhibition organized by the Dusseldorf Art Museum. Now on view at the Mathildenhohe in Darmstadt, West Germany (to September 8), it surveys art in Diisseldorf from the end of the 18th century to 1900, with special attention to the period 18301860, the years when the city's fame as an art center was at its height and wouldbe painters from as far away as Scandinavia, Russia and, most of all, the United States, flocked there to study. With canvases by Eastman Johnson, Albert Bierstadt and other Americans hung alongside the work of their German teachers, rootsminded American art buffs will find this show of more than ordinary interest, particularly if they look for clues to the origin of traits peculiar to these figures which history books like to label typically American.

title: ACCUSER OF SCOTTO ALSO NAMES OTHERS
description: Newly released Federal court documents have identified William Montella, the former general manager of Quin Marine Services in Brooklyn, as a key witness against several dockunion leaders accused of waterfront corruption.

title: Energy ChiefDesignate Hears of Public Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)  Consumer and environmental groups expressed their concerns today to Energy Secretarydesignate Charles. W. Duncan Jr. about the effect of President Carter's energy policies on the environment and the poor.

title: Nancy Neaher Becomes Bride
description: Dr. Nancy Christine Neaher, assistant professor of art history at Wayne State University, and Dr. James B. Maas, professor of psychology at Cornell University, were married in Detroit last evening. Rabbi Richard rHertz performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mr. Victor W. Klein.

title: Dibbs Is Beaten by Clerc In Louisville Quarterfinal
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 28 (UPI)Fifthseeded JoseLuis Clerc of Argentina defeated secondseeded Eddie Dibbs of Miami Beach, 64, 62, tonight in the quarterfinals of the $175,000 Louisville international tennis classic.

title: Two Sets of Bleak Lives
description: WO new writers have charted here, in entirely different ways, two sets of bleak lives. Gail Henley's bleakness arises from poverty; her heroine, a Polish Canadian, grows up on a wretched farm whose only crop is stones. Man, Robison's bleakness is a natural part of the modern sense or disengagement. Both women, surprisingly, can be very funny.

title: Why Nick Nolte Doesn't Wear Neckties
description: LOS ANGELES Nick Nolte, as he pulls the ringtab off a can of Coors, acknowledges that his physicality has helped him land jobs. Indeed, his muscular presence was a prime requisite for Mr. Nolte's careerlaunching part, that of the pugilistic blacksheep brother in the 1975 TV miniseries Rich Man, Poor Man. And though in the wake of that success he rejected a number of heman film roles, his three movies to date have not shown him in a particularly cerebral light: he has played an adventurous skindiver in The Deep, a Viet vet enmeshed in heroin smuggling in Who'll Stop the Rain and an aging pro football star in North Dallas Forty, which opens at some 800 theaters on Friday.

title: Willie Mays to Be Honored In Polo Grounds Outfield
description: Willie Mays will be honored on a 1950 A train during a run from midtown to the site of the old Polo Grounds on Thursday.

title: At This Summer Retreat, Name of the Game Is Dieting
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  The woman was blond, in her 50's, and large, very large, 274 pounds to be exact. Her name, she said, was Marsha of Miami, and she would go no further than that, other than to say she was a practical nurse.

title: Weighing the Yields on Treasury Issues
description: The United States Treasury this week is selling five issues of securities to borrow more than $13 billion to help pay the Federal Government's bills. Investors will have the chance to buy issues maturing from 90 days to 30 years at yields between 9 percent and 9 percent.

title: Inflation in Price of Necessities Makes the Poor Choose Debt or Hunker
description: As if to underline the findings of a Presidential advisory panel that inflation batters the poor, just after the Department of Labor reported on Thursday that the Consumer Price Index showed an Inflation rate of 13.2 percent over the first six months of this year, news came over the wires from San Antonio that 91yearold Mottle Schultz had been jailed overnight for allegedly stealing $15.04 worth of food from a supermarket.

title: Commodities
description: THE emergence of the computer as a prime trading tool in the futures market has generally been a boon to commodity brokers and still another problem for the small trader, who is usually guided by fundamental supplydemand factors or price, volume and other data recorded on charts.

title: Wildlife Group Set Up to Monitor Importation of Endangered Species
description: In an effort to stem the sharply rising numbers of endangered animal and plant species that are imported into the United States, the World Wildlife FundU.S. has established a new organization to monitor and analyze the extent of international wildlife trade in this country.

title: Dance: Paul Taylor's New Profiles
description: CHOREOGRAPHY is like a gigantic threedimensional crossword puzzle, Paul Taylor remarked on public television Saturday night, and then went on to prove why he is one of the great problem solvers in the business.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alcan Aluminum Ltd. has elected to its board of directors Lionel P. Kent of Montreal, former financial adviser to the government of British Columbia.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Many Americans believe rationing would be the fairest way to allocate scarce gasoline. In reality, all nonmarket rationing systems are inherently unfair. They require personal judgments by administrators about who should get what amount, or what uses most deserve top priority. But there is no practical basis for such judgments acceptable to most people.

title: Cosmos Win by 50 As Tueart Scores 3
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 29 Had it not drizzled from time to time, the Cosmos would have had a perfect picnic at. Giants Stadium tonight against the San Jose Earthquake.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Key Treasury Refunding
description: The Treasury's threepart refunding this week holds the key to the nearterm outlook for the credit markets, bond traders and institutional investors believe.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: I have long wondered about the two small circles, near the base lines, on either side of home plate. I am not referring to the two larger, ondeck circles, which are on either side of home plate but farther away from it. What are those mysterious circles?

title: Deaths
description: POLATILLEsther C. (pen name Ellen C. Philthe), 71, on July 20, after a protracted illness. Mrs. Polatin Was an author and mental health educator. She Is survived by her husband, Phillip Polatin, M.D., of Riverdale, her son, Peter Potence M.D., of Los Angeles, and her grandson, Christopher. There will be a private service.

title: SANDINISTS TO DRAFT NEW POPULAR ARMY
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July. 29  The Sandinist guerrillas have embarked on the creation of a large popular army to consolidate their dominant place in the Nicaraguan revolution and assure a major leadership role for their bestknown commander, Tomas Barge Martinez.

title: CREDIT MARKETS. Will the Volcker Rally Last?
description: Heartened by President Carter's nomination of Paul A. Volcker to become chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the credit markets rallied late last week as investors and traders cast a widespread vote of approval.

title: Jane Goldman Wed To Dr. B. H. Lewis
description: Jane Goldman, daUghter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Goldman of Mill Neck, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Benjamin H. Lewis, son of Florence Lewis of San.Francisco and the late Arnold Lewis. Rabbi Ronald Sobel of Temple EmanuEI performed the ceremony at the Goldman home.

title: Notes From Training Camp Jets Spend a Tranquil Sunday
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 29  It's Sunday on the Hofstra campus, and the summer quiet is broken only by a transient student or a Jet football player walking idly along a path.

title: Deaths
description: STEEFELRobert D. The Board and Staff of the Associated YMYWHA1 of Greater New York record with profound sorrow the passing of Robert D. Steefel, beloved husband of our esteemed officer and Trustee. Margaret Steefel. attorney and an outstanding PhIlanttropic leader In the field of health and hosc4tal care. He helped to establish a imbue cooperative and enduring relationship between our MoshuittMontefiore Community Center and the Monte. fiore Hospital end Medical Center. We shall miss his sympathetic understanding and penetrating Interlicence. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Margaret, to his children, Caren and Ted, and to the grandchildren.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Thunderstorms clouds blanket portions of the Middle Atlantic States and the Tennessee Valley. Clouds also cover the upperMississippi and Missouri Valleys, the Northern and Central Plains States, the Intermountain Region and parts of the Rockies.

title: Hospital Doctors Decry Budget Cuts
description: A group of doctors at Metropolitan Hospital  one of four municipal hospitals chosen by the Koch administration for closing  charged yesterday that budget cuts had reduced its staff, equipment and supplies, risking the lives of the people of East Harlem on a daily basis.

title: 6 in Family Killed in Shooting
description: BAY CITY, Mich., July 29 (UPI) A man recently: separated from his wife forced his way into the family home today; fatally shot her and their fthir sleeping children, then shot Iiimself.,to deatn. ine state police said that Thernas Benware, 33 years old, and ene of the children died at a hospital shortly after the shooting in Fraser. Township, 14 miles from Bay City. Killed were Mr. Benware's Wife, Diane, 28; his sons Jeffery, 9, Weldon, 8, and. Jason, 4, and a daughter, Elethea, 3.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON PAUL A. Volcker, the chairmandesignate of the Federal Reserve Board, will be moving into the hot seat as the nation's chief money manager, but he is used to dealing with highpressure situations.

title: Raiders Appear in Good Shape
description: The Oakland Raiders are not ready to fall apart this season, as those who scorn pro football's outlaw team have gleefully predicted. It would be presumptuous indeed to start counting out Al Davis, the wily chief executive of the club, who sees some silver lining in the clouds hanging over the Raiders.

title: De Gustibus
description: While recently engaged in research for an article on nosalt cookery, I was invited to dinner by a good friend and neighbor, Shana Alexander, the author and television personality. She served cold soup, subtly flavored and excellent, and created almost wholly, she confessed, without salt. There was a good deal of guessing as to the ingredients of the soup, only some of which were obvious. There were shrimp and dill and cucumber, that much was plain. But as to the base of the soup, several people guessed, incorrectly, that was yogurt. There was another flavor slightly pungent that defied general analysis.

title: Inflation in Price of Necessities Makes the Poor Choose Debt or Hunker
description: As if to underline the findings of a Presidential advisory panel that inflation batters the poor, just after the Department of Labor reported on Thursday that the Consumer Price Index showed an Inflation rate of 13.2 percent over the first six months of this year, news came over the wires from San Antonio that 91yearold Mottle Schultz had been jailed overnight for allegedly stealing $15.04 worth of food from a supermarket.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Im Friihling, from Morike Lieder, Wolf; Concerto in C for 4 Violins, Telemann; Etude Tableau in C minor, Rachmanineff ; Concerto a Quattro No. 2, Galuppi; Firebird, excerpt, Stravinsky.

title: Jerome V O'Grady, 69, Chief of Track Security
description: Jerome V. (Jerry) O'Grady, president of Pinkerton's New York Racing Security Services Inc., which supervises security at three race tracks, died Saturday at the Lone'sland JewishHillside Medical Center. Mr. O'Grady, who lived in Garden City, L. I., was 69 years old.

title: united Press International
description: PALESTINIAN GUERRILLA BURIED OUTSIDE DAMASCUS: Mourners at the funeral of Zuheir Mohsen helped his wife, Ali, to a car after ceremony. Mr. Mohsen was shot in the head Wednesday by two assassins outside apartment in the French resort of Cannes and died Thursday without regaining consciousness. Among those attending the funeral were President Hafez alAssad, wearing glasses at left, of Syria, Yasir Arafat, next to Mr. Assad, leader of the Palestinian Liberation Organization, and George Habash, beside Mr. Arafat, chief of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

title: Engineers Detect A New Problem In Subway Cars
description: A new problem with 754 subway cars purchased by the city from the Pullman Standard Company has been discovered by Transit Authority engineers, according to City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: The Angels Guardian
description: ALL baseball statistics are relative. One is dependent on another. But one of the purest statistics is runs batted in. Runs win games. Games win pennants. And for the first time in their history, the California Angels might win a pennant. Or at least qualify for the pennant playoff by finishing first in the American League West. If they do, all those fans who did not vote for Don Baylor the AllStar Game balloting will be embarrassed because the Angels cleanup hitter, already approaching 100 runs batted in as August approaches, is the early favorite for the American League's Most Valuable Player Award. If the season ended this week, no question he would deserve it, says E.J. (Buzzie) Bavasi, the Angels executive vice president. If you go by the theory that your most valuable player is the one guy you can least afford to be without, he is the man.

title: Westbury Wins Polo
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., July 29  Peter Rizzo scored five times, including four firsthalf goals, to lead the Westbury, polo team to an 85 victory over Bethpage at Bethpage State Park today. Michael Braunstein provided the other three goals for the victors, while Ted Shapiro and Harvey Rhein led tithe Bethpage attack with two each.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FREE AS A BREEZE For variety, New York park entertainments probably have it over any other great metropolis. Take the new group of diversions scheduled into midweek at various openair spaces throughout the city, geared for the seasonal enjoyment of neighborhood residents and workers.

title: Police Across U.S. Recheck Files As Suspect Says He Murdered 20
description: Authorities from California to Maine are checking their records of unsolved murders following statements made by 50yearold confessed killer and parolee who has implicated himself in 20 murders, authorities in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., said. He is being held in Dutchess County in connection with the stabbing death of a 78yearold woman last week.

title: 2 FederalHelp Proposals Pass Their Early Hurdles
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Two key measures sought by New York City passed some early Congressional hurdles in the last couple of weeks, heartening their supporters. The measures Metropolitan Congressional Notes for welfare reform and socalled targeted fiscal assistance would channel muchneeded funds into the metropolitan region. But the most formidable obstacles to their passage remain.

title: Chess:
description: AMSTERDAM, July 26  Grandmaster Gyula Sax of Hungary held first place in the I.B.M. International Tournament after defeating Hans Ree, Dutch international master, in the 11th round.

title: G.M. May Lower Its Sales Forecast
description: DETROIT, July 29  The General Motors Corporation, which last Friday announced the indefinite layoff of 12,600 plant workers, is expected to announce this week a lowering of its industry sales forecast for the year.

title: A Goldin Audit Finds Schools Overcharged In Emergency Repairs
description: A report released yesterday by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin asserted that because of inadequate administrative procedures the city's Board of Education had failed to detect systematic overcharges and windfall profits by contractors doing emergency school repairs.

title: News Summary
description: Israel and Egypt were invited by Washington to send representatives to discuss the American proposal for an expanded United Nations Truce Supervision Organization force in Sinai, which is strongly opposed by Israel. Israel will send Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan, who has been a severe critic of the proposal. Egypt has endorsed the proposal to use an expanded Truce Supervision force to oversee Israeli troop withdrawals from Sinai, and was expected to send either its Prime Minister or Minister of State for Foreign Affairs. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: Deaths
description: BERGANBenlamin (Bert), sudden. ly in North Miami Beach, Fla. on July 26, beloved husband of Frances. Honorary past President of Howard Friends League and past President of NonParell S&A Club. Services at Boulevard Park West', 1901 Flatbush Ave at Ave L, Brooklyn on Tuesday, July 31 at 11:30AM.

title: Darden Takes 400 At Festival in 45.02
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 29 Even in high school, Tony Darden had the natural ability to run with the world's best quartermilers. Now, it appears that he has found the mental discipline to stay at the too.

title: Lloyd's Insurers Stumble Over Computer Leasing
description: LONDON, July 29  According to an old maxim of the insurance business, there is no such thing as a bad risk, only a bad premium rate.

title: Improved Gas Supply Lets Motorists Choose LowerPriced Stations
description: In dramatic contrast to the last weekend of June and despite widespread concern, there were no lines for the most part at the large numbers of gas stations that were open in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the last weekend of July.

title: Express Mail Service Is Widened; 2 More Stations in City Handle
description: Two more post offices have been added to New York's Express Mail delivery system, which guarantees nextday delivery of packages within the metropolitan area.

title: New Works By Beth Soil
description: THE Dance Theater Workshop opened its second annual OutofTowners series last weekend with a selection of solos choreographed and performed by Beth Soil, a modern dancer from Boston The program, seen Saturday at the American Theater Laboratory, was provocative in a lowkeyed way.

title: Game Halted] By Rain in 7th; Zachry Is Lost
description: The Mets had a victory and a loss yesterday at Shea Stadium. They had to wait out a 70minute rain delay before the umpires awarded them a 40 triumph over the Chicago Cubs at Shea Stadium. Their loss was Pat Zachry, for the season.

title: Market Place
description: AQUICK look through the Bally Park Place prospectus discussing its forthcoming offering of common shares suggests that the company has far to go before its plans for a major casino in Atlantic City are completed.

title: Israel TV Chief's Ouster Starts Debate on Political Control
description: TEL AVIV, July 29  The Israeli Broadcasting Authority tightened its control over the stateowned television last week by votingagainst renewal of the director's contract.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Though it is officially called the Columbus Clippers, New York Yankee executives know it as their Columbus Pipeline. Because of the Yanks many injuries, no fewer than five players have spent some of the 1979 season shuttling back and forth between the Stadium and Columbus, Ohio, home of the Yanks tripleA team, in the International League.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: GAME, SET, AND MATCH. The Tennis Boom of the 1960's and 70's. by Herbert Warren Wind. 229 pages. Dutton. $12.95.

title: 4 KILLED BY BOMBS AT MADRID AIRPORT AND RAIL TERMINALS
description: MADRID, July 29  Powerful synchronized explosions ripped through the domestic arrivals terminal of Madrid's airport and two crowded railway stations today, killing lour people and wounding at least 113. Fifty of the wounded were reported to be in serious condition.

title: Perkins's Tough Road to Success
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. THE new coach is looking. Joe Pisarcik feels the eyes, as if they were piercing through the back of his helmet, as he stands in the huddle calling a 67ZCurl moments later Pisarcik, the Giant quarterback, starts describing what it is to be stared at by I Ray Perkins. Then he stops.

title: Staub's First Hits Help Expos Regain Top Spot From Pirates, 53
description: Rusty Staub is back in Montreal and maybe just in time. Staub got his first hits yesterday since being reacquired by Montreal, and he helped the struggling Expos regain first place in the National League East by defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates. 53. at Montreal.

title: Sailing Couple Return With New Crew Member  From Trip Around the World
description: After two years at sea and many ports of call, Robert Morse, 36, and his wife, Mimi, 32, sailed their sloop, Syzygy, into Westport, Conn., late Friday to embrace waiting relatives in the harbor. They were welcomed home with flags and balloons by a fleet of sailboats and power cruisers. Mrs. Morse gave birth to a son, Richard, last July. The couple went through anxious days on way to hospital in Australia when engine gave out on, their 32foot craft.

title: The City
description: City department stores will now be able to use photographs of merchandise confiscated from alleged shoplifters in court and be able to return the stock immediately to their store shelves, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said.ately to the selling floor. Previously, the merchandise had to be stored as evidence, Mr. Morgenthau said.

title: Outdoors Surf Fishing: The Nighttime Provides an Edge
description: SURF fishermen who cherish the evening cocktail hour or who feel they must eat every supper with family or friends should turn to tennis. With striped bass  and, to a lesser degree, bluefish  the very best time to be abroad is at sundown and thereafter.

title: American Visitors Seek Roots in Lithuania
description: VILNIUS, U.S.S.R.  Genevieve Pladis and her sister Helen flew here from New Jersey this summer to see an aunt they had never known, the sister of their mother, who left Lithuania 64 years ago.

title: Boy, 1, Falls 5 Floors to Death
description: A 1yearold boy died yesterday shortly after he fell from a fifthstory apartment window in Manhattan, the police said. They said the boy, Darryl Harrison of 109 West 112th Street, had been left alone for a few minutes while his 16yearold uncle, Gervase Walker, who was babysiting, checked on a child in another room.

title: EXSENATE AIDE SAID TO ADMIT A FELONY
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)  Daniel Minchew, the chief witness against Senator Herman E. Talmadge at the Senate inquiry into Mr. Talmadge's finances, has agreed to plead guilty to a single felony charge as part of a pleabargaining settlement.

title: Fight Erupts. As Brewers Sweep Series
description: MILWAUKEE, July 29  The New York Yankees got into another benchclearing melee and again lost to the Milwaukee Brewers today. This time the score was 53 and it was the third straight defeat here for the Yankees ney finished their season's work with the Brewers having lost nine of 13 games.

title: New York Living Costs Among Highest in U.S.
description: The cost of living for a family of four the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area was among the highest in the country last fall, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported over the weekend.

title: Columnist Weds Joan Misciagna
description: The marriage of Joan Misciagna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Misciagna of Elmhurst, Queens, to Peter F. Vecsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Necsey. of Hollis, Queens, took place yesterday. The Rev. David Johnson Rowe peiformed the ceremony at the Church in the Gardens, Congregational, in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Pop: Squeeze Plays a Gig At Club 57
description: That this is really a driving, danceable poprock band that partakes of newwave energy but avoids its more scruffy ideals. Squeeze would clearly like to make it big, commercially, and there seems to be no reason why it shouldn't.

title: Moor and Alexander Gain Final in Tennis
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 29 (UPI)Terry Moor of Memphis scored his third upset of the tournament, defeating fifthseeded JoseLuis Clerc of Argentina, 76, 60, tonight in the semifinals of the $175,000 Louisville International Tennis Classic.

title: Soviet Seeks to Spur Its Economy
description: MOSCOW, July 29 (Reuters)  The Soviet Government, worried about some of the worst production figures in 30 years, has called on industry leaders to stimulate the country's sluggish economy. A 9,000word decree urged better planning techniques and incentive programs to improve efficiency and output.
