title: Certificate Rate Ceiling
description: The Treasury announced over the weekend that commercial banks can pay a maximum of 7.70 percent and savings banks may pay 7.95 percent on certificates of deposit maturing in more that four years that are issued in August. The ceiling rates are adjusted monthly according to a formula based on the Treasury's estimate of the rate if would have to pay on fouryear notes The Treasury's estimate last week was 8.95 percent. Commercial banks may pay a rate 1 percentage points below that figure, and savings institutions may pay a rate one point lower.

title: Hopi Spirits Dance Again on the Mesa
description: SHUNGOPOVI, Ariz., July 29 The Kachinas danced here all. day yesterday before making their annual trip home to the sacred San Francisco Peakg to the southwest. The Kachinas are Hopi spirits of fertility; harmony and goodness; they are represented by dancersSin,fantastic costume who give presents to the Hopi children before they descend the cliff at sunset, not to return until next January

title: Jones Drives Williams to German Grand Prix Victory
description: HOCKENHEIM, West Germany, July 29 (AP)  Alan Jones of Australia roared ahead at the opening flag today and captured the 41st German Grand Prix, giving his SaudiWilliams team its second consecutive Formula I victoryThe 32yearold Australian completed 45 laps around the 4.2mile track in 1 hour 24 minutes 48,83 seconds, finishing 2.90 seconds ahead of Clay Regazzoni of Switzerland, his teammate and winner of the British Grand Prix two weeks ago.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: DOHERTYRose, reposing at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broad. way at West 232 Street, Bronx, until 9:30am TuesdaY.

title: ISRAEL AND EGYPT INVITED BY THE U.S. TO NEW SINAI TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Ally 29  The United States attempted today to ease a bitter dispute with Israel over an international peace force in Sinai by inviting Israel and Egypt to send representatives to Washington this week to discuss the matter.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. (RadioWMCA, WGBB, 7:30 P.M.)

title: U.S. Wins All 3 Moscow Relays
description: MOSCOW, July 29 (AP)  The United States men swept all three relay gold medals in the closing day of the Spartakiad track and field competition today, increasing the American team's total to seven.

title: Opera: Sante Fe Troupe Offers Complete Lulu
description: SANTAFE, N.M., July 29The complete Lulu by Alban Berg has now come to the United States. Last night, the operas with its thirdact reconstruction by Friedrich Cerha, was staged by the Santa Fe Opera.

title: Must It Be a 74 Recession Again?
description: As we enter the first Carter recession, it is well to bear in mind some disturbing parallels with the NixonFord recession of 197475.

title: Scandal Still. Unresolved For German ExBanker
description: MUNSTER, West Germany  Ludwig Poullain took 10 years to create and build up the 13thlargest bank in the world. Then, after a suggestion of scandal, he took about one minute to decide to retire.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 29  Paul Hoffmann's 58foot sloop, Thunderhead, sailing out of the. Larchmont Yacht Club, was the first boat to finish today in the third annual Around Long Island Regatta.

title: Bridge:
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 29  One major title eluded New York players here last night at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, but they had a share in another.

title: Kong's Views Still Unorinted
description: THEY had come to cheer for the Mets, but they were waiting for Kong yesterday at Shea Stadium. They waited with the kind of anticipation stirred by a rampaging river, an approaching hurricane or an awakening volcano. Would Kong, also known as Dave Kingman of the Chicago Cubs, erupt again with another home run? Would he hit two, as he did against the Mets last Friday? Or three, as he did on Saturday when he was tied briefly with Mike Schmidt of the Philadelphia Phillies for the majorleague leadership at 35? Would he hit one clear out of the ball park? As it turned out, Kingman didn't, but Schmidt did and regained the leadership at 36.

title: Relief for MiddleIncome Renters Debated Bitterly by U.S. Experts
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Despite widespread reports that middleincome people seeking apartments to rent in major cities face extreme shortages, housing experts are at odds over whether the squeeze is likely to last long enough to warrant a big national effort to promote the construction of rental housing.

title: Advertising
description: IN the future of the Litton Publishing Group, a subsidiary of Litton Industries, is a rare foray into consumer magazine publishing. And it will be a magazine about the future, the near future, and it will be called Next.

title: Midtown Construction: Problem of Prosperity
description: Three years ago the biggest problem facing plannerS in midtown Manhattan was counteracting the fear that Manhattan would become, for corporations and the rich, what the South Bronx had become for the poor  a place from which to seek escape. It was inconceivable that short time ago that Manhattan could one day face an opposite crisis  the problem of too much prosperity but that is what has happened.

title: Accessories in Paris: That OldTime Glamour
description: PARIS, July 26  Where imagination goes haywire, among other places, is in accessories. No Paris couture designer worth his needle expects a woman to go bareheaded at night next fall.

title: But on the Road, the Tourist Places Are Hurting
description: YONKERS  We're getting a lot more neighborhood people, Yonkers folks  a lot of them  people who ordinarily might have been somewhere else, said Eddie Ward, manager of the Howard Johnson's restaurant on Central Avenue along the New York State Thruway. But, he said, they have not been enough on a normal summer weekend, the Howard Johnson's might feed 3,000 people, most of them New Yorkers streaming to and from the country. But this has not been a normal summer, and patronage has been significantly off, Mr. Ward saidan estimated 20 percent or more.

title: Graham Triumphs
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (UPI)Lou Graham came from nowhere to tie the course record with a sevenunderpar 64 today, then sank a threefoot putt on the first playoff hole to defeat Bobby Wadkins and win the $250,000 Philadelphia Golf Classic.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Robert H. Knight, who last week was named chairman of a search committee to find a new president for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, acknowledges that his duty is rather like conducting secret talks in an amphitheater.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY  New York State's Energy Office is offering free work. books to help homeowners, small businesseiand apartmentbuilding managI ers saw fuel this winter.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: New Yale Drama Head Affirms Professionalism
description: Lloyd Richards, who succeeded Robert Brustein as dean of the Yale Drama School and director of the Yale. Repertory Theater, denies his appointment was intended as a move to deprofessionalize the drama program and to open it to all students, as published reports have suggested. Mr. Richards, in an interview, emphasized that that was certainly not the impression left with hid] when he spoke with Yale's new president, A. Bartlett Giamatti, about the post.

title: HighFashion Hoedown Benefits Museum
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 29 Some day, historians from outer space will be studying the social mores of a planet named earth, and they will get to a little community named Southampton and shake their helmets and waggle their antennas in bewilderment. Could it have been possible that masses of people, most of whom migrated at great expense from a crowded, noisy, and hot place called Manhattan, would voluntarily leave their pools and lawns and fresh air for crowded, noisy and hot tents?

title: Iraq's New Chief Purging Leaders In an Effort to Bolster His Position
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29  Iraq's new President, Saddam Hussein, has begun a major purge, accusing some officials of conspiring against the Government with the support of outsiders. Arab press reports said today that between 56 and 250 Iraqis had been arrested and that a number of those had already been executed.

title: Brig. Gen.Robert Denig, Former Marine Publicist
description: Mg. Gen. Robert L. Denig, a former director of public relations for the Marine Corps, died Wednesday at the Bev&ly Manor Convalescent Home in Los Altos, Calif. He was 94 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: GUGLIELMO MARCONI (Italian Line Cruises International). Lett St. Maarten July 27; due at 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Students Are Critical ofJobTraining School in Manhattan
description: Ollie Leonard was 25 year's old, out of work, out of school and out on the streets of Brooklyn when he found what he thought was a way of getting started again.

title: TV: Serpent Fruits Takes Look at Pollution
description: THE best scenes in any of the numerous documentaries about the chemical poisoning of land, sea, water and life forms are always the ones in which the spokesmen for this or that corporation or industry group face the camera and start explaining why a great many formerly robust men who used to work in this or that factory now weigh about 70 pounds, why an unusually large number of women living in a certain area began suffering miscarriages or why all the fish in the river suddenly died.

title: Associated Press
description: TOWER FIRE IN KENYA: Two people died and 14 were rescued by helicopter yesterday when the upper floors of the 17story International House office tower in downtown Nairobi caught fire.

title: Foreign Investments Up in U.S.
description: A total of 104 foreign investments in United States manufacturing facilities were announced in the second quarter of 1979, the Conference Board reported yesterday. It was the highest quarterly total in the 10year history of the board's survey of such investments; the previous high was 101 investments recorded in the second quarter of 1978.

title: Soviet Expected to Import Oil Soon
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The Central Intelligence Agency is again predicting that the Soviet Union will soon be forced to stop exporting oil and start importing it, thus opening up possibilities of serious international economic and strategic disruntions.

title: Leader of Opposition Warns Singh To Shun Quick Decisions on Policy
description: NEW DELHI, July 29 Jagjivan Ram, leader of the opposition Janata Party, warned the new Government headed by Prime Minister Charan Singh today against making any policy decisions until it has proved it has a majority in Parliament.

title: Bodcaw Meeting Delay Is Denied
description: Judge Morey L. Sear, in an unusual Sunday hearing in Federal District Court in New Orleans, refused yesterday to allow a shareholder to postpone a special meeting of the Bodcaw Company that is scheduled for tomorrow in Dallas.

title: The Changing Attitudes of Smith Graduates: Three Classes Compared
description: The inquiry has turned into a largescale study now, spawning reams of paper and computerized data, but began as a personal quest.

title: Envoy Says Palestinians May Join Mideast Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)  Robert Strauss, President Carter's special Middle East negotiator, was quoted today as saying that he had received signals indicating that the United States could bring moderate Palestinians into the Middle East peace talks in two or three months.

title: Fifth Avenue Needs to Be First
description: New Yorks Fifth Avenue is America's grand bazaar, and it became so because it presented the nation's crafts and productive talents in a splendid showcase. Unfortunately, Fifth Avenue today, through timidity and inertia, is becoming a bazaar of a very different kind.

title: Sporting Gear
description: One problem campers often have is keeping track of their tools. The Kamp Kit helps eliminate this worry, combining several tools in a 6by. 10inch carrying case. The extra tools are built into or fit into what at first glance looks like a simple hatchet. The hatchet handle contains a seveninch saw blade, which extends through the hatchet head when you depress a button. Built into the hatchet head are a bottle opener and a nail puller. The hatchet head and the saw blade are removable, so that a shovel head can be inserted Into the handle. The case can be attached to a pack or a belt. The Kamp Kit is available for $23, plus postage, from Uniquip, Space Center, Mira Loma, Calif. 91752, (714) 6857402.

title: Increase in Oil Company Profits Revives Criticism of the Industry
description: Earnings of the nation's major oil cornpanies climbed by an average of 68.9 percent in the second quarter, and these gains have revived accusations of oil industry profiteering that promise to become a focal point as Congress debates President Carter's windfall profits tax.

title: Easy Angel Scores In $727,000 Race
description: LOS ALAMITOS, Calif., July 29 (AP)  Easy Angel became the youngest quarter horse ever to earn more than $400,000 by coming from behind last night to win the $727,000 Dash for Cash  Futurity.

title: Don Miller Dies at 77
description: CLEVELAND, July 29 Don C. Miller, retired United States Bankruptcy Court judge and one of the legendary Four Horsemen when he was a running back at Notre Dame, died here yesterday in Lakeside Hospital, where he had been patient for two weeks. He was 77 years old.

title: Shoplifter, 91, Receives Food, Gifts and Sympathy
description: SAN ANTONIO, July 29 (UPI)  An outpouring of sympathy for Mattie Schultz, who said she wanted God to close her eyes because her plight had forced her to shoplift $15 worth of food to keep from starving, has Unproved the 91yearold woman's outlook on life, a minister said today.

title: A West Side Story
description: The greatest difficulty with otlr ecologically sound roachicidal plan was getting rid of Phillipe. Phillipe is our: building's slender CaribbeanAmerican exterminator. Softspoken Phillipe boasts a son who is stronger than my David; we trade infant stories while he sprays a milkywhite liquid roach spray, which I hate worse than poison, around the house.

title: Deaths
description: BONSALJennle Weart, of Upper Montclair, NJ on Saturday. July 28, 1979, wife of the late Alonzo F. Bonsai, mother of Mrs John E. Soleau, Mrs Philip M. Johnson and Richard I. Bonsai, sister of Mrs Albert Wilkinson, also survived by 11 grandchildren and 1 greatgrandson. Service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church, Valley Road at Bellevue Aye, Upper Montclair, NJ, Tuesday afternoon at 2 o'clock. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to St. James Episcopal Church or the Presby Memorial Iris Garden. Upper Montclair, NJ.

title: WPIXTV to Offer 2 Canadian Series,
description: Despite Canada's proximity to the United States and the absence of a language barrier, Canadian production companies have had scant success over the years in marketing their programs in the United States. Next fall, however, two major series from Canada will be offered in New York, both by WPIXTV. Chahnel 11.

title: Omens for the Arms Treaty
description: The ground is shifting in the Senate's debate of SALT II - in favor of the treaty. Senator Nunn of Georgia has made a seemingly hostile statement that should improve the treaty's chances materially. He says he will vote against the treaty if the Carter Administration fails to agree to a substantial increase in military spending. What this really means is that Senator Nunn accepts the judgment of the Joint Chiefs of Staff: the treaty would be a modest but useful step if the United States takes advantage of the defense measures that t permits while it limits the Soviet buildup.

title: Miss Alcott Is 3Stroke Victor
description: STE. JULIEDEVERCHERES, Quebec, July 29  Amy Alcott overcame laryngitis that left her speechless two days ago and medication that left her groggy today, shot three under par on the final two holes, including an eagle 3 at the 72d hole, and won the $150,000 Peter Jackson Classic by three strokes from Nancy Lopez.

title: Associated Press
description: FORMER TEXTILE MILL,DESTROYED IN PHILADELPHIA FIRE: Fireman battling a sevenalarm fire last night at the Bromley Mills building in the Kensington section of Philadelphia. Flames shot over 100 feet into the air the blocklong building burned, forcing the evacution of nearby residents.

title: Hard. Times Follow Ghana Coup
description: ACCRA, Ghana, July 25  This has been a difficult summer for Ghana. The coup d'etat on June 4 that overthrew Gen. Fred W. Akuffo has been followed by the arrest of 150 people on charges of corruption, the deportation of more than a dozen foreigners, and the execution of eight highranking military officers, including General Akuffo and two other former heads of state.

title: Gushiken Triumphs
description: KITAKYUSHU, Japan, July 29 (AP)  Yoko Gushiken of Japan, pounding out points with sharp counterpunching, scored a unanimous decision over Rafael Pedroza of Panama tonight and defended his World Boxing Association junior flyweight title for the ninth time.

title: Chicago. Bank Makes Money on Loans That Aid Deteriorating Neighborhood
description: CHICAGO, July 26  Five years ago the new owners of the South Shore National Bank set out to disprove the notion of their fellow bankers that making development loans in deteriorating neighborhoods was like throwing money out of the window.

title: Itel Tested By I.B.M.'s New Lines
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 - When I.B.M. speaks, Silicon Valley trembles.

title: Curran Hopes to End liaquity on Carter Peanut Business Pretty Quickly
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The investigation of Presi'ent Carter's family, peanut business appears to be drawing to a close, but the Justice D9partment's special counsel, Paul J. Curran, has given na public indication of how he will resolve the case..

title: Letter: On Life Insurance
description: To the Editor: It is disturbing to see life insurance misrepresented by the Federal Trade Commission staff as an Investment paying 1.3 percent interest. But it is distressing to see this erroneous contention repeated by The New York Times (editorial July 22).

title: Police in Jersey Recover Items Of Ancient Art
description: Officials in Morris County, N.J., hope to learn from museum officials in Peru this week whether a group of preColumbian figurines and bowls found in the vicinity of Dover, N.J., last week were stolen several years ago from a national museum in Lima, Peru.

title: Turkish Premier's Top Adviser Is His Wife, Who Hates Politics
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Like Jimmy Carter; Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit sees his closest friend and most influential adviser across the breakfast table the first thing every morning and on the next pillow the last thing at night.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets in continuing debate on Palestinian rights 10:30 A.M.

title: Amex Board Proposals
description: The Board of the American Stock Exchange has made some proposals aimed at improving the Amex's governing board, including an amendment to its constitution that would increase the governing board from 21 to 25 members. The board also recommended that two of the new posts go to members of the public and another two to members from the trading floor.

title: Europeans Pin Hopes On Volcker
description: PARIS, July 29  Paul A. Volcker, the prospective new Federal Reserve Board chairman, whose confirmation hearings open in Congress tomorrow, is expected to emerge as the trusted economic liaison between America's European allies and a United States Administration for which they have often expressed contempt. The remarkable speed and enthusiasm with which European Governments have welcomed Mr. Volcker's nomination, officials here say, testifies to the pivotal role they see him playing in. fostering good economic relations between Europe and the United States during the difficult months that now seem to lie ahead.,

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  Twelve years ago, Egyptian President Nasser told Secretary General U Thant to remove the United Nations observers separating the Egyptian and Israeli troops. The Secretary General obeyed, and Mideast war began.

title: Deaths
description: HAUGHJane and Cornelius. To Jane, a devoted community servant and skilled community negotiator. Her loss will be felt by the entire West Side. Her family lived our issues. Our thoughts are now with them.

title: Subways: Cash &
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority board should increase the fare to 55 cents rather than cut essential service and maintenance from the subway and bus budget, as it now plans. Governor Carey promised the money needed to hold the fare at 50 cents until Jan. 1, 1982, but his lack of performance means that passengers will encounter less reliable service and dirtier subways in the months aheadand a fare increase to 70 cents in 1980 or 1951. Riders will end up paying more for worse service unless the board exercises its independent authority to stop the political flimflam.

title: Jitters. Over Gasoline Helping Businesses in Town..
description: We had as many people in here this past Saturday as a Saturday just prior to Christmas, said Fred Bass, owner of the Strand secondhandbook store in Greenwich Village. It was one of our best Saturdays ever.

title: CLARENCE TAGGART
description: Clarence Taggart, a retired executive vice president of the Riegel Textile Sales Company, died Friday at his home in Treasure Island, Fla. He was 76 years old.

title: At 19, Ma His Drea
description: LOS ANGELES HE is no longer Earvin Magic Johnson, as he was introduced last March in Murfreesboro, Tenn., Indianapolis, Salt Lake City and wherever television sets were tuned to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournament. He is now known as Magic, period. He is also called Box Office. He wears the most marketable smile this side of Cheryl Tiegs. He will spend what would have been his junior year at Michigan State University as a professional in a place where dreams are made and stars are born.

title: In Lebanon UN and Christian Troops Keep Wary Peace
description: TRIBE; Lebanon, July 27  This small village in southern Lebanon is split by a frontier of sorts: a roadblock and checkpoint manned on one side by Nigerian troops wearing the blue berets and helmets of the United Nations Interim Force, and on the other by soldiers in baggy olbiedrab fatigues who fight for the Christianled militia that has evolved from the turmoil of Lebanon's civil war.

title: Marsh Captures Dutch Golf by Shot
description: NOORDWIJK, the Netherlands, July 29 (AP)  Graham Marsh of Australia scored a twounderpar 70 to lay on the final round and won the $70,000 Dutch open golf championship with a 285 total.

title: Notes on People
description: Carmine Galante, the reputed underworld figure who was shot to death in Brooklyn restaurant July 12, was like an uncle to Salvatore V. Bonanno, Mr. Bonanno says.

title: ArmsPact Debate: A New Script Has Both Sides Winning
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The Senate Armed Services Committee had been meeting for only a few hours on the strategic arms treaty last week when its chairman, John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, attempted to remind his fellow members that the treaty hearings were not a session on dIfense authorization.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Profits of major oil companies soared by 68.9 percent on average in the second quarter, a factor that is reviving charges of profiteering: The profit factor is likely to increase pressures against the companies as the President's proposal for a windfall profits tax wends its way through Congress. [Page A1.]

title: The Ballet: 2 Debuts In Giselle
description: MARIA ELENA LLORENTE and Lazaro Carrell made their New York debuts as Giselle and Albrecht in the National Ballet of Cuba's Saturday afternoon performance of Giselle at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Robert D. Steefel,. 78, a Lawyer Who Specialized in Real Estate
description: Robert D. Steefel, a realestate lawyer and senior partner in the law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, died yesterday after a long illness at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 20, 30, 31, 23, 21 and 17. The supplementary number was 4.

title: Rain Puts Off Pocono
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 29  The CocaCola 500mile NASCAR race, scheduled for today at Pocono Raceway, was postponed until tomorrow because of rain.

title: Brazil's Future
description: DURHAM, N.H.  In March, Brazil, began its fifth administration since the 1964 revolution replaced the civilian Government with military rule. Supporters of the new President, retired General Joao Baptista Figueiredo, say it will be the last military administration. The next six years will determine whether he will succeed; at present the prospects are favorable.

title: Plains Harvestmen Rumble North as Wheat Ripens
description: NORTON, Kan., July 26  This hot and vast plain, yellow and green and brown, running for hundreds of miles in all directions, is wheat country, so it is here that Don Borho, a compact and weathered man from North Dakota, is practicing his trade: the cutting of wheat.

title: Carter Rifts With Europe
description: Relations between President Carter and Europe's two most powerful leaders have at times been strained and even hostile since Mr. Carter took office in January 1977.

title: Florida Becoming Known As Death Penalty State
description: MIAMI, July 28 - The State of Florida has more people awaiting execution on its Death. Row than any:other in the country, and it is the first state in More than a decade to put a man to death against his will.

title: World News Briefs
description: MARSEILLES, France, July 29 (Reuters)  A security company guard whp celebrated, his birthday by rifling, his employer's safe probably got away with a much smaller haul than police first believed, the police chief of Marseilles said today.

title: Big Apple Games: Grass Roots
description: When the bus to Randalls Island pulled up at the corner of 125th Street and Lexington Avenue in East Harlem yesterday morning, Mitchell Harris tossed his gym bag up the steps in front of him and sat in one of the front seats, smoothing his blue warmup pants and telling the man next to him that he had a big race to run today.

title: Study Says Tut Show Aided City Economy
description: For more than three months earlier this year, the Metropolitan Museum of Art helped to generate more than $1 million a day into the city's economy from outoftowners who visited the Treasures of Tutankhamun exhibition, according to a survey commissioned by the museum.

title: 150 Missiles Planted in Missouri Get Intense Care and Acceptance
description: WHITEMAN AIR FORCE BASE, Mo.  As the shadows lengthen on a summer afternoon, the Missouri landscape is one of peace: fat cattle in the fields, little pigs scampering to dinner, white farmhouses amid trees on distant hilltops.

title: Events Today
description: EVERY GOOD BOY DESERVES FAVOUR, by Tom Stopoard and Andre Previn, directed by Mr. stopparr!: starring Ell Wallach, Rene AuberionoIs and Remak Ramsay, Metropolitan Opera House, 7:30.

title: Foyt Texas Winner
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., July 29 (AP)  A.J. Foyt of Houston stalked Tom Bigelow for 28 laps and then took advantage of a painfully slow pit stop by Bigelow today to win the United States Auto Club Grand Prix 200 at Texas World Speedway.

title: Connecticut Canvass Seeks Clues to Slaying of Girl, 12
description: More than a score of Connecticut state police officers conducted a housetohouse search for leads yesterday in the murder of 12yearold Katherine K. Ebersold, who vanished on a bicycle ride Friday and was found dead Saturday in wooded area a mile from her Burlington, Conn., home.

title: Marilyn Bofshever Wed To David H. Brockway
description: Marilyn Bofshever, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Bernard Bofshever of Brooklyn and Margate, Fla., was married at noon yesterday to David Hunt Brockway. son of Mr. and Mrs. George Brockway of Chappaqua, N.Y. Judge Lawrence D. Lenihan of the New Castle Justice Court in Chappaqua performed the ceremony at the Brockway home.

title: Hispanic Artists in Show At the Arsenal Gallery
description: Paintings, collages and sculpture by more than 25 Spanishspeaking artists will be on display next Monday to Sept. 28 at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park, Fifth Avenue and 64th Street.

title: Gerulaitis Beats Slozil
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, July 29 (AP)  Vitas Gerulaitis of the United States downed Pavel Slozil of Czechoslovakia, 62, 62, 64, in the final of the $75,000 Austrian Grand Prix tennis tournament today. The victory was worth $14,300 to Gerulaitis.

title: Russians Seem United in Devotion to Flying Saucei Cult; Why Was the News Suppressed?; A Counterpart of Samizdat
description: MOSCOW, July 30  In this society of Scientific Socialism, there are some people who believe in Communism but not in God. There are others who believe in God but not in Communism. But all of them seem to believe in flying saucers.

title: Lawn Jockey a Vanishing Item
description: HARTFORD, July 30 (AP) Jockey boy statues have been disappearing from the lawns of homes in the Hartford area, and the Black Jockey Liberation Army says it will keep taking them until it has removed all forms of bigotry.

title: Duncan Backed by Senate Energy Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  The Sew ate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources approved today, by 16 to 0, the nomination of Charles W. Duncan Jr. to replace James R. Schlesinger as Secretary of Energy.

title: Airlines Agree to Seek Rise in Worldwide Fares
description: GENEVA, July 30  Most of the world's major airlines have agreed to seek approval from their governments to raise passenger fares and cargo rates on international routes by between 9 and 15 percent to meet higher fuel costs, the International Air Transport Association announced today.

title: Advertising
description: IT looks as though the Media Corporation of America might owe newspapers, magazines, outdoor advertising companies and broadcasters considerably more than the $9.5 million that Albert B. Shepard, its chairman and president, acknowledged it owed at a crowded creditors meeting last Friday.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JULY 30, 1979

title: Bridge:
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 30  The first three days of play in the Summer Nationals of the Ameriain Contract Bridge League indicate that this will be the biggest tournament in bridge history. There were 1,111 tables in play Sunday night, a world record for a single session. With a week remaining, the total table count is 5,929, which is 673 more than the equivalent figure in the recordbreaking tournament in Toronto a year ago.

title: Investor Seeks Seat On Synalloy Board
description: Barry F. Cohen, a New York businessman and investor, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that he had acquired a 5.2 percent interest in the Synalloy Corporation, a metal fabricator, and is seeking a board seat.

title: Continental Oil To Raise Spending
description: The Continental Oil Company saidthat it would increase its capital spending program for this year by $130 million. The increase, primarily for exploration and development of oil and natural gas in the United States, brings the company's total planned outlays for the year to $1.5 billion, up 36 percent from its 1978 expenditures.

title: Taxes
description: THE fight is heating up again over the controvert sial proposal by the Internal Revenue Service that deals with the proper way to report inter. est earned on shortterm obligations when the obligationsoverlap two calendar years. when the I.R.S. issued a ruling on the matter February, it maintained that the correct way to treat the interest on these obligations, primarily the sixmonth savings certificates linked to Treasury bills, was as if the person had cashed in the certificate at yearend. Since there is a penalty  loss of two months interest and reversion to the lower passbook rate of interestfor premature redemption of these certificates, the interest reported under the proposed I.R.S. method would be less than if the person held the certificates to maturity.

title: 400,000 New England Residents Blacked Out by Power Accidents
description: BOSTON, July 30 (AP)  A tree falling on a power line and a mechanical failure at a generating plant caused a huge power failure today that affected 400,000 residents of Massachusetts and Rhode Island, utility officials said.

title: Envoy in Managua Condemns Any Destabilization
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 30  Ambassador Lawrenbe A. Pezzulluresponded to questions about reported attempts by defeated National Guard Officers to organize counterrevolutionary actions by saying today that the United States was opposed to any intervention in the Nicaraguan revolution.

title: Belmont Fans Place Last Bets Before Racing Moves Upstate
description: There was a horse named Saratoga Room in the ninth race yesterday, the perfect hunch bet for tappedout New Yorkers trying to get even before the thoroughbreds headed upstate.

title: Lew Kowarski Dead; Led France's Program In Atomic Technology
description: GENEVA, July 30  Lew Kowarski, Russianborn French nuclear physicist, died of a stroke in a hogpital here on Friday at the age of 72, it was announced today.

title: Jet in NearCollision on Runway Told Not to Land, Tape Indicates
description: A controltower tape recording showed last night that instructions to remain in holding pattern aloft  and not to land were given twice by an air traffic controller to a Polish airliner that nearly collided with a Braniff International jet on a runway at Kennedy International Airport last Friday night.

title: Lebanese Rightists Fight Syrian Troops in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 30 (Reuters)  Syrian troops and Lebanese rightwing militia forces battled with mortars and rockets in Beirut tonight.

title: Blackout in Manhattan Beach
description: About 800 homes in the Manhattan Beach sectipn of Brooklyn lost electric power for an hour and a half last night, according to the Consolidated Edison Company, which Attributed the blackout to a malfunction in an underground feeder cable. The power went out at about 10:15 and was restored at 11:55.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, July 30 (AP)  Shahpur Bakhtiar, the Iranian Prime Minister wh6 fled when militant Moslems seized control of the country, will lead a nonreligibus front in Iran's elections for a constituent assembly, a spokesman said:today.

title: I.C.C. Judge Backs Rail Merger
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 An administrative law judge of the Interstate Commerce Commission issued a preliminary ruling today recommending the approval of a merger between the Grand Trunk Western and the Detroit, Toledo and Ironton railroads.

title: A City's Effect on Weather
description: Those who live downwind of a big city may be blessed, or cursed, with more summer rainfall than those who live upwind, a meteorological study of the St. Louis area has determined.

title: Events Today
description: BUT NEVER JAM TODAY, book by VInnette Carroll and Robert Larimer, lyrics by Mr. Latimer, music by Bert Keyes and Mr. Latimer, directed by MISS Carroll, Longacre Theater, 220 West 18th Street, 6:30.

title: Dibbs and Tanner Gain In Volvo Tennis Tourney
description: NORTH CONWAY, N.H., July 30 (AP)  Fifthseeded Eddie Dibbs, the defending champion, defeated 19yearold Andre Gomez of Ecuador, 63, 65, today, the second day of firstround play at the $175,000 Volvo International tournament at the Mount Cranmore Tennis Club.

title: A Korean, Given Oath As Citizen in Bed, Dies
description: A 49yearold Korean man who last week became an American citizen in special bedside ceremony died of cancer Sunday night at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx, hospital officials said yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Jut), 31 GUGLIELMO MARCONI (Italian Line Cruises international). Left St. Maarten July 27; due at 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Mary McCarthy Mellows As an Expatriate in Paris
description: CASTINE, Me.  Mary McCarthy is out of touch with America.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar rose strongly against most foreign currencies yesterday. Dealers were unable to pin the rise on a particular news event, but pointed to encouragement about the nomination of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and about United States trade figures.

title: Swiss Concern Gets 93% of Maremont
description: Swiss Aluminium Ltd., also known as Alusuisse, said that its takeover of the Maremont Corporation was nearly complete, with 93 percent of the American company's common stock tendered to the Swiss concern at $42 a share.

title: 10 MORE MINISTERS JOIN INDIAN CABINET
description: NEW DELHI, July 30  Ten more junior and senior Cabinet members were sworn in today amid concern that they and their colleagues in the new Government of Prime Minister Charan Singh faced serious problems that could quickly overturn their Government.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THOMAS McMAHON is professor of applied mechanics and biology at Harvard. He is alio the author of Principles of American Nuclear Chemistry: A Novel.. You had to finish the novel.

title: Theater: Stoppard's Every Good Boy
description: EVERY Good Boy Deserves Favour, a play for actors and orchestra, a collaboration between Tom Stoppard, the playwright, and Andre Previn, the composer and conductor, is itself a tIwntrical nun  a play on words and music. This ingenious keyboard come. dy, which began an eightperformance run last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is about the political dissident as the discordant note in the orchestra that we call society.

title: $131 Million Bond Offering Is Sold By M.A.C. at 7.57 Percent Interest
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation sold $131 million in longterm bonds yesterday at an average interest rate that was lower by a full percentage point than the interest rate on its last issue, which was sold in March.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: James R. Lesch, the 57yearold president and chief operating officer of the Hughes Tool Company, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer, effective Sept. 1, succeeding Raymond M. Holiday, who will be 65.

title: Vikings Trade Eller
description: MANKATO, Minn., July 30 (AP) Carl Eller, a fivetime allpro during his 16year National Football League career as a defensive end for Minnesota, was traded by the Vikings to Seattle today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: The ARA Food Services Company, Philadelphia, has named John R. Farquharson president of the institutional food services sector.

title: Begin Wins a Test in Parliament After Dispute on Food Subsidies
description: JERUSALEM, July 30  An attempt by the opposition in Parliament to unseat Menachem Begin's Government because of the country's economic troubles was defeated here today by a vote of 58 to 48.

title: ABCTV Reaches Affiliate Parity With Its Rivals
description: ABCTV, which has been striving the last few years to improve its lineup of affiliated stations, recently has added four more stations to its chain in small cities where the network previously had no regular outlets. Its affiliate total now is at 204, which for the first time puts ABC on an equal footing with CBSTV and NBCTV in terms of its ability to reach a national audience.

title: U.S. Willing to Consider Arms
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (Reuters) The United States, is. willing to consider a request by Nicaragua's new Government for arms and military training, the State Department said today.

title: Livermore Lab Charges Traced to Stark's Aides
description: An article in The New York Times of June 25 incorrectly attributed to the Federal Department of Energy a statement that widespread management improprieties had been found at the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California that might involve the misappropriation of millions of taxpayer dollars.

title: Real Estate Accounting Plan Issued
description: Proposed changes in accounting rules for the real estate industry were issued yesterday by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. They would eliminate most. of the options now available when reporting acquisition, development and construction costs. they would specify which Costs should. be reported as current operating expenses on a company's income statement and which should be capitalized, or listed under assets on the balance sheet, the announcement said. Kenneth A. Mounce, chairman of the institute's real estate accounting committee and a partner in the Los Angeles accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company, said:

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: As the credit markets inched ahead yesterday, encouraged by the strengthening of the dollar in foreignexchange trading, Government securities dealers estimated that the Treasury's new threeyear notes scheduled for sale this afternoon would probably yield 9.10 percent. Rive or take a little rasing activity was quiet yester: day, and several Treasury note dealers said that they seemed to find it more difficult than usual to gauge demand for the new threeyear securities. Some predicted the notes might yield as little as 9.05 percent, and some mentioned rates as high as 9.15 percentan unsually wide spread for predictions a day before a Government financing.

title: Warning on Darvon Will Be Distributed
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) The makers of Darvon, a popular painkill. ing drug, have agreed to begin distributing voluntarily a warning telling of the hazards of using the drug in excess or with other drugs or alcohol, the Government said today.

title: JOHN P. MAYER
description: John P. Mayer, assistant cashier of The New York Times, died Saturday at the age of 62 at his home in Middle Village, Queens.

title: Hospitals Chief Denies Budget Perils Harlem Patients
description: The president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday denied charges by a group of doctors at Metropolitan Hospital, in East Harlem, that budget cutbacks had endangered the lives of patients. The hospital is one of four the Koch administration has selected for closing.

title: New Curbs Drawn Up to Prevent Suicide in Cells by City Prisoners
description: Under new rules by the New York City Department of Correction, all prisoners placed under mental observation at the request of a judge or lawyer will have their belts and shoelaoes taken away before entering a holding cell. The department is also considering installing observation mirrors.

title: Demand for Diesel Cars Pushing Prices Higher
description: For the dieselpowered motorist, long gasoline lines and oddeven days are only a phenomenon to observe as he briskly advances to the diesel pump, often open 24 hours a day.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Pleasure
description: The life of Indian politics is not logic but necessity and maneuver. When a Socialist member of Parliament was asked how he could possibly support the candidacy of conservative Charan Singh, he replied: In India, first we pick out leaders, and then we try to graft an ideology on him.

title: Yanks Win, 72; Rivers to Texas
description: CHICAGO, July 30  The way the season is going for the Yankees, even when they win they have bad luck.

title: Jet Going Home to Soldier Field
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 30  Scott Dierking of the Jets is throwing himself a homecoming party Saturday night at Soldier Field in Chicago.

title: Beaths
description: LOEWENSTEINIrma (nee Fleischhacker), beloved sister, sisterinlaw and Mush,. Services today, 10 AM at Hirsch & Sons Chapel, 1225 Jerome Ave, corner 167 St, Bronx.

title: Associated Press
description: BIKERS COMPLETE CROSSCOUNTRY JOURNEY: Sara Sinclair and Darrin Stockall of Portland, Ore., as they rode into Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after a 98day trip across the United States. They began on April 20.

title: The Gravy Train's Caboose
description: You enter the building and, finding the elevator out of order, start up the narrow staircase  carefully, so you don't lose your balance on the sagging steps or trip on the worn matting. On the second floor, you make your way past partitioned rooms decorated with antique leak stains and textured spots of peeling plaster, praying you don't fall through a spot in the floor weakened. by floods. You pass cartons of papers, desks covered with papers. Some people are reading newspapers, some cackling on the phone, some id stocking feet, some staring into space.

title: United Press International
description: COLLISION AT HOME PLATE: John Stearns, Mets catcher, trying to vault over Dave Parker during the fifth inning last night in Pittsburgh. Parker scored from second when throw to first base by Mets Willie Montanez went wide.

title: Boeing Gets Contract
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (Reuters) The Boeing Company received a $116.2 million contract from the Air Force for offensive avionics, hardware and software, the Defense Department announced today.

title: New York Teachers Are Gaining In Battle for Professional Status
description: The heated and longstanding debate over whether teachers should be treated as professionals like doctors, nurses and practitioners of 28 other fields seems at last to be headed toward resolution in New York State  mainly because it is now being linked politically to the pressing issue of educational quality.

title: WILLIAM S. TODMAN, TV PRODUCER, DIES
description: William S. Todman, a radio and television producer whose partnership with Mark Goodson introduced such landmark quiz and audienceparticipation programs as What's My Line? and The ence is Kigrit, died Suriday night in New York University Hospital following surgery for a heart ailment. He would have been 63 years old today, and had lived in Scarsdale, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Oil Search Set in England
description: LONDON, July 30 (Reuters)  The Department of Energy said today that it had issued four licenses for onshore oil and gas exploration in the south of England. Two licenses have been awarded jointly to the British Gas Corporation and BP Petroleum Develop. ment Ltd. The other two have gone to Conoco Ltd. and to a group led by Carless Exploration Ltd.

title: Grasso Veto Is Upset; Auto Exhaust Testing Put Off a Year, to 81
description: HARTFORD, July 30  A special session of the General Assembly this morning overwhelmingly overturned Gov. Ella T. Grasso's veto of a bill to delay autoemissions testing. But the legislators let stand the veto of a bill that would have cut the minimum wage for waiters and waitresses.

title: Topics
description: After providing ramps for wheelchairs and slot machines at wheelchair height, Caesars World in Atlantic City now promises slot machines equipped with braille. The casino may be more interested in attracting convention groups that prize such special services than in the actual business of handicapped players. Nonetheless, it is striking to see how easy it is to take affirmative action for the handicapped when profit is involved.

title: Environmental. Office Sets Rules For Switches to Leaded Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency said today that under new rules, gasoline stations may put leaded gas into cars designed to take unleaded fuel, but only in the event of a bonafide emergency.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times of June 25 reported incorrectly that an audit by the Department of Energy found widespread management improprieties at the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California. That characterization was made by aides to Representative Fortney H. Stark, Democrat of California. A corrective article appears on page B16.

title: The City
description: A Manhattan lawyer filed suit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday seeking to block the salary increases granted top city officials klast week. The action came as a citizens group was to begin a petition drive to force a referendum on the increases.

title: Rate Raised 1% On Rail Freight
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that it had approved a 1 percent surcharge for the nation's freight railroads to offset higher fuel costs. The rate increase was effective last Saturday.

title: Paleontologist in Colorado Finds Evidence of the Biggest Dinosaur
description: A Utah paleontologist, digging in an ancient dry river bed on a windswept Colorado mesa, has found bones of the biggest dinosaur that has yet been discovered  a huge animal that, he esti mates, would have been able to look into a topfloor window of a five or six. story building.

title: Perilous Cargoes Shipped at Will, Assembly Is Told
description: New York City and New York State lack effective controls on explosive, poisonous, corrosive and radioactive materials carried along highways and city streets, according to police, fire and transportation officials who testified yesterday before an Assembly subcommittee.

title: Union Against Resuming Strike at Newport News
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 30 (AP)  The United Steelworkers of America decided last night not to resume its strike against the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company now, a move that angered hundreds of union members. several hundred stalked out of the Hampton Coliseum during the threehour closed session, saying that the meeting was controlled by international union officials who had decided not to strike.

title: IN THE NATION
description: On the day that President Carter announced the appointment of Paul Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, interest rates on threemonth Treasury bills declined from 9.90 percent to 9.18, and the next day to 9.12.

title: House G.O.P. Fails to Oust Diggs
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)  The House of Representatives narrowly defeated a Republicanled move today to expel Representative Charles C. Diggs, Democrat of Michigan, because of his conviction on charges of padding his payroll.

title: Beaths
description: SECKLERPhilip F. of Lakewood, Florida on July 29, 1979. The brothers of Nathan Strauss Netherland Lodge regretfully record the passing of one of our past masters and brother. Services to be held at Riverside Chapel, 178 St 8, Grand Concourse, Bronx, Tuesday 10AM. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to Masonic Camp 7.

title: Uneasiness in Bourbon Country: A Certain Trust Has Been Lost
description: BARDSTOWN, Ky., July 30  In the Hilton barbershop here on the main strip of North Third Street, over the gentle background whirr of the airconditioner on the day before President.

title: Powell Victor, Oerter 2d
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 30  It is not whether he wins anymore, but rather his presence. Each time Al Oerter steps into the discusthrowing ring now, he seems to generate excitement.

title: U.S. Presses Prague for Access To 3 Seized for Smuggling Bibles
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)  State Department officials said today that they were pressing Czechoslovakia for access to three Americans arrested at the border on charges of trying to smuggle Bibles into the country.

title: Shirley Mason, 79, Was Actress In Vanity Fair and Other Silents
description: LOS ANGELES, July 30 (UPI)  Shirley Mason, a star of silent films, died of cancer Friday at CedarsSinai Medical Center. Miss Mason, who lived with her sister, Viola Dann, in the Marina del Rey area, was 79 years old.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI Petition for an Arrangement Filed by:

title: Music. Previn Interludes
description: ALTHOUGH Andr Previn suggested the idea of Every Good Boy Deserves Favour to Tom Stoppard, and although his music takes up a considerable portion of the show's 70minute length, it hardly determines its effect. That effect derives almost entirely from Mr. Stoppard's spoken drama. The music serves three principal functions: as sound effect, as background and as interlude.

title: Washington Post and Guild Sign Contract After 3Year Wrangling
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  The Washington Post and The Newspaper Guild, the union of editorial and clerical workers, signed a new contract today; ending a frequently embittered threeyear lapse during which the company bargained intermittently and largely disregarded the terms of the expired contract.

title: Expos Post Split, Stay In First
description: MONTREAL, July 30 (UPI)  Ellis Valentine celebrated his 25th birthday by hitting two home nuts and Larry Parrish and Chris Speier. also homered tonight to help the Montreal Expos score a 51 victory and a split of a doubleheader with the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Building Contracts Up by 5% in Value
description: The total value of construction contracts awarded, a key barometer of economic activity, rose 5 percent to $15.3 billion in June from the yearearlier level, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company said yesterday. After inflation, however, actual physical voltiMe last month was down from a year ago, Dodge noted.

title: Around the Nation
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 30 (AP)  A Federal appeals court has ruled that tapes made illegally by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of conversations of Raymond L.S. Patriarca, the reputed leader of the New England underworld, could not be released for publication because the release would violate Mr. Patriarca's privacy.

title: Beaths
description: HANSENBernhard J. on his way from Norway to Heaven. In his Passing he leaves Mama Joan, Sheryl, Erick, Victoria and 3 monuments, Victor, Billy and Margaret. We shall all miss him. THE GRADERS.

title: U.S. Boxers Lose Twice
description: MOSCOW, July 30 (AP)  American boxers were dealt a blow at the Spartakiad competition today when two more members of the team lost in quarterfinals, leaving only Andre McCoy of New Bedford, Mass., with a chance for gold medal.

title: Yields on Bills Off at Treasury; (000 omitted In dollar figures)
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and the 182day maturities.

title: Associated Press
description: HER DAUGHTER SHOT: Virginia Long leaves her Philadelphia home, where her 23yearold daughter, Janice, was shot three times, allegedly by her estranged husband. The man shot himself later.

title: Saving of a Mansion On West Side Sought
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission will hold a hearing Sept. 11 on whether a mansion on the corner of 89th Street and Riverside Drive should be saved by being declared a city landmark.

title: State Accused of Paying Unionist in NoShow Job
description: ALBANY, July 30  The president of the Public Employees Federation spent 10 y ars on the state payroll working n y full time for his union, the State Commission of Investigation charged today.

title: Today's an Odd Day, But It All Evens Out
description: Today is July 31, and it means that drivers of cars having odd or even numbers as the last number on their license plates can buy gasoline in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: VOLCKER SAYS JUMP IN SUPPLY OF MONEY SHARPENS INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  Paul A. Volcker, chairmandesignate of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that inflation had been caused by excessive growth of the money supply and suggested he would press for a reduction even if it should mean still higher interest rates. In confirmation hearings before the Senate Banking Committee, he proclaimed his independence of the Carter Administration, predicted inevitable conflicts with it and outlined a philosophy stressing the effects of growth in the money supply.

title: HOUSE WILL REJECT PANAMA COMPROMISE
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The House of Representatives voted threetoone today to stand by its version of a Panama Canal treaties bill that the Carter Administration says would amount to breaking the treaties.

title: VANCE TELLS SENATE 3% ARMSFUNDS RISE REMAINS ESSENTIAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  In what appeared to be an effort to insure more support for the strategic arms treaty, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that it was essential to uphold a commitment to the Atlantic alliance to increase military spending by 3 percent annually.

title: Appeals Court Upsets Conviction Of Reporter Withholding Source
description: Without addressing the constitutional issues, an appellate court in Brooklyn yesterday unanimously reversed the conviction on contempt charges of a reporter who had refused to identify a confidential source in a drug case.

title: House Delays Vote on ConflictofInterests Exemptions
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)  The House abruptly postponed today a vote on legislation that would exempt Cabinet members and aides who are leaving President Carter's Administration from a tough new conflictofinterests law.

title: Gregory Leaves Giants Camp
description: Jack Gregory, defensive captain of the Giants, left training camp at Pleasantville, N.Y., yesterday afternoon and reportedly was destined for his Mississippi home.

title: The Joys of Inflation
description: People hate inflation. Governments don't. Inflation erodes earnings, savings, pensions; it hurts people. But inflation fattens taxes, increases the national product, expands reported corporate profits, and enables newspapers business pages to report happily: Business Profits Up Retail Sales Increase 10 Percent. The aura of prosperity enhances the status of incumbent officials.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Paul A. Volcker said inflation had been caused by excessive growth of the money supply and implied he would press for a reduction even if it means higher interest rates. In confirmation hearings before the Senate Banking Commitee, the chairmandesignate of the Federal Reserve Board proclaimed his independence of the Carter Administration and predicted inevitable conflicts with it. [Page A1.]

title: Emery Air Income Gains
description: Secondquarter net income of Emery Air Freight climbed 98 percent to a record $8.3 million, or 54 cents a share, on, sales of $138 million, up 35 percent. me year earner rigure was 55.6 million, or 36 cents a share. In the report yesterday, John C. Emery Sr., president of the world's largest air cargo company, said, Portions of the, overall second quarter gains can be attributed to windfalls resulting from the teamsters strike against trucking companies and the walkout at United Air Lines, as well as shipments diverted to our fleet by the grounding of the DC10. He also noted that improvenients were made in both domestic and international air freight operating income ratios. The company handled 1.6 million shipments, compared with 1.3 million last year.

title: Soviet Denies Intention To Expel U.S. Reporter
description: MOSCOW, July 30  The Soviet Government newspaper lzvestia today denied that any decision had been made to expel David Satter, an American journalist who represents The Financial Times of London here.

title: Judge Acts In Bagley Case
description: RICHMOND, July 311 (AP)  A Federal judge refused today to dismiss fraud and conspiracy charges against Smith Bagley, an R.J. Reynolds tobacco heir, and four codefendants accused of conspiring to rig the price of stock in a food and textile conglomerate.

title: Metals Futures in Major Slide
description: A huge wave of selling sent gold, silver, platinum and copper futures plunging to their daily permissible limits yesterday in one of the broadest price breaks recorded in the New York metals market.

title: Judges Act to Prevent Disruption Of the Power Supply of Massena
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)  Two Federal judges issued orders today to delay the possible disruption of power for Massena, N.Y..

title: McCannErickson Wins Marx Toys
description: McCannErickson has just picked up all the toys and games of the Marx division of Louis Marx & Company. They bill about $5 million combined.

title: Girl, 5, Abducted in Florida, Is Rescued
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., July 30 (UPI)  Police officers chased a speeding station wagon through alleys and between buildings today and rammed it, rescuing 5yearold Caroline Thompson. An 18yearold man was arrested and charged with kidnapping the child from a motel parking lot in Florida on Saturday.

title: Officers of 6 Large Unions Set Up a CarterforPresident Committee
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  A small group of labor leaders, one of whom said The President is in trouble and needs help now, announced today the formation of a Carter for President Committee.

title: OBSERVER
description: The news that Richard Nixon will soon be living on the East Side of Manhattan prompts speculation about what might be said in a sidewalk summit of the Giants. This would occur if, by one of those rare, happy accidents, Jacqueline Onassis, Greta Garbo and the former President all found themselves simultaneously hurrying home from Madison Avenue with their shopping bags full of bagels. The meeting might be reported as follows:

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: MONTREAL, July 30 (Reuters) The Asbestos Corporation lost another round in court today in its battle to prevent the possible expropriation of its assets by the Quebec government.

title: Hospital Union Official Partly Blinded in Fight
description: The head of the Harlem Hospital chapter of the municipal hospital workers union was reported yesterday in danger of losing the sight of one eye as the result of a fight involving an internal union dismite.

title: News Summary
description: Increased support for the arms treaty was apparently sought by Secretary of State Vance, who said it was essential to uphold a 1977 Administration pledge to the Atlantic alliance to raise military spending by 3 percent a year. His statement seemed to be directed to advocates of increased spending and to indicate that the Administration would agree to compensate for rising inflation by commensurate rises in the military budget. [Page Al, Column 4.]

title: Dance: Jubilation! Troupe
description: A NEW dance company that called itself Jubilation! appeared Sunday night at Pace University's Schimmel Center for the Arts. That exclamation point was no extravagance, for Jubilation! offered exclamatory dancing.

title: The Outcasts of Sports
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 30  The sports business is booming these days up and down the Pacific Coast. Everywhere, that is, except in the nearly empty and forsaken home of the Oakland A's, the Foreign Legion of baseball.

title: Boy Slain by Bicycle Thief
description: A 14yearold Bronx boy was fatally stabbed an the chest yesterday by a youth who. tried to steal his bicycle, the police said. The slaying occurred at 8:90 P.M. at the pedestrian mall at Yankee Stadium off River Avenue and 157th Street. The victim was Tireak Gandy of 711 Walton Avenue his assailant escaped.

title: Group Prayer Reported At Camp David Parley
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) President Carter joined hands with religious leaders who participated in intensive discussions with him at Camp David earlier this month and asked that they pray. with him, according to one of the participants.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination  10:30 A. M. and 3 P.M.

title: council Panel Would Limit Nude Bathing
description: The great nudesunbathing debate continued In the City'Counbil yesterday with unanimous committee support of a measure that provides for certain optional swimsuit areas.

title: City Refinancing Realizes Savings From Mortgages
description: A New York City refinancing plan to sell portions of MitchellLama housing mortgages at large discounts to help solve the city's financial problems has reached its goal and soon will far surpass it, according to housing and budget officials.

title: The Power of Negative Thinking
description: The recent history of the United States would have been somewhat different if there had been no Herbert Marcuse, who died Sunday at the age of 81 while on visit to his native Germany.

title: Shell Oil Inquiry Closed by F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) An investigation into whether the Shell Oil Company violated antitrust law has been closed, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: DC 10 HEARING TOLD OF UNHEEDED STEPS
description: CHICAGO, July 30  An American Airlines mechanic, testifying at the opening of Federal hearings into the nation's worst air disaster, disclosed today that his onthejob training in maintenance of DC10 engine mounts had differed markedly from the airline's written instructions.

title: Tiny Hitchhiker Delays Airliner for 40 Minutes
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 30 (UPI) A tiny Japanese beetle grounded an Eastern Air Lines 727 jet for 90 minutes last Friday while passengers fumed and airline officials searched for the tiny intruder.

title: Bills Spur Synthetic Fuel Plants
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  Leaders of the Senate Energy Committee outlined today the fast track legislation they plan to send to the floor in September to accelerate construction of synthetic fuel plants and other installations designed to reduce the nation's reliance on imported oil. me measure would permit the chairman of a new Energy Mobilization Board to override substantive state and Federal laws and procedures if they interfered with completion of a relatively small number, probably a dozen or less, of the highest priority projects.

title: Talmadge Accuser Pleads. Guilty in Bargain. With U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)  Daniel Minchew, the chief accuser in a Senate investigation of Senator Herman E. Talmadge, pleaded guilty today to submitting a false $2,289 expense account to the Senate.

title: Labor Again Asks Guidelines Review
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) In an unusual appeal, the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has urged the Supreme Court for a second time to review the labor federation's challenge to President Carter's antiinflation wageprice euidelines.

title: Rubber Union President Attacks Bargaining Unit
description: DETROIT, July 30  Peter C. Bornmarito, president of the United Rubber Workers union, has challenged the integrity of the bargaining unit representing union members at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.

title: Cocaine Worth Millions And Arms Cache Seized
description: Fortyfour pounds of cocaine and weapons cache of more than 90 firearms, including a machine gun and thousands of rounds of ammunition, were seized in raids Friday on three Queens apartments, drugenforcement authorities said yesterday.

title: Concert: Santa Fe chamber Festival Attains Big Time
description: ANTAFE, July 30  It is the Santa Fe Opera that gets the most publicity, but another form of musical activity has been going on in this city for seven summers. The Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival, founded by Alicia Schachter and her husband, Sheldon Rich, has reached the big time, and currently is in the process of branching out. When the sixweek season ends next Monday, the group of some 20 top American musicians will move to Seattle for a fiveday series and then hop the continent to play in New York's 92d Street Y Aug. 2530.

title: Panama Treaty Goes to Senate
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (Reuters) President Carter today sent to the Senate for ratification a treaty signed with Panama last January on exchanging prisoners. The treaty would permit citizens of either nation convicted in the other country to serve their sentences in their home country if they wish.

title: U.N. ABRUPTLY CUTS PALESTINIAN DEBATE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 30 The Security Council abruptly cut off a debate on Palestinian rights today amid indications the Carter Administration wanted time to assess what could be a shift in policy toward Israel. The Council debate was put off until Aug. 23.

title: Male Fly Benefits Through Female Imitation
description: AN. ENTOMOLOGIST has learned that some male scorpion flies assume the role of transvestites to steal food from other males and present it as their own courtship gift to a female.

title: Saving Money, and Oil, on Amtrak
description: If Amtrak had as many riders as political friends, it would be coining money. But the passenger rail system needs all the financial help it can scrounge. Fares cover just a third of its costs; the rest must be paid by Washington. Even now, when energy conservation is a primary public concern, the price is too high.

title: About New York
description: The New Yorker who has aged with his city for five or six decades measures progress by change, which usually means loss and includes such progress as the vanishing of the 5cent tare, the classic hulk of Pennsylvania Station, the ferry Imes across the rivers, the trolley ear and the keep off the grass way of life in parks that were once trim and green.

title: German Cost of Living Up
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, July 30 (Reuters)  West cost of living in July was sixtenths to seventenths of 1 percent higher than in June and was up 4.5 to 4.6 percent from a year earlier, provisional figures showed. In June, the cost of living rose fourtenths of 1 percent from the prior month and was up 3.9 percent on an annual basis.

title: TV: Detective School
description: ALTHOUGH it's unusual to find anything favorable to say about a 30minute situation comedy, particularly one that is being shown for only four weeks during the summer, Detective School, which will be seen from 8:30 to 9 o'clock tonight on ABCTV, does indeed have its amusing moments.

title: Mrs. John Ford, 86
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., July 30 (AP)  Mary Ford, wife of John Ford, the late film director, died of respiratory failure yesterday at Eisenhower Medical Center here. She was 86 years old. The couple had been married 53 years when he died in 1973. Two children survive. Arrangements for services will be announced.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The. SALT H treaty in its present form is not in America's interests nor, more importantly, does it serve the goal of world peace. The treaty should be either amended or rejected. The treaty now permit's an exception from the laudable principle of numerical equality in missiles in allowing the Soviet Union to keep the 308 giant SS18 missiles it has built, while permitting the U.S. none. Each SS18 can carry up to 10 nuclear warheads, and each warhead is more powerful than any existing American one.

title: Beaths
description: ABRAHAMSHarry of Valdosta, Georgia, beloved husband of Bess, devoted father of Jackie (Mrs. M. E. Wahnish) of Orlando Florida, Shirley (Mrs. H. M. Glges) of White Plains, NY, and Gloria (Mrs. I. M. Kulbersh) of Tifton, Georgia. Loving grandfather and great grandfather. Service Tuesday, 2 PM at Temple Israel of Valdosta, Georgia.

title: Trial Lawyers Gathering To Learn Winning Ways
description: HOUSTON, July 30  The trial lawyers who are holding their annual convention here are entrepreneurs, the gamblers of the legal profession, taking fees from 15 to 40 percent of the award if they win a case and nothing if they lose.

title: U.S. Delays Meeting With Israel And Egypt on Sinai Unit Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  The United States was forced today to delay a meeting it had hoped to convene with Egypt and Israel this week on resolving a dispute about an international force to oversee Israeli withdrawals from Sinai.

title: Son Grieves After Tragedy at Family Home
description: Linford Krauss Jr. sat on the steps of his ruined home yesterday in Spinnerstory, Pa., following a family dispute in which his father, Linford Krauss Sr., allegedly shot and killed his wife and wounded two daughters and their maternal grandfather. The elder Krauss then set fire to the home and took his own life.

title: CARTER SAYS ADVICE BUOYED HIS RESOLVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  President Carter said..today that the intensive dit cussions he'liOrd at COnii *yid earlier this month and the unbelievably favorable response received at the White House to his July 15 energy speech had restored hit own determination, selfassurance, confidence and will as President.

title: Maxim's Gains Historic Status
description: PARIS, July 30 (Reuters)  Maxim's, the celebrated Paris restaurant, has been declared a historical monument by the French Government.

title: Amid Trinidad's New Oil Prosperity, Vital Services Are a Shambles
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad  Two women with relentless brooms struggled against the tide of cigarette butts on the floor of the downtown office of Textel, the Governmentowned external telecommunications company, but it was futile. Pinched together on rows of chairs, the crowd hoping to place overseas telephone calls had been waiting and smoking for many hours.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. ( TelevisionChannel 9, 7:30 P.M. RadioWMCA, WGBB, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Satellite Photcgraph
description: Yesterday's Weatherat 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI.

title: Summer School Is All a Matter of Attitude
description: The air is heavy, and although the window is open the American flag at the front of the room is totally immobile:The hours drag, and as the morning goes on it becomes harder to care about the fact that 7 times 5 is 35.

title: ExxonBid Fight May Shape Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  The Federal Trade Commission's suit to stop the Exxon Corporation from buying the Reliance, Electric Company could establish new standards in antitrust law that would inhibit conglomerate mergers. antitrust lawyers say:

title: Soviet Spartakiad Draws Mixed Reviews
description: MOSCOW, July 30  As a dress rehearsal for the 1980 Olympics, the Soviet Spartakiad sports festival is drawing mixed reviews from the 2,500 foreign athletes and the 801 journalists who came to see what to expect next year.

title: Brow,: Takes His First Formal Step In Quest for the Presidency in 1980
description: LOS ANGELES, July 30  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. took his first formal step toward challenging President Carter for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination today when he notified the Federal Elections Commission that he had formed an exploratory campaign committee.

title: 13 Tremors Shake Mount Etna
description: CATANIA, Sicily, July 30 (Reuters) Thirteen tremors were recorded during the night and early today from Mount Etna. Explosions could be heard from the volcano and it was belching smoke. Two of the tremors were felt in Catania and nearby villages but no damage was reported.

title: Spinach Used to Create Solar Electricity
description: A JAPANESE team has reported finding a highly efficient method of converting sunlight directly into electric energy, using a component of spinach as an intermediary.

title: Oil Cutbacks Aimed at Averting Glut
description: Just as the world's oil supply regains its balance after six months of tumult, more militant members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are taking steps to prevent a priceeroding oil glut from developing late this year or early next year.

title: Car Makers Battle With 79 Backlog
description: DETROIT, July 30  American automobile manufacturers, already in the midst of their worst sales year since 1974, are struggling to help dealers move a huge backlog of unsold large cars.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Rosen Accepts Casino Position
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 30 (AP)  Al Rosen, former president of the New York Yankees, will join Bally's proposed Park Place casino hotel as an executive vice president, Bally officials announced today.

title: Associated Press /Ronald Kennedy
description: COLLISION MARS START OF POCONO 500: After car spun out on the hazardous first turn at Pocono Raceway, Al Holbert jumped from his vehicle before it caught fire. Accident triggered a fivecar pileup. Holbert was uninjured. Cale Yarborough won the race, averaging 114.871 miles an hour. Page C13.

title: Notes on People
description: Remember Officer Obie in the song and movie Alice's Restaurant? He's actually Police Chief William J. Obanhein of Stockbridge, Mass., who, one critic wrote, played himself in the 1969 movie with such pleased and puzzled *sincerity that he may be the most appealing villain since Captain Hook. Well, over the weekend Chief Obie was having Ms troubles with assorted music lovers, and by some accounts, but not all, he was again the villain.

title: Los Angeles Accord Reached
description: LOS ANGELES, July 30 (UPI) County negotiators reached tentative agreement today with unions representing more than 47,000 of the county's 60,000 employees, possibly averting a strike against the nation's biggest county government. Details of the agreement, reached in the face of a 12:01 A.M. Wednesday strike deadline, were not disclosed, but it was unofficially reported that union representatives had accepted Increases of slightly more than 7 percent.

title: Braths
description: COOPERClarissa B., oh New York City, on July 29, sister of Cara A. Cooper, also of New York. Services will be private.

title: JOHN BAYNE BRECKINRIDGE
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 30 (AP) John Bayne Breckinridge, a Lexington lawyer and threetime Congressman, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 65 years old. tie was first elected to the House of Representatives in 1972. He served six years and was defeated for renomination in the Democratic primary last year.,

title: EARNINGS Texas Instruments Net Climbs by 30%
description: Texas Instruments, makers of semiconductors, calculators, watches, and missile guidance systems, reported yesterday that it had a 30 percent jump in secondquarter net income to $44.6 million, or $1.95 a share, from $34.3 million, or $1.50 a share, a year ago. Net sales were $784.2 million, up 28 percent.

title: PLO. Is Driving Hard for Worldwide Recognition
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 30 While the Palestine Liberation Organization has. suffered serious setbacks in the field recently, it has been gaining in its campaign to win international recognition.

title: Armstrong Cork Net Up
description: A $3.1 million loss on foreign exchange translations reduced secondquarter net income of the Armstrong Cork Company 12 percent to $18.1 million, or 70 cents a share, according to narry A. Jensen, president. Sales were $342.8 million, up 5 percent. Net income in the quarter a year ago was $20.7 million, and the company had a $400,000 foreign exchange gain. While new housing is expected to slacken in the rest of the year, Armstrong's major market of home improvement and commercial construction business should provide excellent opportunities for us, the executive said. He also cited favorable foreign business, where we expect to see more vigor than in our domestic economy.

title: ForeignBought Banks Found to Aid Consumers
